About the Book

关于本书

What Do You Say After You Say Hello? explains what makes the winners win, the losers lose, and the in-betweens so boring . . .

《打招呼之后你该说什么？》解释了为什么赢家会赢，输家会输，而中间阶层的人则如此无聊……

In it, Dr Eric Berne reveals how everyone’s life follows a predetermined script – a script they compose for themselves during early childhood. The script may be a sad one, it may be a successful one; it decides how a person will relate to his colleagues, what sort of person he will marry, how many children he will have, and even what sort of bed he will die in . . .

在书中，埃里克·伯恩博士揭示了每个人的人生都遵循着一个预先设定的剧本——一个他们在幼年时期就为自己谱写的剧本。这个剧本可能是悲伤的，也可能是成功的；它决定了一个人如何与同事相处，会与什么样的人结婚，会生几个孩子，甚至会死在什么样的床上……

What Do You Say After You Say Hello? demonstrates how each life script gets written, how it works and, more important, how anyone can improvise or change his script to make a happy ending . . .

《打招呼之后该说什么？》一书阐述了每个人的人生剧本是如何编写的，它是如何运作的，更重要的是，它还阐述了任何人如何即兴发挥或改变自己的剧本，从而获得一个美好的结局……

#↩

PART IV The Script in Clinical Practice

第四部分 临床实践中的脚本

CHAPTER SIXTEEN The Preliminary Phases

第十六章 预备阶段

A Introductory

#↩

What Do You Say
After You Say Hello?

你道别之后会说什么？

THE PSYCHOLOGY OF HUMAN DESTINY

人类命运心理学

Eric Berne, MD

埃里克·伯恩，医学博士

#↩

Preface

前言

This book is in direct succession to my previous ones on the transactional approach, and outlines the new developments in thinking and practice which have taken place during the last five years, chiefly the rapid advance in script analysis. During this period there has been a great increase in the number of trained transactional analysts. They are testing the established theories in many different fields, including industry, corrections, education, and politics, as well as in a variety of clinical situations. Many of them are making original contributions of their own, as mentioned in the text and footnotes.

本书是我之前关于人际沟通分析方法的著作的直接续篇，概述了过去五年中该领域在思想和实践方面的新发展，尤其是脚本分析的快速进步。在此期间，受过专业训练的人际沟通分析师人数大幅增加。他们正在工业、矫正、教育、政治等诸多领域以及各种临床情境中检验既有理论。正如正文和脚注中所述，他们中的许多人也做出了自己的原创性贡献。

This is primarily intended as an advanced textbook of psychotherapy, and professionals of different backgrounds should have no difficulty in translating into their own dialects the short and simple annals of transactional analysis. No doubt some nonprofessionals will read it too, and for that reason I have tried to make it accessible to them. It may demand thinking, but I hope it will not require deciphering.

本书主要面向高级心理治疗领域，不同背景的专业人士应该都能轻松地将简明扼要的交互分析理论转化为他们自己的语言。当然，一些非专业人士也会阅读本书，因此我力求使其易于理解。本书或许需要一些思考，但我希望它不会让人感到晦涩难懂。

Conventional psychotherapy ordinarily employs three different dialects: therapist-therapist, therapist-patient, and patient-patient, which are as different from each other as mandarin and Cantonese, or ancient Greek and modern Greek. Experience shows that eliminating these as far as possible in favour of a kua-yu or lingua franca of basic English increases the ‘communication’ which many therapists so ardently court (and so diligently leave waiting at the altar, as the saying is). I have tried to avoid the fashion popular in the social, behavioral, and psychiatric sciences of masking uncertainty with redundancy and vagueness with prolixity, a practice which has its origins in the Faculty of Medicine of the University of Paris in the fourteenth century.

传统心理治疗通常采用三种不同的“方言”：治疗师与治疗师、治疗师与患者、患者与患者，它们之间的差异堪比普通话和粤语，或是古希腊语和现代希腊语。经验表明，尽可能地消除这些“方言”，转而使用基本的英语作为通用语，可以提高许多治疗师热切追求（却又常常将其搁置）的“沟通”。我一直试图避免社会科学、行为科学和精神病学领域盛行的用冗余掩盖不确定性、用冗长掩盖模糊的做法，这种做法起源于十四世纪巴黎大学医学院。

This has led to charges of ‘popularization’ and ‘oversimplification’ – terms reminiscent of the old Central Committee accusations of ‘bourgeois cosmopolitanism’ and ‘capitalist deviation.’ Given the choice between the arcane and the open, between overcomplication and simplicity, I have thrown in with the ‘people,’ tossing in a big word now and then as a sort of hamburger to distract the watchdogs of the academies, while I slip in through the basement doors and say Hello to my friends.

这导致了“通俗化”和“过度简化”的指责——这些词语让人想起中央委员会过去对“资产阶级世界主义”和“资本主义偏离”的指责。如果要在晦涩难懂和通俗易懂、过于复杂和简单明了之间做出选择，我选择了“人民”阵营，时不时地抛出一个晦涩难懂的词汇，就像扔汉堡包一样，用来分散学院派监督者的注意力，同时我溜进地下室的门，向我的朋友们打个招呼。

It is quite impossible to thank everybody who has helped in the development of transactional analysis, since they now number in the thousands. The ones I know best are the Teaching Members of the International Transactional Analysis Association, and the members of the San Francisco Transactional Analysis Seminar, which is the one I attend regularly every week. Those who have been most actively concerned with script analysis include Carl Bonner, Melvin Boyce, Michael Breen, Viola Callaghan, Hedges Capers, Leonard Campos, William Collins, Joseph Concannon, Patricia Crossman, John Dusay, Mary Edwards, Franklin Ernst, Kenneth Everts, Robert Goulding, Martin Groder, Gordon Haiberg, Thomas Harris, James Horewitz, Muriel James, Pat Jarvis, Stephen Karpman, David Kupfer, Pamela Levin, Jack Lindheimer, Paul McCormick, Jay Nichols, Margaret Northcott, Edward Olivier, W. Ray Poindexter, Solon Samuels, Myra Schapps, Jacqui Schiff, Zelig Selinger, Claude M. Steiner, James Yates, and Robert Zechnich.

要感谢所有为交互分析发展做出贡献的人几乎是不可能的，因为人数已达数千。我最熟悉的是国际交互分析协会的教学会员，以及我每周定期参加的旧金山交互分析研讨会的成员。积极参与剧本分析的人士包括：卡尔·邦纳、梅尔文·博伊斯、迈克尔·布林、维奥拉·卡拉汉、赫奇斯·卡珀斯、伦纳德·坎波斯、威廉·柯林斯、约瑟夫·康卡农、帕特里夏·克罗斯曼、约翰·杜赛、玛丽·爱德华兹、富兰克林·恩斯特、肯尼斯·埃弗茨、罗伯特·古尔丁、马丁·格罗德、戈登·海伯格、托马斯·哈里斯、詹姆斯·霍雷维茨、缪里尔·詹姆斯、帕特·贾维斯、斯蒂芬·卡普曼、大卫·库普弗、帕梅拉·莱文、杰克·林德海默、保罗·麦考密克、杰伊·尼科尔斯、玛格丽特·诺斯科特、爱德华·奥利维尔、W·雷·波因德克斯特、索伦·塞缪尔斯、迈拉·沙普斯、杰奎·希夫、泽利格·塞林格、克劳德·M·施泰纳、詹姆斯·耶茨和罗伯特·泽克尼奇。

In addition, I want to thank my secretary in San Francisco, Pamela Blum, for keeping the Seminar running smoothly and contributing her own ideas; and also her successors, Elaine Wark and Arden Rose; and particularly my secretary in Carmel, Mrs Mary N. Williams, without whose conscientiousness, skill, and application the physical manuscript, through all its drafts and changes, could never have come into being. My fifteen-year-old son, Terence, ably assisted me in collating the bibliography and drawings and other details of the manuscript, and my daughter, Ellen Calcaterra, read it and made many valuable suggestions. Finally, I want to thank my patients for being such good sports about revealing themselves, and for letting me go away on vacations so that I could think; and also the millions of readers in fifteen languages who encouraged me by their interest in reading one or another of my books.

此外，我还要感谢我在旧金山的秘书帕梅拉·布鲁姆，感谢她让研讨会顺利进行并贡献了自己的想法；还要感谢她的继任者伊莱恩·沃克和阿登·罗斯；尤其要感谢我在卡梅尔的秘书玛丽·N·威廉姆斯夫人，没有她的认真负责、精湛技艺和辛勤付出，这份手稿，历经无数次的修改和润色，根本不可能最终完成。我十五岁的儿子特伦斯出色地协助我整理了手稿的参考书目、插图和其他细节，我的女儿艾伦·卡尔卡特拉阅读了手稿并提出了许多宝贵的建议。最后，我要感谢我的病人们，感谢他们如此配合地向我坦诚相待，并允许我休假思考；还要感谢用十五种语言阅读我作品的数百万读者，他们的热情鼓励了我。

#↩

Semantics

语义学

As in my other books, he may refer to human beings of either sex, while she may be used if I think a statement applies more to women than to men; sometimes he may also be used for grammatical simplicity to distinguish therapist (male) from patient. I hope these convenient syntactic devices will not be taken amiss by emancipated women. Is means that I have a reasonably firm conviction about something, based on the clinical experience of myself and others. Seems to be or appears to be means that I am waiting for further evidence before making a firm commitment. The case histories have been drawn from my own experience and from those presented at seminars and supervisory sessions. Some are composites, and all have been masked from outside recognition, although significant incidents or dialogues are faithfully reported.

如同我其他著作一样，这里的“他”可能指代任何性别的人，而“她”则用于我认为某个陈述更适用于女性而非男性的情况；有时，为了语法简洁，我也会使用“他”来区分治疗师（男性）和患者。我希望这些方便的句法用法不会被思想解放的女性所误解。“是”表示我基于自身及他人的临床经验，对某事抱有相当坚定的信念。“似乎是”或“看起来是”表示我正在等待进一步的证据，然后再做出最终决定。案例均取材于我自身的经验以及在研讨会和督导会议上分享的案例。部分案例为综合案例，所有案例均已进行匿名处理，但重要的事件或对话均已如实记录。

— Eric Berne

——埃里克·伯恩

#↩

PART I

第一部分

General Considerations

一般考虑因素

#↩

CHAPTER ONE

第一章

Introduction

介绍

A • What Do You Say After You Say Hello?

A. 你打完招呼后会说什么？

This childlike question, so apparently artless and free of the profundity expected of scientific inquiry, really contains within itself all the basic questions of human living and all the fundamental problems of the social sciences. It is the question that babies ‘ask’ themselves, that children learn to accept corrupted answers to, that teen-agers ask each other and their advisors, that grownups evade by accepting the corrupted answers of their betters, and that wise old philosophers write books about without ever finding the answer. It contains both the primal question of social psychology: Why do people talk to each other? and the primal question of social psychiatry: Why do people like to be liked? Its answer is the answer to the questions posed by the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse: war or peace, famine or plenty, pestilence or health, death or life. It is no wonder that few people find the answer in their lifetimes, since most go through life without ever finding the answer to the question which precedes it: How do you say Hello?

这个看似稚嫩的问题，看似天真无邪，不带一丝科学探究应有的深邃，实则蕴含着人类生活的所有基本问题和社会科学的所有根本难题。这是婴儿会“问”自己的问题，是孩子们学会接受各种歪曲答案的问题，是青少年彼此询问、向导师请教的问题，是成年人通过接受长辈们歪曲的答案来逃避的问题，也是睿智的老哲学家们著书立说却始终找不到答案的问题。它既包含了社会心理学的根本问题：人们为什么会交谈？也包含了社会精神病学的根本问题：人们为什么渴望被喜欢？它的答案就是启示录四骑士提出的问题的答案：战争还是和平，饥荒还是丰收，瘟疫还是健康，死亡还是生命。难怪很少有人一生都能找到答案，因为大多数人终其一生都未能找到这个问题的答案：你好，该怎么说？

B • How Do You Say Hello?

B • 你怎么说你好？

This is the secret of Buddhism, of Christianity, of Judaism, of Platonism, of atheism, and above all, of humanism. The famous ‘sound of one hand clapping’ in Zen is the sound of one person saying Hello to another, and it is also the sound of the Golden Rule in whatever Bible it is stated. To say Hello rightly is to see the other person, to be aware of him as a phenomenon, to happen to him and to be ready for him to happen to you. Perhaps the people who show this ability to the highest degree are the Fiji Islanders, for one of the rare jewels of the world is the genuine Fijian smile. It starts slowly, it illuminates the whole face, it rests there long enough to be clearly recognized and to recognize clearly, and it fades with secret slowness as it passes by. It can be matched elsewhere only by the smiles of an uncorrupted mother and infant greeting each other, and also, in Western countries, by a certain kind of open personality. fn1

这就是佛教、基督教、犹太教、柏拉图主义、无神论，尤其是人文主义的奥秘。禅宗著名的“单掌拍击”是人与人之间互致问候的声音，也是圣经中黄金法则的体现。正确地问候对方，意味着看到对方，意识到他是一个独特的存在，感受他，并准备好接受他对你的影响。或许，斐济岛民最能展现这种能力，因为斐济人真诚的微笑是世间罕见的瑰宝。它缓缓绽放，照亮整张脸庞，停留足够长的时间，让人清晰地辨认，也清晰地感知，然后悄然消逝。这种微笑，唯有纯真无邪的母子间互致问候的微笑，以及在西方国家某种开朗的性格才能与之媲美。

This book discusses four questions: How do you say Hello? How do you say Hello back? What do you say after you say Hello? and, principally, the plaintive query, What is everybody doing instead of saying Hello? These questions will be answered briefly here. The explanation of the answers will occupy the rest of this psychiatric textbook, which is addressed first to the therapist, secondly to his patients as they get cured, and thirdly to anyone else who cares to listen.

本书探讨四个问题：如何说“你好”？如何回应“你好”？说完“你好”之后该说什么？以及，最主要的，那个令人忧虑的问题：大家都在做什么，而不是说“你好”？本书将对这些问题进行简要解答。答案的详细解释将占据这本精神病学教科书的其余部分。本书首先面向治疗师，其次面向正在康复的患者，最后面向所有愿意倾听的人。

1. In order to say Hello, you first get rid of all the trash which has accumulated in your head ever since you came home from the maternity ward, and then you recognize that this particular Hello will never happen again. It may take years to learn how to do this.

1. 要开口说“你好”，首先要清除自产后回家以来积攒在脑海里的所有杂念，然后你意识到，这声“你好”将永不再来。学会做到这一点，或许需要数年时间。

2. In order to say Hello back, you get rid of all the trash in your head and see that there is somebody standing there or walking by, waiting for you to say Hello back. It may take years to learn how to do that .

2. 为了回应别人的问候，你需要清除脑海中所有的杂念，然后意识到有人站在那里或从旁边走过，等着你回应。学会做到这一点可能需要数年时间。

3. After you say Hello, you get rid of all the trash that is coming back into your head; all the after-burns of all the grievances you have experienced and all the reach-backs of all the troubles you are planning to get into. Then you will be speechless and will not have anything to say. After more years of practice, you might think of something worth saying.

3. 当你道别之后，所有涌入脑海的垃圾都会被清除掉；所有你经历过的委屈和即将面临的麻烦都会被清除掉。那时你会哑口无言，什么也说不出来。经过多年的练习，你或许会想到一些值得说的话。

4. Mostly, this book is about the trash: the things people are doing to each other instead of saying Hello. It is written in the hope that those with training and talent for such things can help themselves and others to recognize what I am calling (in a philosophical sense) ‘trash,’ since the first problem in answering the other three questions is to see what is trash and what isn’t. The way people speak who are learning to say Hello is called ‘Martian,’ to distinguish it from everyday Earth-talk, which, as history shows from the earliest recorded times in Egypt and Babylonia to the present, has led to wars, famines, pestilence, and death; and, in the survivors, to a certain amount of mental confusion. It is hoped that in the long run, Martian, properly learned and properly taught, will help to eliminate these plagues. Martian, for example, is the language of dreams, which show things the way they really are.

4. 这本书主要探讨的是“垃圾”：人们彼此之间用各种方式代替“你好”的交流。本书的写作目的在于，希望那些受过相关训练且在这方面有天赋的人能够帮助自己和他人识别我（从哲学意义上讲）称之为“垃圾”的东西，因为回答其他三个问题的首要问题是区分什么是垃圾，什么不是垃圾。人们学习如何说“你好”的方式被称为“火星语”，以区别于日常的地球语言。历史表明，从埃及和巴比伦最早的文字记载到今天，地球语言导致了战争、饥荒、瘟疫和死亡；幸存者也因此遭受了一定程度的精神混乱。希望从长远来看，正确学习和教授的火星语能够帮助消除这些祸患。例如，火星语是梦境的语言，它能展现事物的真实面貌。

C • An Illustration

C • 插图

To illustrate the possible value of this approach, let us consider a dying patient, that is, a patient with an incurable disease and a limited time to live. Mort, a thirty-year-old man with a slowly developing form of cancer, incurable in the present state of knowledge, was given at worst two years, and at best, five. His psychiatric complaint was tics, consisting of nodding his head or shaking his feet for reasons unknown to him. In his treatment group he soon found the explanation: he was damming his fears behind a continuous wall of music which ran through his mind, and his tics were his way of keeping time with that music. It was established by careful observation that it was this way ’round and not the other, that is, that it was not music keeping time with tics, but body movements keeping time with mental music. At this point everyone, including Mort, saw that if the music were taken away by psychotherapy, a vast reservoir of apprehension would be released. The consequences of this were unforeseeable, unless his fears could be replaced by more agreeable emotions. What to do?

为了说明这种方法的潜在价值，我们不妨设想一位临终病人，也就是身患绝症、时日无多的病人。莫特，一位三十岁的男子，患有一种缓慢发展的癌症，以目前的医学水平而言，这种癌症无法治愈。医生估计他最差的寿命是两年，最好的情况是五年。他的精神症状是抽动症，表现为不明原因地点头或抖腿。在治疗小组中，他很快找到了答案：他用脑海中持续不断的音乐来压制自己的恐惧，而他的抽动症则是他与这音乐保持节奏的方式。通过仔细观察，人们发现事实并非如此，也就是说，不是音乐与抽动症同步，而是身体动作与脑海中的音乐同步。此时，包括莫特在内的所有人都意识到，如果通过心理治疗消除这种“音乐”，他内心深处积压的巨大焦虑就会释放出来。除非他的恐惧能够被更愉悦的情绪所取代，否则后果将难以预料。该怎么办？

It soon became clear that all the members of the group knew they were going to die sooner or later, and that they all had feelings about it which they were holding back in various ways. Just as with Mort, the time and effort they spent covering up were blackmail payments made to death, which prevented them from fully enjoying life. Such being the case, they might do more living in the twenty or fifty years left to each of them than Mort could do in the two or five years left to him. Thus it was determined that it was not the duration of life, but the quality of living which was important: not a startling or novel discovery, but one arrived at in a more poignant way than usual because of the presence of the dying man, which had a deep effect on everyone.

很快，所有人都意识到自己迟早会死，并且都对此有所隐瞒，只是各自以不同的方式压抑着这种感受。就像莫特一样，他们花费在掩盖真相上的时间和精力，实际上是在用死亡来勒索他们，使他们无法真正享受生活。既然如此，他们每个人剩下的二三十年，或许比莫特剩下的两五年活得更精彩。因此，他们最终得出结论：重要的不是生命的长短，而是生活的质量。这并非什么惊人的发现，但由于那位垂死之人的存在，这一结论的得出方式比以往更加深刻，也更令人动容。

It was agreed by the other members (who understood Martian talk, which they gladly taught Mort, and which he gladly learned) that living meant such simple things as seeing the trees, hearing the birds sing, and saying Hello to people: experiences of awareness and spontaneity without drama or hypocrisy, and with reticence and decorum. They also agreed that in order to do these things, all of them, including Mort, had to get tough about the trash in their heads. When they saw that his situation was, in a way, not much more tragic than their own, the sadness and timidity caused by his presence lifted. They could now be merry with him and he with them; he and they could talk as equals. They could get tough with him about his trash, because now he knew the value of toughness, and why they were being tough; in return, he had the privilege of getting tough with them about their trash. In effect, Mort turned in his cancer card and resumed his membership in the human race, although everyone, including himself, still fully realized that his predicament was more acute than anyone else’s. 1

其他成员（他们听得懂火星语，并乐于教给莫特，莫特也欣然学习）一致认为，生活意味着一些简单的事情，比如看看树木，听听鸟儿歌唱，和人打个招呼：体验觉知和自发性，不带戏剧性或虚伪，举止得体而含蓄。他们也一致认为，为了做到这些，包括莫特在内的所有人，都必须正视自己脑海中的那些糟粕。当他们意识到莫特的处境在某种程度上并不比他们更悲惨时，他带来的悲伤和怯懦便消散了。他们现在可以和他一起快乐，他也可以和他们一起快乐；他们可以平等地交谈。他们可以对他的糟粕提出严厉批评，因为他现在明白了严厉的价值，也明白了他们为何如此严厉；作为回报，他也有权对他们的糟粕提出严厉批评。实际上，莫特交出了他的癌症病史，重新加入了人类大家庭，尽管包括他自己在内的所有人都清楚地意识到，他的处境比任何人都更加艰难。

This situation illustrates more clearly than most others the pathos and depth of the Hello problem, which, in Mort’s case, went through three stages. When he first entered the group, the others did not know that he was a condemned man. They first addressed him in the manner customary in that group. Their approaches were basically set by each member’s upbringing – the way his parents had taught him to greet other people, adjustments learned later in life, and a certain respect and frankness appropriate to psychotherapy. Mort, being a newcomer, responded the way he would anywhere else, pretending to be the ambitious, red-blooded American boy his parents had wanted him to be. But when he stated, during his third session, that he was a doomed man, the other members felt confused and betrayed. They wondered if they had said anything which would make them look bad in their own eyes and his, and especially in the eyes of the therapist. They seemed, in fact, angry at both Mort and the therapist for not telling them sooner, almost as though they had been tricked. In effect, they had said Hello to Mort in a standardized way, without realizing to whom they were speaking. Now that they knew he was a special person, they wished they could go back and start over, in which case they would treat him differently.

这种情况比其他大多数情况都更清晰地展现了“你好”问题的悲情和深度。在莫特的案例中，这个问题经历了三个阶段。他刚加入小组时，其他成员并不知道他是一个被判死刑的人。起初，他们以小组惯例的方式与他打招呼。他们的方式基本上取决于每个成员的成长经历——父母教他们如何问候他人、后来在生活中学会的适应方式，以及心理治疗中应有的尊重和坦诚。莫特作为新成员，像在其他任何地方一样回应，假装成父母希望他成为的那种雄心勃勃、热情洋溢的美国男孩。但在第三次治疗中，当他坦白自己是一个注定要死的人时，其他成员感到困惑和被背叛。他们怀疑自己是否说了什么话，让自己在自己、莫特，尤其是治疗师眼中显得很糟糕。事实上，他们似乎对莫特和治疗师都感到愤怒，责怪他们没有早点告诉他们，仿佛自己被骗了一样。实际上，他们只是用一种千篇一律的方式向莫特打招呼，却没意识到自己是在和谁说话。现在他们知道他是个特别的人，真希望能够回到过去重新开始，那样他们一定会用不同的方式对待他。

So they did start over. Instead of talking forthrightly, as they had before, they addressed him softly and cautiously, as though to say: ‘See how I’m going out of my way to be thoughtful of your tragedy?’ None of them wanted to risk his good name now by speaking out to a dying man. But this was unfair, since it gave Mort the upper hand. In particular, nobody dared to laugh very long or very loud in such a presence. This was corrected when the problem of what Mort could do was solved; then the tension lifted and they could go back and start over for the third time, talking to him as a member of the human race, without restraint. Thus, the three stages were represented by the superficial Hello, the tense, sympathetic Hello, and the relaxed, real Hello.

于是他们重新开始。他们不再像之前那样直言不讳，而是轻声细语、小心翼翼地与他交谈，仿佛在说：“你看，我多么体贴周到地关心你的遭遇啊！” 谁也不想因为跟一个垂死之人说话而损害他的名誉。但这并不公平，因为这让莫特占了上风。尤其是在这种场合，谁也不敢长时间或大声地大笑。直到莫特的能力问题得到解决，这种情况才有所改善；紧张的气氛随之消散，他们才得以第三次重新开始，像对待一个普通人一样，毫无顾忌地与他交谈。因此，这三个阶段分别对应着：敷衍的问候、紧张而充满同情的问候，以及轻松而真诚的问候。

Zoe cannot say Hello to Mort until she knows who he is and that can change from week to week, or even from hour to hour. Each time she meets him, she knows a little more about him than she did the last time, and she must say Hello to him in a slightly different way if she wants to keep up with their advancing friendship. But since she can never know all about him, nor anticipate all the changes, she can never say a perfect Hello, but only come closer and closer to it.

佐伊只有在真正了解莫特之后才能向他打招呼，而莫特的身份可能每周都在变化，甚至每小时都在变化。每次见到他，她都会比上次多了解一些，如果想维系这段日益深厚的友谊，她就必须用略微不同的方式向他问好。但由于她永远无法完全了解他，也无法预料到所有的变化，她永远无法说出完美的“你好”，只能一步步接近那个完美的模样。

D • The Handshake

D • 握手

Many patients who come to a psychiatrist for the first time introduce themselves and shake hands when he invites them into his office. Some psychiatrists, indeed, offer their own hands first. I have a different policy in regard to handshakes. If the patient proffers his hand in a hearty way, I will shake it in order to avoid being rude, but in a noncommittal fashion, because I am wondering why he is being so hearty. If he offers it in a way which merely suggests that he considers it good manners, I will return the compliment in such fashion that we understand each other: this pleasant ritual will not interfere with the job to be done. If he proffers it in a way which indicates that he is desperate, then I will shake it firmly and reassuringly to let him know that I understand his need. But my manner when I enter the waiting room, the expression on my face and the position of my arms, indicates clearly enough to most newcomers that this amenity will be omitted unless they insist upon it. This is intended to establish, and usually does establish, that we are both there for a more serious purpose than to prove that we are good fellows or to exchange courtesies. Mainly, I do not shake hands with them because I do not know them, and I do not expect them to shake hands with me, because they do not know me; also, some people who come to psychiatrists object to being touched, and it is a courtesy to them to refrain from doing so.

许多初次就诊的精神科患者会在被邀请进入诊室时自我介绍并握手。事实上，有些精神科医生也会主动伸出手。但我对于握手有不同的做法。如果患者热情地伸出手，为了避免失礼，我会握手，但不会显得过于热情，因为我也在思考他为何如此热情。如果他只是出于礼貌而握手，我也会以彼此都能理解的方式回应：这种友好的礼节不会影响诊疗工作。如果他伸出手时流露出绝望之情，我会坚定而有力地握手，让他知道我理解他的处境。但我进入候诊室时的举止、表情和手臂的姿势，已经足以让大多数初次就诊者明白，除非他们坚持，否则我不会握手。这样做是为了表明（通常也确实如此），我们来此的目的并非为了证明彼此是好朋友或寒暄客套，而是为了更严肃的目的。主要是因为我不认识他们，所以我不与他们握手；我也不期望他们与我握手，因为他们也不认识我；此外，有些来看精神科医生的人不喜欢被触碰，避免触碰他们也是出于礼貌。

The ending of the interview is a different matter. By that time I know a great deal about the patient, and he knows something about me. Thus, when he leaves, I make a point of shaking hands with him, and I know enough about him to know how to do it properly. This handshake means something very important to him: that I am accepting fn2 him even after he has told me all the ‘bad’ things about himself. If he needs comforting, my handshake is such that it will comfort him; if he needs assertion of his masculinity, my handshake will evoke his masculinity. This is not a carefully thought out device to seduce the patient; it is a spontaneous and freely-given recognition of him as I now know him after talking for an hour with him about his most intimate concerns. On the other side, if he has lied to me out of malice rather than natural embarrassment, or tried to exploit or browbeat me, I will not shake hands with him, so that he knows he will have to behave differently if he wants me on his side.

面谈结束时的情况则有所不同。那时，我对这位病人已经了解颇多，他也对我有所了解。因此，当他离开时，我会特意与他握手，而且我对他的了解足以让我知道如何得体地握手。这个握手对他意义非凡：它表明，即便他向我倾诉了所有关于自己的“缺点”，我仍然接纳他。如果他需要安慰，我的握手就能给他带来慰藉；如果他需要彰显自己的男子气概，我的握手就能唤起他的男子气概。这并非精心策划的诱惑病人的手段；而是在与他交谈一个小时，深入了解他最私密的感受之后，我自然而然、毫无保留地表达对他的认可。另一方面，如果他出于恶意而不是出于自然的尴尬而对我撒谎，或者试图利用我或胁迫我，我将不会与他握手，让他知道如果他想让我站在他这边，他就必须改变他的行为。

With women, it is slightly different. If one needs a palpable sign that I accept her, I will shake hands in a way suitable to her needs; if (as I know by this time) another shrinks from contact with men, I will say farewell in a correct way but let her pass without a handshake. This latter case illustrates most clearly the reason for not shaking hands as a greeting: if I shake hands with her at the start, before I know with whom I am shaking hands, I awaken her abhorrence. I have, in effect, intruded upon and insulted her before the interview, by forcing her, out of good manners, and against her inclination, to touch me and let me touch her, however courteously.

对女性而言，情况略有不同。如果对方需要一个明确的信号来表明我接受她，我会以适合她的方式握手；如果（正如我此时所知）对方不愿与男性接触，我会以得体的方式道别，但不会与她握手。后一种情况最能说明为什么不应该握手作为问候：如果我在一开始就与她握手，而我甚至还不清楚对方是谁，就会激起她的反感。实际上，我强迫她出于礼貌，违背她的意愿，与我接触，即使我的动作再礼貌，也已经侵犯并冒犯了她，而这实际上是在正式会面之前就侵犯了她的隐私。

In therapy groups, I follow a similar policy. I do not say Hello on entering, because I have not seen the members for a whole week, and I do not know to whom I am saying Hello. A light or cordial Hello might be quite out of place in the light of something that has happened to them in the interval. But I do make a very strong point of saying Good-by to each member at the end of the meeting, because then I know to whom I am saying Good-by, and how to say it in each case. For example, suppose one woman’s mother has died since the last meeting. A genial Hello from me would seem out of place to her. She might forgive me for it, but there is no need to put that strain on her. By the time the meeting is over, I know how to say Good-by to her in her bereavement.

在治疗小组中，我遵循类似的原则。我不会在进入小组时打招呼，因为我已经整整一周没见到这些成员了，我不知道该跟谁打招呼。考虑到他们在这段时间里可能经历了什么，一句轻描淡写或客套的“你好”可能显得很不合时宜。但我非常重视在每次小组会议结束时与每位成员道别，因为这样我就知道该跟谁道别，以及在每种情况下该如何表达。例如，假设一位女士的母亲在上次会议后去世了。如果我热情地跟她打招呼，她会觉得很不自在。她或许会原谅我，但我没有必要给她增加这种压力。等到会议结束时，我知道如何以恰当的方式向她道别，让她感受到我的关怀。

E • Friends

E • 朋友

Socially, it is different, since friends are for stroking. With them, Hello and Good-by range from an open handshake to a big hug, depending on what they are ready for or need; or sometimes it is josh and jive to keep from getting too involved, a ‘smile when you say that.’ But one thing in life is more certain than taxes and just as certain as death: the sooner you make new friends, the sooner you’ll have old ones.

社交场合则有所不同，因为朋友是用来亲近的。和他们打招呼和道别的方式多种多样，从握手到拥抱都有，取决于他们的意愿和需求；有时为了避免过于亲密，会开些玩笑，比如一句“你说这话的时候笑一笑”。但人生中有一件事比税收更确定，也和死亡一样确定：你越早结交新朋友，就能越早拥有老朋友。

F • The Theory

F • 理论

So much for Hello and Good-by. What happens in between falls into the framework of a specific theory of personality and group dynamics, which is also a therapeutic method, known as transactional analysis. In order to appreciate what follows, it is first necessary to understand the principles of this approach.

以上便是初次见面和告别。接下来发生的事情则属于一种特定的人格和群体动力学理论框架，这种理论同时也是一种治疗方法，即交互分析。为了更好地理解接下来的内容，首先需要了解这种方法的基本原理。

References

参考

1 The advantages of coming back to life instead of waiting for death are shown in: (1) ‘Terminal Cancer Ward: Patients Build Atmosphere of Dignity.’ Journal of the American Medical Association . 208:1289, May 26, 1969. (2) Klagsbrun, S. C. ‘Cancer Emotions, and Nurses.’ Summary of Scientific Proceedings . 122nd Annual Meeting, American Psychiatric Association, Washington, D.C., 1969.

1. 与其坐以待毙，不如重获新生，其优势体现在以下文献中：(1)《晚期癌症病房：患者营造尊严氛围》，《美国医学会杂志》，208:1289，1969年5月26日。(2) Klagsbrun, S. C.《癌症情绪与护士》，美国精神病学会第122届年会科学会议论文摘要，华盛顿特区，1969年。

fn1 Oddly enough, in my experience, such smiles are most frequently seen in girls in their twenties, with long black hair.

fn1 奇怪的是，根据我的经验，这种笑容最常出现在二十多岁、留着黑色长发的女孩身上。

fn2 ‘Acceptance’ is not used here in its ill-defined, sentimental sense; it means, specifically, that I am willing to spend more time with him. This involves a serious commitment which may, in some cases, mean one or more years of patience, effort, ups and downs, and getting up in the morning.

fn2 这里的“接受”并非指其含义模糊、感伤的层面；它具体指的是我愿意花更多的时间陪伴他。这需要认真的承诺，在某些情况下，可能意味着一年或更长时间的耐心、努力、经历起伏，以及每天早晨起床。

#↩

CHAPTER TWO

第二章

Principles of Transactional Analysis

人际沟通分析原理

The principles of transactional analysis have been described previously on numerous occasions. The most detailed account can be found in the writer’s work on Transactional Analysis in Psychotherapy ; 1 its application to group dynamics is outlined in The Structure and Dynamics of Organizations and Groups ; 2 its use in analyzing games is described in Games People Play ; 3 its application to clinical practice is found in Principles of Group Treatment ; 4 and a summary of the theory is given in popular form in A Layman’s Guide to Psychiatry and Psychoanalysis . 5 Hence, only a brief outline will be given here, for the benefit of those readers who do not have any of these works immediately to hand.

人际沟通分析的原理此前已被多次阐述。最详尽的论述见于笔者所著的《心理治疗中的人际沟通分析》；其在群体动力学中的应用概述于《组织与群体的结构与动力学》；其在博弈分析中的运用见于《人间游戏》；其在临床实践中的应用见于《团体治疗原则》；而其理论概述则以通俗易懂的方式呈现于《精神病学与精神分析入门指南》中。因此，本文仅作简要概述，以方便那些手边没有上述著作的读者。

A • Structural Analysis

A • 结构分析

The basic interest of transactional analysis is the study of ego states, which are coherent systems of thought and feeling manifested by corresponding patterns of behavior. Each human being exhibits three types of ego states. (1) Those derived from parental figures, colloquially called the Parent. In this state, he feels, thinks, acts, talks, and responds just as one of his parents did when he was little. This ego state is active, for example, in raising his own children. Even when he is not actually exhibiting this ego state, it influences his behavior as the ‘Parental influence,’ performing the functions of a conscience. (2) The ego state in which he appraises his environment objectively, and calculates its possibilities and probabilities on the basis of past experience, is called the Adult ego state, or the Adult. The Adult functions like a computer. (3) Each person carries within a little boy or little girl, who feels, thinks, acts, talks, and responds just the way he or she did when he or she was a child of a certain age. This ego state is called the Child. The Child is not regarded as ‘childish’ or ‘immature,’ which are Parental words, but as ‘childlike,’ meaning like a child of a certain age, and the important factor here is the age, which may be anywhere between two and five years in ordinary circumstances. It is important for the individual to understand his Child, not only because it is going to be with him all his life, but also because it is the most valuable part of his personality.

人际沟通分析的核心在于研究自我状态，即由相应的行为模式所体现的连贯的思维和情感系统。每个人都展现出三种自我状态。(1) 源自父母形象的自我状态，俗称“父母”。在这种状态下，个体的感受、思考、行动、言语和反应都如同他小时候的父母一样。这种自我状态在例如养育子女的过程中发挥着积极作用。即使个体并非刻意展现这种自我状态，它也会以“父母影响”的形式影响其行为，发挥着良知的作用。(2) 在这种自我状态下，个体客观地评估环境，并根据过去的经验计算其可能性和概率，这种自我状态被称为“成人”自我状态，或简称“成人”。“成人”的运作方式如同计算机。(3) 每个人内心都住着一个小男孩或小女孩，他的感受、思考、行动、言语和反应都如同他/她童年时期那样。这种自我状态被称为“孩童”。“孩童”并非被视为“幼稚”或“不成熟”（这些都是父母常用的词汇），而是“像孩子一样”，意味着像某个特定年龄段的孩子。这里的关键因素是年龄，在通常情况下，这个年龄段可能在两到五岁之间。对个体而言，了解自己的“孩童”至关重要，不仅因为它将伴随其一生，更因为它是其人格中最宝贵的部分。

FIGURE 1A

图 1A

FIGURE 1B

图 1B

FIGURE 1C

图 1C

Figure 1A , then, purports to be the complete personality diagram of any human being whatsoever, encompassing everything he may feel, think, say, or do. (Its more convenient abbreviated form is shown in Figure 1B .) A more detailed analysis does not yield new ego states, but only subdivisions within the primary ones. Thus, it is evident that careful study will show two Parental components in most cases, one derived from the father, the other from the mother; it will also uncover within the Child ego state the Parent, Adult, and Child components which were already there when the Child was fixated, as can be verified by observing actual children. This second-order analysis is represented in Figure 1C . The separation of one feeling-and-behavior pattern from another in diagnosing ego states is called structural analysis . In the text, ego states will be denoted Parent (P), Adult (A), and Child (C), capitalized, while parent, adult, or child, uncapitalized, will denote actual people.

因此，图1A旨在展现任何人类的完整人格图，涵盖其所有感受、想法、言语和行为。（其更便于理解的简化形式如图1B所示。）更详细的分析并不会产生新的自我状态，而只会揭示主要自我状态内部的细分。因此，显而易见，仔细研究在大多数情况下会发现两个“父母”成分，一个源自父亲，另一个源自母亲；研究还会揭示“儿童”自我状态中存在的“父母”、“成人”和“儿童”成分，这些成分在“儿童”固着形成时就已经存在，这一点可以通过观察真实的儿童来验证。这种二阶分析如图1C所示。在诊断自我状态时，将一种感受和行为模式与另一种模式区分开来的过程称为结构分析。在文中，“父母”（P）、“成人”（A）和“儿童”（C）将用大写字母表示，而“父母”、“成人”或“儿童”（小写）则指代实际的人。

FIGURE 1D

图 1D

There we will also encounter descriptive terms which are self-explanatory or which will be explained: the Natural or Nurturing Parent and the Controlling Parent, and the Natural, the Adapted, and the Rebellious Child. Where the ‘structural’ Child is represented by horizontal divisions, the ‘descriptive’ Child is shown with vertical ones, as in Figure 1D .

我们还会遇到一些描述性术语，有些术语本身就很容易理解，有些则会在下文中进行解释：例如“自然型”或“养育型”父母和“控制型”父母，以及“天性型”、“适应型”和“叛逆型”儿童。如图 1D 所示，“结构型”儿童用水平分割线表示，“描述型”儿童则用垂直分割线表示。

B • Transactional Analysis

B • 交易分析

From the above, it is evident that when two people confront each other, there are six ego states involved, three in each person, as in Figure 2A . Since ego states are as different from each other as actual people are, it is important to know which ego state is active in each person when something takes place between them. What happens can then be represented by arrows drawn between the two ‘people’ in the diagram. In the simplest transactions, the arrows are parallel, and these are called complementary transactions. It is evident that there are nine possible types of complementary transactions (PP, PA, PC, AP, AA, AC, CP, CA, CC) as shown in Figure 2B . Figure 2A represents, as an example, a PC transaction between two spouses, in which the stimulus is from the husband’s Parent ego state to the wife’s Child ego state, and the response is from her Child to his Parent. In the best situation, this may represent a fatherly husband taking care of a grateful wife. As long as the transactions are complementary, with parallel arrows, communication may proceed indefinitely.

从以上内容可以看出，当两个人互动时，会涉及到六种自我状态，每人三种，如图2A所示。由于自我状态如同真实的人一样千差万别，因此了解当两人之间发生某种互动时，每个人处于哪种自我状态至关重要。互动过程可以用图中连接两人的箭头来表示。在最简单的互动中，箭头平行，这类互动被称为互补互动。如图2B所示，互补互动共有九种类型（PP、PA、PC、AP、AA、AC、CP、CA、CC）。图2A以夫妻间的一次PC互动为例，其中刺激来自丈夫的父母自我状态，指向妻子的儿童自我状态，而回应则来自妻子的儿童自我状态，指向丈夫的父母自我状态。在理想情况下，这可能代表一位慈父般的丈夫照顾一位心怀感激的妻子。只要互动是互补的，箭头平行，沟通就可以无限进行下去。

FIGURE 2A

图 2A

FIGURE 2B

图 2B

In Figures 3A and 3B something has gone wrong. In Figure 3A an Adult-to-Adult stimulus (AA), such as a request for information, receives a Child-to-Parent response (CP), so that the stimulus and response arrows, instead of being parallel, are crossed. A transaction of this type is called a crossed transaction , and in such a situation communication is broken off. If, for example, the husband asks as a matter of information ‘Where are my cuff links?’ and the wife replies ‘Why do you always blame me for everything?’ a crossed transaction has occurred, and they can no longer talk about cuff links. This is crossed transaction Type I, which represents the common form of transference reaction as it occurs in psychotherapy, and is also the type of transaction which causes most of the troubles in the world. Figure 3B represents crossed transaction Type II, in which an Adult-to-Adult stimulus (AA), such as a question, receives a patronizing or pompous Parent-to-Child response (PC). This is the commonest type of counter-transference reaction and the second most common cause of trouble in personal and political relationships.

图3A和3B中出现了问题。在图3A中，成人对成人的刺激（AA），例如询问信息，却得到了儿童对父母的回应（CP），因此刺激和回应的箭头不是平行的，而是交叉的。这种类型的互动被称为交叉互动，在这种情况下，沟通中断了。例如，如果丈夫询问“我的袖扣在哪儿？”，妻子回答“你为什么总是责怪我？”，那么就发生了交叉互动，他们无法再谈论袖扣了。这是交叉互动类型I，代表了心理治疗中常见的移情反应形式，也是造成世界上大多数问题的互动类型。图3B代表交叉互动类型II，其中成人对成人的刺激（AA），例如提问，却得到了居高临下或傲慢的父母对儿童的回应（PC）。这是最常见的反移情反应类型，也是人际关系和政治关系中第二大常见问题的原因。

FIGURE 3A

图 3A

FIGURE 3B

图 3B

Careful inspection of the relationship diagram in Figure 2B will show that 72 types of crossed transactions are mathematically possible (9x9=81 combinations, less the 9 complementary ones), fn1 but fortunately only about four of them occur often enough to be of major concern in clinical work or in everyday life. These are the ones described above, Type I (AA–CP), the transference reaction; and Type II (AA–PC), the counter-transference reaction; plus Type III (CP–AA), the ‘exasperating response,’ where someone who wants sympathy gets facts instead, and Type IV (PC–AA), ‘impudence,’ where someone who expects compliance gets what he considers a ‘smart aleck’ response instead, in the form of a factual statement.

仔细观察图 2B 中的关系图可知，理论上存在 72 种交叉交易类型（9×9=81 种组合，减去 9 种互补组合），但幸运的是，只有大约四种类型出现频率高到足以在临床工作或日常生活中引起重视。这些类型包括上文所述的 I 型（AA–CP），即移情反应；II 型（AA–PC），即反移情反应；以及 III 型（CP–AA），即“激怒反应”，在这种反应中，寻求同情的人得到的却是事实；还有 IV 型（PC–AA），即“无礼”，在这种反应中，期望顺从的人得到的却是他认为“自作聪明”的回应，这种回应以事实陈述的形式呈现。

Complementary and crossed transactions are simple, one-level transactions. There are two types of ulterior or two-level transactions, angular and duplex. Figure 4A represents an angular transaction in which an ostensibly Adult-to-Adult stimulus, such as a rational-sounding sales appeal, is actually devised to hook some other ego state – either the Parent or the Child – in the respondent. Here the unbroken line, Adult-to-Adult, represents the social or overt level of the transaction, while the dotted line represents the psychological or covert level. If the angular transaction is successful in this case, the response will be Child-to-Adult rather than Adult-to-Adult; if it is unsuccessful, the Adult of the respondent maintains control and the response will be from the Adult instead of the Child. Considering the various ways in which the ego states can be involved, it may be seen from the diagrams ( Figures 4A and 2B ) that there are 18 types of successful angular transactions in which the dotted line is responded to, and for each of these there is an unsuccessful angular transaction in which the response is thrown back parallel to the unbroken line.

互补型和交叉型交易是简单的单层交易。而隐蔽型或双层交易则有两种类型：角度型和双重型。图 4A 展示了一种角度型交易，其中表面上看似成人对成人的刺激（例如听起来理性的销售说辞）实际上是为了诱发受访者的某种其他自我状态——父母型或儿童型。图中实线（成人对成人）代表交易的社会或显性层面，虚线代表心理或隐性层面。如果角度型交易成功，受访者的反应将是儿童对成人的，而非成人对成人的；如果交易失败，受访者的成人自我状态将保持控制，反应将来自成人自我状态而非儿童自我状态。考虑到自我状态可以参与的各种方式，从图表（图 4A 和 2B）可以看出，有 18 种成功的角度交易类型，其中虚线表示响应；而对于每一种成功的角度交易，都存在一种不成功的角度交易，其中响应与实线平行地被抛回。

FIGURE 4A

图 4A

Figure 4B represents a duplex transaction. In this case there are two distinct levels, the underlying psychological or covert level being different from the social or overt level. A study of the diagrams will show that there are 81 2 or 6561 different types of duplex transactions possible. fn2 If we subtract those in which the social and psychological levels duplicate each other (which are, in effect, the 81 types of simple transactions) there are actually 6480 types of duplex transactions. Fortunately again, only about six of these are of common clinical or everyday significance. fn3

图 4B 展示了一种双重交易。在这种情况下，存在两个不同的层次，潜在的心理或隐蔽层次与社会或显性层次不同。研究这些图表可知，双重交易共有 81 种类型，即 6561 种不同的类型。如果我们减去社会层次和心理层次相互重复的类型（实际上就是 81 种简单的交易类型），那么实际上还有 6480 种双重交易类型。幸运的是，其中只有大约六种具有常见的临床或日常意义。

FIGURE 4B

图 4B

The reader may wonder why there are so many numbers in this section. There are three reasons. (1) The Child reason is that lots of people like to figure out numbers. (2) The Adult reason is to demonstrate that transactional analysis is more precise than most other social and psychological theories. (3) The Parent reason is to show that even though it is so precise, it does not fence people in. For example, if we engage in only three transactions, and each time we have a choice among 6597 varieties, then we can have our three transactions in 6597 3 ways. This gives us about 300 billion different ways of structuring our three exchanges with each other. That certainly gives us all the room we need to express our individualities. It means that the whole population of the world could pair off, and each couple have three exchanges 200 times in a row, without any pair ever duplicating what any other pair did, or repeating anything they themselves had done before. Since most people engage in hundreds or thousands of transactions every day, each person has trillions and trillions of combinations at his disposal. Even if he has an aversion to 5000 of the 6597 possible types of transactions, and never gets into them, there is still plenty of room to maneuver in, and there is no necessity for his behavior to be stereotyped unless he himself sets it up that way. If he does so, as most people do, that is not the fault of transactional analysis, but of other influences that form the chief subject matter of this book.

读者可能会好奇为什么本节会出现这么多数字。原因有三：(1) 从儿童的角度来看，很多人喜欢计算数字。(2) 从成人的角度来看，是为了证明交互分析比大多数其他社会和心理学理论更加精确。(3) 从父母的角度来看，是为了表明即使交互分析如此精确，它也不会限制人们的思维。例如，如果我们只进行三次交互，每次交互都有 6597 种选择，那么这三次交互就有 6597 种不同的方式。这意味着我们大约有 3000 亿种不同的方式来构建这三次交互。这无疑给了我们充分的空间来表达我们的个性。这意味着全世界的人口都可以两两配对，每对伴侣连续进行 200 次交互，而没有任何一对伴侣会重复其他伴侣的行为，也不会重复自己之前做过的事情。由于大多数人每天都会进行成百上千笔交易，每个人都拥有数万亿种组合可供选择。即使他对6597种可能的交易类型中的5000种感到厌恶，并且从未涉足其中，仍然有很大的回旋余地，除非他自己刻意为之，否则他的行为完全没有必要被定型。如果他像大多数人一样刻意如此，那并非交易分析的错，而是其他因素的影响，而这些因素正是本书的主要论述内容。

Since this system as a whole, in all its branches, is referred to as transactional analysis, what has been described above, the analysis of single transactions, is called transactional analysis proper , which is the second step after structural analysis. Transactional analysis proper gives a rigorous definition of the system as a whole, which will be of interest principally to those trained in scientific methodology. A transaction consisting of a single stimulus and a single response, verbal or nonverbal, is the unit of social action. It is called a transaction because each party gains something from it, and that is why he engages in it. 6 Anything that happens between two or more people can be broken down into a series of single transactions, and this gives all the advantages which any science attains when it has a well-defined system of units.

由于整个系统及其所有分支都被称为交互分析，因此上述对单个交互的分析被称为真正的交互分析，它是结构分析之后的第二步。真正的交互分析对整个系统给出了严格的定义，这主要对接受过科学方法论训练的人有意义。由单个刺激和单个反应（无论是口头的还是非口头的）组成的交互是社会行为的基本单位。之所以称之为交互，是因为每一方都能从中获得某些东西，这也是他们参与其中的原因。两个人或多人之间发生的任何事情都可以分解为一系列单个交互，这使得任何科学在拥有明确定义的单元系统时都能获得所有优势。

Transactional analysis is a theory of personality and social action, and a clinical method of psychotherapy, based on the analysis of all possible transactions between two or more people, on the basis of specifically defined ego states, into a finite number of established types (nine complementary, 72 crossed, 6480 duplex, and 36 angular). Only about 15 of these commonly occur in ordinary practice; the rest are largely of academic interest. Any system or approach which is not based on the rigorous analysis of single transactions into their component specific ego states is not transactional analysis. This definition, in effect, purports to set up a model for all possible forms of human social behavior. This model is efficient because it follows the principle of scientific economy (sometimes known as ‘Occam’s razor’), making only two assumptions: (1) that human beings can change from one ego state to another, and (2) that if A says something and B says something shortly thereafter, it can be verified whether or not what B said was a response to what A said. It is also very effective because, so far, no examples have been found among thousands or millions of interchanges between human beings which could not be dealt with by the model; and it is rigorous as well, because it is limited by simple arithmetical considerations.

人际沟通分析是一种人格和社会行为理论，也是一种临床心理治疗方法。它基于对两个人或多人之间所有可能沟通的分析，并根据特定定义的自我状态，将其归纳为有限数量的既定类型（九种互补型、72种交叉型、6480种双重型和36种角度型）。在日常实践中，通常只出现其中约15种；其余的则主要用于学术研究。任何不基于对单个沟通进行严格分析，将其分解为构成该沟通的特定自我状态的系统或方法，都不能称之为人际沟通分析。实际上，这个定义旨在建立一个涵盖所有可能人类社会行为形式的模型。该模型之所以有效，是因为它遵循科学经济原则（有时被称为“奥卡姆剃刀”），仅基于两个假设：（1）人类可以从一种自我状态转换到另一种自我状态；（2）如果A说了什么，B随后不久也说了什么，那么可以验证B所说的话是否是对A所说的话的回应。它还非常有效，因为到目前为止，在成千上万甚至数百万次的人类交流中，还没有发现任何该模型无法处理的例子；而且它也很严谨，因为它仅限于简单的算术考虑。

The best way to understand the ‘transactional viewpoint’ is to ask: ‘What would a one- or two- or three-year-old child do that would correspond to this grownup’s behavior?’

要理解“交易视角”，最好的方法是问：“一个一岁、两岁或三岁的孩子会做什么来对应这个成年人的行为？”

C • Time Structuring

C • 时间结构

It is also possible to classify long series of transactions, extending even to a whole lifetime, so that significant human social behavior, both short term and long term, can be predicted. Such chains of transactions take place, even when they yield little instinctual satisfaction, because most people become very uneasy when they are faced with a period of unstructured time; hence, they find cocktail parties, for example, less boring than being by themselves. The need to structure time is based on three drives or hungers. The first is stimulus or sensation hunger . Far from trying to avoid stimulating situations, as some people have claimed, most organisms, including human beings, seek them out. The need for sensation is the reason why roller coasters make money and why prisoners will do almost anything to avoid solitary confinement. The second drive is recognition hunger , the quest for special kinds of sensations which can only be supplied by another human being, or in some cases, by other animals. 7 That is why milk is not enough for baby monkeys and human infants; they also need the sound and smell and warmth and touch of mothering or else they wither away, just as grownups do if there is no one to say Hello to them. The third hunger is structure hunger , which is why groups tend to grow into organizations, and why time-structurers are among the most sought after and the most highly rewarded members of any society.

也可以对持续一生的长期交易序列进行分类，从而预测重要的人类社会行为，包括短期和长期行为。即使这类交易链带来的本能满足感微乎其微，它们仍然会发生，因为大多数人在面对一段无序的时间时会感到非常不安；因此，例如，他们觉得鸡尾酒会比独处更有趣。对时间进行结构化的需求基于三种驱动力或欲望。第一种是刺激或感觉的渴望。大多数生物，包括人类，并非像某些人声称的那样试图避免刺激性情境，而是会主动寻求刺激。对感觉的需求正是过山车盈利的原因，也是囚犯会竭尽全力避免单独监禁的原因。第二种驱动力是认同的渴望，即寻求只能由其他人，或者在某些情况下，由其他动物提供的特殊感觉。这就是为什么母乳对幼猴和人类婴儿来说不够的原因；他们也需要母爱的声音、气味、温暖和抚触，否则就会像成年人一样，如果没有人跟他们打招呼，就会逐渐凋零。第三种渴望是结构渴望，这就是为什么群体往往会发展成组织，以及为什么时间管理者是任何社会中最受欢迎、回报最高的成员之一。

An interesting example combining both stimulus hunger and structure hunger is found among rats raised in a state of sensory deprivation, that is, in complete darkness, or in a constantly lighted white cage with no variation. Later in the lives of these animals, after they had been put in ordinary cages with ‘normal’ rats, it was found that they would go to food in a maze if it was placed on a checkerboard, but they would not go to food if it was placed on a simple background. Normally raised rats would go to the food regardless of the background. This showed that the hunger of the deprived rats for a structured stimulus was more important than their hunger for food. The experimenters concluded that the need for structured stimuli (or as they put it, for ‘perceptual experience’) may involve biological processes just as basic as food hunger, and that the effects of early sensory deprivation may persist throughout life in the form of a strong attraction to complicated stimuli. 8

一个有趣的例子结合了刺激渴求和结构渴求，那就是在感觉剥夺状态下饲养的大鼠。这些大鼠要么完全生活在黑暗中，要么生活在始终保持光照的白色笼子里，没有任何变化。后来，当这些大鼠被放回普通笼子里与“正常”大鼠一起饲养时，研究人员发现，如果迷宫中的食物放在棋盘格图案上，它们会去吃；但如果食物放在简单的背景上，它们则不会去吃。而正常饲养的大鼠无论背景如何都会去吃食物。这表明，感觉剥夺的大鼠对结构化刺激的渴求比对食物的渴求更为重要。实验人员得出结论，对结构化刺激（或者如他们所说，对“感知体验”）的需求可能涉及与食物渴求同样基本的生物过程，并且早期感觉剥夺的影响可能会以对复杂刺激的强烈偏好的形式持续终生。

There are four basic classifications for the short-term structuring of time in human social behavior, with two limiting cases. Thus, if two or more people are in a room together, they have six possible kinds of social behavior to choose from. At one extreme the limiting case is withdrawal , in which the people do not overtly communicate with each other. This may occur in such diverse situations as a subway train or a therapy group of withdrawn schizophrenics. Next to withdrawal, in which each individual remains wrapped in his own thoughts, the safest form of social action is rituals . These are highly stylized interchanges which may be informal or may be formalized into ceremonies which are completely predictable. The transactions which make up rituals convey little information, but are more in the nature of signs of mutual recognition. The units of a ritual are called strokes , by analogy with the way in which infants are recognized by their mothers. Rituals are programed from outside by tradition and social custom.

人类社会行为中，短期时间结构可分为四种基本类型，并存在两种极端情况。因此，如果两个人或更多人身处同一房间，他们可以选择六种不同的社会行为。极端情况之一是退缩，即人们之间不进行公开交流。这种情况可能发生在各种不同的情境中，例如地铁车厢或精神分裂症患者的治疗小组。除了退缩（每个人都沉浸在自己的思绪中）之外，最安全的社会行为形式是仪式。仪式是高度程式化的交流，可以是非正式的，也可以是完全可预测的正式仪式。构成仪式的互动传递的信息很少，更像是相互认可的标志。仪式的基本单元被称为“抚摸”，类似于母亲识别婴儿的方式。仪式是由传统和社会习俗从外部设定的。

The next safest forms of social action are called activities , what is commonly called work , in which the transactions are programed by the material that is being worked with, whether it be wood and concrete, or problems in arithmetic. Work transactions are typically Adult-to-Adult, oriented toward the external reality – that is, the subject of the activity. Next in order are pastimes , which are not as stylized and predictable as rituals, but have a certain repetitive quality and are in the nature of multiple-choice, sentence-completion interchanges, such as take place at cocktail parties where people do not know each other very well. Pastimes are largely socially programed by talking about acceptable subjects in acceptable ways, but individual notes may creep in, leading to the next form of social action, which is called games .

次要的安全社交行为形式被称为活动，也就是我们常说的“工作”。在这些工作中，互动内容由所使用的材料决定，无论是木材、混凝土，还是算术题。工作中的互动通常是成人之间的交流，面向外部现实——也就是活动的主题。接下来是消遣，它不像仪式那样程式化和可预测，但具有一定的重复性，类似于选择题或填空题之类的互动，例如在不太熟悉的鸡尾酒会上进行的那种。消遣在很大程度上是通过以恰当的方式谈论恰当的话题来构建的，但个人的私下交流也可能悄然发生，从而引出下一种社交行为形式——游戏。

Games are sets of ulterior transactions, repetitive in nature, with a well-defined psychological payoff. Since an ulterior transaction means that the agent pretends to be doing one thing while he is really doing something else, all games involve a con. But a con only works if there is a weakness it can hook into, a handle or ‘gimmick’ to get hold of in the respondent, such as fear, greed, sentimentality, or irritability. After the ‘mark’ is hooked, the player pulls some sort of switch in order to get his payoff. The switch is followed by a moment of confusion or crossup while the mark tries to figure out what has happened to him. Then both players collect their payoffs as the game ends. The payoff, which is mutual, consists of feelings (not necessarily similar) which the game arouses in both the agent and the respondent. Unless a set of transactions has these four features, it is not a game – that is, the transactions must be ulterior so that there is a con, and the con must be followed by a switch, a crossup, and a payoff. This can be represented by a formula.

博弈是一系列重复性的、带有明确心理回报的秘密交易。由于秘密交易意味着行为者假装做一件事，而实际上却在做另一件事，因此所有博弈都包含欺骗。但欺骗只有在找到可以利用的弱点，找到可以抓住的把柄或“伎俩”时才能奏效，例如恐惧、贪婪、感性或易怒。在“目标”上钩后，玩家会采取某种手段来获取回报。在“目标”试图弄清发生了什么事之前，会有一段混乱或困惑的时期。然后，随着博弈结束，双方玩家都获得了各自的回报。这种回报是相互的，它包含博弈在行为者和目标玩家身上激起的感受（不一定相同）。除非一组交易具备这四个特征，否则它就不是博弈——也就是说，这些交易必须是别有用心的，包含欺骗行为，而欺骗行为之后必须有交换、交叉和收益。这可以用一个公式来表示。

C + G = R → S → X → P (Formula G)

C + G = R → S → X → P（公式 G）

C+G means that the con hooks into a gimmick, so that the respondent responds (R). The player then pulls the switch (S), and that is followed by a moment of confusion or crossup (X), after which both players collect their payoffs (P). Whatever fits this formula is a game, and whatever does not fit it is not a game.

C+G 指的是骗子先用花招引诱受骗者做出反应 (R)。然后骗子拉动开关 (S)，之后会产生短暂的混乱或误会 (X)，最后双方玩家各自获得收益 (P)。符合这个公式的就是游戏，不符合这个公式的就不是游戏。

For example, the mere fact of repetition or persistence does not constitute a game. Thus, in a therapy group, if a scared patient repeatedly asks the therapist for reassurance every week (‘Tell me I’ll get better, doctor’) and when he receives it, says ‘Thank you’, that is not necessarily an ulterior transaction. The patient has stated his need frankly and has had it gratified, and does not take advantage of the situation in any way, but gives a courteous response. These transactions, therefore, do not constitute a game but an operation, and operations, no matter how often they are repeated, must be distinguished from games, just as rational procedures must be distinguished from rituals.

例如，重复或坚持本身并不构成游戏。因此，在治疗小组中，如果一位恐惧的患者每周都反复向治疗师寻求安慰（“医生，告诉我我会好起来的”），并在得到安慰后说“谢谢”，这并不一定是一种别有用心的交易。患者坦诚地表达了自己的需求并得到了满足，并没有以任何方式利用这种情况，而是礼貌地回应。因此，这些互动并非游戏，而是一种操作。操作，无论重复多少次，都必须与游戏区分开来，正如理性程序必须与仪式区分开来一样。

If another patient, however, asks the therapist for reassurance, and upon receiving it, uses the response to make the therapist look stupid, that constitutes a game. For example, a patient asked: ‘Do you think I’ll get better, doctor?’ and the sentimental therapist replied ‘Of course you will.’ At that point the patient revealed her ulterior motive in asking the question. Instead of saying ‘Thank you’, as in a straight transaction, she pulled the switch with: ‘What makes you think you know everything?’ This reply crossed the therapist up and threw him off balance for a moment, which is what the patient wanted to do. Then the game ended, the patient feeling elated at having conned the therapist, and he feeling frustrated; and those were the payoffs.

然而，如果另一位病人向治疗师寻求安慰，并在得到肯定的回答后，利用这个回答让治疗师显得愚蠢，这就构成了一场游戏。例如，一位病人问：“医生，您觉得我会好起来吗？” 而那位感性的治疗师回答说：“当然会。” 这时，病人暴露了她提问的真正目的。她没有像平常那样说“谢谢”，而是反问道：“您凭什么认为自己什么都懂？” 这句话让治疗师措手不及，一时不知所措，这正是病人想要达到的目的。游戏结束，病人因戏弄了治疗师而沾沾自喜，而治疗师则感到沮丧；这就是这场游戏的收益。

This game followed Formula G precisely. The con was the original question, and the gimmick was the therapist’s sentimentality. When the con hooked into the gimmick, he responded in the way she expected. Then she pulled the switch, causing a crossup, after which each collected a payoff. So

这个游戏完全遵循了G公式。骗局在于最初的问题，而噱头在于治疗师的感性。当骗子被噱头吸引时，他的回答正如她所预料的那样。然后她拉动开关，制造出交叉局面，之后双方各得一份回报。

C + H = R → S → X → P

C + H = R → S → X → P

This is a simple example of the game called, from the patient’s side, ‘Slug Him,’ or ‘Whammy,’ and from the therapist’s side, ‘I’m Only Trying To Help You.’ Colloquially, the payoff is called a trading stamp . ‘Good’ feelings are spoken of as ‘gold’ trading stamps and distressing feelings are said to be ‘brown’ or ‘blue’ trading stamps. In this case the patient got a counterfeit-gold trading stamp for a counterfeit triumph or success, and the therapist got a brown one, which is not unusual.

这是一个简单的例子，患者称之为“揍他”或“打他”，治疗师称之为“我只是想帮你”。通俗地说，游戏的奖励被称为“交易印章”。“好”的感觉被比作“金色”的交易印章，而“坏”的感觉则被比作“棕色”或“蓝色”的交易印章。在这个例子中，患者因为虚假的胜利或成功而获得了一张假的金色交易印章，而治疗师则获得了一张棕色的交易印章，这并不罕见。

Each game has a slogan or motto by which it can be recognized, such as ‘I’m Only Trying To Help You.’ This slogan is colloquially called a ‘sweatshirt’. Usually the name of the game is taken from its slogan.

每款游戏都有一个标志性的口号或标语，例如“我只是想帮你”。这句口号俗称“卫衣”。游戏名称通常取自其口号。

Beyond games lies the other limiting case of what can take place between people, which is called intimacy . Bilateral intimacy is defined as a candid, game-free relationship, with mutual free giving and receiving and without exploitation. Intimacy can be one-sided, since one party may be candid and freely giving, while the other may be devious and exploitative.

游戏之外，人与人之间可能存在的另一种极端情况，即亲密关系。双向亲密关系被定义为一种坦诚、不带任何游戏成分的关系，双方自由地付出和接受，且不存在任何剥削。亲密关系也可能是单向的，因为一方可能坦诚且慷慨，而另一方则可能狡诈且具有剥削性。

Sexual activities offer examples which cover this whole spectrum of social behavior. It is evident that they can take place in withdrawal, that they can be part of a ritualistic ceremony, or that they can be all in a day’s work, a pastime for a rainy day, a game of mutual exploitation, or acts of real intimacy.

性行为提供了涵盖社会行为方方面面的例证。显而易见，性行为可以发生在隐秘的角落，可以成为某种仪式的一部分，也可以是日常琐事、雨天消遣、相互利用的游戏，或是真正亲密的行为。

D • Scripts

D • 脚本

The above forms of social action are ways of structuring time with the object of avoiding boredom and at the same time getting the greatest possible satisfaction out of each situation. Each person, in addition, has a preconscious life plan, or script, by which he structures longer periods of time – months, years, or his whole life – filling them with ritual activities, pastimes, and games which further the script while giving him immediate satisfaction, usually interrupted by periods of withdrawal and sometimes by episodes of intimacy. Scripts are usually based on childlike illusions which may persist throughout a whole lifetime; but in more sensitive, perceptive, and intelligent people these illusions dissolve one by one, leading to the various life crises described by Erikson. 9 Among these crises are the adolescent reappraisal of parents; the protests, often bizarre, of middle age; and the emergence of philosophy after that. Sometimes, however, overly desperate attempts to maintain the illusions in later life lead to depression or spiritualism, while the abandonment of all illusions may lead to despair.

上述社会行为形式都是为了避免无聊，同时尽可能从每种情境中获得满足感而构建时间的方式。此外，每个人都有一个潜意识的生活计划或脚本，以此来构建较长的时间周期——数月、数年，甚至一生——并用仪式性活动、消遣和游戏来填充这些时间，这些活动、消遣和游戏既能推进脚本的运行，又能带来即时的满足感，通常会被一段段的退缩期，有时也会被亲密时刻所打断。这些脚本通常基于孩童般的幻想，这些幻想可能会持续一生；但在更敏感、更有洞察力和更聪明的人身上，这些幻想会逐一瓦解，从而导致埃里克森所描述的各种人生危机。这些危机包括青少年时期对父母的重新评价；中年时期常常显得怪异的抗议；以及之后哲学的兴起。然而，有时，在晚年过后，过于拼命地维持幻想会导致抑郁或唯灵论，而放弃所有幻想则可能导致绝望。

Time structuring is an objective term for the existential problem of what to do after saying Hello. What follows is the attempt to answer this question by observing what it is that people actually do after they say Hello, and by inserting a few hints of what might be. This can be profitably done by investigating the nature of life scripts and the course of their development. 10

时间结构是一个客观术语，用来描述“打招呼之后该做什么”这一存在主义问题。以下内容将尝试通过观察人们在打招呼之后实际采取的行动，并给出一些可能的线索，来回答这个问题。研究生活脚本的本质及其发展过程，将有助于我们更有效地完成这项工作。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

6 ‘The transaction, or exchange, seems the central focus toward which various social scientists have been gravitating. I could hardly agree more with Blau’s position that exchange is both the most obvious point of common reference for all social science and the most likely building block with which (by adding the cement of communications) we can put together the analysis of more complex social relationships and structures.’ From Alfred Kuhn’s review of Blau, Peter M. Exchange and Power in Social Life . Wiley, New York, 1964; in Science 147:137, January 8, 1965.

6 “交易或交换似乎是众多社会科学家关注的核心焦点。我完全赞同布劳的观点，即交换既是所有社会科学最显而易见的共同参照点，也是最有可能的构建模块，通过添加沟通这一要素，我们可以将更复杂的社会关系和结构分析融会贯通。” 摘自阿尔弗雷德·库恩对彼得·M·布劳《社会生活中的交换与权力》（Wiley出版社，纽约，1964年；《科学》杂志，1965年1月8日，第147卷，第137页）一书的书评。

9 Erikson, E. H. Identity and the Life Cycle . International Universities Press, New York, 1959.

10 For a systematic critique of transactional analysis theory, see Shapiro, S. S. ‘Critique of Eric Berne’s Contributions to Subself Theory’. Psychological Reports 25: 283–296, 1969.

10 有关交互分析理论的系统性批判，请参阅 Shapiro, S. S.“对 Eric Berne 对自我理论的贡献的批判”。《心理学报告》25: 283–296, 1969。

fn1 This can be verified by drawing each one separately or writing them out: PP–PA, PP–PC, PA–PP, PA–PC, and so on down to CC–CA, after which some of them can be matched with examples from clinical practice or daily life.

fn1 这可以通过分别画出每个字母或写出它们来验证：PP–PA、PP–PC、PA–PP、PA–PC，以此类推，直到 CC–CA，之后可以将其中一些与临床实践或日常生活中的例子进行匹配。

fn2 This can be worked out as follows. Take the nine complementary transactions from Figure 2B , and add the 72 crossed transactions. For each one of these 81 possibilities at the social or overt level, there are the same 81 possibilities at the psychological or covert level. Again, many of these combinations can be found in clinical and personal situations by someone who has learned to recognize ego state in action.

fn2 这可以按如下方式计算。取图 2B 中的九个互补交易，再加上 72 个交叉交易。对于社交或公开层面的这 81 种可能性中的每一种，在心理或隐蔽层面都存在相同的 81 种可能性。同样，对于那些已经学会识别自我状态的人来说，在临床和个人情境中都可以找到许多这样的组合。

fn3 (AA–AA)+(CC–CC) (as in Figure 4B ), (AA–AA)+(PP–PP), (AA–AA) +(PC–CP), (PP–PP)+(CC–CC), (AA–AA)+(CA–CA), (AA–AA)+(PA–PA). Others enter in special situations such as child-rearing, teaching, or child psychiatry, where the overt level may be complementary (PC–CP, CC–CC) or crossed (AA–CP, Type I), for example, while the covert level may be any of the 81 possibilities. In order to visualize these, it is best to draw the transactional diagrams and then translate them into actual situations.

fn3 (AA–AA)+(CC–CC)（如图 4B 所示），(AA–AA)+(PP–PP)，(AA–AA)+(PC–CP)，(PP–PP)+(CC–CC)，(AA–AA)+(CA–CA)，(AA–AA)+(PA–PA)。其他情况则出现在特殊情境中，例如育儿、教学或儿童精神病学，在这些情境中，显性层面可能是互补的（例如 PC–CP、CC–CC）或交叉的（例如 AA–CP、I 型），而隐性层面可能是 81 种可能性中的任何一种。为了更好地理解这些，最好先绘制交互图，然后将其转化为实际情境。

#↩

PART II

第二部分

Parental Programing

家长指导

#↩

CHAPTER THREE

第三章

Human Destiny

人类的命运

A • Life Plans

A • 人生规划

The destiny of every human being is decided by what goes on inside his skull when he is confronted with what goes on outside his skull. Each person designs his own life. Freedom gives him the power to carry out his own designs, and power gives him the freedom to interfere with the designs of others. Even if the outcome is decided by men he has never met or germs he will never see, his last words and the words on his gravestone will cry out his striving. If by great misfortune he dies in dust and silence, only those who know him best will get the slogan right, and all outside the private chambers of friendship, marriage, and medicine will see him wrong. In most cases he has spent his life deceiving the world, and usually himself as well. We will hear more about these illusions later.

每个人的命运都取决于他面对外界环境时内心的想法。每个人都在设计自己的人生。自由赋予他实现自己计划的力量，而权力又赋予他干预他人计划的自由。即便最终的结局是由他素未谋面的人或他永远不会见到的病菌决定的，他临终的遗言和墓碑上的铭文也会彰显他的奋斗。如果他不幸默默无闻地死去，只有最了解他的人才能真正理解他的人生格言，而所有身处友谊、婚姻和医学之外的人都会认为他错了。在大多数情况下，他的一生都在欺骗世界，通常也欺骗自己。我们稍后会详细探讨这些幻象。

Each person decides in early childhood how he will live and how he will die, and that plan, which he carries in his head wherever he goes, is called his script. His trivial behavior may be decided by reason, but his important decisions are already made: what kind of person he will marry, how many children he will have, what kind of bed he will die in, and who will be there when he does. It may not be what he wants, but it is what he wants it to be.

每个人在幼年时期就决定了自己的人生道路，包括如何生活和如何离世。这个计划，无论走到哪里都铭刻在心，被称为他的“剧本”。他琐碎的行为或许出于理性，但重要的决定早已注定：他会娶什么样的人，生几个孩子，死在什么样的床上，以及谁会在他临终时陪伴在他身边。这或许并非他真正想要的，但却是他希望看到的结局。

MAGDA

玛格达

Magda was a devoted wife and mother, but when her youngest boy got very sick, she realized to her horror that in the back of her mind was an idea, a picture, or perhaps even a wish that the much-loved son would die. It reminded her of the time when her husband was overseas with the army and the same thing had happened. She was haunted by an eerie wish that he would get killed. In both cases she pictured herself in terrible grief and affliction. This would be her cross to bear, and everyone would admire the way she bore it.

玛格达是一位贤惠的妻子和慈爱的母亲，但当她的小儿子重病时，她惊恐地意识到，在她内心深处，竟有一个念头、一幅画面，甚至是一个愿望——她希望自己心爱的儿子死去。这让她想起丈夫在海外服役时也发生过类似的事情。她一直被一个诡异的愿望所困扰，希望他战死沙场。在这两种情况下，她都想象自己身处巨大的悲痛和痛苦之中。她相信这将是她必须承受的十字架，而她承受这一切的方式，将令所有人敬佩。

Q. What would happen after that?

问：之后会发生什么？

A. I never got that far. I’d be free, and then I could do what I wanted to. Start over.

A. 我从未走到那一步。那样我就自由了，然后我就可以做我想做的事，重新开始。

When Magda was in grade school she had had many sexual adventures with her classmates, and the guilt of that had been with her ever since. The death of her son or husband would be a punishment or an expiation for this, and would free her from her mother’s curse. She would no longer feel like an outcast. People would exclaim: ‘Isn’t she courageous!’ and acknowledge her as a fullfledged member of the human race.

玛格达小学时就和同学有过许多性冒险，这件事一直让她背负着沉重的罪恶感。她希望儿子或丈夫的死能成为对这段往事的惩罚或赎罪，让她摆脱母亲的诅咒。她将不再感到自己被排斥在外。人们会惊叹：“她真勇敢！”并承认她是人类社会中的一员。

Throughout most of her life she had had this tragic cinema planned out and pictured in her mind. It was the third act of her life drama, or script, as written in her childhood. Act I: Sexual Guilt and Confusion. Act II: Mother’s Curse. Act III: Expiation. Act IV: Release, and a New Life. But in reality she was leading a very conventional life, in accordance with the teachings of her parents, and doing what she could to keep her loved ones healthy and happy. This was counter to the plot of her script – a counterscript – and was certainly not as dramatic or exciting.

在她生命的大部分时间里，这出悲剧电影的情节都已在她脑海中构思和呈现。这是她人生剧本的第三幕，或者说是她童年时写就的剧本。第一幕：性方面的罪恶感和困惑。第二幕：母亲的诅咒。第三幕：赎罪。第四幕：解脱，以及新生。但实际上，她过着非常循规蹈矩的生活，遵循着父母的教诲，尽其所能地让所爱之人健康快乐。这与她剧本的情节——一个反剧本——背道而驰，当然也不像剧本里那样充满戏剧性和刺激。

A script is an ongoing life plan formed in early childhood under parental pressure. It is the psychological force which propels the person toward his destiny, regardless of whether he fights it or says it is his own free will.

人生剧本是指在童年早期父母压力下形成的、持续发展的人生规划。它是一种心理力量，无论个体是否抗拒，或者声称这是出于自由意志，都会驱使他走向自己的命运。

It is not our intention in this book to reduce all human behavior or all human life to a formula. Quite the contrary. A real person may be defined as one who acts spontaneously in a rational and trustworthy way with decent consideration for others. One who follows a formula is a not-real, or unreal, person. But since these seem to constitute the bulk of humanity, it is necessary to try to learn something about them.

本书的目的并非将所有人类行为或人生简化为某种公式。恰恰相反。一个真正的人可以定义为：能够自发地、理性地、值得信赖地行事，并给予他人应有的体谅。而那些墨守成规的人，则不是真正的人，或者说是虚假的人。但既然后者似乎构成了人类的主体，我们就有必要尝试去了解他们。

DELLA

来自

Della was a neighbor of Magda’s, in her late twenties, and led much the same kind of domestic life. But her husband, a salesman, traveled a lot. Sometimes when he was away Della would start out drinking and end up far away from home. She ‘blacked out’ these episodes, and as is common in such cases, she knew what happened only because she would find herself in strange places with the names and telephone numbers of strange men in her purse when she came to. This not only horrified her, but terrified her, since it meant that she could ruin her life some day by picking up an indiscreet or evil man.

黛拉是玛格达的邻居，二十多岁，过着和玛格达类似的家庭生活。但她的丈夫是推销员，经常出差。有时丈夫不在家，黛拉会开始喝酒，结果不知不觉就到了很远的地方。她对这些事“断片”了，而这种情况很常见，她之所以知道发生了什么，是因为醒来后发现自己身处陌生的地方，钱包里装着一些陌生男人的姓名和电话号码。这不仅让她感到恐惧，也让她感到害怕，因为这意味着她将来可能会因为和一个不谨慎或邪恶的男人交往而毁掉自己的人生。

Scripts are planned early in childhood, so if this was a script, it must have had its origins there. Della’s mother died when she was little and her father was away all day, working. Della didn’t get along very well with the other kids in school. She felt inferior, and led a lonely life. But late in childhood she discovered a way to be popular. Like Magda, she offered herself for sexy play to a gang of little boys. She had never thought of the connection between those school days in the hayloft and her current behavior. But all along in her head she was carrying the outline of her life drama. Act I: The setup. Fun and Guilt in a Hayloft. Act II: An outbreak of script. Fun and Guilt While Drunk and Irresponsible. Act III: The payoff. Denunciation and Ruin. She loses everything – husband, children, and position. Act IV: The final release. Suicide. Then everybody feels sorry and forgives her.

剧本的构思往往在童年早期就已形成，所以如果这真的是个剧本，那它的雏形一定就源于此。黛拉的母亲在她很小的时候就去世了，父亲整天在外工作。黛拉在学校里和其他孩子相处得并不融洽。她感到自卑，过着孤独的生活。但在童年后期，她找到了一种让自己受欢迎的方法。和玛格达一样，她主动向一群小男孩献身，进行性游戏。她从未想过自己在干草堆里的日子和现在的行为之间有什么联系。但其实，她的脑海里一直都萦绕着她人生剧本的轮廓。第一幕：铺垫。干草堆里的乐趣与愧疚。第二幕：剧本爆发。醉酒和不负责任时的乐趣与愧疚。第三幕：高潮。谴责与毁灭。她失去了一切——丈夫、孩子和地位。第四幕：最终的解脱。自杀。然后，所有人都感到惋惜，原谅了她。

Both Magda and Della lived in their peaceful counterscripts with a feeling of impending doom. The script was a tragic drama which would bring them release and reconciliation. The difference was that Magda was waiting patiently for an act of God to fulfill her destiny – salvation; while Della, propelled by the compulsion of an inner demon, was hurrying impatiently toward hers – damnation, death, and forgiveness. Thus, from the same beginnings (‘sexual delinquency’) these two women were moving by diverse means to different ends.

玛格达和德拉都生活在各自平静的人生剧本中，却都隐隐感到末日将至。她们的剧本都是一出悲剧，最终将带给她们解脱与和解。不同之处在于，玛格达耐心地等待着上帝的旨意来实现她的命运——救赎；而德拉则被内心恶魔的驱使，急切地奔向她的命运——诅咒、死亡和宽恕。因此，尽管起点相同（“性犯罪”），这两个女人却以截然不同的方式走向了不同的结局。

The psychotherapist is sitting in his office like a wise man and is getting paid to do something about all this. Both Magda and Della will be free if somebody dies, but his job is to find a better way to free them. He leaves his office and walks down the street past the stockbroker’s, the taxi stand, and the saloon. Nearly everybody he sees is waiting for a Big Killing. In the grocery store a woman is shouting at her daughter: ‘How many times have I got to tell you not to touch that?’ while somebody admires her little boy: ‘Isn’t he cute!’ When he gets to the hospital, a paranoid says: ‘How do I get out of here, doctor?’ A depressive says: ‘What am I living for?’ and a schizophrenic answers: ‘Don’t diet, liveit. I’m not really that stupid.’ That’s what they all said yesterday. They’re stuck, while the ones on the outside are still hoping. ‘Shall we increase his dose of medication?’ asks a medical student. Dr Q turns to the schizophrenic and looks him in the eye. The schizophrenic looks back at him. ‘Shall we increase your medication?’ asks Dr Q. The boy thinks a while and then replies, ‘No.’ Dr Q puts out his hand and says: ‘Hello.’ The schizophrenic shakes hands with him and says: ‘Hello.’ Then they both turn to the medical student, and Dr Q says: ‘Hello.’ The medical student looks flustered, but five years later, at a psychiatric meeting, he walks up to Dr Q and says: ‘Hi, Dr Q. Hello.’

心理治疗师像个智者一样坐在办公室里，拿着薪水，为这一切做些什么。如果有人死了，玛格达和德拉就能获得自由，但他的工作是找到更好的方法让她们解脱。他离开办公室，沿着街道走去，经过股票经纪人、出租车站和酒吧。他看到的几乎每个人都在等待一场大屠杀。在杂货店里，一个女人冲着女儿大喊：“我跟你说过多少遍了，别碰那个？”与此同时，有人欣赏着自己的小男孩：“他真可爱！”当他来到医院时，一个妄想症患者问：“医生，我该怎么离开这里？”一个抑郁症患者问：“我活着是为了什么？”一个精神分裂症患者回答：“别节食，好好生活。我没那么傻。”昨天他们都是这么说的。他们被困住了，而那些在外面的人仍然抱有希望。 “要不要增加他的药量？”一位医学生问道。Q医生转向那位精神分裂症患者，看着他的眼睛。患者也看着他。“要不要增加你的药量？”Q医生问道。男孩想了一会儿，然后回答说：“不用。”Q医生伸出手说：“你好。”精神分裂症患者和他握手，也说：“你好。”然后他们俩都转向那位医学生，Q医生说：“你好。”医学生显得有些慌乱，但五年后，在一次精神病学会议上，他走到Q医生面前说：“你好，Q医生。你好。”

MARY

玛丽

‘Some day I’m going to open a nursery school, get married four times, make a lot of money on the stock market, and become a famous surgeon,’ said drunken Mary.

“总有一天我会开办一所幼儿园，结四次婚，在股市上赚很多钱，然后成为一名著名的外科医生，”醉醺醺的玛丽说道。

This is not a script. First, she didn’t get any of these ideas from her parents. They hated children, didn’t believe in divorce, thought the stock market was too speculative, and that surgeons charged too much. Second, her personality was not suited to any of these things. She was uptight with children, frigidly cool with men, scared of the market, and her hands shook from drinking. Thirdly, she had long ago decided to be a realtor during the day, and an alcoholic evenings and weekends. Fourthly, none of those projects really turned her on. They were more expressions of what she couldn’t do rather than of what she could. And fifthly, it was obvious to anyone who heard her that she wasn’t ever going to do any of them.

这不是剧本。首先，她的这些想法都不是来自父母。他们讨厌孩子，不相信离婚，认为股市投机性太强，而且外科医生收费过高。其次，她的性格根本不适合做这些事。她对孩子很紧张，对男人冷若冰霜，害怕股市，而且因为酗酒，手还会发抖。第三，她早就决定白天做房地产经纪人，晚上和周末则沉溺于酒精。第四，这些项目都无法真正激发她的兴趣。它们与其说是展现了她的能力，不如说是表达了她做不到的事情。第五，任何听过她说话的人都知道，她根本不可能去做这些事。

A script requires (1) Parental directives. (2) A suitable personality development. (3) A childhood decision. (4) A real turn-on to a particular method of success or failure, and (5) A convincing attitude (or a credible stance, as they say nowadays).

剧本需要满足以下条件：（1）父母的指示；（2）合适的性格发展；（3）童年时期的决定；（4）对某种成功或失败方式的真正兴趣；以及（5）令人信服的态度（或者用现在的话来说，可信的立场）。

In this book we will consider what is known so far about the script apparatus, and what can be done to change it.

本书将探讨目前已知的关于文字装置的知识，以及如何对其进行改进。

B • On Stage and Off Stage

B • 台上台下

Theatrical scripts are intuitively derived from life scripts, and a good way to start is to consider the connections and similarities between them. 1

戏剧剧本往往源于生活剧本，一个好的切入点是思考二者之间的联系和相似之处。

1. Both are based on a limited number of themes, the best known of which is the Oedipal tragedy. The others can likewise be found in Greek drama and Greek mythology. Other people had the rude dithyrambs and lewd orgies of the ancient priestly dramas, but the Greeks and Hebrews were the first to distill out and record the more homely and recognizable patterns of human living. Human life, it is true, is full of epic Agon, Pathos, Threnos, and Theophany, as in the Primal Rituals, but these are much easier to understand and contemplate if they are played out in ordinary language, Bam! and Wow! with a man and a maid in the moonlight under the laurel tree when along comes Bigmouth, whoever he or she may be. Reduced to this level by the Greek poets, the life of every human being is already charted in Bulfinch or Graves. fn1 If the gods smile on him, he will be a going concern. But if they frown he becomes something else, and if he wants to remove the curse or live more comfortably with it, he becomes a patient.

1. 两者都基于有限的主题，其中最著名的当属俄狄浦斯悲剧。其他主题同样可以在希腊戏剧和希腊神话中找到。其他民族也有古代祭司戏剧中粗俗的酒神颂歌和淫乱的狂欢，但希腊人和希伯来人率先提炼并记录了更为朴实、易于理解的人类生活模式。诚然，人类生活充满了史诗般的对抗、悲怆、激情和神显，正如原始仪式中所展现的那样，但如果用日常语言来演绎，比如在月光下的月桂树下，一个男人和一个女仆突然出现（无论他是谁），那么这些就更容易理解和思考了。经希腊诗人简化，每个人的生活都已在布尔芬奇或格雷夫斯的著作中有所描绘。 fn1 如果神明眷顾，他便能顺风顺水；但如果神明惩罚，他便会变成另一种模样；如果他想要摆脱诅咒或更安稳地与诅咒共存，他便会沦为病人。

For the transactional script analyst, as for the play analyst, this means that if you know the plot and the character, you know what his outcome will be, unless some changes can be made. For example, it is clear to the psychotherapist, as to the drama critic, that Medea had her mind made up to kill her children, unless someone could talk her out of it; and it should be equally clear to both of them that if she had gone to her treatment group that week, the whole thing would never have happened.

对于剧本分析师而言，正如对于戏剧分析师而言一样，这意味着如果你了解剧情和人物，你就能知道他的结局，除非做出一些改变。例如，对于心理治疗师和戏剧评论家来说，很明显，美狄亚已经下定决心要杀死她的孩子，除非有人能劝阻她；而且他们都应该同样清楚地认识到，如果她那周去了治疗小组，这一切就不会发生。

2. Not only do certain life courses have predictable outcomes if they are allowed to go on as they are, but a certain dialogue of specific words spoken a certain way is necessary to establish the proper motivation for the outcome. In both the theater and in real life, the cues have to be memorized and spoken just right so that the other people will respond in a way that justifies and advances the action. If the hero changes his lines and his ego state, the other people respond differently. This throws the whole script off, and that is the aim of therapeutic script analysis. If Hamlet begins to use lines from Abie’s Irish Rose , Ophelia has to change her lines, too, in order to make sense of it, and the whole performance will proceed differently. The two of them might then take off together instead of skulking around the castle – a bad play, but probably a better life. 2

2. 某些人生轨迹不仅会按照既定的方式发展，并产生可预测的结果，而且特定的对话，以特定的方式说出特定的词语，对于确立结果的合理动机至关重要。无论是在戏剧舞台上还是在现实生活中，这些提示都必须被牢记，并且必须恰到好处地表达出来，才能使其他人做出符合剧情发展并推动情节发展的反应。如果主人公改变了台词和自我状态，其他人的反应也会随之改变。这会打乱整个剧本的节奏，而这正是治疗性剧本分析的目的所在。如果哈姆雷特开始引用艾比的《爱尔兰玫瑰》中的台词，奥菲莉娅也必须改变她的台词才能理解，整个演出的走向也会随之改变。两人或许会一起离开，而不是在城堡里偷偷摸摸地徘徊——虽然这出戏可能不太好，但或许能让他们拥有更好的生活。

3. A script has to be rehearsed and rewritten before it is ready for the most dramatic performance. In the theater there are readings, rewrites, rehearsals, and tryouts before the big time. A life script starts off in childhood in a primitive form called the protocol . Here the other players are limited to parents and brothers and sisters; or in an institution or foster home, to tablemates and those in charge. These all play their roles rather rigidly because every family is an institution, and the child does not learn much flexibility from them. As he moves into adolescence, he begins to meet more people. He seeks out those who will play the roles his script requires (they will do it because he plays some role their scripts require). At this time, he rewrites his script to take account of his new environment. The basic plot remains the same, but the action is a little different. In most cases (except for adolescent suicide or murder), this is rehearsal – something like a small-town tryout. Through several such adaptations, he gets it into final form for the biggest production of all – the farewell performance, the final payoff on the script. If it is a ‘good’ one, it takes place at a farewell dinner. If it is a ‘bad’ one, he says good-by from a hospital bed, the door of a prison cell or psychiatric ward, the gallows, or the morgue.

3. 剧本必须经过排练和修改才能最终呈现出最精彩的表演。在剧院里，正式演出前会有剧本朗读、修改、排练和试演。人生剧本始于童年，以一种被称为“规则”的原始形式出现。此时，其他参与者仅限于父母、兄弟姐妹；或者在机构或寄养家庭中，仅限于同桌和监护人。由于每个家庭都像一个机构，孩子很难从中学会灵活变通，所以每个人都相当刻板地扮演着自己的角色。随着进入青春期，孩子开始接触更多的人。他会寻找那些愿意扮演他剧本所需角色的人（他们之所以愿意，是因为他扮演了他们剧本所需的角色）。此时，他会根据新的环境修改自己的剧本。基本情节保持不变，但行动方式略有不同。在大多数情况下（青少年自杀或谋杀除外），这就像排练——类似于小镇的试演。经过多次修改，他最终将剧本定稿，准备进行最重要的演出——告别演出，剧本的最终高潮。如果演出“成功”，演出将在告别晚宴上举行。如果演出“失败”，他将在病床上、监狱牢房或精神病院门口、绞刑架上，或停尸房里道别。

4. Almost every script has roles for ‘good guys’ and ‘bad guys’, and for ‘winners’ and ‘losers.’ What is considered good or bad, 3 and what is a winner or a loser, is something peculiar to each script, but it is very clear that every script has these four characters, sometimes combined in two roles. In a cowboy script, for example, the good guy is a winner and the bad guy is a loser. Good means brave, quick on the draw, honest, and pure; bad may mean cowardly, slow on the draw, crooked, and interested in girls. A winner is someone who survives; a loser is someone who is hanged or gets shot. In a soap opera, a winner is a girl who gets a man; a loser is a girl who loses a man. In a paper-shuffle opera, the winner is the man who gets the best contract or the most proxies; a loser is a man who doesn’t know how to shuffle papers.

4. 几乎每个剧本都有“好人”和“坏人”，以及“赢家”和“输家”。好坏的定义，以及赢家和输家的划分，因剧本而异，但很明显，每个剧本都有这四个角色，有时甚至会合并成两个角色。例如，在西部牛仔剧本中，好人是赢家，坏人是输家。好人意味着勇敢、反应快、诚实、纯洁；坏人则可能意味着胆小、反应慢、狡猾、喜欢女人。赢家是活下来的人；输家是被绞死或枪杀的人。在肥皂剧中，赢家是找到男人的女孩；输家是失去男人的女孩。在政治剧中，赢家是拿到最佳合同或最多代理权的人；输家是不懂政治运作的人。

In script analysis, winners are called ‘princes’ or ‘princesses,’ and losers are called ‘frogs.’ The object of script analysis is to turn frogs into princes and princesses. In order to do this, the therapist has to find out who the good guys and the bad guys are in the patient’s script, and also what kind of a winner he can be. The patient fights being a winner because he is not in treatment for that purpose, but only to be made into a braver loser. This is natural enough, since if he becomes a braver loser, he can follow his script more comfortably, whereas if he becomes a winner he has to throw away all or most of his script and start over, which most people are reluctant to do.

在剧本分析中，赢家被称为“王子”或“公主”，输家被称为“青蛙”。剧本分析的目标是将“青蛙”变成“王子”和“公主”。为了达到这个目的，治疗师必须找出患者剧本中的好人和坏人，以及他能成为什么样的赢家。患者抗拒成为赢家，因为他接受治疗的目的并非如此，而是为了成为一个更勇敢的失败者。这很自然，因为如果他成为一个更勇敢的失败者，他就能更轻松地遵循自己的剧本；而如果他成为赢家，他就必须抛弃全部或大部分剧本，重新开始，而大多数人都不愿意这样做。

5. All scripts, whether in the theater or in real life, are essentially answers to the basic question of human encounter: ‘What do you say after you say Hello?’ The Oedipal drama and the Oedipal life, for example, both hinge entirely on this question. Whenever Oedipus meets an older man, he first says Hello. The next thing he has to say, driven by his script is: ‘Wanna fight?’ If the older man says ‘No,’ Oedipus has nothing further to say to him, and can only stand dumbly wondering whether to talk about the weather, the conduct of the current war, or who is going to win in the Olympic games. The easiest way out is to mumble ‘Pleased to meetcha,’ ‘ Si vales bene est, ego valeo ,’ or ‘Everything in moderation,’ and go on his way. But if the older one says ‘Yes,’ Oedipus answers: ‘Groovy!’ because now he has found his man and he knows what to say next.

5. 所有剧本，无论是戏剧还是现实生活，本质上都是对人际交往基本问题的回答：“打招呼之后该说什么？”例如，俄狄浦斯的戏剧和俄狄浦斯的生活都完全围绕着这个问题展开。每当俄狄浦斯遇到一位长者，他首先都会说“你好”。接下来，按照剧本的指示，他必须说：“想打架吗？”如果长者回答“不想”，俄狄浦斯就无话可说，只能呆呆地站在那里，不知该聊什么，是该聊天气、当前的战争局势，还是奥运会的胜负。最简单的办法是含糊其辞地说“很高兴见到你”、“Si vales bene est, ego valeo”（如果一切顺利，我也会很高兴）或者“凡事适度”，然后继续前行。但如果长者回答“想”，俄狄浦斯就会回答：“太好了！”因为他找到了目标，知道接下来该说什么了。
