6. Life-script scenes have to be set up and motivated ahead of time, just like theatrical scenes. A simple example is running out of gas. This is nearly always set up two or three days in advance by looking at the gauge, ‘planning’ to get gas ‘sometime soon,’ and then not doing it. In fact it is impossible to run out of gas ‘right now’ except in a strange car with a broken gauge. It is nearly always an impending event, a preplanned scene in a loser’s script. Many winners go through a whole lifetime without ever running dry.

6. 人生剧本中的场景必须像戏剧场景一样，提前设置并设定动机。一个简单的例子就是车子没油了。这种情况几乎总是提前两三天就安排好的：看看油表，“计划”着“找个时间”去加油，然后就没去。事实上，除非是在一辆油表坏了的陌生车里，否则“现在”根本不可能没油。这几乎总是一个即将发生的事件，是失败者剧本里预先安排好的场景。许多成功人士一生都不会遇到“没油”的情况。

Life scripts are based on parental programing, which the child seeks out for three reasons. (1) It gives a purpose to life where it might otherwise be wanting. A child does most things for the sake of people, usually his parents. (2) It gives him an acceptable way to structure his time (acceptable, that is, to his parents). (3) People have to be told how to do things. Learning for oneself may be inspiring, but it is not very practical. A man does not become a good pilot by wrecking a few airplanes and learning by his errors. He has to learn through other people’s failures, not his own. A surgeon has to have a teacher, rather than taking out appendixes one after the other to find out all the things that can go wrong. So parents program their children by passing on to them what they have learned, or what they think they have learned. If they are losers, they will pass on their loser’s programing, and if they are winners, then they will pass on that kind of program. The long-term pattern always has a story line. While the outcome is determined for better or for worse by parental programing, the child is often free to select his own plot.

人生剧本基于父母的“编程”，孩子寻求这种“编程”的原因有三点：(1) 它赋予人生意义，弥补了人生的缺失。孩子做大多数事情都是为了别人，通常是父母。(2) 它为孩子提供了一种可接受的时间安排方式（即父母认可的方式）。(3) 人们需要被告知如何做事。自学或许令人鼓舞，但并不实用。一个人不可能通过坠毁几架飞机并从错误中学习而成为一名优秀的飞行员。他必须从他人的失败中学习，而不是从自己的失败中学习。外科医生需要一位老师，而不是一个接一个地切除阑尾来找出所有可能出错的地方。因此，父母通过向孩子传递他们所学到的，或者他们认为自己所学到的东西，来“编程”孩子。如果他们是失败者，他们就会传递失败者的“编程”；如果他们是成功者，他们就会传递成功的“编程”。长期的模式总是有其故事主线的。虽然结局的好坏是由父母的安排决定的，但孩子通常可以自由选择自己的故事情节。

C • Myths and Fairy Tales

C • 神话和童话

The first and most archaic version of the script, the primal protocol, is conceived in the mind of the child at an age when few people outside his immediate family are real to him. We assume that his parents appear to him as huge figures endowed with magic powers, like the giants and giantesses, ogres and gorgons of mythology, if only because they are three times as tall and ten times as big as he is.

剧本的第一个也是最古老的版本，即原始协议，是在孩童时期构思的，那时除了直系亲属之外，几乎没有人对他来说是真实的。我们推测，在他眼中，父母如同神话中的巨人、女巨人、食人魔和戈耳工一般，拥有强大的魔法力量，这仅仅是因为他们的身高是他的三倍，体型是他的十倍。

As he grows older and becomes more sophisticated, he moves from this classical universe into a more romantic world. He devises the first palimpsest, or rewrite, of his script, to make it correspond with his new view of his surroundings. If conditions are right, he is helped here by fairy tales and animal stories at first read to him by his mother, and later read by himself in his leisure hours when he is free to let his imagination roam. There is magic in these, too, but less earthshaking. They give him a whole new set of characters to play their roles in his fancies: all the personalities in the animal kingdom, which are familiar to him either as warm-blooded playmates and companions, or as fleeting figures of fear or fascination seen or heard in the distance, or as semi-imaginary creatures of unknown capabilities that he has only heard or read about. Or perhaps this comes to him from the television screen, where at that age even the commercials have a halo. Even in the worst case, without book or screen, or even mother, somewhere he knows there is a cow, or can imagine his own distorted beasts.

随着年龄增长，他变得更加成熟世故，逐渐从古典世界过渡到更浪漫的领域。他开始构思自己的剧本，或者说是剧本的重写，使其与他对周围环境的新认知相符。如果条件合适，童话故事和动物故事会帮助他做到这一点。起初，这些故事是母亲读给他听的；后来，当他闲暇时可以自由地让想象力驰骋时，这些故事就成了他阅读的素材。这些故事也蕴含着魔力，但远不及童话故事那样惊天动地。它们为他创造了一系列全新的角色，在他的想象中扮演着各自的角色：动物王国里形形色色的生物，他要么把它们当作温血的玩伴和伙伴，要么把它们当作远处转瞬即逝、令人恐惧或着迷的身影，要么把它们当作半虚构的、拥有未知能力的生物，只闻其名或闻其书。或许，这些想象也来自电视屏幕，在那个年纪，就连广告都仿佛披上了一层光环。即使在最糟糕的情况下，没有书，没有屏幕，甚至没有母亲，他仍然知道某个地方有一头牛，或者可以想象出自己扭曲的野兽。

In the first stage he is dealing with magical people who can perhaps on occasion turn themselves into animals. In this second stage he is merely attributing to animals certain human characteristics, a tendency which persists in adult life to some degree in people associated with stables, kennels, and dolphin tanks.

在第一阶段，他描写的是一些拥有魔法的人，这些人或许偶尔可以把自己变成动物。在第二阶段，他只是将某些人类特征赋予动物，这种倾向在与马厩、犬舍和海豚馆相关的人群中，成年后仍会在一定程度上存在。

In the third stage, in adolescence, he reviews his script once more to adapt it to the current reality as he hopes it will be, still romanticized and still golden, or sometimes gilded with the aid of drugs. Gradually, as the years go by, he moves closer to reality, which is the actual likelihood that the people and things around him will give the desired responses. In this way, through the decades, he prepares himself for his farewell performance. It is this farewell performance which, above all, it is the therapist’s business to change.

在第三阶段，也就是青春期，他会再次审视自己的剧本，使其适应他所期盼的现实——依然是浪漫的、美好的，有时甚至借助药物来粉饰。随着岁月的流逝，他逐渐接近现实，也就是他周围的人和事更有可能给予他所期望的回应。就这样，几十年来，他一直在为自己的告别演出做准备。而治疗师的首要任务，正是改变这场告别演出。

Below are some examples to show the similarity between myths, fairy tales, and real people. These are best understood from the transactional viewpoint, the Martian one referred to earlier, which is based on its own myth – one devised by game and script analysts as a way of seeing human life more objectively. Here Mario the Martian comes to Earth and has to go back and ‘tell it like it is’ – not like the Earth people say it is, or want him to think it is. He doesn’t listen to big words nor tables of statistics, but watches what people are actually doing to, for, and with each other, rather than what they say they are doing. Here, then, is the story of Europa.

以下例子展现了神话、童话和现实人物之间的相似之处。要理解这些相似之处，最好从交易视角出发，也就是前面提到的火星视角。火星视角本身就基于一个神话——一个由游戏和剧本分析师构思的神话，旨在更客观地看待人类生活。在这个神话中，火星人马里奥来到地球，必须回去“如实讲述”——而不是像地球人所说的那样，或者他们想让他相信的那样。他不听那些华丽的辞藻，也不看那些统计数据，而是观察人们彼此之间实际的所作所为，而不是他们自以为是的言辞。这就是木卫二的故事。

THE STORY OF EUROPA

欧罗巴的故事

Europa was Neptune’s granddaughter. One day she was in a seaside meadow gathering flowers when a beautiful bull appeared and knelt at her feet. His eyes invited her to get on his back. She was so taken with his melodious voice and friendly manner that she thought it would be fun to ride around the dell. But the moment she mounted, he took off over the sea, for he was really Jupiter in disguise, and Jupiter would stop at nothing when he saw a girl he liked. Europa did not fare too badly, however, because after they landed in Crete she gave birth to three kings and had a continent named after her. All this is supposed to have happened in 1522 B.C. and the story can be found in the Second Idyllium of Moschus.

欧罗巴是海王星尼普顿的孙女。一天，她在海边草地上采花，这时一头美丽的公牛出现，跪在她脚边。公牛的眼神仿佛在邀请她骑上去。欧罗巴被它悦耳的嗓音和友善的举止深深吸引，心想骑着它在山谷里兜风一定很有趣。然而，就在她骑上牛背的那一刻，公牛却扬长而去，飞向大海。原来，它其实是伪装成公牛的朱庇特，而朱庇特一旦看上心仪的女子，就会不惜一切代价。不过，欧罗巴的遭遇也并非全然悲惨，因为他们最终抵达克里特岛后，她生下了三位国王，甚至有一块大陆以她的名字命名。据说这一切都发生在公元前1522年，这个故事记载在莫斯库斯的《第二田园诗》中。

Jupiter, the abductor, came of a rather unusual family. His father, Saturn, according to Hesiod’s Theogony , had six children. He ate the first five as soon as they were born, so when Jupiter, the sixth, came along, his mother hid him and put in his place a stone wrapped in swaddles, which his father gobbled. When Jupiter grew up, he and his grandmother forced Saturn to disgorge the stone and also the five babies he had eaten: Pluto, Neptune, Vesta, Ceres, and Juno. Now after Jupiter was through with Europa, she took up with Danaus, King of Egypt, and by him she had a daughter named Amymone. Amymone’s father, the King, sent her to carry water to the city of Argos, and while she was doing that, Neptune saw her and was filled with love. He rescued her from a lecherous satyr, and carried her off for himself, he being her own great-grandfather, just as Jupiter, who carried off her mother, was her mother’s granduncle.

劫掠者朱庇特出身于一个相当不寻常的家庭。根据赫西俄德的《神谱》，他的父亲萨图恩有六个孩子。前五个孩子一出生，他就把他们吃掉了。所以当第六个孩子朱庇特出生时，他的母亲把他藏了起来，用襁褓包裹着一块石头代替，结果被他的父亲吞了下去。朱庇特长大后，他和他的祖母强迫萨图恩吐出石头，以及他吃掉的五个孩子：冥王哈迪斯、海王星、灶神星、谷神星和朱诺。朱庇特吃掉欧罗巴后，欧罗巴嫁给了埃及国王达那俄斯，并生下了一个女儿，名叫阿米莫涅。阿米莫涅的父亲，也就是国王，派她去阿尔戈斯城运水。途中，海王星尼普顿看到了她，并被她深深吸引。他从好色的萨提尔手中救出了她，并将她带走，因为他是她的曾祖父，就像带走她母亲的朱庇特是她母亲的叔祖父一样。

Now let us list the significant transactions in this family saga by stimulus and response. Each response, of course, can become the stimulus for the next transaction.

现在让我们按刺激和反应列出这个家族故事中的重要事件。当然，每一个反应都可能成为下一次事件的刺激因素。

1. Stimulus: A beautiful maiden gracefully gathers flowers. Response: An amorous god, her granduncle, turns himself into a golden bull.

1. 刺激：一位美丽的少女优雅地采摘鲜花。反应：一位好色的神，也就是她的叔祖父，把自己变成了一头金牛。

2. Response: The maiden strokes his sides and pats his head. Response: The bull kisses her hands and rolls his eyes.

2. 回应：少女抚摸他的腰侧，轻拍他的头。回应：公牛亲吻她的手，翻了个白眼。

3. The maiden mounts his back. The bull abducts her.

3. 少女骑上公牛的背。公牛掳走了她。

4. She expresses fear and wonder, and asks him who he is. He reassures her, and all turns out well.

4. 她既害怕又好奇，问他是谁。他安慰了她，最后一切都平安无事。

5. Stimulus: A father eats his children. Response: The mother feeds him a stone.

5. 刺激：父亲吃掉了自己的孩子。反应：母亲喂他吃了一块石头。

6. Response: The saved son forces the father to give up the eaten children and the swallowed stone.

6. 回应：获救的儿子迫使父亲交出被吃掉的孩子和吞下的石头。

7. Stimulus: A beautiful maiden is sent by her father to fetch water. Response: She gets into trouble with a satyr, what would nowadays be called a ‘wolf’.

7. 事件：一位美丽的少女奉父亲之命去打水。结果：她与一个萨提尔（如今会被称为“狼”）发生了冲突。

8. Stimulus: Her beauty excites her great-grandfather. Response: He saves her from the satyr and carries her off.

8. 刺激：她的美貌令她的曾祖父心动。反应：他从萨提尔手中救下她，并将她带走。

To a script analyst, the most interesting feature of this series of mythical transactions (in Moschus’s version) is that in spite of Europa’s wild lamentations and protests, she never expressly says ‘Stop!’ or ‘Take me back at once!’ but instead quickly switches into trying to guess the identity of her abductor. In other words, while she makes loud token protests, she is careful not to abort the drama, but instead resigns herself to it and becomes curious about its outcome. Thus her lamentations have the ambiguous quality which in Martian is called ‘gamy’ or ‘scripty’. In fact, she is playing the game called ‘Rapo’, which fits into her destined script of becoming the mother of kings, providing it happens ‘against her will’. Taking a personal interest in her abductor is not the firmest way to discourage him; but her protests disclaim her own responsibility for having flirted with him in the first place.

对剧本分析家而言，这一系列神话故事（莫斯库斯版本）最有趣的特点在于，尽管欧罗巴发出疯狂的哀嚎和抗议，她却从未明确地说出“住手！”或“立刻带我回去！”，而是迅速转而猜测绑架者的身份。换句话说，尽管她发出响亮的象征性抗议，但她小心翼翼地不让这场闹剧戛然而止，而是顺其自然，并对结局感到好奇。因此，她的哀嚎带有一种暧昧的特质，在火星语中被称为“游戏性”或“剧本性”。事实上，她是在玩一种名为“拉波”（Rapo）的游戏，这符合她注定成为众王之母的剧本，前提是这一切“违背她的意愿”。对绑架者表现出个人兴趣并非阻止他的最佳方法；但她的抗议也表明她否认自己当初与他调情的责任。

There is a more familiar story which includes most of these transactions, though in a slightly different order. The following version is taken from Andrew Lang and Grimm. This tale is known from earliest years to nearly all literate children in English-speaking countries, and others as well, and is a common stimulus to their imaginations.

还有一个更为人熟知的故事，包含了大部分这些情节，只是顺序略有不同。以下版本出自安德鲁·朗和格林兄弟的著作。几乎所有英语国家以及其他地区的识字儿童从小就耳熟能详这个故事，它常常激发孩子们的想象力。

LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD

小红帽

There was a sweet little maiden named Little Red Riding Hood (LRRH), and one day her mother sent her through the woods to bring food to her grandmother. On the way she met a seductive wolf who thought she was a nice morsel. He told her to turn on, tune in, drop out, and pick flowers, instead of looking solemn. While she dallied, the wolf went to her grandmother’s house and ate up the old lady. When LRRH arrived, he pretended he was her grandmother and invited her to get into bed with him. She did so, and noticed many peculiar things about his appearance which made her wonder if it really was the old lady. He first tried to reassure her, and then ate her up (apparently without chewing her). A hunter came and rescued her by cutting the wolf open, and let her grandmother out alive as well. Then LRRH happily helped the hunter fill the wolf’s belly with stones. In some versions, LRRH calls for help and the hunter kills the wolf with an ax and rescues her in the nick of time before the villain can eat her up.

从前有个名叫小红帽（LRRH）的可爱小女孩，有一天，妈妈让她穿过森林去给奶奶送吃的。路上，她遇到了一只色眯眯的狼，狼觉得她是个美味的猎物。狼让她放松下来，融入人群，放下一切，去采花，别再摆出一副严肃的样子。小红帽磨蹭的时候，狼去了奶奶家，把老奶奶吃了。小红帽赶到后，狼假装是奶奶，邀请她上床。小红帽照做了，却发现狼的外表有很多奇怪之处，让她怀疑他是不是奶奶。狼先是试图安抚她，然后就把她吃了（显然没怎么咀嚼）。这时，一个猎人来了，剖开了狼的肚子，救出了小红帽，也救出了奶奶。之后，小红帽高兴地帮猎人往狼肚子里塞石头。在某些版本中，LRRH呼救，猎人用斧头杀死了狼，在恶棍吃掉她之前及时救了她。

Here again there is a seductive scene between an innocent maiden who likes to gather flowers and a crafty animal who betrays her. The animal likes to eat children but ends up with stones in his belly instead. Like Amymone, LRRH is sent on a helpful errand, gets into trouble with a wolf on the way, and gets chummy with her rescuer.

这里又出现了一段充满诱惑的场景：一位天真烂漫、喜爱采花的少女，与一只狡猾奸诈、背叛她的动物相遇。这只动物喜欢吃小孩，结果却吞下了石头。和艾米蒙一样，小红帽也被派去帮忙，途中与狼发生了冲突，最终与救命恩人成了好朋友。

To a Martian, this story raises interesting questions. He takes it at face value, including the talking wolf, even though he has never met one. But given what happens, he wonders what it is all about and what kind of people it happens to. Here, then, are his thoughts on the matter.

对一个火星人来说，这个故事引发了一些有趣的疑问。他全盘接受了故事的内容，包括那只会说话的狼——尽管他从未见过狼。但随着故事的展开，他不禁思考这究竟是怎么回事，又会发生在什么样的人身上。以下是他对此事的思考。

A MARTIAN REACTION

火星反应

One day LRRH’s mother sent her through the woods to bring food to her grandmother, and on the way she met a wolf. What kind of a mother sends a little girl into a forest where there are wolves? Why didn’t her mother do it herself, or go along with LRRH? If grandmother was so helpless, why did mother leave her all by herself in a hut far away? But if LRRH had to go, how come her mother had never warned her not to stop and talk to wolves? The story makes it clear that LRRH had never been told that this was dangerous. No mother could really be that stupid, so it sounds as if her mother didn’t care much what happened to LRRH, or maybe even wanted to get rid of her. No little girl is that stupid either. How could LRRH look at the wolf’s eyes, ears, hands, and teeth, and still think it was her grandmother? Why didn’t she get out of there as fast as she could? And a mean little thing she was, too, gathering up stones to put into the wolf’s belly. At any rate, any straight-thinking girl, after talking to the wolf, would certainly not have stopped to pick flowers, but would have said to herself: ‘That son of a bitch is going to eat up my grandmother if I don’t get some help fast.’

有一天，LRRH的妈妈让她穿过树林去给奶奶送食物，路上她遇到了一匹狼。什么样的妈妈会把一个小女孩送到有狼的森林里去呢？为什么妈妈自己不去，或者陪着LRRH一起去？如果奶奶真的那么无助，妈妈为什么把她一个人留在远处的小屋里？但如果LRRH非去不可，为什么妈妈从来没有警告过她不要停下来和狼说话？故事清楚地表明，LRRH从未被告知这样做很危险。没有哪个妈妈会这么愚蠢，所以听起来好像妈妈根本不在乎LRRH的安危，甚至可能想摆脱她。也没有哪个小女孩会这么愚蠢。LRRH怎么可能看着狼的眼睛、耳朵、爪子和牙齿，还以为那是奶奶呢？她为什么不赶紧离开那里呢？她真是个心肠歹毒的小家伙，竟然捡石头喂狼。总之，任何一个头脑清醒的女孩，在和狼交谈之后，肯定不会停下来摘花，而是会对自己说：“如果我再不赶紧找人帮忙，那该死的狼就要把我奶奶吃掉了。”

Even the grandmother and the hunter aren’t above suspicion. If we now treat the dramatis personae of this story as real people, each with his or her own script, we see how neatly their personalities mesh from a Martian point of view.

就连祖母和猎人也并非完全无辜。如果我们把故事中的人物都当作真实存在的人，每个人都有自己的剧本，那么从火星人的视角来看，我们就会发现他们的性格是多么契合。

1. The mother is evidently trying to lose her daughter ‘accidentally’, or at least she wants to end up saying: ‘Isn’t it awful, you can’t even walk through the park nowadays without some wolf …’ etc.

1. 这位母亲显然想“不小心”弄丢她的女儿，或者至少她想最后说：“太可怕了，现在连在公园里走走都会遇到狼……”等等。

2. The wolf, instead of eating rabbits and such, is obviously overreaching himself, and he must know that he will come to a bad end that way, so he must want to invite trouble. He evidently read Nietzsche or someone similar in his youth (if he can talk and tie on a bonnet, why shouldn’t he be able to read?), and his motto is something like ‘Live dangerously and die gloriously.’

2. 这匹狼显然是在好高骛远，它不去吃兔子之类的猎物，而是选择自讨苦吃。它肯定知道这样做会招致厄运，所以才故意招惹麻烦。它年轻时显然读过尼采或者类似的著作（既然它会说话、会戴帽子，为什么不会读书呢？），它的座右铭大概是“生而危险，死而辉煌”。

3. Grandmother lives alone and leaves her door unlatched, so she may be hoping for something interesting to happen, something which couldn’t happen if she were living with her folks. Maybe that’s why she didn’t move in with them, or at least live next door. She was probably young enough to be ripe for adventure, since LRRH was still a little girl.

3. 奶奶独自居住，而且不锁门，所以她可能期待着发生一些有趣的事情，一些如果和父母住在一起就不可能发生的事情。也许这就是她没有搬去和他们一起住，或者至少没有住在隔壁的原因。她当时可能还很年轻，正值冒险的年纪，因为小红帽当时还是个小女孩。

4. The hunter is obviously a rescuer who enjoys working over his vanquished opponents with sweet little maidens to help: quite clearly an adolescent script.

4. 猎人显然是一位拯救者，他喜欢用甜美的小姑娘来帮助他征服对手：这显然是一个青少年剧本。

5. LRRH tells the wolf quite explicitly where he can meet her again, and even climbs into bed with him. She is obviously playing ‘Rapo,’ and ends up quite happy about the whole affair.

5. 小红帽非常明确地告诉狼下次可以在哪里见到她，甚至还爬上了他的床。她显然是在玩弄“拉波”这个角色，最终对整件事都非常满意。

The truth of the matter is that everybody in the story is looking for action at almost any price. If the payoff at the end is taken at face value, then the whole thing was a plot to do in the poor wolf by making him think he was outsmarting everybody, using LRRH as bait. In that case, the moral of the story is not that innocent maidens should keep out of forests where there are wolves, but that wolves should keep away from innocent-looking maidens and their grandmothers; in short, a wolf should not walk through the forest alone. This also raises the interesting question of what the mother did after she got rid of LRRH for the day.

事实是，故事里的每个人都在不惜一切代价寻求刺激。如果仅从字面意思理解结尾，那么整件事其实是一个阴谋，目的是让可怜的狼误以为自己智胜了所有人，而小红帽则成了诱饵。这样看来，故事的寓意并非是天真少女应该远离有狼出没的森林，而是狼应该远离看似天真无邪的少女及其祖母；简而言之，狼不应该独自穿过森林。这也引出了一个有趣的问题：母亲在摆脱小红帽一天之后做了什么？

If all this seems cynical or facetious, let us now consider LRRH in real life. The crucial question here is that with such a mother, and after such an experience, what was LRRH like after she grew up?

如果这一切听起来像是愤世嫉俗或滑稽可笑，那么现在让我们来探讨一下现实生活中的LRRH。关键问题是，在这样一位母亲的教导下，经历了这样的事情之后，LRRH长大后会变成什么样呢？

A LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD SCRIPT

小红帽剧本

In the psychoanalytic literature, a great deal of attention is devoted to the symbolic meaning of the stones put into the wolf’s belly. For the transactional analyst, however, the most significant items are the transactions between the people involved.

在精神分析文献中，人们非常关注放入狼腹中的石头所蕴含的象征意义。然而，对于人际沟通分析师而言，最重要的却是相关人员之间的互动。

Carrie came for treatment at the age of thirty, complaining that she had headaches, depressions, didn’t know what she wanted to do, and couldn’t find a satisfactory boy friend. Like all the Little Red Riding Hoods in Dr Q’s experience, she had a red coat. She was always trying to be helpful in an indirect sort of way. One day she came in and said:

凯莉三十岁那年来就诊，抱怨自己头痛、抑郁，不知道自己想做什么，也找不到满意的男朋友。就像Q医生遇到的所有小红帽一样，她穿着一件红外套。她总是试图用一种委婉的方式帮助别人。有一天，她走进诊室，说道：

‘There’s a sick dog in the street down from your office. Do you want to call the SPCA?’

“你办公室附近的街上有一只生病的狗。你想打电话给动物保护协会吗？”

‘Why don’t you call the SPCA?’ asked Dr Q.

“你为什么不给动物保护协会打电话呢？”Q医生问道。

To which she replied: ‘Who, me?’

她回答说：“谁？我吗？”

She herself never rescued anybody, but she always knew where rescuers could be found. This is typical of LRRH. Dr Q then asked her if she had ever worked in an office where someone had to go out to get the refreshments for the coffee break, which she had.

她本人从未救过任何人，但她总是知道哪里可以找到救援人员。这正是LRRH的典型特征。Q医生接着问她是否曾在需要有人外出购买咖啡休息时间点心的办公室工作过，她回答说有过。

‘Who went out to get the refreshments?’

谁出去买茶点了？

‘Me, of course,’ she replied.

“当然是我，”她回答道。

The scripty part of her story was as follows. During the time she was six to ten years old, her mother used to send her over to her (maternal) grandparents’ house on errands and to play. Often when she got there her grandmother was out and she played with her grandfather, mostly him feeling under her dress. She never told her mother because she knew that her mother would get angry at her and call her a liar.

她故事的剧本部分是这样的：在她六岁到十岁之间，母亲经常让她去外公外婆家办事或玩耍。她到家时，外婆往往不在家，她就和外公玩，外公经常会摸她的裙子底下。她从没告诉过母亲，因为她知道母亲会生她的气，说她撒谎。

Nowadays she met men and ‘boys’ frequently, and many of them dated her, but she always broke up with them after two or three dates. Each time she told Dr Q about her latest breakup he would ask why it happened, and she would reply: ‘Ha! Ha! Ha! Because he’s a junior wolf.’ Thus she spent years of her life trotting through the forests of the financial district bringing sandwiches to people, and continually brushing off junior wolves: a dull, depressing kind of existence. The most exciting event in her life, actually, was the affair with her grandfather. It now appeared that she was going to spend the rest of her days waiting for a repetition of that.

如今她经常遇到男人和“男孩”，其中不少人跟她约会，但她总是两三次之后就分手。每次她跟Q医生谈起最近一次分手的事，他都会问为什么，她总是回答：“哈哈哈哈！因为他是个小狼崽子。”就这样，她把大半辈子都耗在了金融区的“森林”里，给人们送三明治，不断地甩掉那些小狼崽子：一种枯燥乏味、令人沮丧的生活。事实上，她生命中最刺激的事，是跟她祖父的那段情。现在看来，她余生似乎都要在等待那段情缘的重现中度过。

This tells us how LRRH spent her life after the story ended. The wolf affair was by far the most interesting thing that ever happened to her. When she grew up, she passed the time trotting through forests, bringing goodies to people, and eternally hoping to meet another wolf. But all she ran into were wolf cubs, whom she contemptuously brushed aside. Carrie’s story also tells us who the wolf really was, and why LRRH was bold enough to get into bed with him: it was her grandfather.

这告诉我们小红帽在故事结束后是如何生活的。与狼的这段情事无疑是她人生中最有趣的事情。长大后，她常在森林里漫步，给人们带去礼物，并一直渴望能再次遇到狼。但她遇到的只有狼崽，她都轻蔑地将它们抛在脑后。凯莉的故事也揭示了那匹狼的真实身份，以及小红帽为何如此大胆地与它同床共枕：原来，那是她的祖父。

The characteristics of a real-life LRRH are as follows:

现实生活中的LRRH具有以下特点：

1. Her mother used to send her on errands.

1. 她母亲过去常常派她去跑腿。

2. She was seduced by her grandfather, but didn’t tell her mother. If she had, she would have been called a liar. Sometimes she pretended to be too stupid to know what was going on.

2. 她被祖父诱奸了，但没有告诉母亲。如果说了，母亲会说她是骗子。有时她会装傻充愣，不知道发生了什么。

3. She doesn’t often rescue people herself, but likes to arrange rescues, and is always looking out for such opportunities.

3. 她自己不常去救人，但她喜欢安排救援，并且总是在寻找这样的机会。

4. When she grows up, she is the one chosen to run errands. She often scurries or wanders like a little girl, rather than walking in a dignified way.

4. 她长大后，被选中去跑腿办事。她常常像个小女孩一样四处奔跑或闲逛，而不是端庄地走路。

5. She is waiting for something really exciting to happen and is bored in the meantime, since all she meets nowadays are junior wolves, whom she looks down on.

5. 她期待着一些真正激动人心的事情发生，但与此同时她感到很无聊，因为她现在遇到的都是些小狼崽，她瞧不起它们。

6. She enjoys filling wolves’ bellies with stones, or the everyday equivalent of that.

6. 她喜欢往狼肚子里塞石头，或者做类似的事情。

7. It is not clear yet whether the male psychiatrist is there to rescue her, or is merely a nice, nonsexual grandfather with whom she feels comfortable and slightly nostalgic, and whom she settles for because she can’t have the real thing.

7. 目前还不清楚这位男精神科医生是来拯救她的，还是仅仅是一个和蔼可亲、没有性欲的祖父，让她感到舒适和略带怀旧之情，而她因为得不到真正的伴侣而选择了他。

8. She laughs and agrees when he says she reminds him of LRRH.

8. 当他说她让他想起小红帽时，她笑着表示同意。

9. Oddly enough, she nearly always owns and wears a red coat.

9. 奇怪的是，她几乎总是拥有一件红色外套，并且经常穿着它。

It should be noted that the scripts of a Little Red Riding Hood’s mother, maternal grandfather, and maternal grandmother must be complementary in order to allow such sexual incidents to happen more than once. The happy ending of the tale is also suspect, and does not occur in real life. Fairy tales are told by well-meaning parents, and the happy ending is an intrusion of a benevolent but mendacious Parental ego state; tales made up by children themselves are more realistic, and do not necessarily have happy endings; in fact, they are notoriously gruesome. 4

值得注意的是，小红帽的母亲、外祖父和外祖母的剧本必须相互配合，才能使此类性事件多次发生。故事的幸福结局也值得怀疑，现实生活中并不存在。童话故事是由好心的父母讲述的，而幸福结局是父母出于善意却又虚伪的自我状态的介入；孩子们自己编造的故事则更加现实，并不一定有幸福的结局；事实上，它们往往极其残酷。

D • Waiting for Rigor Mortis

D • 等待尸僵

One object of script analysis is to fit the patient’s life plan into the grand historical psychology of the whole human race, a psychology which apparently has changed but little from cave days, through the early farming and ranching settlements and the great totalitarian governments of the Middle East, up to the present time. Joseph Campbell in The Hero With A Thousand Faces , which is the best textbook for script analysts, summarizes this as follows:

剧本分析的目标之一是将患者的生活规划融入整个人类宏大的历史心理框架中。这种心理似乎从穴居时代到早期的农牧定居点，再到中东的极权政府，直至今日，变化甚微。约瑟夫·坎贝尔在其著作《千面英雄》（剧本分析的最佳教科书）中对此作了如下总结：

‘Freud, Jung, and their followers have demonstrated irrefutably that the logic, the heroes, and the deeds of myth survive into modern times … The latest incarnation of Oedipus, the continued romance of Beauty and the Beast, stand this afternoon on the corner of Forty-Second Street and Fifth Avenue, waiting for the traffic light to change.’ He points out that while the hero of myth achieves a world-historical triumph, the hero of the fairy tale achieves merely a small domestic victory. And patients are patients, we may add, because they cannot achieve the victories they aim for and still survive. Hence they come to the doctor, ‘the knower of all the secret ways and words of potency. His role is precisely that of the Wise Old Man of the myths and fairy tales whose words assist the hero through the trials and terrors of the weird adventure.’

“弗洛伊德、荣格及其追随者已经无可辩驳地证明，神话的逻辑、英雄和事迹在现代依然存在……俄狄浦斯的最新化身，美女与野兽的浪漫故事，今天下午就站在第四十二街和第五大道的拐角处，等待着交通灯变绿。”他指出，神话中的英雄取得了举世瞩目的胜利，而童话故事中的英雄仅仅获得了一场小小的家庭胜利。我们还可以补充一点，病人之所以是病人，是因为他们无法在获得自己渴望的胜利的同时还能活下来。因此，他们才会去找医生，“医生知晓所有秘诀和疗愈之道。他的角色正是神话和童话故事中那位睿智的老人，他的话语帮助英雄度过奇异冒险中的种种考验和恐惧。”

That, at any rate, is the way the Child in the patient sees it, no matter how his Adult tells the story, and it is quite evident that all children, since the beginning of humanity, have had to cope with the same problems, and have had about the same weapons at their disposal. When it comes to the cutting, life is the same old wine in new bottles: coconut and bamboo bottles gave way to goatskins, goatskins to pottery, pottery to glass, and glass to plastic, but the grapes have hardly changed at all, and there is the same old intoxication on top and the same old dregs at the bottom. So, as Campbell says, there will be found little variation in the shapes of the adventures and the characters involved. Hence, if we know some of the elements of the patient’s script, we can predict with some confidence where he is heading, and head him off before he meets with misfortune or disaster. That is called preventive psychiatry, or ‘making progress.’ Even better, we can get him to change his script or give it up altogether, which is curative psychiatry, or ‘getting well.’

无论如何，无论成年一方如何讲述，病人内心深处的孩童都是这样看待问题的。显而易见，自人类诞生以来，所有孩童都不得不面对同样的问题，并且拥有几乎相同的应对手段。就人生而言，就像是旧瓶装新酒：椰子瓶和竹瓶被羊皮瓶取代，羊皮瓶被陶瓶取代，陶瓶被玻璃瓶取代，玻璃瓶被塑料瓶取代，但酒本身却几乎没有变化，顶部的酒液和底部的残渣依然如故。因此，正如坎贝尔所说，冒险经历和其中涉及的人物几乎没有什么变化。所以，如果我们了解病人人生剧本的一些要素，我们就能比较有把握地预测他的走向，并在他遭遇不幸或灾难之前阻止他。这叫做预防精神病学，或者说“取得进展”。更好的是，我们可以让他改变他的治疗方案，或者完全放弃治疗方案，这就是治疗精神病学，或者说“康复”。

Thus, it is not a matter of doctrine or necessity to find precisely the myth or fairy tale which the patient is following; but the closer we can come, the better. Without such a historical foundation, errors are frequent. A mere episode in the patient’s life, or his favorite game, may be mistaken for the whole script; or the occurrence of a single animal symbol, such as a wolf, may lead the therapist to bark up the wrong tree. Relating the patient’s life or his Child’s life plan to a coherent story which has survived for hundreds or thousands of years because of its universal appeal to the primitive layers of the human mind, at least gives a feeling of working from a solid foundation, and at best may give very precise clues as to what needs to be done to avert or change a bad ending.

因此，找到患者所遵循的神话或童话故事并非教条或必要之举；但我们越接近，效果越好。缺乏这样的历史基础，错误就很容易发生。患者生活中的某个片段，或是他最喜欢的游戏，都可能被误认为是整个故事；或者，某个动物象征（例如狼）的出现，就可能导致治疗师误入歧途。将患者的生活或其童年时期的生活规划与一个连贯的故事联系起来——这个故事之所以流传数百年甚至数千年，是因为它对人类心灵的原始层面具有普遍的吸引力——至少能让人感到工作是有坚实基础的，而最好的情况是，它还能提供非常精确的线索，帮助我们找到避免或改变不良结局的方法。

THE WAITING FOR RIGOR MORTIS SCRIPT

等待尸僵剧本

For example, a fairy tale may reveal elements of a script which are otherwise hard to dig up, such as the ‘script illusion.’ The transactional analyst believes that psychiatric symptoms result from some form of self-deception. But patients can be cured just because their lives and their disabilities are based on a figment of the imagination.

例如，童话故事可能会揭示一些难以挖掘的剧本元素，例如“剧本错觉”。人际沟通分析师认为，精神症状源于某种形式的自我欺骗。但患者也可能被治愈，仅仅因为他们的生活和残疾都基于想象的产物。

In the script known as ‘Frigid Woman,’ or ‘Waiting for Rigor Mortis ’ (WRM), the mother keeps telling her daughter that men are beasts, but it is a wife’s duty to submit to their bestiality. If the mother pushes hard enough, the girl may even get the idea that she will die if she has an orgasm. Usually such mothers are great snobs, and they offer a release or an ‘antiscript’ that will lift the curse. It is all right for the daughter to have sex if she marries a very important person, such as the Prince with the Golden Apples. But failing that, she tells her erroneously, ‘all your troubles will be over when you reach your menopause, because then you won’t be in danger of feeling sexy any more.’

在名为《冷漠的女人》或《等待尸僵》（WRM）的剧本中，母亲不断告诉女儿男人是野兽，但妻子有义务顺从他们的兽性。如果母亲的强迫足够强烈，女儿甚至可能认为如果达到性高潮就会死去。通常，这样的母亲都是势利眼，她们会提供一种解脱或“反剧本”，声称可以解除诅咒。如果女儿嫁给一位非常重要的人，比如拥有金苹果的王子，那么她就可以享受性爱。但如果没能嫁给王子，母亲就会错误地告诉女儿：“当你绝经后，所有的烦恼都会结束，因为那时你就不会再有性欲的危险了。”

Now it already appears as though we have three illusions: Orgathanatos, or the fatal orgasm; the Prince with the Golden Apples; and Blessed Relief, or the purifying menopause. But none of these is the real script illusion. The girl has tested Orgathanatos by masturbation, and knows it is not fatal. The Prince with the Golden Apples is not an illusion, because it is just possible that she might find such a man, just as she might win the Irish Sweepstakes or get four aces in a poker game; both of these things are unlikely, but not mythical; they do happen. And Blessed Relief is not something her Child really wants. In order to find the script illusion, we need the fairy tale which corresponds to WRM.

现在看来，我们似乎已经有了三种幻象：致命的性高潮（Orgathanatos）、金苹果王子和净化的更年期（Blessed Relief）。但这些都不是剧本真正的幻象。女孩已经通过自慰验证了“致命的性高潮”，并且知道它并非致命的。金苹果王子也不是幻象，因为她完全有可能遇到这样的男人，就像她有可能赢得爱尔兰彩票或在扑克牌局中拿到四张A一样；这两件事虽然不太可能，但并非神话，它们确实会发生。而净化的更年期也不是她的孩子真正想要的。为了找到剧本的幻象，我们需要与WRM相对应的童话故事。

THE STORY OF SLEEPING BEAUTY

睡美人的故事

An angry fairy says that Briar Rose will prick her finger with a spindle and fall down dead. Another fairy commutes this to a hundred years of sleep. When she is fifteen Briar Rose does prick her finger, and immediately falls asleep. At the same moment everybody and everything else in the castle also fall asleep. During the hundred years, many princes try to get to her through the briars which have grown up around her, but none succeeds. At last, after the time is up, a prince arrives who manages to get through because the briars let him. When he finds the princess and kisses her, she wakes up and they fall in love. At the same moment, everybody and everything else in the castle take up exactly where they left off, as though nothing had happened and no time had passed since they fell asleep. The princess herself is still only fifteen years old, not 115. She and the prince get married, and in one version, they live happily ever after; in another, this is only the beginning of their troubles. 5

一位愤怒的仙女说，睡美人布莱尔·罗斯会被纺锤刺破手指，然后倒地身亡。另一位仙女则改口说，她会沉睡一百年。布莱尔·罗斯十五岁时，果然刺破了手指，立刻睡着了。与此同时，城堡里所有人和所有东西也都睡着了。一百年间，许多王子试图穿过环绕着她的荆棘丛去见她，但都失败了。最终，时间到了，一位王子出现了，因为荆棘丛让他得以穿过。当他找到公主并吻了她时，公主醒了过来，两人坠入爱河。与此同时，城堡里所有人和所有东西都恢复了之前的状态，仿佛什么都没发生过，时间也没有流逝。公主本人仍然只有十五岁，而不是一百一十五岁。她和王子结婚了，在一个版本中，他们从此过上了幸福的生活；在另一个版本中，这仅仅是他们苦难的开始。

There are many magic sleeps in mythology. Perhaps the best known is that of Brunhilde, who is left sleeping on the mountain with a ring of fire around her which only a hero can penetrate, and that is accomplished by Siegfried. 6

神话中有很多神奇的睡眠。其中最著名的或许是布伦希尔德的睡眠，她被困在山上，周围环绕着一圈火焰，只有英雄才能穿透火焰，而齐格弗里德做到了这一点。

In one way or another, with slight alterations, almost everything in the story of Sleeping Beauty could actually happen. Girls do prick their fingers and faint, and they do fall asleep in their towers, and princes do wander around in the forest and look for fair maidens. The one thing that cannot happen is for everything and everybody to be unchanged and unaged after the lapse of so many years. This is a real illusion because it is not only improbable, it is impossible. And this is just the illusion on which WRM scripts are based: that when the Prince does come, Rose will be fifteen years old again instead of thirty, forty, or fifty, and they will have a whole lifetime ahead of them. This is the illusion of sustained youth, a modest daughter of the illusion of immortality. It is hard to tell Rose in real life that princes are younger men, and that by the time they reach her age they have become kings, and are much less interesting. That is the most distressing part of the script analyst’s job: to break up the illusion, to inform the patient’s Child that there is no Santa Claus, and make it stick. It is much easier for both of them if there is the patient’s favorite fairy tale to work with.

以某种方式，稍加改动，睡美人故事中的几乎所有情节都可能发生。女孩们确实会刺破手指晕倒，她们确实会在高塔中沉睡，王子们也确实会在森林里漫步，寻找美丽的少女。唯一不可能发生的是，在经历了这么多年之后，所有人和事都保持不变，容颜不老。这是一种真正的错觉，因为它不仅不太可能，而且根本不可能。而这正是WRM剧本所基于的错觉：当王子出现时，罗丝将再次回到十五岁，而不是三十岁、四十岁或五十岁，他们将拥有漫长的一生。这是青春永驻的错觉，是永生错觉的谦逊女儿。在现实生活中，很难告诉罗丝，王子都是比她年轻的人，当他们到了她这个年纪时，他们已经成为国王，变得索然无味。剧本分析师工作中最为棘手的部分在于：打破幻想，告诉患者的孩子根本没有圣诞老人，并且让他们真正接受这个事实。如果能用患者最喜欢的童话故事来分析，对双方来说都会容易得多。

One of the practical problems of WRM is that if Rose does find the Prince with the Golden Apples, she often feels outclassed and has to find fault and play ‘Blemish’ to bring him down to her level, so that he ends up wishing she would go back in the briars and fall asleep again. On the other hand, if she settles for less – the Prince with the Silver Apples, or even ordinary McIntoshes from the grocery store – she will feel cheated and take it out on him, meanwhile always keeping an eye out for the Golden One. Thus, neither the frigid script nor the magic antiscript offers much chance for fulfillment. Also, as in the fairy tale, there is his mother to contend with as well as her witch.

《玫瑰玫瑰》的一个实际问题是，如果玫瑰真的找到了拥有金苹果的王子，她常常会觉得自己不如他，于是不得不挑剔他，扮演“瑕疵”的角色，把他拉低到和自己一样的水平，最终让他希望她回到荆棘丛里继续沉睡。另一方面，如果她退而求其次——比如找到了拥有银苹果的王子，甚至是超市里普通的麦金托什家的孩子——她就会觉得自己被欺骗了，并把气撒在他身上，同时仍然时刻留意着金苹果王子的出现。因此，无论是冷酷的剧本还是充满魔力的反剧本，都很难让故事圆满落幕。此外，就像童话故事里一样，她还要应付王子的母亲和她那邪恶的女巫。

This script is important because a great many people in the world, in one way or another, spend their lives waiting for rigor mortis .

这段文字之所以重要，是因为世界上有许多人，无论以何种方式，都在等待着尸僵的到来。

E • The Family Drama

E • 家庭剧

Another good way to uncover the plot and some of the most important lines in a person’s script is to ask: ‘If your family life were put on the stage, what kind of play would it be?’ Such family dramas are usually named after the Greek Oedipus and Electra plays, in which the boy competes with father for his mommy and the girl wants daddy for her own. 7 But the script analyst has to know what the parents, called for convenience Supideo and Artcele, are up to meanwhile. Supideo is the other side of the Oedipus drama, and expresses the frank or disguised sexual feelings of the mother for her son, while Artcele is the other side of Electra and shows father’s feelings for the girl. A close inquiry will nearly always reveal rather obvious transactions which demonstrate that these feelings are not imaginary, even though the parent tries to conceal them, usually by playing ‘Uproar’ with the child. That is, the disturbed parent tries to cover up his Child sexual feelings for his offspring by coming on Parental and ordering the offspring about in a quarrelsome way. But on certain occasions they leak out, despite all efforts to disguise them by ‘Uproar’ and other devices. Actually, the happiest parents are often those who openly admire the attractiveness of their children.

另一种揭示人物剧本情节和关键台词的好方法是问自己：“如果你的家庭生活被搬上舞台，它会是什么样的剧？”这类家庭剧通常以古希腊的俄狄浦斯和厄勒克特拉的故事命名，故事中男孩与父亲争夺母亲，女孩则渴望得到父亲。但剧本分析者必须了解父母（为了方便起见，我们称之为苏皮迪奥和阿尔特塞勒）的内心世界。苏皮迪奥是俄狄浦斯戏剧的另一面，表达了母亲对儿子坦率或隐晦的性欲；而阿尔特塞勒则是厄勒克特拉戏剧的另一面，展现了父亲对女儿的感情。仔细探究几乎总能揭示出一些显而易见的互动，表明这些感情并非虚构，即使父母试图掩盖，通常是通过与孩子玩“吵闹”游戏。也就是说，心怀不满的父母试图通过扮演父母的角色，用争吵的方式命令子女，来掩盖自己对子女的性欲。但有时，尽管他们竭尽全力用“吵闹”和其他手段掩饰，这些性欲还是会流露出来。事实上，最幸福的父母往往是那些公开欣赏自己孩子魅力的父母。

The Supideo and Artcele dramas, like Oedipus and Electra, have many variations. As the children grow older, they may be played out as mother sleeping with son’s boyfriend or father sleeping with his daughter’s chum. Farther out and even more ‘gamy’ versions are mother sleeping with daughter’s boyfriend or father sleeping with son’s girl. fn2 This compliment may be returned by the young Oedipus sleeping with father’s mistress, or Electra with mother’s lover. Sometimes the family script calls for one or several members to be homosexual, with corresponding variations in child sex play, incest between siblings, and later seductions of each other’s partners. Any deviations from the standard Oedipus (son wondering or dreaming about sex with mother) or Electra (daughter wondering or dreaming about father) roles will undoubtedly influence the whole life course of the person.

苏皮德奥和阿特塞勒的悲剧，如同俄狄浦斯和厄勒克特拉的故事一样，有很多变体。随着孩子们长大，这些情节可能会演变成母亲与儿子的男友发生关系，或者父亲与女儿的朋友发生关系。更离谱、更“淫秽”的版本则是母亲与女儿的男友发生关系，或者父亲与儿子的女友发生关系。 fn2 这种“致敬”也可能以小俄狄浦斯与父亲的情妇，或者厄勒克特拉与母亲的情人发生关系来回应。有时，家庭剧本要求一个或多个成员是同性恋，并相应地衍生出儿童性游戏、兄妹乱伦以及日后勾引彼此伴侣等情节。任何偏离标准俄狄浦斯（儿子幻想或梦见与母亲发生性关系）或厄勒克特拉（女儿幻想或梦见与父亲发生性关系）角色的情节，无疑都会影响人的一生。

In addition to, or beyond, the sexual aspects of the family drama, there are even more poignant ones. A jilted homosexual girl attacked her lover, held a knife to her throat, and cried: ‘You’ll let me give you these wounds, but you won’t let me heal them.’ This perhaps is the motto of all family dramas, the origin of all parental anguish, the basis for youthful rebellion, and the cry of couples not yet ready for divorce. The wounded flee, and the cry above is the Martian translation of the ad: ‘Mary, come home. All is forgiven.’ And that is why children stick with even the most miserable parents. It hurts to be wounded, but it feels so good to be healed.

除了家庭剧的性层面之外，还有更令人心碎的层面。一个被抛弃的同性恋女孩袭击了她的爱人，用刀抵着他的喉咙，哭喊道：“你让我给你留下这些伤痕，却不让我治愈它们。”这或许是所有家庭剧的座右铭，是所有父母痛苦的根源，是青春期叛逆的根源，也是那些尚未准备好离婚的伴侣的呐喊。受伤的人逃离，而上面这句呐喊，是火星人对“玛丽，回家吧。一切都过去了”广告的另一种诠释。这就是为什么孩子们即使在最痛苦的父母身边也会选择留下。受伤固然痛苦，但被治愈的感觉却如此美好。

F • Human Destiny

F • 人类命运

It is incredible to think, at first, that man’s fate, all his nobility and all his degradation, is decided by a child no more than six years old, and usually three, but that is what script theory claims. It is a little easier to believe after talking to a child of six, or maybe three. And it is very easy to believe by looking around at what is happening in the world today, and what happened yesterday, and seeing what will probably happen tomorrow. The history of human scripts can be found on ancient monuments, in courtrooms and morgues, in gambling houses and letters to the editor, and in political debates, where whole nations are talked down the righteous road by somebody trying to prove that what his parents told him in the nursery will work for the whole world. But fortunately, some people have good scripts, and some even succeed in freeing themselves to do things their own way.

乍一看，一个人的命运，包括他的高贵与堕落，竟然由一个不超过六岁，通常是三岁的孩子决定，这简直令人难以置信。但这就是“命运剧本”理论的说法。和六岁，甚至三岁的孩子聊过之后，或许会更容易相信。而环顾当今世界正在发生的事情，以及昨天发生的事情，再看看明天可能发生的事情，就更容易相信了。人类“命运剧本”的历史可以在古代遗迹、法庭和停尸房、赌场和读者来信，以及政治辩论中找到踪迹。在政治辩论中，有人试图证明父母在婴儿时期告诉他的那些道理适用于全世界，从而引导整个国家走上正义之路。但幸运的是，有些人拥有优秀的“命运剧本”，有些人甚至成功地摆脱了束缚，按照自己的方式行事。

Human destiny shows that, by diverse means, men come to the same ends, and by the same means they come to diverse ends. They carry their scripts and their counterscripts around in their heads in the form of Parental voices telling them what to do and not do, and their aspirations in the form of Child pictures of how they would like it to be, and among the three of them they put their shows on the road. There they find themselves entangled in a web of other people’s scripts: first their parents, then their spouses, and over all of them, the scripts of those who govern the places where they live. There are also chemical hazards like infectious diseases, and physical ones, such as hard objects that the human body is not constructed to withstand.

人类的命运表明，人们通过不同的途径最终殊途同归，而通过相同的途径，他们也走向不同的结局。他们的脑海中既有父母的声音告诉他们该做什么、不该做什么，也有孩童般的憧憬描绘着他们理想中的生活图景，三者交织在一起，最终将他们的人生轨迹交织在一起。在那里，他们发现自己被他人的剧本所束缚：首先是父母的剧本，然后是配偶的剧本，最后，凌驾于所有人之上的，是他们所居住之地统治者的剧本。此外，还有诸如传染病之类的化学危害，以及诸如人体无法承受的坚硬物体之类的物理危害。

The script is what the person planned to do in early childhood, and the life course is what actually happens. The life course is determined by genes, by parental background, and by external circumstances. An individual whose genes cause mental retardation, physical deformity, or early death from cancer or diabetes, will have little opportunity to make his own life decisions or to carry them through to completion. The course of his life will be determined by inheritance (or perhaps birth injury). If the parents themselves suffered from severe physical or emotional deprivation as infants, that may destroy their children’s chances of carrying out a script, or perhaps even of forming one. They may kill their offspring by neglect or abuse, or condemn them to life in an institution from an early age. Diseases, accidents, oppression, and war may terminate even the most carefully thought out and best supported life plan. So can a walk or a drive through the script of an unknown person: an assassin, thug, or car-crasher. A combination of these – genes plus oppression, for example – may close so many avenues to members of a certain line that they have few choices in planning their scripts, and it may make a tragic life course almost inevitable.

剧本指的是一个人在幼年时期所计划的人生轨迹，而人生历程则是实际发生的一切。人生历程由基因、父母背景和外部环境决定。如果一个人的基因导致智力低下、身体畸形，或因癌症或糖尿病而早逝，那么他几乎没有机会自主做出人生决定，也无法将计划贯彻到底。他的人生轨迹将由遗传（或出生时的创伤）决定。如果父母在婴儿时期遭受严重的身体或情感剥夺，这可能会摧毁他们的孩子实现人生剧本的机会，甚至可能剥夺他们形成人生剧本的机会。他们可能会因疏忽或虐待而导致子女夭折，或者从小就将他们送进福利机构。疾病、意外、压迫和战争甚至可能终结最精心策划、支持最充分的人生计划。同样，一次偶然的邂逅，例如刺客、暴徒或车祸肇事者，也可能改变一个人的人生剧本。这些因素的结合——例如基因加上压迫——可能会关闭某些血脉成员的许多道路，以至于他们在规划自己的人生剧本时几乎没有选择，这可能会使悲剧的人生轨迹几乎不可避免。

But even with strict limitations, there are nearly always some alternatives open. An aerial bomb, an epidemic, or a massacre may leave no choice at all, but at the next level, the person may be able to choose between killing, being killed, or killing himself, and there his choice will depend on his script, that is, the kind of decision he made in early childhood.

但即便面临诸多限制，几乎总会有一些其他选择。空袭、瘟疫或屠杀或许会让人别无选择，但在更高层次上，人们或许可以在杀人、被杀或自杀之间做出选择，而此时，他的选择将取决于他的“剧本”，也就是他在童年早期做出的决定。

The difference between life course and life plan can be illustrated by considering two rats used in an experiment to show that the early experiences of a mother rat can affect the behavior of her offspring. 8 The first animal was named Victor Purdue-Wistar III, or Victor for short. (Purdue-Wistar was the actual surname of the rats used in this experiment, and Victor and Arthur were the forenames of their godfathers, the experimenters.) Victor came from a long line of experimental subjects, and his genes suited him for this station in life. His mother, Victoria, had been handled and caressed when she was a pup. His distant cousin, Arthur Purdue-Wistar III (Arthur) was equally suited to being an experimental subject. His mother, Arthuria, had been left in her cage and was never handled or caressed when she was little. When the two cousins grew up, it was found that Victor weighed more, explored less, and dropped his excretions more often than Arthur did. What happened to them in the long run, after the experiment was over, is not stated, but it probably depended upon external forces, such as what the experimenters needed to use them for. Thus, their life courses were determined by their genes, their mothers’ early experiences, and decisions made by stronger forces over which they had no control and to which there was no appeal. Any ‘scripts’ or ‘plans’ they wanted to carry out as individuals were limited by all of this. Thus Victor, who liked to vegetate, could so indulge himself; while Arthur, who wanted to explore, was frustrated in his cage; and neither of them, however strong the urge, could seek for immortality through reproduction.

生命历程和生命规划之间的区别可以通过两只实验鼠的例子来说明，该实验表明母鼠的早期经历会影响其后代的行为。第一只老鼠名叫维克多·普渡-威斯塔三世（Victor Purdue-Wistar III），简称维克多（Victor）。（普渡-威斯塔是实验鼠的姓氏，维克多和亚瑟是它们的教父——实验者——的名字。）维克多出身于一个长期被用作实验对象的家族，他的基因使他适合从事实验。他的母亲维多利亚（Victoria）幼年时曾被人抚摸和照料。他的远房表亲亚瑟·普渡-威斯塔三世（简称亚瑟）同样适合作为实验对象。他的母亲阿瑟莉亚（Arthuria）幼年时被留在笼子里，从未被人抚摸或照料。当这两只表亲长大后，人们发现维克多比亚瑟体重更重，探索活动更少，排泄也更频繁。实验结束后，他们的最终命运如何，文中并未提及，但很可能取决于外部因素，例如实验者需要利用他们做什么。因此，他们的人生轨迹由基因、母亲的早期经历以及他们无法控制且无力抗衡的更强大力量所决定。他们作为个体想要执行的任何“剧本”或“计划”都受到这一切的限制。因此，喜欢安于现状的维克多得以如此；而渴望探索的亚瑟则被困于牢笼之中，倍感挫败；无论他们多么渴望，都无法通过繁衍后代来获得永生。

Tom, Dick, and Harry, distant cousins of Victor and Arthur, had a different experience. Tom was programed to press a lever in order to avoid getting an electric shock, and as a reward he would get a pellet of food. Dick was programed the same way, except that his treat was a drink of alcohol. Harry was also programed to avoid the unpleasant shock, and his reward was a pleasant shock instead. Then they were switched around so that in the long run all three of them learned all three of the programs. After that, they were put in a cage with three levers: one for food, one for alcohol, and one for the pleasant shock. Then each one could make his own ‘decision’ as to how he wanted to spend his life: eating, lying in a drunken stupor, or getting electric thrills, or any combination or alternation of these. Furthermore, there was a treadmill in the new cage, and each one could decide whether he wanted to take exercise along with his other rewards.

汤姆、迪克和哈利是维克多和亚瑟的远房表亲，他们的经历截然不同。汤姆被设定为按下控制杆以避免电击，作为奖励，他会得到一颗食物颗粒。迪克的设定也一样，只不过他的奖励是一杯酒。哈利也被设定为避免令人不快的电击，而他的奖励则是一杯令人愉悦的电击。之后，他们被互换了程序，最终三个人都学会了所有三个程序。随后，他们被关进一个笼子里，笼子里有三个控制杆：一个控制食物，一个控制酒，一个控制令人愉悦的电击。然后，每个人都可以“决定”自己想要如何度过余生：吃东西、醉醺醺地躺着、享受电击的快感，或者这三者的任意组合或交替。此外，新笼子里还有一个跑步机，每个人都可以决定是否要将锻炼与其它奖励结合起来。

This was exactly like a script decision, for each rat could decide whether he wanted to spend his life as a gourmand, an alcoholic, a thrill-seeker, or an athlete, or whether he preferred a moderate combination. But although each could follow his ‘script decision’ and take the consequences as long as he remained in the cage, the actual outcomes of their lives depended on an external force majeure , for the experimenter could interrupt the experiment and break up the ‘script’ whenever he felt like it. Thus their life courses and their life styles were largely determined by their ‘life plans’ up to the final outcome, which was decided by someone else. But these ‘life plans’ could only be chosen from among the alternatives offered by their ‘parents,’ the experimenters who programed them. And even that choice was influenced by things that had happened to them earlier.

这就像是预先设定好的剧本，每只老鼠都可以选择自己想成为美食家、酒鬼、冒险家、运动员，或者两者兼顾。虽然只要待在笼子里，每只老鼠都可以按照自己的“剧本”行事并承担后果，但它们人生的最终结局却取决于外部因素，因为实验者可以随时中断实验，打破“剧本”。因此，它们的人生轨迹和生活方式很大程度上是由它们的“人生规划”决定的，直至最终结果，而最终结果却由他人决定。但这些“人生规划”只能从它们的“父母”（即设定它们的实验者）提供的选项中选择。而且，即使是这个选择，也会受到它们之前经历的影响。

Although men are not laboratory animals, they often behave as though they are. Sometimes they are put in cages and treated like rats, manipulated and sacrificed at the will of their masters. But many times the cage has an open door, and a man has only to walk out if he wishes. If he does not, it is usually his script which keeps him there. That is familiar and reassuring, and after looking out at the great world of freedom with all its joys and dangers, he turns back to the cage with its buttons and levers, knowing that if he keeps busy pushing them, and pushes the right one at the right time, he will be assured of food, drink, and an occasional thrill. But always, such a caged person hopes or fears that some force greater than himself, the Great Experimenter or the Great Computer, will change or end it all.

虽然人并非实验室动物，但他们的行为却常常如同动物一般。有时，他们被关进笼子，像老鼠一样被对待，任由主人摆布和宰杀。但很多时候，笼门敞开，人只要愿意，随时可以走出去。如果他不愿走出去，通常是他早已习惯的命运将他困于其中。这种习惯既熟悉又令人安心，当他眺望过充满欢乐与危险的自由世界后，他又会回到笼子旁，面对着按钮和操纵杆，因为他知道，只要他不停地按压它们，并在正确的时间按下正确的按钮，就能确保获得食物、饮水，以及偶尔的刺激。然而，始终笼罩着他的，是希望或恐惧着某种超越自身的力量——伟大的实验者或伟大的计算机——能够改变或终结这一切。

The forces of human destiny are foursome and fearsome: demonic parental programing, abetted by the inner voice the ancients called the Daemon ; constructive parental programing, aided by the thrust of life called Phusis long ago; external forces, still called Fate; and independent aspirations, for which the ancients had no human name, since for them such were the privileges mainly of gods and kings. And as a resultant of these forces there are four kinds of life courses, which may be mixed, and lead to one or another kind of final destiny: scripty, counterscripty, forced, and independent.

人类命运的力量有四种，而且都十分可怕：一是父母灌输的恶魔般的程序，这种程序受到古人称之为“恶魔”的内在声音的助推；二是父母灌输的建设性程序，这种程序受到远古时期被称为“生命力”（Phusis）的推动；三是外在的力量，至今仍被称为“命运”；四是独立的抱负，古人没有给这种抱负赋予人类的名称，因为在他们看来，这主要是神和君王的特权。由于这些力量的影响，产生了四种人生轨迹，它们可以相互交织，并最终导向不同的命运：既定的、反既定的、被迫的和自主的。

G • Historical

G • 历史

As a clinician, the psychiatrist or the clinical psychologist is interested in everything that may affect the patient’s behavior. In the following chapters no attempt is made to discuss all the factors which might affect the life course of the individual, but only those which are known at present to have a strong influence on the life plan .

作为临床医生，精神科医生或临床心理学家对所有可能影响患者行为的因素都感兴趣。以下章节并非旨在探讨所有可能影响个体生命历程的因素，而仅讨论目前已知对人生规划具有显著影响的因素。

But before we go on to consider how scripts are chosen, reinforced, and put into operation, and to dissect out the elements which make them up, we should state that the idea is not entirely new. There are many allusions in classical and modern literature to the fact that all the world’s a stage and all the people in it merely players, but allusions are different from a sustained and informed investigation into the matter. Such investigations have been carried on by many psychiatrists and their pupils, but they have been unable to go very far in a systematic way because they did not have at their disposal the powerful weapons of structural analysis (diagraming and classifying transactions), game analysis (uncovering the con, the gimmick, the switch, and the payoff), and script analysis (the script matrix with the dreams, sweat shirts, trading stamps, and other elements derived from it).

但在我们深入探讨脚本是如何被选择、强化和运用，以及剖析其构成要素之前，我们应该指出，这个观点并非全新。古典和现代文学中有很多关于“世界是一个舞台，世人皆为演员”的暗示，但暗示与对这一主题进行持续深入的研究截然不同。许多精神病学家及其学生都曾进行过此类研究，但由于缺乏结构分析（绘制和分类行为图）、博弈分析（揭示骗局、噱头、转换和回报）以及脚本分析（包含梦境、运动衫、交易邮票和其他衍生元素的脚本矩阵）等强大的工具，他们始终未能系统地深入研究。

The general idea that human lives follow the patterns found in myths, legends, and fairy tales, is most elegantly elaborated in Joseph Campbell’s book, previously referred to. 9 He bases his psychological thinking mainly on Jung and Freud. Jung’s best-known ideas in this connection are the Archetypes (corresponding to the magic figures in a script) and the Persona (which is the style the script is played in). 9 The rest of Jung’s ideas are not easy to understand or to relate to real people without very special training, and even then they are subject to different interpretations. In general, Jung is in favor of thinking about myths and fairy tales, and that is an important part of his influence.

人类生活遵循神话、传说和童话故事中模式这一普遍观点，在约瑟夫·坎贝尔的著作中得到了最精辟的阐述，该书此前已提及。 9 他的心理学思想主要基于荣格和弗洛伊德。荣格在这方面最著名的理论是原型（对应于剧本中的魔法人物）和人格面具（即剧本的表演风格）。 9 荣格的其他理论，如果没有接受过非常专业的训练，很难理解或将其与现实生活联系起来，即使接受了训练，这些理论也容易产生不同的解读。总的来说，荣格倾向于思考神话和童话故事，这也是他影响深远的重要原因之一。

Freud directly relates many aspects of human living to a single drama, the Oedipus myth. In psychoanalytic language, the patient is Oedipus, a ‘character’ who exhibits ‘reactions.’ Oedipus is something going on in the patient’s head. In script analysis, Oedipus is an ongoing drama that is actually taking place right now, divided into scenes and acts, with a build-up, a climax, and an ending. It is essential for others to play their parts, and the patient sees that they do. He only knows what to say to people whose scripts match or dovetail with his own. If his script calls for him to kill a king and marry a queen, he has to find a king whose script calls for him to be killed, and a queen whose script calls for her to be stupid enough to marry him. Some of Freud’s followers, such as Glover, are beginning to recognize that Oedipus is a drama rather than merely a set of ‘reactions,’ while Rank, Campbell’s chief predecessor, showed that most important myths and fairy tales come from a single basic plot, and that this plot appears in the dreams and lives of large numbers of people all over the world.

弗洛伊德直接将人类生活的诸多方面与单一的戏剧——俄狄浦斯神话——联系起来。在精神分析的语言中，病人就是俄狄浦斯，一个展现“反应”的“角色”。俄狄浦斯是病人头脑中正在发生的事情。在剧本分析中，俄狄浦斯是一出正在上演的戏剧，它被划分为场景和幕，包含铺垫、高潮和结局。其他人扮演各自的角色至关重要，而病人也看到了这一点。他只知道该对那些剧本与他自身剧本相符或契合的人说什么。如果他的剧本要求他弑君娶王后，他就必须找到一个剧本要求他被杀的国王，以及一个剧本要求她愚蠢到嫁给他的王后。弗洛伊德的一些追随者，如格洛弗，开始认识到俄狄浦斯是一出戏剧，而不仅仅是一系列“反应”。而坎贝尔的主要前辈兰克则表明，大多数重要的神话和童话都源于一个基本情节，而这个情节出现在世界各地大量人群的梦境和生活中。

Freud speaks of the repetition compulsion and the destiny compulsion, but his followers have not pursued these ideas very far to apply them to the entire life courses of their patients. Erikson is the most active psychoanalyst in making systematic studies of the human life-cycle from birth to death, and naturally, many of his findings are corroborated by script analysis. In general, it may be said that script analysis is Freudian, but it is not psychoanalytic.

弗洛伊德谈到重复强迫和命运强迫，但他的追随者并没有深入研究这些概念，将其应用于患者的整个生命历程。埃里克森是系统研究人类从出生到死亡生命周期的最活跃的精神分析学家，他的许多发现自然也得到了脚本分析的佐证。总的来说，可以说脚本分析是弗洛伊德式的，但它并非精神分析。

Of all those who preceded transactional analysis, Alfred Adler comes the closest to talking like a script analyst.

在人际沟通分析理论出现之前的所有理论家当中，阿尔弗雷德·阿德勒的理论最接近于剧本分析师的风格。

If I know the goal of a person I know in a general way what will happen. I am in a position to bring into their proper order each of the successive movements made … We must remember that the person under observation would not know what to do with himself were he not oriented toward some goal … which determines his lifeline … the psychic life of man is made to fit into the fifth act like a character drawn by a good dramatist … every psychic phenomenon, if it is to give us any understanding of a person, can only be grasped and understood if regarded as a preparation for some goal … an attempt at a planned final compensation and a (secret) life plan … the life plan remains in the unconscious, so that the patient may believe that an implacable fate and not a long-prepared and long-meditated plan for which he alone is responsible, is at work … Such a man concludes his account and reconciles himself with life by constructing one or a number of ‘if-clauses.’ ‘If conditions had been different …’

如果我知道一个人的目标，我就能大致了解将会发生什么。我能够将他/她接下来的每一个举动都按其应有的顺序排列……我们必须记住，如果被观察的人没有某个目标，他/她将不知所措……这个目标决定了他的人生轨迹……人的精神生活就像一位优秀剧作家笔下的人物，注定要融入第五幕……任何精神现象，如果想要让我们对一个人有所了解，就只能将其视为为某个目标所做的准备……一种对最终补偿的计划和（秘密的）人生规划……这个人生规划存在于潜意识中，因此患者可能会认为，起作用的是无情的命运，而不是他/她自己精心准备和深思熟虑的计划……这样的人会通过构建一个或多个“如果”来结束自己的叙述，并与生活和解。“如果情况不同……”

The only exceptions which a script analyst would take to these statements are (1) that the life plan is usually not unconscious; (2) that the person is by no means solely responsible for it; and (3) that the goal and the manner of reaching it (the actual transactions, word for word) can be predicted much more precisely than even Adler claimed. 9

脚本分析师对这些说法唯一提出的例外是：（1）人生规划通常并非无意识的；（2）个人绝非对此负有全部责任；（3）目标及其实现方式（实际的言行）的预测精度甚至远超阿德勒的断言。

Recently, R. D. Laing, the British psychiatrist, has described in a radio broadcast a view of life which is amazingly similar, even in its terminology, to the theory discussed in this book. For example, he uses the word ‘injunction’ for strong parental programing. 10 Since, at this writing, he has not yet published these ideas, it is not possible to evaluate them properly.

最近，英国精神病学家R·D·莱恩在一次广播节目中描述了一种人生观，这种人生观与本书讨论的理论惊人地相似，甚至连术语都如出一辙。例如，他用“禁令”（injunction）一词来指代强烈的父母教化。 10 由于截至本文撰写之时，他尚未发表这些观点，因此无法对其进行恰当的评价。

Far older than all these, however, are the script analysts of ancient India, who based their prognostications largely on astrology. As the Panchatantra very aptly says, about 200 B.C.E. :

然而，比所有这些都更古老的是古印度的文字分析家，他们的预测主要基于占星术。正如《五卷书》非常恰当地记载，大约在公元前200年：

These five are fixed for every man

这五点对每个男人来说都是固定的。

Before he leaves the womb:

在他离开母体之前：

His length of days, his fate, his wealth,

他的寿命、他的命运、他的财富

His learning, and his tomb. 11

他的学识，以及他的陵墓。

We need only make some slight changes to bring this up to date.

我们只需要做一些小小的改动就能让它与时俱进。

These five are taken from your sires,

这五个名字取自你的祖先。

Six summers from the womb:

从子宫里到现在的六个夏天：

Your length of days, your fate, your wealth,

你的生命长度、你的命运、你的财富

Your learning, and your tomb.

你的学问，以及你的坟墓。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 For a discussion of the use of transactional analysis in the theater, see Schechner, R. ‘Approaches to Theory/Criticism.’ Tulane Drama Review 10: Summer 1966, pp. 20–53. Also Wagner, A. ‘Transactional Analysis and Acting.’ Ibid. 11: Summer 1967, pp. 81–88, and Berne, E. ‘Notes on Games and Theater,’ in the same issue, pp. 89–91.

1 关于在戏剧中使用交互分析的讨论，参见 Schechner, R. ‘Approaches to Theory/Criticism.’ Tulane Drama Review 10: Summer 1966, pp. 20–53. 另见 Wagner, A. ‘Transactional Analysis and Acting.’ Ibid. 11: Summer 1967, pp. 81–88，以及 Berne, E. ‘Notes on Games and Theater,’ in the same issue, pp. 89–91。

2 Wagner, A. ‘Permission and Protection,’ The Drama Review 13: Spring 1969, pp. 108–110, incorporates some of the more recent advances. For the direct application of transactional script theory to dramatic scripts, see the same issue pp. 110–114: Steiner, C. M. ‘A Script Checklist,’ and Cheney, W. D. ‘Hamlet: His Script Checklist.’ Both articles are reprinted from the Transactional Analysis Bulletin (Vol. 6, April, 1967, and Vol. 7, July, 1968).

2 Wagner, A. 的文章《许可与保护》（载于《戏剧评论》第13卷，1969年春季刊，第108-110页）纳入了一些最新的研究进展。关于将交互脚本理论直接应用于戏剧剧本，请参见同一期第110-114页：Steiner, C. M. 的《剧本检查清单》和 Cheney, W. D. 的《哈姆雷特：他的剧本检查清单》。这两篇文章均转载自《交互分析公报》（第6卷，1967年4月；第7卷，1968年7月）。

3 For a historical consideration of one aspect of ‘good guys’ and ‘bad guys,’ see my article ‘The Mythology of Dark and Fair: Psychiatric Use of Folklore,’ Journal of American Folklore 1–12, 1959. This gives a bibliography of about 100 items, including a few of the early psychoanalytic articles on fairy tales.

3 关于“好人”和“坏人”某一方面的历史考证，请参阅我的文章《黑暗与光明的神话：民间传说的精神病学应用》，载于《美国民俗学杂志》1-12，1959 年。该文章列出了约 100 项参考文献，其中包括一些早期关于童话的精神分析文章。

Geza Roheim is the most prolific writer on the folk tales of primitive people. See Roheim, G., Psychoanalysis and Anthropology , International Universities Press, New York, 1950.

盖扎·罗海姆是研究原始民族民间故事最多产的作家。参见罗海姆，《精神分析与人类学》，国际大学出版社，纽约，1950年。

4 I do not pretend to be enough of a scholar to give a complete variorum or an authorized version of the stories of Europa, Amymone, Little Red Riding Hood, and Sleeping Beauty. Even the color of Europa’s bull varies in different accounts between white and gold. The versions given above suffice for the present purpose. The sources of Europa and Amymone are as follows:

4 我不敢妄称自己是博学之士，无法提供欧罗巴、阿米莫涅、小红帽和睡美人故事的完整版本或权威版本。甚至欧罗巴的公牛的颜色在不同的版本中也有不同的说法，从白色到金色不等。以上版本已足以满足当前的需求。欧罗巴和阿米莫涅的故事来源如下：

Bulfinch’s Mythology , Graves’ The Greek Myths , Hamilton’s Mythology , Lemprière’s Classical Dictionary (London, 1818), Hesiod and Moschus (Family Classical Library No. XXX, London, 1832), Ovid’s Metamorphoses , and my mother’s copy of Edwards’ Handbook of Mythology with the title page missing (Eldredge & Brothers, date unknown).

布尔芬奇的《神话》、格雷夫斯的《希腊神话》、汉密尔顿的《神话》、伦普里埃的《古典词典》（伦敦，1818 年）、赫西俄德和莫斯库斯（家庭古典图书馆第 XXX 号，伦敦，1832 年）、奥维德的《变形记》，以及我母亲那本缺了扉页的爱德华兹《神话手册》（埃尔德里奇兄弟出版社，日期不详）。

LRRH comes out of Andrew Lang’s Blue Fairy Book , The Grimms’ Fairy Tales (Grosset & Dunlap edition), and Funk & Wagnalls’ Standard Dictionary of Folklore, Mythology, and Legend (New York, 1950). In France she is known as ‘Petit Chaperon Rouge,’ or ‘Little Red Hood’ (Perrault, 1697) and in Germany as ‘Rotkäppchen,’ or ‘Little Red Cap.’

小红帽（LRRH）的故事出自安德鲁·朗的《蓝色童话书》、格林童话（格罗塞特和邓拉普版）以及芬克和瓦格纳尔的《民俗、神话和传说标准词典》（纽约，1950年）。在法国，她被称为“Petit Chaperon Rouge”（佩罗，1697年），在德国则被称为“Rotkäppchen”（小红帽）。

The psychoanalysts’ tendency to focus on filling the wolf’s belly with stones is irrelevant to the present purpose, and this episode sounds to me like an interpolation, anyway. The psychoanalytic literature on LRRH starts with two papers in 1912, one by O. Rank and the other by M. Wulff, followed by Freud’s paper on ‘The Occurrence in Dreams of Material from Fairy Tales’ (1913), most easily available in the paperback edition of his Delusion and Dream (Beacon Press, Boston, 1956). One of the best-known discussions is that of Erich Fromm in The Forgotten Language (Grove Press, New York, 1951). Fromm says: ‘Most of the symbolism in this fairy tale can be understood without difficulty. The “little cap of red velvet” is a symbol of menstruation.’ He does not state by whom it can be understood without difficulty, or to whom it is a symbol of menstruation. A recent paper by L. Veszy-Wagner, ‘Little Red Riding Hood on the Couch’ ( Psychoanalytic Forum 1:399–415, 1966), at least gives case material, although it is not convincing. Probably the best suggestions are offered by Elizabeth Crawford in her paper ‘The Wolf As Condensation’ ( American Imago , 12:307–314, 1955).

精神分析学家们倾向于用石头填满狼的肚子，但这与本文的目的无关，而且在我看来，这段内容听起来像是后人添加的。关于《小红帽与月经》的精神分析文献始于1912年的两篇论文，一篇是O. Rank的，另一篇是M. Wulff的，之后是弗洛伊德1913年发表的论文《童话故事素材在梦中的出现》，这篇论文最容易找到，收录于他的《妄想与梦》（Beacon出版社，波士顿，1956年）平装版中。最著名的论述之一是埃里希·弗洛姆在《被遗忘的语言》（Grove出版社，纽约，1951年）中的论述。弗洛姆说：“这则童话故事中的大部分象征意义都很容易理解。‘红色天鹅绒小帽子’象征着月经。”但他没有说明谁能轻易理解这个象征意义，也没有说明对谁而言，这个象征意义是月经的象征。 L. Veszy-Wagner 近期发表的论文《沙发上的小红帽》（《精神分析论坛》1:399–415，1966）至少提供了案例材料，尽管并不令人信服。Elizabeth Crawford 在其论文《作为凝缩的狼》（《美国意象》12:307–314，1955）中提出的建议或许最为精辟。

In real life, wolves are not as bad as they appear in fairy tales. See ‘Wolves Social as Dogs … can be taught to be friendly to people,’ by P. McBroom, Science News 90:174, September 10, 1966. This summarizes the studies of G. B. Raab and J. H. Woolpy on the social lives of wolves, from which it appears that wolves also play transactional games. Specifically, outcast wolves play ‘Wooden Leg,’ limping as though to ask for special consideration.

现实生活中，狼并不像童话故事里那样邪恶。参见P. McBroom发表于1966年9月10日《科学新闻》90:174的文章《狼和狗一样具有社交性……可以被训练成对人友好》。这篇文章总结了G. B. Raab和J. H. Woolpy对狼社会生活的研究，研究表明狼也会玩交易游戏。具体来说，被排斥的狼会玩“假腿游戏”，跛着脚走路，仿佛在寻求特殊照顾。

5 ‘Sleeping Beauty’ or ‘Briar Rose’ again comes from Andrew Lang’s Blue Fairy Book and the Grimms. There is an expanded version, with sinister illustrations by Arthur Rackham, which is also very popular.

5.《睡美人》或《荆棘玫瑰》同样出自安德鲁·朗的《蓝皮童话书》和格林兄弟的童话故事。还有一个由亚瑟·拉克姆绘制了阴森插图的扩展版本，也非常受欢迎。

6 For further information about the recent use of fairy tales in psychiatry, see Heuscher, J. A Psychiatric Study of Fairy Tales . C. C. Thomas, Springfield, 1963. This gives an existential symbolic interpretation. D. Dinnerstein’s analysis of the story of ‘The Little Mermaid’ ( Contemporary Psychoanalysis 104–112, 1967), uses a ‘maturational’ approach which involves some of the elements related to the evolution of a script.

6 关于近期童话故事在精神病学中的应用，详见Heuscher, J.，《童话故事的精神病学研究》，C. C. Thomas出版社，斯普林菲尔德，1963年。该书给出了存在主义的象征性解释。D. Dinnerstein对《小美人鱼》故事的分析（《当代精神分析》，104-112页，1967年）采用了一种“成熟”方法，其中涉及一些与剧本演变相关的要素。

Most directly connected with script analysis, however, is the work of H. Dieckmann, who relates fairy tales to the life patterns of his patients in a systematic way. See Dieckmann, H. ‘Das Lieblingsmärchen der Kindheit und seine Beziehung zu Neurose und Persönlichkeit.’ Praxis der Kinderpsychologie und Kinderpsychiatrie 6:202–208, August–September, 1967. Also Märchen und Träume als Helfer des Menschen . Bonz Verlag, Stuttgart, 1966.

然而，与剧本分析最直接相关的是 H. Dieckmann 的作品，他系统地将童话故事与患者的生活模式联系起来。参见 Dieckmann, H. ‘Das Lieblingsmärchen der Kindheit und seine Beziehung zu Neurose und Persönlichkeit.’ Praxis der Kinderpsychologie und Kinderpsychiatrie 6:202–208, August–September, 1967。还有 Märchen und Träume als Helfer des Menschen。 Bonz 出版社，斯图加特，1966 年。

7 Cf. Flugel, J.C.: The Psychoanalytic Study of the Family . Hogarth Press, London, 1921.

7 参见 Flugel, J.C.:《家庭的精神分析研究》。伦敦霍加斯出版社，1921 年。

8 Denenberg, V. H. and Whimby, A. E.: ‘Behavior of Adult Rats is Modified by the Experiences Their Mothers Had as Infants,’ Science 142:1192–1193, November 29, 1963.

8 Denenberg, V. H. 和 Whimby, A. E.:‘成年大鼠的行为受其母亲婴儿时期经历的影响’，《科学》142:1192–1193，1963 年 11 月 29 日。

9 The bibliography for the historical background of the script concept is as follows:

9. 剧本概念历史背景的参考书目如下：

Adler, A. ‘Individual Psychology’ in The World of Psychology , ed. G. B. Levitas, George Braziller, New York, 1963.

阿德勒，A.《个体心理学》，载于《心理学世界》，G.B.莱维塔斯编辑，乔治·布拉齐勒出版社，纽约，1963年。

Campbell, J. The Hero With A Thousand Faces . Pantheon Books, New York, 1949.

坎贝尔，J.《千面英雄》。万神殿出版社，纽约，1949年。

Erikson, E. Childhood and Society . W. W. Norton & Company, New York, 1950.

埃里克森，E.《童年与社会》。纽约：W. W. Norton & Company，1950年。

Freud, S. Beyond the Pleasure Principle . International Psychoanalytical Press, London, 1922.

弗洛伊德，S.《超越快乐原则》。国际精神分析出版社，伦敦，1922年。

Glover, E. The Technique of Psycho-Analysis . International Universities Press, New York, 1955.

格洛弗，E.《精神分析技术》。国际大学出版社，纽约，1955年。

Jung, C. G. Psychological Types . Harcourt, Brace & Company, New York, 1946.

荣格，C.G.心理类型。哈考特、布雷斯公司，纽约，1946年。

Rank, O. The Myth of the Birth of the Hero . Nervous and Mental Disease Monographs, New York, 1910.

Rank, O.《英雄诞生的神话》。神经和精神疾病专著，纽约，1910 年。

10 First used in this connection by C. M. Steiner ( Transactional Analysis Bulletin 5:133, April 1966).

10 C. M. Steiner 首次将此用于此领域（《交易分析公报》5:133，1966 年 4 月）。

11 Panchatantra , trans. A. W. Ryder. University of Chicago Press, 1925, p. 237. Although these fables are dated back to 200 B.C.E. , this version is from a manuscript of A.D. 1199, probably from the Hebrew codex. The five-book original is lost, but many of the tales are repeated in the four-book medieval Hitopadesa . Some date the Sanskrit original as late as A.D. 300.

11 《五卷书》，A. W. Ryder 译，芝加哥大学出版社，1925 年，第 237 页。虽然这些寓言故事可追溯至公元前 200 年，但此版本出自公元 1199 年的一份手稿，很可能源自希伯来文抄本。五卷本原著已佚失，但其中许多故事在四卷本中世纪《希托帕德沙》中有所记载。一些学者认为梵文原著的成书时间晚至公元 300 年。

fn1 Personally, I prefer Lemprière’s Classical Dictionary (Tenth edition, 1818).

fn1 我个人更喜欢伦普里埃的古典词典（第十版，1818 年）。

fn2 This may occur when mother has no son of her own to play Jocasta with, and similarly if father has no daughter of his own.

fn2 当母亲没有自己的儿子可以一起玩伊俄卡斯忒游戏时，或者当父亲没有自己的女儿时，都可能发生这种情况。

#↩

CHAPTER FOUR

第四章

Prenatal Influences

产前影响

A • Introductory

A • 引言

The script scene began long ages past, when life first oozed out of the mud and began to transmit the results of its experiences chemically, through genes, to its descendants. This chemical branch culminated in the spider, who spins his strange circular geometry without instruction, the coiled spirals in his chromosomes supplying him with instant engineering drawings that will bridge any corner where the flies abound. 1 In his case, the script is written in fixed molecules of organic acids (DNA) bequeathed him by his parents, and he spends his life as an educated pen point, carrying out their instructions with no possibility of deviation or improvement except by drugs or some untoward accident beyond his control.

剧本的场景始于遥远的过去，那时生命从泥沼中渗出，开始通过基因以化学方式将自身的经历传递给后代。这一化学分支最终演化成蜘蛛，它无需指令就能织出奇特的圆形几何图案，其染色体中的螺旋结构为它提供了即时的工程图纸，足以跨越任何苍蝇横行的角落。 1 就蜘蛛而言，剧本是用父母留给它的固定有机酸分子（DNA）书写的，它终其一生都像一支受过教育的笔尖，执行着父母的指令，除了药物或一些无法控制的意外事故外，没有任何偏离或改进的可能。

In man, too, the genes determine chemically some of the patterns he must follow, and from which he cannot deviate. They also set the upper limit for his individual aspirations: how far he can go as an athlete, thinker, or musician, for example, although because of psychological barriers great or small, few men reach their full possibilities even in these fields. Many a man with the chemistry of a great ballet dancer spends his time dancing with other people’s dishes in a lunchroom, and others with the genes of a mathematician pass their days juggling other people’s papers in the back room of a bank or bookie joint. But within his chemical limitations, whatever they are, each man has enormous possibilities for determining his own fate. Usually, however, his parents decide it for him long before he can see what they are doing.

在人类身上，基因也从化学层面决定了他必须遵循的一些模式，而这些模式是他无法偏离的。基因也设定了他个人抱负的上限：例如，作为运动员、思想家或音乐家，他能达到什么高度。然而，由于各种程度的心理障碍，即使在这些领域，也很少有人能充分发挥自己的潜力。许多拥有芭蕾舞演员般天赋的人，却只能在餐厅里摆弄别人的餐具；而另一些拥有数学家基因的人，却只能在银行或博彩公司的后台处理别人的文件。但是，无论这些基因限制是什么，每个人都拥有巨大的潜力去决定自己的命运。然而，通常情况下，父母在他能够理解父母的所作所为之前，就已经替他做出了决定。

As life broke free to some extent from rigid chemical patterns, other ways of regulating behavior gradually evolved to take up the slack. The most primitive of these is probably imprinting, which is barely one step beyond a reflex. 2 Imprinting assures that an infant organism will automatically follow a certain object and treat it like a mother, whether it is really his mother or merely a yellow card drawn past him on a string. This automatic response helps to insure his survival in moments of stress, but if it goes awry it can make trouble, too.

随着生命在某种程度上摆脱了僵化的化学模式，其他行为调节方式逐渐进化出来以填补空白。其中最原始的或许是印刻，它几乎与反射无异。印刻确保幼体会自动跟随某个物体，并将其视为母亲，无论该物体真的是它的母亲，还是仅仅是一张用绳子拉过它的黄牌。这种自动反应有助于确保幼体在压力时刻的生存，但如果出现偏差，也会造成麻烦。

The next step came when some animals stayed with their mothers and learned through play; patterns too complex or variable to be transmitted through the genes could be taught with a playful bite or roll or a box on the ear. 3 Then came imitation and a response to voice signals, so that the young could do not only what their genes prompted them to, and what they learned at their mothers’ breasts, but also what they saw and heard in the real living of the seas and plains and forests.

下一步是当一些动物留在母亲身边并通过玩耍学习时；那些过于复杂或多变而无法通过基因传递的行为模式，可以通过玩耍时的轻咬、翻滚或用盒子敲打耳朵来传授。 3 随后出现了模仿和对声音信号的反应，这样幼崽不仅能够做到基因驱使它们去做的事情，以及在母亲乳房上学到的东西，还能做到在海洋、平原和森林的真实生活中所见所闻。

It is now known that almost every kind of living organism can be trained. Bacteria can be ‘trained’ chemically to use one kind of sugar as a substitute for another. Almost all other animals, from worms on up, can be trained psychologically, by conditioned reflexes, to go through new and special patterns of behavior. This is probably, in the long run, chemical, too, and depends on more flexible kinds of DNA than are found in the genes. But training requires trainers, and they are something else. They have to be one cut or dimension above the organisms they are training. This means they must be tamed. Taming is as different from training as a cat is from a tiger. Taming, in animals, means that the animal obeys his master even when his master isn’t there. This is different from training, because training requires an outside stimulus to start off a certain pattern of behavior, while taming assures the behavior because the stimulus is inside the animal’s head. A trained animal will obey his master’s voice when he hears it out loud; a tamed one doesn’t need to hear the sound, because he carries it around in his brain. Thus, wild animals can be trained to do tricks at their trainer’s command, but they cannot easily be house-broken. Tame animals go further than that; they can be taught to behave as their master wishes even when he is away. There are various degrees of tameness, and the tamest animals of all are human children.

现在我们知道，几乎所有种类的生物都可以被训练。细菌可以通过化学方法“训练”，用一种糖代替另一种糖。几乎所有其他动物，从蠕虫到大型动物，都可以通过条件反射进行心理训练，从而养成新的、特殊的行为模式。从长远来看，这可能也与化学有关，并且依赖于比基因中更灵活的DNA。但是，训练需要训练者，而训练者本身就与生物体不同。他们必须比被训练的生物体高出一个层次或维度。这意味着他们必须被驯服。驯服与训练的区别就像猫与老虎的区别一样。在动物身上，驯服意味着动物即使在主人不在场的情况下也会服从主人。这与训练不同，因为训练需要外部刺激来启动某种行为模式，而驯服则确保了行为的发生，因为刺激存在于动物的内心。一只受过训练的动物会在听到主人的声音时服从它；驯服的动物不需要听到声音，因为它们的大脑里就储存着声音信息。因此，野生动物可以被训练成听从驯兽员的指令表演各种把戏，但它们很难被驯服成家畜。驯服的动物则更进一步；即使主人不在身边，它们也能被训练成按照主人的意愿行事。驯服的程度各不相同，而最驯服的动物莫过于人类孩童。

The most intelligent animals – monkeys, apes, and people (and maybe dolphins too) – have another special capacity, and that is invention. This means that they can do things that none of their kind has ever done before: anything from piling one wooden box on another, to putting two rods together to form a longer one, 4 to shooting for the moon.

最聪明的动物——猴子、猿类和人类（或许还有海豚）——都拥有另一种特殊能力，那就是创造。这意味着它们可以做到同类从未做过的事情：从把一个木箱堆在另一个木箱上，到把两根木棍连接起来形成一根更长的木棍，再到射向月球，无所不能。

In order to account for this progression, we can assume that DNA is evolving into ever softer and more pliable forms. Starting out as the brittle molecules of genes, which cannot be molded, but only shattered, it thawed out enough so that it could be slightly altered by repeated gentle blows of conditioning, although it would spring back if these were not reinforced from time to time. Then it softened still more so that it could record the echoes of vanished voices and events, and keep them there for a lifetime, long after they were forgotten. In still more flexible form, it became the vehicle for memory and consciousness. And in its most sensitive form to date, it shifts and vibrates in the zephyrs of experience to give us thinking and invention. What will come forth when it becomes even more delicate in its responses none of us now living will ever know, but some day our descendants will be wondrous beings that only poets presently can dimly contemplate.

为了解释这种演进，我们可以假设DNA正在进化成越来越柔软、越来越灵活的形式。最初，它是脆弱的基因分子，无法被塑造，只能破碎。后来，它逐渐变得柔软，能够通过反复的、轻柔的条件反射进行轻微的改变，但如果这些条件反射没有得到强化，它又会恢复原状。之后，它变得更加柔软，能够记录那些消逝的声音和事件的回响，并将它们永远保存下来，即使它们早已被遗忘。在更加灵活的形态下，它成为了记忆和意识的载体。而在其迄今为止最敏感的形态下，它在经验的微风中波动振动，赋予我们思考和创造的能力。当它对事物的反应变得更加敏锐时，将会出现什么，我们现在活着的人都无从知晓，但总有一天，我们的后代将成为奇妙的存在，而如今只有诗人才能隐约地想象它们。

Human beings have all the capacities mentioned above. Their behavior patterns are determined by rigid reflex genes, primitive imprinting, infant play and imitation, parental training, social taming, and spontaneous invention. Scripts involve all of these. The typical human being, whom we will call ‘Jeder,’ represents nearly every member of the human race in every soil and clime. He carries out his script because it is planted in his head at an early age by his parents, and stays there for the rest of his life, even after their vocal ‘flesh’ has gone forevermore. It acts like a computer tape or a player-piano roll, which brings out the responses in the planned order long after the person who punched the holes has departed the scene. Jeder meanwhile sits before the piano, moving his fingers along the keyboard under the illusion that it is he who brings the folksy ballad or the stately concerto to its foregone conclusion.

人类具备上述所有能力。他们的行为模式由僵化的反射基因、原始印记、婴儿游戏和模仿、父母教养、社会驯化以及自发创造共同决定。所有这些因素都构成了“脚本”。我们称典型的人类为“耶德”，他几乎代表了所有生活在不同土壤和气候中的人类。他之所以执行自己的“脚本”，是因为它由父母在幼年时期植入他的脑海，并伴随他一生，即便父母的“血肉之躯”永远离世。它就像电脑磁带或自动钢琴卷轴，即使打孔的人早已离开，也能按照预先设定的顺序播放出相应的乐曲。与此同时，“耶德”坐在钢琴前，手指在键盘上飞舞，他误以为自己才是演奏民谣或庄严协奏曲的人，并最终完成了早已注定的乐章。

B • Ancestral Influences

B • 祖先的影响

Some scripts can be traced back in a clinical interview to the great-grandparents, and if the family has a recorded history, as is often the case with kings and their courtiers, it may go back a thousand years in time. No doubt scripts began when the first manlike creatures appeared on earth, 5 and there is no reason to suspect that their scenes and acts and outcomes were different then than they are now. Certainly the life courses of the kings of Egypt, which are the oldest reliable biographies we have, are typical scripts. The story of Amenhotep IV, 3500 years in the past, who changed his name to Ikhnaton is a good example. 6 By this change he brought on both greatness and the fury of those who followed him. If information about remote ancestors, or the great-grandparents, can be obtained, so much the better for the script analysis, but in ordinary practice, in most cases, it starts with the grandparents.

有些剧本可以通过临床访谈追溯到曾祖父母辈，如果家族有文字记载的历史（例如国王及其朝臣的家族），其历史甚至可以追溯到一千年前。毫无疑问，剧本的起源可以追溯到地球上第一批类人生物出现之时，而且没有理由怀疑当时的剧本场景、行为和结局与现在有所不同。埃及国王的生平事迹，作为我们现存最古老、最可靠的传记，无疑是典型的剧本。3500年前的阿蒙霍特普四世的故事就是一个很好的例子，他将自己的名字改为伊赫那顿。这一改变既带来了他的伟大，也招致了后人的愤怒。如果能够获得关于远祖或曾祖父母的信息，对剧本分析将大有裨益，但在通常情况下，大多数情况下，剧本分析都是从祖父母辈开始的。

It is common knowledge, even proverbial, how much grandparents, alive or dead, influence the lives of their grandchildren. For a good script, ‘To make a lady, start with the grandmother,’ and for a bad one, ‘From shirtsleeves to shirtsleeves in three generations.’ Many children at an early age not only want to imitate their forebears, but would like actually to be their own grandparents. 7 This desire may not only have a strong influence on their life scripts, but it may cause considerable confusion in their relationships with their parents. 8 American mothers in particular, it is said, favor their fathers over their husbands, and encourage their sons to take after grandfather instead of Dad. 9

众所周知，祖父母（无论在世与否）对孙辈的生活影响巨大，这几乎已成为一句老生常谈。一句好谚语是“要想成为淑女，先从祖母做起”，一句坏谚语则是“三代人都是衣衫褴褛”。许多孩子从小不仅想模仿祖辈，甚至渴望成为自己的祖父母。这种愿望不仅会深刻影响他们的人生轨迹，还可能导致他们与父母关系出现诸多混乱。据说，美国母亲尤其偏爱父亲而非丈夫，并鼓励儿子效仿祖父而非父亲。

The most productive single question to ask in regard to ancestral influences is ‘What kind of lives did your grandparents lead?’ There are four types of reports commonly given in answer to this.

关于祖先的影响，最有效的一个问题是“你的祖父母过着怎样的生活？”。对此，通常会给出四种类型的回答。

1. Ancestral Pride . A winner or ‘prince’ will state in a matter-of-fact way, ‘My ancestors were kings of Ireland,’ or ‘My great-great-grandfather was the Chief Rabbi of Lublin.’ It is apparent that the speaker has ‘permission’ to follow in the footsteps of these ancestors and become an outstanding personality. If the statement is made pompously or solemnly, however, the speaker is probably a loser or ‘frog,’ and is using his ancestry to justify his existence because he himself does not have ‘permission’ to excel.

1. 祖先荣耀。成功者或“王子”会以一种不容置疑的语气说道：“我的祖先是爱尔兰国王”，或者“我的曾曾祖父是卢布林的首席拉比”。显然，说话者“有资格”追随先辈的脚步，成为杰出人物。然而，如果这种说法显得傲慢或庄重，那么说话者很可能是一个失败者或“青蛙”，他只是在用自己的血统来证明自己的存在，因为他自己并没有“资格”去取得卓越成就。

If the response is: ‘(My mother was always telling me that) my ancestors were Irish kings, ha, ha,’ or ‘(My mother was always telling me that) my great-great-grandfather was the Chief Rabbi, ha, ha,’ it is usually given from a not-OK position; the speaker is allowed to imitate his illustrious ancestors, but only in their losing characteristics. These replies may mean: ‘I’m as drunk as an Irish king should be, so that makes me like an Irish king, ha ha!’ or ‘I’m as poor as a Chief Rabbi should be, so that makes me like a Chief Rabbi, ha ha!’ In such cases, the early programing was: ‘You’re descended from Irish kings, and they were great drinkers,’ or ‘You’re descended from a Chief Rabbi, and they were very poor.’ This is equivalent to a directive: ‘Be like your famous ancestor …’ with the clear implication from mother ‘… so drink a lot, your father does,’ or ‘… so don’t make money, your father doesn’t.’

如果回答是：“（我母亲总是告诉我）我的祖先是爱尔兰国王，哈哈”，或者“（我母亲总是告诉我）我的曾曾祖父是首席拉比，哈哈”，这通常是出于一种不赞同的态度；说话者可以模仿他杰出的祖先，但只能模仿他们失败的特征。这些回答可能意味着：“我喝得像个爱尔兰国王，所以我就像个爱尔兰国王，哈哈！”或者“我穷得像个首席拉比，所以我就像个首席拉比，哈哈！”在这种情况下，早期的潜意识灌输是：“你是爱尔兰国王的后裔，他们都是嗜酒如命的人。”或者“你是首席拉比的后裔，他们非常贫穷。”这相当于一条指令：“要像你著名的祖先那样……”母亲的言外之意是“……所以要多喝酒，你父亲就是这么做的。”或者“……所以不要赚钱，你父亲也不赚钱。”

In all these cases the ancestor is a family euhemerus, 10 a heroic model from the past who can be imitated but never surpassed, and these are different ways that people deal with euhemeri.

在所有这些例子中，祖先都是家族的英雄， 10 是过去可以模仿但永远无法超越的英雄榜样，而这些是人们对待英雄的不同方式。
