Similarly ‘Come and See How Cute’ means ‘Put on a good show!’ ‘Hurry Up’ and ‘You Can Just Sit There Till You Do’ are negative commands or injunctions: ‘Don’t keep me waiting!’ and ‘Don’t talk back!’ ‘Let Him Take His Time,’ however, is a license of permission. He understands these differences first from his parents’ reactions, and later, when he has vocabulary, from their actual words.

例如，第五章开头提到的许多训练口号实际上都是父母的指令。“公开表演”实际上是一个炫耀的指令。孩子很快就会通过观察母亲在他表演时表现出的喜悦和在他表演失败时表现出的失望来理解这一点。同样，“快来看我多可爱”的意思是“好好表现！”。“快点”和“你就坐在那儿等着吧”是否定性的指令或命令：“别让我等！”和“别顶嘴！”。然而，“让他慢慢来”则是一种许可。孩子首先从父母的反应中理解这些区别，后来，当他有了词汇量之后，就从父母的话语中理解了这些区别。

The child is born free, but he soon learns different. During the first two years he is programed mainly by his mother. This program forms the original skeleton, or anlage, of his script, the ‘primal protocol,’ at first concerned with swallowing or being swallowed, and then, when he gets teeth, with tearing or being torn. It is being a hammer or being an anvil, as Goethe put it, the most primitive versions of being a winner or being a loser, as seen in Greek myths and Primal Rituals, where children are devoured and the limbs of the poet lie scattered on the ground. Even in the nursery, it is often already apparent who is in control, the mother or the baby. This may be reversed sooner or later, but echoes of the original situation can still be heard in times of stress or temper. But very few people can remember anything from this period, which in many ways is the most important, so it has to be reconstructed with the help of parents, relatives, nursemaids, and pediatricians, conjectures made about dreams, and perhaps the family album.

孩子生而自由，但很快就会明白并非如此。在最初的两年里，他的行为模式主要由母亲塑造。这种塑造构成了他行为模式的雏形，或者说是“原始程序”，最初关注的是吞咽或被吞咽，后来，当他长出牙齿后，则关注的是撕咬或被撕咬。正如歌德所说，这就像锤子或铁砧，是最原始的胜负模式，正如希腊神话和原始仪式中所展现的那样，孩子们被吞噬，诗人的肢体散落在地。即使在育儿室里，通常也已经能看出谁在掌控局面——是母亲还是婴儿。这种情况或许迟早会发生逆转，但在压力或情绪激动时，我们仍然能听到最初这种状态的回响。但很少有人能记住这段时期的事情，而这段时期在很多方面都是最重要的，因此必须借助父母、亲戚、保姆和儿科医生的帮助，以及对梦境的推测，或许还有家庭相册来重建这段时期。

From two to six the ground is firmer, because nearly everyone remembers a few transactions, incidents, or impressions from that phase of script development, which parallels and is closely connected with the progress of the Oedipus complex. In fact, after weaning and toilet training, the directives which are most universal throughout the world and have the most lasting effects are those concerned with sexuality and aggression. The organism and the species survive by means of circuits which have been built in by natural selection. Since nursing, sex, and fighting require the presence of another person, they are ‘social’ activities. These urges give character or quality to the individual: acquisitiveness, maleness and femaleness, and aggressiveness. Also built in are circuits which tone down such urges. These give rise to the opposite tendencies: renunciation, reticence, and restraint. Those qualities enable people to live together at least part of the time in reasonable tranquillity, a dull roar of competition rather than an unmitigated and unremitting bedlam of grabbing, copulation, and fighting. And in some way which is not clear, excretion becomes mixed up in this system of socialization, and the circuits built in for its control give rise to qualities of orderliness.

从两岁到六岁，人生的根基更加稳固，因为几乎每个人都能记住这一阶段的一些经历、事件或印象，这与俄狄浦斯情结的发展进程平行且密切相关。事实上，断奶和如厕训练之后，世界上最普遍、影响最深远的指令是与性和攻击性相关的指令。生物体和物种依靠自然选择形成的内在回路生存。由于哺乳、性行为和打斗都需要他人参与，因此它们属于“社会性”活动。这些冲动赋予个体性格或特质：占有欲、男性特质、女性特质和攻击性。同时，体内也存在抑制这些冲动的回路，从而产生相反的倾向：克制、沉默和矜持。这些特质使人们至少在某些时候能够相对平静地共同生活，一种沉闷的竞争声，而非肆无忌惮、永无休止的争斗、交媾和打斗。在某种程度上，排泄融入了这种社会化体系，而为控制排泄而建立的回路产生了秩序感。

Parental programing determines how and when the urges are expressed, and how and when the restraints are imposed. It uses the circuits which are already built in, and sets them up in a certain way in order to get certain results or payoffs. As a result of this programing, new qualities emerge, which are compromises between urges and controls. From acquisitiveness and renunciation emerge patience; from maleness or femaleness and reticence emerge masculinity and femininity; from fighting and restraint emerge shrewdness, and from messiness and orderliness come tidiness. All these qualities: patience, masculinity and femininity, shrewdness, and tidiness are taught by the parents and programed in during the plastic years between two and six.

父母的教养方式决定了欲望表达的方式和时间，以及约束的施加方式和时间。它利用孩子体内已有的神经回路，并以特定的方式进行设置，以达到特定的结果或回报。这种教养方式催生出新的品质，这些品质是欲望与控制之间的一种妥协。从贪婪和克制中衍生出耐心；从男性或女性特质和沉默寡言中衍生出阳刚和阴柔；从争斗和克制中衍生出精明；从混乱和秩序中衍生出整洁。所有这些品质：耐心、阳刚和阴柔、精明和整洁，都是父母在孩子两岁到六岁这个可塑性极强的时期教导和灌输的。

Physiologically, programing means facilitation, the establishment of a path of lessened resistance. Operationally, it means that a given stimulus will evoke, with a high degree of probability, an already established response. Phenomenologically, parental programing means that a response is determined by parental directives, sound tracks previously recorded, whose voices can be heard by listening carefully to what goes on inside one’s own head.

从生理学角度来看，编程意味着促进，即建立一条阻力较小的路径。从操作层面来看，它意味着特定的刺激会以很高的概率引发一种已建立的反应。从现象学角度来看，父母编程意味着反应是由父母的指令决定的，这些指令就像预先录制好的音轨，可以通过仔细聆听自己内心的声音来感知。

B • Thinking Martian

B • 思考的火星人

When parents interfere with or try to influence their children’s free expression, their directives are interpreted differently by the parent, the onlookers, and the child himself. In fact there are five different viewpoints. (1) What the parent says he meant. (2) What a naive onlooker thinks he meant. (3) The literal meaning of what was said. (4) What the parent ‘really’ meant. (5) What the child gets out of it. The first two are ‘square’ or ‘Earthian,’ and the last three are ‘real’ or Martian.

当父母干预或试图影响孩子的自由表达时，他们的指令会被父母、旁观者和孩子自己以不同的方式解读。实际上，存在五种不同的视角。(1) 父母声称的本意。(2) 一个不了解情况的旁观者认为的本意。(3) 话语的字面意思。(4) 父母“真正”的本意。(5) 孩子从中得到的感受。前两种视角是“老套”或“地球式”的，后三种视角则是“真实”或“火星式”的。

BUTCH

布奇

Let us consider the example of a high school boy who was a heavy drinker. His mother caught him sniffing the whiskey bottle at the age of six and said: ‘You’re too young to be drinking whiskey.’

让我们来看一个例子：一个高中男生酗酒成性。他六岁时，母亲发现他在闻威士忌酒瓶，便说：“你年纪太小，不能喝威士忌。”

(1) What the mother says she meant was: ‘I don’t want my son drinking whiskey.’ (2) A naive onlooker, his uncle, concurred: ‘Of course she doesn’t want the kid drinking whiskey. No sensible mother would.’ (3) What she actually said was: ‘ You’re too young to be drinking whiskey.’ (4) And that is what she meant: ‘Drinking whiskey is a man’s job, and you’re still a boy.’ (5) What Butch got out of it was: ‘When the time comes to prove you’re a man, you’ll have to drink whiskey.’

（1）母亲说的意思是：“我不想让我儿子喝威士忌。”（2）他叔叔，一个天真的旁观者，附和道：“她当然不想让孩子喝威士忌。哪个明智的母亲会这么做呢？”（3）她实际说的是：“你太小了，不能喝威士忌。”（4）这才是她真正的意思：“喝威士忌是男人的事，而你还是个孩子。”（5）布奇从中得到的答案是：“等到你证明自己是个男人的时候，你就得喝威士忌。”

Thus, to an Earthian, the mother’s rebuke sounded like ‘common sense.’ But children think Martian until they are discouraged from doing it by their parents. That is why their uncorrupted thoughts seem so fresh and new. A child’s job is to find out what his parents really mean. This helps to maintain their love, or at least their protection, or in difficult cases, his mere survival. But beyond that, he loves his parents, and his chief aim in life is to please them (if they will let him), and in order to do that he has to know what they really want.

因此，对地球人来说，母亲的责备听起来像是“常识”。但孩子们的思维方式却带有火星人的色彩，直到父母阻止他们这样做为止。这就是为什么他们纯真的思想显得如此清新脱俗。孩子的职责是弄明白父母的真实想法。这有助于维系父母的爱，或者至少获得他们的保护，在困境中，甚至关乎自身的生存。除此之外，孩子爱着父母，他人生的主要目标就是取悦他们（如果他们愿意的话），而为了做到这一点，他必须知道父母真正想要的是什么。

Hence, from each directive, however indirectly it is put he tries to extract the imperative essence or the Martian core. In this way he programs his life plan. Cats and pigeons can do it too, although it takes them longer. It is called programing because the effects of the directives are likely to be permanent. For the child, his parents’ wish is his command, and will remain so for the rest of his life unless some drastic upheaval occurs. Only ordeal (war, prison) or ecstasy (conversion, love) can release him quickly, while life experience or psychotherapy may do it more slowly. The death of the parents does not always lift the spell; in most cases it only makes it more binding. As long as his Child is adapted rather than free, no matter what miserable tasks his Parent demands, the ‘script-driven’ person will perform them, and no matter what sacrifices are required, the ‘script-ridden’ one will make them. The parallel with the pimp and the prostitute is striking. She would rather be exploited and suffer with him, and get whatever satisfactions she can out of that, than venture into the unknown world without his protection.

因此，无论指令表达得多么间接，他都试图从中提炼出其根本本质或核心。他以此方式为自己的生活制定计划。猫和鸽子也能做到这一点，尽管它们需要更长的时间。之所以称之为“编程”，是因为指令的影响很可能是永久性的。对于孩子而言，父母的意愿就是他的命令，除非发生某种剧烈的变故，否则这种命令将伴随他一生。只有磨难（战争、监狱）或狂喜（皈依、爱情）才能让他迅速解脱，而生活经验或心理治疗则可能需要更长时间。父母的去世并不总是能解除这种魔咒；在大多数情况下，它只会让魔咒更加根深蒂固。只要孩子是被适应而非自由的，无论父母要求他完成多么痛苦的任务，“受剧本驱动”的人都会执行，无论需要做出怎样的牺牲，“被剧本束缚”的人都会做出牺牲。这与皮条客和妓女之间的相似之处令人震惊。她宁愿被他利用、与他一起受苦，并从中获得任何可能的满足感，也不愿在没有他保护的情况下冒险进入未知的世界。

Martian translates words into their true meanings according to their results, and judges people not according to their apparent intent, but from the ‘final display.’ Thus, many seemly parental protections are really unseemly assignments. A teen-age boy had bad luck with his car and ran up repair bills which distressed his father. The ‘good’ father ‘communicated’ with him from time to time on the subject, and on one occasion graciously grumped: ‘Well, it is tough on me, but don’t worry too much about it.’ This genteel generosity was naturally taken by the son to mean: ‘Do worry some.’ But if the boy said he was worrying or did something unusual to try to remedy the situation, the father could rebuke him by saying ‘I told you not to worry too much .’ The Martian translation of the ‘nice’ attitude: ‘Don’t worry too much!’ is, ‘Keep worrying until I can tell you you are worrying too much.’

火星人会根据结果将词语翻译成其真实含义，评判他人并非依据其表面意图，而是依据其“最终表现”。因此，许多看似出于父母保护的行为，实际上却是不恰当的安排。一个十几岁的男孩汽车出了故障，维修费用高昂，令他的父亲十分苦恼。这位“好”父亲时不时地就此事与儿子“沟通”，有一次，他温和地抱怨道：“唉，这对我来说确实很麻烦，但你别太担心。”儿子自然而然地将这种温和的宽容理解为：“你尽管担心吧。”但如果男孩说他很担心，或者做了些不同寻常的事情试图解决问题，父亲就可以斥责他说：“我不是告诉过你别太担心吗？”火星人对这种“好”态度——“别太担心！”——的解读是：“继续担心，直到我告诉你你担心过度为止。”

An even more dramatic example concerns a skillful waitress who was able to maneuver between the tables and hurly-burly of a busy and crowded restaurant with her hands and arms loaded with plates of hot food. Her surefootedness excited the admiration of both the management and the customers. Then one day her parents came to eat there and admire her in their turn. When she flitted past their table with her customary load, her overly apprehensive mother cried: ‘Be careful!’ whereupon for the first time in her career, the girl … Well, even the most Earthian reader can finish the story without a translation. In short, ‘Be careful!’ too often means: ‘Make a mistake so I can tell you I told you to be careful,’ and that is the final display. ‘Be careful, ha ha!’ is even more of a provocation. As a straight Adult instruction ‘Be careful!’ may have some value, but Parental overconcern or a Child Ha Ha gives it a different turn.

一个更戏剧性的例子是关于一位技艺娴熟的女服务员，她双手捧着满满一盘盘热腾腾的菜肴，却能在熙熙攘攘、人来人往的餐厅里穿梭自如。她的稳健身手赢得了餐厅经理和顾客们的赞赏。有一天，她的父母来这家餐厅吃饭，也想亲眼见识一下她的手艺。当她像往常一样端着满满的餐盘从父母桌旁走过时，她那过度紧张的母亲喊道：“小心！”于是，这位女服务员职业生涯中第一次……好吧，即使是最通情达理的读者也能不看翻译就读懂这个故事。简而言之，“小心！”常常意味着：“故意犯错，好让我告诉你我叮嘱过你小心”，而这已经是最终的结局了。“小心，哈哈！”则更具挑衅意味。作为一条直接的成人指令，“小心！”或许还有点意义，但父母的过度担忧或孩子的“哈哈”之语，就完全变了味儿。

In Butch’s case, ‘You’re too young to be drinking!’ from a crapulent mother meant ‘Hurry up and start drinking so I can object,’ and that was the final display of that maneuver. Butch knew what he had to do sooner or later if he wanted his mother’s reluctant attention, her poor substitute for love. Her wish, as he interpreted it, became his mission. He had a good example in his hard-working father, who drank heavily on weekends. By the time he was sixteen, Butch was getting drunk regularly. When he was seventeen, his uncle sat him down at a table with a bottle of whiskey between them and said: ‘Butch, I’m going to teach you how to drink.’

对布奇来说，他那肥胖母亲的一句“你年纪太小不能喝酒！”其实是“快点开始喝，这样我才能反对”，而这正是这种伎俩的最终体现。布奇知道，如果他想要得到母亲勉强的关注——那只是她用来代替爱的可怜替代品——他迟早都得这么做。在他看来，母亲的愿望就成了他的使命。他勤劳的父亲周末酗酒，这给他树立了一个很好的榜样。到了十六岁，布奇已经经常喝得酩酊大醉。十七岁那年，他的叔叔让他坐在桌旁，两人中间放着一瓶威士忌，叔叔说：“布奇，我要教你怎么喝酒。”

His father used to say to him with a contemptuous smile: ‘You’re so stupid.’ That was about the only time his father ever spoke to him, so Butch decided early that the thing to do was act stupid – another example of the value of Martian thinking, since his father made it clear that he didn’t want any ‘smart asses’ around the house. What he was really saying was:

他父亲过去常常带着轻蔑的笑容对他说：“你真蠢。” 那几乎是他父亲唯一一次跟他说话，所以布奇很早就决定要装傻——这再次体现了火星思维的价值，因为他父亲明确表示，他不想家里有任何“自作聪明的人”。他父亲真正想说的是：

FIGURE 6

图 6

‘You’d better act stupid when I’m around here,’ and Butch knew it. So much for Martian.

“我在这儿的时候，你最好装傻，”布奇心知肚明。火星人计划就此作罢。

Many children are brought up in families where the father works hard and drinks hard. Working hard is a prescription for filling in time between drinks. But drinking can interfere with work, and drink is the curse of the working class. On the other hand, work interferes with drinking, and work is the curse of the drinking class. Drinking and working run counter to each other. If drinking is part of a life plan or script, then working is a counterscript.

许多孩子成长于这样的家庭：父亲努力工作，也酗酒。努力工作是为了填补饮酒间隙的空隙。但饮酒会影响工作，而饮酒是工人阶级的诅咒。另一方面，工作也会影响饮酒，而工作是酗酒阶级的诅咒。饮酒和工作是相互矛盾的。如果饮酒是人生规划或剧本的一部分，那么工作就是与之相反的剧本。

Butch’s script directives are shown in the ‘script matrix’ 1 in Figure 6 . On top, father’s irritable Parent is saying: ‘Be a man, but don’t act smart,’ while on the bottom his jeering Child is saying: ‘Act stupid, ha ha.’ On top, mother’s doting Parent is saying: ‘Be a man, but you’re too young yet,’ while on the bottom her Child is daring him: ‘Don’t be a sissy, have a drink.’ In between, his father’s Adult, with the help of his uncle, is showing him the proper way to drink.

图 6 中的“脚本矩阵” 1 展示了 Butch 的脚本指令。上方，父亲暴躁的“家长”角色说：“像个男人，但别耍小聪明。”下方，他嘲笑的孩子角色说：“装傻，哈哈。”上方，母亲慈爱的“家长”角色说：“像个男人，但你还太小。”下方，她的孩子角色挑衅道：“别娘娘腔，喝一杯。”中间，他父亲的“成年人”角色在叔叔的帮助下，正在向他示范正确的饮酒方式。

C • The Little Lawyer

C • 小律师

Martian thinking enables the child to find out what the parents ‘really’ want, that is, what they will respond most favorably to. By using it effectively, he insures his survival and expresses his love for them. In this way he builds up the ego state known as the Adapted Child. The Adapted Child wants and needs to behave in an adapted way, and tries to avoid nonadaptive behavior or even nonadaptive feelings, which will get less than the best responses from those around him. Meanwhile his self-expressive or Natural Child must be held in leash. The balance between the two forms of behavior is held by the Adult in the child (AC in Figure 7 ), which must behave like an exceedingly agile computer in order to decide what is necessary and what is permissible from moment to moment in each situation. This Adult becomes very adept at figuring out what people want or will tolerate, or at worst, what they will get the most excited or angry about, or perhaps feel the most guilty, helpless, scared, or hurt about. Thus the Adult in the child is a keen and perceptive student of human nature, and is therefore called the Professor. In fact, he knows more practical psychology and psychiatry than any grownup professor does, although, after many years of training and experience, a grownup professor may know as much as thirty-three per cent of what he knew when he was four years old.

火星思维使孩子能够了解父母“真正”想要什么，也就是他们最乐于接受什么。通过有效地运用这种思维，孩子既能确保自身生存，又能表达对父母的爱。这样，孩子便能建立起被称为“适应型儿童”的自我状态。“适应型儿童”渴望并需要以适应环境的方式行事，并努力避免不适应的行为，甚至不适应的情绪，因为这些行为或情绪往往得不到周围人的最佳回应。与此同时，孩子内心那个自我表达的“自然型儿童”必须受到约束。这两种行为模式之间的平衡由孩子内心的“成人”（图7中的AC）维持，这个“成人”必须像一台极其灵活的计算机一样运作，才能在每种情况下随时判断什么是必要的，什么是允许的。这个“成人”非常擅长揣摩人们的需求和容忍度，或者更糟糕的是，能够洞察人们最兴奋、最愤怒、最内疚、最无助、最恐惧或最受伤的原因。因此，孩童内心深处的“成人”是一位敏锐而富有洞察力的人性研究者，故被称为“教授”。事实上，他比任何成年教授都更精通实用心理学和精神病学，尽管经过多年的训练和经验积累，成年教授的知识水平可能只相当于他四岁时的百分之三十三。

After he has learned Martian thinking, so that he has a sound Adapted Child, the Professor turns his attention to legal thinking, in order to find more ways for the Natural Child to express himself. Legal thinking starts during the plastic years, but reaches its fullest development in later childhood, and if encouraged by the parents may persist into maturity, giving rise to lawyers. Legal thinking is colloquially called cop-out thinking. fn1 Cop-out thinking is particularly common in personal sexual ethics. Thus a girl who is instructed by her parents not to lose her virginity may have mutual masturbation, or perform fellatio or a variety of other sexual acts which enable her to obey the letter of the parental law, although she may know that the parents ‘really meant’ not to get sexy. If the parents warn her against ‘sex,’ she may have intercourse without orgasm. The classical sexual cop-out was that used by the prostitutes of Paris at the beginning of this century. (It may still be used, for all I know.) When they went to confession they were excused for their profession on the grounds that it was a matter of business, providing they didn’t get turned on. Only if they enjoyed it was it treated as a sin. 2

在教授掌握了火星思维，从而培养出一个健全的适应型儿童之后，他便将注意力转向法律思维，以便为自然型儿童找到更多表达自我的方式。法律思维始于可塑期，但在儿童后期发展最为成熟，如果得到父母的鼓励，它甚至可以延续到成年，最终造就律师。法律思维俗称“逃避型思维”。逃避型思维在个人性伦理中尤为常见。例如，一个被父母告诫不要失去童贞的女孩，可能会进行相互手淫、口交或其他各种性行为，从而遵守父母的字面规定，尽管她可能知道父母“真正”的意思是不要发生性行为。如果父母警告她不要“发生性行为”，她可能会在没有性高潮的情况下进行性交。本世纪初巴黎妓女使用的正是这种经典的性逃避策略。 （就我所知，它可能仍然在使用。）当他们去忏悔时，只要他们没有从中获得性快感，他们的职业就会被豁免，理由是这只是工作。只有当他们从中获得快感时，才会被视为罪过。

What parents do is give a prohibition which they think will cover the situation, not giving enough credit to the shrewdness which they themselves have usually taught to their offspring. Thus a boy who is told ‘Don’t mess around with women’ may take this as a permission to mess around with other boys, or in some cases with sheep or cows, and in a legal way of thinking he is in the clear, since he is not doing anything his parents have forbidden. A girl who was told ‘Don’t let boys touch you,’ decided that meant it was all right to touch herself. By this cop-out her Adapted Child remained compliant to her mother’s wishes, while her Natural Child enjoyed the pleasures of masturbation. A boy who was similarly told ‘Don’t fool around with girls,’ took this as a permission to fool around with himself. Neither of these people was actually breaking a parental prohibition. Because the child treats such restrictions as a lawyer would, looking for the cop-out, they are often called in script analysis by the legal term ‘injunction.’

父母通常会给出他们认为足以涵盖所有情况的禁令，却低估了他们自己通常教给子女的机智。因此，一个被告知“不要和女人乱搞”的男孩可能会把这理解为可以和其他男孩乱搞，甚至在某些情况下可以和羊或牛乱搞。从法律角度来看，他似乎没有做错任何事，因为他没有违反父母的禁令。一个被告知“不要让男孩碰你”的女孩则认为这意味着可以自慰。通过这种逃避责任的方式，她“适应型”的孩子仍然顺从母亲的意愿，而她“自然型”的孩子则享受着自慰的快感。一个被告知“不要和女孩乱搞”的男孩则认为这是可以自慰的许可。实际上，这两个人都没有违反父母的禁令。由于孩子像律师一样看待这些限制，寻找其中的漏洞，因此在剧本分析中，它们通常被称为法律术语“禁令”。

Some children enjoy being compliant and do not look for cop-outs. Others have more interesting things to do. But just as many people devote themselves to the problem of how to transgress without breaking the law, so many children are interested in the question of how to be naughty without actually disobeying their parents. In both cases, this kind of shrewdness is taught and encouraged by the parents themselves, and is part of the parental programing. In some cases this may result in the formation of an antiscript, whereby the child succeeds in reversing the whole intent of the script, without actually disobeying any of the original script directions.

有些孩子喜欢顺从，不找借口逃避责任。另一些孩子则有更有趣的事情要做。正如许多人致力于研究如何在不违法的情况下越轨一样，许多孩子也热衷于研究如何在不违背父母意愿的情况下调皮捣蛋。在这两种情况下，这种精明都是父母教导和鼓励的，也是父母教育的一部分。在某些情况下，这可能会导致一种“反剧本”的形成，孩子成功地颠覆了整个剧本的意图，而实际上并没有违背任何原剧本的指示。

D • The Script Apparatus

D • 脚本装置

Transactional analysts did not start out with the idea that human life plans are constructed like myths and fairy tales. They simply observed that childhood decisions, rather than grownup planning, seemed to determine the individual’s ultimate destiny. No matter what people thought or said they were doing with their lives, they seemed driven by some inner compulsion to strive for a final payoff that was often different from what they put down in their autobiographies or employment resumés. Many who said they wanted to make money lost it, while all around them others were growing rich. Some who claimed to be seeking love found hate even in the ones who loved them. Parents who declared they did everything to make their children happy ended up with addicts, convicts, and suicides. Righteous Bible students committed murders and child rapes. These were the contradictions which had existed since the beginning of the human race; they were the ones that operas sang about and that sold newspapers.

人际沟通分析师最初并非认为人生规划如同神话童话般构建。他们只是观察到，童年时期的决定，而非成年后的规划，似乎决定了个人的最终命运。无论人们如何自称或自认为正在规划人生，他们似乎都受到某种内在冲动的驱使，去追求最终的回报，而这回报往往与他们在自传或求职简历中所写的内容截然不同。许多声称想要赚钱的人最终却一无所有，而他们周围的人却越来越富有。一些自称寻求爱的人，甚至在爱他们的人身上也感受到了恨意。那些声称竭尽全力让孩子快乐的父母，最终却养出了瘾君子、罪犯和自杀者。一些自诩虔诚的圣经学者犯下了谋杀和强奸儿童的罪行。这些矛盾自人类诞生之初就已存在；它们是歌剧吟唱的主题，也是报纸畅销的源泉。

It gradually became clear that while none of this made Adult sense, it did make sense to the Child part of the personality. That was the part that liked myths and fairy tales, and believed that that was the way the world once was or could be. It was not surprising, therefore, to find that when children planned their lives they often followed the plot of a favorite story. The real surprise was that these plans persisted for twenty, forty, or eighty years, and that in the end they usually prevailed over ‘common sense.’ Working backward from a suicide, car crash, delirium tremens, jail sentence, or divorce, and ignoring the ‘diagnosis’ to find out what really happened, soon showed that these outcomes were nearly all planned before the age of six. 3 The plans or scripts had certain elements in common, which formed a ‘script apparatus.’ The same apparatus seemed to be at work in good scripts: creators, leaders, heroes, venerable grandfathers, and people eminent in their professions. This apparatus had to do with how the life time was structured, and turned out to be the same as the apparatus used in fairy tales for that purpose.

渐渐地，人们发现，虽然这一切对成年人来说毫无道理，但对人格中孩童的部分来说却合情合理。孩童喜欢神话和童话，并相信世界曾经或可能就是那样。因此，孩子们规划人生时常常遵循他们最喜欢的故事情节，也就不足为奇了。真正令人惊讶的是，这些计划竟然持续了二十年、四十年甚至八十年，而且最终它们通常战胜了“常识”。从自杀、车祸、震颤性谵妄、监禁或离婚等事件倒推，忽略“诊断”结果去探究真相，很快就会发现，这些结果几乎都是在六岁之前就已经计划好的。这些计划或剧本有一些共同的要素，构成了一种“剧本机制”。这种机制似乎也存在于优秀的剧本中：创造者、领导者、英雄、德高望重的祖父以及各行各业的杰出人士。这个装置与生命时间的结构有关，结果发现它与童话故事中用于此目的的装置相同。

In such stories, the programing is done by giants and giantesses, ogres and witches, fairy godmothers and grateful beasts, and sulky magicians of either sex. In real life all these parts are played by the parents.

在这些故事里，负责编程的是巨人、女巨人、食人魔、女巫、仙女教母、感恩的野兽，以及阴郁的男女魔法师。而在现实生活中，所有这些角色都由父母扮演。

Psychotherapists know more about ‘bad’ scripts than about ‘good’ ones because they are more dramatic and people spend more time talking about them. Freud, for example, cites innumerable case histories of losers, and about the only winners in his works are Moses, Leonardo da Vinci, and himself. Only a few winners bother to find out how they got that way, while losers are often very anxious to know so that they can do something about it. In the following sections, therefore, we will deal first with losing scripts, where our knowledge is quite precise. There, the script apparatus consists of the following items, translated by the child into Martian imperatives.

心理治疗师对“坏”脚本的了解比对“好”脚本的了解更多，因为坏脚本更具戏剧性，人们也更愿意花时间谈论它们。例如，弗洛伊德引用了无数失败者的案例，而他著作中几乎只有摩西、达芬奇和他自己是成功者。只有少数成功者会费心去探究自己是如何成功的，而失败者往往非常渴望了解原因，以便采取行动。因此，在接下来的章节中，我们将首先讨论失败脚本，因为我们对这方面的了解相当精确。失败脚本的构成要素包括以下几项，这些要素被儿童转化为类似火星命令式的指令。

1. The parents tell the child how to end his life. ‘Get lost!’ and ‘Drop dead!’ are death decrees. So is ‘Die rich.’ ‘You’ll end up like your (alcoholic) father,’ is a life sentence. Such a command is called the script payoff, or curse.

1. 父母告诉孩子如何结束自己的生命。“滚开！”和“去死吧！”是死亡判决。“死得有钱”也是如此。“你会像你（酗酒的）父亲一样”则是终身监禁。这样的命令被称为“剧本回报”，或者说是诅咒。

2. They then give him an unfair negative command that will keep him from lifting the curse: ‘Don’t bother me!’ or ‘Don’t act smart!’ (= Get lost!) or ‘Stop complaining!’ (= Drop dead!). This is the script injunction or stopper. Injunctions are given by a Controlling Parent or a crazy Child ego state.

2. 然后，他们会给他下达不公平的负面指令，阻止他解除诅咒：“别烦我！”或“别耍小聪明！”（=滚开！）或“别抱怨了！”（=去死！）。这就是脚本式的禁令或阻止器。禁令通常由控制欲强的父母或疯狂的孩童自我状态发出。

3. They encourage behavior that will lead into the payoff: ‘Have a drink!’ or ‘You aren’t going to let him get away with that!’ This is called the script provocation, or come-on. It comes from a mischievous Child ego state, or demon, in the parent, and is usually accompanied by a ‘ha ha.’

3. 他们会鼓励孩子做出能带来回报的行为，比如：“喝一杯！”或者“你不会让他得逞的！”这被称为脚本式挑衅或引诱。它源于父母内心顽皮的孩童自我状态，或者说是“恶魔”，通常伴随着一声“哈哈”。

4. They also give him a prescription for filling in time while waiting for the action. This is in the form of a moral precept. ‘Work hard!’ may mean ‘Work hard all week so you can get drunk on Saturday night.’ ‘Take care of every penny!’ may mean ‘Take care of every penny so you can lose it all at once.’ This is the antiscript slogan, and comes from a nurturing Parent ego state.

4. 他们还给他开出了打发时间的“处方”，也就是一条道德准则。“努力工作！”可能意味着“努力工作一整周，这样你周六晚上就可以喝个痛快。”“精打细算！”可能意味着“精打细算一分钱，这样你就可以一次性全部挥霍掉。”这是一种反脚本式的口号，源于一种充满关爱的父母自我状态。

5. In addition, they teach him what he has to know in real life to carry out the script: how to mix drinks, how to keep books, how to cheat. This is the pattern or program, a form of Adult instruction.

5. 此外，他们还会教他如何在现实生活中执行剧本：如何调酒、如何记账、如何作弊。这就是模式或程序，一种成人指导的形式。

6. The child, on his part, has urges and impulses which fight the whole script apparatus that is laid on him by his parents. ‘Knock on the door!’ ( vs . Get lost), ‘Act smart!’ ‘Take off!’ ( vs . Work hard), ‘Spend it all now!’ ( vs . Save every penny), ‘Do it wrong.’ These are called scripty impulses, or the demon.

6. 孩子自身也存在着一些冲动和欲望，这些冲动和欲望与父母强加给他的所有行为准则相抗衡。“敲门！”（而不是“滚开”），“装聪明！”“走开！”（而不是“努力学习”），“现在就把钱都花光！”（而不是“省吃俭用”），“做错事”。这些被称为“脚本冲动”，或者说是“魔鬼”。

7. Tucked away somewhere is a way to lift the curse. ‘You can succeed after you’re forty.’ This spellbreaker is called the antiscript or internal release. But often the only antiscript is death. ‘You’ll get your reward in heaven.’

7. 某个地方藏着解除诅咒的方法。“你四十岁以后也能成功。”这种破除诅咒的方法被称为反咒或内在解脱。但通常唯一的反咒就是死亡。“你会在天堂得到奖赏。”

Exactly the same apparatus for structuring time is found in myths and fairy tales. The payoff or curse: ‘Get lost!’ (Hansel and Gretel) or ‘Drop dead!’ (Snow White and Sleeping Beauty). The injunction or stopper: ‘Don’t be too curious!’ (Adam and Eve, Pandora). The provocation or come-on: ‘Prick your finger with a spindle, ha ha.’ (Sleeping Beauty). The counterscript slogan: ‘Work hard until you meet the prince!’ (Kari Woodengown), or ‘Be nice until she says she loves you!’ (Beauty and the Beast). The pattern or program: ‘Be kind to animals and they’ll help you in time of need.’ (Pretty Goldilocks). The impulse or demon: ‘I’ll take just one look!’ (Bluebeard). The antiscript or spellbreaker: ‘You can stop being a frog when she throws you against the wall.’ (The Frog Prince), or ‘You’ll be free after twelve years of labor.’ (Hercules).

神话和童话中也存在着完全相同的时间结构机制。例如，惩罚或诅咒：“滚开！”（《汉塞尔与格蕾特》）或“去死吧！”（《白雪公主》和《睡美人》）。告诫或阻止：“别太好奇！”（《亚当与夏娃》和《潘多拉》）。挑衅或诱惑：“用纺锤扎破你的手指，哈哈。”（《睡美人》）。反面口号：“努力工作，直到遇见王子！”（《卡莉·伍登》）或“对她好，直到她说爱你！”（《美女与野兽》）。模式或准则：“善待动物，它们会在你需要的时候帮助你。”（《金发姑娘》）。冲动或恶魔：“我只想看一眼！”（《蓝胡子》）。反剧本或破咒语：“当她把你扔到墙上时，你就可以不再是青蛙了。”（《青蛙王子》），或者“经过十二年的劳动，你将获得自由。”（《大力士》）。

This is the anatomy of the script apparatus. The curse, the stopper, and the come-on form the script controls, and the other four items can be used to fight them. But the child lives in a fairy-tale world, beautiful, mediocre, or gruesome, and believes mainly in magic. Thus he seeks a magic way out, through superstition and fantasies. When that doesn’t work, he falls back on the demon.

这就是脚本装置的构造。诅咒、阻止和诱惑构成了脚本的控制，而其他四件物品则可以用来对抗它们。但孩子生活在一个童话世界里，这个世界或美丽、或平庸、或恐怖，他主要相信魔法。因此，他试图通过迷信和幻想找到一条魔法出路。当这条路行不通时，他便求助于恶魔。

But the demon has one peculiarity. When the demon in the child says ‘I’m going to defy you, ha ha!’ the demon in the parent says ‘That’s exactly what I want you to do, ha ha.’ Thus the script provocation and the scripty impulses, the come-on and the demon, work together to bring about the loser’s doom. The parent wins when the child loses, and the child loses by trying to win. All of these elements will be considered in more detail in Chapter Seven .

但这个恶魔有一个奇特之处。当孩子心中的恶魔说“我要反抗你，哈哈！”时，父母心中的恶魔也会说“这正是我要你做的，哈哈。”于是，剧本式的挑衅和剧本式的冲动，诱惑和恶魔，共同作用，最终导致失败者的毁灭。孩子失败时，父母获胜；孩子试图获胜，结果却失败了。所有这些要素将在第七章中进行更详细的探讨。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 The script matrix was first described by Claude M. Steiner. See his article ‘Script and Counterscript.’ Transactional Analysis Bulletin 5:133–135, April 1966. (Counterscript is his term for our ‘antiscript.’) See also Steiner, C. M. Games Alcoholics Play . Grove Press, New York, 1972.

1 脚本矩阵最早由克劳德·M·施泰纳提出。参见他的文章《脚本与反脚本》，载于《人际沟通分析公报》5:133–135，1966年4月。（反脚本是他对我们所称的“反脚本”的称呼。）另见施泰纳，《酗酒者的游戏》，格罗夫出版社，纽约，1972年。

2 Philippe, C. L. Bubu of Montparnasse (with preface by T. S. Eliot). Berkeley Publishing Company, New York, 1957.

2 Philippe, C. L. 蒙帕纳斯的布布（T. S. Eliot 作序）。伯克利出版公司，纽约，1957 年。

3 A few dozen scripts have been gone over in some detail at the San Francisco Transactional Analysis Seminars. These, and those worked out in my own practice, are the ones I am most closely acquainted with. Many other script analysts accept the principles given here on the basis of their own experience, which includes altogether perhaps a few thousand cases in hospitals, clinics, schools and prisons, and private practice too.

3 在旧金山人际沟通分析研讨会上，我们详细探讨了几十个脚本。这些脚本，以及我在自身实践中处理过的脚本，是我最熟悉的。许多其他脚本分析师也根据自身经验接受这里提出的原则，他们的经验可能包括数千个案例，这些案例来自医院、诊所、学校、监狱以及私人诊所。

fn1 ‘Cop-out’ has several meanings: to arrest, to settle for a lesser sentence (‘cop a plea’), to talk too much (‘fink out’), and to find an alibi or a crooked way out. It is used here in the last sense.

fn1 “Cop-out”有多种含义：被捕、接受较轻的判决（“认罪”）、泄露秘密（“告密”）以及寻找不在场证明或不正当的脱身之计。这里使用的是最后一种含义。

#↩

CHAPTER SEVEN

第七章

The Script Apparatus

脚本装置

In order to understand how the script works and how to deal with it in treatment, it is necessary to have a detailed knowledge of the script apparatus as we understand it today. There are still a few gaps in our insight into its basic framework, and some uncertainties about its transmission, but our model has developed into quite a sophisticated one in the short space of ten years since the first description was written. 1 At that time it was like the one-cylinder Duryea of 1893, while now it is like a rather advanced Model-T Ford.

为了理解脚本的运作方式以及如何在治疗中运用它，必须对我们今天所理解的脚本机制有详细的了解。我们对脚本基本框架的理解仍然存在一些空白，对其传递方式也存在一些不确定性，但自首次描述以来的短短十年间，我们的模型已经发展得相当完善。 1 当时它就像1893年的单缸杜里亚发动机，而现在它就像一辆相当先进的T型福特汽车。

Summarizing from the brief examples just given, the apparatus consists of seven items. The payoff or curse, the injunction or stopper, and the provocation or come-on, together control the unfolding of the script toward its destiny, and are therefore called the script controls. These are all programed in before the age of six in most cases. So is the antiscript or spellbreaker, if there is one. Later, the counterscript slogans or prescription, and the parental behavior patterns and instructions, begin to take firmer hold. The demon represents the most archaic layer of the personality (the Child in the child), and is there from the beginning. fn1

综上所述，这套机制由七个部分组成。回报或诅咒、禁令或阻止、以及挑衅或诱惑，共同控制着剧本走向其既定命运的进程，因此被称为剧本控制。在大多数情况下，这些控制项在六岁之前就已经被植入。反剧本或破咒器（如果存在的话）也是如此。之后，反剧本的口号或规范，以及父母的行为模式和指示，开始逐渐巩固。恶魔代表着人格中最古老的层面（孩童中的孩童），它从一开始就存在。

A • The Script Payoff

A • 剧本收益

The payoffs that come up in clinical practice can usually be reduced to four alternatives: be a loner, be a bum, go crazy, or drop dead. Drug or alcohol addiction is the pleasantest way to accomplish any of these. The child may interpret the decree in Martian or legal thinking, which is often to his advantage. In one case, where the mother told all the children they would end up in the state hospital, they all did. The girls ended up as patients, and the boys as psychiatrists.

临床实践中，人们面临的后果通常可以归结为四种选择：孤独终老、游手好闲、精神崩溃或猝死。而吸毒或酗酒则是实现这四种结局最轻松的方式。孩子可能会用火星人的思维或法律的逻辑来解读判决，这往往对他有利。曾有一个案例，母亲告诉所有孩子他们最终都会被送进州立医院，结果他们都真的去了。女孩们最终成了病人，男孩们则成了精神科医生。

Violence is a special kind of payoff, and occurs in ‘tissue scripts.’ Tissue scripts are different from all others because their currency is human flesh, blood, and bones. It is probable that a child who has seen, caused, or suffered mayhem or bloodshed is different from other children and can never be the same again. If the parents turn the child out at an early age to fend for himself, he is naturally much concerned with money, and that often becomes the chief currency of his script and his payoff. If they berate him and tell him to drop dead, then words may become the script currency. The script currency must be distinguished from the script theme. The chief themes of life scripts are the same as those which are found in fairy tales: love, hate, gratitude, and revenge. Any of the currencies can be used to express any of these themes.

暴力是一种特殊的回报方式，它出现在“血肉剧本”中。血肉剧本与其他剧本截然不同，因为它的货币是血肉之躯。目睹、制造或遭受过暴力或流血的孩子，很可能与其他孩子不同，并且永远无法恢复如初。如果父母在孩子很小的时候就将他赶出家门，让他自谋生路，他自然会非常在意金钱，而金钱往往会成为他剧本和回报的主要货币。如果他们辱骂他，甚至让他去死，那么言语就可能成为剧本的货币。剧本的货币必须与剧本的主题区分开来。人生剧本的主要主题与童话故事中的主题相同：爱、恨、感恩和复仇。任何一种货币都可以用来表达这些主题中的任何一种。

The main question for the script analyst here is: ‘In how many ways can a parent tell a child to live forever, or to drop dead?’ He can say it quite literally, ‘Long life!’ in a toast or a prayer, or ‘Drop dead!’ in a quarrel. It is difficult to realize or admit the almost incredible power which a mother’s words have over a child (or a wife’s over a husband, and vice versa). In my experience, a considerable number of legitimate hospital admissions have taken place shortly after the patient was told by a loved one (or even a hated one) to drop dead.

这里剧本分析者要问的主要问题是：“父母究竟有多少种方式可以对孩子说‘祝你长命百岁’或‘让你去死’？”他可以直接说“祝你长命百岁！”（在祝酒词或祈祷中），也可以在争吵中说“让你去死！”。我们很难意识到或承认母亲的话语对孩子（或妻子对丈夫，反之亦然）拥有多么不可思议的力量。以我的经验来看，相当多的正当入院案例都发生在患者被亲人（甚至是憎恨的人）诅咒“去死”之后不久。

In many cases it is a grandparent who controls these payoffs, either directly or through the parent. Grandmother may save the patient from a father’s death decree by offering a ‘life membership’ instead. Or she may give mother a Medea script (or ‘overscript’), which forces her to drive her children to their deaths in one way or another.

在许多情况下，祖父母直接或通过父母掌控着这些利益分配。祖母可能会提供“终身会员资格”来使病人免于父亲的死亡判决。或者，她可能会给母亲一份“美狄亚处方”（或“附加处方”），迫使她以某种方式将子女推向死亡。

All this is fed into the Parent of the little boy or girl, and is likely to stay there for life: someone’s gentle hope that he will live forever, or a harsh voice urging him closer to his death. Sometimes there is no animosity in the death decree, but just futility or despair. But since he drinks her wishes in from the day he is born, it is usually mother who makes the decision for him. Father may join or contradict her later: add his weight to her curse, or commute it.

所有这些都会灌输给小男孩或小女孩的父母，并可能伴随他一生：有人温柔地希望他能长生不老，也有人严厉地催促他走向死亡。有时，死亡的判决中并没有恶意，只有无力感或绝望。但由于他从出生之日起就吸收着母亲的意愿，通常是母亲替他做决定。父亲之后可能会同意或反对母亲的观点：要么支持母亲的诅咒，要么减轻诅咒的影响。

Patients can usually remember their childhood responses to payoff directives, things they didn’t say out loud.

患者通常能够回忆起他们小时候对奖励指令的反应，那些他们当时没有说出口的话。

Mother: ‘You’re just like your father.’ (Who got a divorce and lives in a room by himself.) Son: Good. Smart guy, father.

母亲：“你跟你父亲真像。”（你父亲离了婚，独自住在一个房间里。）儿子：“好。父亲是个聪明人。”

Father: ‘You’ll end up like your aunt.’ (Mother’s sister, who is in a mental hospital or committed suicide.) Daughter: If you say so.

父亲：“你会变成你姑姑那样。”（母亲的妹妹，她进了精神病院或者自杀了。）女儿：“好吧，你这么说。”

Mother: ‘Drop dead.’ Daughter: I don’t want to, but if you say so I guess I have to.

母亲：“去死吧。”女儿：“我不想死，但既然你这么说，我想我也只能死了。”

Father: ‘With your temper, you’ll kill somebody some day.’ Son: Well, if it can’t be you, it’ll be somebody else.

父亲：“你这脾气，总有一天会杀人的。” 儿子：“就算不是你，也会是别人。”

The child is very forgiving, and only makes his decision to follow the directive after dozens or even hundreds of such transactions. One girl from a very confused family, where she got no support from her parents, described very clearly the day she made her final decision. When she was thirteen, her brothers took her out in the barn and put her through all kinds of sexual stunts, which she went through in order to please them. After they finished, they began to laugh at her and talk about her. They decided that now she would either have to become a hooker or go crazy. She thought about it very carefully for the rest of the night, and by morning she had decided to go crazy, which she did very effectively, and stayed that way for years afterward. Her explanation was very simple. ‘I didn’t want to be a hooker.’

这个孩子非常宽容，只有在经历了几十次甚至几百次这样的遭遇后，才会最终决定服从指令。一个来自混乱家庭的女孩，在父母的完全不关照下，清晰地描述了她做出最终决定的那一天。十三岁那年，她的哥哥们把她带到谷仓里，强迫她做各种性行为，而她为了取悦他们，不得不照做。完事后，他们开始嘲笑她，议论她。他们决定，她要么去当妓女，要么就疯掉。那天晚上，她仔细地思考了很久，到了早上，她决定疯掉，而且她真的疯了，此后几年都保持着这种状态。她的解释很简单：“我不想当妓女。”

While the script payoff is bestowed or decreed by the parents, it will not take effect unless it is accepted by the child. His acceptance speech will not have the fanfare and finish of a Madison Avenue presidential inauguration, but he will say it as clearly as he dares at least once. ‘When I grow up, I’m going to be like mommy’ (= get married and have children), or ‘When I’m big, I’m going to do what daddy did’ (= get killed in a war), or ‘I wish I was dead.’ The patient should be asked: ‘What did you decide to do with your life when you were little?’ If he gives a conventional answer (‘I wanted to be a fireman’), this should be clarified with: ‘What I mean is, how did you decide you would end up?’ Since payoff decisions are often first made earlier than he can remember, he may not be able to give the desired answer, but it can be inferred from some of his later adventures.

虽然人生剧本的结局是由父母设定或决定的，但只有孩子接受它才会生效。他的接受宣言不会像麦迪逊大道总统就职典礼那样盛大隆重，但他至少会尽可能清晰地表达一次。“我长大后要像妈妈一样”（=结婚生子），或者“我长大后要像爸爸一样”（=战死沙场），或者“我真希望自己死了”。应该问孩子：“你小时候决定了自己的人生方向吗？”如果他给出了一个常规答案（比如“我想当消防员”），应该追问：“我的意思是，你是怎么决定自己最终会成为什么样的人的？”由于人生剧本的结局往往在他记事之前就已经做出，他可能无法给出我们想要的答案，但我们可以从他后来的经历中推断出来。

B • The Injunction

B • 禁令

Real-life injunctions do not take effect by magic, but depend upon the physiological properties of the human mind. It is not enough to say once ‘Don’t eat those apples!’ or ‘Don’t open that chest!’ Any Martian knows that an injunction given in that way is really a challenge. For an injunction to be locked in solidly in the mind of a child, it must be repeated frequently and transgressions must be punished, although there are exceptional cases, as with battered children, where a single shattering experience may engrave an injunction for life.

现实生活中的禁令并非凭空生效，而是取决于人类心理的生理特性。仅仅说一遍“别吃那些苹果！”或“别打开那个箱子！”是不够的。任何一个火星人都知道，这样下达的禁令实际上是一种挑战。要想让禁令牢牢地印在孩子的脑海里，就必须反复强调，并且对违规行为进行惩罚。当然，也有例外，比如遭受虐待的孩子，一次毁灭性的经历就可能让他们终生铭记禁令。

The injunction is the most important part of the script apparatus, and varies in intensity. Hence, injunctions can be classified in the same way as games, into first, second, and third degrees. There is a tendency for each type to produce its own kind of person: winner, nonwinner, or loser. (These terms will be explained in more detail later. A nonwinner is someone who neither wins nor loses, but just manages to come out even.) First-degree injunctions (socially acceptable and mild) are straight directives reinforced by approval or discouragement. (‘You’ve been nice and quiet.’ ‘Don’t be too ambitious.’) With these it is still possible to grow a winner. Second-degree (devious and tough) are crooked directives crookedly enforced by a kind of blackmail of seductive smiles and threatening frowns, which is the best way to raise a nonwinner (‘Don’t tell your father.’ ‘Keep your mouth shut.’) Third-degree (very rough and harsh) are unreasonable stoppers enforced by fear. Words become screams, facial expressions become nightmarish distortions, and physical chastisement becomes viciousness. (‘I’ll knock your goddam teeth in.’) This is one of the surest ways to produce a loser.

指令是脚本机制中最重要的部分，其强度各不相同。因此，指令可以像游戏一样分为一级、二级和三级。每种类型的指令都倾向于塑造出特定类型的人：赢家、非赢家或输家。（这些术语将在后面详细解释。非赢家既非赢家也非输家，只是勉强维持平衡。）一级指令（社会认可且较为温和）是直接的指示，辅以赞扬或劝阻。（例如：“你一直很乖很安静。”“别太野心勃勃。”）即使是一级指令，也仍然有可能培养出赢家。二级（狡猾而强硬）是扭曲的指令，通过诱人的微笑和威胁的皱眉进行敲诈勒索，这是培养失败者的最佳方法（“别告诉你爸爸。”“闭嘴。”）。三级（极其粗暴而残酷）是利用恐惧来强制执行的不合理的禁令。言语变成尖叫，面部表情变成噩梦般的扭曲，体罚变成恶毒的暴力。（“我要打掉你的牙！”）这是培养失败者的最有效方法之一。

The injunction, like the payoff, is complicated by the fact that most children have two parents. Thus one may say ‘Don’t act smart!’ and the other ‘Don’t act stupid.’ Such contradictory injunctions put the child in a difficult position. But most people who marry have compatible injunctions, such as ‘Don’t act smart!’ and ‘Keep quiet or I’ll knock your goddam brains out!’ which make a sad combination.

禁令，就像收益一样，因为大多数孩子都有父母双方而变得复杂。因此，一方可能会说“别耍小聪明！”，而另一方可能会说“别犯傻”。这种相互矛盾的禁令会让孩子陷入困境。但大多数已婚人士的禁令却往往相互矛盾，比如“别耍小聪明！”和“闭嘴，不然我就揍扁你！”，这组合起来就令人唏嘘了。

Stoppers are implanted at such a tender age that the parents look like magical figures to the little boy or girl. The part of the mother who gives out injunctions (her Controlling Parent or Child) is called colloquially ‘the fairy godmother’ if she is benevolent, or ‘the witch mother’ if she is not. In some cases, ‘mother’s crazy Child’ seems the most suitable label. Similarly, the Controlling Father is called ‘the jolly green giant,’ ‘the ugly troll,’ or ‘father’s crazy Child,’ whichever is appropriate. 2

孩子很小的时候就被灌输了控制欲，以至于在他们眼里，父母就像魔法师一样。母亲中那个发出指令的一方（控制型父母或孩子）如果仁慈，就被俗称为“仙女教母”，如果冷酷无情，就被称为“女巫妈妈”。在某些情况下，“母亲的疯孩子”似乎是最贴切的称呼。同样，控制型父亲也会被称作“快乐的绿巨人”、“丑陋的巨魔”或“父亲的疯孩子”，具体用哪个词取决于情况。

C • The Come-on

C • 挑逗

Provocation or seduction is what makes lechers, addicts, criminals, gamblers, and others with losing scripts. For a boy it is the real Odyssey scene of a living Ulysses, mother as a Siren luring him to his doom, or as Circe turning him into a swine. For a girl it is father as the Dirty Old Man. In early years it starts out as a general invitation to be a loser: ‘He sure is clumsy, ha ha,’ or ‘She sure is a shit walker, ha ha.’ Then it moves on to more specific jeers and teases. ‘He’s always banging his head, ha ha,’ or ‘She’s always losing her pants, ha ha.’ In adolescence it is promoted into personal transactions. ‘Take a good look, baby!’ (and maybe an accidental or on-purpose feel), ‘Have a drink,’ ‘Now’s your chance,’ ‘Throw it all in, what’s the difference,’ each accompanied by its ha ha.

挑衅或诱惑造就了好色之徒、瘾君子、罪犯、赌徒以及其他注定失败的人。对男孩来说，这就像现实版的《奥德赛》：一个活生生的尤利西斯，母亲如同塞壬女妖引诱他走向毁灭，或是喀耳刻将他变成猪。对女孩来说，父亲则扮演着猥琐老头的角色。在童年时期，这最初只是泛泛地邀请孩子成为失败者：“他真笨，哈哈”，或者“她真邋遢，哈哈”。随后，嘲讽和戏弄变得更加具体：“他总是撞到头，哈哈”，或者“她总是丢裤子，哈哈”。到了青春期，这种诱惑就演变成了人身攻击。 “好好看看，宝贝！”（也许带有一种无意或故意的感觉），“喝一杯”，“现在是你的机会”，“全都放进去，有什么区别呢”，每一句都伴随着一声哈哈大笑。

The come-on is the Parent’s voice whispering to the Child at the critical moment: not to stop thinking about sex or money, not to let them get away with that. ‘Come on baby. What’ve you got to lose?’ This is the demon in the Parent, and the demon in the Child responds. Then the Parent does a quick switch, and Jeder falls flat on his face. ‘There you go again,’ says the gleeful Parent, and Jeder answers ‘Ha ha!’ with what is colloquially called ‘a shit-eating smile.’

诱惑的话语是父母在关键时刻对孩子耳语：别停止想着性或金钱，别让他们得逞。“来吧宝贝，你还有什么可失去的？”这是父母内心的恶魔，孩子内心的恶魔也随之回应。然后父母迅速切换，杰德顿时跌倒在地。“你又来了，”得意洋洋的父母说道，杰德则带着一种俗称“吃屎般的笑容”回应道：“哈哈！”

The come-on is what promotes hang-ups in children, and for that it must start early. The parent takes the child’s yen for closeness and turns it into a yen for something else. Once this perverted love is fixed, it becomes a hang-up.

这种诱导行为会助长孩子的心理障碍，而且这种诱导必须从很小的时候就开始。父母利用孩子对亲密关系的渴望，将其转化为对其他事物的渴望。一旦这种扭曲的爱被固定下来，它就会变成心理障碍。

D • The Electrode

D • 电极

The come-on originates from the Child in the father or the mother, and is inserted into the Parent of the child, PC in Jeder in Figure 7 . There it acts like a ‘positive’ electrode, giving an automatic response. When the Parent in his head (PC) pushes the button, Jeder jumps to it, whether the rest of him wants to or not. He says something stupid, acts clumsy, has another drink, or puts it all on the next race, ha ha ha. The origin of the injunctions is not always so clear, but they, too, are inserted into PC, where they act like a ‘negative’ electrode. This keeps Jeder from doing certain things such as talking or thinking clearly, or turns him off if he comes on too strong, as with sex or smiling. Many people know the instantaneous turn-off in the midst of sexual excitement, and have observed the smile which turns on and then instantaneously off as though someone in the smiler’s head had pulled a switch. Because of these effects, PC, the Parent in the Child, is called the ‘electrode.’

这种“挑逗”源自父亲或母亲的“孩子”本能，并被植入到孩子的“父母”本能中，即图7中Jeder的PC部分。在那里，它就像一个“正极”电极，引发自动反应。当Jeder脑海中的“父母”本能（PC）按下按钮时，无论他内心其他部分是否愿意，他都会立即做出反应。他可能会说些蠢话，举止笨拙，再喝一杯，或者把所有精力都投入到下一场比赛中，哈哈哈哈。这些“禁令”的来源并不总是那么清晰，但它们也被植入到PC部分，在那里它们就像一个“负极”电极。这使得Jeder无法进行某些活动，例如清晰地说话或思考，或者在他表现得过于强烈时（例如性行为或微笑）让他感到不适。许多人都体验过在性兴奋时瞬间失去兴趣的现象，也观察到过笑容瞬间绽放又瞬间消失，仿佛有人在微笑者的脑海中拨动了一个开关。由于这些影响，PC（孩子中的父母）被称为“电极”。

FIGURE 7

图 7

The electrode got its name from a patient named Norvil who sat very still and very tense during his group sessions, unless he was spoken to. Then he answered instantly with a string of careful clichés (‘Norvil finally said something, ha ha’), after which he crunched up again. It soon became clear that it was a strict Father Parent in his head who controlled him with the ‘Sit Still’ turn-off switch, and the ‘Talk’ button that turned him on. Norvil worked in an experimental laboratory, and he himself was struck with the similarity between his reactions and those of an animal with an electrode in its brain.

这种电极的名字来源于一位名叫诺维尔的病人。在小组治疗期间，他总是纹丝不动，身体也十分紧张，除非有人跟他说话。一旦有人开口，他就会立刻用一连串精心设计的陈词滥调回应（比如“诺维尔终于说话了，哈哈”），然后又会再次紧绷起来。很快，人们就发现，他脑子里有一个严厉的父亲形象，用“保持静止”的开关控制着他，而“说话”的按钮则让他“开启”。诺维尔在一家实验室工作，他自己也惊讶地发现，他的反应与脑子里植入电极的动物的反应如此相似。

The electrode is the decisive challenge for the therapist. He, together with the patient’s Adult, must neutralize it, so that the Child can get permission to live freely and react spontaneously, in the face of the parents’ programing to the contrary, and their threats if he disobeys. This is difficult enough with milder controls, but if the injunction is a demand made by a witch or giant whose features are distorted with rage, whose voice smashes through all the defenses of the child’s mind, and whose hand is ever ready to strike humiliation and terror into his face and head, it requires enormous therapeutic power.

电极是治疗师面临的决定性挑战。他必须与患者的“成人”部分共同作用，消除电极的影响，这样“儿童”才能获得自由生活和自发反应的许可，即使面对父母的相反教条和威胁（如果违背他们的意愿），也能如此。即使是较温和的控制手段，这都已颇具挑战；但如果发出指令的是一个面目狰狞、怒火中烧的女巫或巨人，他们的声音震慑着孩子心灵的所有防线，他们的手随时准备将羞辱和恐惧击打在孩子的脸上和头上，那么这就需要治疗师付出巨大的努力。

E • Bags and Things

E • 包袋及其他物品

If a child is boxed in by contradictory controls, there may be only one way out which allows him some measure of self-expression. He is then forced into that kind of activity or response no matter how inappropriate it may be. In such a case it is often evident to the people around him that he is responding to what is in his head rather than to the external situation, and he is then said to be in a bag. If his bag is backed up by some talent or ability, and by a winning payoff command, it may be a winner’s bag, but in most cases people in a bag are losers because their behavior is nonadaptive. A person who breaks out of a bag (or ‘container,’ as it is sometimes called) will immediately proceed to do his thing, that is, whatever he has always wanted most to do. If that happens to be adaptive and is controlled with some Adult rationality, he may turn out to be a winner, but if he indulges too often and too well, he will end up being a loser. In fact, when a person starts to do his thing, after he breaks out of his bag, his payoff command will determine whether he does it judiciously so as to be a winner, or overdoes it like a loser. In some cases, however, he may be able to leave his payoff command in the bag along with the rest of his parentally programed script apparatus, and then he is really his own man and can decide his own destiny. But it is difficult for Jeder to know, without the appraisal of an objective outsider, whether he is really a maverick or liberated person, or is only an angry rebel, or maybe even a schizophrenic who has jumped out of his bag and into a bottle, with or without pulling the cork in after him.

如果一个孩子被相互矛盾的控制所束缚，可能只有一条出路能让他进行某种程度的自我表达。于是，无论这种行为或反应多么不恰当，他都会被迫去做。在这种情况下，周围的人往往会发现，他是在回应自己脑海中的想法，而不是对外部环境做出反应，这时人们就说他“被困在袋子里”。如果他的“袋子”里有某种天赋或能力支撑，并且有成功的动力，那它可能是一个“赢家的袋子”，但大多数情况下，“被困在袋子里”的人都是失败者，因为他们的行为缺乏适应性。一个挣脱“袋子”（有时也被称为“容器”）的人会立即去做他一直想做的事，也就是他一直以来最想做的事。如果这种行为恰好具有适应性，并且受到某种成人理性的约束，他最终可能会成为赢家；但如果他过于放纵自己，最终只会成为失败者。事实上，当一个人挣脱束缚，开始做自己想做的事时，他内心的“回报指令”将决定他是明智地行事，最终成为赢家，还是用力过猛，最终落得个失败者的下场。然而，在某些情况下，他或许能够将“回报指令”连同父母灌输给他的其他行为模式一起留在“袋子”里，这样他才能真正成为自己人，掌控自己的命运。但是，如果没有客观的局外人的评判，杰德很难判断他究竟是一个特立独行、获得解放的人，还是一个愤怒的叛逆者，甚至可能是一个精神分裂症患者，跳出“袋子”后又跳进酒瓶，至于他是否拔掉了瓶塞，那就不得而知了。

F • The Prescription

F • 处方

The ‘natural’ Parent in the mother and father (as distinguished from the controlling Parent) is biologically programed to some extent, and is naturally nurturing and protective. Both parents, whatever their inner problems, fundamentally wish Jeder well. They may be badly informed, but as ‘natural’ parents they are well meaning, or at least harmless. They encourage Jeder in ways which, in their picture of the world and their theory of living, are meant to bring him well-being and success. They transmit to him, usually from the grandparents, prescriptions which are often the epitome of Earthian squareness: ‘Work hard!’ ‘Be a good girl!’ ‘Save your money!’ and ‘Always be on time!’ are common middle-class examples. But each family has its specialty: ‘Don’t eat starches!’ ‘Never sit on a public toilet seat!’ ‘Take a laxative every day!’ or ‘Masturbation will drain your spinal cord!’ 3 are examples of this. ‘Never draw to an inside straight!’ is one of the best because it has a Zenlike quality; used symbolically as well as literally, it becomes good Martian and may come in handy at unexpected times.

父母身上“自然”的父母角色（与控制型父母角色相对）在某种程度上是生物本能，天生具有养育和保护的倾向。无论他们内心存在什么问题，父母双方都真心希望杰德幸福。他们或许见识有限，但作为“自然”的父母，他们的出发点是好的，或者至少是无害的。他们鼓励杰德的方式，在他们眼中的世界和生活理念中，旨在为他带来幸福和成功。他们通常从祖父母那里传承一些教条，这些教条往往是世俗教条的典型代表：“努力工作！”“做个乖女孩！”“存钱！”“永远准时！”这些都是常见的中产阶级例子。但每个家庭都有自己的特色：“不要吃淀粉类食物！”“永远不要坐在公共厕所的马桶座上！”“每天服用泻药！”或者“手淫会耗尽你的脊髓！”这些都是例子。 “永远不要画内直！” 这句话是最好的格言之一，因为它具有禅意；无论是象征意义还是字面意义，它都能起到很好的作用，并且在意想不到的时候派上用场。

Since the prescription comes from a nurturing Parent, and the script controls from a controlling Parent or a crazy Child, there is plenty of room for contradictions. These are of two types, internal and external. An internal contradiction comes from two different ego states in the same parent. Father’s Parent on top says ‘Save your money,’ and his Child on the bottom says ‘Put it all on the last roll.’ If one parent says ‘Save your money,’ and it is the other who gives the directive to gamble it away, that is an external contradiction.

由于教诲来自慈爱的父母，而行为准则则来自控制欲强的父母或叛逆的孩子，因此矛盾在所难免。矛盾分为两种：内在矛盾和外在矛盾。内在矛盾源于同一位父母的两种不同的自我状态。例如，父亲的“父母”一面说“存钱”，而他的“孩子”一面却说“把钱都押在最后一轮”。如果一位父母说“存钱”，而另一位却指示孩子把钱全部赌光，这就是外在矛盾。

The script controls are inserted and take effect early in life, while the counterscript slogans only become meaningful later. Jeder understands the prohibition ‘Mussentouchit!’ when he is two, while he really doesn’t understand the precept ‘Save your money!’ until he is a teen-ager and needs money to buy things with. Thus, his script controls are given by a mother who seems a magic figure to his youthful eyes, and have all the power and endurance of a witch’s curse; his prescription is given by a benevolent, hard-working housewife, and is merely advisory.

脚本控制在人生早期就已植入并生效，而反脚本口号则要到后期才变得有意义。杰德两岁时就明白“不能碰它！”的禁令，但直到十几岁需要用钱买东西时，他才真正理解“省钱！”的准则。因此，在他稚嫩的眼中，他的脚本控制来自一位如同魔法般的母亲，拥有如同女巫诅咒般的力量和持久性；而他的处方则来自一位善良勤劳的家庭主妇，仅仅是建议而已。

This is an unequal contest in which the controls are bound to win if there is a head-on conflict, unless some other element can be introduced, such as a therapist. An added difficulty is that the script tells it like it is: people really do act clumsy, as the child well knows; while the counterscript is usually square as far as his experience is concerned: he may or may not have seen someone attain happiness by working hard, being a good girl, saving money, or being on time, not eating starches, avoiding public toilets, taking laxatives, and not masturbating.

这是一场不公平的较量，如果双方正面冲突，控制方必然获胜，除非引入其他因素，例如治疗师。另一个难点在于，既定的叙事模式直白地描述了人们的笨拙行为，孩子对此深有体会；而与之相反的叙事模式则与他的经验相悖：他可能见过也可能没见过有人通过努力工作、做个乖女孩、存钱、守时、不吃淀粉类食物、不去公共厕所、服用泻药以及不手淫而获得幸福。

The alternation between script and counterscript explains something that often puzzles patients when the therapist says that their confusion began in early childhood. ‘Then how come all through high school I was normal?’ they will ask. The answer is that in high school they were following the counterscript, and then something happened which caused an ‘outbreak of script.’ This is an ‘at least’ reply; it doesn’t solve the problem, but it at least indicates where to look.

脚本和反脚本之间的交替可以解释一些令患者困惑的问题，比如治疗师告诉他们，他们的困惑始于童年早期。“那为什么我整个高中时期都很正常呢？”他们会问。答案是，他们在高中时期遵循的是反脚本，后来发生了一些事情，导致了“脚本的爆发”。这至少是一个解释；它并不能解决问题，但至少指明了解决问题的方向。

An attempt to satisfy a bad script and a well-meaning counterscript at the same time may lead to some strange behavior, as in the girl whose father’s angry Parent frequently told her to ‘Drop dead!’ while her mother’s anxious Parent kept telling her to wear her rubbers so she wouldn’t get her feet wet. So when she dropped off the bridge she wore her rubbers. (She survived.)

试图同时满足一个糟糕的剧本和一个善意的反剧本可能会导致一些奇怪的行为，就像那个女孩一样，她父亲愤怒的“父母”经常对她说“去死吧！”，而她母亲焦虑的“父母”则一直叮嘱她穿上橡胶鞋，以免弄湿脚。所以当她从桥上掉下去时，她穿着橡胶鞋。（她活了下来。）

The counterscript determines the person’s style of life, and the script controls his ultimate destiny. If they are harmonious, they may pass by unnoticed on the inside pages, but if they are in conflict they may bring surprises and make headlines. Thus, Hard-Working Church Deacon may end up President of Council, Retires After Thirty Years, or Jailed For Embezzlement, and Devoted Housewife comes out Mother of the Year, Celebrates Golden Anniversary, or Leaps From Roof of Building. In fact it seems as though there are two kinds of people in the world: real people and plastic people, as the Flower Children used to say. The real people make their own decisions, while the plastic people are run by fortune cookies.

反命题决定了一个人的生活方式，而命题则掌控着他的最终命运。如果两者和谐共处，它们或许会在人生的内页悄然流逝；但如果两者冲突，则可能带来意想不到的后果，甚至成为头条新闻。因此，勤勉的教会执事最终可能成为理事会主席，在三十年后退休，或者因挪用公款而锒铛入狱；而贤惠的家庭主妇最终可能荣膺年度最佳母亲，庆祝金婚纪念日，或者从楼顶纵身跃下。事实上，正如嬉皮士们所说，这世上似乎只有两种人：真实的人和虚伪的人。真实的人自主做决定，而虚伪的人则被幸运饼干的指引所左右。

The Fortune Cookie Theory of human living says that each child gets to pull two cookies from the family bowl: one square and one jagged. The square one is a slogan, such as ‘Work hard!’ or ‘Stick with it!’ while the jagged one is a scripty joker, such as ‘Forget your homework,’ ‘Act clumsy,’ or ‘Drop dead.’ Between the two, unless he throws them away, his life style and his final destiny are written.

人生的“幸运饼干理论”认为，每个孩子都能从家里的饼干碗里抽出两块饼干：一块是正方形的，一块是锯齿状的。正方形的饼干上写着一句格言，比如“努力学习！”或“坚持下去！”；锯齿状的饼干上写着一些滑稽的玩笑，比如“忘记作业”、“装傻充愣”或“去死吧”。这两块饼干，除非孩子把它们扔掉，否则就决定了他的人生轨迹和最终命运。

G • Parental Patterns

G • 父母模式

To make a lady, you start with the grandmother, and to make a schizophrenic, you start with the grandmother, too. Zoe (as we will call Jeder’s sister) can only be a lady if her mother teaches her what she has to know. She must learn very early how to smile and walk and sit by imitation, as most girls do, and later, by spoken instructions, how to dress, how to make herself agreeable to the people around her, and how to say ‘No’ gracefully. Father may have something to say about these things, but handling father is also a matter for feminine instruction. Father may impose the controls, but it is mother who gives the pattern and the Adult instructions for carrying them out. The script matrix for a beautiful lady named Zoe is shown in Figure 8 . Whether Zoe makes a career out of being a lady, or eventually rebels against the system and its restrictions, depends as much on what her script calls for as on her own decision. She may have permission for moderate sex or drinking, but if she suddenly becomes more active, is that breaking out of her script, or merely following a provocation to rebel? In the first case, her father would say (as the Martians put it): ‘No, no, not that shaggy!’ and in the second (secretly, to himself): ‘Now she’s showing some spirit, ha ha. Nothing stuffy about my little girl!’

培养一位淑女，要从祖母开始；培养一位精神分裂症患者，同样也要从祖母开始。佐伊（我们暂且这样称呼杰德的妹妹）只有母亲教会她所有必要的知识，才能成为一位淑女。她必须像大多数女孩一样，很早就通过模仿学习如何微笑、走路和坐姿；之后，通过口头指导，学习如何穿衣打扮，如何与周围的人相处融洽，以及如何优雅地说“不”。父亲或许会对这些事情发表意见，但如何应对父亲也是女性需要学习的。父亲或许会施加控制，但母亲才是提供模式和执行这些模式的成年人指导的人。图8展示了一位名叫佐伊的美丽淑女的剧本矩阵。佐伊最终能否成为一名淑女，或者最终反抗体制及其限制，既取决于剧本的安排，也取决于她自身的选择。她或许被允许适度地进行性行为或饮酒，但如果她突然变得更加活跃，这究竟是打破常规，还是仅仅受到挑衅而反抗？如果是前者，她的父亲会说（就像火星人说的那样）：“不行，不行，别那么邋遢！”如果是后者（他私下里对自己说）：“她现在有点儿活力了，哈哈。我的小女儿一点儿也不古板！”

On the other side, if Zoe’s mother doesn’t sit right, doesn’t dress right, and is awkward in her femininity, Zoe is likely to be that way, too. This often happens to girls with schizoid mothers. It also happens to girls whose mothers died when they were very young, so that they have no pattern to follow. ‘When I get up in the morning, I can’t even decide what to put on,’ said one paranoid schizophrenic whose mother died when she was four.

另一方面，如果佐伊的母亲坐姿不端正、穿着不得体，举止也缺乏女性魅力，那么佐伊很可能也会如此。这种情况经常发生在患有精神分裂症母亲的女孩身上。也发生在那些幼年丧母、缺乏榜样可循的女孩身上。“我早上起床的时候，甚至都不知道该穿什么衣服，”一位患有偏执型精神分裂症、四岁时母亲去世的女孩说道。

In the case of a boy, the script and the pattern are more likely to influence his choice of a working career. As a small child, Jeder may say: ‘When I grow up I want to be a lawyer (policeman, thief) like father.’ But this does not always come true. Whether it does or not depends on mother’s programing, which reads: ‘Get (don’t get) into something with plenty of risks and lots of fast action like (not like) your father.’ These controls, like all script controls, refer not so much to the choice of a particular profession, but rather to special types of transactions (in this case, straight or crooked, risky or safe, etc.). 4 But for or against, father is the one who offers the pattern.

对于男孩来说，剧本和模式更有可能影响他选择职业。年幼的杰德可能会说：“我长大后想和爸爸一样当律师（警察、小偷）。”但这并不总是会实现。这是否会发生取决于母亲的“编程”，即：“像（不像）你爸爸那样，去做（不去做）充满风险和刺激的事情。”这些控制，就像所有剧本控制一样，与其说是针对特定职业的选择，不如说是针对特定类型的交易（在这种情况下，是光明正大还是不正当，风险高还是风险低等等）。但无论结果如何，父亲才是提供这种模式的人。

FIGURE 8

图 8

Jeder may apparently go against his mother’s wishes when he takes up his father’s occupation. This may be a true defiance, or antiscript. On the other hand, there are three mothers: Parent, Adult, and Child. He may be going against the spoken wishes of her Parent or Adult, by complying with the unspoken but evident glee of her Child. The controls take effect when the little boy notes her rapt attention and fascinated smile while she listens to father’s account of his latest adventure. The same applies to father’s controls on Zoe. His Parent or Adult may continually warn her against getting pregnant, but may show a childlike interest and pleasure when one of her classmates does. This is a provocation she is likely to comply with, especially if mother has given her the pattern and Zoe herself was conceived out of wedlock.

杰德继承父亲的职业，这显然违背了他母亲的意愿。这或许是一种真正的反抗，或者说是违背既定的模式。另一方面，他身上有三位母亲：父母、成人和孩子。他或许违背了父母或成人的意愿，却顺从了孩子那无声却显而易见的喜悦。当小男孩注意到孩子全神贯注地听父亲讲述最新冒险经历，脸上洋溢着着迷的笑容时，这种控制便开始生效。同样的道理也适用于父亲对佐伊的控制。他的父母或成人或许会不断警告她不要怀孕，但当她的同学怀孕时，他却会表现出孩子般的兴趣和喜悦。这是一种她很可能会顺从的挑衅，尤其是在母亲已经给她灌输了这种模式，而佐伊本身又是非婚生的情况下。

Sometimes the matrix is reversed, but in most cases the controls come from the parent of the opposite sex, and the pattern from the parent of the same. In any case, the pattern is the final display, the final common pathway for all the script directives.

有时矩阵会反转，但大多数情况下，控制元素来自异性父级，而图案元素来自同性父级。无论如何，图案元素是最终显示，是所有脚本指令的最终通用路径。

H • The Demon

H • 恶魔

The demon is the jester in human existence, and the joker in psychotherapy. No matter how well Jeder lays his plans, the demon can come in at the critical moment and upset them all, usually with a smile and a ha ha. And no matter how well the therapist plans his psychotherapy, the patient always has the upper hand. At the point when the therapist thinks he has four aces, Jeder plays his joker, and his demon wins the pot. Then he skips merrily off, leaving the doctor to leaf through the deck trying to figure out what happened.

恶魔是人类生活中的弄臣，也是心理治疗中的小丑。无论杰德的计划多么周密，恶魔总能在关键时刻出现，搅乱一切，通常还带着一丝微笑和一声“哈哈”。同样，无论治疗师的心理治疗计划多么完善，病人总是占据上风。当治疗师以为自己手握四张王牌时，杰德却打出了他的小丑牌，恶魔赢得了胜利。然后，他兴高采烈地溜走了，留下医生独自翻阅牌堆，试图弄明白究竟发生了什么。

Even if he is ready for it, there may be little he can do. The doctor may know ahead of time that just as Jeder gets his stone rolled up to the brow of the hill, the demon will distract his attention, and it will roll all the way down again. There may be others who know about it, too, but the demon is already at work, and sees to it that Jeder keeps away from anyone who would interfere. So the patient starts to miss appointments, or drifts away, and if anyone pressures him he just plain quits. He may return after he has Sisyphused out, sadder, but not much wiser, nor even aware of his glee.

即便他做好了准备，也可能无能为力。医生或许早就知道，就在杰德将石头滚到山顶的那一刻，恶魔会分散他的注意力，让石头再次滚落下来。或许还有其他人也知道这件事，但恶魔早已开始行动，确保杰德远离任何可能干预的人。于是，病人开始错过预约，或者渐渐疏远，如果有人给他施加压力，他就会干脆放弃。或许他会在西西弗斯式的徒劳之后回来，更加悲伤，但并不会变得更明智，甚至意识不到自己曾经的喜悦。

The demon first appears in the high chair, when Jeder scatters his food on the floor with a merry glint, waiting to see what his parents will do. If they make friends with it, it will go on to later mischief, and then perhaps into humorous fun and jokes. If they beat it down, it will lurk surly in the background, ready to leap out at an unguarded moment and scramble his life as it originally scrambled his food.

恶魔第一次出现是在高脚椅上，杰德兴高采烈地把食物撒在地上，等着看父母会怎么做。如果他们和它交朋友，它之后会继续捣蛋，然后或许会带来一些滑稽的乐趣和笑话。如果他们把它打败了，它就会阴沉地潜伏在暗处，伺机在杰德不注意的时候跳出来，像当初弄乱食物一样，再次搅乱他的生活。

I • Permission

我 • 许可

Negatives are usually said loud and clear, with vigorous enforcement, while positives often fall like raindrops on the stream of life, making little sound and only small ripples. ‘Work hard!’ is found in copybooks, but ‘Stop loafing!’ is more likely to be heard in the home. ‘Always be on time’ is an instructive motto, but ‘Don’t be late!’ is heard more frequently in real life, and ‘Don’t be stupid!’ is more popular than ‘Be bright!’

否定句通常被大声宣告，并辅以强有力的执行，而肯定句则往往像雨滴落在生活之河上，悄无声息，泛起细小的涟漪。“努力工作！”常见于教科书，但“别偷懒！”更常在家中听到。“准时”是一句有益的格言，但“别迟到！”在现实生活中更为常见，而“别犯傻！”比“要聪明！”更受欢迎。

So it turns out that most programing is negative. Every parent fills his children’s heads with such restraints. But he also gives them permissions. Prohibitions hamper adaptation to circumstances (nonadaptive), while permissions give a free choice. Permissions do not cause the child trouble, since there is no compulsion attached. True permissions are merely permits, like a fishing license. A boy with a fishing license is not compelled to fish. He can use it or not as he wishes, and he goes fishing when he feels like it and when circumstances allow.

所以，事实证明，大多数的“程序化教育”都是负面的。每个父母都会在孩子脑子里灌输这类限制。但他们也会给予孩子一些“许可”。禁令会阻碍孩子适应环境（非适应性），而许可则赋予他们自由选择的权利。许可不会给孩子带来麻烦，因为它不包含任何强制力。真正的许可仅仅是授权，就像钓鱼许可证一样。一个持有钓鱼许可证的孩子并没有被强迫去钓鱼。他可以根据自己的意愿选择是否使用许可证，想去钓鱼的时候，只要环境允许，他就可以去。

It should be said again that being beautiful (like being successful) is not a matter of anatomy, but of parental permission. Anatomy makes one pretty or photogenic, but only father’s smile can make beauty shine from a woman’s eyes. Children do things for someone. The boy is bright or athletic or successful for mother, and the girl is bright or beautiful or fertile for father. Or, on the other side, the boy is stupid or weak or clumsy for his parents, and the girl is stupid or ugly or frigid for hers, if that is what they want. It should be added that they have to learn from someone if they want to do it well. To do it for someone and to learn from someone is the real meaning of the script apparatus. As already noted, the children usually do it for the parent of the opposite sex and learn from the parent of the same sex.

需要再次强调的是，美丽（如同成功）并非取决于生理构造，而是取决于父母的认可。生理构造使人漂亮或上镜，但只有父亲的微笑才能让女人的眼中绽放光彩。孩子们做事是为了取悦他人。男孩聪明、运动能力强或事业有成，是为了取悦母亲；女孩聪明、美丽或生育能力强，是为了取悦父亲。反之，如果父母希望如此，男孩也可以被父母视为愚笨、软弱或笨拙；女孩也可以被父母视为愚笨、丑陋或冷漠。此外，孩子们若想做好某件事，就必须向他人学习。为他人做事并向他人学习，这才是剧本机制的真正含义。正如前文所述，孩子们通常为异性父母做事，并向同性父母学习。

Permissions are the chief therapeutic instrument of the script analyst because they offer the only chance for an outsider to free the patient from the curses laid on him by his parents. The therapist gives permission to the patient’s Child by saying either ‘It’s all right to do it,’ or ‘You don’t have to do it.’ Both say to the Parent ‘Let him alone.’ Thus there are positive and negative permissions. In a positive permission, or license, ‘Let him alone!’ means ‘Let him do it!’ This cuts off the injunction. In a negative permission, or external release, it means ‘Stop pushing him into it!’ This cuts off the provocation. Some permissions can be regarded either way. This is particularly true of antiscripts. Thus when the Prince kissed Sleeping Beauty in the Wood, he was offering her both a license to wake up and a release from the witch’s curse.

许可是脚本分析师的主要治疗工具，因为它是局外人将患者从父母施加的诅咒中解救出来的唯一机会。治疗师通过说“这样做没问题”或“你不必这样做”来给予患者内心的“孩子”许可。这两种说法都向“父母”传达了“别管他”的信息。因此，许可分为积极许可和消极许可。在积极许可或授权中，“别管他！”意味着“让他去做！”这切断了禁令。在消极许可或外部释放中，它意味着“别再逼他了！”这切断了挑衅。有些许可可以同时被理解为积极和消极两种含义。反脚本尤其如此。例如，当王子在森林里亲吻睡美人时，他既给了她醒来的许可，也给了她解除女巫诅咒的许可。

One of the most important permissions is a license to stop acting stupid and start thinking. Many patients of advanced years have not had a single independent thought since early childhood, and have quite forgotten how it feels to think, or even what thinking means. With properly timed permission, however, they are able to come through, and are more than delighted when they say out loud at the age of sixty-five or seventy what may be the first intelligent observation of their adult lives. Often it is necessary to undo the work of previous therapists in order to give a patient permission to think. Some of them have spent years in mental hospitals or clinics where the slightest attempt on their part to think independently came up against powerful resistance from the staff. There they were taught that thinking is really a sin called ‘intellectualizing,’ to which they must confess promptly and promise never to indulge in again.

最重要的许可之一，就是允许他们停止愚蠢的行为，开始思考。许多高龄患者自幼年起就从未有过独立思考，他们早已忘记了思考的感觉，甚至忘记了思考的意义。然而，只要给予他们恰当的许可，他们就能走出困境，并在六十五岁或七十岁时，说出他们成年生活中第一个理智的见解，而他们为此感到无比欣喜。通常，为了允许患者思考，必须先纠正之前治疗师的干预。有些患者曾在精神病院或诊所待过多年，在那里，他们哪怕最轻微的独立思考尝试都会遭到工作人员的强烈抵制。他们被灌输了一种观念：思考实际上是一种罪过，叫做“理性化”，他们必须立即忏悔，并承诺永不再犯。

Many addictions and obsessions are based on parental come-ons. ‘Don’t stop taking drugs (or you may stop coming home to ask for money)’ says the mother of the heroin addict. ‘Don’t stop thinking about sex,’ says the parent of a lecher or a nymphomaniac. And the whole concept of permissions as a therapeutic instrument was started by a gambler who said: ‘I don’t need someone to tell me to stop gambling, I need someone to give me permission to stop, because somebody in my head says I can’t.’

许多成瘾和痴迷都源于父母的诱导。“别停止吸毒（否则你可能就不回家要钱了）”，海洛因成瘾者的母亲会这样说。“别停止想性”，好色之徒或性欲亢进者的父母会这样说。而“许可”作为一种治疗手段的概念，则是由一位赌徒提出的，他说：“我不需要别人告诉我停止赌博，我需要有人允许我停止，因为我脑子里有个声音告诉我我做不到。”

A permission, then, allows Jeder to be flexible, instead of responding with fixed patterns frozen by slogans and controls. This has nothing to do with ‘permissive upbringing,’ since that is full of imperatives, too. The most important permissions are to love and to change and to do things well. A person with permission is just as easy to spot as one who is all tied up. ‘He sure has permission to think,’ ‘She sure has permission to be beautiful,’ and ‘They sure have permission to enjoy themselves,’ are Martian expressions of admiration.

因此，许可赋予了杰德灵活性，而非让他被口号和控制所束缚，只能做出僵化的回应。这与“放任式教育”毫无关系，因为后者也充满了命令。最重要的许可是爱、改变和把事情做好。一个拥有许可的人和一个人一样容易辨认，后者则完全受制于束缚。“他当然有思考的许可”、“她当然有展现美丽的许可”以及“他们当然有享受生活的许可”都是火星人表达赞赏的方式。

(One of the frontiers of script analysis is the further study of permissions, primarily through observation of eye movements in very young children. Thus, in some situations, the child glances sideways at his parents to see if he has ‘permission’ to do something; in other cases, he seems to be ‘at liberty’ to follow his own inclinations without consulting them. Such observations, carefully evaluated, may result in a significant distinction between ‘permissions’ and ‘liberties.’)

（脚本分析的前沿领域之一是对许可的进一步研究，主要通过观察幼儿的眼动来开展。例如，在某些情况下，孩子会侧目看向父母，看看自己是否“被允许”做某事；而在另一些情况下，他似乎可以“自由”地按照自己的意愿行事，而无需征求父母的意见。仔细评估这些观察结果，或许能够揭示“许可”和“自由”之间的重要区别。）

J • The Internal Release

J • 内部发布

The spellbreaker, or internal release, is the element which lifts the injunction and frees the person from his script so that he can fulfill his own autonomous aspirations. It is a pre-set ‘self-destruct’ which is obvious in some scripts but has to be hunted for or decoded in others, much like the pronouncements of the Delphic oracle which served the same function in Ancient Greece. Not much is known about it clinically, because people come for treatment just because they cannot find it by themselves; but the therapist doesn’t wait for it or try it out. For example, in a ‘Waiting for Rigor Mortis ’ or ‘Sleeping Beauty’ script, the patient thinks she will be freed of her frigidity when she meets the Prince with the Golden Apples, and may very likely feel that the therapist is that Prince. But he declines the honor, mainly for ethical reasons, but also because when her previous (unlicensed) therapist took on the job, his Golden Apples turned to dust.

破咒者，或者说内在释放，是解除禁忌、使人摆脱既定剧本的关键要素，从而使其能够实现自主的愿望。它是一种预设的“自我毁灭”机制，在某些剧本中显而易见，但在另一些剧本中则需要寻找或解读，就像古希腊德尔斐神谕所发挥的相同作用一样。临床上对此知之甚少，因为人们前来接受治疗仅仅是因为他们自己无法找到它；但治疗师不会坐等它出现或尝试。例如，在“等待尸僵”或“睡美人”式的剧本中，患者认为当她遇到拥有金苹果的王子时，她就能摆脱性冷淡，并且很可能认为治疗师就是那位王子。但治疗师拒绝了这份殊荣，主要是出于伦理原因，但也因为当她之前的（无证）治疗师接手这项工作时，他的金苹果化为尘埃。

Sometimes the spellbreaker is merely ironic. This is a common situation in losers’ scripts: ‘Things will be better after you’re dead.’

有时，破除魔咒仅仅是一种反讽。这在失败者的剧本中很常见：“你死了之后一切都会好起来的。”

The internal release may be event-centered or time-centered. ‘When you meet a Prince,’ ‘After you die fighting,’ or ‘After you have three children’ are event-centered antiscripts. ‘When you pass the age at which your father died’ or ‘After you’ve stayed with the company thirty years’ are time-centered.

内部释放可以是事件中心式的，也可以是时间中心式的。“当你遇见一位王子”、“在你战斗至死之后”或“在你生了三个孩子之后”都是事件中心式的反脚本。“当你超过你父亲去世的年龄之后”或“在你为公司工作满三十年之后”则是时间中心式的。

Here is an example of how the internal release comes up in clinical practice.

以下是临床实践中内部释放的一个例子。

CHUCK

查克

Chuck was a general practitioner in an isolated area in the Rockies. There was no other doctor for miles around. He worked day and night, but no matter how hard he worked there was never enough to support his large family and he was always in debt to the bank. For a long time he had advertised in medical journals for a partner to give him some relief, but he insisted that no one suitable had ever shown up. He operated in fields, homes, and hospitals, and sometimes at the bottom of a mountain crag. He was immensely resourceful and almost completely exhausted, but not quite. He came for treatment with his wife because they were having marital problems, and his blood pressure was going up.

查克是落基山脉一个偏远地区的全科医生。方圆几英里内都没有其他医生。他日夜操劳，但无论多么努力，收入都不足以养活庞大的家庭，而且总是欠着银行的债。他长期以来一直在医学期刊上刊登广告寻找合伙人来分担工作，但他坚称始终没有合适的人选出现。他曾在田野、民宅、医院，有时甚至在山脚下行医。他足智多谋，几乎筋疲力尽，但又不至于完全倒下。他和妻子一起来就诊，因为他们的婚姻出现了问题，而且他的血压也升高了。

In the end, he found a University Hospital not far away which had some fellowships for general practitioners who wanted to become specialists. This time he did find someone to take his place as a country doctor. He gave up his complex practice and found that he had enough assets to keep his family going while he settled down as a surgical resident with a small stipend.

最后，他在离家不远的地方找到了一家大学附属医院，那里有一些面向希望成为专科医生的全科医生的进修机会。这一次，他终于找到了人接替他做乡村医生的工作。他放弃了繁重的诊疗工作，发现自己拥有的资产足以维持家人的生活，于是他安顿下来，成为一名收入微薄的外科住院医师。

‘I’ve always wanted to do this,’ he said. ‘But I never thought I’d get away from my driving Father Parent until after I’d had a coronary. But I didn’t have a coronary, and this is the happiest time of my life.’

“我一直都想这么做，”他说。“但我从未想过，在我心脏病发作之前，我能摆脱我那开车的父亲。但我没有心脏病发作，这是我一生中最幸福的时光。”

It is evident that his spellbreaker was to have a coronary, and he thought that was the only way he would ever get off the hook. But with the help of the group he did manage to break out of his script in good health.

很明显，他原本的计划是让破咒者突发心脏病，他认为这是他摆脱困境的唯一办法。但在大家的帮助下，他最终成功地摆脱了困境，并且身体健康。

Chuck illustrates in a relatively simple and clear-cut way the action of the whole script apparatus, as illustrated in the ‘script matrix’ in Figure 9 . His counterscript came from both parents: ‘Work hard.’ His father then gave him the pattern of a hard-working doctor. His mother’s injunction was ‘Never give up. Work hard until you drop dead.’ But his father gave him the spellbreaker: ‘You can relax if you have a coronary, ha ha.’ What his treatment did was get into that part of his brain or mind whence all these voices sent their directives. The injunction was then lifted by giving him permission: ‘You can relax without having a coronary.’ When this permission made its way through all the shells and devices protecting the script apparatus, it broke the curse.

查克用一种相对简单明了的方式阐释了整个脚本机制的运作，如图9所示的“脚本矩阵”。他的反脚本来自父母双方：“努力工作。”他的父亲给他树立了勤奋医生的榜样。他的母亲告诫他：“永不放弃。努力工作直到死去。”但他的父亲给了他一个破除魔咒的答案：“如果你得了心脏病，就可以放松了，哈哈。”他的治疗作用在于，它触及了他大脑或思维中发出所有这些指令的那部分区域。然后，通过给予他许可，解除了禁令：“你可以放松，而不会得心脏病。”当这个许可穿过保护脚本机制的所有外壳和装置时，它就打破了诅咒。

Note that it was useless to say to him ‘If you keep on this way you’ll have a coronary.’ (1) He was well aware of that threat, and telling him again only made him feel more miserable because (2) he wanted a coronary, which would free him one way or another. What he needed was not a threat, nor an order (he already had enough orders in his head), but a license that would liberate him from those orders, and that is what he got. Then he ceased to be a victim of his script, and became his own master to do his thing. He still worked hard, and he still followed his father’s medical pattern, but he was no longer script-ridden to overwork nor script-driven to drop dead. Thus, at the age of fifty, he became free to fulfill the autonomous aspirations of his own choice.

注意，对他说“你再这样下去会心脏病发作”是没用的。(1) 他很清楚这个威胁，再说一遍只会让他更痛苦，因为(2) 他想要心脏病发作，这样无论如何都能让他解脱。他需要的不是威胁，也不是命令（他脑子里已经塞满了命令），而是一份能让他摆脱这些命令的许可，而他也确实得到了。于是，他不再是自己人生剧本的受害者，而是成为了自己的主人，可以随心所欲地做自己想做的事。他仍然努力工作，仍然遵循着父亲的医疗模式，但他不再受制于过度劳累，也不再受制于死亡的命运。就这样，五十岁那年，他终于可以自由地追求自己选择的人生目标了。

FIGURE 9

图 9

K • The Script Equipment

K • 脚本设备

The script equipment is the nuts and bolts from which the script apparatus is built, a do-it-yourself kit partly supplied by the parents and partly by the child himself.

剧本设备是剧本装置的基本组成部分，它是一个 DIY 套件，一部分由家长提供，一部分由孩子自己提供。

CLEMENTINE

克莱门汀

Clementine was depressed by an unhappy love affair. She was afraid to be frank with her lover because she might lose him. On the other hand, she was afraid she might lose him if she wasn’t frank. There was nothing sinister in it, actually. It was just that she didn’t want him to know how passionate she really was. The conflict sometimes made her frigid and sometimes panicky. When she talked about it she felt so mixed up that she clutched her head.

克莱门汀因一段不幸的恋情而郁郁寡欢。她害怕对爱人坦诚相待，因为那样可能会失去他。另一方面，她又害怕如果不坦诚，反而会失去他。其实，这其中并没有什么阴谋。她只是不想让他知道自己内心深处的热情。这种矛盾让她时而冷漠，时而恐慌。每当谈起这件事，她都感到无比混乱，忍不住抱住了头。

What would her parents say about it? Well, her father would say: ‘Take it easy. Don’t lose your head.’ And her mother? ‘He’s taking advantage of you. Don’t get too attached to him. He’ll leave sooner or later. You’re not good enough for him. He’s not good enough for you.’ She went on to tell an adventure.

她父母会怎么说呢？嗯，她父亲会说：“冷静点，别太冲动。”她母亲会怎么说呢？“他是在利用你，别对他太投入。他迟早会离开的。你配不上他，他也配不上你。”她接着讲了一个冒险故事。

When she was about five, an adolescent uncle had got sexy with her, and made her feel sexy, too. She never told her parents. One day when she was taking a bath, her father told her how cute she was. There were some visitors in the house and he had held her up naked for them to see. The sexy uncle was one of them. What were her reactions? ‘I want to hide. I want to hide.’ ‘My God, they’ll find out what I’ve been doing.’ How did you feel toward your father for doing that? ‘I wanted to kick him in the penis. I knew what a penis looked like, too, from my uncle’s erections.’ Was there any ha ha? ‘Yes, deep down, there was. I had a secret. And worst of all, I knew I liked it under all the other feelings.’

她五岁左右的时候，一个十几岁的叔叔对她动了情，也让她觉得自己很性感。她从未告诉过父母。有一天，她洗澡的时候，父亲夸她可爱。当时家里来了几个客人，父亲把她抱起来让他们看，她当时一丝不挂。那个动情的叔叔就是其中之一。她当时的反应是什么？“我想躲起来。我想躲起来。”“我的天哪，他们会发现我做了什么。”你当时对父亲的这种行为有什么感觉？“我真想踢他的下体。从叔叔勃起的样子，我知道阴茎长什么样了。”你当时觉得好笑吗？“是的，内心深处是的。我藏着一个秘密。更糟糕的是，我知道在所有其他感觉之下，我其实挺喜欢那种感觉的。”

From these reactions Clementine had constructed a script, which was to have passionate love affairs and then get left. Along with that, however, she also wanted to get married, stay married, and have children.

根据这些反应，克莱门汀构思了一个剧本：先经历激情四溢的恋情，然后被抛弃。但与此同时，她也渴望结婚、维持婚姻，并生儿育女。

1. There were two counterscript slogans from her father: ‘Take it easy,’ and ‘Don’t lose your head.’ These fitted in with her aspirations of getting married and raising a family.

1. 她父亲曾给她提出两条相反的建议：“放轻松点”和“别慌张”。这些建议与她结婚生子的愿望不谋而合。

2. There were five injunctions from mother, all telescoped into ‘Don’t get attached to anyone.’

2. 母亲下了五条诫命，全部都归结为“不要对任何人产生感情”。

3. There was a strong seduction to be passionate and sexy from her uncle, reinforced by the nude provocation from her father.

3. 她叔叔强烈诱惑她变得热情性感，而她父亲的裸体挑逗更是强化了这种诱惑。

4. These seductions and provocations from Parental demons had reinforced her own demon throughout her life.

4. 父母的这些恶魔般的诱惑和挑衅，在她的一生中不断强化着她自己的恶魔。

5. There was a strong implication of a built-in release: the familiar Prince with the Golden Apples – not like father; if she could only find one.

5. 有强烈的暗示，那就是一个内置的释放：熟悉的王子带着金苹果——不像父亲那样；如果她能找到一个的话。

The interesting thing is that this whole bit came out in one session. As someone remarked, she was quite happy to hold it up for everyone to see.

有趣的是，这一切都是在一次谈话中说出来的。正如有人所说，她很乐意把这件事展示给大家看。

L • Aspirations and Conversations

L • 愿望与对话

Caught in the mesh of his script apparatus, Jeder meanwhile has his own autonomous aspirations. These usually appear to him in day dreams in his leisure hours, or in hypnagogic hallucinations before he falls asleep: the brave deeds he should have done this morning, or the tranquil scenes he looks forward to in later years. All men and all women have their secret gardens, whose gates they guard against the profane invasion of the vulgar crowd. These are visual pictures of what they would do if they could do as they pleased. The lucky ones find the right time, place, and person, and get to do it, while the rest must wander wistfully outside their own walls. And that is what this book is about: what happens outside those walls, the external transactions that parch or water the flowers within.

身陷剧本罗网的杰德，却也拥有着自己独立的渴望。这些渴望通常出现在他闲暇时的白日梦中，或是入睡前的催眠幻觉里：他本该在今天早上完成的英勇事迹，或是他期盼在晚年拥有的宁静景象。每个人都有自己的秘密花园，守护着它的大门，抵御庸俗人群的侵扰。这些花园是他们如果能够随心所欲会去做的事情的视觉化呈现。幸运的人找到了合适的时机、地点和人，得以实现这些愿望，而其他人则只能在自己的花园之外，满怀憧憬地徘徊。这本书讲述的正是这些：花园之外发生的一切，那些滋润或干涸花园的外部互动。

What people want to do is shown in visual pictures, the home movies they make inside their skulls. What they do do is decided by voices, the skull-rapping of internal dialogue.
