Each sentence they say and each scripty decision is the result of such a dialogue: Mother says and Father says and Adult says You’d better, while Child, thus encircled, tries to break through to get what he wants. No one can know the enormous, amazing, and almost infinite amount of dialogue he has stored up in the dim-lit caverns of his mind. There are complete answers there to questions he never even dreamed of. But if the right button is pushed, sometimes they pour out in sheer poetry.

人们想做什么，会以视觉图像的形式展现出来，就像他们在脑海里拍摄的家庭电影。而他们实际做什么，则是由内心的声音决定的，是脑海里不断回响的内心对话。他们说的每一句话，做的每一个决定，都是这种对话的结果：母亲说，父亲说，成年人说“你最好……”，而孩子，就这样被包围着，试图突破束缚，得到自己想要的东西。没有人能够知道，在他昏暗的脑海深处，究竟储存着多少庞大、惊人、几乎无穷无尽的对话。那里有他从未想过的问题的完整答案。但如果按下正确的按钮，有时它们会如诗如画般倾泻而出。

Grasp your right forefinger in your left hand. What is your hand saying to your finger, and what does finger have to say for himself? If you do this right, you will soon find a lively and meaningful conversation going on between them. The amazing part is that it was there all the time, and so are hundreds of others. If you have a cold and an upset stomach, what is your churning stomach saying to your congested nose? If you are sitting with your foot swinging, what has your foot got to say to you today? Ask it and it will answer. The dialogue is right there in your head. All this was discovered, or at least brought into full light by the originator of Gestalt therapy, F. S. Perls. 5 Similarly, all your decisions are made by four or five people in your head, whose voices you can overlook if you are too proud to hear them, but they will be there next time if you care to listen. Script analysts learn how to amplify and identify these voices, and that is an important part of their therapy. 6

用左手握住你的右手食指。你的手在对你的手指说什么？你的手指又在对自己说什么？如果你这样做，你很快就会发现它们之间正在进行一场生动而有意义的对话。神奇的是，这种对话一直都在那里，而且还有成百上千种其他的对话也存在。如果你感冒了，胃也不舒服，你翻江倒海的胃在对堵塞的鼻子说什么？如果你坐着时脚在晃动，你的脚今天想对你说些什么？问问它，它会回答。对话就在你的脑海里。所有这一切都是由格式塔疗法的创始人F.S.珀尔斯发现的，或者至少是他充分阐明的。同样地，你所有的决定都是由你脑海里的四五个“人”做出的，如果你太骄傲而听不到他们的声音，你可能会忽略它们，但如果你愿意倾听，下次它们还会在那里。剧本分析师学习如何放大和识别这些声音，这是他们治疗的重要组成部分。

The object of script analysis is to free Jeder and Zoe so that they can open the garden of their aspirations to the world. It does that by cutting through the Babel in their heads until the Child can say: ‘But this is what I want to do, and I would rather do it my own way.’

剧本分析的目的是解放杰德和佐伊，让他们能够向世界敞开他们梦想的花园。它通过打破他们头脑中的巴别塔来实现这一目标，直到孩子能够说：“但这就是我想做的，我宁愿用我自己的方式来做。”

M • Winners

M • 获奖者

Winners are programed, too. Instead of a curse, there is a blessing: ‘Long life!’ or ‘Be a great man.’ The injunction is adaptive instead of constricting: ‘Don’t be selfish!’ and the come-on is ‘Well done!’ With such benevolent controls, and all his permissions, there is still his demon to contend with, lurking in the murky caverns of his primal mind. If his demon is a friend instead of an enemy, then he will have it made.

成功者也同样被设定了程序。他们得到的不是诅咒，而是祝福：“长寿！”或“成为伟人”。告诫是适应性的，而非束缚性的：“不要自私！”而鼓励的话语则是“干得好！”。即便拥有如此仁慈的控制和所有许可，他仍然要与潜伏在他原始意识深处的恶魔抗争。如果他的恶魔是朋友而非敌人，那么他便能成功。

N • Does Everyone Have a Script?

N • 每个人都有剧本吗？

At present, there is no way to answer this question with any degree of certainty, but it is certain that everyone is programed to some extent from early years. As previously mentioned, some people can become autonomous through drastic external circumstances, others by internal reorganization, and still others by applying the antiscript. The key lies in permissions. The more permissions Jeder has, the less he is bound by his script. On the other side, the more severely the script controls were reinforced, the more script-bound he is. It is likely that the human race as a whole forms a curve. At one end are those who become autonomous by one means or another, and at the other end are those who are script-bound, with most people in between, subject to changes in circumstances or outlook. Among the script-bound, there are two types. Script-driven people are those who have lots of permissions, but must fulfill the demands of their scripts before they can enjoy them. A good example is the hard worker who can have fun in his spare time. Script-ridden people are those who have few permissions, but must spend as much time as possible fulfilling their scripts at any cost. A typical example is the heavy drinker or drug addict who must speed toward his doom as quickly as he can. The script-ridden are the victims of tragic or ‘hamartic’ scripts. On the other hand, it is a rare person who has not at one time or another heard the voice of the demon in his head, telling him to buy when he should sell, or stay when he should go, or speak when he should remain silent. 7

目前，这个问题尚无法给出确切的答案，但可以肯定的是，每个人从幼年起就在某种程度上被“设定”了。正如前文所述，有些人可以通过剧烈的外部环境变化获得自主性，有些人可以通过内部重组获得自主性，还有些人可以通过应用反脚本获得自主性。关键在于权限。杰德拥有的权限越多，他受脚本的束缚就越少。反之，脚本控制越严格，他就越受脚本的束缚。人类整体可能呈现出一条曲线。一端是那些通过各种方式获得自主性的人，另一端是那些受脚本束缚的人，而大多数人则介于两者之间，会受到环境或观念变化的影响。在受脚本束缚的人中，又可以分为两类。脚本驱动型的人拥有很多权限，但必须先满足脚本的要求才能享受这些权限。一个很好的例子就是那些努力工作，却能在闲暇时间享受乐趣的人。受剧本束缚的人往往权限有限，却必须不惜一切代价尽可能多地完成自己的剧本。一个典型的例子是酗酒者或吸毒者，他们必须尽快走向毁灭。受剧本束缚的人是悲剧或“不义”剧本的受害者。另一方面，几乎每个人都曾听到过脑海中恶魔的声音，告诉他该卖的时候买，该走的时候留，该沉默的时候说话。

O • The Antiscript

O • 反脚本

But there are some people who rebel against their scripts, apparently doing the opposite of what they are ‘supposed’ to. Common examples are the ‘rebellious’ adolescent and the woman who says ‘The last thing I want to do is be like my mother.’ Such cases have to be evaluated very carefully, as there are several possibilities. (1) They may have been living on their counterscripts, and the apparent rebellion is merely ‘an outbreak of script.’ (2) Conversely, they may have been living on their scripts, and shifted to their counterscripts. (3) They may have found the spellbreaker, and been released from their scripts. (4) They may have different script directives from each parent, or from two different sets of parents, and are shifting from one set to another. (5) They may be merely following a special script directive that tells them to rebel. (6) The person may be a ‘script failure’ who has despaired of carrying out his script directives and has simply given up. This is the cause of many depressions and schizophrenic breakdowns. (7) On the other hand, he may have freed himself and ‘got out of his script’ through his own efforts or with the help of psychotherapy. (8) But this must be carefully distinguished from ‘going into an antiscript.’ These many alternatives emphasize how thorough the script analyst must be if he (and his patient) are to understand correctly the origin of certain changes in behavior.

但有些人会反抗既定的人生剧本，表面上做着与“应该”做的事情截然相反的事。常见的例子包括“叛逆”的青少年和说“我最不想做的就是像我妈妈那样”的女性。这类情况需要仔细评估，因为存在几种可能性。(1) 他们可能一直按照反剧本生活，而表面上的反叛仅仅是“剧本的爆发”。(2) 相反，他们可能一直按照既定的剧本生活，后来转向了反剧本。(3) 他们可能找到了破除魔咒的人，从而摆脱了既定的剧本。(4) 他们可能来自父母双方，或者来自两组不同的父母，并且正在从一组剧本转向另一组。(5) 他们可能只是在遵循某种特殊的剧本指令，该指令告诉他们要反叛。(6) 这个人可能是一个“剧本失败者”，他对执行既定的剧本指令感到绝望，并彻底放弃了。这是许多抑郁症和精神分裂症发作的原因。(7) 另一方面，他可能通过自身努力或心理治疗的帮助，摆脱了束缚，走出了“剧本”。(8) 但这必须与“进入反剧本”仔细区分开来。这些多种可能性凸显了剧本分析师必须多么细致入微，才能（以及他的患者）正确理解某些行为改变的根源。

An antiscript resembles closely what Erikson calls ‘identity diffusion.’ 8 If the script is compared to a computer punch card, then an antiscript is attained by turning the card around. This is a very rough analogy, but it makes the point. Where mother says ‘Don’t drink,’ Jeder drinks. Where she says ‘Take a shower every day,’ he doesn’t wash. Where she says ‘Don’t think,’ he thinks, and where she says ‘Study hard,’ he drops out. In short, Jeder is meticulously defiant. But since he has to consult his programing to know precisely how and where to be defiant, he is just as surely programed by disobeying each instruction as he would be if he obeyed them all. Thus, where ‘freedom’ is really defiance, it is only an illusion. Inverting his programing still leaves him programed. Such an inversion, turning the card around rather than tearing it up, is called an antiscript, and antiscripts offer a fertile field for further study.

反脚本与埃里克森所说的“身份扩散”非常相似。如果将脚本比作电脑穿孔卡片，那么反脚本就是将卡片翻转过来。这只是一个非常粗略的比喻，但却能说明问题。母亲说“不要喝酒”，杰德却喝了；母亲说“每天洗澡”，他却不洗；母亲说“不要思考”，他却思考；母亲说“努力学习”，他却辍学了。简而言之，杰德一丝不苟地反抗。但由于他必须参考自己的程序才能确切地知道如何以及在何处反抗，因此，他违抗每一条指令与他遵守所有指令一样，都必然受到程序的约束。因此，当“自由”实际上变成反抗时，它只是一种幻觉。即使反转了他的程序，他仍然受到程序的约束。这种将牌翻过来而不是撕掉的做法被称为反手牌，反手牌为进一步研究提供了一个肥沃的领域。

P • Summary

P • 摘要

The script apparatus of a loser consists on one hand of injunctions, provocations, and a curse. These are the script controls, and are firmly implanted by the age of six. To combat this programing, he has an inner demon, and is sometimes supplied with an internal release. Later he comes to understand slogans, which give him a counterscript. Throughout, he is learning behavior patterns, which serve both the script and the counterscript. A winner has the same apparatus, but the programing is more adaptive, and he usually has more autonomy because he has more permissions. But in all human beings the demon persists, to bring sudden pleasure or grief.

失败者的脚本机制一方面包含禁令、挑衅和诅咒。这些是脚本控制机制，早在六岁时就已根深蒂固。为了对抗这种程序设定，他内心深处潜藏着一个恶魔，有时还会获得某种内在的释放。后来，他开始理解口号，这为他提供了一种反脚本。在此过程中，他不断学习各种行为模式，这些模式既服务于脚本，也服务于反脚本。成功者拥有同样的机制，但他们的程序设定更具适应性，而且通常拥有更大的自主权，因为他们拥有更多的权限。然而，在所有人类身上，恶魔始终存在，随时可能带来突如其来的快乐或悲伤。

It should be noted that the script controls are parameters or strictures, which merely set limits on what Jeder can do, while the behavior patterns he learns from his parents, including their games, tell him how he can actually structure his time. Thus, the script is a complete plan for living, offering both strictures and structures.

需要注意的是，脚本中的控制项是参数或限制条件，它们仅仅限制了杰德可以做的事情；而他从父母那里学到的行为模式，包括他们玩的游戏，则告诉他如何真正安排自己的时间。因此，脚本是一套完整的生活计划，既包含限制条件，也包含结构。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 Berne, E. Transactional Analysis in Psychotherapy. Loc. cit .

1 Berne, E. 心理治疗中的交互分析。同上。

2 The fairy godmother and witch-mother, ‘electrode-like’ introjects, derived from transaction and introspective observations, will be easily recognized as allied to the good and bad introjected objects of Melaine Klein postulated on psychoanalytic grounds, and to the elaborations of her concepts by Fairbairn. In fact, Fairbairn is one of the best heuristic bridges between transactional analysis and psychoanalysis.

2. 仙女教母和女巫母亲，这些“电极状”的内摄对象，源于交互和内省的观察，很容易被识别为与梅兰妮·克莱因基于精神分析提出的善与恶内摄对象，以及费尔贝恩对她概念的阐述密切相关。事实上，费尔贝恩是交互分析和精神分析之间最佳的启发式桥梁之一。

Klein, M. The Psychoanalysis of Children . Hogarth Press, London, 1932.

克莱因，M.《儿童精神分析》。伦敦霍加斯出版社，1932年。

Fairbairn, W. R. D. The Object-Relations Theory of Personality . Basic Books, New York, 1954.

费尔贝恩，W. R. D. 人格的客体关系理论。基础书籍出版社，纽约，1954 年。

All this is disappointing from a literary point of view. It brings an unfortunate confrontation with Wordsworth, and Francis Thompson’s line ‘each child has a fairy godmother in its soul’ has to be modified, in this light, to include less benevolent mentors.

从文学角度来看，这一切都令人失望。它不幸地与华兹华斯产生了冲突，弗朗西斯·汤普森那句“每个孩子心中都有一个仙女教母”在这种情况下必须加以修改，以涵盖那些不那么仁慈的导师。

Cf. Sharpe, E. F. ‘Francis Thompson: A Psycho-Analytical Study,’ in her Collected Papers on Psycho-Analysis . Hogarth Press, London, 1950.

参见 Sharpe, E. F.《弗朗西斯·汤普森：精神分析研究》，载于其《精神分析论文集》。伦敦霍加斯出版社，1950 年。

3 Cf. Berne, E. ‘The Problem of Masturbation.’ Diseases of the Nervous System 10:3–7, 1944.

3 参见 Berne, E.《手淫问题》。神经系统疾病 10:3–7, 1944。

4 Cf. Berne, E. ‘Concerning the Nature of Diagnosis.’ International Record of Medicine 165:283–292, 1952. The differences between the types of transactions engaged in by mechanics, as compared with farmers, show in their faces. Since they were presumably born with the same assortment of facial muscles and nerves going to them, the differences must be due to some sort of ‘electrodes’ in their central nervous systems. In one case the electrodes says ‘Look alert’ and in the other ‘Wait and see,’ and these slogans describe the kinds of transactions they are engaged in.

4 参见 Berne, E.，《论诊断的本质》，《国际医学记录》165:283–292，1952。机械工和农民所从事的交易类型之间的差异，从他们的脸上就能看出来。既然他们生来就拥有相同的面部肌肉和神经，那么这些差异必然是由于他们中枢神经系统中的某种“电极”造成的。一种情况下，这些电极发出“保持警惕”的信号，另一种情况下则发出“静观其变”的信号，而这些口号恰恰描述了他们所从事的交易类型。

5 Perls, F. S. Gestalt Therapy Verbatim (J. O. Stevens, ed.). Real People Press, Lafayette, California, 1969.

5 Perls, F. S.格式塔疗法实录（J. O. Stevens 编辑）。Real People Press，加利福尼亚州拉斐特，1969 年。

6 Cf. Shapiro, S. B. ‘Transactional Aspects of Ego Therapy.’ American Journal of Psychology 56:479–498, 1953.

6 参见 Shapiro, S. B. ‘自我疗法的交互方面’。《美国心理学杂志》56:479–498, 1953。

7 The injunction, of course, has the same effect and the same origin as the Superego of psychoanalysis, and the counterscript slogan belongs here also. The demon is the same as the original concept of the Id. The situation seems to be this: the demon itself, the impulse, is an ‘id impulse.’ But phenomenologically, the demon is experienced as a living voice. This is the voice of the actual parent (or more precisely, the voice of the demon in the parent) implanted in the child. Speaking for the parent’s Id, it also speaks for the Id of the still wordless child.

7 当然，这条禁令与精神分析中的超我具有相同的效果和起源，反驳的口号也适用于此。魔鬼与本我的原始概念相同。情况似乎是这样的：魔鬼本身，即冲动，是一种“本我冲动”。但从现象学的角度来看，魔鬼被体验为一种鲜活的声音。这是植入孩子体内的父母的真实声音（或者更准确地说，是父母体内魔鬼的声音）。它代表父母的本我发声，也代表着那个尚未开口说话的孩子的本我发声。

Re ‘mother’s crazy Child,’ see Denenberg and Whimby, ‘Behavior of Adult Rats is Modified by the Experiences Their Mothers Had as Infants.’ Loc. cit .

关于“母亲的疯狂孩子”，参见 Denenberg 和 Whimby，“成年老鼠的行为受其母亲婴儿时期经历的影响”。同上。

8 Erikson, E. Identity and the Life Cycle, Loc. cit .

8 Erikson, E. 身份与生命周期，同上。

fn1 The reader is once more reminded that Parent, Adult, and Child, capitalized, refer to ego states, while parent, adult, and child, without capitals, refer to actual people.

fn1 再次提醒读者，首字母大写的 Parent、Adult 和 Child 指的是自我状态，而首字母小写的 parent、adult 和 child 指的是实际的人。

#↩

CHAPTER EIGHT

第八章

Later Childhood

童年后期

A • Plots and Heroes

A • 情节与英雄

Later childhood, from six to ten, is called by psychoanalysis the latent period . It is a ‘locomotor’ phase, 1 when the child locomotes himself around the neighborhood to see what he can see. So far, he has only a sketchy idea, a protocol, as to how he is going to put his script equipment together to make himself into a person with a goal in life. He is ready to turn from animals who eat people or who act like people, to people themselves.

精神分析将六岁到十岁的儿童后期称为潜伏期。这是一个“运动”阶段，孩子会在附近四处走动，探索周围的世界。到目前为止，他对于如何构建自己的人生目标，成为一个有目标的人，只有粗略的概念和初步的规划。他准备从“吃人”或“像人一样行事”的动物，转变为真正的人。

A child who starts out wanting to live forever or love forever can be made to change his mind in the course of five or six years 2 until he decides, quite appropriately in view of his limited experience, to die young or never to risk loving anyone again. Or he may learn from his parents that life and love with all their risks are worthwhile. Once the decision is made, he knows who he is, and begins to look at the outside world with the question: ‘What can happen to people like me?’ He knows what the payoff is supposed to be, but doesn’t really know what it means, how it will feel, or how to go about getting it. He has to find some sort of plot or matrix into which all his script equipment will fit, and some sort of hero to show him the path. He also looks wistfully for heroes with similar equipment who have followed different, and perhaps happier, paths, hoping to find a way out, or a way in.

一个孩子最初渴望永生或永生，但五六年之后，他的想法可能会发生转变，最终，考虑到他有限的人生阅历，他或许会做出一个看似合情合理的决定：要么英年早逝，要么永远不再冒险去爱任何人。又或许，他会从父母那里领悟到，生命和爱情，即便充满风险，也依然值得珍惜。一旦做出决定，他便认清了自己，开始带着这样的疑问审视外部世界：“像我这样的人会怎样？”他知道最终的回报应该是什么，但却并不真正了解它的意义、感受，以及如何才能获得它。他必须找到某种情节或框架，将他所有的人生经历融入其中，并找到一位英雄来指引方向。他也会满怀憧憬地寻找那些拥有相似经历、却走上不同道路（或许更加幸福）的英雄，希望能从中找到出路，或者找到一条通往幸福的道路。

The matrix and the hero are offered to him in stories which he reads in books or which are read to him or told to him by some reliable person: mother, grandmother, or children on the street, or perhaps a carefully indoctrinated kindergarten teacher. The telling of these tales is a story in itself – more real and fascinating than the tale that is told. What happens between Jeder and his mother, for example, between the time she says: ‘After you’ve brushed your teeth I’ll read you a story,’ and the moment when she smiles ‘That’s all!’ and tucks him in? What is his final question, and how does she tuck him in? Those times help form the flesh of his life plan, while the tales told or the book story give him the bones. What he ends up with, bone-wise, are (a) a hero – someone he would like to be; (b) a villain – someone he may find an excuse to be; (c) a type – what he knows he has to be; (d) a plot – a matrix of events which enables him to switch from one to the other; (e) a cast – those others who will motivate the switches; and (f) an ethos – a set of ethical standards which will justify him in feeling angry, hurt, guilty, righteous, or triumphant. If external events permit, his life course will then be the same as the life plan he forms around this armature or matrix. For this reason, it is important to know what his favorite story or fairy tale was as a child, since this will be the plot of his script, with all its unattainable illusions and avoidable tragedies.

故事中的矩阵和英雄形象，要么来自他从书中读到的，要么来自某些可靠的人——母亲、祖母、街头的孩子，甚至是经过精心灌输的幼儿园老师——讲述给他听的故事。这些故事的讲述本身就是一个故事——比故事本身更真实、更引人入胜。例如，杰德和他母亲之间发生了什么？从她说“你刷完牙我就给你讲个故事”到她微笑着说“好了！”并给他盖好被子，这期间发生了什么？他最后一个问题是什么？她又是如何给他盖好被子的？这些时刻构成了他人生规划的血肉，而那些被讲述的故事或书中的故事则为他勾勒出骨架。最终，他拥有的，从骨架上来说，是：（a）一个英雄——他想要成为的人；（b）一个反派——他可能会找到借口成为的人；（c）一种类型——他知道自己必须成为的人。 (d) 情节——一个事件矩阵，使他能够在不同情绪之间切换；(e) 角色——那些促使他进行情绪切换的人或事物；以及 (f) 伦理——一套道德标准，使他能够合理地表达愤怒、受伤、内疚、正义或胜利等情绪。如果外部事件允许，他的人生轨迹将与他围绕这个框架或矩阵所构建的人生规划完全一致。因此，了解他童年最喜欢的故事或童话至关重要，因为这将成为他人生剧本的情节，其中包含着所有无法实现的幻想和可以避免的悲剧。

B • Rackets

B • 球拍

During this period, Jeder also makes a definite decision about what kind of feelings he will work for. He has previously experimented with this, feeling by turns angry, hurt, guilty, scared, inadequate, righteous, and triumphant, and has discovered that certain of these are treated with indifference or outright disapproval by his family, while one of them is acceptable and gets results. That is the one that becomes his racket. The favored feeling becomes a sort of conditioned reflex which may persist for the rest of his life.

在此期间，杰德也最终决定了自己要追求哪种情绪。他之前曾尝试过，体验过愤怒、受伤、内疚、恐惧、无力感、正义感和胜利感，并发现其中一些情绪会被家人漠视甚至强烈反对，而只有一种情绪能够被接受并带来成效。这种情绪便成了他的谋生之道。这种他偏爱的情绪逐渐形成了一种条件反射，或许会伴随他一生。

In order to clarify this, we can use the roulette-wheel theory of feeling. Suppose there is a housing development with 36 houses built in a circle around a central plaza, and suppose that there is a baby waiting to be born wherever it is that babies wait to be born. The Great Computer in charge of such matters spins a roulette wheel, and the ball falls in slot 17. The Great Computer then announces ‘The next baby will go to house 17.’ He makes five more spins, and comes up with 23, 11, 26, 35, and 31, so the next five babies go to the houses with those numbers. Ten years later, each of the children has learned how he is supposed to react. The one in house 17 has learned: ‘In this family, when the going gets rough, we feel angry.’ The one in house 23 has learned: ‘In this family, when the going gets rough, we feel hurt.’ The babies at 11, 26, and 35 have learned that when the going gets rough their respective families feel guilty, scared, or inadequate. The baby in 31 learns that ‘In this family, when the going gets rough, we find out what to do about it.’ It should be apparent that numbers 17, 23, 11, 26, and 35 are likely to be losers, and 31 is more likely to be a winner.

为了阐明这一点，我们可以用轮盘赌的情感理论来解释。假设有一个住宅区，36栋房子围绕着一个中心广场呈环形排列。假设在任何一个等待婴儿出生的地方，都有一个婴儿正在等待降生。负责此事的“超级计算机”转动轮盘，小球落入了17号槽。超级计算机随即宣布：“下一个婴儿将入住17号房子。”它又转动了五次轮盘，分别得到了23、11、26、35和31这五个数字，于是接下来的五个婴儿分别入住这五个数字对应的房子。十年后，每个孩子都学会了如何应对这种情况。 17号房子里的孩子学会了：“在这个家里，遇到困难时，我们会感到愤怒。” 23号房子里的孩子学会了：“在这个家里，遇到困难时，我们会感到受伤。” 11号、26号和35号房子里的孩子学会了，遇到困难时，他们各自的家庭会感到内疚、害怕或无能为力。31号房子里的孩子学会了：“在这个家里，遇到困难时，我们会想办法解决。” 显然，17号、23号、11号、26号和35号房子里的孩子很可能是失败者，而31号房子里的孩子更有可能是成功者。

But supposing when the Great Computer made the spins, other numbers had come up, or the same numbers in a different order? Perhaps Baby A, instead of going to 17, would have gone to 11, and learned to cultivate guilt instead of anger, and Baby B, in 23, might have traded places with Baby F in 31. Then instead of Baby B being a loser and Baby F a winner, it would be the other way round.

但假设当那台“大计算机”进行转盘时，出现的是其他数字，或者相同的数字顺序不同呢？也许婴儿A不是到了17岁，而是到了11岁，学会了培养愧疚而不是愤怒；而婴儿B，到了23岁，可能就和婴儿F，到了31岁，互换了位置。这样一来，就不是婴儿B是输家，婴儿F是赢家，而是反过来了。

This is another way of saying that aside from a doubtful influence of the genes, favorite feelings are learned from the parents. A patient whose favored feeling is guilt might go for anger if he had been born in a different household. Yet each will defend his favored feeling as the natural or even inevitable one in a given situation. That is one reason for having treatment groups. If those six babies were in such a group twenty years later, and Baby A related an incident, ending: ‘Naturally, I felt angry!’ Baby B would say: ‘My feelings would have been hurt;’ Baby C: ‘I would have felt guilty;’ Baby D: ‘I would have felt scared;’ Baby E: ‘I would have felt inadequate;’ and Baby F (who would presumably be the therapist by this time): ‘I would have found out what to do about it.’ Which of the babies is right? Each one is convinced that his is the ‘natural’ reaction. The truth is that none of them is ‘natural,’ really; each one has been learned, or rather decided upon, in early childhood.

换句话说，除了基因可能产生的影响之外，人们偏爱的感受大多是从父母那里习得的。一个偏爱内疚的病人，如果出生在另一个家庭，他可能会选择愤怒。然而，每个人都会辩称自己偏爱的感受是自然的，甚至是特定情况下不可避免的。这正是设立治疗小组的原因之一。假设这六个婴儿二十年后参加这样的小组，A 讲述了一件事，最后说道：“我当时很生气！” B 会说：“我会感到受伤；” C 会说：“我会感到内疚；” D 会说：“我会感到害怕；” E 会说：“我会感到无能为力；” F 会说（此时他很可能已经是治疗师了）：“我会找到解决办法。” 哪个婴儿是对的呢？他们都坚信自己的反应是“自然的”。但事实是，这些反应都不是真正“自然的”；每一种反应都是在幼儿时期习得的，或者更确切地说，是他们自己选择的。

To put it in simpler terms, nearly all angers, hurts, guilts, fears, and inadequate feelings are rackets, and in any well-run group it is not difficult to distinguish the few such reactions which are genuinely appropriate. A racket, then, is a feeling, out of all the possible feelings, that is habitually turned on by a given person as his payoff in the games he plays. Group members soon recognize this, and can predict when a certain patient is going to collect an anger trading stamp, when another is going to collect a hurt trading stamp, and so on. The object of collecting such trading stamps is to turn them in for a script payoff.

简单来说，几乎所有的愤怒、伤痛、内疚、恐惧和不足感都是“套路”，在任何运作良好的团体中，都不难区分出真正恰当的少数反应。“套路”指的是，在所有可能的感受中，某人习惯性地选择某种感受，作为他在游戏中获利的手段。团体成员很快就能意识到这一点，并能预测某个患者何时会收集“愤怒交易印章”，何时会收集“伤痛交易印章”，等等。收集这些“交易印章”的目的是为了换取剧本奖励。

Each person in the group is scandalized at the idea that his favored feeling is not a natural, universal, and inevitable response to the situations he meets. People in the anger racket, in particular, become very angry when their feelings are questioned, just as people in the hurt racket feel hurt.

群体中的每个人都对自己的感受并非自然、普遍且不可避免的反应感到震惊，因为他们无法接受这样的事实：自己偏爱的情感并非面对困境时的自然反应。尤其是那些“愤怒型”群体成员，一旦自己的感受受到质疑，就会变得异常愤怒，正如那些“受伤型”群体成员感到受伤一样。

C • Trading Stamps

C • 交易邮票

Psychological ‘trading stamps’ are called that because they are used the same way as the little blue, green, or brown stamps that people get as a premium when they buy groceries or gasoline. The following are some observations concerning commercial trading stamps.

心理上的“交易印章”之所以得名，是因为它们的使用方式与人们购买食品杂货或汽油时获得的蓝色、绿色或棕色小印章类似。以下是一些关于商业交易印章的观察。

1. They are usually obtained as a bonus in the course of legitimate business transactions; that is, the person has to buy groceries to get trading stamps.

1. 它们通常是在合法商业交易过程中作为奖励获得的；也就是说，这个人必须购买食品杂货才能获得交易印章。

2. Most people who collect them have a favorite color. If offered other colors, they may not bother to take them, or may give them away. Some people, however, will collect any type of trading stamp.

2. 大多数集邮者都有自己偏爱的颜色。如果有人提供其他颜色，他们可能根本不会收，或者会把剩下的送人。不过，也有一些人会收集任何类型的集邮品。

3. Some people paste them into their little ‘books’ every day, and others at regular intervals, while still others leave them lying around until some day when they are bored and have nothing better to do, and then they paste them up all at once. Some neglect them until they need something, and then count them in the hope that they have enough to get it free from the trading-stamp store.

3. 有些人每天都把邮票贴到他们的小“册子”里，有些人则定期贴，还有些人则把它们随意放置，直到某天无聊无事可做时，才一股脑地全部贴上去。有些人则一直忽略邮票，直到需要什么东西时才想起它们，然后数一数，希望数量足够从集邮店免费兑换。

4. Some people like to talk about them, look through the catalogue together, boast about how many stamps they have, or discuss which color offers better merchandise or better bargains.

4. 有些人喜欢谈论邮票，一起翻阅目录，吹嘘自己有多少邮票，或者讨论哪种颜色的邮票商品更好或更划算。

5. Some people save only a few and then turn them in for trivial premiums; others save more, and get bigger bonuses; and still others become deeply involved in trying to collect enough stamps for one of the really large prizes.

5. 有些人只攒了几张邮票，然后兑换成微不足道的奖金；有些人攒得更多，获得了更大的奖金；还有些人则全身心投入到收集邮票的活动中，希望能赢得真正的大奖。

6. Some people know that the trading stamps are not really ‘free’ because their cost must be added to the cost of the groceries; some really do not stop to think about this; some know it, but pretend they don’t, because they enjoy both the collecting and the illusion of getting something for nothing. (In some cases, the cost of the trading stamps is not added to the cost of the groceries; in such cases, the grocer has to take their cost as his own loss. But in principle, it is the customer who pays for the trading stamps.)

6. 有些人知道这些交易券并非真正“免费”，因为它们的成本必须加到食品杂货的价格里；有些人根本没想过这个问题；有些人明知故犯，因为他们既享受收集的过程，也享受那种不劳而获的错觉。（在某些情况下，交易券的成本不会加到食品杂货的价格里；在这种情况下，杂货商必须自行承担这部分成本。但原则上，最终还是顾客在为交易券买单。）

7. Some people prefer to go to ‘straight’ grocery stores where they pay only for the groceries; with the money they save, they can then buy their own merchandise wherever and whenever they want to.

7. 有些人喜欢去“纯粹”的杂货店，在那里他们只支付杂货的费用；用省下来的钱，他们可以随时随地购买自己想要的商品。

8. For those who are eager to get something ‘free,’ it is possible to buy counterfeit trading stamps.

8. 对于那些渴望获得“免费”东西的人来说，购买伪造的交易邮票是可能的。

9. It is usually hard for a person who seriously collects trading stamps to give them up. He may put them in a drawer and forget about them for a while, but if he suddenly gets a large fistful in some special transaction, he may pull them out again to count them and see what they are good for.

9. 对于认真收集集邮邮票的人来说，通常很难放弃它们。他可能会把它们放在抽屉里，过一段时间就忘了，但如果他突然在一次特殊的交易中得到一大把，他可能会再次把它们拿出来清点，看看它们有什么用。

Psychological trading stamps are the currency of transactional ‘rackets.’ When Jeder is young, his parents teach him how to feel when things get difficult: most commonly, angry, hurt, guilty, scared, or inadequate; but sometimes stupid, baffled, surprised, righteous, or triumphant. These feelings become rackets when Jeder learns to exploit them and play games in order to collect as many as possible of his favorite, partly because in the course of time this favorite feeling becomes sexualized, or is a substitute for sexual feelings. For example, much ‘justified’ grownup anger belongs in this category, and is usually the payoff in a game of ‘Now I’ve Got You, You Son of a Bitch.’ The patient’s Child is full of suppressed anger, and he waits until someone does something to justify his expressing it. Justification means that his Adult goes along with his Child in saying to his Parent: ‘No one can reasonably blame me for getting angry under such conditions.’ Thus relieved of Parental censure, he turns on the offender and says in effect: ‘Ha! No one can blame me, so now I’ve got you,’ etc. In transactional language, he gets a ‘free’ mad, that is, free of guilt. Sometimes it works differently. The Parent says to the Child: ‘You aren’t going to let him get away with that, are you?’ and the Adult sides with the Parent: ‘Anyone would get angry under such conditions.’ The Child may be only too happy to comply with these urgings; or on the other hand, he may be as reluctant to do battle as Ferdinand the Bull, but is forced to enter the fray.

心理交易印章是交易“骗局”的货币。杰德小时候，父母教他遇到困难时该如何感受：最常见的是愤怒、受伤、内疚、恐惧或无能为力；但有时也会感到愚蠢、困惑、惊讶、义愤填膺或胜利。当杰德学会利用这些感受，并玩弄心计来尽可能多地收集他最喜欢的感受时，这些感受就变成了骗局。部分原因是，随着时间的推移，这种他最喜欢的感受被性化了，或者说成了性欲的替代品。例如，许多“正当”的成年人愤怒就属于这一类，通常是“现在我抓到你了，你这混蛋”游戏中的奖励。病人的“孩子”内心充满了压抑的愤怒，他等待着有人做出某种事来证明他表达愤怒的合理性。辩解意味着，成年人会附和孩子，对父母说：“在这种情况下，没人能合理地责怪我生气。” 这样一来，摆脱了父母的责备，他便转而攻击冒犯者，实际上是说：“哈！没人能责怪我，现在我抓到你了！”等等。用交易的语言来说，他获得了一次“免费的”愤怒，也就是说，他没有感到内疚。有时情况则不同。父母对孩子说：“你不会让他逍遥法外吧？” 成年人则站在父母一边：“在这种情况下，任何人都会生气。” 孩子可能非常乐意顺从这些劝告；或者，他可能像公牛费迪南德一样不愿战斗，但最终还是被迫卷入其中。

Psychological trading stamps follow the same pattern as commercial ones. 3

心理交易邮票遵循与商业邮票相同的模式。

1. They are usually obtained as a by-product of legitimate transactions. Marital arguments, for example, usually start over some actual problem, which is the ‘groceries.’ While the Adult is carrying on its business, the Child is eagerly waiting to pick up bonuses.

1. 它们通常是合法交易的副产品。例如，夫妻争吵通常源于一些实际问题，比如“买菜”。当成年人忙于处理日常事务时，孩子则翘首以盼，等着领取额外奖励。

2. People who collect psychological trading stamps have favorite ‘colors,’ and if offered other colors, they may not bother to take them. A person who collects angers will let guilts and fears go by, or let someone else pick them up. In fact, in a soundly structured marital game, one spouse will pick up all the angers while the other picks up all the guilts or inadequacies, so that they both ‘win’ and add to their collections. There are some people, however, who will collect any kind of trading stamps. These are people who are starved for feelings and will play ‘Greenhouse,’ happily showing off any kind of feeling that comes along. Psychologists are especially prone to pick up windblown feelings from the sidewalk, and if they are group therapists, to encourage their patients to do likewise.

2. 收集心理“交换印章”的人有自己偏爱的“颜色”，如果提供其他颜色，他们可能根本不会理会。收集愤怒情绪的人会放任内疚和恐惧，或者让别人去收集。事实上，在一个结构合理的婚姻游戏中，一方会收集所有的愤怒情绪，而另一方则会收集所有的内疚或不足感，这样双方都能“获胜”，并增加各自的“交换印章”。然而，有些人会收集任何类型的“交换印章”。这些人渴望感受，会玩“温室游戏”，乐于展示任何涌现的情绪。心理学家尤其喜欢从人行道上收集随风飘散的情绪，如果他们是团体治疗师，还会鼓励他们的患者也这样做。

3. Some people go over their hurts and angers every night before going to sleep; others do it less frequently; while still others only do it when they are bored and have nothing better to do. Some wait until they need one big justification, and then count up all their hurts and angers in the hope that they have enough to warrant an outburst of anger, a ‘free’ sulk, or some other dramatic emotional display. Some people like to save them and some like to spend them.

3. 有些人每晚睡前都会回顾自己的伤痛和愤怒；有些人则频率较低；还有些人只有在无聊无事可做时才会这样做。有些人会等到需要一个充分的理由时，才开始细数自己所有的伤痛和愤怒，希望积攒到足以引发一场怒火爆发、一场“免费”的闷闷不乐，或其他一些戏剧性的情绪表现。有些人喜欢把这些情绪积攒起来，有些人则喜欢把它们释放出来。

4. People like to show their collections of feelings to others, and to talk about who has more or better angers, hurts, guilts, fears, etc. In fact, many saloons become showrooms where people can go to boast about their trading stamps: ‘You think your wife is unreasonable – well, listen to this!’ or ‘I know what you mean. It takes even less than that to hurt (scare) me. Yesterday …’ or ‘Embarrassed (guilty, inadequate)? I coulda sunk through the floor!’

4. 人们喜欢向他人展示自己的各种情绪，并谈论谁的愤怒、伤痛、愧疚、恐惧等等更多、更强烈。事实上，许多酒吧都成了人们炫耀自己“情感印记”的场所：“你觉得你老婆不讲道理？听听这个！”或者“我懂你的意思。其实我更容易受伤（害怕）。昨天……”或者“尴尬（愧疚、自卑）？我当时简直要崩溃了！”

5. The ‘store’ where psychological trading stamps are redeemed has the same array of prizes as the commercial trading-stamp center: little ones, bigger ones, and really big ones. For one or two ‘books’ the person can get a small prize, such as a free (‘justified’) drunk or sexual fantasy; for ten ‘books’ he can get a toy (unsuccessful) suicide or an adultery, and for one hundred ‘books’ he can get one of the big ones: a free quit (divorce, leave treatment, quit job), a free go to the mental hospital (colloquially known as a free crazy), a free suicide, or a free homicide.

5. 兑换心理交易印章的“商店”提供的奖品与商业交易印章中心的奖品种类相同：小奖、大奖和超级大奖。集齐一两本“印章”就能获得小奖，例如一次免费的（“正当的”）醉酒或性幻想；集齐十本“印章”就能获得一次玩具（未成功的）自杀或婚外情；集齐一百本“印章”就能获得一项大奖：一次免费的“退出”（离婚、停止治疗、辞职）、一次免费的精神病院之旅（俗称“免费疯人院”）、一次免费的自杀或一次免费的杀人。

6. Some people learn that psychological trading stamps are not really free, and that the collected feelings have to be paid for in loneliness, insomnia, raised blood pressure, or stomach trouble, so they stop collecting them. Others never do learn about this. Some know it, but continue to play games and collect payoffs because otherwise their lives would be too drab; since they feel little justification for their way of living, they have to content themselves with collecting small justifications for small outbursts of vitality.

6. 有些人逐渐明白，心理交易券并非真正免费，收集这些情绪需要付出孤独、失眠、血压升高或胃部不适的代价，于是他们停止收集。另一些人则始终不明白这一点。有些人明知如此，却依然沉迷其中，继续收集回报，因为否则他们的生活会显得过于单调乏味；由于他们觉得自己的生活方式缺乏正当性，所以只能满足于收集一些微不足道的理由，来为自己短暂的活力爆发找到些许慰藉。

7. Some people prefer to talk straight rather than play games: that is, they will not act provocatively in order to get trading stamps, and will refuse to respond to the spurious provocative behavior of others. With the energy thus saved, they are ready when they meet the right person at the right time in the right place for more legitimate expressions of feeling. (In some cases, people collect psychological trading stamps painlessly and someone else pays the price. Thus a criminal may enjoy all the pleasures of robbing a bank without feeling bad about it or getting caught; apparently, some professional con men and card sharps can live very happily in this way if they do not get too greedy and push too hard. Some teen-agers enjoy dismaying their elders without feeling any remorse or other ill effects. But in principle, the person who collects trading stamps usually has to pay for them sooner or later.)

7. 有些人更喜欢直言不讳，而不是玩弄心机：也就是说，他们不会为了获得“交易印记”而故意挑衅，也不会回应他人虚假的挑衅行为。这样一来，他们就能节省精力，在合适的时间、合适的地点遇到合适的人时，以更正当的方式表达自己的情感。（在某些情况下，人们可以毫不费力地收集心理上的“交易印记”，而代价却由他人承担。例如，罪犯可以享受抢劫银行的快感，却不会感到愧疚或被抓；显然，一些职业骗子和老千如果不太贪婪、不太过分，也能靠这种方式过得很开心。有些青少年喜欢让长辈感到沮丧，却不会感到任何愧疚或其他不良后果。但原则上，收集“交易印记”的人迟早都要为此付出代价。）

8. Some people, particularly paranoids, collect ‘counterfeit’ trading stamps. If no one will provoke them, they imagine provocations. Then, if they are impatient, they can get a free suicide or a free homicide without having to rely on the natural course of events to supply enough irritations for a legitimate outburst. In this respect, there are two types of paranoids. The Child paranoid collects counterfeit wrongs and says ‘See what they did to me,’ while the Parent paranoid collects counterfeit rights, and says ‘They can’t do this to me.’ In fact there are ‘check raisers’ as well as true counterfeiters among paranoids. Those with delusions can pick up very small trading stamps here and there and raise each of them into a very large denomination so as to get a large payoff quickly. Those with voice hallucinations can manufacture trading stamps ad infinitum right out of their heads. 4

8. 有些人，尤其是妄想症患者，会收集“伪造”的交易邮票。如果没人挑衅他们，他们就会臆想出挑衅的理由。这样，如果他们不耐烦，就能轻易地自杀或杀人，而无需依赖自然事件的发生来获得足够的刺激，从而引发一场正当的情绪爆发。在这方面，妄想症患者可以分为两类。“孩童型妄想症患者”收集伪造的错误，并说“看看他们对我做了什么”，而“父母型妄想症患者”收集伪造的权利，并说“他们不能这样对我”。事实上，妄想症患者中既有“抬高面值者”，也有真正的伪造者。那些有妄想症的人可以到处收集小面值的交易邮票，然后将它们面值抬高，从而迅速获得巨额回报。那些有幻听的人甚至可以凭空捏造出无限的交易邮票。

9. It is just as hard for a patient to give up a lifelong collection of hard-earned psychological trading stamps as it would be for a housewife to burn her commercial ones. This is one factor hindering recovery, since, in order to be cured, the patient must not only stop playing games compulsively, but must also forgo the pleasure of using the stamps he has collected previously. ‘Forgiveness’ of previous wrongs is not enough: they have to become truly irrelevant for the future course of his life if he truly gives up his script. In my experience, ‘forgiveness’ means putting the trading stamps away in a drawer, rather than disposing of them permanently; they will stay in the drawer as long as things go smoothly, but if there is a new offense, they will be pulled out and added to the new payoff in calculating the prize. Thus an alcoholic who ‘forgives’ his wife will not go on just a little binge if she slips up again, but may throw in all the trading stamps he has got from all her slips or insults over the whole course of their marriage, and go on an epical bender perhaps ending in delirium tremens.

9. 对病人来说，放弃毕生辛苦积累的心理交易邮票，就像家庭主妇烧掉她的商业邮票一样困难。这是阻碍康复的一个因素，因为为了治愈，病人不仅要停止强迫性地玩游戏，还要放弃使用之前收集的邮票所带来的快感。“原谅”过去的错误是不够的：如果他真的放弃了自己的剧本，这些错误必须对他未来的生活轨迹真正无关紧要。以我的经验来看，“原谅”意味着把交易邮票收进抽屉里，而不是永久丢弃；只要一切顺利，它们就会一直待在抽屉里，但如果出现新的错误，它们就会被拿出来，加到新的收益中，以计算最终的奖励。因此，一个“原谅”妻子的酗酒者，如果妻子再次犯错，他不会只是小酌几杯，而是会把婚姻期间妻子所有失言或侮辱所积累的“筹码”全部拿出来，进行一场史诗般的狂欢，甚至可能以震颤性谵妄告终。

So far, nothing has been said about ‘good’ feelings such as righteousness, triumph, and joy. Righteousness stamps are made of fool’s gold, and will not pass as currency anywhere except in fool’s paradise. Triumph stamps glitter, but they are not collected by people of good taste because they are only gilt. They can be turned in, however, for a free celebration, and can thus be used worthily to bring fun to a large number of people. Joy, like despair, is a genuine feeling, and is not the payoff of a game; thus we can speak of golden joy, just as we speak of black despair.

到目前为止，我们还没有谈到诸如正义、胜利和喜悦之类的“美好”感受。正义邮票是用假金制成的，除了在虚幻的天堂里，在其他任何地方都无法流通。胜利邮票闪闪发光，但有品位的人不会收藏，因为它们只是镀金的。然而，它们可以用来兑换免费的庆祝活动，因此可以名正言顺地用来给许多人带来欢乐。喜悦，就像绝望一样，是一种真实的情感，而不是游戏的奖赏；因此，我们可以谈论金色的喜悦，正如我们可以谈论黑色的绝望一样。

The important clinical point about ‘good’ feelings is that people who save ‘brown’ stamps, the ‘bad’ feelings or ‘feeling bads’ discussed above, are often reluctant to accept ‘gold’ stamps when they are offered in the form of compliments or ‘strokes.’ They are quite comfortable with the familiar, bad, old feelings, but do not know where to put good ones, and so they will turn them away or ignore them by pretending not to hear. As a matter of fact, a zealous collector of ‘brown’ stamps can turn even the most sincere compliments into veiled insults, so that instead of wasting them by refusing them or not hearing them, he will transform them into counterfeit browns. The most common example is: ‘My, you look good today!’ bringing out the response: ‘I knew you didn’t like the way I looked last week.’ Another is: ‘My, that’s a beautiful dress!’ eliciting: ‘So you didn’t like the one I wore yesterday!’ With a little practice, anyone can learn to transform compliments into insults, and by spraying a little feces over a pleasant gold stamp, turn it into an unpleasant brown one.

关于“好”感觉的重要临床意义在于，那些积攒“棕色”邮票（即上文讨论的“坏”感觉或“不愉快感受”）的人，往往不愿接受以赞美或“抚慰”形式出现的“金色”邮票。他们对熟悉的、糟糕的、陈旧的感受习以为常，却不知该如何安置美好的感受，因此他们会拒绝或假装没听见。事实上，一个热衷于收集“棕色”邮票的人，甚至能将最真诚的赞美转化为隐晦的侮辱，这样一来，他们就不会因为拒绝或无视而浪费这些赞美，而是会将它们转化为伪造的“棕色”邮票。最常见的例子是：“哇，你今天真漂亮！” 对方可能会回应：“我就知道你不喜欢我上周的样子。” 另一个例子是：“哇，这条裙子真漂亮！” 对方可能会回应：“所以你不喜欢我昨天穿的那条！” 只要稍加练习，任何人都能学会把赞美变成侮辱，就像在漂亮的金色印章上喷点粪便，就能把它变成难看的棕色印章一样。

The following anecdote illustrates how easy it is for a Martian to understand the concept of psychological trading stamps. A woman came home from a group meeting one day where she had heard it for the first time, and explained it to her twelve-year-old son. He said ‘OK, mom, I’ll be back soon.’ When he returned, he had made a small roll of perforated paper stamps and a little dispenser to hold them, together with a paper book with the pages ruled off into squares. On the first page he had written: ‘This page when full of stamps entitles you to one free suffer.’ He understood perfectly. If people do not spontaneously provoke you, insult you, entice you or frighten you, then you start a game in order to make them do it. In this way you collect a free mad, hurt, guilt, or fright, and a few of these add up to one free suffer.

以下这个轶事说明了火星人理解“心理交易邮票”概念有多么容易。一天，一位女士参加完一个小组会议，第一次听到了这个概念，回家后便向她十二岁的儿子解释了一番。儿子说：“好的，妈妈，我很快就回来。”回来时，他已经准备好了一小卷带孔的纸质邮票和一个用来装邮票的小盒子，还有一本纸质小册子，书页上画满了方格。他在第一页写道：“这一页贴满邮票，你就能获得一次免费的痛苦。”儿子完全明白了。如果人们没有主动挑衅你、侮辱你、引诱你或吓唬你，那么你就发起一个游戏，让他们这么做。这样，你就能收集到免费的愤怒、伤害、内疚或恐惧，而几次这样的情绪累积起来，就能获得一次免费的痛苦。

There is another similarity between psychological trading stamps and commercial ones. They are both canceled once they are used, but people still like to talk nostalgically about the ones they turned in. The key word here is ‘recall.’ Real people, in ordinary conversation, say ‘Do you remember when …’ whereas ‘Do you recall …’ is usually used in referring to trading stamps that were used up and canceled long ago. ‘Do you remember the good time we had in Yosemite?’ is reminiscence, whereas: ‘Do you recall what happened at Yosemite? First you dented the fender, and furthermore you forgot to … and then, as I recall, you … and in addition …’ etc. is a worn-out reproach which is not good for a justified anger any more. Lawyers habitually use the world ‘recall’ rather than ‘remember’ in the exercise of their profession, when they bring out the plaintiff’s often faded and sometimes counterfeit trading stamps to show the judge or jury. Lawyers are, in fact, philatelists, connoisseurs of psychological trading stamps; they can look over a collection, large or small, and estimate its current market value at the big redemption store in the courthouse.

心理交易印章和商业印章之间还有另一个相似之处。它们一旦使用就会被注销，但人们仍然喜欢怀念地谈论他们交回的那些印章。这里的关键词是“回忆”。在日常对话中，人们会说“你还记得……吗？”，而“你还记得……”通常用于指代早已用完并注销的交易印章。“你还记得我们在优胜美地度过的美好时光吗？”是回忆，而“你还记得在优胜美地发生了什么事吗？你先是撞凹了挡泥板，而且你还忘了……然后，我记得你……此外……”等等，则是一种陈旧的责备，不再适合用来表达正当的愤怒。律师在执业过程中也习惯性地使用“回忆”而不是“记得”，当他们拿出原告那些往往褪色甚至伪造的交易印章向法官或陪审团展示时。事实上，律师都是集邮家，是心理交易邮票的鉴赏家；他们可以查看一套邮票，无论大小，并估算出它在法院大型兑换商店的当前市场价值。

Crooked spouses can con each other by pulling out used or counterfeit trading stamps. Thus, Francisco discovered that his wife Angela was having an affair with her employer, and in fact rescued her when the employer threatened her with violence. After a tempestuous scene, she thanked him and he forgave her. But afterward, whenever he got drunk, which was often, he brought the matter up again, and there was another scene. In trading-stamp language, in the first scene he got a justified anger, she genuinely thanked him, and he generously forgave her. That was a decent settlement, and all the trading stamps were canceled.

奸诈的夫妻会利用旧邮票或伪造邮票互相欺骗。弗朗西斯科发现妻子安吉拉与她的雇主有染，并在雇主威胁要对她施暴时出手相救。一番激烈的争吵后，安吉拉向他道谢，他也原谅了她。但之后，每当弗朗西斯科喝醉（这种情况经常发生）时，他都会再次提起这件事，于是又爆发了一场争吵。用邮票交易的术语来说，第一次争吵中，他理所当然地发怒了，安吉拉真诚地感谢了他，而他则宽容地原谅了她。这算是一个体面的结局，所有邮票都被注销了。

But, as noted, ‘forgive’ in practice means to put the stamps in the drawer until they are needed again, even though they have already been cashed in. In this case, Francisco pulled out the old canceled stamps every Saturday night and waved them in Angela’s face. Instead of pointing out that they had already been used, Angela would hang her head and let Francisco have another free anger. In return, she would fob off on him some counterfeit thank-you stamps. The first time she thanked him, she gave him true stamps of golden gratitude, but after that her thanks were tired and spurious, ‘fool’s gold’ or iron pyrites, which he, in his drunken foolishness, cherished like the real thing. When he was sober, both of them could be honest and regard the matter as settled. But when he was drinking, they became crooked with each other. He blackmailed her with phony reruns, and she paid him off in kind.

但正如前面提到的，“原谅”在实践中意味着把邮票收起来，直到下次需要时再拿出来，即使它们已经被兑现过。在这种情况下，弗朗西斯科每个星期六晚上都会拿出那些旧的、已经盖销的邮票，在安吉拉面前挥舞。安吉拉非但没有指出它们已经被用过了，反而低着头，任由弗朗西斯科再次发泄怒火。作为回报，她会给他一些伪造的感谢邮票。第一次她感谢他时，给了他真正的、象征着金色感激的邮票，但之后她的感谢就变得苍白无力，如同“愚人金”或黄铁矿，而他却在醉酒的愚蠢中，把它们视作真金白银。当他清醒的时候，他们两人都能坦诚相待，认为这件事已经了结。但当他喝酒时，他们就互相欺骗。他用伪造的重播邮票敲诈她，而她则以同样的方式偿还他。

Thus the analogy between commercial and psychological trading stamps is almost perfect. Each person tends to handle both kinds in the same way, according to his upbringing. Some people are raised to cash them in and forget it. Others are taught to save them and savor them; they keep their paper stamps and gloat over them as they mount up in anticipation of the day when they will be able to cash them in for a big prize; and they deal the same way with their angers, hurts, fears, and guilts, keeping them bottled up until they have enough for a really big payoff. Still others have permission to cheat, and use considerable ingenuity in doing so.

因此，商业和心理交易券之间的类比几乎完美。每个人处理这两种交易券的方式都倾向于相同，这取决于他们的成长经历。有些人从小就被教育要兑换成现金，然后就忘掉它。另一些人则被教导要积攒并细细品味；他们保留着纸质交易券，并对其不断积累感到欣喜，期待着有一天能用它们兑换到丰厚的回报；他们处理愤怒、伤痛、恐惧和内疚的方式也相同，将它们深藏心底，直到积累到足以获得真正巨大回报的程度。还有一些人被允许作弊，并且会巧妙地运用各种手段来达到目的。

Psychological trading stamps exist as emotional memories, which probably take the form of molecular patterns in a continual state of agitation, or electrical potentials which go round and round in a circle of Jordan curve; and neither of them is completely exhausted until there is some kind of discharge of the piled-up energy. The rate at which the configurations or the potentials decay is probably based partly on genes and partly on ‘early conditioning’ which in our terms falls into the category of parental programing. At any rate, if a person brings out the same old trading stamps again and again to exhibit to his audience, they begin to look more and more tired and shopworn, and so does the audience.

心理交易印记以情感记忆的形式存在，这些记忆可能以持续活跃的分子模式或沿约当曲线循环往复的电位形式存在；而且，只有当积累的能量以某种方式释放时，它们才会完全耗尽。这些构型或电位的衰减速度可能部分取决于基因，部分取决于“早期条件反射”，用我们的话来说，这属于父母教养的范畴。无论如何，如果一个人反复拿出同样的旧交易印记来向观众展示，这些印记就会显得越来越陈旧乏味，观众也会如此。

D • Illusions

D • 幻觉

Childhood illusions have mainly to do with rewards for being good and punishments for being bad. Good means mainly not being angry (‘Temper, temper!’) or sexy (‘Nasty, nasty!’) but it is all right to be frightened or ashamed. That is, Jeder is not supposed to express either his ‘instinct for self-preservation,’ whose expression can be quite satisfying, or his ‘instinct for preservation of the species,’ whose expression can be very pleasurable even at an early age; but he is allowed to have as many unsatisfying, unpleasant feelings as he wishes.

童年的幻想主要与做好事有奖惩、做坏事有罚有关。做好事主要意味着不生气（“发脾气，发脾气！”）或不性感（“真恶心，真恶心！”），但感到害怕或羞愧也是可以的。也就是说，杰德不应该表现出他“自我保护的本能”（这种本能的表达可能相当令人满意），也不应该表现出他“延续物种的本能”（这种本能的表达即使在很小的时候也能带来极大的愉悦）；但他可以拥有任何他想要的、令人不快或不愉快的感受。

There are many systems which make formal rules about rewards and punishments. Besides legal systems, which exist everywhere, there are religious and ideological ones. Half the world are ‘true believers’ (about one billion Christians and half a billion Moslems) for whom the rules regarding afterlife are most important. The ‘heathen’ half are judged during their earthly sojourns by local gods or by their national governments. For the script analyst, however, the most important codes are the informal, hidden ones which are peculiar to each family.

许多体系都制定了关于奖惩的正式规则。除了无处不在的法律体系之外，还有宗教和意识形态体系。世界上有一半的人是“真正的信徒”（约十亿基督徒和五亿穆斯林），对他们来说，关于来世的规则至关重要。而“异教徒”则在尘世间由当地神灵或国家政府审判。然而，对于剧本分析家来说，最重要的准则却是那些非正式的、隐秘的、每个家庭独有的规则。

For small children, there is usually some sort of Santa Claus who is watching their behavior and keeping the accounts. But he is for the ‘little kids,’ and ‘big kids’ don’t believe in him, at least not in Santa Claus as a man in a masquerade costume who comes on a certain day of the year. In fact, not believing in that kind of Santa Claus is what separates big kids from the little ones, along with the knowledge of where babies come from. But big kids, and grownups too, have their own versions of Santa, each one different. Some grownups are more interested in Santa Claus’s family than in Santa himself, and firmly believe that if they behave properly they will sooner or later have their chance with either his son, Prince Charming, or his daughter Snegurotchka, the Snow-Maiden, or even with his Missis, Mrs Menopause. In fact, most people spend their lives waiting for Santa Claus, or for some member of his family.

对于小孩子来说，通常会有一个类似圣诞老人的人物在观察他们的行为并记录他们的功课。但这只是针对“小孩子”的，而“大孩子”并不相信他，至少不相信圣诞老人会穿着奇装异服，在一年中的某一天出现。事实上，不相信这种圣诞老人，以及对婴儿由来一事的了解，正是区分大孩子和小孩子的关键所在。但大孩子，以及成年人，都有他们自己版本的圣诞老人，每个版本都不一样。有些成年人对圣诞老人的家人比对圣诞老人本人更感兴趣，他们坚信，只要自己表现得好，迟早会有机会见到他的儿子——白马王子，或者他的女儿——雪姑娘，甚至是他的妻子——更年期夫人。事实上，大多数人一生都在等待圣诞老人，或者他的某个家人。

And then there is his opposite number down below. Where Santa himself is a jolly man in a red suit who comes from the North Pole bringing gifts, his opposite number is a grim man in a black cloak who comes from the South Pole carrying a scythe, and his name is Death. Thus the human race is split during later childhood into the Life Crowd, who will spend their lives waiting for Santa Claus, and the Death Crowd, who will spend their lives waiting for Death. These are the basic illusions on which all scripts are based: that either Santa Claus will come eventually bringing gifts for the winners, or Death will come eventually and solve all the problems for the losers. Thus the first question to ask about illusions is: ‘Are you waiting for Santa Claus, or Death?’

然后，还有他位于下方的对立面。圣诞老人是一位身穿红色衣服、从北极带来礼物的和蔼老人，而他的对立面是一位身披黑色斗篷、手持镰刀、从南极而来的阴沉老人，他的名字叫死神。因此，人类在童年后期被分为两类：一类是“生命之群”，他们将终生等待圣诞老人的到来；另一类是“死亡之群”，他们将终生等待死神的降临。这些是所有故事剧本所基于的基本错觉：要么圣诞老人最终会到来，为胜利者带来礼物；要么死神最终会到来，为失败者解决所有问题。因此，关于错觉，首先要问的问题是：“你是在等待圣诞老人，还是在等待死神？”

But before the Final Gift (immortality) or the Final Solution (death), there are meanwhile others. Santa can bestow a winning lottery ticket, a life pension, or prolonged youth. Death can bestow a permanent disability, a cessation of sexual desire, or premature old age, each of which relieves the person of some of his duties. For example, women in the Death Crowd are convinced that menopause will offer succor and surcease: that all sexual desire will vanish, to be replaced by hot flashes and melancholia which will excuse them forevermore from living. This sad myth, that Mrs Menopause will rescue them, is titled ‘Wooden Ovaries’ in the language of script analysis. Some men also grab for this with ‘Wooden Testicles,’ the myth of the male menopause.

但在最终的礼物（永生）或最终的解决方案（死亡）到来之前，还有其他的礼物。圣诞老人可以赐予一张中奖彩票、终身养老金或青春永驻。死亡可以带来永久性残疾、性欲消退或早衰，每一种都使人摆脱了一些责任。例如，死亡人群中的女性深信更年期会带来救赎和解脱：她们认为所有性欲都会消失，取而代之的是潮热和忧郁，这将使她们永远摆脱生活的束缚。这种认为更年期女士会拯救她们的悲哀迷思，在剧本分析中被称为“木质卵巢”。一些男性也试图用“木质睾丸”——男性更年期的迷思——来寻求慰藉。

Every script is based on some such illusion, and it is the grievous but necessary task of script analysis to undermine it, hence the blunt titles which get this done with the most dispatch and the shortest pain. The transactional importance of the illusion is that it provides a cause, and a reason for saving up trading stamps. Thus people who are waiting for Santa Claus will save either compliments to show how good they have been, or ‘suffers’ of various kinds to arouse his compassion, while those who are waiting for Death will save guilt or futility stamps to show that they are worthy of him or will welcome him with gratitude. But any kind of stamp may be offered to either Santa Claus or Death in the hope that with clever salesmanship the desired merchandise will be forthcoming.

每部剧本都建立在某种幻觉之上，而剧本分析这项艰巨却又必不可少的任务就是揭穿这种幻觉，因此才有了直白的标题，它们能以最快捷、最省力的方式完成这项任务。这种幻觉在交易中的重要性在于，它为人们积攒交易邮票提供了理由和目的。因此，那些等待圣诞老人到来的人会积攒赞美之词来证明自己有多乖，或者积攒各种“苦难”来博取他的同情；而那些等待死神降临的人则会积攒罪恶感或徒劳感的邮票，以表明自己配得上死神，或者表示将满怀感激地迎接他的到来。但无论献给圣诞老人还是死神，任何种类的邮票都可以被献上，人们希望凭借巧妙的推销技巧，就能得到想要的商品。

The illusion, then, has to do with the store where the trading stamps are turned in, and there are two different stores, each with different rules. By doing enough good, or enduring enough suffering, Jeder can collect enough gold or brown stamps to turn in on a free gift from Santa’s Store. By collecting enough guilts or futilities, he can get a free gift from the Death Shop. Actually, Santa and Death do not actually run stores. They are more like itinerant peddlers. Jeder has to wait for Santa or Death to come, and he never knows when they will. That is why he must save his trading stamps and always have them ready, because if he misses his opportunity when Santa or Death does pass by, he never knows when he will get another chance. If he is saving cheerios, then he must think positively at all times, because if he relaxes even for a moment, that might be the very moment of Santa’s arrival. Similarly, if he is saving suffers, he must not risk ever looking happy because if Santa catches him off guard he will have lost his opportunity. It is the same with people in the Death Crowd. They cannot afford to risk even a single moment free of guilt or futility, for that might be the very moment of Death’s visit, and then they would be condemned to live until the next round, which might be – well, only Death knows how long the suspense might have to continue.

那么，这个幻象就与兑换印章的商店有关，实际上有两个不同的商店，每个商店的规则都不一样。杰德可以通过行善或忍受苦难来收集足够的金币或棕色印章，从而在圣诞老人商店兑换一份免费礼物。通过收集足够的罪恶感或徒劳感，他可以从死神商店获得一份免费礼物。实际上，圣诞老人和死神并没有真正经营商店，他们更像是四处游荡的小贩。杰德必须等待圣诞老人或死神的到来，但他永远不知道他们何时会来。这就是为什么他必须积攒印章，并且时刻准备好，因为如果错过了圣诞老人或死神路过的机会，他就不知道何时才能再次获得机会。如果他积攒的是麦片，那么他必须时刻保持积极的心态，因为哪怕放松片刻，圣诞老人也可能就会出现。同样地，如果他积攒的是苦难感，他就绝不能让自己看起来开心，因为如果圣诞老人让他措手不及，他就会失去机会。死亡人群也是如此。他们连一刻摆脱罪恶感或徒劳感的风险都承受不起，因为那可能正是死神降临的时刻，然后他们就注定要活到下一轮，而下一轮——嗯，只有死神才知道这悬念还要持续多久。

Illusions are the ‘if onlys’ and ‘some days’ upon which most people base their existence. In some countries, government lotteries offer the only possibility for Jeder to make his dreams come true, and thousands of men spend their lives, day after day, waiting for their numbers to come up. Now the truth of the matter is that there is a Santa Claus: at every drawing, somebody’s number does come up and his dreams do come true. But oddly enough, in most cases, this does not bring happiness, and many people let their winnings slip through their fingers and return to their former state. This is because the whole system of illusions is a magical one: not only will the reward arrive magically, but it will be magic in itself. A proper child knows that the real Santa Claus will come down the chimney while he is asleep and leave him a little red wagon or a golden orange. But it will not be an ordinary little red wagon or orange; instead, a magical and unique one studded with rubies and diamonds. When Jeder discovers that the little red wagon or orange has indeed arrived, but that it is just an ordinary one like everybody else’s, he is disappointed and asks: ‘Is that all?’ much to the mystification of his parents, who thought they were giving him exactly what he wanted. Similarly, the man who wins the lottery finds that the things he buys are the same as the things other people have, so he often says: ‘Is that all?’ and blows it. He would rather go back and sit under the tree hoping for magic than enjoy what he has. That is, illusions are more attractive than reality, and even the most attractive reality may be abandoned in favor of the most tenuous or improbable illusion.

大多数人的生活都建立在“要是……就好了”和“总有一天”的幻想之上。在一些国家，政府彩票是人们实现梦想的唯一途径，成千上万的人日复一日地等待着中奖。事实上，圣诞老人的确存在：每次开奖，总会有人中奖，他们的梦想也会成真。但奇怪的是，在大多数情况下，这并没有带来幸福，许多人眼睁睁地看着奖金从指缝间溜走，最终又回到了原点。这是因为整个幻想体系都充满了魔力：奖励不仅会神奇地到来，而且它本身就是魔法。一个懂事的孩子都知道，真正的圣诞老人会在他睡着的时候从烟囱里下来，给他留下一辆红色小车或一个金橙。但这并非普通的红色小车或金橙；而是一辆镶满红宝石和钻石的、独一无二的魔法小车或金橙。当杰德发现他想要的小红车或橘子确实到了，但却只是一辆和别人一样的普通车时，他很失望，问道：“就这些吗？”这让他的父母百思不得其解，因为他们以为已经给了他想要的东西。同样，中了彩票的人发现自己买的东西和别人拥有的没什么两样，于是他常常会说：“就这些吗？”然后就放弃了。他宁愿回到圣诞树下，盼望奇迹发生，也不愿享受自己已经拥有的东西。也就是说，幻象比现实更有吸引力，即使是最诱人的现实，也可能被最虚幻或最不切实际的幻象所取代。

Among the most remarkable examples of this are certain people with a ‘Never Give Up’ script. One of the things they are reluctant to give up are their bowel movements, so that they suffer from chronic constipation. The illusion is that if they only hold on long enough Santa Claus will come, or if he doesn’t at least they have something of their own to make up for the gifts they won’t get. Some of these people are in an excellent position to enjoy a rewarding reality, but they would rather ‘sit’ at home, waiting for they know not what or whom to come and rescue them. One such woman, even when she was lying flat on the analytic couch, would say: ‘I’m sitting here thinking.’ At home she spent a lot of constipated time doing just that. She found it hard to mingle with people, because wherever she went she carried a psychological toilet with her, and no matter what her Adult was doing, her Child was sitting on its favorite seat.

最引人注目的例子莫过于那些奉行“永不放弃”信条的人。他们不愿放弃的事情之一就是排便，因此饱受慢性便秘的折磨。他们幻想，只要坚持足够长的时间，圣诞老人就会来；即便圣诞老人没来，他们至少也能得到一些补偿，弥补那些没收到的礼物。这些人中有些明明拥有享受美好生活的绝佳条件，却宁愿“待”在家里，等待着不知何人或何事来拯救他们。一位这样的女士，即便平躺在心理分析的沙发上，也会说：“我坐在这里思考。”在家时，她便秘难耐，只能不停地思考。她发现自己很难与人交往，因为无论走到哪里，她都带着一个心理厕所，无论她内心的“成人”在做什么，“儿童”都如影随形地坐在它最爱的“马桶”上。

Actually, the Child almost never gives up its illusions. Some of them are universal, as Freud pointed out, and probably arise in the first few months of life, or even in the womb, which is a magical world man can only find later through love, sex, or drugs (or perhaps, with vicious people, through massacre). Freud names as the three earliest ones: ‘I am immortal, omnipotent, and irresistible.’ Of course these primal illusions do not last long in the face of infant reality: mother, father, time, gravity, unknown and frightening sights and sounds, and internal sensations of hunger, fear, and pain. But they are replaced by conditional illusions which are strong influences in the formation of scripts. There they appear as If Onlys: ‘If only I behave in the right way, Santa Claus will come.’

事实上，孩童几乎从未放弃过他们的幻想。正如弗洛伊德所指出的，有些幻想是普遍存在的，可能在出生后的最初几个月，甚至在子宫内就已出现。子宫是一个神奇的世界，人类只能在日后通过爱、性或毒品（或者，对于恶人来说，或许是通过屠杀）才能体验到。弗洛伊德列举了最早的三种幻想：“我是永生的、全能的、不可抗拒的。” 当然，这些原始幻想在婴儿的现实面前很快就消失了：母亲、父亲、时间、重力、未知而可怕的景象和声音，以及饥饿、恐惧和疼痛等内在感受。但它们会被条件性幻想所取代，这些幻想对脚本的形成有着强大的影响。在脚本中，它们以“如果……就好了”的形式出现：“如果我表现得正确，圣诞老人就会来。”

Parents everywhere are the same in regard to illusions. If the child believes they are magicians, it is partly because they believe it themselves. There is no actual or conceivable parent who has not somehow conveyed to his offspring: ‘If you do what I tell you, everything will come out all right.’ To the child this means: ‘If I do what they tell me, I’ll be protected by magic, and all my best dreams will come true.’ He believes this so firmly that it is almost impossible to shake his faith. If he doesn’t make it, it is not because the magic has gone, but because he has broken the rules. And if he defies or abandons the parental directives, it does not mean that he has lost his belief in his illusions. It may only mean that he cannot stand the requirements any longer, or doesn’t think he will ever meet them. Hence the envy and derision which some people direct at those who follow the rules. The inner Child still believes in Santa Claus, but the rebels are saying ‘I can get it from him wholesale’ (drugs or revolution), while the futilists cry: ‘Who needs his sour grapes? The grapes of death are sweeter.’ But as they get older, a few people are able to give up the illusions themselves, and they seem to do so without the envy or derision of those who have not.

父母在对待幻想这件事上都大同小异。如果孩子相信自己是魔法师，部分原因是他们自己也相信。没有哪个父母不曾以某种方式向子女传达过这样的信息：“如果你听我的话，一切都会好起来的。” 对孩子来说，这意味着：“如果我听他们的话，我就会受到魔法的保护，我所有的梦想都会实现。” 他对此深信不疑，几乎不可能动摇他的信念。如果他失败了，那不是因为魔法消失了，而是因为他违反了规则。如果他违抗或放弃父母的指示，并不意味着他失去了对幻想的信念。这可能仅仅意味着他再也无法承受这些要求，或者认为自己永远无法达到这些要求。因此，有些人会对那些遵守规则的人感到嫉妒和嘲笑。内心深处的小孩仍然相信圣诞老人，但叛逆者却说“我可以批量从他那里得到”（毒品或革命），而虚无主义者则高喊：“谁需要他的酸葡萄？死亡的葡萄更甜。”但随着年龄的增长，有些人能够自己放弃这些幻想，而且他们似乎并没有因此而受到那些没有放弃幻想的人的嫉妒或嘲笑。

The Parental precept, at best, reads: ‘Do right and no harm can befall you!’ a motto which has been the basis of ethical systems in every country throughout recorded history, starting with the oldest known written instructions by Ptahhotep, in ancient Egypt, five thousand years ago. 5 At worst it reads: ‘The world will be a better place if you kill certain people, and in that way you will attain immortality, become omnipotent, and acquire irresistible power.’ Oddly enough, from the Child’s point of view, both of these are slogans of love, for they are both based on the same Parental promise: ‘If you do as I tell you, I will love and protect you, and without me you are nothing.’ This shows up clearly when the promise is given in writing. In the first case, it is the Lord who will love and protect you, as it is written in the Bible, and in the second it is Hitler, as it is written in Mein Kampf and other productions. Hitler promised the thousand-year Reich, which is practical immortality, and his followers did indeed acquire omnipotence and irresistible power over the Poles, Gypsies, Jews, painters, musicians, writers, and politicians whom they imprisoned in their extermination camps. While this was going on, however, reality took over in the Napoleonic form of infantry, artillery, and air support, and millions of Hitler’s followers became mortal, impotent, and resistible.

父母的训诫，往好了说，是：“行善，免遭伤害！”这句格言是历史上所有国家伦理体系的基础，最早可追溯到五千年前古埃及的普塔霍特普所著的已知最古老的文字训诫。往坏了说，则是：“如果你杀了某些人，世界会变得更美好，这样你就能获得永生、全能和不可抗拒的力量。”奇怪的是，从孩子的角度来看，这两种说法都是爱的口号，因为它们都基于同一个父母的承诺：“如果你听我的话，我会爱你、保护你，没有我，你什么都不是。”这一点在书面承诺中体现得尤为明显。在第一种情况下，爱护你的是上帝，正如《圣经》中所写；在第二种情况下，爱护你的是希特勒，正如《我的奋斗》和其他作品中所写。希特勒承诺建立千年帝国，这实际上等同于永生。他的追随者确实获得了无所不能的权力，对被囚禁在灭绝营中的波兰人、吉普赛人、犹太人、画家、音乐家、作家和政治家拥有了不可抗拒的统治力。然而，与此同时，现实以拿破仑式的步兵、炮兵和空中支援的形式占据了上风，数百万希特勒的追随者也变得脆弱不堪，终究难逃被征服的命运。

It takes enormous power to shatter these primal illusions, and this occurs most commonly in wartime. When Tolstoy’s Count goes into battle, he cries in outrage: ‘Why are they firing at me? Everybody likes me (= I am irresistible).’ 6 The same applies to the conditional illusion: ‘If I do what my Parent tells me, everything will come out all right.’ The most horrifying example of smashing this almost universal belief by force is shown in the notorious picture of a little boy about nine years old standing in the middle of a street in Poland, alone and friendless despite the onlookers who line the sidewalk, while an armed Death’s Head Trooper stands over him. The expression on his face says very plainly: ‘But mother told me if I was a good boy everything would be all right.’ The most brutal psychological blow that any human being can sustain is proof that his good mother deceived him, and that is the devastating torture which the German soldier is inflicting on the little boy he has cornered.

打破这些原始的错觉需要巨大的力量，而这种情况最常发生在战争时期。托尔斯泰笔下的伯爵在战场上愤怒地喊道：“他们为什么要向我开枪？人人都喜欢我（=我魅力无穷）。” 同样的道理也适用于条件错觉：“如果我听从父母的指示，一切都会好起来的。” 用武力打破这种几乎普遍存在的信念的最恐怖的例子，莫过于那张臭名昭著的照片：一个大约九岁的小男孩孤零零地站在波兰街头，尽管人行道两旁站满了围观者，他却孤身一人，没有朋友，而一个全副武装的骷髅兵正站在他面前。他脸上的表情清楚地表明：“可是妈妈告诉我，如果我乖，一切都会好起来的。” 任何人所能遭受的最残酷的心理打击莫过于证明自己善良的母亲欺骗了他，而这正是那个德国士兵正在对被他逼到角落的小男孩施加的毁灭性折磨。

The therapist, with full humanity and poignancy, and with the patient’s explicit and voluntary consent, may have to perform a similar task: not torture, but surgery. In order for the patient to get better, his illusion, upon which his whole life is based, must be undermined so that he can live in the world which is here today, rather than in his ‘If Only’ or ‘Some Day.’ This is the most painful task which the script analyst has to perform: to tell his patients finally that there is no Santa Claus. But by careful preparation, the blow can be softened and the patient may, in the long run, forgive him.

治疗师带着充分的人文关怀和真挚的同情，在征得患者明确且自愿的同意后，可能不得不执行一项类似的任务：不是折磨，而是手术。为了让患者康复，必须打破他赖以生存的幻想，让他能够活在当下，而不是活在“如果当初……”或“总有一天……”的幻想中。这是剧本分析师必须执行的最痛苦的任务：最终告诉患者，世上没有圣诞老人。但通过周密的准备，可以减轻这种打击，患者最终或许会原谅他。

One of the favorite illusions of later childhood is shaken when Jeder finds out where babies come from. In order to maintain the fiction of his parents’ purity, he has to make the reservation: ‘All right, but my parents don’t do that.’ It is difficult for the therapist to avoid seeming crass and cynical when he confronts Jeder with the fact that he was not a virgin birth, so they must have done it at least once, and if he has brothers and sisters, several times. This is equivalent to telling him that his mother betrayed him, something no man should tell another unless the other pays him to do just that. Sometimes he has the opposite task of restoring to some semblance of decency the picture which mother herself or external circumstances have smeared into degradation. And for millions of children, this illusion is an unattainable luxury, and they must exist in a bare state of psychological as well as material subsistence.

当杰德发现婴儿的由来时，他童年后期最珍视的幻想之一便开始动摇。为了维持父母纯洁无瑕的假象，他不得不辩解道：“好吧，但我的父母不会那样做。”当治疗师直面杰德并非处女所生的事实时，他很难不显得粗鲁和愤世嫉俗。这意味着他的父母至少有过一次生育经历，如果他有兄弟姐妹，那可能不止一次。这相当于告诉他，他的母亲背叛了他——除非对方付钱让他这么做，否则任何人都不会对另一个人说出这样的话。有时，治疗师的任务恰恰相反，他需要努力恢复母亲或外部环境所玷污的、令人不齿的形象。对于数百万儿童来说，这种幻想是一种遥不可及的奢侈，他们只能在赤裸裸的心理和物质生存状态下苟延残喘。

The beliefs in Santa Claus, Death, and mother’s virginity may be regarded as normal because they are eagerly grasped and give spiritual nourishment to idealistic or weaker spirits whenever they are made available. On the other hand, confused people are confused because they have their own special illusions. These range from ‘If you take a colonic irrigation every day, you’ll be healthy and happy’ to ‘You can prevent your father from dying if you get sick. If he dies, it’s because you didn’t get sick enough.’ There are also private contracts with God, contracts God was never consulted about and which He never signed; and which He would in fact refuse to sign: ‘If I sacrifice my children, my mother will stay healthy’ is a common example, or ‘God will send me a miracle if I don’t have any orgasms.’ As already noted, the latter was institutionalized among the prostitutes of Paris as ‘No matter how many men I have sex with, or even knowingly infect with disease, I can still go to Heaven as long as it is done in the course of business and I don’t enjoy it.’ 7

对圣诞老人、死亡和母亲贞洁的信仰之所以被视为正常，是因为它们很容易被接受，并且每当人们接触到这些信仰时，它们都能为理想主义或意志薄弱的人们提供精神滋养。另一方面，那些感到困惑的人之所以困惑，是因为他们有自己独特的幻想。这些幻想五花八门，从“如果你每天进行灌肠，你就会健康快乐”到“如果你生病，你就能阻止你父亲的死亡。如果他死了，那是因为你病得不够重”。此外，还有一些与上帝签订的私人契约，这些契约从未征求过上帝的意见，也从未被祂签署过。而祂实际上会拒绝签署这样的契约：“如果我牺牲我的孩子，我的母亲就会保持健康”就是一个常见的例子，或者“如果我没有性高潮，上帝就会赐给我一个奇迹”。正如前面提到的，后者在巴黎的妓女中被奉为圭臬，她们认为“无论我与多少男人发生性关系，甚至明知故犯地传染疾病，只要是为了赚钱，而且我并不从中获得快感，我仍然可以上天堂。”

In early childhood, then, magical illusions are accepted in their most romantic forms. In later childhood, they are tested against reality, and parts of them are reluctantly relinquished, leaving only a secret core to form the existential basis of life. Only the strongest can face the absurd gambles of living without any illusions. One of the hardest to give up, even in later life, is the illusion of autonomy or self-determination.

因此，在幼儿时期，人们接受的往往是充满浪漫色彩的奇幻幻想。到了儿童后期，这些幻想会受到现实的考验，人们会不情愿地放弃其中的一部分，只留下一个隐秘的核心，构成生命存在的基础。只有最坚强的人才能面对失去所有幻想后生活的种种荒诞抉择。而即便到了成年，最难放弃的幻想之一，便是自主或自我决定的幻想。

This is illustrated in Figure 10 . The genuine autonomous area which represents true rational Adult functioning, free of Parental prejudices and wishful Child thinking, is marked A1. This aspect of the personality is actually free to make Adult judgments based on carefully gathered knowledge and observation. It may work efficiently in a trade or profession, where a mechanic or a surgeon uses good judgment based on previous education, observation, and experience. The area marked P is clearly recognized by the individual as Parental influence: ideas and preferences he got from his parents concerning food, dress, manners, and religion, for example. These he may refer to as his ‘upbringing.’ The area marked C he credits to wishful desires or early tastes, the things that come from his Child. Insofar as he recognizes and separates these three areas, he is autonomous: he knows what is Adult and practical, what he accepts that came from others, and what he does that is determined by early impulses rather than by practical thinking and rational decisions.

如图10所示，真正的自主区域代表了摆脱父母偏见和孩童般幻想的、真正理性的成人功能，标记为A1。人格的这一方面能够基于精心收集的知识和观察做出成人的判断。它能在行业或职业中高效运作，例如，机械师或外科医生能够根据以往的教育、观察和经验做出良好的判断。标记为P的区域被个体清晰地识别为父母的影响：例如，他从父母那里获得的关于食物、穿着、礼仪和宗教等方面的观念和偏好。他可能将这些称为他的“成长经历”。标记为C的区域则归因于他孩童时期的愿望或早期的喜好。只要他能够识别并区分这三个区域，他就具备自主性：他知道什么是成人的、实际的，什么是他接受的、来自他人的，以及什么是他受早期冲动而非实际思考和理性决策所驱动的行为。

The areas marked ‘Delusions’ and ‘Illusions’ is where he lives in error. The delusions are things that he treats as though they were his own ideas, based on observation and judgment, whereas in reality they are ideas imposed on him by his parents, which are so ingrown that he thinks they are part of his Real Self. The illusions, similarly, are ideas from his Child that he accepts as Adult and rational and tries to justify as such. Delusions and illusions may be called contaminations. The illusion of autonomy, then, is based on the erroneous idea that the whole area, A1, shown in Figure 10 is uncontaminated and autonomous Adult, whereas it actually includes large areas that really belong to the Parent and the Child. True autonomy is the recognition that the Adult boundaries are truly shown in Figure 11 , and that the shaded areas belong to the other ego states.

标有“妄想”和“错觉”的区域是他生活在错误之中的地方。妄想是他基于观察和判断而形成的，他误以为是自己的想法，而实际上这些想法是父母强加给他的，并且根深蒂固，以至于他认为这些想法是他真实自我的一部分。同样，错觉是他从孩童时期接受的想法，他将其视为成人的、理性的，并试图以此来证明其合理性。妄想和错觉可以被称为污染。因此，自主性的错觉是基于一个错误的观念，即图10所示的整个区域A1是未受污染的、自主的成人状态，而实际上它包含了真正属于父母和孩童时期的很大一部分区域。真正的自主性在于认识到成人状态的边界在图11中清晰可见，而阴影区域属于其他自我状态。

FIGURE 10

图 10

FIGURE 11

图 11

In fact, Figures 10 and 11 give us a measure of autonomy. The area of A in Figure 11 , divided by the area of A in Figure 10 , may be called ‘Degree of Autonomy.’ Where A-10 is large and A-11 is small, there is little autonomy and great illusion. If A-10 is small (though always bigger than A-11), and A-11 is large (though always smaller than A-10), then there is less illusion and more autonomy.

事实上，图 10 和图 11 为我们提供了一种衡量自主性的指标。图 11 中 A 区域的面积除以图 10 中 A 区域的面积，可以称为“自主程度”。当 A-10 较大而 A-11 较小时，自主性较低，错觉较强。如果 A-10 较小（但始终大于 A-11），而 A-11 较大（但始终小于 A-10），则错觉较少，自主性较高。

E • Games

E • 游戏

During early infancy the child is straight, starting off in the first position, I’m OK – You’re OK. But corruption quickly sets in, and he discovers that his OK is not a completely undisputed automatic birthright, but depends to some extent on his behavior, and more particularly on his responses to his mother. In the course of learning his table manners, he may discover that his feeling of unblemished OKness is granted by her only with certain reservations, and this is wounding. He responds by casting aspersions on her OKness, although when dinner is over they may kiss and make up. But the groundwork has already been laid for game-playing, which begins to flower during his toilet training, where he has the upper hand. During mealtimes he is hungry, and wants something from her; in the bathroom, she wants something from him. At the table, he has to respond to her in a certain way to keep his OK grade; now she has to treat him right to keep her OK. In rare cases both of them may still be straight, but usually by this time she is conning him by working his gimmicks just a little, and he is doing the same.

在婴儿早期，孩子一开始是正直的，占据主导地位，我很好——你也很好。但很快，这种“好”的感觉就开始转变，他发现自己的“好”并非与生俱来、毫无争议，而是在某种程度上取决于他的行为，尤其是他对母亲的反应。在学习餐桌礼仪的过程中，他可能会发现母亲给予他“好”的感觉是有条件的，这会让他感到受伤。他会质疑母亲的“好”，尽管晚餐结束后他们可能会和好如初。但这种“游戏”的雏形已经形成，并在他进行如厕训练时开始显现，此时他占据了上风。吃饭时他饿了，想要从母亲那里得到些什么；在卫生间里，母亲则想要从他那里得到些什么。在餐桌上，他必须以某种方式回应母亲才能保住自己的“好”；现在，母亲必须善待他才能保住自己的“好”。在极少数情况下，他们两人可能仍然是异性恋，但通常到了这个时候，她会稍微利用他的一些伎俩来欺骗他，而他也同样如此。

By the time he enters school, he has probably learned a few soft games, or perhaps two or three hard ones, or in the worst cases he may already be game-ridden. It depends on how smart and tough his parents are. The more they ‘play it smart,’ the crookeder he will be; and the tougher they are, the harder he will have to play in order to survive. Clinical experience shows that the most effective way to corrupt and tighten a child is to give him frequent enemas against his will, just as the most effective way to corrupt and disintegrate him is to spank him cruelly when he cries from pain.

等他入学的时候，可能已经学会了一些比较温和的游戏，或者两三种比较难的游戏，最糟糕的情况是，他可能已经沉迷于各种游戏了。这取决于他父母的聪明程度和强硬程度。他们越是“精明”，他就越会耍花招；他们越是强硬，他为了生存就不得不玩更难的游戏。临床经验表明，让孩子变得乖戾和固执的最有效方法是违背他的意愿给他灌肠，正如让孩子变得乖戾和崩溃的最有效方法是在他因疼痛哭泣时狠狠地打他一样。

In grade school he has a chance to try out, on the general population of other children and teachers, the games he has learned at home. He sharpens some up, tones others down, abandons some, and picks up new ones from the group. He also has a chance to test out his convictions and his position. If he thinks he is OK, his teacher can confirm this or shake him up by putting him down, and if he is convinced he is not-OK, she can confirm that (which is only what he expects) or try to build him up (which may make him uneasy). If he thinks the rest of the world is OK, he will include her unless she has to prove she isn’t. If he is convinced others are not-OK, he will try to prove it by getting her angry.

在小学，他有机会在其他孩子和老师面前尝试在家学到的游戏。他会改进一些游戏，降低一些游戏的难度，放弃一些游戏，并从群体中学习新的游戏。他也有机会检验自己的信念和立场。如果他觉得自己没问题，老师可以肯定这一点，也可以通过贬低他来让他感到不安；如果他觉得自己有问题，老师可以证实这一点（这正是他所期望的），也可以试图鼓励他（这可能会让他感到不安）。如果他认为其他人都很好，他就会接纳她，除非她需要证明自己有问题。如果他确信其他人有问题，他就会试图通过激怒她来证明这一点。

There are many special situations which neither the child nor the teacher can foresee or cope with. The teacher may play the game called ‘Argentina.’ ‘What’s the most interesting thing about Argentina?’ she asks. ‘Pampas,’ says somebody, ‘Nooo.’ ‘Patagonia,’ says somebody else. ‘Noooooo.’ ‘Aconcagua,’ offers another pupil. ‘Noooooooo.’ By this time they know what’s up. It’s no use remembering what’s in the book, or what they’re interested in. They’re supposed to guess what’s in her mind, so she’s got them in a corner, and they give up. ‘Nobody else wants to answer?’ she asks in her phony gentle tone. ‘Gauchos!’ she declares triumphantly, making them all feel stupid simultaneously. There is nothing they can do to stop her, and it is very hard for even the most charitable student to let her keep her OK. On the other hand, even the most skillful teacher may have trouble keeping her OK with a pupil whose body is being violated with enemas at home. He may refuse to answer, and then if she tries to force him, she is raping his mind as well, and that proves that she is no better than his parents. But there’s nothing she can do to help him, either.

有很多特殊情况，孩子和老师都无法预料或应对。老师可能会玩一个叫“阿根廷”的游戏。“阿根廷最有趣的地方是什么？”她问。“潘帕斯草原，”有人说。“不要啊！”“巴塔哥尼亚，”另一个人说。“不要啊！”“阿空加瓜山，”又一个学生说。“不要啊！”这时他们就知道是怎么回事了。记住书里的内容，或者自己感兴趣的东西都没用。他们得猜老师心里想的是什么，所以老师把他们逼到了墙角，他们只好放弃。“还有人想回答吗？”她用假装温柔的语气问。“高乔人！”她得意洋洋地宣布，让所有人都觉得自己很蠢。他们无力阻止她，即使是最宽容的学生也很难让她继续说下去。另一方面，即使是最有经验的老师，如果学生在家遭受灌肠这种性侵犯，她也很难安心。他可能拒绝配合，如果老师强迫他，就等于也在侵犯他的精神，这证明她和他的父母没什么两样。但她也无能为力。

Each of the lower positions has its own assortment of games, and by playing them with the teacher, Jeder can see which ones she falls for and sharpen his skill. In the second or arrogant position (+ –) he may try ‘Now I’ve Got You,’ in the third or depressive one (– +), ‘Kick Me,’ and from futility (– –), ‘Making Teacher Sorry.’ He may give up the ones she declines or has an antithesis for. But he also tries them out on his schoolmates.

每个较低的位置都有其独特的游戏，杰德通过和老师玩这些游戏，可以观察她喜欢哪些游戏，并磨练自己的技巧。在第二个位置（傲慢位置，+ -）时，他可能会尝试“现在我抓到你了”；在第三个位置（沮丧位置，- +）时，他可能会尝试“踢我”；在无力位置（- -）时，他可能会尝试“让老师后悔”。如果老师拒绝或有相反的应对方法，他可能会放弃。但他也会在同学身上尝试这些游戏。

The fourth position is in many ways the hardest to deal with. But if the teacher keeps her cool and strokes Jeder with judicious words, neither marshmallows, rebukes, nor apologies, she may loosen his grip on the harsh rock of futility and float him part way up toward the sunshine of OKness.

第四个位置在很多方面都是最难应对的。但如果老师保持冷静，用恰当的言辞安抚杰德，既不甜言蜜语，也不斥责，更不道歉，或许就能让他松开紧抓着无力感这块坚硬岩石的手，让他缓缓升向阳光明媚的幸福境界。

Thus, later childhood is the period that determines which games from the domestic repertoire become fixed favorites and which ones, if any, are given up. The most important single question here is: ‘How did your teachers get along with you at school?’ and next to that, ‘How did the other kids get along with you at school?’

因此，童年后期决定了哪些家庭游戏会成为孩子们的最爱，哪些游戏（如果有的话）会被放弃。这里最重要的问题是：“你在学校里和老师相处得怎么样？”其次是：“你在学校里和其他孩子相处得怎么样？”

F • The Persona

F • 角色

By the end of this phase, something else has come into full flower, something which answers the question: ‘If you can’t talk straight and tell it like it is, what’s the most comfortable way to be crooked?’ Everything Jeder has learned from his parents, his teachers, his schoolmates, his friends, and his enemies, goes into answering this. The result is his persona.

在这个阶段的末期，另一种东西也完全绽放，它回答了这样一个问题：“如果你不能直言不讳，那么最舒服的耍花招的方式是什么？”杰德从父母、老师、同学、朋友甚至敌人那里学到的一切，都融入到了这个问题的答案中。最终，他的人格塑造就此完成。

Jung defines the persona as an ‘ ad hoc adopted attitude,’ a mask which the person ‘knows corresponds with his conscious intentions, while it also meets with the requirements and opinions of his environment.’ Thus he ‘deceives others, and also often himself, as to his real character.’ 8 It is then a social personality, and the social personalities of most people resemble the personality of a child of the latent period, about six to ten years of age. This is because the persona is indeed formed by outside influences and the child’s own decisions, at just that period. When he is on his social behavior, good, tough, likable, challenging, grown-up Jeder need not (though he may) come on as either Parent, Adult, or Child. Instead, he may behave like a grade school boy, adapting himself under the guidance of his Adult, and within Parental restrictions, to his social situation. This adaptation emerges as his persona, and that, too, fits in with his script. If he has a winning one, his persona will be attractive, and if a losing one, repulsive, except to his own kind. Often it is modeled on his hero. The real Child is hidden behind the persona, and may lurk there watching for an opportunity to spring if enough trading stamps can be collected to justify dropping the mask.

荣格将人格面具定义为一种“临时采取的态度”，一种面具，这个人“知道它符合自己的意识意图，同时也符合环境的要求和意见”。因此，他“欺骗他人，也常常欺骗自己，使其对自己的真实性格产生误解”。 8 这是一种社会人格，大多数人的社会人格类似于潜伏期儿童（大约六到十岁）的人格。这是因为人格面具的确是在这个时期由外部影响和儿童自身的选择共同形成的。当他进行社交活动时，一个善良、坚强、讨人喜欢、富有挑战性、成熟的杰德（Jeder）不必（尽管他可能会）表现得像父母、成人或儿童。相反，他可能像一个小学生一样，在成人的指导下，并在父母的限制下，适应他的社交情境。这种适应就形成了他的人格面具，而这也符合他预设的剧本。如果他拥有一个成功的形象，他的形象就会很有魅力；如果是一个失败的形象，除了同类之外，其他人都会觉得他令人厌恶。这个形象通常模仿他心目中的英雄。真正的孩子隐藏在这个形象背后，潜伏在那里，伺机而动，一旦收集到足够的交易印章，他就会摘下面具，展现真实的自我。

The question to ask the patient here is: ‘What kind of person are you?’ or better: ‘What do other people think of you?’

这里应该问患者的问题是：“你是什么样的人？”或者更好的是：“别人怎么看待你？”

G • The Family Culture

G • 家庭文化

All culture is family culture, things learned as a knee baby. Details and techniques may be learned outside the home, but their value is determined by the family. The script analyst goes to the heart of the matter with a single pointed question: ‘What did your family talk about at the dinner table?’ By this he hopes to ascertain the subject matter, which may or may not be important, and also the kinds of transactions which took place, which is always important. Some child-and-family therapists even have themselves invited to dinner at the patient’s house, with the idea that this is the best way to get the greatest amount of reliable information in a short time.

所有文化都是家庭文化，都是从婴儿时期就开始习得的。细节和技巧或许可以在家庭之外学习，但它们的价值却由家庭决定。剧本分析师会用一个直击要害的问题来探究问题的核心：“你们家在餐桌上都聊些什么？”他希望借此确定谈话的主题（这或许重要，或许不重要），以及谈话中发生的互动类型（这始终至关重要）。一些儿童和家庭治疗师甚至会亲自到患者家中用餐，他们认为这是在短时间内获取最多可靠信息的最佳方式。

One of the script analyst’s slogans is, or should be, ‘Think sphincter!’ Freud 9 and Abraham 10 were the first to elaborate the idea that character structure centers around bodily orifices. Both games and scripts do likewise, and the physiological signs and symptoms which form an important feature of every game and script usually center around a particular orifice or sphincter. The family culture, as shown at the dinner table, tends to revolve around the ‘family sphincter,’ and knowing which is the family’s favorite is a great help in treating the patient.

剧本分析师的口号之一是（或者应该是）“想想括约肌！”弗洛伊德和亚伯拉罕最早阐述了人物结构围绕身体孔口展开的观点。游戏和剧本也遵循同样的规律，构成每个游戏和剧本重要特征的生理体征和症状通常都围绕着某个特定的孔口或括约肌展开。家庭文化，正如餐桌上所展现的那样，往往围绕着“家庭括约肌”运转，了解哪个是家庭成员最重视的，对治疗病人大有裨益。

The four external sphincters concerned are the oral, the anal, the urethral, and the vaginal, and perhaps more important are the internal sphincters related to these. There is also an illusory sphincter which may be called, as it is in psychoanalysis, the cloacal.

涉及的四个外括约肌分别是口腔括约肌、肛门括约肌、尿道括约肌和阴道括约肌，而与这些括约肌相关的内括约肌或许更为重要。此外，还有一个假想的括约肌，在精神分析学中，它被称为泄殖腔括约肌。

Although the mouth does have its own external sphincter, the Orbicularis oris , that is not usually the muscle ‘oral’ families are concerned with, although some do have a motto, ‘Keep your mouth shut.’ What ‘oral’ families mainly talk about is food, and the sphincters chiefly concerned are those of the throat, stomach, and duodenum.
