Thus, ‘oral’ families are typically diet faddists and stomach worriers, and those are the subjects they talk about at dinner. ‘Hysterical’ members of such families have spasms of the throat muscles, and ‘psychosomatic’ members have spasms of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum, or, conversely, they throw up or have fears of throwing up.

虽然口腔本身也有外括约肌——口轮匝肌，但这通常不是“口唇”家族所关注的肌肉，尽管有些家族成员确实奉行“闭嘴”的信条。“口唇”家族主要谈论的是食物，他们主要关注的括约肌是咽喉、胃和十二指肠的括约肌。因此，“口唇”家族成员通常是饮食狂热者和肠胃焦虑者，这些也是他们在餐桌上谈论的话题。这类家族中的“歇斯底里”型成员会出现咽喉肌肉痉挛，“心身”型成员则会出现食管、胃和十二指肠痉挛，或者相反，他们会呕吐或害怕呕吐。

The anus is the sphincter par excellence. ‘Anal’ families talk about bowel movements, laxatives, and enemas, or the more aristocratic colonic irrigations. Life for them is a round of poisonous matter that has to be got rid of promptly at any cost. They are fascinated by intestinal products, and proud of themselves or their children when these are large and firm and shapely. Diarrhea is judged by its copiousness, while mucous or bloody colitis is of eternal interest and can be worn with an air of modest distinction. The whole culture merges with sexuality (or anti-sexuality) in the motto ‘Keep a tight ass hole or you’ll get screwed.’ This means keep a poker face as well, and the philosophy may pay off in making money.

肛门是绝佳的括约肌。“肛门文化”家族谈论的都是排便、泻药、灌肠，或是更显高雅的结肠灌洗。对他们而言，生活就是一场必须不惜一切代价迅速排出的“毒物”循环。他们对肠道分泌物着迷，如果自己或孩子的排便量大、结实、形状优美，他们便会引以为傲。腹泻的评判标准是量多，而黏液性或血性结肠炎则永远是他们关注的焦点，他们甚至会带着一种谦逊的优越感来看待这些疾病。整个文化都与性（或反性）融为一体，奉行着“保持肛门紧闭，否则你会被坑”的格言。这也意味着要保持扑克脸，而这种理念或许能让他们赚到钱。

Urethral families talk a lot, long streams of watered-down ideas with a few stutters at the end, although they are never really finished talking, as there are always some last drops left which can be squeezed out if there is time. Some of them are full of piss and vinegar, and when they get pissed off they piss on people, or so they say. Some of the children rebel against the system by tightening up their urethral sphincters and holding their urine as long as possible, getting considerable pleasure from the unpleasant sensations which result and even more pleasure when they finally let loose, sometimes at night in bed. fn1

尿道家族的人话很多，滔滔不绝地讲着一些稀薄的想法，结尾还有些结巴，但他们似乎永远也说不完，总有最后一点话要说，只要有时间就能挤出来。他们当中有些人脾气暴躁，据说一旦生气就会朝人撒尿。有些孩子会通过收紧尿道括约肌、尽可能长时间憋尿来反抗这种制度，从由此产生的不适感中获得极大的快感，而最终释放出来时，有时甚至在夜里躺在床上，他们更是感到无比的快感。

Some families talk at mealtimes about the wickedness of sex. Their motto is ‘In our family, the women keep their legs crossed.’ Even when their legs are not crossed, they keep their vaginal sphincters up tight. In other families the vaginal sphincters are wide open and the legs loose, and the table talk is vulgar and pornographic.

有些家庭会在餐桌上谈论性的罪恶。他们的座右铭是“在我们家，女人要翘二郎腿”。即使不翘腿，她们也会紧紧地收紧阴道括约肌。而在另一些家庭，阴道括约肌大开，双腿放松，餐桌上的谈话也粗俗不堪，甚至带有色情意味。

These are common examples illustrating the theory of sphincters, or as it is usually called, the theory of infantile sexuality. This theory is most fully and clearly developed by Erikson. 11 He considers five stages of development, each centered around a particular anatomical zone (oral, anal, or genital). Each zone can be ‘used’ in five different ways or modes, including Incorporative (1 and 2), Retentive, Eliminative, and Intrusive, so that he ends up with a basic matrix of twenty-five slots. He relates certain of these slots to particular attitudes and characteristics, and to particular lines of personal development, which are similar to scripty life courses.

这些是阐释括约肌理论（或通常所说的婴儿性欲理论）的常见例子。埃里克森对这一理论进行了最完整、最清晰的阐述。他认为性欲发展分为五个阶段，每个阶段都围绕一个特定的解剖区域（口腔、肛门或生殖器）展开。每个区域都可以以五种不同的方式或模式“使用”，包括内化（1和2）、保留、排泄和侵入，最终形成一个包含25个基本位置的矩阵。他将其中一些位置与特定的态度和特征，以及特定的个人发展路径联系起来，这些路径类似于脚本式的生命历程。

Using Erikson’s language, the parental injunction ‘Keep your mouth shut’ is oral retentive; ‘Keep a tight ass hole’ is anal retentive, and ‘Keep your legs crossed’ is phallic retentive. Food fads are oral incorporative, vomiting is oral eliminative, and obscene talk is intrusive. Hence, a question about table talk can often place the family culture very precisely as to zone and mode. This is important because particular games and scripts, and their accompanying physical symptoms, are based in appropriate zones and modes. For example, ‘Schlemiel’ is anal as to zone, and ‘I’m Only Trying to Help You’ is intrusive as to mode, while ‘Alcoholic’ is oral incorporative.

用埃里克森的术语来说，父母的训诫“闭嘴”属于口唇期固着型；“闭紧你的屁眼”属于肛门期固着型；“双腿交叉”属于阳具期固着型。饮食潮流属于口唇期内化型，呕吐属于口唇期排泄型，而粗俗的言语属于侵入型。因此，关于餐桌谈话的问题往往能够非常精确地确定家庭文化的领域和模式。这一点很重要，因为特定的游戏和脚本，以及它们伴随的生理症状，都基于相应的领域和模式。例如，“笨蛋”在领域上属于肛门期，“我只是想帮你”在模式上属于侵入型，而“酗酒”则属于口唇期内化型。

The mythical ‘cloacal sphincter’ exists in the minds of confused people whose Child thinks that there is only one opening down below in both sexes, which opening can be closed off at will. This leads to scripts which are difficult for more realistic people to understand, especially if the mouth is also included. Thus a catatonic schizophrenic may close off everything at once: he keeps all his sphincters clamped down so that nothing can get in or out of his mouth, bladder, or rectum, and he may have to be tube-fed, catheterized, and clystered at regular intervals to insure his physical well-being and survival. Here the script slogan is ‘Better death than to let them in!’ and this is taken literally by the Child who controls the sphincters and who, in such cases, is very confused about how they are assembled and how they work.

神话般的“泄殖腔括约肌”存在于一些认知混乱的人的脑海中，他们的“孩子”认为男女下体只有一个开口，而且可以随意关闭。这导致了一些难以被更现实的人理解的思维模式，尤其是在口腔也被纳入其中的情况下。因此，一个紧张性精神分裂症患者可能会同时关闭所有通道：他紧紧夹住所有括约肌，使任何东西都无法进入或排出他的口腔、膀胱或直肠，他可能需要定期接受管饲、导尿和灌肠，以确保他的身体健康和生存。在这种情况下，他们的思维模式口号是“宁死不让它们进来！”，而控制括约肌的“孩子”会字面理解这句话，在这种情况下，他们对括约肌的组成和运作方式感到非常困惑。

Most scripts, however, are centered mainly around one particular sphincter, and the psychology of the script is related to that physiological area. That is why the script analyst ‘thinks sphincter.’ The constant tightening of one sphincter can affect all the muscles of the body, and this muscle set is related to the person’s emotional attitude and interests and also influences the way others respond to him. This works according to the model of the ‘infected splinter.’

然而，大多数脚本主要围绕某个特定的括约肌展开，脚本的心理机制也与该生理区域相关。这就是为什么脚本分析师会“思考括约肌”。一个括约肌的持续收紧会影响全身肌肉，而这组肌肉又与个人的情绪态度和兴趣相关，并影响他人对他的反应。这符合“感染的木刺”模型。

If Jeder has a small infected splinter in his right big toe, he will start to limp. This affects the muscles of his leg, and in order to compensate, the muscles of his back will tighten up. After a while, the muscles in his shoulders will also be affected, and pretty soon the muscles of his neck are involved. If he walks a lot, the disturbance in muscular balance progresses until eventually the muscles of his head and scalp are also affected; then he may get a headache. As walking becomes more difficult and his body is held more and more stiffly and the infection progresses, his circulation and digestion may become labored. At this point, someone might say: ‘This is a very difficult condition to cure, since it involves his internal organs and his head as well as all the muscles in his body. This is a disease of the whole organism.’ But along comes a surgeon, and says: ‘I can cure the whole thing, including his fever, his headache, and all his muscular tension.’ He pulls out the splinter, the infection subsides, Jeder stops limping, his scalp and neck muscles relax, and the headache vanishes; and as the rest of his body relaxes, everything returns to normal. Thus, even though the condition involves the whole body, it can be cured by looking in the right place for the splinter and removing it. Then not only Jeder, but all the people around him are relieved, and they can relax, too.

如果杰德的右脚大脚趾扎了一根感染的小木刺，他就会开始跛行。这会影响他腿部的肌肉，为了代偿，他背部的肌肉会紧绷起来。过一段时间，他的肩膀肌肉也会受到影响，很快颈部肌肉也会受到影响。如果他走很多路，肌肉平衡紊乱的情况就会加重，最终头部和头皮的肌肉也会受到影响；这时他可能会头痛。随着行走越来越困难，身体越来越僵硬，感染也越来越严重，他的血液循环和消化功能可能会受到影响。这时，有人可能会说：“这种情况很难治愈，因为它不仅影响到全身肌肉，还影响到他的内脏器官和头部。” “这是一种全身性疾病。”这时，一位外科医生来了，说：“我可以治好他的病，包括发烧、头痛和所有肌肉紧张。”他拔出了木刺，感染消退了，杰德不再跛行，头皮和颈部肌肉放松下来，头痛也消失了；随着身体其他部位的放松，一切都恢复了正常。因此，即使这种疾病影响到全身，只要找到木刺并取出，就能治愈。这样一来，不仅杰德，他周围的人也都松了一口气，可以放松下来了。

A similar chain of events happens when a sphincter is held tight. In order to give the sphincter traction and support, the surrounding muscles tighten up. To compensate for that, more distant muscles are affected, and eventually the whole body is involved. This is easily demonstrated. Suppose the reader, as he sits reading, tightens up his anus. He will immediately notice that this involves the muscles of his lower back and legs. If he now rises up out of his chair, keeping his anus tight, he will note that he has to purse his lips, which in turn affects the muscles in his scalp. In other words, keeping his anus tight changes the muscular dynamics of his whole body. That is exactly what happens with people whose script calls for them to ‘Keep a tight ass hole or you’ll get screwed.’ Every muscle in their bodies becomes involved, including their muscles of facial expression. The facial expression influences the way other people respond to them, and in fact gives the come-on to the Child of the other person, the script antagonist, who is destined to bring about the script switch.

当括约肌收紧时，也会发生类似的连锁反应。为了给括约肌提供牵引力和支撑，周围的肌肉会收紧。为了弥补这种收紧，更远处的肌肉也会受到影响，最终全身都会参与其中。这一点很容易证明。假设读者坐着阅读时收紧肛门。他会立刻注意到，这会牵动他下背部和腿部的肌肉。如果他现在从椅子上站起来，同时保持肛门收紧，他会注意到他必须抿嘴，这反过来又会影响他头皮的肌肉。换句话说，保持肛门收紧会改变他全身的肌肉动态。这正是那些剧本要求他们“收紧肛门，否则你就完蛋了”的人的真实写照。他们身体的每一块肌肉都会参与其中，包括面部表情肌。面部表情会影响其他人对他们的反应，实际上会挑逗对方内心深处的孩子，也就是剧本中的反派角色，而这个角色注定会促成剧本的转变。

Here is how it works. Suppose we call the man with the tight anus Angus, and his opposite number, his script antagonist, Lana. Lana is looking for an Angus, and Angus is looking for a Lana. Lana knows instantly when she has found an Angus because of his facial expression. She confirms her Child’s intuitive judgment in the course of their conversation as he reveals his attitudes and interests. Lana’s role in the script of an Angus is to bring about the script switch. Angus’s counterscript is to keep tight at all times, but his script is something else. No matter how hard he tries to keep tight according to the parental precept, sooner or later he drops his guard for a moment, and then his script takes over. In this moment of weakness he relaxes. That is just what Lana has been waiting for. She pulls the switch, and somehow or other, Angus ‘gets screwed’ as she moves in to fulfill her mission. And as long as Angus tries to keep a tight anus, he is going to ‘get screwed’ again and again. That is how the script works – unless it calls for him to be a winner, and then he is the one who will do the screwing, as in the case of some anal financiers.

事情是这样的。假设我们把那个肛门紧绷的男人叫做安格斯，把他的对立面，也就是他的剧本对手，叫做拉娜。拉娜在寻找安格斯，而安格斯也在寻找拉娜。拉娜一眼就能看出她找到了安格斯，因为他的表情很像。在和安格斯的对话中，拉娜证实了她孩子的直觉判断，因为安格斯会展现出他的态度和兴趣。拉娜在安格斯的剧本中扮演的角色是促成剧本转换。安格斯的反剧本是始终保持紧绷，但他的剧本却截然不同。无论他多么努力地按照父母的教诲保持紧绷，迟早他都会放松警惕，然后他的剧本就会接管一切。在这脆弱的时刻，他放松了下来。这正是拉娜一直在等待的。她拨动开关，不知何故，安格斯在她完成任务的过程中“遭殃”。只要安格斯继续紧闭肛门，他就会一次又一次地被“操”。这就是剧本的套路——除非剧本要求他成为赢家，那样的话，他就成了操别人的那个人，就像某些肛门金融家那样。

Thus, the script analyst thinks sphincter so he will know what he is dealing with. The patient who gives up his script is much more relaxed in all the muscles of his body. The woman who formerly kept a tight anus, for example, will stop squirming in her chair, and the one who kept a tight vagina will no longer sit with her arms and legs tensely crossed and her right foot wrapped tightly around the inside of her left ankle.

因此，脚本分析师会思考括约肌，以便了解自己面对的是什么。放弃脚本的患者全身肌肉都会放松许多。例如，以前肛门紧绷的女性将不再在椅子上扭动，而以前阴道紧绷的女性将不再双臂双腿紧张地交叉坐着，右脚也不会紧紧地缠绕在左脚踝内侧。

With these remarks about the autocrats of the dinner table, who teach their children which muscles to anchor their bodies to for the rest of their lives, we conclude our survey of those influences which are most important in later childhood, and are now ready to consider the next stage in the development of the script.

以上是对餐桌上的独裁者们的评价，他们教会孩子们在余生中应该依靠哪些肌肉来支撑自己的身体。至此，我们结束了对儿童后期最重要的影响因素的调查，现在准备考虑剧本发展的下一个阶段。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 Erikson, E. Childhood and Society. Loc. cit ., p. 81.

1 Erikson, E. 童年与社会。同上，第 81 页。

2 The time schedules given here, up to the age of puberty, are based mainly on memories of grown-up patients and reports of parents about their offspring, corroborated by reading, and only to a lesser extent by direct observation of children. Child psychiatrists and nursery and grade school teachers, such as those who attend the San Francisco Transactional Analysis Seminars, have for the most part found the dating acceptable.

2 此处给出的青春期前的时间表主要基于成年患者的回忆和父母对其子女的描述，并辅以阅读资料，而直接观察儿童的情况则较少。儿童精神科医生、幼儿园和小学教师，例如参加旧金山人际沟通分析研讨会的教师，大多认为这种时间安排是可以接受的。

3 The parallel between psychological trading stamps and commercial ones is truly amazing. See Fox, H. W. The Economics of Trading Stamps . Public Affairs Press, Washington, D.C., 1968. Almost every observation about household savers applies equally well to those who trade in psychological stamps.

3 心理交易邮票与商业邮票之间的相似之处着实令人惊叹。参见 H. W. Fox 的《交易邮票的经济学》（The Economics of Trading Stamps），公共事务出版社，华盛顿特区，1968 年。几乎所有关于家庭储蓄者的观察结果同样适用于那些交易心理邮票的人。

4 Dr Robert Zechnich ( Transactional Analysis Bulletin 7: 44, April, 1968) first made the thought-provoking observation that there are Child paranoids and Parent paranoids, and Dr Stephen Karpman pointed out that while hallucinations are truly counterfeit, delusions are not entirely so.

4 罗伯特·泽克尼奇博士（《人际沟通分析公报》7: 44，1968 年 4 月）首先提出了一个发人深省的观点，即存在儿童妄想症和父母妄想症，而斯蒂芬·卡普曼博士指出，虽然幻觉确实是伪造的，但妄想并不完全如此。

5 Breasted, J. The Dawn of Conscience . Charles Scribner’s Sons, New York, 1933.

5 布雷斯特德，J.《良知的曙光》。查尔斯·斯克里布纳之子出版社，纽约，1933年。

6 Tolstoy, L. War and Peace . The Modern Library, New York.

6 托尔斯泰，L.《战争与和平》。纽约现代文库。

7 Philippe, C.-L. Bubu of Montparnasse. Loc. cit .

7 Philippe, C.-L. Bubu of Montparnasse. 同上。

10 Abraham, K. Selected Papers . Hogarth Press, London, 1948.

10 Abraham, K. Selected Papers. Hogarth Press, London, 1948.

11 Erikson, E. Childhood and Society. Loc. cit ., Chapter 2.

11 埃里克森，E.《童年与社会》。同上，第 2 章。

fn1 But please do not beat bed wetters in an attempt to cure them.

fn1 但请不要为了治好尿床的孩子而殴打他们。

#↩

CHAPTER NINE

第九章

Adolescence

青春期

Adolescence means high school and college days, driver’s license, bar-mitzvah, initiation, having your own thing and your own things. It means hair here and there, brassières and menstruation, shaving, and maybe an undeserved affliction that blows your plans and your mind – acne. It means deciding what you are going to be the rest of your life, or at least how to fill in your time until you do decide. It means (if you really want to find out what it means) reading the three hundred or so books in print on the subject, as well as some of the very good ones that have gone out of print, and several thousand articles in magazines and scientific journals. For the script analyst it means a rehearsal, or a tryout before the show takes to the road. It means now you really are on the spot to answer the question, because if you don’t you may not make it: ‘What do you say after you say Hello?’ or ‘When your parents and teachers no longer structure your time completely, how do you structure your time?’

青春期意味着高中和大学时光，驾照，成人礼，各种仪式，拥有自己的爱好和物品。它意味着头发时不时地冒出来，穿胸罩，经历月经，刮胡子，或许还会遭遇一些不该经历的折磨——痤疮，它会让你的计划和想法彻底崩塌。它意味着你要决定自己余生要成为什么样的人，或者至少要决定在做出决定之前如何打发时间。它意味着（如果你真的想了解它的意义），你要阅读大约三百本关于这个主题的书籍，以及一些已经绝版的优秀作品，还有几千篇发表在杂志和科学期刊上的文章。对于剧本分析家来说，它意味着排练，或者说是演出开始前的试演。它意味着现在你必须立刻回答这个问题，因为如果你回答不好，你可能就没机会了：“你好之后该说什么？”或者“当你的父母和老师不再完全安排你的时间时，你该如何安排自己的时间？”

A • Pastimes

A • 消遣

Silences can be filled in by talking about things, cars or sports, usually a form of showing off, with points for the one with the most knowledge. The script comes into play by knowing more than anybody or less than anybody, by talking about triumphs or misfortunes, ‘I had a bigger time than you,’ or ‘I had a worse woe than you.’ Some people are such losers that even their misfortunes are trivial, and they can’t win either way. Another topic with people you know better is ideas and feelings, comparing philosophies, ‘Me Too’ or ‘With Me It’s Different.’ A winner can be nobler or tougher, while a loser can produce bigger guilts and suffers; in between, a nonwinner may be stuck with merely mediocre feelings. A third area is PTA: ‘What do you do with delinquent teachers, or delinquent parents, or delinquent boy or girl friends?’ This is the Life Crowd, waiting for Santa Claus, who will bring a better car, a better football team, better times, or better teachers, parents, boy or girl friends. The Death Crowd may despise all this and spend their time in more scripty ways, smoking marijuana, dropping LSD, going on ‘trips’ together, and ‘really rapping.’ In any case, whichever crowd he runs with, Jeder learns what is acceptable and what is not acceptable to say and how to say it, and compares trading stamps with others of his ilk.

沉默可以通过谈论事物、汽车或体育来打破，这通常是一种炫耀，谁知道得最多谁就能得分。人们会根据自己的知识水平来决定谁比谁懂得多或比谁少，谈论成功或失败，比如“我比你过得更精彩”或“我比你更惨”。有些人如此失败，以至于他们的不幸都显得微不足道，无论怎样都无法取胜。与更熟悉的人谈论另一个话题是想法和感受，比较彼此的哲学理念，“我也是”或“我不一样”。赢家可能更高尚或更坚韧，而输家可能承受更大的愧疚和痛苦；介于两者之间的失败者可能只是困于平庸的感受中。第三个领域是家长教师协会（PTA）：“该如何处理不守规矩的老师、家长或男女朋友？” 这是“生活派”，他们等待着圣诞老人，希望他能带来更好的车、更好的足球队、更好的生活，或者更好的老师、家长、男女朋友。“死亡派”可能鄙视这一切，他们把时间花在更程式化的事情上，比如抽大麻、嗑LSD、一起“旅行”以及“认真说唱”。无论如何，无论他属于哪个群体，杰德都会学会哪些话该说，哪些话不该说，以及如何表达，并与其他同类人交流交换邮票的经验。

B • New Heroes

B • 新英雄

From such talk, from reading, and from what he sees, Jeder replaces the mythical or magical heroes of his script protocol with more workable figures, real live people or real dead ones whom he can emulate. He also learns more about real villains and how they work. At the same time he acquires a nickname, or a name form (Frederick, Fred, or Freddie; Charles, Charlie, or Chuck) which tells him how he looks to others and what he has to fight against or be. Fatso, Horseface, Blinky, or Meathead will have to work extra hard to have a happy ending. Busty and The Hairy Ape may find that sex comes easy, but what if they want something else?

从这些谈话、阅读和所见所闻中，杰德用更实际的人物——活生生的人或已故的人——取代了他剧本中神话或魔法般的英雄，并可以模仿他们。他还更多地了解了真正的反派及其行事方式。与此同时，他获得了一个绰号或名字形式（弗雷德里克、弗雷德或弗雷迪；查尔斯、查理或查克），这告诉他别人眼中的自己，以及他必须与之斗争或成为什么样的人。胖子、马脸、眨眼或肉头必须付出额外的努力才能获得幸福的结局。丰满的和毛茸茸的猿猴可能会发现性爱唾手可得，但如果他们想要别的呢？

C • The Totem

C • 图腾

A great many people have an animal or sometimes a vegetable which recurs again and again in their dreams. This is their totem. Thus there are bird-women, spider-women, snake-, cat-, and horse-women, rose- and herb- and cabbage-women, and many others, too. Among men, dogs, horses, tigers, large constrictor snakes, and trees are favorites. The totem appears in many forms. Sometimes it is fearsome, as spiders and snakes almost always are, and sometimes it is benevolent, as cats and cabbages usually are. If a cat-woman has an abortion or miscarriage, it is quite likely that dead kittens will appear in her dreams.

许多人的梦境中反复出现某种动物，有时也可能是某种植物。这就是他们的图腾。因此，有鸟女、蜘蛛女、蛇女、猫女、马女、玫瑰女、草药女、卷心菜女等等。在男性中，狗、马、老虎、大型蟒蛇和树木是常见的图腾。图腾以多种形式出现。有时它令人恐惧，就像蜘蛛和蛇几乎总是如此；有时它又很仁慈，就像猫和卷心菜通常那样。如果一个猫女流产，她很可能会梦见死去的小猫。

In real life, the patient reacts to the totem animal very much as he does in dreaming. Negative totems are often connected with allergic reactions, and positive ones are highly favored as pets, although they may cause allergies, too. Some people envy their totems and try to be them. Many women would like to be cats, and say so frequently. Women’s leg-and-arm movements are usually highly stylized in social situations, but their totem animals can often be surmised by watching movements of the head. They may imitate cats, birds, or snakes, which can be easily verified by watching cats, birds, or snakes. Men are freer with their limbs and bodies, and some stamp their feet like horses or throw out their arms like constrictors. This is not mere fancy on the part of the observer, since it can be confirmed by listening carefully to their metaphors and by hearing their dreams.

在现实生活中，患者对图腾动物的反应与梦境中非常相似。负面图腾通常与过敏反应有关，而正面图腾则备受青睐，常被当作宠物饲养，尽管它们也可能引起过敏。有些人羡慕自己的图腾，并试图成为它们。许多女性渴望成为猫，并且经常这样说。女性在社交场合的肢体动作通常比较程式化，但她们的图腾动物往往可以通过观察头部动作来推测。她们可能会模仿猫、鸟或蛇，这一点可以通过观察猫、鸟或蛇的行为来轻易验证。男性的肢体动作则更为自由，有些人会像马一样跺脚，或者像蟒蛇一样张开双臂。这并非观察者的臆测，因为仔细聆听他们的比喻和梦境就能证实这一点。

Totemism is usually given up by the age of sixteen. If it persists into later adolescence in the form of dreams, phobias, imitations, or hobbies, it should certainly be taken into account. If it is not that obvious, positive totemism is easily elicited by asking: ‘Which is your favorite animal?’ or ‘Which animal would you like to be?’ and negative totemism by: ‘Which animal are you most scared of?’

图腾崇拜通常在十六岁左右消失。如果它以梦境、恐惧症、模仿或爱好等形式持续到青春期后期，则务必予以重视。如果图腾崇拜并不明显，可以通过询问“你最喜欢的动物是什么？”或“你想成为哪种动物？”来轻松探究其积极的方面，而通过询问“你最害怕哪种动物？”来探究其消极的方面。

D • New Feelings

D • 新的感受

Masturbation is something of his own. He is not sure what to do with his new sex feelings or how to fit them into his plan, so he reacts to them with the earlier feelings he has become familiar with, his racket. Masturbation may also put him through the agony of a true existential crisis: it is something he does or does not do at a given moment, and it is (or should be) his decision alone; and once he has done it, he, and he alone, must take the consequences. These may be private feelings such as guilt (because masturbation is wicked), fear (because it will damage his health, he thinks), or inadequacy (because it will weaken his will power, he thinks). All these are ‘head transactions’ between the Parent and the Child in his skull. On the other hand, he may have transactional feelings which depend on the reactions, real or imaginary, of his public: hurt, anger, or embarrassment, because now he thinks they have a real reason to make fun of him, hate him, or shame him. In any case, masturbation gives him a way of fitting the new sex feelings in with the old feelings he learned as a child.

自慰是他自己的一种行为。他不确定该如何处理自己新生的性感受，也不知道该如何将其融入自己的计划，于是他用之前熟悉的、熟悉的性冲动来应对。自慰也可能让他经历一场真正的存在主义危机：这是他在某个特定时刻选择做或不做的事情，而且（或者说应该是）完全由他自己决定；一旦做了，就必须由他自己承担后果。这些后果可能是一些私密的感受，例如内疚（因为他认为自慰是邪恶的）、恐惧（因为他认为这会损害他的健康）或无力感（因为他认为这会削弱他的意志力）。所有这些都是他脑海中“父母”和“孩子”之间的“心理互动”。另一方面，他可能存在一种交易性的情感，这种情感取决于公众的反应，无论这种反应是真实的还是想象的：受伤、愤怒或尴尬，因为他现在认为他们有充分的理由嘲笑他、憎恨他或羞辱他。无论如何，自慰让他能够将新的性感受与他童年时期习得的旧有感受融合起来。

But he also learns to be more flexible. From his schoolmates and teachers he gets ‘permission’ to react with feelings other than those encouraged at home, and he also learns to cool it: not everybody takes seriously the things his folks worry about. This switch in his feeling-system gradually separates him from his family and draws him closer to people his own age. He adapts his script to the new situation and makes it more ‘presentable.’ He may even change his role from being a total failure to being a partial success, from being a loser to being merely a nonwinner and at least breaking even. If he has a winning script, he discovers that that requires a certain objectivity. He is now in a competitive situation and victories do not come automatically, but only after a certain amount of planning and work; and he learns to take a few losses without getting shaken up.

但他同时也学会了更加灵活。从同学和老师那里，他获得了“许可”，可以表达与在家不被鼓励的情绪不同的感受，他也学会了冷静下来：并非所有人都像父母那样担忧。这种情感系统的转变逐渐让他与家人疏远，并让他与同龄人更加亲近。他调整自己的剧本以适应新的环境，使其更加“得体”。他甚至可能改变自己的角色，从彻底的失败者变成部分成功者，从失败者变成勉强及格，至少能收支平衡。如果他有一套成功的剧本，他会发现这需要一定的客观性。他现在身处竞争环境中，胜利并非唾手可得，而是需要一定的计划和努力；他学会了坦然接受一些失败而不慌乱。

E • Physical Reactions

E • 物理反应

Under all this stress and change, and the need to keep cool in order to get what he wants, good or bad, he becomes more aware of his bodily reactions. His mother and father can no longer surround him with love and protection, or on the other hand, he is no longer inclined simply to cower before their rage, drunkenness, whining, or brawls. Whatever the situation at home, he is on his own outside. He must rise before his fellows and recite, and walk down long and often lonely corridors under the critical gaze of other boys and girls, many of whom already know his weaknesses. So sometimes he sweats aromatically, his hands shake, his heart pounds; girls blush, their clothes become moist, and their stomachs gurgle. In both sexes, there is an assorted loosening and tightening up of various internal and external sphincters, and this reorganization in the long run may determine which ‘psychosomatic’ illnesses will play a major role in their scripts. Jeder becomes resphincterized.

在所有这些压力和变化之下，为了得到自己想要的东西（无论好坏），他必须保持冷静，这让他更加关注自己的身体反应。他的父母再也无法用爱和保护包围他，或者说，他也不再愿意在他们的愤怒、醉酒、抱怨或争吵面前卑躬屈膝。无论家里的情况如何，在外面他都只能靠自己。他必须在同伴面前起身背诵，在其他男孩女孩挑剔的目光下走过漫长而常常孤独的走廊，他们中的许多人早已了解他的弱点。所以有时他会汗流浃背，双手颤抖，心跳加速；女孩们会脸红，衣服湿透，肚子咕噜作响。无论男女，各种内外括约肌都会出现不同程度的放松和紧缩，而这种长期的重组可能会决定哪些“心身”疾病会在他们的人生剧本中扮演重要角色。杰德的括约肌功能也随之发生了变化。

F • The Front Room and the Back Room

F • 前厅和后厅

What goes on in ‘the front room’ and what goes on in ‘the back room’ may be of two different colors, as the following anecdote shows. Cassandra was a clergyman’s daughter who dressed in the sloppy but oddly erotic style of Loser Sex, and her life had the same quality: sloppy but oddly erotic. It was evident that her father had somehow instructed her to be seductive, while her mother had not taught her the conventional techniques for carrying this off. She agreed that her mother had not shown her how to dress or cultivate her body, but denied at first that her father had taught her to be sexy: ‘He was a very proper man, and very moral, as a clergyman should be.’ On further questioning by the therapist and the other group members concerning her father’s attitude toward women, she said that it was very proper and approving, except that once in a while he sat in the back room with a few friends and they told sexy jokes, which were usually not to the credit of the female sex. Thus, her father was very proper in the ‘front room,’ but showed another side of his personality in the ‘back room.’ In other words, he showed his Parent or good little boy in the front room and his naughty Child in the room behind.

正如以下轶事所示，“前厅”和“后厅”里发生的事情可能截然不同。卡桑德拉是一位牧师的女儿，她的穿着打扮邋遢却又带着一种奇特的性感，这种风格被称为“失败者性爱”（Loser Sex），而她的生活也同样如此：邋遢却又带着一种奇特的性感。显然，她的父亲不知何故教过她如何展现诱惑力，而她的母亲却没有教过她如何做到这一点。她承认母亲没有教过她如何穿衣打扮或锻炼身体，但起初否认父亲教过她如何性感：“他是个非常正派、非常有道德的人，就像一个牧师应该有的样子。”在治疗师和其他小组成员进一步询问她父亲对女性的态度时，她说父亲的态度非常正派且赞同，只是偶尔会和几个朋友坐在后厅里讲一些低俗的笑话，这些笑话通常都带有贬损女性的意味。因此，她的父亲在“前厅”里举止得体，但在“后厅”里却展现出截然不同的一面。换句话说，他在前厅里扮演慈父或乖儿子的角色，而在后厅里则扮演淘气的孩子。

Children become aware very early in life that their parents have several sides to their characters, but they don’t know how to evaluate that until they are adolescents. If they live in homes where there is ‘front room’ behavior and ‘back room’ behavior, they may resent this as part of the world’s hypocrisy. A woman took her eighteen-year-old son to dinner when he came home from college for the holidays. She ordered a Martini for herself, but told him he couldn’t have one, although she knew he liked liquor, and indeed, drank excessively. The group members had spent hours listening to her complaints about her son’s drinking. Now they agreed that it would have been better if she had either not ordered a drink, or else allowed him to have one with her, but that the way she did it she was setting him up for an alcoholic script.

孩子们很小的时候就意识到父母性格有好几面，但直到青春期才懂得如何评价这些面。如果他们生活在家庭中，父母的行为分明，有“前厅”和“后厅”，他们可能会因此感到愤恨，认为这是世间虚伪的一部分。一位母亲在她18岁的儿子放假回家时带他去吃饭。她给自己点了一杯马提尼，却不让儿子喝，尽管她知道儿子喜欢喝酒，而且确实经常酗酒。小组的成员们花了几个小时听她抱怨儿子喝酒。现在他们一致认为，如果她不点酒，或者允许儿子和她一起喝，情况会更好，但她现在的做法无异于在为儿子日后酗酒埋下伏笔。

In script language, the front room represents the antiscript, where the parental precepts hold sway, while the back room represents the script, where the real action is.

在剧本语言中，前厅代表反剧本，父母的教条在那里占据主导地位；而后厅代表剧本，真正的行动在那里发生。

G • Script and Antiscript

G • 脚本和反脚本

Adolescence is the period when Jeder oscillates, or agonizes, between his script and his antiscript. He tries to follow his parents’ precepts, then rebels against them, only to find himself following their script programing. He sees the futility of that and falls back on the precepts again. By the end of his adolescence, when he graduates from college, for example, or gets out of the army, he has made some sort of decision; he either settles down and follows the precepts, or breaks away and slides downhill toward his script payoff. He is likely to continue on this chosen course until he reaches forty, when he goes through his second agony. If he has followed his parents’ precepts, he then tries to break out: he gets a divorce, quits his job, absconds with the profits, or at least dyes his hair and buys a guitar. If he has gone down with the script, he tries to reform by joining AA or going to a psychiatrist.

青春期是杰德在既定剧本和反剧本之间摇摆不定、痛苦挣扎的时期。他试图遵循父母的教诲，然后又反抗，最终却发现自己又回到了父母的剧本模式中。他意识到这种做法的徒劳，于是再次回归教诲。到了青春期末期，例如大学毕业或退伍时，他通常会做出某种决定：要么安定下来，遵循教诲；要么挣脱束缚，滑向剧本设定的回报之路。他很可能会沿着这条路走下去，直到四十岁，经历第二次痛苦。如果他遵循了父母的教诲，他就会尝试挣脱束缚：离婚、辞职、卷款潜逃，或者至少染个头发，买把吉他。如果他屈服于剧本，他就会尝试通过加入匿名戒酒互助会或去看心理医生来改变自己。

But adolescence is the period when he first feels that he can make an autonomous choice: unfortunately, this feeling of autonomy may be part of the illusion. What he often does is merely alternate more or less violently between the precepts of the Parent in his parents, and the provocations of the Child they put forth. Teen-age drug users are not necessarily rebelling against parental authority. They are rebelling against Parental slogans, but in so doing, they may simply be following the demonic come-ons, the ‘crazy Child,’ of the very same parents. ‘I don’t want my son drinking,’ says mother as she takes a drink. If he doesn’t drink, he is a good boy, a mama’s boy. If he does drink, he is a bad boy, but he is still a mama’s boy. ‘Don’t let anybody up your skirt,’ says father to his daughter, looking at the waitress’s skirt. Whichever way she plays it, she is still daddy’s girl. She can either shack up in high school and then reform, or remain a virgin until she is married and then have affairs later. But somewhere in between, perhaps both the boy and girl can make up their own minds and free themselves from their scripts and live life their own ways. Especially if they have permission to make up their own minds, and not ‘permission to make up your own mind (as long as you make it up my way).’

但青春期是他第一次觉得自己可以做出自主选择的时期：不幸的是，这种自主感可能只是一种错觉。他通常只是在父母的“父母”教条和他们灌输的“孩子”的挑衅之间或多或少地激烈地交替。青少年吸毒者未必是在反抗父母的权威。他们是在反抗“父母”的口号，但这样做，他们可能只是在追随父母身上那些恶魔般的诱惑，那些“疯狂的孩子”的指令。“我不想让我的儿子喝酒，”母亲一边喝着酒一边说。如果他不喝酒，他就是个好孩子，一个妈宝男。如果他喝酒，他就是个坏孩子，但他仍然是妈宝男。“别让任何人掀你的裙子，”父亲看着女服务员的裙子对女儿说。无论她怎么做，她仍然是爸爸的乖女儿。她要么高中时就和人同居，然后改过自新；要么保持处女之身直到结婚，婚后再出轨。但或许在两者之间，男孩和女孩都能做出自己的选择，摆脱既定的剧本，活出自己的人生。尤其是在他们被允许自己做决定的情况下，而不是“允许你做决定（只要你按我的方式来）”。

H • The World Image

H • 世界图像

The child has a picture of the world which is quite different from the way it appears to his parents. It is a fairy-tale world, full of monsters and magic, and it persists all through his life and forms the archaic background for his script. A simple example is the night fear or night terror, where Jeder calls out that there is a bear in his room. His parents come in and turn on the light and show him that there are no bears there, or else become angry and tell him to hush up and go to sleep. Either way, his Child knows that there is, or was, a bear in the room nevertheless. Like Galileo, he cries: ‘Eppur se muove.’ The difference in the two ways of handling it does not change the fact of the bear. The reasoning approach means that when there is a bear your parents will come and protect you and the bear will go into hiding; the angry approach means that when there is a bear you are on your own. But the bear stays, either way.

孩子眼中的世界与父母眼中的世界截然不同。那是一个充满怪兽和魔法的童话世界，它贯穿孩子的一生，构成了他人生剧本的古老背景。一个简单的例子就是夜惊或夜惊症，杰德会大喊房间里有只熊。他的父母进来打开灯，让他看到房间里并没有熊，或者生气地让他安静下来睡觉。但无论如何，孩子心里都清楚房间里有一只熊，或者曾经有一只熊。就像伽利略一样，他会哭喊：“Eppur se muove”（熊在动）。两种不同的处理方式并不能改变熊存在的事实。理性的方式意味着，当有熊的时候，父母会来保护你，熊会躲起来；愤怒的方式则意味着，当有熊的时候，你只能靠自己。但无论如何，熊始终都在。

By the time he grows up, Jeder’s world image or script set has become much more elaborate and also much better hidden, unless it reappears with its original distortions in the form of delusions. Usually, however, there is no inkling of it until it appears in a dream, and then suddenly much of the patient’s behavior becomes coherent and understandable. One woman was preoccupied with money troubles because her husband got into complex financial scrapes with various employers. But when the other group members questioned some of his actions, Wanda would angrily defend him. She was also much preoccupied with the quality of her family’s diet. Actually she had no reason to worry, since her parents were well off and she could always borrow money from them. For about two years, the therapist was unable to construct a coherent picture in his own mind of what was going on, until one night she had a ‘script dream.’ She was ‘living in a concentration camp which was run by some rich people who lived up on the hill.’ The only way to get enough food was either to please these rich people or trick them.

等到杰德长大成人，他的世界观或剧本体系会变得更加复杂，也更加隐蔽，除非它以妄想的形式重新出现，并带有最初的扭曲。然而，通常情况下，直到它出现在梦中，患者才会有所察觉，然后突然间，患者的许多行为变得连贯且易于理解。一位女士因为丈夫与不同的雇主之间复杂的财务纠纷而忧心忡忡。但当其他组员质疑他某些行为时，旺达会愤怒地维护他。她也非常在意家人的饮食质量。实际上，她完全没有理由担心，因为她的父母家境富裕，她总能从他们那里借钱。大约两年时间里，治疗师始终无法在脑海中构建出一幅关于她所经历的一切的连贯画面，直到一天晚上，她做了一个“剧本梦”。梦中，她“生活在一个由住在山上的一些富人管理的集中营里”。要想获得足够的食物，唯一的办法就是取悦这些富人，或者欺骗他们。

This dream made her way of life easier to understand. Her husband was playing ‘Let’s Pull a Fast One on Joey’ with his employers, so that Wanda could play ‘Making Ends Meet.’ If he ever made any money, he was always careful to lose it at the first opportunity so that the games could continue. When things got really bad, Wanda pitched in and helped him pull a fast one on her parents. In the long run, much to their chagrin, his employers and her parents always managed to end up in control of the situation. She had to deny all this angrily in the group because it was so obviously unprofitable that, if she ever admitted it, the games would be broken up (which they eventually were). Thus, she was actually living much the way she did in her dream, her parents and her husband’s employers being the rich people who lived up on the hill and ran her life, and whom they had to please or trick to survive.

这个梦让她更容易理解自己的生活方式。她的丈夫和他的雇主们玩着“捉弄乔伊”的游戏，好让旺达能玩“勉强糊口”的游戏。如果他赚了点钱，总是小心翼翼地在第一时间把它输光，这样游戏才能继续下去。当情况变得非常糟糕时，旺达会帮他捉弄自己的父母。最终，令他们懊恼的是，他的雇主和她的父母总是能掌控局面。她不得不在众人面前愤怒地否认这一切，因为这显然是得不偿失的，如果她承认了，游戏就会被终止（而最终也确实如此）。因此，她实际上过着和梦里几乎一样的生活，她的父母和她丈夫的雇主就是住在山上、掌控着她生活的有钱人，他们为了生存不得不讨好或欺骗这些人。

Here the concentration camp was her world picture or script set. She lived in reality as she would have to live if she lived in the camp of her dream. Her treatment up to that time was typical of ‘making progress.’ She had made a great deal of progress, but now it was clear that this progress meant merely ‘how to live better in a concentration camp.’ It had no effect on her script, but simply made her more comfortable while living it out. In order to get well, she had to get out of the concentration camp and into the real world, which for her was a comfortable one, or would be after the family affairs were in order. It is interesting to note how she and her husband selected each other on the basis of having complementary scripts. His script called for some rich people up on the hill to play tricks on, and a scared wife. Hers called for a trickster who would make her life easier in her enslavement.

在这里，集中营就是她的世界图景或剧本。她活在现实中，就像她如果生活在梦寐以求的集中营里就必须经历的那样。她之前的待遇是典型的“进步”。她确实取得了很大的进步，但现在很明显，这种进步仅仅意味着“如何在集中营里更好地生活”。它对她的剧本没有任何影响，只是让她在剧本中生活得更舒适一些。为了康复，她必须离开集中营，回到真实的世界——对她来说，真实的世界是舒适的，或者说，在家庭事务安排妥当之后会是舒适的。值得注意的是，她和丈夫选择彼此是基于他们互补的剧本。他的剧本需要一个住在山上的富人来捉弄他，以及一个胆怯的妻子。而她的剧本则需要一个骗子，让她在被奴役的日子里过得更轻松一些。

The script set is usually so far removed from the reality of the patient’s life that there is no way to reconstruct it by mere observation or interpretation. The best hope of getting a clear picture of it is through a dream. The ‘script-set dream’ is recognizable because as soon as the patient tells it, many things fall into place. Pictorially, it has no resemblance to the patient’s actual way of life, but transactionally, it is an exact replica. A woman who was always ‘looking for a way out’ dreamed that she was being chased, and found a tunnel that sloped downward. She crept into the tunnel and the people chasing her could not follow. They just stood guard hoping she would come out again. She discovered, however, that there was another gang of dangerous people waiting for her at the other end of the tunnel. Thus she could go neither forward nor back; at the same time, if she relaxed, she would slide down into the arms of those who were waiting below. Therefore she had to press with her hands against the sides of the tunnel, and as long as she did that she was safe.

剧本设定通常与患者的真实生活相去甚远，仅凭观察或解读根本无法重现。想要清晰了解它，最好的办法是通过梦境。“剧本设定的梦”之所以容易辨认，是因为患者一旦讲述梦境，许多细节便会迎刃而解。从画面上看，它与患者的真实生活毫无相似之处，但从本质上讲，它却是一个精确的复制品。一位总是“寻找出路”的女子梦见自己被人追赶，发现了一条向下倾斜的隧道。她悄悄溜进隧道，追赶她的人无法跟上，只能守在隧道口，盼着她能再次出来。然而，她发现隧道的另一端还有另一伙危险人物在等着她。因此，她既不能前进也不能后退；同时，如果她放松警惕，就会滑落到下方那些人的怀抱中。因此，她必须用双手抵住隧道壁，只要她这样做，她就是安全的。

In script language, most of her life had been spent trapped in a tunnel in this cramped position, and it seemed clear from her attitudes and past history that the end of the script called for her to get tired of holding on and slide down into the arms of waiting death. She, too, had made considerable ‘progress’ during her treatment up to that point. Translated, that progress meant ‘how to be more comfortable while holding on to the sides of a tunnel and waiting for death.’ A script cure meant to get her out of the tunnel and into the real world, which again was a comfortable one for her. The tunnel was her script set. There are, of course, many other interpretations of this dream, as any freshman who has taken Psychology 1 can readily see. But the script interpretation is important because it tells the therapist and the other group members, as well as the patient and her husband, what they are dealing with and what has to be done, and emphasizes that ‘progress’ is not enough.

用剧本语言来说，她的大半生都被困在隧道里，处于这种狭窄的境地。从她的态度和过往经历来看，剧本的结局似乎是让她筋疲力尽，最终滑入死神的怀抱。在此之前，她在治疗过程中也取得了相当大的“进步”。这种进步被解读为“如何在紧紧抓住隧道壁等待死亡的同时，变得更加舒适”。剧本式的治疗意味着让她走出隧道，回到现实世界——而现实世界对她来说依然舒适。隧道就是她的剧本。当然，对于这个梦境还有许多其他的解释，任何上过心理学入门课的大一新生都能轻易看出这一点。但剧本式的解读至关重要，因为它告诉治疗师和其他小组成员，以及患者和她的丈夫，他们正在面对什么，需要做什么，并强调“进步”是不够的。

The tunnel scene had probably remained unchanged since early childhood, as the patient had had this dream many times before. The concentration-camp scene is evidently a later adaptation of a childhood nightmare which Wanda was unable to recall. It was clearly based on early experiences modified by reading and adolescent fantasies. Adolescence, then, is the period when the fearsome tunnels of infancy are given a more realistic and contemporary form to build the operative script set for the patient’s life plan. Wanda’s reluctance to probe into her husband’s ‘tricks’ shows how tenaciously people cling to their script scenes while complaining about how disagreeable they are.

隧道场景可能自幼年起就未曾改变，因为病人此前曾多次做过类似的梦。集中营场景显然是旺达后来根据童年噩梦改编而成，而她本人已无法回忆起这个噩梦的内容。它显然基于早期经历，并经阅读和青春期幻想的加工。因此，青春期是这样一个时期：童年时期令人恐惧的隧道被赋予了更现实、更现代的形式，从而构建出病人人生规划的行动脚本。旺达不愿探究丈夫的“伎俩”，这表明人们在抱怨这些脚本有多么令人不快的同时，仍然会多么顽固地坚持自己的剧本。

One script set that can continue unchanged for a lifetime is the bathroom. In the last chapter, we gave an example of a woman whose Child spent her life sitting on the toilet, even when her body was lying on the couch. In her case, progress meant ‘how to have a richer social life and enjoy parties while carrying your toilet around wherever you go.’ Getting well meant that she had to get up and go out and leave her security blanket behind, and this she was reluctant to do. Another girl who complained that she was ill at ease in company lived her script life crunched up on a small ledge on the face of a sheer cliff. She had a portable cliff that she carried with her wherever she went. She could make progress by being happier while crunched up on a cliff, or get well by coming down and dancing with the other people.

有一种剧本可以终生不变地延续下去，那就是厕所。上一章我们举了一个例子：一位女士的“孩子”一生都坐在马桶上，即使她的身体躺在沙发上。对她来说，“进步”意味着“如何拥有更丰富的社交生活，享受派对，同时无论去哪里都带着马桶”。“康复”意味着她必须起身走出去，离开她的“安全毯”，而她对此很不情愿。另一个女孩抱怨自己不善交际，她的“剧本”是蜷缩在陡峭悬崖边的一小块岩架上。她随身带着一个“移动悬崖”。她可以通过蜷缩在悬崖上获得快乐来取得进步，也可以通过下来和其他人一起跳舞来康复。

I • Sweatshirts

我 • 运动衫

All the items which have been discussed so far in this chapter are condensed into the patient’s demeanor, the way he ‘comes on,’ and that is called his ‘sweatshirt.’ The sweatshirt, in an exceedingly creative, artistic, and economical phrase or two, indicates to the experienced eye the patient’s favorite pastime, game, and feeling, his nickname, what he does in the front room and the back room, what kind of a mental world he lives in, what kind of ending his script calls for, and sometimes the critical sphincter, his hero, and his totem.

本章迄今为止讨论的所有事项都浓缩在病人的举止中，他“出场”的方式，也就是他所谓的“卫衣”。卫衣，用一两句极富创意、艺术性和简洁性的短语，就能向经验丰富的人表明病人最喜欢的消遣、游戏和感受，他的绰号，他在前厅和后厅做什么，他生活在什么样的精神世界中，他的剧本需要什么样的结局，有时甚至是关键的括约肌、他的英雄和他的图腾。

The sweatshirt is usually adopted in high school or early college years, the age when sweatshirts are popular. In later life it may be embroidered or the wording changed slightly, but the core of the meaning will remain unchanged.

运动衫通常在高中或大学早期流行，因为那时正是运动衫风靡的时期。长大后，运动衫上的图案可能会绣上花纹，文字也可能稍作改动，但其核心含义却不会改变。

All competent clinicians, of whatever school, have one thing in common: they are good observers. Since they are all observing the same thing – human behavior – there is bound to be a similarity in what they see and how they sort out and account for their observations. Hence the psychoanalytic idea 1 of ‘character defense’ or ‘character armor,’ the Jungian concept 2 of ‘attitude,’ the Adlerian notion 3 of ‘life lie’ or ‘life style,’ and the transactional metaphor of ‘sweatshirt’ all describe very similar phenomena. fn1

所有合格的临床医生，无论属于哪个学派，都有一个共同点：他们都是优秀的观察者。由于他们观察的都是同一件事——人类行为——因此，他们所观察到的现象以及他们如何整理和解释这些观察结果必然存在相似之处。因此，精神分析中的“性格防御”或“性格盔甲”概念、荣格学派的“态度”概念、阿德勒学派的“生活谎言”或“生活方式”概念，以及“运动衫”这一交易隐喻，都描述了非常相似的现象。

An actual sweatshirt (‘Hell’s Angels,’ ‘The Losers,’ ‘Black Panthers,’ ‘Harvard Track Team,’ or even ‘Beethoven’) states which gang a person belongs to, and gives some indication of his philosophy and how he is likely to respond to certain stimuli; but it does not indicate exactly how he will go about conning someone and what payoff he expects. For example, it is clear that many members of the first three gangs mentioned above are riding on the ‘Fuck You’ streetcar, but without knowing each member of the gang intimately (in the clinical sense) it is not possible to predict which ones want to be killed in order to become martyrs, which ones want merely to be manhandled so that they can cry ‘Police brutality!’ 4 and which ones are straight. The sweatshirt indicates their collective attitude and the games they share in common, but each one is playing out his own script with its own individual payoff.

一件印有“地狱天使”、“失败者”、“黑豹”、“哈佛田径队”甚至“贝多芬”字样的运动衫，不仅表明了一个人所属的帮派，也暗示了他的某种理念以及他对某些刺激的反应；但它并不能准确地表明他会如何行骗以及他期望从中获得什么好处。例如，很明显，上面提到的前三个帮派的许多成员都乘坐着“去你的”有轨电车，但如果不深入了解每个成员（以临床意义上的了解），就无法预测哪些人渴望被杀以成为烈士，哪些人只想被人粗暴对待以便高喊“警察暴行！” 4 ，以及哪些人是直男。运动衫反映了他们的集体态度和共同的游戏规则，但每个人都在按照自己的剧本行事，并追求各自的回报。

A transactional or script sweatshirt is an attitude which is clearly advertised by the person’s demeanor, just as clearly as though he wore a sweatshirt with his script slogan printed on the front. Some common script sweatshirts are ‘Kick Me,’ ‘Don’t Kick Me,’ ‘I’m Proud I’m an Alcoholic,’ ‘Look How Hard I’m Trying,’ ‘Buzz Off,’ ‘I am Fragile,’ and ‘Need a Fix?’ Some sweatshirts have a message on the front and a ‘kicker’ on the back: for example, a woman comes on like ‘I’m Looking For a Husband,’ but when she turns her back it clearly says: ‘But You Don’t Qualify.’ The man with ‘I’m Proud I’m an Alcoholic’ on his forehead may have ‘But Remember It’s a Sickness’ on his back. Transsexuals wear particularly flamboyant ones with the front slogan ‘Don’t You Think I’m Fascinating?’ while on the back it says ‘Isn’t That Enough?’

所谓“交易型”或“标语型”卫衣，指的是一种态度，这种态度会通过穿着者的举止清晰地展现出来，就像他穿着一件正面印有标语的卫衣一样。一些常见的标语型卫衣包括“踢我”、“别踢我”、“我以身为酒鬼为荣”、“看看我有多努力”、“滚开”、“我很脆弱”和“需要戒酒吗？”。有些卫衣正面印着信息，背面则印着“反讽”：例如，一位女士正面写着“我在找老公”，但当她转身时，背面却清晰地写着：“但你不符合条件”。一位额头上印着“我以身为酒鬼为荣”的男士，背面可能印着“但记住，这是一种疾病”。变性人穿着特别艳丽的T恤，正面标语是“你不觉得我很迷人吗？”，背面则写着“这还不够吗？”

Other sweatshirts give a picture of a more ‘clubbish’ way of life. ‘Nobody Knows the Trouble I’ve Seen’ (NOKTIS) is a fraternity with many branches, one of which is the Melancholy Litvaks’ Club. The Melancholy Litvaks’ Club can be visualized by a Martian as a little wooden building, sparsely furnished with run-down furniture. There are no pictures on the wall, only a framed motto reading ‘Why Not Kill Yourself Today?’ There is a small library consisting of statistical reports and books by pessimistic philosophers. The point of NOKTIS is not the total amount of trouble, but the fact that Nobody Knows. The NOKTIS makes sure that nobody ever finds out, either, because if anybody did know, then he couldn’t say ‘Nobody knows,’ and his sweatshirt would lose its point.

其他一些卫衣则展现了一种更“俱乐部式”的生活方式。“无人知晓我所经历的苦难”（NOKTIS）是一个拥有众多分支的兄弟会，其中之一便是忧郁立陶宛人俱乐部。如果用火星人的视角来想象，忧郁立陶宛人俱乐部就像一座简陋的小木屋，里面摆放着一些破旧的家具。墙上没有挂画，只有一幅装裱起来的格言：“何不今天就自杀？”。俱乐部里有一个小型图书馆，藏书包括统计报告和悲观哲学家的著作。NOKTIS的重点不在于苦难的多少，而在于“无人知晓”这一事实。NOKTIS也确保无人知晓真相，因为一旦有人知道，他就无法再说“无人知晓”，他的卫衣也就失去了意义。

The sweatshirt is usually derived from a favorite slogan of the parents, such as ‘Nobody in the world will love you like your father and mother do.’ This resigned, plod-ahead sweatshirt is disjunctive, and merely serves to separate the wearer from the people around him. By a simple twist it can be transformed into a conjunctive one which will attract other people instead of putting them off, and lead to appropriate ‘Ain’t It Awful’ pastimes and games: ‘Nobody loves me like my father and mother do.’ What attracts other people is the back of this sweatshirt, which reads: ‘How about you?’

这件卫衣通常印着父母最喜欢的一句口号，比如“世界上没有人会像你爸妈那样爱你”。这种无奈、消极的卫衣带有疏离感，只会让穿着者与周围的人格格不入。但只要稍作改动，它就能变成一件充满凝聚力的卫衣，吸引他人而非疏远他人，并引发一些恰到好处的“真糟糕”式的消遣和游戏：“没有人会像我爸妈那样爱我。”真正吸引人的是这件卫衣的背面，上面写着：“你呢？”

We can now consider in detail two common sweatshirts, and we shall try to demonstrate the usefulness of this concept in predicting significant items of behavior.

现在我们可以详细考虑两种常见的运动衫，我们将尝试证明这一概念在预测重要行为方面的实用性。

YOU CAN’T TRUST ANYBODY

你不能相信任何人

There are certain people who quickly make it clear that they do not trust anybody. That is, they talk about life that way, but their behavior is not entirely consistent with what they say, because actually they are continually ‘trusting’ people, but it usually turns out badly. The concept of sweatshirts has an advantage over the more naive approaches of ‘character defense,’ ‘attitude,’ and ‘life style’ because they tend to take things at face value, while the transactional analyst is accustomed to look first of all for the con or paradox, and is gratified rather than surprised when he finds it. That is what he looks for when he finds a sweatshirt, and that is what gives him his therapeutic advantage. To put it another way, character analysts analyze the front of the sweatshirt very effectively, but fail to look at the back where the game slogan or ‘kicker’ is written, or at least it takes them a long time to get around to it, while the game analyst looks there right at the beginning.

有些人会很快表明他们不信任任何人。也就是说，他们口头上是这样说的，但他们的行为却与他们的言论并不完全一致，因为实际上他们一直在“信任”别人，只是结果往往不太好。“卫衣”的概念比“性格防御”、“态度”和“生活方式”等更天真的分析方法更有优势，因为这些方法往往只看表面，而交易分析师习惯于首先寻找其中的欺骗或悖论，并且发现后会感到欣喜而非惊讶。这就是他分析卫衣时所寻找的东西，也是他具有治疗优势的原因。换句话说，性格分析师能非常有效地分析卫衣的正面，但却忽略了背面印着的标语或“关键信息”，或者至少他们需要很长时间才会注意到这一点，而交易分析师则会在一开始就关注那里。

The sweatshirt ‘You Can’t Trust Anybody’ (or ‘You Can’t Trust Anybody Nowadays,’ YOCTAN) is therefore not taken at face value. It does not mean that the wearer will avoid entanglements with people because he does not trust them. Quite the contrary. It means that he will seek entanglements for the express purpose of proving his slogan and reinforcing his position (I’m OK – They’re not-OK). Hence the YOCTAN player picks untrustworthy people, makes ambiguous contracts with them, and then gratefully, or even gleefully, collects brown stamps when something goes wrong, thus confirming his position that ‘You Can’t Trust Anybody.’ In extreme cases he may feel entitled to a ‘free’ homicide, justified by repeated betrayals at the hands of people carefully chosen for their untrustworthiness. Once having collected enough brown stamps for such a payoff, the YOCTAN player may pick as his victim someone he has never met, perhaps a public figure whose murder rates the label of ‘assassination.’

因此，印有“你不能相信任何人”（或“如今你不能相信任何人”，简称YOCTAN）字样的卫衣并非表面意思。它并非意味着穿着者会因为不信任他人而避免与人交往。恰恰相反，它意味着他会刻意制造麻烦，以证明自己的口号并强化自己的立场（我没问题——他们有问题）。因此，YOCTAN玩家会挑选不可信的人，与他们签订模棱两可的合同，然后在事情出错时欣喜若狂地收集“棕色印章”（即背叛），以此来证实他“你不能相信任何人”的观点。在极端情况下，他甚至可能觉得自己有权“免费”杀人，理由是那些精心挑选的、不可信的人屡次背叛了他。一旦收集到足够的棕色邮票以获得这样的回报，YOCTAN 玩家可能会选择他从未见过的人作为受害者，也许是被谋杀的公众人物，其谋杀行为会被贴上“暗杀”的标签。

Other YOCTAN players may seize upon such an event to prove that the ‘authorities,’ such as the police who arrest the assassin, are untrustworthy. The police, of course, are paid for YOCTAN. It is part of their job not to be too trusting. Thus a tournament is started in which amateur or semi-professional YOCTAN players are pitted against professionals. The battle cries of such a tournament, ‘frame-up,’ ‘codes,’ and ‘conspiracy,’ may go on for years or even centuries, the object being to prove such propositions as: ‘Homer was not really Homer, but another man of the same name,’ ‘Raisuli loved Perdicaris,’ and ‘Gavrilo Princip was not really Gavrilo Princip, but another man of the same name.’

其他YOCTAN玩家可能会利用这类事件来证明“权威人士”（例如逮捕刺客的警察）不可信。当然，警察是YOCTAN的受雇人员，不轻易相信他人是他们的职责之一。于是，一场YOCTAN锦标赛应运而生，业余或半职业玩家与职业玩家展开较量。这种锦标赛的口号——“陷害”、“密码”和“阴谋”——可能会持续数年甚至数百年，其目的在于证明诸如“荷马并非真正的荷马，而是另一个同名的人”、“莱苏利爱上了佩尔狄卡里斯”以及“加夫里洛·普林西普并非真正的加夫里洛·普林西普，而是另一个同名的人”之类的命题。

The YOCTAN sweatshirt gives the following information about the wearer. His favorite pastime is discussing double-crosses. His favorite game is YOCTAN, proving that others are untrustworthy. His favorite feeling is triumph: ‘Now I’ve Got You, You Son of a Bitch.’ His nickname is Cagey, and the critical sphincter is his anus (‘Keep a tight ass hole or you’ll get screwed.’). His hero is the man who proves that ‘the authorities’ are untrustworthy. What he does in the front room is come on in a blandly righteous or ingenuous way, while in the back room he is scheming and untrustworthy (like the landlady who self-righteously said: ‘You can’t trust any of your tenants nowadays. Only the other day I was going through the desk of one of them, and you’ll never guess what I found!’). His mental world is a self-righteous one in which he is entitled to do all sorts of shady things, provided the aim is to uncover the untrustworthiness of others. His script calls for him to be done in by someone he trusts so that with his dying breath he can call out his slogan: ‘I knew it. You can’t trust anybody nowadays.’

YOCTAN卫衣透露了穿着者的以下信息。他最喜欢的消遣是讨论尔虞我诈。他最喜欢的游戏是YOCTAN，用来证明别人不可信。他最喜欢的感觉是胜利：“现在我抓到你了，你这狗娘养的！”他的绰号是Cagey，而他最看重的括约肌是他的肛门（“屁股要紧，不然你就完蛋了。”）。他的英雄是那个证明“权威人士”不可信的人。他在前厅里装出一副平淡无奇、义正言辞或天真的模样，而在后屋里，他则阴险狡诈、不可信赖（就像那个自以为是的房东太太说：“现在的房客一个都不能信。前几天我翻了一个房客的桌子，你绝对猜不到我发现了什么！”）。他的精神世界自以为是，认为自己有权做任何见不得光的事，只要目的是为了揭露他人的不可信。他的剧本安排他被自己信任的人杀死，这样他就能在临终前喊出他的口号：“我就知道！现在谁都不能信。”

Thus, the front of his sweatshirt, ‘You Can’t Trust Anybody Nowadays,’ is a bland invitation to well-meaning people, such as unwary therapists, to prove that they are exceptions. If they don’t take the trouble to look, ahead of time, it is only after the dust of battle settles down and the victorious player walks away, that they see what is written on the back: ‘Now Maybe You’ll Believe Me.’ If the therapist is alert, however, he still must be careful not to move too soon, or the patient will say: ‘See, I can’t even trust you.’ Then when he walks away, the kicker is still valid, so he wins either way.

因此，他运动衫正面的标语“如今谁都不能信”其实是在邀请那些好心人，比如粗心的治疗师，来证明自己是个例外。如果他们事先不仔细查看，那么只有在尘埃落定、胜利者离去之后，他们才会看到背面写着的：“现在也许你会相信我了”。然而，如果治疗师足够警觉，他仍然必须小心，不要操之过急，否则病人会说：“你看，连你我都信不了。”这样，即使他转身离开，这句“踢球”依然有效，所以无论如何他都赢了。

DOESN’T EVERYBODY?

难道不是每个人都这样吗？

The thesis of this approach to life is: ‘It’s all right to have measles, since everybody has it.’ Of course it isn’t all right, since measles can be a dangerous disease. The classical example of ‘Doesn’t Everybody?’ occurred when a woman who was addicted to colonic irrigations came into a therapy group. She began to talk about her adventures at the colonic-irrigation parlor and everybody listened tolerantly until someone asked ‘What’s a colonic irrigation?’ The woman seemed surprised to learn that there could be so many people in one room who didn’t take colonic irrigations. ‘Doesn’t everybody?’ Both her parents did, and most of her friendships were made at the irrigation parlour. The chief topic of conversation at her bridge club was comparing one irrigation parlor with another.

这种人生观的核心论点是：“得麻疹没关系，反正人人都得过。” 当然，这并非没关系，因为麻疹可能是一种危险的疾病。一个经典的例子就是“难道不是人人都得过吗？”：一位沉迷于灌肠的女士参加了一个治疗小组。她开始讲述自己在灌肠中心的经历，大家都很宽容地听着，直到有人问：“什么是灌肠？” 这位女士似乎很惊讶，原来在一个房间里竟然有这么多人不做灌肠。“难道不是人人都做吗？” 她的父母都做过，而且她的大部分朋友都是在灌肠中心认识的。她桥牌俱乐部的主要话题就是比较不同的灌肠中心。

The ‘Doesn’t Everybody?’ sweatshirt is a favorite at high school, especially among cheer leaders, drum majorettes, and boys on the make, and even at that age it may have sinister connotations if it is reinforced by parents at home or teachers in the classroom. It is also good for business, where it is heavily exploited by undertakers, and in a lighter way by insurance salesmen. Interestingly enough, many stock salesmen, who are almost as conservative as undertakers, are wary of it. The key word, and the one that gives it its explosive political quality, is ‘Everybody.’ Who is Everybody? For the wearers of this sweatshirt, Everybody is ‘The people I say are OK, including me, I hope.’ For this reason, they usually have two other sweatshirts that they wear on appropriate occasions. They put on ‘Doesn’t Everybody?’ when they go out among strangers. But when they are with the people they admire, they wear either ‘How’m I Doing?’ or ‘I Know Prominent People.’ They are devotees of what Sinclair Lewis made into Babbittry 5 and what Alan Harrington satirically called ‘Centralism,’ the doctrine that the safest place to be is in dead center; Harrington’s hero became such a thorough Centralist that he was able to sell an insurance policy every thirty seconds or so. 6

“难道不是每个人都这样吗？”这件卫衣在高中很受欢迎，尤其受到啦啦队员、鼓乐队指挥和那些一心想出风头的男生的喜爱。即使在那个年纪，如果家长在家或老师在课堂上强化这种观念，它也可能带有某种不祥的含义。这件卫衣在商业领域也颇受欢迎，殡葬业者会大量利用它，保险推销员也会以一种较为轻松的方式使用它。有趣的是，许多股票推销员——他们几乎和殡葬业者一样保守——却对这件卫衣心存戒备。关键在于“每个人”这个词，正是它赋予了这件卫衣爆炸性的政治意义。那么，“每个人”指的是谁呢？对于这件卫衣的穿着者来说，“每个人”指的是“我认为没问题的人，包括我自己，我希望如此”。因此，他们通常会准备另外两件卫衣，在合适的场合穿着。当他们与陌生人接触时，就会穿上这件印着“难道不是每个人都这样吗？”的卫衣。但当他们与自己崇拜的人在一起时，他们要么表现得“我做得怎么样？”，要么表现得“我认识名人”。他们是辛克莱·刘易斯所著《巴比特主义》的信徒，也是艾伦·哈灵顿讽刺地称之为“集中制”的信奉者，这种信条认为最安全的地方就是绝对的中心；哈灵顿笔下的主人公成了一个彻头彻尾的集中制信徒，以至于他每三十秒左右就能卖出一份保险单。

The wearer of this sweatshirt has, for his favorite pastime, ‘Me Too,’ and his favorite game is ‘Come To Find Out’ that actually ‘everybody’ doesn’t, as he knew all along. Thus his favorite feeling is being taken by (phony) surprise. His nickname is Creepy and his hero is someone who keeps everybody in line. In the front room he does what he thinks the OK people are doing and conspicuously avoids the not-OK ones, while in the back room he performs outlandish deeds, or even horrors. He lives in a world where he is misunderstood except by his cronies, and his script calls for him to be done in for one of his secret misdeeds. He does not protest much when the end comes, because he feels he really deserves it according to his own slogan: ‘He who breaks the rules of Everybody must suffer.’ And that is the kicker on the back of his sweatshirt. ‘He’s Different – Must Be a Kook or a Communist or Something.’

这件卫衣的穿着者最爱的消遣是“我也是”（Me Too），他最爱的游戏是“结果发现其实并非所有人都这么想”，因为他早就知道了。因此，他最喜欢的感觉就是被（假装的）惊讶吓一跳。他的绰号是“怪人”（Creepy），他的偶像是那种能让所有人守规矩的人。在前厅里，他做着他认为“正常人”会做的事，并刻意避开那些“不正常”的人；而在后厅里，他会做出一些古怪甚至恐怖的事情。他生活在一个除了他的同伙之外无人理解他的世界里，他的剧本安排他最终会因为某个秘密的恶行而被处死。当结局来临时，他并没有过多抗议，因为他觉得这是他应得的，正如他自己的口号所说：“打破‘人人平等’规则的人必须受苦。”而这正是他卫衣背面的标语：“他与众不同——一定是疯子、共产主义者或者别的什么人。”

Closely allied to the sweatshirt is the tombstone, which we shall consider in the next chapter.

与运动衫密切相关的是墓碑，我们将在下一章中讨论它。

References

参考

1 Reich, W. Character Analysis . Farrar, Straus & Company, New York, 3rd ed. 1949.

1 Reich, W. 性格分析。Farrar, Straus & Company，纽约，第 3 版，1949 年。

2 Jung, C. G. Psychological Types. Loc. cit .

2 荣格，C. G. 心理类型。同上。

3 Adler, A. op. cit .

3 Adler, A. 同上。

4 Grier, W. H. & Cobb, P. M. Black Rage . Bantam Books, New York, 1969. This work contains many examples of antiscript strivings overtaken and undermined by losing scripts.

4 Grier, W. H. & Cobb, P. M.《黑色愤怒》。纽约，Bantam Books，1969 年。这部作品包含了许多反文字斗争被失败的文字所吞噬和破坏的例子。

5 Lewis, S. Babbitt . Harcourt, Brace and World, New York, 1949.

5 Lewis, S. Babbitt. Harcourt, Brace and World, New York, 1949.

6 Harrington, A. Revelations of Dr Modesto . Alfred A. Knopf, New York, 1955.

6 哈灵顿，A.《莫德斯托博士的启示录》。纽约：阿尔弗雷德·A·克诺夫出版社，1955年。

fn1 Many psychoanalysts consider that ‘transactional games’ is merely a synonym for character defenses. This is not so. The sweatshirt is the character defense. Games belong to the open system of social psychology, and not to the closed energy system described by Freud.

fn1 许多精神分析学家认为“互动游戏”仅仅是人格防御机制的同义词。事实并非如此。运动衫是一种人格防御机制。游戏属于社会心理学的开放系统，而非弗洛伊德所描述的封闭能量系统。

#↩

CHAPTER TEN

第十章

Maturity and Death

成熟与死亡

A • Maturity

A • 成熟度

Maturity can be defined in four different ways. (1) Trial by law. A person is mature when he is mentally competent and has reached the age of twenty-one. According to Hebrew law, a boy becomes a man when he reaches the age of thirteen. (2) Trial by Parental prejudice. A person is mature when he does things my way, and immature if he does them his way. (3) Trial by initiation. A person is mature when he has passed certain tests. In primitive societies these tests are tough and traditional. In industrial countries, he gets his maturity certificate when he passes his driving test. In special cases, he may be given psychological tests and his maturity or immaturity is then certified by the psychologist. (4) Trial by living. For the script analyst, maturity is tested by external events. The tests begin when the person is about to come out of a supervised and sheltered environment and the world moves in on him on its own terms. They start in the senior year at college, the final year of apprenticeship, at promotion or parole time, at the end of the honeymoon, or whenever the first opportunity offers itself in open competition or cooperation for script failure or success.

成熟可以从四个方面来定义。(1) 法律标准。一个人心智健全且年满二十一岁即被视为成熟。根据希伯来律法，男孩在十三岁时成为男人。(2) 父母观念标准。一个人如果按照父母的方式行事，则被视为成熟；如果按照父母的方式行事，则被视为不成熟。(3) 成人礼标准。一个人通过某些考验即被视为成熟。在原始社会，这些考验既严格又传统。在工业化国家，一个人通过驾驶考试即可获得“成熟证书”。在特殊情况下，他可能需要接受心理测试，并由心理学家来证明其成熟或不成熟。(4) 生活考验。对于剧本分析家而言，成熟度是通过外部事件来检验的。当一个人即将离开受监管和保护的环境，开始面对外部世界时，考验便开始了。他们从大学最后一年、学徒生涯的最后一年、晋升或假释期间、蜜月结束时，或者任何时候，只要有机会在公开竞争或合作中，就去尝试剧本的成败。

From this point of view, the common successes and failures in life depend on parental permissions. Jeder does or does not have permission to graduate from college, complete his apprenticeship, stay married, stop drinking, get promoted or elected or paroled, stay out of the mental hospital, or get well if he goes to a psychiatrist.

从这个角度来看，人生中常见的成功和失败都取决于父母的许可。杰德能否从大学毕业、完成学徒期、维持婚姻、戒酒、升职或当选、获得假释、不进精神病院，或者去看精神科医生后能否康复，都取决于他是否获得了许可。

Through grade school and high school and the early years of college, it is possible to survive failures and even juvenile hall and reform school, especially in this country where minors are often given another chance. Nevertheless, there is a small number of suicides, 1 homicides, and addictions among adolescents, and a larger number of optional car crashes and psychoses. In less lenient countries, a failure to matriculate into college, or a criminal record, are for real, and one such mark is enough to set the individual’s course for the rest of his life. For the most part, however, early failures are rehearsals rather than final performances, and playing for keeps does not begin until the twenties.

从小学、中学到大学早期，即使遭遇失败，甚至被送进少年管教所或感化院，也并非不可能，尤其是在这个未成年人往往能获得第二次机会的国家。尽管如此，青少年自杀、他杀和吸毒的案例仍然不少，而车祸和精神病等意外事故的发生率则更高。在一些对青少年管教更为严苛的国家，未能考上大学或留下犯罪记录是无法挽回的，一次这样的污点就足以决定一个人的一生。然而，在大多数情况下，早期的失败只是预演，而非最终的结局，真正的考验要到二十多岁才会到来。

B • The Mortgage

B • 抵押贷款

In order to play for keeps, put himself to the test, and know who he is, Jeder must take on a mortgage. In this country, he is not a man until he makes a down payment on a house, goes heavily into debt in business, or mortgages his working years to bring up his children. Those who have no mortgages are regarded as carefree, beautiful, or lucky people, but not as real people. The banker’s television commercials show the great day in Jeder’s life: the day he mortgages his earnings for the next twenty or thirty years to buy a house. The day he pays off the mortgage he is out of it and ready for the old people’s home. This danger can be averted by taking on a bigger mortgage for a bigger house. In other parts of the world, he can mortgage himself for a bride. Just as the young man here, if he works hard, can become the ‘owner’ or ower of a $50,000 house, so the young man in New Guinea can become the ‘owner’ or ower of a 50,000-potato bride. If he pays that off too fast, he may be able to move up to a roomier 100,000-potato model.

为了真正投入，为了考验自己，为了认清自我，杰德必须背负房贷。在这个国家，一个人只有付清房贷、在生意上背负巨债，或者抵押自己的职业生涯来养育子女，才算得上是一个真正的男人。那些没有房贷的人会被视为无忧无虑、英俊潇洒或幸运儿，但绝不是真正的人。银行家的电视广告描绘了杰德人生中的重要时刻：他抵押未来二三十年的收入去买房。还清贷款的那一天，他就彻底摆脱了债务，准备去养老院了。这种危险可以通过背负更大的房贷去买更大的房子来避免。在世界其他地方，他甚至可以抵押自己去娶妻。就像这里的年轻人如果努力工作，就能拥有一套价值 5 万美元的房子一样，新几内亚的年轻人也能拥有一个价值 5 万个土豆的新娘。如果他还清贷款太快，或许还能升级到更宽敞的、价值 10 万个土豆的“新娘”。

Most well-organized societies, in one way or another, provide a way for young people to mortgage themselves and thus give meaning to their lives. Otherwise they might just spend their time enjoying themselves, as they do still in a few places. In that case, there is no easy way of telling the winners from the losers. With a mortgage system, the population readily divides itself. People who don’t even have enough gumption to mortgage themselves are losers (according to those who run the system). People who spend their lives paying off the mortgage, so that they can never get much ahead, are the silent majority of nonwinners. The people who hold the mortgages are the winners.

大多数组织良好的社会，都会以某种方式为年轻人提供抵押贷款的途径，从而赋予他们生活意义。否则，他们可能只会像某些地方现在这样，终日享乐。在这种情况下，就很难区分赢家和输家。而抵押贷款制度则能轻易地将人群划分开来。那些连抵押贷款的勇气都没有的人，在制度管理者眼中，就是输家。那些终其一生都在偿还抵押贷款，以至于永远无法摆脱困境的人，则是沉默的大多数，而非赢家。而那些拥有抵押贷款的人，才是真正的赢家。

People who are not interested in money-or-potato mortgages can do it another way – by becoming addicts. In that way there is a lifelong mortgage on their bodies which they can never pay off, so they are always playing for keeps.

对金钱或土豆抵押贷款不感兴趣的人还可以用另一种方式——染上毒瘾。这样一来，他们的身体就背负着终身的债务，永远无法偿还，所以他们总是孤注一掷。

C • Addictions

C • 成瘾

The simplest and most direct way to become a real loser is through crime, gambling, or drug addiction. Criminals are divided into two types: winners, who are professionals, and seldom if ever go to prison, and losers, who are following the injunction: ‘Don’t have any fun!’ The losers have what fun they can while they are at large, but then follow their scripts by spending drab years in prison. If they are released by discharge, parole, or legal technicality, they soon manage to get back in again.

成为真正失败者的最简单直接的方法就是犯罪、赌博或吸毒。罪犯分为两类：一类是成功者，他们是专业人士，很少甚至从未入狱；另一类是失败者，他们奉行着“别寻欢作乐！”的准则。失败者在逍遥法外时尽情享乐，但之后便会按照既定剧本，在监狱里度过枯燥乏味的岁月。即便他们因假释、缓刑或法律漏洞而获释，很快也会再次锒铛入狱。

Gamblers can also be winners or losers. The winners play carefully and save or invest their money. They like to quit when they are ahead. The losers play luck and hunches, and if they win by chance, get rid of their winnings as soon as they can, perhaps by following the famous slogan: ‘It may be crooked, but it’s the only game in town.’ If they have permission to be winners, they win; otherwise they are compelled to lose. What a gambling addict needs is not an analysis, which is seldom successful, of why he gambles, but permission to stop being a loser. If he gets it, he will either stop gambling, or continue and win.

赌徒既可以是赢家，也可以是输家。赢家谨慎行事，会把钱存起来或投资。他们喜欢在盈利时收手。输家则靠运气和直觉，如果侥幸赢了，他们会尽快把赢来的钱抛售出去，或许会遵循那句著名的口号：“这或许不正当，但却是唯一的选择。” 如果他们被允许成为赢家，他们就会赢；否则，他们就只能输。赌徒需要的不是分析自己赌博的原因（这种分析很少成功），而是允许自己不再输。如果他们得到了这种允许，他们要么会停止赌博，要么会继续赌博并最终获胜。

The mother’s influence is most clearly shown in certain types of drug addicts. As previously noted, these are encouraged with the slogan: ‘Heroin, shmeroin, what’s the difference as long as he loves his mother?’ What such people need is permission to stop taking drugs, which means permission to leave their mothers and strike out for themselves, and that is exactly what the highly successful Synanon movement provides. Where mother’s script injunction says ‘Don’t leave me!’ Synanon says ‘Stay here instead.’

母亲的影响在某些类型的吸毒者身上体现得最为明显。正如前文所述，他们被灌输这样一种口号：“海洛因算什么，只要他爱他妈妈，有什么区别？”这些人真正需要的是戒毒的许可，这意味着离开母亲、独立生活的许可，而这正是卓有成效的锡安农（Synanon）运动所提供的。母亲的训诫是“别离开我！”，而锡安农则说“留在这里吧。”

This also applies to alcoholics and Alcoholics Anonymous. Claude M. Steiner 2 discovered that almost all alcoholics had been analyzed, cajoled, or threatened concerning their drinking, but that none of his cases had ever been told simply: ‘Stop drinking!’ Their previous jousts with therapists were based on such slogans as: ‘Let’s analyze why you drink,’ ‘Why don’t you stop drinking!’, or ‘If you keep on drinking you’ll injure yourself.’ Each of these is quite different in effect from the simple imperative ‘Stop drinking!’ The ‘Alcoholic’ player is quite willing to spend years analyzing why he drinks or explaining regretfully how he backslid, providing that in the meantime he can keep on drinking. The threat that he will injure himself is the most naive and ineffectual of all, because that is exactly what he is trying to do, following his script injunction ‘Kill yourself!’ The threats merely add to his satisfaction by providing the gruesome details of exactly how he is bringing about his death, and by assuring him that he will be successful in fulfilling the destiny demanded by his mother. What the alcoholic needs is first permission to stop drinking, if he can take it, and then a clear and unqualified Adult contract to desist, if he can give it.

这一点也适用于酗酒者和匿名戒酒互助会。克劳德·M·施泰纳发现，几乎所有酗酒者都曾被分析、劝说或威胁过，但他的案例中，没有一个人被简单地告知：“停止饮酒！”他们之前与治疗师的争论都基于诸如“让我们分析一下你为什么喝酒”、“你为什么不停止饮酒！”或“如果你继续喝酒，你会伤害自己”之类的口号。这些口号的效果与简单的命令“停止饮酒！”截然不同。酗酒者非常愿意花费数年时间分析自己喝酒的原因，或者懊悔地解释自己是如何复吸的，只要在此期间他可以继续喝酒。他威胁要伤害自己，这是所有威胁中最天真、最无效的，因为这正是他正在做的，他按照剧本指示“去死吧！”。这些威胁只会让他更加满足，因为它们详细描述了他如何走向死亡，并让他确信自己能够成功完成母亲赋予他的使命。这个酗酒者首先需要的是停止饮酒的许可（如果他能接受的话），然后是一份清晰、无附加条件的成年人戒酒协议（如果他能签署的话）。

D • The Drama Triangle

D • 戏剧三角

During the period of maturity, the dramatic nature of the script is brought into full flower. Drama in life, as in the theater, is based on ‘switches,’ and these switches have been neatly summarized by Stephen Karpman 3 in a simple diagram he calls ‘The Drama Triangle,’ which is shown in Figure 12 . Each hero in a drama or in life (the protagonist) starts off in one of the three main roles: Rescuer, Persecutor, or Victim, with the other principal player (the antagonist) in one of the other roles. When the crisis occurs, the two players move around the triangle, thus switching roles. One of the commonest switches occurs in divorces. During the marriage, for example, the husband is the persecutor and the wife plays the part of the victim. Once the divorce complaint is filed, these roles are reversed: the wife becomes the persecutor, and the husband the victim, while his lawyer and her lawyer play the part of competing rescuers.

在成熟期，剧本的戏剧性特质得以充分展现。人生中的戏剧，如同戏剧一样，都建立在“角色转换”之上。斯蒂芬·卡普曼（Stephen Karpman）用他称之为“戏剧三角”的简单图表（如图12所示）精辟地概括了这些转换。戏剧或人生中的每个英雄（主角）最初都扮演着三个主要角色之一：拯救者、迫害者或受害者，而另一位主要角色（反派）则扮演着其他角色之一。当危机发生时，这两个角色会在三角中移动，从而互换角色。最常见的角色转换之一发生在离婚中。例如，在婚姻期间，丈夫是迫害者，妻子是受害者。一旦提起离婚诉讼，这些角色就会颠倒：妻子成为迫害者，丈夫成为受害者，而双方的律师则扮演着相互竞争的拯救者角色。

FIGURE 12

图 12

In fact, all struggles in life are struggles to move around the triangle in accordance with the demands of the script. Thus the criminal persecutes his victims; the victim then files a complaint, and becomes the plaintiff or persecutor with the criminal now the victim. If he is caught, the police also become his persecutors. He then hires a professional rescuer, a lawyer, who persecutes the policeman. In an interrupted rape, there is a race around the triangle. The criminal who is persecuting the girl victim becomes the victim of the rescuing policeman. The criminal’s lawyer tries to rescue him by persecuting the girl victim and the policeman as well. Fairy tales, treated as dramas, show exactly this feature. Little Red Riding Hood, for example, is a victim of the persecuting wolf until the hunter rescues her, when she suddenly becomes the persecutor, putting stones in the belly of the now victimized wolf.

事实上，人生中的所有挣扎都是围绕着三角关系展开的，一切都按照剧本的设定进行。例如，罪犯迫害受害者；受害者提起诉讼，自己则成为原告或原告，而罪犯则成了受害者。如果罪犯被抓，警察也成了他的原告。之后，他会聘请一位专业的律师来“拯救”他，而律师反过来又会“迫害”警察。在强奸案中，也存在着围绕三角关系的拉锯战。原本迫害女孩的罪犯，反而成了前来营救的警察的受害者。罪犯的律师为了替他脱罪，反过来又会“迫害”女孩和警察。童话故事，如果被当作戏剧来演绎，恰恰展现了这种特点。例如，小红帽原本是狼的受害者，直到猎人救了她，她才突然变成了“迫害者”，往狼肚子里塞石头。

Minor roles in script dramas are the Connection and the Patsy, who are available to all three of the main characters. The Connection is the person who supplies what is needed for the switch, usually for a price, and is fully aware of his role: the man who sells liquor, drugs, influence, or guns. A gun, for example, often called an ‘equalizer,’ turns a coward (victim) into a braggart (persecutor), or switches the defensive into the offensive. The Patsy is there to be conned into preventing the switch, or speeding it up. The classical Patsies are juries, and the most poignant are mothers who pay to keep their sons out of jail. Sometimes the Patsy is passive and merely acts as bait for the switch, like Little Red Riding Hood’s grandmother. It should be noted that the switch referred to here is the same switch that is included in the formula for games given in Chapter Two .

在剧本戏剧中，次要角色包括“中间人”和“替罪羊”，他们可供三位主角使用。“中间人”负责提供“交换”所需的资源，通常需要付费，并且完全清楚自己的角色：他/她可能贩卖酒水、毒品、影响力或枪支。例如，枪支常被称为“平衡器”，它可以将懦夫（受害者）变成吹牛大王（迫害者），或者将防守方转变为进攻方。“替罪羊”的作用是被欺骗，从而阻止或加速“交换”。经典的“替罪羊”是陪审团成员，其中最令人心酸的是那些花钱让儿子免于牢狱之灾的母亲。有时，“替罪羊”是被动的，仅仅充当“交换”的诱饵，就像小红帽的奶奶一样。需要注意的是，这里提到的“交换”与第二章中提到的博弈公式中的“交换”是同一个。

Karpman has many interesting variables in his fully developed theory, besides role switches. These include space switches (private-public, open-closed, near-far) which precede, cause, or follow role switches, and script velocity (number of role switches in a given unit of time). Thus, his thinking reaches far beyond the original roles as described for the game of ‘Alcoholic,’ 4 and brings fascinating insights into numerous aspects of life, psychotherapy, and the theater.

卡普曼在其完整的理论中除了角色转换之外，还包含许多有趣的变量。这些变量包括空间转换（私人-公共、开放-封闭、近-远），它们先于、导致或继发于角色转换；以及脚本速度（单位时间内角色转换的次数）。因此，他的思考远远超越了最初在“酗酒者”游戏中描述的角色，并为生活、心理治疗和戏剧的诸多方面带来了引人入胜的见解。

E • Life Expectancy

E • 预期寿命

A recent study of causes of death concluded that many people die when they are ready to, and that coronary thromboses, for example, can be brought about almost by an act of will. 5 It is certainly true that most people have in their life plans a certain life span. The key question here is: ‘How long are you going to live?’ Usually the life span has an element of competition. The Child of a man whose father died at the age of forty, for example, may not have permission to live longer than his father did, and will exist in a state of vague apprehension throughout most of his fourth decade. He becomes more and more aware that he fully expects to die before he is forty, and the most trying period will be the year between his thirty-ninth and fortieth birthdays, after which his way of living may change in one of four ways: (1) He settles down to a more relaxed way of life because he has passed the dangerous age and survived it. (2) He goes into a state of depression because by surviving he has disobeyed his script injunction and therefore loses his mother’s love. (3) He begins to live a more hectic life because now he is living on borrowed time and death can strike at any moment. (4) He withdraws because his reprieve is conditional and will be withdrawn if he is caught enjoying himself. It is evident that (1) has permission to live longer than his father if he can make it, (2) does not have permission, (3) has permission to get away with what he can, and (4) has permission to make deals. In fact, (4) is an excellent example of the one-sided contract with God previously referred to, since (4), without consulting God, thinks he knows how to placate Him.

最近一项关于死因的研究得出结论：许多人会在自己准备好的时候死去，例如，冠状动脉血栓几乎可以由意志力促成。 5 大多数人的人生规划中都设定了一定的寿命，这的确不假。关键问题是：“你打算活多久？” 通常，寿命规划中存在着竞争的因素。例如，如果一个人的父亲在四十岁去世，那么他的孩子可能没有被允许活得比父亲更久，并且在四十岁左右的大部分时间里，他都会生活在一种模糊的焦虑之中。他越来越意识到自己很可能在四十岁之前死去，而最难熬的时期将是他三十九岁到四十岁之间的那一年，之后他的生活方式可能会发生以下四种变化之一：（1）他安定下来，过上更加轻松的生活，因为他已经度过了危险的年龄并活了下来。 (2) 他陷入抑郁，因为他活了下来，违背了剧本的禁令，因此失去了母亲的爱。(3) 他开始过着更加忙碌的生活，因为他现在是在苟延残喘，死亡随时可能降临。(4) 他退缩了，因为他的宽恕是有条件的，如果他被发现寻欢作乐，宽恕就会被收回。显然，(1) 如果能活下来，他有权比他父亲活得更久；(2) 没有这个权利；(3) 可以逍遥法外；(4) 可以做他能做的事。事实上，(4) 正是之前提到的与上帝单方面签订的契约的绝佳例证，因为 (4) 在没有咨询上帝的情况下，就认为自己知道如何取悦上帝。

A more competitive person, however, will determine to live longer than his father did and will probably succeed in doing so. He then has to pass the hazard of living longer than his mother did, which is more difficult, since few men care to compete with their own mothers. Similarly, a daughter will competitively outlive her mother, but if her father died at an older age, she may find it difficult to live longer than he did. At any rate, a person who lives longer than both his parents did often feels uneasy in his later years. The next hurdle may be to outlive his script hero. For example, a physician came for treatment at the age of thirty-seven because his father had died when he was thirty-seven and he was afraid of dying. He withdrew from treatment shortly after his thirty-eighth birthday, because then he was ‘safe.’ By that time he had become more competitive, and his goal now was to live to be seventy-one. For a long time he was unable to account for this choice of date. Since his hero was Sir William Osler, in whose footsteps he wanted to follow, the therapist took the trouble to find out that Sir William had died at the age of seventy. The patient had read several biographies of his hero, and now recollected that many years previously he had determined to outlive him.

然而，更具竞争心的人会立志比父亲活得更久，而且很可能成功。接下来，他必须克服比母亲活得更久的风险，这更加困难，因为很少有男人愿意与自己的母亲竞争。同样，女儿也会在竞争中力争比母亲活得更久，但如果父亲去世时年纪较大，她可能就很难比父亲活得更久。无论如何，比父母都活得更久的人，晚年往往会感到不安。下一个挑战可能是比他心目中的英雄活得更久。例如，一位医生37岁时前来就诊，因为他的父亲在他37岁时去世，他害怕死亡。38岁生日后不久，他就停止了治疗，因为他觉得那时自己“安全”了。那时，他变得更加好胜，他的目标是活到71岁。很长一段时间，他都无法解释自己为什么会选择这个日期。由于他的偶像是威廉·奥斯勒爵士，他想追随奥斯勒爵士的脚步，治疗师特意查明奥斯勒爵士享年七十岁。这位病人读过几本奥斯勒爵士的传记，现在想起多年前他曾下定决心要比奥斯勒爵士活得更久。

The treatment of such life-span neuroses is very simple. The therapist merely has to give the patient permission to live longer than his father. Psychoanalysis may be successful in such cases not primarily because of the conflicts which are resolved, but merely because the analytic situation offers protection during the critical year. Indeed, there is no conflict to resolve, since it is not pathological for the Child to feel bad about living longer than his father. That is merely a special example of ‘survival neurosis’ which occurs to some degree in everyone who survives where others die. This is one of the principal influences in ‘war neuroses,’ and ‘Hiroshima neuroses,’ and ‘concentration-camp neuroses.’ The survivors almost always feel guilty because they have survived while others have died ‘in their place.’ 6 This indeed is what makes ‘the person who has actually seen someone else killed’ different from other human beings. The Child will not ‘recover’ or ‘be cured’ of this feeling. The best that can be done is to put the feeling under Adult control so that the person can carry on a normal life and get permission to enjoy himself to some extent.

治疗这种寿命神经症非常简单。治疗师只需允许患者比他的父亲活得更久。精神分析在这种情况下之所以有效，主要并非因为解决了冲突，而是因为分析环境在关键的一年中提供了保护。事实上，根本不存在需要解决的冲突，因为孩子因为比父亲活得更久而感到难过并非病态。这只是“生存神经症”的一个特殊例子，这种神经症在某种程度上存在于所有在他人死亡中幸存下来的人身上。这是“战争神经症”、“广岛神经症”和“集中营神经症”的主要影响因素之一。幸存者几乎总是感到内疚，因为他们活了下来，而其他人却“代替他们”死去。这正是“亲眼目睹他人死亡的人”与其他人不同的原因。孩子无法“恢复”或“治愈”这种感觉。最好的办法是让成年人控制这种感觉，这样这个人就可以继续正常的生活，并在一定程度上获得享受生活的权利。

F • Old Age

F • 老年

Vitality in old age depends on three factors: (1) constitutional robustness; (2) physical health; (3) type of script. The onset of old age is determined by the same three factors. Thus some people are vital at eighty and others start vegetating at forty. Constitutional robustness is a force majeure , that is, it cannot be changed by Parental programing. Physical disability is sometimes a force majeure , and sometimes a script payoff. In the ‘Cripple’ Script it is both. The crippling itself may occur because of unavoidable physical illness, but it is welcomed because it is part of the script and fulfills mother’s injunction to end up disabled. This occurs occasionally in cases of poliomyelitis in young adults, where the man in the wheel chair says: ‘When I knew I had polio I almost welcomed it, as though I had been waiting for something like that.’ If his script called for him to be a cripple, and Nature did not help him out, he might have crashed a car. Nature’s solution is simpler to deal with.

老年活力取决于三个因素：(1) 体质强健；(2) 身体健康；(3) 剧本类型。衰老的开始也由这三个因素决定。因此，有些人八十岁依然活力充沛，而有些人四十岁就开始衰老。体质强健是一种不可抗力，也就是说，它无法通过父母的设定来改变。身体残疾有时是一种不可抗力，有时则是剧本的回报。在“残疾人”剧本中，两者兼而有之。残疾本身可能是由于不可避免的疾病造成的，但它却被欣然接受，因为它是剧本的一部分，满足了母亲让他最终成为残疾人的意愿。这种情况偶尔会在年轻成年人患上小儿麻痹症的案例中出现，坐在轮椅上的病人会说：“当我知道自己得了小儿麻痹症时，我几乎是欣然接受的，仿佛我一直在等待这样的事情发生。”如果他的剧本要求他成为一个残疾人，而大自然又没有帮助他，他可能早就出车祸了。大自然的解决方案更容易应对。

Older people may similarly welcome a stroke or a coronary occlusion, but for a different reason: not because it is part of the script, but because it relieves them of the compulsion to carry on with their script strivings. For the Child in them, these catastrophes become ‘Wooden Leg’ or ‘Wooden Heart,’ so that they can say to the Parent in their heads: ‘Even you can’t expect a man with a Wooden Leg or a Wooden Heart to carry on your witch’s curse.’ Faced with a blood clot in Jeder’s brain or heart, only the most ruthless parent does not concede defeat.

老年人或许也会欣然接受中风或冠状动脉阻塞，但原因不同：并非因为这是命运的安排，而是因为这让他们摆脱了继续履行既定人生使命的束缚。对他们内心深处的孩童而言，这些灾难变成了“木腿”或“木心”，这样他们就可以对内心深处的父母说：“即使是你，也不能指望一个木腿或木心的人继续执行你那巫婆的诅咒。”面对杰德大脑或心脏中的血栓，只有最冷酷无情的父母才会拒绝认输。

If a disability occurs early in life, it may fit very well into mother’s script, or may throw it off completely. If it fits, the child will be raised as a professional cripple, sometimes with the help of outside organizations devoted to helping Crippled Children (as long as they stay crippled) or Mentally Retarded Children (as long as they stay mentally retarded). (The drag is due to the fact that the government subsidy usually stops if the child recovers.) In such cases, the mother learns to ‘face it,’ and teaches the child to do likewise. If it does not fit the mother’s script, however, she does not learn to face it. She keeps trying, and the child learns to do likewise, so that he ends up as a one-legged jitterbug, a clubfooted broad-jumper, or a brain-damaged orthopedic specialist (all these examples exist or have existed in real life). The Crippled Children’s organization and the Mentally Retarded organization pitch in here, too, and are delighted if one of their protégés makes it (with outside help). If the mother’s script does not call for a physically or mentally disabled child, and the disability is so severe that it is necessarily permanent, then her life becomes a script-frustrated tragedy.
