If her script does call for a disabled child, and the disability is borderline, and possibly remediable, then the child’s life becomes an unnecessary, script-inflicted tragedy.

如果孩子在幼年时期就患有残疾，这可能完全符合母亲的预期，也可能彻底颠覆她的计划。如果符合预期，孩子会被培养成一个“职业残疾人”，有时会得到专门帮助残疾儿童（只要他们保持残疾状态）或智力障碍儿童（只要他们保持智力障碍状态）的外部机构的帮助。（令人沮丧的是，如果孩子康复，政府补贴通常会停止。）在这种情况下，母亲会学会“面对现实”，并教导孩子也这样做。然而，如果孩子不符合母亲的预期，她就不会学会面对现实。她会继续尝试，孩子也会学会这样做，最终导致孩子成为一个独腿的摇摆舞者、一个患有先天性马蹄内翻的跳远运动员，或者一个脑损伤的骨科专家（所有这些例子在现实生活中都存在或曾经存在过）。残疾儿童组织和智障儿童组织也会参与其中，如果他们的受助者（在外界帮助下）成功，他们会非常高兴。如果母亲的剧本中没有要求生一个身患残疾或智力障碍的孩子，而且孩子的残疾程度严重到必然是永久性的，那么她的人生就成了一场因剧本限制而受挫的悲剧。如果她的剧本中确实要求生一个残疾的孩子，而且孩子的残疾程度处于临界状态，或许可以治愈，那么孩子的人生就成了一场不必要的、由剧本强加的悲剧。

Now to return to old age. Even people with robust constitutions and no physical disabilities (or only minor or hypochondriacal ones) can begin to vegetate at an early age if they have ‘Open-Ended’ Scripts. These are commonly people living on pensions. The Parental precept is: ‘Work hard, and don’t take any chances,’ and the payoff is ‘After that, give up.’ Once Jeder has put in his twenty or thirty years, and Santa Claus has come and given him his retirement banquet and gold watch, he doesn’t know what to do. He is accustomed to following his script directives, but now they are exhausted, and he has no further programing in his head. Therefore he is content to sit and wait until something turns up: Death, for instance.

现在回到老年话题。即使是体质强健、没有身体残疾（或只有轻微残疾或疑病症）的人，如果被灌输了“开放式”的人生剧本，也可能在很年轻的时候就开始变得萎靡不振。这些人通常是靠养老金生活的人。父母的教诲是：“努力工作，不要冒险”，而回报则是“之后就放弃”。当杰德工作了二三十年，圣诞老人送来了退休晚宴和金表之后，他就不知道该做什么了。他习惯于按照剧本的指示行事，但现在这些指示已经失效，他的大脑里也没有新的程序了。因此，他满足于坐着等待，直到某种事情发生：比如死亡。

This raises an interesting question. What do you do after Santa Claus comes? With an ‘Until’ Script, he comes down the chimney and brings a Freedom Certificate. Jeder has fulfilled the requirements of his script, is freed of the curse by the antiscript, and is now at liberty to do what he always wanted to do since he was a little boy. But going his own way is full of dangers, as many Greek myths attest. While he is free of his witch parent, he is also unprotected, and can easily come to grief. This is shown in fairy tales as well. A curse gives protection as well as trial and tribulation. The same witch that laid on the curse sees that the victim continues to live while he is under it. Thus, Sleeping Beauty was protected by the briar forest for a hundred years. But the moment she woke up, and could tell the witch to buzz off, her troubles began. A handy situation is to have a double script: an ‘Until’ Script from one parent and an ‘After’ Script from the other. In the commonest case this reads ‘You can’t be free until you have raised three children’ (from mother), and ‘After you are free you will become creative’ (from father). Thus in the first half of her life Zoe is controlled and protected by her mother and in the second half by her father. In the case of a man, the double-script directive may be the same as above, but the control and protection are reversed: Father during the first phase and Mother during the second.

这引出了一个有趣的问题：圣诞老人来过之后，你该怎么办？他带着一份“直到”的剧本，从烟囱里下来，带来了一张自由证书。杰德完成了剧本的要求，被反剧本解除了诅咒，现在可以自由地去做他从小就一直想做的事情了。但是，正如许多希腊神话所证明的那样，走自己的路充满了危险。虽然他摆脱了女巫父母的控制，但也失去了保护，很容易遭遇不幸。童话故事中也有类似的描写。诅咒既能带来保护，也能带来考验和磨难。施加诅咒的女巫会确保受害者在诅咒期间继续活着。因此，睡美人被荆棘森林保护了一百年。但是，当她醒来，能够让女巫滚开的那一刻，她的麻烦就开始了。一个巧妙的例子是父母双方都持有双重指令：一方发出“直到”指令，另一方发出“之后”指令。最常见的情况是，母亲说“你只有养育三个孩子才能获得自由”，父亲说“获得自由后你才能变得有创造力”。因此，佐伊人生的前半段受到母亲的控制和保护，后半段则受到父亲的控制和保护。如果是男性，双重指令可能与上述相同，但控制和保护的角色却相反：前半段由父亲主导，后半段由母亲主导。

The vegetating aged are divided into three classes, and in this country the insignia are financial. Those with losers’ scripts live alone in rooming houses or rundown hotels, and are called old men and old women. Those with nonwinning scripts own and live in small houses where they are free to develop their idiosyncrasies and eccentricities, so that they are known as old characters. Those with winning scripts live in retirement homes run by financial promoters, and are called Senior Citizens, or Mr and Mrs Taxpayer, which is how they sign their Letters to the Editor.

那些步履蹒跚的老年人被分为三类，在这个国家，他们的标志是经济状况。那些剧本落选的人独自住在廉价旅馆或破旧的旅馆里，被称为老头老太太。那些剧本未中奖的人拥有并居住在小房子里，在那里他们可以自由地发展自己的怪癖和古怪习惯，因此被称为老顽固。那些剧本中奖的人住在由金融推广者经营的养老院里，被称为老年人，或者纳税人先生和太太，这也是他们给编辑写信时署名的方式。

The cure for the scriptless aged is permission, but they seldom use it. There are thousands of older men living in small rooms in every large city, each of them wishing there was someone to cook for him, talk to him, and listen to him. At the same time, there are thousands of older women living under the same circumstances, wishing they had someone to cook for, talk to, and listen to. Even if the twain do happen to meet, they rarely take advantage of it, each preferring to remain in his or her familiar drab surroundings hunched over a glass or a TV set, or sitting with folded hands, waiting for a riskless, sinless death. Those were mother’s directives when they were little, and these are the directives they are following seventy or eighty years later. They never took chances before, beyond a small bet at the racetrack or the stadium, so why should they jeopardize everything now? The script has vanished by its own fulfillment, but the old slogan lingers on, and when death comes they will greet him gladly. And on the front of the tombstone they will carve: ‘Gone to rest with his forebears,’ and on the back it will say: ‘I lived a good life, and never took any chances.’

治愈那些没有人生剧本的老人的良方是许可，但他们很少使用。每个大城市里都有成千上万的老人住在狭小的房间里，他们都渴望有人为他们做饭、与他们交谈、倾听他们的心声。与此同时，也有成千上万的老人生活在同样的境况下，渴望有人为他们做饭、与他们交谈、倾听他们的心声。即便两人真的相遇，他们也很少会珍惜，而是各自待在熟悉的单调环境中，弓着身子对着酒杯或电视机，或者双手合十，静静地等待着无风险、无罪的死亡。那是他们小时候母亲的嘱咐，七八十年后的今天，他们依然遵循着这些嘱咐。他们以前从未冒险，除了在赛马场或体育场小赌一把，所以现在为什么要冒险呢？剧本已经随着时间的流逝而消失，但那句古老的格言却依然萦绕，当死亡来临时，他们会欣然迎接。墓碑正面将刻上：“与先祖同眠”，背面将刻上：“我一生安息，从未冒险。”

They say that in the next century, children will be grown in bottles, according to specifications laid down by the state and the parents, and there they will be genetically programed. But everybody is already raised in a bottle according to specifications laid down by the state and his parents, and there he is script-programed. Script-programing is easier to shake off than genetic programing, but few people exercise the privilege. For the ones who do, there can be a more inspiring tombstone. Nearly all pious epitaphs, translated into Martian, come out ‘Raised in a bottle, and stayed there, too.’ And so they stand, row after row of crosses and other symbols in the graveyard, all with the same motto. Only here and there is a surprise: ‘Raised in a bottle – but I jumped out.’ Many people refuse to do that, even when there is no cork.

他们说，在下一个世纪，孩子们将在瓶子里长大，按照国家和父母制定的规范，在那里他们的基因将被预先设定。但事实上，每个人现在都已经在瓶子里长大，按照国家和父母制定的规范，在那里他们的行为已被预先设定。摆脱预先设定的程序比摆脱基因程序更容易，但很少有人会行使这项权利。对于那些选择这样做的人来说，他们的墓碑或许会更加鼓舞人心。几乎所有虔诚的墓志铭，翻译成火星语，都是“瓶中长大，并一直留在那里”。于是，它们像一排排十字架和其他符号一样，矗立在墓地里，都刻着同样的格言。只有偶尔会出现一些令人惊讶的句子：“瓶中长大——但我跳了出来。”许多人拒绝这样做，即使瓶子里没有塞子。

G • The Death Scene

G • 死亡场景

Death is not an act, nor even an event, for the one who dies. It is both for those who survive. What it can be, and should be, is a transaction. The physical horror of the Nazi death camps was compounded by the psychological horror, the prevention of dignity, self-assertion, or self-expression in the gas chamber. There was no brave blindfold and cigarette, no defiance, no famous last words: in sum, no death transaction. There were transactional stimuli from the dying, but no response from the killers. Thus, force majeure takes from the script its most poignant moment, the deathbed scene, and in one sense the whole human purpose of life is to set up that scene.

对逝者而言，死亡并非一种行为，甚至算不上一个事件。但对幸存者而言，两者皆是。死亡可以，也应该是一种交易。纳粹死亡集中营的肉体恐怖与心理恐怖交织在一起，在毒气室里，尊严、自我主张和自我表达都被剥夺。没有勇敢的蒙眼和香烟，没有反抗，没有著名的遗言：总之，死亡并非交易。临终者身上有交易性的刺激，但刽子手却毫无反应。因此，不可抗力夺走了剧本中最令人心碎的时刻——临终场景，从某种意义上说，人生的全部意义就在于促成这一场景的发生。

In script analysis, this is brought out by the question: ‘Who will be there at your deathbed, and what will your last words be?’ An added question is: ‘What will their last words be?’ The answer to the first query is usually some version of ‘I showed them’ – ‘them’ being the parents, especially mother in the case of a man and father in the case of a woman. The implication is either ‘I showed them I did what they wanted me to,’ or ‘I showed them I didn’t have to do what they wanted me to.’

在剧本分析中，这个问题引出了另一个问题：“谁会陪在你临终之际？你的遗言是什么？” 另一个问题是：“他们的遗言是什么？” 第一个问题的答案通常是“我让他们看到了”——这里的“他们”指的是父母，如果是男性，则尤其指母亲；如果是女性，则指父亲。其隐含的意义要么是“我让他们看到了我做了他们想让我做的事”，要么是“我让他们看到了我不必做他们想让我做的事”。

The answer to this question is, in effect, a summary of Jeder’s life goal, and can be used by the therapist as a powerful instrument in breaking up the games and getting Jeder out of his script:

这个问题的答案实际上是对杰德人生目标的总结，治疗师可以利用这个答案作为强有力的工具，打破杰德的游戏规则，让他摆脱自己的剧本：

‘So your whole life boils down to showing them you were right to feel hurt, frightened, angry, inadequate, or guilty. Very well. Then that will be your greatest accomplishment – if you want to keep it that way. But maybe you would like to find a more worthwhile purpose in living.’

“所以你的人生归根结底就是为了向他们证明，你感到受伤、害怕、愤怒、自卑或内疚都是理所当然的。很好。那么，如果你想继续这样下去，这将会是你最大的成就。但或许你应该找到更有意义的人生目标。”

The deathbed scene may be part of the hidden, or script contract in marriage. The husband or wife may have a very clear image of the other partner dying first. In such cases, the spouse often has the complementary script, and is obligingly planning to do so. Thus, they get along well and pass contented years together. But if they each have the image of the other dying first, so that the scripts are crossed in this respect, those years will be contentious instead of contented, even though the scripts are complementary in other ways, as they must be for the marriage to take place. The difficulties will come out most clearly when one or the other is ill or in pain. A common script based on the death scene is found in the marriage of a younger woman to an older man. Even if the cynics say she marries him for his bread, the script scene is equally important, and she will always be at his side in time of danger, on the good side to take care of him, but also so as not to miss the final payoff transaction. If he is intuitively aware of this, the marriage may have only a very narrow margin of safety, since it is not easy to get along with someone who is waiting for you to die. The same situation, with the double payoff, may arise in the marriage of a younger man to an older woman, although these are less common. It is evident that the original script protocol has father in place of the aging husband, or mother in place of the aging wife.

临终场景可能是婚姻中某种隐秘的、或称“剧本契约”的一部分。夫妻双方可能都清楚地预想着对方会先离世。在这种情况下，配偶往往也拥有与之互补的剧本，并会顺从地做好相应的安排。因此，他们相处融洽，共同度过幸福的岁月。但如果双方都预想着对方会先离世，导致剧本在这方面出现冲突，那么即使剧本在其他方面互补（正如婚姻维系所必需的那样），这些岁月也将充满争吵而非幸福。当一方生病或遭受痛苦时，这些矛盾会最为明显。基于临终场景的常见剧本体现在年轻女子嫁给年长男子的婚姻中。即使有人愤世嫉俗地认为她是为了养活自己才嫁给他，但这个剧本场景同样重要。她会在丈夫危难之际始终陪伴在他身边，尽心尽力地照顾他，同时也为了不错过最终的“回报”。如果他本能地意识到这一点，那么这段婚姻的安全余地可能非常有限，因为很难与一个盼着你死的人相处。同样的情况，加上双重的利益冲突，也可能出现在年轻男子与年长女子的婚姻中，尽管这种情况并不常见。显然，最初的剧本中，年迈的丈夫是由父亲扮演，年迈的妻子是由母亲扮演。

H • The Gallows Laugh

H • 绞刑架上的笑声

Actual death scenes result from either force majeure or script directives. The untimely death due to ineluctable forces of fate – disease or violence in time of peace or war – is always a stark and simple tragedy. Scripty deaths are usually marked by the gallows smile or gallows humor. The man who dies with a smile on his face or a joke on his lips is dying the death his script calls for, and the smile or joke says: ‘Well, mother, I’m now following your instruction, ha ha. I hope you’re happy.’ The criminals of London in the eighteenth century were true disciples of gallows humor, often entertaining the admiring crowd with a final epigram as the trap was sprung, 7 because their deaths followed their mothers’ injunction: ‘You’ll end on the gallows as your father did, my boy!’ The last words of many famous men were also jokes because they were likewise at peace with their mothers: ‘You’ll die famous, son.’ Deaths due to human force majeure are not accompanied by such levity, because they may be in direct contradiction to mother’s injunction: ‘Live long!’ or ‘Die happy!’ There are no stories of gallows humor in German concentration camps (as far as I know). There is also a special injunction ‘Enjoy death as you enjoyed life!’ which permits a deathbed joke even if death comes sooner than mother could tolerate. Such a joke is, in fact, an attempt to ease the mother’s bereavement.

实际的死亡场景要么是不可抗力造成的，要么是剧本要求的。因命运不可抗拒的力量——和平时期或战争时期的疾病或暴力——导致的过早死亡，总是一种残酷而简单的悲剧。剧本安排的死亡通常带有黑色幽默或苦涩的微笑。一个面带微笑或嘴里说着笑话死去的人，正是按照剧本的设定死去，而这微笑或笑话仿佛在说：“好吧，老妈，我现在正在遵照您的指示行事，哈哈。” “我希望你快乐。”十八世纪伦敦的罪犯们是绞刑架下幽默的忠实信徒，他们常常在绞刑架落下时，用一句最后的俏皮话来逗乐围观的人群，因为他们的死都遵循了母亲的遗言：“孩子，你会像你父亲一样死在绞刑架上！”许多名人的遗言也都是玩笑，因为他们同样与母亲心意相通：“儿子，你会名垂青史。”因人为不可抗力而死的人则不会有这种轻松的临终关怀，因为这可能与母亲的遗言直接相悖：“长寿！”或“死得其所！”据我所知，德国集中营里没有关于绞刑架下幽默的故事。此外，还有一条特殊的遗言：“像享受生活一样享受死亡！”即使死亡来得比母亲所能承受的还要早，这条遗言也允许人们在临终前开个玩笑。这样的玩笑实际上是为了减轻母亲的丧子之痛。

All this means that in most cases the witch parent plans Jeder’s life span and the manner of his death, and barring internal or external upheavals, he will, by his own decision, carry out the parental decree.

这一切都意味着，在大多数情况下，巫婆父母会计划杰德的寿命和死亡方式，除非发生内部或外部动荡，否则杰德会按照自己的意愿执行父母的命令。

I • The Posthumous Scene

I • 死后场景

In success scripts, this is usually visualized with good reality sense. Jeder has built up a large organization, or left a large body of work, or a lot of children and grandchildren, and he knows that his life production will survive him and that those connected with it will see him to his grave.

在成功故事中，这通常会以高度现实感的方式呈现出来。杰德建立了一个庞大的组织，或者留下了大量的成就，或者拥有众多的子孙后代，他知道他毕生的事业将超越他的年龄，那些与他相关的人将陪伴他走到生命的尽头。

Those with tragic scripts, however, have a pathetic fallacy about what will happen after their deaths. The romantic suicide, for example, says: ‘They’ll be sorry,’ and imagines a sad, sentimental funeral which may or may not come to pass. The angry suicide says: ‘I’ll fix them,’ and may be equally misguided, since they may be glad to have him out of the way. ‘I’ll show them’ may fail by not getting his name in the papers much beyond the obituary file. On the other hand, the futility or frustration suicide, who tries to kill himself unobtrusively with the fantasy that nobody will really notice or care, may make the front-page headlines due to some unforeseen complication. Even the man who kills himself so his wife can have the insurance money may be foiled if he has neglected to read his policy carefully.

然而，那些抱有悲剧色彩的自杀者，往往对死后会发生什么抱有一种移情谬误。例如，浪漫的自杀者会想：“他们会后悔的”，并想象着一场悲伤感伤的葬礼，而这葬礼或许会发生，或许不会。愤怒的自杀者会想：“我要让他们好看”，但这种想法也可能同样错误，因为他们或许会很高兴他终于解脱。“我要让他们看看”的计划可能会失败，因为他的名字可能只会出现在讣告中，而不会在报纸上留下什么痕迹。另一方面，那些因徒劳或挫败感而自杀的人，试图悄无声息地结束自己的生命，幻想着没有人会注意到或在意，但最终却可能因为一些意想不到的并发症而登上头版头条。即使是那些为了让妻子获得保险金而自杀的人，如果他没有仔细阅读保单，也可能功亏一篑。

In general, the consequences of killing oneself are no more predictable than the consequences of killing someone else. Except for soldiers and gangsters, death, either suicide or homicide, is a poor way to try to solve life’s problems. Certainly, prospective suicides should be firmly told the two inviolable rules of death: (1) No parent is allowed to die until all of the children are over eighteen. (2) No child is allowed to die while either of his parents is still living.

一般来说，自杀的后果与杀人的后果一样难以预料。除了士兵和黑帮分子之外，无论是自杀还是他杀，死亡都不是解决人生问题的良方。当然，应该让那些有自杀倾向的人牢记两条不可违背的死亡法则：（1）父母双方都不得在所有子女年满十八岁之前去世。（2）子女不得在父母双方中任何一方在世时去世。

The cases of people who have no minor children and no living parent have to be considered on their individual merits, but every patient who is accepted for treatment must make a firm commitment not to violate either of the two rules, if one or both apply. A similar commitment required of certain patients is that they will never use for improper purposes (including suicidal attempts) any medications prescribed by the therapist.

对于没有未成年子女且父母双亡的患者，其个案需根据具体情况而定。但所有接受治疗的患者都必须郑重承诺，如果符合上述两项规定中的一项或两项，则不得违反任何一项。某些患者还需承诺，绝不会将治疗师开具的任何药物用于不正当用途（包括自杀）。

J • The Tombstone

J • 墓碑

The tombstone, like the sweatshirt, has two sides. The questions here are: ‘What will they put on your tombstone?’ and ‘What will you put on your tombstone?’ A typical answer is: ‘They’ll say “She was a good girl,” and I’ll say: “I tried hard but I didn’t make it.”’ Once more, ‘they’ usually means the parents, or parental people. ‘Their’ epitaph is the antiscript, while the patient himself writes his script injunction on his tombstone – in the case above: ‘Try hard but be sure not to make it.’ Thus the tombstone speaks nothing but good of the dead, for one side says that he fulfilled the precepts of his antiscript, while the other indicates that he was also an obedient child who followed his mother’s script instructions, however encouraging or discouraging they might have been.

墓碑就像卫衣一样，有两面。这里的问题是：“他们会在你的墓碑上刻什么？”和“你会在你的墓碑上刻什么？”一个典型的答案是：“他们会说‘她是个好女孩’，我会说：‘我努力过，但我没能成功。’”这里的“他们”通常指的是父母或监护人。“他们”的墓志铭是反遗嘱，而病人自己则在墓碑上写下他自己的遗嘱——在上面的例子中是：“努力过，但一定要成功。”因此，墓碑上只记载着死者的美好，因为一面写着他履行了反遗嘱的教诲，而另一面则表明他也是一个听话的孩子，遵循了母亲的遗嘱指示，无论这些指示是鼓励还是劝阻。

If the patient tries to avoid reading his tombstone by saying there won’t be one, that answer has its own meaning. Whoever cops out on death is also copping out on life. But the therapist should then insist on getting the two epitaphs with the question: ‘What would be on it if there was one?’ or ‘Here you’ve got to have one.’

如果病人试图通过说“不会有墓碑”来回避阅读自己的墓志铭，这种说法本身就蕴含着意义。逃避死亡的人，也就等于逃避了生命。但治疗师应该坚持要读到这两段墓志铭，并提出这样的问题：“如果有墓志铭，上面会写些什么？”或者“你必须得有一段。”

K • The Testament

K • 遗嘱

Whatever the person’s fantasies about what will happen after his death, his will or his posthumous papers offer the last chance for a payoff. His whole life may have been based on a falsehood or a concealed treasure which is only revealed as a triumph after his death – a trick which he plays on posterity. There are many historical examples of this: hidden talents which only come to light when the manuscript or the canvases are found hidden in a closet, or works out of character which are found concealed among the papers. Hidden wealth and hidden poverty are commonly revealed during the probate of wills. Wills are also favorite vehicles for switch tricks. The commonest has already been mentioned: mother leaves the bulk of her property to the ‘faithless’ daughter and cuts the devoted one off with a pittance. Sometimes bigamy only comes to light after the will is read. The question here is: ‘What is going to be the most important item in your will? What is going to be the biggest surprise for those you leave behind after you die?’

无论一个人对死后会发生什么抱有怎样的幻想，他的遗嘱或遗物都提供了最后一次机会来兑现承诺。他的一生或许都建立在谎言或隐藏的宝藏之上，而这些宝藏只有在他死后才会以胜利者的姿态出现——这是他与后人开的一个玩笑。历史上有很多这样的例子：隐藏的才华只有在手稿或画作被发现时才会重见天日，或者与他个人风格不符的作品在遗物中被发现。隐藏的财富和贫困通常会在遗嘱认证过程中被揭露。遗嘱也是玩弄权术的常用工具。最常见的例子前面已经提到过：母亲将大部分财产留给“不忠”的女儿，而只给忠贞的女儿留下一点点。有时，重婚罪也只有在遗嘱被宣读后才会暴露出来。这里的问题是：“你遗嘱中最重要的一项是什么？你死后，留给身后亲人的最大惊喜是什么？”

We have now followed Jeder in his script from before birth until after death. But there are many more interesting things to consider before we go on to talk about treatment.

我们已经按照杰德的剧本，从出生前一直写到去世后。但在讨论治疗方法之前，还有许多其他有趣的事情值得我们思考。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 The suicide rate increases roughly with age, and is lower for females than for males at all ages save early adolescence.

1 自杀率大致随年龄增长而增加，除青春期早期外，所有年龄段的女性自杀率均低于男性。

2 Steiner, C. M. ‘The Alcoholic Game,’ Transactional Analysis Bulletin 7:6–16, January, 1968.

2 Steiner, C. M.《酒精游戏》，《人际沟通分析公报》7:6–16，1968 年 1 月。

3 Karpman, S. ‘Fairy Tales and Script Drama Analysis.’ Transactional Analysis Bulletin 7: 39–43, April, 1968.

3 Karpman, S. ‘童话故事和剧本戏剧分析’。”《人际沟通分析公报》7：39–43，1968 年 4 月。

4 Berne, E. Games People Play. Loc. cit .

4 Berne, E.《人们玩的游戏》。同上。

5 Cf. early deaths following bereavement as described by W. D. Rees & S. G. Lutkins in British Medical Journal 4:13, October 7, 1967, and summarized in Current Medical Digest , March, 1968.

5 参见 W. D. Rees 和 S. G. Lutkins 在《英国医学杂志》4:13（1967 年 10 月 7 日）中描述的丧亲后早期死亡，以及《当代医学文摘》（1968 年 3 月）中的总结。

6 Lifton, R. J. Death in Life . Random House, New York, 1968.

6 Lifton, R. J.《生死之间》。纽约兰登书屋，1968 年。

7 Cf. Grose, F. A Classical Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue . Digest Books, Northfield, Illinois, 1971 (facsimile of 1811 edition).

7 参见 Grose, F.《通俗语言古典词典》。Digest Books，伊利诺伊州诺斯菲尔德，1971 年（1811 年版影印本）。

#↩

PART III

第三部分

The Script in Action

剧本实战

#↩

CHAPTER ELEVEN

第十一章

Types of Scripts

脚本类型

A • Winners, Nonwinners, and Losers

A • 赢家、非赢家和输家

Scripts are designed to last a lifetime. They are based on childhood decisions and parental programing which is continually reinforced. The reinforcement may take the form of daily contact, as with men who work for their fathers, or women who telephone their mothers every morning to gossip, or it may be applied less frequently and more subtly, but just as powerfully, through occasional correspondence. After the parents die, their instructions may be remembered more vividly than ever.

人生剧本的设计旨在伴随一生。它们基于童年时期的决定和父母的教诲，并不断得到强化。这种强化可能以日常接触的形式出现，例如男性为父亲工作，女性每天早上打电话给母亲闲聊；也可能以频率较低、更为微妙但同样强大的方式呈现，例如偶尔的书信往来。父母去世后，他们的教诲或许会比以往任何时候都更加清晰地被铭记。

In script language, as noted, a loser is called a frog 1 and a winner is called a prince or a princess. Parents want their children to be either winners or losers. They may want them to be ‘happy’ in the role they have chosen for them, but do not want them to be transformed, except in special cases. A mother who is raising a frog may want her daughter to be a happy frog, but will put down any attempts of the girl to become a princess. (‘Who do you think you are?’) A father who is raising a prince wants his son to be happy, but often he would rather see him unhappy than transformed into a frog. (‘How can you do that to us? We’ve given you the best of everything.’)

如前所述，在文字语言中，失败者被称为青蛙，而胜利者被称为王子或公主。父母希望自己的孩子要么成为胜利者，要么成为失败者。他们可能希望孩子在自己选择的角色中感到“快乐”，但除非特殊情况，否则不希望孩子发生改变。一位养育青蛙的母亲可能希望女儿成为一只快乐的青蛙，但会打压女儿任何成为公主的尝试（“你以为你是谁？”）。一位养育王子的父亲希望儿子快乐，但通常宁愿看到儿子不快乐，也不愿看到他变成青蛙（“你怎么能这样对我们？我们已经给了你最好的。”）。

The first thing to be decided about a script is whether it is a winning one or a losing one. This can often be discovered very quickly by listening to the person talk. A winner says things like: ‘I made a mistake, but it won’t happen again,’ or ‘Now I know the right way to do it.’ A loser says ‘If only …’ ‘I should’ve …’ and ‘Yes, but …’ There are also near misses, nonwinners whose scripts require them to work very hard, not for the purpose of winning, but just to stay even. These are ‘at leasters,’ people who say ‘Well, at least I didn’t …’ or ‘At least, I have this much to be thankful for.’ Nonwinners make excellent members, employees, and serfs, since they are loyal, hard-working, and grateful, and not inclined to cause trouble. Socially, they are pleasant people, and in the community, admirable. Winners make trouble for the rest of the world only indirectly, when they are fighting among themselves and involve innocent bystanders, sometimes by the millions. Losers cause the most grief to themselves and others. Even if they come out on top they are still losers, and drag other people down with them when the payoff comes. fn1

判断一个剧本是成功剧本还是失败剧本，首先要确定的是它是成功剧本还是失败剧本。通常，通过倾听一个人的谈话就能很快发现这一点。成功者会说：“我犯了个错误，但不会再犯了。”或者“现在我知道正确的做法了。”而失败者则会说“要是……就好了”、“我应该……”以及“是的，但是……”。还有一些人与成功擦肩而过，他们并非成功者，他们的剧本要求他们非常努力，并非为了获胜，而是为了维持现状。这些人被称为“至少”型人格，他们会说“好吧，至少我没有……”或者“至少，我还有这些值得感恩的事情。”失败者是优秀的成员、员工和仆人，因为他们忠诚、勤奋、感恩，而且不愿惹是生非。在社交场合，他们是令人愉快的人，在社区中也备受尊敬。胜利者只有在内斗并牵连无辜旁观者时，才会间接地给世界带来麻烦，有时甚至会牵连数百万人。失败者给自己和他人带来最大的痛苦。即使他们最终获胜，他们仍然是失败者，并且在获利时会拖累其他人。

fn1 All this (and much of what follows) may sound familiar to some readers because it is reduced to simple terms and I have said it elsewhere 2 in much the same way, since this particular section was written several years ago.

fn1 所有这些（以及接下来的大部分内容）对一些读者来说可能听起来很熟悉，因为它被简化为简单的术语，而且我在其他地方也以类似的方式说过 2 ，因为这一部分是几年前写的。

A winner is defined as a person who fulfills his contract with the world and with himself. That is, he sets out to do something, says that he is committed to doing it, and in the long run does it. His contract, or ambition, may be to save $100,000, run the mile in less than four minutes, or get a Ph.D. If he accomplishes his goal, he is a winner. If he ends up in debt, sprains his ankle in the shower, or flunks out in his junior year, he is clearly a loser. If he saves $10,000, comes in second at 4:05, or goes into industry with an M.A., he is an at-leaster: not a loser, but a nonwinner. The important thing is that he sets the goal himself, usually on the basis of Parental programing, but with his Adult making the final commitment. Note that the man who goes for 4:05 and makes it is still a winner, while the one who goes for 3:59 and only makes 4:05 is a nonwinner, even though he beats the one whose ambition is lower. On a short-term basis, a winner is one who becomes captain of the team, dates the Queen of the May, or wins at the poker game. A nonwinner never gets near the ball, dates the runner-up, or comes out even. A loser doesn’t make the team, doesn’t get a date, or comes out broke.

赢家的定义是：履行了与世界和自身契约的人。也就是说，他立志去做某件事，并承诺会坚持到底，最终也确实做到了。他的契约或抱负可能是攒够10万美元，在4分钟内跑完一英里，或者获得博士学位。如果他实现了目标，他就是赢家。如果他最终负债累累，在淋浴时扭伤了脚踝，或者大三挂科，那他显然是个失败者。如果他攒够了1万美元，以4分05秒的成绩获得第二名，或者带着硕士学位进入企业工作，那他至少算得上是一个“赢家”：不是失败者，但也不是真正的赢家。重要的是，他自己设定了目标，通常是基于父母的引导，但最终的决定权在于他的成年人。注意，用时4分05秒完成跳绳的人仍然是赢家，而用时3分59秒却只跳到4分05秒的人则不是赢家，即使他击败了目标较低的人。短期来看，赢家可以成为球队队长、与五月皇后约会或在扑克牌局中获胜。非赢家则连跳绳的机会都没有、只能和亚军约会或打成平手。输家则无法入选球队、无法约会或身无分文。

Furthermore, the captain of the second team is on the same level as the captain of the first team, since each person is entitled to choose his own league and is judged by the standards which he himself sets up. As an extreme example, ‘living on less money than anyone else on the street without getting sick’ is a league. Whoever does it is a winner. One who tries it and gets sick is a loser. The typical, classical loser is the man who makes himself suffer sickness or damage for no good cause (like Della in Chapter Three ). If he has a good cause, then he may become a successful martyr, which is the best way to win by losing.

此外，第二队的队长与第一队的队长地位相同，因为每个人都有权选择自己的联赛，并按照自己设定的标准接受评判。举个极端的例子，“在街头生活，却比任何人都穷，而且不会生病”就是一个联赛。做到的人就是赢家。尝试过却生病的人就是输家。典型的、经典的输家是那种无缘无故让自己遭受疾病或伤害的人（就像第三章中的德拉）。如果他有正当的理由，那么他可能会成为一个成功的殉道者，这才是以失败取胜的最佳方式。

A winner knows what he’ll do next if he loses, but doesn’t talk about it; a loser doesn’t know what he’ll do if he loses, but talks about what he’ll do if he wins. Thus, it takes only a few minutes of listening to pick out the winners and losers at a gambling table or a stockbroker’s, in a domestic argument or in family therapy.

赢家知道输了之后该怎么办，但他不会谈论这件事；输家不知道输了之后该怎么办，但他会谈论赢了之后该怎么办。因此，只需几分钟的倾听，就能分辨出赌桌上、股票经纪人办公室、家庭争吵中或家庭治疗中的赢家和输家。

The basic rule seems to be that a winning script payoff comes from the nurturing Parent through the counterscript slogans. A nonwinner gets his payoff from the controlling Parent through injunctions. A loser is led down the path to a bad payoff by the provocations and seductions of his parent’s crazy Child, which tempts his self-destructive demon.

基本规律似乎是：成功的剧本带来的回报来自培育型父母通过反剧本口号给予的回报。失败者则从控制型父母那里获得回报，后者通过禁令来控制他们。失败者则被其父母疯狂的孩子的挑衅和诱惑引向糟糕的回报之路，这诱惑着他自我毁灭的恶魔。

B • Script Time

B • 脚本时间

Winning or losing, the script is a way to structure the time between the first Hello at mother’s breast and the last Good-by at the grave. This life time is emptied and filled by not doing and doing; by never doing, always doing, not doing before, not doing after, doing over and over, and doing until there is nothing left to do. This gives rise to ‘Never’ and ‘Always,’ ‘Until’ and ‘After,’ ‘Over and Over,’ and ‘Open-Ended’ scripts. These are best understood by reference to Greek myths, since the Greeks had a strong feeling for such things.

无论输赢，人生剧本都是一种构建从母亲怀抱中第一次“你好”到坟墓前最后一次“再见”之间时光的方式。这段人生时光因不作为和作为而变得空虚和充盈；因不作为、总是作为、之前不作为、之后不作为、反复作为、以及一直做到无事可做而变得空虚和充盈。这便产生了“从不”和“总是”、“直到”和“之后”、“反复”以及“开放式”等人生剧本。要理解这些剧本，最好参考希腊神话，因为希腊人对这类事物有着强烈的感受。

‘Never’ scripts are represented by Tantalus, who through all eternity was to suffer from hunger and thirst in sight of food and water, but never to eat or drink again. People with such scripts are forbidden by their parents to do the things they most want to, and so spend their lives being tantalized and surrounded by temptations. They go along with the Parental curse because the Child in them is afraid of the things they want the most, so they are really tantalizing themselves.

“永不”剧本的代表人物是坦塔罗斯，他永世忍受着饥渴的折磨，即使食物和水就在眼前，却永远无法再次进食饮水。拥有这种剧本的人被父母禁止去做他们最渴望的事情，因此他们一生都在诱惑的煎熬中度过。他们顺从父母的诅咒，因为他们内心深处的孩子害怕自己最渴望的东西，所以实际上是在自我折磨。

‘Always’ scripts follow Arachne, who dared to challenge the Goddess Minerva in needlework, and as a punishment was turned into a spider and condemned to spend all her time spinning webs. Such scripts come from spiteful parents, who say: ‘If that’s what you want to do, then you can just spend the rest of your life doing it.’

“永远”的故事往往取材于阿拉克涅，她胆敢挑战女神密涅瓦的刺绣技艺，结果被惩罚变成一只蜘蛛，终生只能织网。这类故事通常出自心怀怨恨的父母之口，他们会说：“既然你执意如此，那就让你余生都去做吧。”

‘Until’ or ‘Before’ scripts follow the story of Jason, who was told that he could not become a king before he had performed certain tasks. In due time he got his reward and lived for ten years in happiness. Hercules had a similar script: he could not become a god until he had first been a slave for twelve years.

“直到”或“之前”的剧本遵循着伊阿宋的故事：他被告知，在完成某些任务之前，他无法成为国王。最终，他获得了奖赏，并幸福地生活了十年。赫拉克勒斯的剧本也与之类似：他必须先做十二年的奴隶，才能成为神。

‘After’ scripts come from Damocles. Damocles was allowed to enjoy the happiness of being a king, until he noticed that a sword was hanging over his head, suspended by a single horsehair. The motto of ‘After’ scripts is ‘You can enjoy yourself for a while, but after that your troubles begin.’

“之后”的题词源于达摩克利斯的故事。达摩克利斯曾享受着身为国王的幸福，直到他发现一把剑悬在他的头顶，仅靠一根马鬃悬挂着。“之后”题词的格言是：“你可以享受片刻，但之后你的苦难就开始了。”

‘Over and Over’ scripts are Sisyphus. He was condemned to roll a heavy stone up a hill, and just as he was about to reach the top the stone rolled back and he had to start over again. This is the classical ‘Almost Made It’ script, with one ‘If only’ after another.

“一遍又一遍”的剧本就像西西弗斯的故事。他被判处推巨石上山，眼看就要到达山顶，巨石却滚落下来，他不得不重新开始。这就是典型的“差一点就成功”的剧本，里面充斥着一个又一个的“要是……就好了”。

The ‘Open-Ended’ script is the nonwinner or ‘Pie in the Sky’ scenario, and follows the story of Philemon and Baucis, who were turned into laurel trees as a reward for their good deeds. Old people who have carried out their Parental instructions don’t know what to do next after it is all over, and spend the rest of their lives like vegetables, or gossiping like leaves rustling in the wind. This is the fate of many a mother whose children have grown up and scattered, and of retired men who have put in their thirty years of work according to company regulations and their parents’ instructions. As already noted, ‘Senior Citizen’ communities are filled with couples who have completed their scripts and don’t know how to structure their time while waiting for the Promised Land where people who have treated their employees decently can drive their big black cars slowly down the left-hand lane without being honked at by a bunch of ill-bred teen-agers in their hot rods. ‘Was pretty feisty myself as a teen-ager,’ says Dad, ‘but nowadays.’ And Mom adds: ‘You wouldn’t believe what they … And we’ve always paid our …’

“开放式结局”剧本是注定失败的，或者说是“空中楼阁”，它讲述的是菲利蒙和鲍西斯的故事，他们因行善积德而被化作月桂树。那些完成了父母遗愿的老人们，在一切结束后不知何去何从，只能像植物一样虚度余生，或者像风中沙沙作响的落叶一样闲聊八卦。许多子女长大离家的母亲，以及那些按照公司规章和父母遗愿工作了三十年的退休男士，都面临着同样的命运。正如前文所述，“老年社区”里住满了完成了人生剧本的夫妇，他们不知道该如何安排时间，只能等待着“应许之地”的到来——在那里，那些善待员工的人可以开着黑色大车，悠闲地行驶在左侧车道上，而不用担心被一群开着改装车的没教养的青少年鸣笛催促。 “我青少年时期也挺叛逆的，”爸爸说，“但现在……”妈妈补充道：“你简直无法想象他们……而且我们一直都按时缴纳……”

C • Sex and Scripts

C • 性和脚本

All of these script types have their sexual aspects. ‘Never’ scripts may forbid either love or sex, or both. If they forbid love but not sex, they are a license for promiscuity, a license which some sailors and soldiers and wanderers take full advantage of, and which prostitutes and courtesans use to make a living. If they forbid sex but not love, they produce priests, monks, nuns, and people who do good deeds such as raising orphan children. The promiscuous people are continually tantalized by the sight of devoted lovers and happy families, while the philanthropists are continually tempted to jump over the wall.

所有这些剧本类型都包含性方面的元素。“永不”剧本可能禁止爱情或性，或两者都禁止。如果禁止爱情而不禁止性，就等于纵容滥交，一些水手、士兵和流浪者会充分利用这种纵容，而妓女和交际花则以此为生。如果禁止性而不禁止爱情，就会造就神父、僧侣、修女以及从事诸如抚养孤儿等善行的人。那些放荡不羁的人会不断被恩爱的恋人和幸福的家庭所诱惑，而那些行善者则会不断受到诱惑，想要翻墙越墙。

‘Always’ scripts are typified by young people who are driven out of their homes for the sins which their parents have prompted them to. ‘If you’re pregnant, go earn your living on the streets’ and ‘If you want to take drugs, you’re on your own’ are examples of these. The father who turned his daughter into the storm may have had lecherous thoughts about her since she was ten (ten? eight?), and the one who threw his son out of the house for smoking pot may get drunk that night to ease his pain.

“永远”式的叙事手法通常用来描述那些因父母怂恿而犯下罪行而被赶出家门的年轻人。“如果你怀孕了，就去街头谋生”和“如果你想吸毒，那就自求多福吧”就是这类叙事手法的例子。那个把女儿逼到绝境的父亲，或许从她十岁（或者八岁？）起就对她心怀不轨；而那个因为儿子吸食大麻就把他赶出家门的父亲，或许会在当晚借酒消愁。

The parental programing in ‘Until’ scripts is the loudest of all, since it usually consists of outright commands: ‘You can’t have sex until you’re married, and you can’t get married as long as you have to take care of your mother (or until you finish college).’ The Parental influence in ‘After’ scripts is almost as outspoken, and the hanging sword gleams with visible threats: ‘After you get married and have children, your troubles will begin.’ Translated into action now, this means ‘Gather ye rosebuds while ye may.’ After marriage, it shortens to ‘Once you have children your troubles will begin.’ fn2

“直到”脚本中的父母灌输最为强烈，因为它通常以直接命令的形式出现：“结婚前不能有性生活，而且在你照顾母亲期间（或大学毕业之前）不能结婚。”“之后”脚本中的父母影响也几乎同样直白，如同悬在空中的利剑，闪烁着明显的威胁：“结婚生子后，你的麻烦就开始了。”如果现在付诸行动，那就是“趁着年轻，赶紧享受美好时光”。结婚后，则简化为“一旦有了孩子，你的麻烦就开始了。”

fn2 Part of this section follows the language of my previous work, referred to above, but I don’t know any better way to say it. I have been saying it this way in lectures for a long time now, as is well known to many script analysts.

fn2 本节部分内容沿用了我之前作品（如上所述）的语言，但我实在想不出更好的表达方式。长期以来，我在讲课中一直这样表述，许多剧本分析专家对此也心知肚明。

‘Over and Over’ scripts produce always a bridesmaid and never a bride, and others who try hard again and again, and never quite succeed in making it. ‘Open-Ended’ scripts end with aging men and women who lose their vitality without much regret and are content with reminiscing about past conquests. Just as women with such scripts wait eagerly for the menopause, with the hope that that will solve their ‘sexual problems,’ so the men wait until they have put in their time on the job with a similar hope of relief from sexual obligations.

“反复”式的剧本总是造就伴娘而非新娘，也造就那些一次又一次努力却始终无法如愿的人。“开放式结局”式的剧本则以年迈的男女告终，他们逐渐失去活力，却鲜有遗憾，满足于回忆过去的辉煌。正如拥有这种剧本的女性热切期盼更年期的到来，希望借此解决她们的“性问题”一样，男性也同样期盼着在事业圆满后，能够从性方面的负担中解脱出来。

At the more intimate level, each of these scripts has its own bearing on the actual orgasm. The ‘Never’ script, of course, besides making spinsters and bachelors and prostitutes and pimps, also makes frigid women who never have one, not a single one in their whole lives, and also produces impotent men who can have orgasms providing there is no love, the classical situation described by Freud of the man who is impotent with his wife but not with prostitutes. The ‘Always’ script produces nymphomaniacs and Don Juans, who spend their lives continually chasing after the promise of an orgasm.

在更私密的层面上，每一种剧本都对实际的性高潮产生影响。“永不”剧本当然会造就老处女、单身汉、妓女和皮条客，也会造就性冷淡的女性，她们一生从未体验过性高潮，甚至一次也没有；还会造就阳痿的男性，只要没有爱情，他们就能获得性高潮——这正是弗洛伊德所描述的经典情况：男性对妻子阳痿，但对妓女却可以。“总是”剧本则会造就性欲亢进者和唐璜，他们终其一生都在不断追逐性高潮的诱惑。

The ‘Until’ script favors harried housewives and tired businessmen, neither of whom can get sexually aroused until every last detail of the household or the office has been put in order. Even after they are aroused, they may be interrupted at the most critical moments by games of ‘Refrigerator Door’ and ‘Note Pad,’ little things they have to jump out of bed to take care of right now, such as checking the refrigerator door to make sure it is closed, or jotting down a few things that have to be done first thing in the morning at the office. ‘After’ scripts interfere with sex because of apprehension. Fear of pregnancy, for example, keeps the woman from having an enjoyable orgasm and may cause the man to have his too quickly. Coitus interruptus , where the man withdraws just before he comes as a method of birth control, keeps both parties in a jumpy state right from the beginning, and usually leaves the woman stranded high and wet if the couple is too shy to use some way for her to get her satisfaction. In fact the word satisfaction, which is usually used in discussing this particular problem, is a giveaway that something is wrong, since a good orgasm should be far more substantial than the pale ghost called satisfaction.

“直到”模式更适合忙碌的家庭主妇和疲惫的商务人士，他们只有在把家里或办公室的每一个细节都安排妥当之后才能性欲高涨。即使他们已经性欲高涨，也可能在最关键的时刻被“冰箱门”和“记事本”之类的琐事打断——这些小事他们必须立刻从床上跳起来处理，比如检查冰箱门是否关好，或者记下明天早上在办公室必须先完成的几件事。“之后”模式则会因为焦虑而影响性生活。例如，对怀孕的恐惧会让女性无法获得愉悦的性高潮，也可能导致男性过早射精。体外射精，即男性在射精前抽出作为一种避孕方法，会让双方从一开始就处于紧张状态，如果夫妻双方都羞于使用某种方式让女性获得满足，通常会导致女性在性高潮后仍然湿润难耐。事实上，“满足感”这个词（通常用于讨论这个问题）恰恰暴露了问题所在，因为一次好的性高潮应该比“满足感”这种苍白的幻觉要深刻得多。

The ‘Over and Over’ script is one which will ring a bell for many women losers, who get higher and higher during intercourse, until just as they are about to make it, the man comes, possibly with the woman’s help, and she rolls all the way down again. This may happen night after night for years. The ‘Open-End’ script has its effect in older people who regard sex as an effort or an obligation. Once over the hill, they are ‘too old’ to have sex, and their glands wither away from disuse, along with their skins and often their muscles and brains as well. Now they have nothing to do but fill in time until their pipes rust away. In order to avoid such vegetating, a script should not have a time limit on it, but should be designed to last a whole lifetime, no matter how long that lifetime may be.

“反复”模式会让许多性生活不和谐的女性感同身受。她们在性交过程中越陷越深，直到即将达到高潮时，男性却在她们的帮助下射精，然后她们的性欲又骤然下降。这种情况可能年复一年地反复发生。“开放式”模式则对那些将性视为一种负担或义务的老年人影响尤为明显。一旦过了青春期，他们就觉得自己“太老”了，无法再进行性生活，他们的腺体因长期缺乏而萎缩，皮肤、肌肉甚至大脑也常常随之衰退。如今，他们除了消磨时间，直到身体机能彻底衰退之外，别无他事可做。为了避免这种萎靡不振的状态，理想的性生活模式不应设限，而应设计成能够持续一生，无论这一生有多长。

The sexual potency, drive, and power of a human being are to some extent determined by his inheritance and his chemistry, but they seem to be even more strongly influenced by the script decisions he makes in early childhood, and by the parental programing which brings about those decisions. Thus, not only the authority and frequency of his sexual activities throughout his whole lifetime, but also his ability and readiness to love, are to a large extent already decided at the age of six. This seems to apply even more strongly to women. Some of them decide very early that they want to be mothers when they grow up, while others resolve at the same period to remain virgins or virgin brides forever. In any case, sexual activity in both sexes is continually interfered with by parental opinions, adult precautions, childhood decisions, and social pressures and fears, so that natural urges and cycles are suppressed, exaggerated, distorted, disregarded, or contaminated. The result is that whatever is called ‘sex’ becomes the instrument of gamy behavior. The simple transactions of Greek myths, the pows, bams, and kazams that took place on Mount Olympus, which form the basis for the original version of the script, are elaborated into the trickery and subterfuges of folk tales, so that Europa becomes transformed into Little Red Riding Hood, Proserpina into Cinderella, and Ulysses into the stupid prince who is changed into a frog.

人类的性能力、性欲和性能力在一定程度上取决于遗传和生理因素，但似乎更受童年早期做出的人生抉择以及促成这些抉择的父母教养的影响。因此，一个人一生中性行为的权威性和频率，以及他爱的能力和意愿，在很大程度上在六岁时就已经决定了。这种情况似乎对女性更为显著。有些女性很早就决定长大后要成为母亲，而另一些女性则在同一时期就决心终身保持处女之身。无论如何，两性的性行为都不断受到父母的意见、成年人的预防措施、童年的决定以及社会压力和恐惧的干扰，导致自然的欲望和生理周期被压制、夸大、扭曲、忽视或污染。其结果是，任何被称为“性”的行为都沦为淫乱行为的工具。希腊神话中发生在奥林匹斯山上的简单交易，即“砰”、“砰”、“咔嚓”等，构成了剧本原版的基础，被扩展成民间故事中的诡计和诡计，使得欧罗巴变成了小红帽，珀耳塞福涅变成了灰姑娘，而尤利西斯变成了被变成青蛙的愚蠢王子。

D • Clock Time and Goal Time

D • 时钟时间和目标时间

The ways of filling in short periods of social time were discussed in Chapter Two , the available options being withdrawal, rituals, pastimes, activities, games, and intimacy. Each of these has a beginning and an ending called a switch point. Over a longer period, the script also has its switch points, which usually mean that the players switch from one role to another in the drama triangle.

第二章讨论了如何填补短暂的社交空档，可行的方式包括独处、仪式、消遣、活动、游戏和亲密关系。每一种方式都有开始和结束，称为转换点。在较长的时间跨度内，剧本也存在转换点，通常意味着角色在戏剧三角中转换角色。

Richard Schechner has made a careful and scholarly analysis of time patterns in the theater 3 which also applies to the dramaturgy of real-life scripts. The two most important types he calls ‘set time’ and ‘event time.’ Set time runs by a clock or calendar. The action begins and ends at a certain moment, or a certain time is given for its performance, as with a football game. For script analysis, we can call this clock time (CT). In event time, the activity is to be completed, like a baseball game, no matter how long or short a time it takes by the clock. We will call this goal time (GT). There are also combinations of these. A boxing match can terminate either when all the rounds are completed, which takes a set time or clock time, or when there is a knockout, which is event time or goal time.

理查德·谢克纳对戏剧中的时间模式进行了细致而学术的分析，这种分析同样适用于现实生活剧本的戏剧结构。他将其中最重要的两种时间类型称为“设定时间”和“事件时间”。设定时间以时钟或日历为准。动作在特定时刻开始和结束，或者说，动作的完成时间是固定的，例如足球比赛。在剧本分析中，我们可以将这种时间称为“时钟时间”（CT）。在事件时间中，活动必须完成，例如棒球比赛，无论耗时长短。我们将这种时间称为“目标时间”（GT）。此外，还有这两种时间类型的组合。例如，一场拳击比赛可以在所有回合结束后结束（这属于设定时间或时钟时间），也可以在出现击倒对手时结束（这属于事件时间或目标时间）。

Schechner’s ideas are useful to the script analyst, particularly in dealing with ‘Can’ and ‘Can’t’ scripts. A child doing his homework can be given five different instructions. ‘You need plenty of sleep, so you can stop at nine o’clock.’ This is called Clock Time Can. ‘You need plenty of sleep, so you can’t work after nine o’clock.’ This is called Clock Time Can’t. ‘Your homework is important, so you can stay up and finish it.’ This is Goal Time Can. ‘Your homework is important, so you can’t go to bed until you finish it.’ This is Goal Time Can’t. The two Cans may relieve him, and the two Can’ts may irritate him, but none of them box him in. ‘You have to finish your homework by nine o’clock so you can get to sleep.’ Here Clock Time and Goal Time are combined, which is called a ‘Hurryup.’ It is evident that each of these instructions can have a different effect on his homework and on his sleep, and when he grows up, on his working habits and his sleeping habits. From a Martian point of view, the effects on the child’s script may be quite different from what the parents say they meant. For instance, Clock Time Can’t may end up with insomnia, and Goal Time Can’t may throw in the sponge some day. (Chuck in Chapter Six was on Goal Time Can’t and threw in with psychotherapy instead of with a coronary occlusion. Others prefer the coronary.)

谢克纳的理论对剧本分析师很有帮助，尤其是在处理“可以”和“不可以”的剧本时。一个孩子做作业时，可以给出五种不同的指示。“你需要充足的睡眠，所以你可以在九点钟停止做作业。”这叫做“时钟时间可以”。“你需要充足的睡眠，所以你九点钟以后不能做作业。”这叫做“时钟时间不可以”。“你的作业很重要，所以你可以熬夜完成它。”这叫做“目标时间可以”。“你的作业很重要，所以你必须完成它才能睡觉。”这叫做“目标时间不可以”。两个“能”或许能让他放松，两个“不能”或许会让他烦躁，但它们都无法束缚他。“你必须在九点前完成作业，这样才能睡觉。”这里，“时钟时间”和“目标时间”结合在了一起，被称为“催促”。显然，每条指令都会对他的作业和睡眠产生不同的影响，长大后，还会影响他的学习习惯和睡眠习惯。从火星人的角度来看，这些指令对孩子的影响可能与父母的本意大相径庭。例如，“时钟时间不能”最终可能导致失眠，“目标时间不能”则可能让他有一天放弃。（第六章中的查克就因为“目标时间不能”而放弃了，他选择了心理治疗而不是冠状动脉阻塞。其他人则更倾向于冠状动脉阻塞。）

This list is important because it helps to explain how people choose to fill in their time while following their script injunctions. ‘You can live until you’re forty’ (CT Can) is usually busy trying to get done what he wants to do; ‘You can live until your wife dies’ (GT Can) is likely to spend more time worrying about how to postpone the event and keep his wife alive. ‘You can’t do it until you meet the right man’ (GT Can’t) may spend a lot of time looking for man, where ‘You can’t do it until you’re twenty-one’ (CT Can’t) has time for other things. It also explains why some people are run by the clock while others are goal oriented.

这份清单之所以重要，是因为它有助于解释人们如何在遵循既定人生准则的同时选择如何安排时间。“你可以活到四十岁”（CT Can）的人通常忙于完成自己想做的事情；“你可以活到妻子去世”（GT Can）的人则可能花更多时间担心如何延缓妻子的离世，让她活下去。“你得等到遇到对的人才能做这件事”（GT Can’t）的人可能会花大量时间寻找伴侣，而“你得等到二十一岁才能做这件事”（CT Can’t）的人则有时间做其他事情。这份清单也解释了为什么有些人被时间束缚，而有些人则目标明确。

References

参考

1 Young, D. ‘The Frog Game.’ Loc. cit .

1 Young, D.《青蛙游戏》。同上。

2 Berne, E. Sex in Human Loving . Simon & Schuster, New York, 1970.

2 Berne, E. 人类爱情中的性。西蒙与舒斯特出版社，纽约，1970 年。

3 Schechner, R. Public Domain . The Bobbs-Merrill Company, New York, 1969, Chapter 2.

3 Schechner, R. Public Domain. The Bobbs-Merrill Company, New York, 1969, Chapter 2.

#↩

CHAPTER TWELVE

第十二章

Some Typical Scripts

一些典型脚本

Scripts are artificial systems which limit spontaneous and creative human aspirations, just as games are artificial structures which limit spontaneous and creative intimacy. The script is like a piece of decorated, frosted glass which Jeder’s parents place between him and the world (and themselves), and which he then secures and keeps in good repair. He peers at the world through it, and the world peers back, hoping to see at least a flicker, and perhaps a burst, of his true humanity. But since the world is peering through its own frosted glass, the visibility is no better than that between two skin divers with cloudy face pieces at the bottom of a muddy river. The Martian has rubbed his face piece with No-Fog, so he can see a little better. Here are some examples of what he sees, which may help to explain how the script gives an answer in each case to the question: ‘What do you say or do after you say Hello?’

剧本是人为构建的系统，它限制了人类自发而富有创造力的愿望，正如游戏是人为构建的结构，限制了自发而富有创造力的亲密关系一样。剧本就像一块装饰过的磨砂玻璃，杰德的父母把它放在他和世界（以及他们自己）之间，然后他小心翼翼地保护着它，并使其完好无损。他透过这块玻璃凝视着世界，世界也凝视着他，希望能至少看到他真实人性的一丝闪光，或许是爆发。但由于世界也透过它自己的磨砂玻璃凝视着他，所以能见度并不比两个戴着雾蒙蒙面罩的潜水员在浑浊的河底之间的视线好多少。火星人用防雾剂擦了擦他的面罩，这样他就能看得更清楚一些。以下是他所看到的一些例子，这些例子或许有助于解释剧本是如何在每种情况下回答“说了‘你好’之后，你会说什么或做什么？”这个问题的。

A • Little Pink Riding Hood, or The Waif

A • 小粉红骑帽，或流浪儿

Little Pink Riding Hood was an orphan, and she used to sit in a clearing in the forest waiting for someone who needed help to pass by. Sometimes she would wander down the paths in case anyone needed her in another part of the woods. She was very poor and could not offer very much, but whatever she had she shared freely. She could hold things when people needed an extra pair of hands, and her head was full of wise precepts which she had learned from her parents while they were still alive. She was also full of merry quips, and she liked to cheer up men who were scared of getting lost in the forest. In this way she made many friends. But she was nearly always alone on weekends because then everybody went on picnics in the meadows and left her alone and a little scared herself to be in the forest. Sometimes they invited her to go along, but as she got older this happened less and less often.

小红帽是个孤儿，她常常坐在森林里的一片空地上，等待需要帮助的人路过。有时，她也会沿着小路漫步，看看有没有人需要她，尤其是在森林的其他地方。她很穷，能提供的并不多，但她总是慷慨地分享自己拥有的一切。当人们需要帮忙的时候，她可以帮忙拿东西。她脑子里充满了从父母那里学来的智慧箴言。她也总是妙语连珠，喜欢逗那些害怕在森林里迷路的人开心。就这样，她结交了很多朋友。但是，每到周末，她几乎总是孤身一人，因为那时大家都会去草地上野餐，把她一个人留在森林里，这让她有点害怕。有时，他们会邀请她一起去，但随着她长大，这种情况越来越少了。

She led a different life from Little Red Riding Hood, and in fact the one time they met they did not get along well together. Little Red Riding Hood was hurrying through the forest and passed by the clearing where Little Pink Riding Hood sat. She stopped to say Hello, and the two of them looked at each other for a minute, thinking they might become friends because they looked a little bit like each other except that one wore a pink cloak and the other a red one.

她和小红帽过着截然不同的生活，事实上，她们唯一一次见面时，彼此相处得并不融洽。小红帽匆匆穿过森林，路过小粉红帽坐着的那片空地。她停下来打招呼，两人互相看了看，觉得她们或许能成为朋友，因为她们长得有点像，只是一个穿着粉色斗篷，另一个穿着红色斗篷。

‘Where are you going?’ asked Pink. ‘I’ve never seen you around here before.’

“你要去哪儿？”Pink问道，“我以前从没在这儿见过你。”

‘I’m taking my grandmother some sandwiches my mother made,’ replied Red.

“我正要给奶奶带些我妈妈做的三明治，”雷德回答道。

‘Oh, how nice,’ said Pink. ‘I don’t have any mother.’

“哦，真好，”Pink说。“我没有母亲。”

‘Furthermore,’ said Red proudly, ‘when I get to my grandmother’s, I’m going to be eaten by a wolf – I think.’

“此外，”雷德骄傲地说，“我想，当我到奶奶家时，我会被狼吃掉。”

‘Oh,’ said Pink. ‘Well, a sandwich a day keeps the wolf away. And it’s a wise child that knows her own wolf when she meets him.’

“哦，”平克说。“嗯，一天一个三明治，就能把狼赶走。而且，聪明的孩子一遇到狼就能认出来。”

‘I don’t think those merry quips are funny,’ said Red. ‘So good-by.’

“我觉得那些俏皮话一点也不好笑，”雷德说。“再见。”

‘How stuck-up can you get?’ asked Pink. But Red had already departed. ‘She has no sense of humor,’ thought Pink to herself, ‘but I think she needs help.’ So Little Pink Riding Hood struck out into the forest to find a hunter who would protect Little Red Riding Hood from the wolf. Eventually she found one, an old friend of hers, and she told him that Little Red Riding Hood was in trouble. She followed him to the door of the hut where Red’s grandmother lived and saw everything that happened there. Little Red in bed with the wolf, the wolf trying to eat her, the hunter killing the wolf, and he and Little Red laughing and joking as they cut the wolf open and put stones in his belly. But Red didn’t even bother to thank Pink, which made Pink sad. And after it was all over, the hunter was better friends with Red than he had been with Pink, which made Pink even sadder. She was so sad that she began to eat peppy berries every day, and then she couldn’t sleep, so she would eat sleepy berries at night. She was still a cute kid and still liked to help people, but sometimes she thought the best thing to do would be to take an overdose of sleepy berries.

“你还能有多傲慢？”粉红问道。但小红帽已经离开了。“她一点幽默感都没有，”粉红心想，“但我认为她需要帮助。”于是，小粉红走进森林，寻找一位猎人来保护小红帽免受狼的伤害。最终，她找到了一位猎人，是她的一位老朋友，她告诉他小红帽遇到了麻烦。她跟着猎人来到小红帽奶奶住的小屋门口，目睹了那里发生的一切：小红帽和狼躺在床上，狼试图吃掉她，猎人杀死了狼，然后他和小红帽一边说笑一边剖开狼的肚子，往狼肚子里塞石头。但小红帽甚至没有向粉红道谢，这让粉红感到难过。事情结束后，猎人和小红帽的关系比和粉红的关系更好，这让粉红更加难过。她非常难过，开始每天吃提神浆果，结果睡不着觉，晚上就吃瞌睡浆果。她仍然是个可爱的孩子，仍然喜欢帮助别人，但有时她觉得最好的办法就是服用过量的瞌睡浆果。

CLINICAL ANALYSIS

临床分析

Thesis : Little Pink Riding Hood is an orphan, or has reason to feel like one. She is a cute kid, full of wise precepts and merry quips, but she leaves it to others to do the real thinking, organize things, and carry them through. She is conscientious and always ready to help people, and has many ‘friends’ as a result, but somehow she usually gets left out in the end. She then begins to drink and take stimulating drugs and sleeping pills, and often thinks of suicide. After she says Hello, she makes some merry quips, but that is only to pass the time until she has a chance to ask: ‘Can I help you with anything?’ Thus she could have a ‘deep’ relationship with a loser, but didn’t do so well with winners after the quips were over.

论点：小红帽是个孤儿，或者至少有理由觉得自己是个孤儿。她是个可爱的孩子，充满智慧的箴言和俏皮话，但她总是把真正思考、组织和执行的事情交给别人。她认真负责，总是乐于助人，因此有很多“朋友”，但不知为何，她最终总是被冷落。于是，她开始酗酒、服用兴奋剂和安眠药，并且经常想到自杀。她打招呼后会说一些俏皮话，但这只是为了打发时间，直到有机会问：“我能帮上什么忙吗？”因此，她可能与一个失败者建立起“深厚”的关系，但在俏皮话结束后，她与成功者的关系却并不融洽。

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS:
临床诊断： 		Chronic-depressive reaction.
慢性抑郁反应。
FAIRY TALE:
童话： 		Little Pink Riding Hood.
粉红小红帽。
ROLES:
角色： 		Helpful Child , Victim, Rescuer.
乐于助人的孩子，受害者，救助者。
SWITCHES:
开关： 		Rescuer (advising, nurturing Parent) to Victim (sad Child).
拯救者（提供建议、养育的父母）对受害者（悲伤的孩子）。
PARENTAL PRECEPT:
父母训诫： 		‘Be a good helpful girl.’
“做一个乐于助人的好女孩。”
PARENTAL PATTERN:
父母模式： 		‘Here’s how to help people.’
“以下是如何帮助他人的方法。”
PARENTAL INJUNCTION:
父母禁令： 		‘Don’t have much, don’t get much, and wither away.’
“一无所有，得不到多少，最终就会凋零。”
CHILDHOOD SLOGAN:
童年口号： 		‘Do your duty and don’t complain.’
“尽职尽责，不要抱怨。”
POSITION:
位置： 		‘I’m not-OK, because I complain.’
“我不好，因为我总是抱怨。”
‘They’re OK because they can have things.’
“他们没事，因为他们可以拥有一些东西。”
DECISION:
决定： 		‘I’ll punish myself for complaining.’
“我要惩罚自己，因为我抱怨了。”
SCRIPT:
脚本： 		Wither away.
消亡。
ANTISCRIPT:
反脚本： 		Learn how to help people.
学习如何帮助他人。
SWEATSHIRT:
运动衫： 		Front – ‘I’m a Cute Kid.’
正面——“我是个可爱的小孩。”
Back – ‘But I’m an Orphan.’
返回——“但我是一个孤儿。”
GAME:
游戏： 		‘No Matter How Hard I Try.’
无论我多么努力。
TRADING STAMPS:
交易邮票： 		Depressions.
抑郁症。
FINAL PAYOFF:
最终回报： 		Suicide.
自杀。
EPITAPHS:
墓志铭： 		‘She was a Good Kid.’
“她是个好孩子。”
‘I Tried.’
'我试过。'
ANTITHESIS:
对立： 		Stop being a cute kid.
别再装可爱了。
PERMISSION:
允许： 		To use her Adult to get something worthwhile.
利用她的成年身份去获得一些有价值的东西。

CLASSIFICATION

分类

Little Pink Riding Hood is a loser’s script, since everything she gets she loses. It is a Goal-Structured Can’t script, with the standard slogan: ‘You can’t make it unless you meet a Prince.’ It is based on a ‘Never’ plan, ‘Never ask for anything for yourself.’ After she says Hello she proves she is a helpful, cute kid.

小红帽的故事是一个失败者的剧本，因为她得到的一切都会失去。这是一个目标导向的“不可能”剧本，其标准口号是：“除非你遇到王子，否则你不可能成功。”它基于一个“永不”的计划：“永远不要为自己索取任何东西。”在她说完“你好”之后，她证明了自己是一个乐于助人、可爱的孩子。

B • Sisyphus, or There I Go Again

B • 西西弗斯，或者我又来了

This is about Jack and his Uncle Homer. Jack’s father was a war hero who got killed in battle when Jack was a little boy, and his mother died soon after. He was raised by his Uncle Homer who was a poor sport, a boaster, and not above cheating. He taught Jack all sorts of athletic and competitive games. But if Jack won, Homer would fly into a rage and say: ‘You think your shit don’t stink?’ If Jack lost, his uncle would laugh at him in a contemptuous, friendly way. So after a while Jack began to lose on purpose. The more he lost, the happier and more friendly his uncle became. Jack wanted to be a photographer, but his uncle said that was for sissies, and told him he should be an athletic hero instead. So Jack became a professional baseball player. What Homer really wanted was for Jack to try to be an athletic hero and fail.

故事的主角是杰克和他的霍默叔叔。杰克的父亲是一位战争英雄，在杰克还是个小男孩的时候就战死沙场，他的母亲不久后也去世了。杰克由霍默叔叔抚养长大，霍默叔叔是个不争气、爱吹牛、还经常作弊的人。他教杰克各种各样的体育游戏和竞技游戏。但如果杰克赢了，霍默叔叔就会勃然大怒，骂道：“你以为你拉的屎不臭吗？” 如果杰克输了，叔叔就会用一种既轻蔑又友好的语气嘲笑他。所以过了一段时间，杰克开始故意输掉比赛。他输得越多，叔叔就越高兴，也越和蔼。杰克想当摄影师，但叔叔说那是娘娘腔才干的事，让他去当体育英雄。于是杰克成了一名职业棒球运动员。霍默叔叔真正想看到的，是杰克尝试成为体育英雄，然后失败。

With his uncle for a friend, it was not surprising that just as Jack was on his way up into the big leagues, he sprained his arm and had to retire from the game. As he said later, it was hard to explain how an experienced player like himself could get such a bad sprain in spring training, when everybody was taking it easy so as not to get injured before the beginning of the season.

杰克的叔叔是他的朋友，所以当他即将进入大联盟时，却扭伤了手臂，不得不退役，这并不令人意外。正如他后来所说，很难解释像他这样经验丰富的球员，怎么会在春训期间扭伤得这么严重，因为当时每个人都在小心翼翼地训练，以免在赛季开始前受伤。

Jack then became a salesman. He always started off very well, and got bigger and bigger orders until he became a favorite of the boss. At that point he felt a compulsion to goof off. He would sleep late and neglect his paper work, so that his deliveries were late. He was such a good salesman that he didn’t even have to go out and sell, the customers would call him; but he would forget to put in their orders. As a result of all this, he had to have long, helpful dinners with the boss to discuss his problems in a personal way. After each dinner he would perk up a little, but after a while things would start to slide again. Sooner or later there would be a final dinner during which he would be fired in a friendly way. Then he would look for another job and start the whole cycle over. One difficulty was that he felt salesmen always had to lie and cheat a little, and that bothered him.

杰克后来成了一名销售员。他一开始总是表现出色，订单越来越多，最终成了老板的宠儿。但那时他却开始偷懒。他经常睡懒觉，疏于处理文书工作，导致送货延误。他销售能力太强，甚至不用亲自出门推销，客户就会主动打电话给他；但他却总是忘记把订单录入系统。结果，他不得不和老板进行长时间的“友好”晚餐，私下讨论自己的问题。每次晚餐后，他都会稍微振作一些，但过一段时间后，情况又会开始恶化。迟早有一天，他会和老板进行最后一次晚餐，在这次晚餐上，他会被友好地解雇。然后，他又会去找另一份工作，周而复始。他感到困扰的一点是，他觉得销售员总是需要撒谎和欺骗，这让他很不舒服。

As a result of his treatment, Jack broke loose from his uncle and decided to go back to school and become a social worker.

由于接受了治疗，杰克摆脱了叔叔的控制，决定重返校园，成为一名社会工作者。

CLINICAL ANALYSIS

临床分析

Thesis : Sisyphus works very hard and gets right to the brink of success. At that point he gives up, stops working, and loses everything he has gained. Then he has to start over from the bottom, and repeats the cycle.

论点：西西弗斯辛勤劳作，几乎就要成功了。然而，就在这时，他放弃了，停止了工作，失去了所有已获得的成果。然后，他不得不从头再来，周而复始。

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS:
临床诊断： 		Depressive reaction.
抑郁反应。
MYTH:
神话： 		Sisyphus.
西西弗斯。
ROLES:
角色： 		Deserted Child , Persecutor, Rescuer.
被遗弃的孩子、迫害者、拯救者。
SWITCHES:
开关： 		Hero (success) to Victim (failure) to Rescuer.
从英雄（成功）到受害者（失败）再到拯救者。
PARENTAL PRECEPT:
父母训诫： 		‘Be a tough hero, not a sissy.’
“要做个坚强的英雄，别做个娘娘腔。”
PARENTAL PATTERN:
父母模式： 		‘Cheat a little.’
“稍微作弊一下。”
PARENTAL INJUNCTION:
父母禁令： 		‘Don’t succeed.’
“不要成功。”
CHILDHOOD SLOGAN:
童年口号： 		‘I am the son of a hero.’
“我是英雄之子。”
POSITION:
位置： 		‘I’m not-OK because I’m really a sissy.’
“我感觉不太好，因为我其实是个娘娘腔。”
‘They’re OK because they’re successful.’
“他们没问题，因为他们很成功。”
DECISION:
决定： 		‘I’ve got to be a hero.’
“我必须成为英雄。”
SCRIPT:
脚本： 		Don’t make it.
别做。
SWEATSHIRT:
运动衫： 		Front – ‘I’m a Super-Salesman.’
正面——“我是一名超级销售员。”
Back – ‘But Don’t Buy Anything from Me.’
返回——“但不要从我这里买任何东西。”
GAMES:
游戏： 		‘There I Go Again,’
《我又来了》
‘Schlemiel.’
“笨蛋。”
TRADING STAMPS:
交易邮票： 		Depressions and guilts.
抑郁和内疚。
FINAL PAYOFF:
最终回报： 		Impotence and suicide.
阳痿与自杀。
EPITAPHS:
墓志铭： 		‘He Tried Hard.’
“他很努力。”
‘I Didn’t Make It.’
“我没成功。”
ANTITHESIS:
对立： 		Stop listening to your uncle.
别听你叔叔的。
PERMISSION:
允许： 		To go back to school and be a social worker for deserted children.
重返校园，成为一名为被遗弃儿童服务的社工。

CLASSIFICATION

分类

Sisyphus is a loser’s script, since every time he gets near the top he rolls all the way down again. It is a Goal-Structured Can’t Script, with the slogan: ‘Without me you can’t make it.’ It is based on an ‘Over and Over’ plan, ‘Try as often as you want to.’ The time between Hello and Good-by is structured with a game of ‘There I Go Again.’

西西弗斯的故事是一个失败者的剧本，因为他每次接近顶峰，都会一路滚落下去。这是一个目标导向的“不可能”剧本，口号是：“没有我，你做不到。”它基于“一遍又一遍”的计划，“想尝试多少次就尝试多少次”。从“你好”到“再见”之间的这段时间，就像一场“我又来了”的游戏。

C • Little Miss Muffet, or You Can’t Scare Me

C • 小玛菲特小姐，或者你吓不倒我

Muffy sat on a bar stool night after night, drinking whiskey sours. One evening a rather rough character sat down beside her. He frightened her, but she didn’t run away. Eventually she married him in order to take care of him so that he could write better novels. When he was drunk he beat her physically and when he was sober, he humiliated her verbally, but still she didn’t run away. The group members were at first sorry for her and horrified at her husband’s behavior, but as the months elapsed, their attitude changed.

玛菲夜复一夜地坐在酒吧的高脚凳上，喝着威士忌酸酒。一天晚上，一个粗鲁的男人在她旁边坐了下来。他吓坏了她，但她没有逃走。最终，为了照顾他，让他能写出更好的小说，她嫁给了他。他喝醉时会殴打她，清醒时会羞辱她，但她仍然没有离开。起初，小组成员们对她感到同情，对她丈夫的行为感到震惊，但几个月过去了，他们的态度发生了变化。

‘How about getting up off your tuffet and doing something about it?’ they would say. ‘You seem real happy when you have a sad story to tell us, so you’re really playing a hard game of “Ain’t it Awful.”’

他们会说：“不如你从凳子上站起来，做点什么吧。你讲悲伤的故事时看起来很高兴，所以你其实是在玩‘真是太糟糕了’的游戏。”

One day Dr Q asked her what her favorite fairy tale was.

有一天，Q博士问她最喜欢的童话故事是什么。

‘I don’t have one,’ she replied. ‘But I have a favorite nursery rhyme, “Little Miss Muffet.”’

“我没有，”她回答说。“但我最喜欢的童谣是《小玛菲特小姐》。”

‘So that’s why you sit on your tuffet.’

所以这就是你坐在小凳子上的原因吧。

‘Yes, I was sitting on one when he met me.’

“是的，我当时就坐在一个上面，他遇见了我。”

‘So why doesn’t he frighten you away?’

“那他为什么不吓跑你呢？”

‘Because when I was little, my mother told me if I ever ran away from home I would get into worse trouble than I was in already.’

“因为我小时候，我妈妈告诉我，如果我离家出走，我会陷入比现在更严重的麻烦。”

‘Well, what about the original tuffet?’ someone asked.

“那么，原来的矮凳呢？”有人问道。

‘Oh, you mean the potty? Well, they certainly made me sit there, and they frightened me with their threats, but I was too scared to get up and run away.’

“哦，你是说便盆吗？嗯，他们确实让我坐在那里，还用威胁吓唬我，但我太害怕了，不敢起来逃跑。”

Thus her script was like Miss Muffet’s, only she wasn’t allowed to run away, and didn’t know where she could run to. Meanwhile, instead of whey she drank whiskey. The group gave her permission to get up off her tuffet, throw away her whey, and strike out for herself. Previously, she had always looked sour, but now she began to smile.

所以她的剧本和玛菲特小姐的剧本很像，只是她不被允许逃跑，也不知道能逃到哪里去。与此同时，她喝的不是乳清，而是威士忌。大家允许她离开小凳子，扔掉乳清，独自闯荡。以前她总是愁眉苦脸的，但现在她开始笑了。

What her husband knew was that after you said Hello to Miss Muffet, you said Boo! and she was supposed to run away. Most girls did, but Muffy didn’t. If you say Boo! to Miss Muffet and she doesn’t run away, the only thing to do is say Boo! again, and that is what he did. In fact, one way or another, that was about all he ever said to her, except maybe Pooh!

她丈夫知道，跟玛菲小姐打完招呼后，要喊一声“Boo！”，她就会跑开。大多数女孩都会跑，但玛菲没有。如果你对玛菲小姐喊“Boo！”她没有跑，唯一的办法就是再喊一声“Boo！”，而他也确实这么做了。事实上，不管怎样，除了可能还会说“小熊维尼”之外，他几乎只跟她说过这几句话。

CLINICAL ANALYSIS

临床分析

Thesis : Little Miss Muffet sits on a tuffet feeling curdy and waiting for a spider, which is all she can hope for. When he comes he tries to frighten her, but she decides that he is the most beautiful spider in the world and stays with him. He continues to frighten her periodically and she refuses to run away. But when he says that she frightens him, that really scares her. She looks around for another spider, but can’t find one as beautiful as her own, so she sticks with him as long as she can help him spin.

论点：小玛菲特坐在矮凳上，心情烦躁，盼望着一只蜘蛛的到来，这是她唯一的愿望。蜘蛛来了，想吓唬她，但她却觉得它是世界上最漂亮的蜘蛛，于是留下来陪它。蜘蛛时不时地吓唬她，她也不肯逃走。可是，当蜘蛛说她吓到它时，她真的吓坏了。她四处寻找另一只蜘蛛，却找不到像她这只一样漂亮的，所以只要能帮它吐丝结茧，她就一直陪着它。

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS:
临床诊断： 		Character disorder.
人格障碍。
NURSERY RHYME:
童谣： 		Little Miss Muffet.
小玛菲特小姐。
ROLES:
角色： 		Rescuer , Victim.
救援者，受害者。
SWITCHES:
开关： 		Victim (of circumstances) to Rescuer (of men) to Victim (of men).
（环境的）受害者到（男性的）救助者到（男性的）受害者。
PARENTAL PRECEPT:
父母训诫： 		‘Don’t give up.’
不要放弃。
PARENTAL PATTERN:
父母模式： 		‘Here’s how to endure it – drink.’
“忍受的办法就是喝酒。”
PARENTAL INJUNCTION:
父母禁令： 		‘Don’t leave, or you’ll get into worse trouble.’
“别走，否则你会惹上更大的麻烦。”
POSITION:
位置： 		‘I’m OK – if I help him produce.’
“如果我能帮他生产，我就没问题。”
‘He’s OK – he’s producing.’
“他没事——他正在工作。”
DECISION:
决定： 		‘If I can’t produce, I’ll find someone who can.’
“如果我做不了，我会找能做的人。”
SWEATSHIRT:
运动衫： 		Front – ‘I Can Handle It.’
正面 – ‘我能应付。’
Back – ‘Kick Me.’
返回 – ‘踢我。’
GAMES:
游戏： 		‘Kick Me,’ ‘Ain’t It Awful.’
“踢我”，“真是太糟糕了。”
ANTITHESIS:
对立： 		Stop sitting on your tuffet and stop drinking.
别再坐在小凳子上了，也别再喝酒了。
PERMISSION:
允许： 		To strike out on her own.
她决定独自闯荡。

CLASSIFICATION

分类

Little Miss Muffet is a nonwinner’s script. She is not ever going to get ahead, but at least she has a spider to sit down beside her. It is a Goal-Structured Can Script with the slogan: ‘You can help him produce.’ It is based on an ‘Until’ plan, ‘Sit by yourself until you meet a spider prince, then you can start living.’ The time between Hello and Good Night is structured with quarrels and drinking and loving and work.

《小玛菲特》是一个注定失败的故事。她永远不会出人头地，但至少她身边有只蜘蛛可以陪伴。这是一个目标导向的“可行计划”故事，其口号是：“你可以帮助他创造未来。”它基于一个“直到”计划：“独自一人待着，直到遇到蜘蛛王子，然后你才能开始真正地生活。”从“你好”到“晚安”这段时间，充满了争吵、喝酒、恋爱和工作。

D • Old Soldiers Never Die, or Who Needs Me?

D • 老兵永不消亡，或者谁需要我？

Mac was a brave soldier and took good care of his men. But one day through ignorance or disobedience a lot of them got killed, and Mac blamed himself. That, along with malaria, malnutrition, and a few other things, caused him to break down. When he recovered he worked and worked and worked so he wouldn’t think, but no matter how hard he worked he never seemed to get ahead, and there was always more work to be done if he wanted to get out of debt. Mac was a caterer and went to all sorts of weddings and other celebrations, but he never had anything to celebrate himself. He was always an onlooker, helping other people feel good with food, drink, comfort, and advice, and that made him feel needed, as much as he could feel that way. The worst time was at night when he was alone and his thoughts went round and round. The best times were on Saturday night, when he got drunk and could forget and was almost one of the crowd.

麦克是个勇敢的士兵，对部下照顾有加。但有一天，由于无知或违抗命令，许多士兵阵亡，麦克为此自责不已。疟疾、营养不良以及其他一些疾病让他精神崩溃。康复后，他拼命工作，试图让自己不去想太多，但无论他多么努力，似乎都无法摆脱困境，而且要想还清债务，总有更多的工作要做。麦克是个餐饮承办人，经常参加各种婚礼和其他庆祝活动，但他自己却从未有过值得庆祝的事情。他总是旁观者，用食物、饮料、安慰和建议让别人感到快乐，这让他觉得自己被需要，尽管这种感觉很渺小。最难熬的是夜晚，他独自一人，思绪纷乱。最美好的时光是星期六晚上，他喝得酩酊大醉，忘却一切烦恼，几乎融入了人群。

This started long before he went into the army. His mother ran away with a soldier when he was six, and when he knew she was gone for sure, he fell into a raging fever and tried to die, because that meant she didn’t need him. He began to work hard very early in high school, but whenever he got a little ahead, his father would somehow trick him out of the money. If he bought something for himself, his father would sell it. He was jealous of the other boys at school because they had mothers, and got into lots of fights. He didn’t mind bloody noses in the schoolyard, but he couldn’t stand the sight of dead bodies in the war. He was a good marksman, but he always felt sorry for the enemies he killed, nor did he hold it against them that his own men got killed. Because he blamed himself for that, he felt that his dead buddies were watching from somewhere, so he was very careful not to add insult to injury by having a good time. Except when he was drunk, and that didn’t count – or did it? He could never be sure. Once or twice he tried to crash his car, and did get badly banged up, but survived. His chief way of trying to kill himself was by smoking heavily even when he had bronchitis. After a long period of treatment, he made friends with his mother, and that made him feel better again.

这一切在他参军之前很久就开始了。六岁那年，他的母亲跟一个士兵私奔了。当他确信母亲真的走了之后，他高烧不退，试图结束自己的生命，因为这意味着母亲不再需要他了。高中时，他很早就开始努力学习，但每当他稍微领先一步，父亲就会想方设法骗走他的钱。如果他给自己买了什么东西，父亲就会把它卖掉。他嫉妒学校里其他有母亲的男孩，经常和他们打架。他不介意在操场上被人打得鼻青脸肿，但却无法忍受看到战场上的尸体。他枪法很准，但他总是为自己杀死的敌人感到难过，也不会因为自己战友的牺牲而责怪他们。因为他为此自责，他觉得死去的战友们在某个地方看着他，所以他非常小心，从不让自己的享乐雪上加霜。除非他喝醉了，而那不算数——或者说，真的不算吗？他始终无法确定。他曾一两次试图驾车撞毁车辆，虽然都受了重伤，但都活了下来。他主要的自杀方式是即使患有支气管炎也大量吸烟。经过长时间的治疗，他与母亲重归于好，这让他感觉好多了。

CLINICAL ANALYSIS

临床分析

Thesis : The old soldier wasn’t good enough for his mother and failed his friends. As a result, he is condemned to work hard forever without getting ahead. He is a spectator in life and cannot join in the fun. He is always willing to help others, and that means more work, but it makes him feel needed. Death will be his only release, but he can’t hurt the ones who love him by actual suicide. All he can do is slowly fade away.

论点：这位老兵辜负了母亲的期望，也辜负了朋友的期望。因此，他注定要永远辛勤劳作却始终无法出人头地。他只能作为人生的旁观者，无法参与其中。他总是乐于助人，这意味着他要付出更多，但这让他感到自己被需要。死亡是他唯一的解脱，但他无法通过自杀伤害那些爱他的人。他所能做的，只是慢慢地消逝。

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS:
临床诊断： 		Compensated schizophrenia.
代偿性精神分裂症。
SONG:
歌曲： 		Old Soldiers Never Die.
老兵不死。
ROLES:
角色： 		Failed Rescuer , Persecutor, Victim.
失败的救援者、迫害者、受害者。
SWITCHES:
开关： 		Victim (of mother and father) to Rescuer (of men) to Victim (of circumstances).
（父母的）受害者到（男人的）救助者到（环境的）受害者。
PARENTAL PRECEPT:
父母训诫： 		‘Work hard and help people.’
“努力工作，帮助他人。”
PARENTAL PATTERN:
父母模式： 		‘Here’s how to endure it – drink.’
“忍受的办法就是喝酒。”
PARENTAL INJUNCTION:
父母禁令： 		‘Don’t get ahead.’
“不要自作聪明。”
POSITION:
位置： 		‘I’m not-OK.’
“我不太好。”
‘They’re all OK.’
“他们都很好。”
DECISION:
决定： 		‘I’ll work myself to death.’
“我会工作到死。”
SWEATSHIRT:
运动衫： 		Front – ‘I’m a nice guy.’
正面——“我是一个好人。”
Back – ‘Even if it kills me.’
返回——“即使这会要了我的命。”
PASTIME:
消遣： 		Reminiscing about the war.
回忆战争。
GAME:
游戏： 		‘I’m Only Trying to Help You.’
“我只是想帮你。”
ANTITHESIS:
对立： 		Stop killing yourself.
别再自杀了。
PERMISSION:
允许： 		Tune in and get ahead.
收看节目，抢占先机。

CLASSIFICATION

分类

Old Soldier is a nonwinner’s script because it is a point of honor with old soldiers not to get ahead. It is a Goal-Structured Can’t Script with the slogan: ‘You can’t get ahead until they need you again.’ It is based on an ‘After’ plan, ‘After the war is over you can only fade away.’ The waiting time is filled by helping people and soldier talk.

《老兵》是一部“非赢家剧本”，因为对老兵来说，不争名利是一种荣誉。它是一种目标导向的“不可能剧本”，其口号是：“只有当他们再次需要你的时候，你才能出人头地。”它基于一个“战后”计划：“战争结束后，你只能逐渐淡出人们的视线。”等待的时间则用来帮助他人和与老兵交谈。

E • The Dragon-Slayer or Daddy Knows Best

E • 屠龙者或爸爸最懂

Once upon a time there was a man named George, who was equally celebrated for slaying dragons and for fertilizing barren women. He wandered around the countryside as a completely free spirit – or so it seemed. Cantering through the meadows on a summer’s day, he saw columns of smoke and forks of flame shooting upward in the distance. As he approached the scene, he heard a terrible roaring, mingled with the shrill screams of a maiden in distress. ‘Aha!’ he cried, couching his lance. ‘This is my third dragon and maiden in less than a week. I will slay the dragon, and no doubt my bravery will be richly rewarded.’ A moment later he cried to the dragon: ‘Avast, lubber!’ and to the maiden: ‘Have no fear!’ The dragon drew back and began to paw the ground in anticipation not only of a double meal, but also of what he loved best, a good fight. The maiden, whose name was Ursula, threw her arms out and cried: ‘My hero! I am saved.’ She was delighted, not only in anticipation of being saved and watching a good fight, but also (since she was not really a maiden) at the prospect of showing gratitude to her rescuer.

从前有个名叫乔治的男人，他屠龙的本领和让不孕的女子受孕的本领都同样闻名遐迩。他像个完全自由的精灵一样在乡间游荡——至少表面上看起来是这样。在一个夏日，他策马驰骋在草地上，看到远处升腾起缕缕浓烟和火焰。他循声而去，听到一声可怕的咆哮，夹杂着少女凄厉的尖叫。“啊哈！”他喊道，同时收起了长矛。“这已经是不到一周内我遇到的第三条龙和第三位少女了。我一定要屠龙，我的英勇必将得到丰厚的回报。”片刻之后，他对着巨龙喊道：“滚开，笨蛋！”又对少女说：“别害怕！”巨龙后退一步，开始刨地，它不仅期待着一顿丰盛的晚餐，更期待着它最爱的——一场酣畅淋漓的战斗。这位名叫乌苏拉的少女张开双臂，喊道：“我的英雄！我得救了！”她欣喜若狂，不仅因为自己获救并期待观看一场精彩的战斗，而且（因为她实际上并非少女）也因为有机会向救命恩人表达感激之情。

George and the dragon backed off from each other, preparing for the charge, while Ursula cheered them both on. At that moment, another figure appeared on the scene, richly accoutered with a silver-mounted saddle and fat alforjas filled with golden coins.

乔治和巨龙各自后退，准备发起冲锋，乌苏拉则在一旁为他们加油鼓劲。就在这时，另一个身影出现在众人面前，他身披华丽的银饰马鞍，胸前挎着装满金币的鼓。

‘Hey boy!’ cried the new arrival. George turned and said in surprise: ‘Father! How nice to see you!’ He turned his back on the dragon, dismounted from his horse, and went to kiss his father’s foot. A lively conversation ensued, with George saying ‘Yes, father. Certainly, father. Whatever you say, father.’ Neither Ursula nor the dragon could hear father’s side of the conversation, but it soon became apparent that it was going to go on indefinitely.

“嘿，孩子！”新来的人喊道。乔治转过身，惊讶地说：“爸爸！见到您真高兴！”他背对着巨龙，下了马，走过去亲吻父亲的脚。父子俩开始热烈地交谈起来，乔治说：“是的，爸爸。当然，爸爸。您说什么都行，爸爸。”乌苏拉和巨龙都听不到父亲那边的对话，但很快他们就意识到，这场对话将会没完没了地持续下去。

‘Oh, for Christ’s sake!’ said Ursula, stamping her foot in disgust. ‘Some hero! As soon as his old man appears, he’s right over there bowing and scraping, and he has no time for poor little me.’

“我的天哪！”乌苏拉厌恶地跺了跺脚，“真是个英雄！他老爸一出现，他就立刻跪舔，根本没空搭理我这个可怜的小家伙。”

‘You said it,’ said the dragon. ‘This is going to go on forever.’ So he turned off his flame thrower and rolled over and fell asleep.

“你说得对，”巨龙说，“这将会永远持续下去。”于是他关掉火焰喷射器，翻了个身，睡着了。

But eventually the old man rode off, and George was ready to return to the fray. He couched his lance again, and waited for the dragon to get up and charge and Ursula to cheer him on. Instead Ursula said: ‘Jerk!’ and walked away. The dragon got to his feet and said ‘Crumb!’ and he, too, walked away. When George saw that, he yelled: ‘Hey dad!’ and galloped after his father. Ursula and the dragon both turned at the same moment and both shouted after him: ‘Too bad he’s so old, or I’d take him on instead of you.’

但最终老人骑马离去，乔治准备重返战场。他重新收起长矛，等着巨龙起身冲锋，等着乌苏拉为他加油助威。没想到乌苏拉却骂了句“混蛋！”，然后走开了。巨龙站起身，骂了句“该死！”，也走开了。乔治见状，大喊一声“嘿，爸爸！”，策马追了上去。乌苏拉和巨龙同时转过身，齐声喊道：“可惜他年纪大了，不然我就替你去对付他了。”

F • Sigmund, or If You Can’t Do It One Way, Try Another

F • 西格蒙德，或者说，如果你不能用一种方法做，那就试试另一种方法

Sigmund decided to be a great man. He was a hard worker, and tried to get into the Establishment, which would have been Heaven for him, but they wouldn’t let him in. So he decided to look into Hell instead. There was no Establishment there, and no one was paying any attention to it. So he became an authority on Hell, which in this case was the Unconscious. He was so successful that after a while he became the Establishment.

西格蒙德决心成为一个伟大的人。他勤奋努力，试图进入所谓的“体制内”，对他来说，那将是天堂，但他们却拒绝了他。于是，他决定转而研究地狱。那里没有“体制内”，也没有人关注它。因此，他成为了地狱的权威，而他所研究的地狱，实际上就是无意识。他如此成功，以至于不久之后，他自己就成为了“体制内”的一员。

CLINICAL ANALYSIS

临床分析

Thesis : Jeder decides to be a great man. People put all sorts of obstacles in his way. Instead of spending his life fighting them head on, he goes around them to find a challenge worthy of his mettle, and becomes a great man.

论点：杰德决心成为伟大的人。人们在他前进的道路上设置了各种各样的障碍。他没有选择正面对抗，而是绕过这些障碍，寻找真正能发挥他才能的挑战，最终成为了伟大的人。

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS:
临床诊断： 		Phobias.
恐惧症。
HEROES:
英雄： 		Hannibal and Napoleon.
汉尼拔和拿破仑。
ROLES:
角色： 		Hero , Opponents.
英雄，对手。
SWITCHES:
开关： 		Hero, Victim, Hero.
英雄，受害者，英雄。
PARENTAL PRECEPT:
父母训诫： 		‘Work hard, and don’t give up.’
努力工作，永不放弃。
PARENTAL PATTERN:
父母模式： 		‘Use your intelligence and find out what to do about it.’
“运用你的智慧，找出解决办法。”
PARENTAL INJUNCTION:
父母禁令： 		‘Be a great man.’
“要做一个伟大的人。”
POSITION:
位置： 		‘I’m OK – if I produce.’
“如果我能拿出成绩，我就没问题。”
‘They’re OK – if they think.’
“如果他们会思考，他们就没事。”
DECISION:
决定： 		‘If I can’t get to Heaven, I’ll move Hell.’
“如果我上不了天堂，我就去地狱。”
SWEATSHIRT:
运动衫： 		None visible.
没有可见部分。
TRADING STAMPS:
交易邮票： 		Not a collector.
我不是收藏家。
GAME:
游戏： 		No time for games.
没时间玩游戏。
ANTITHESIS:
对立： 		None necessary.
无需这样做。
PERMISSION:
允许： 		Already has enough.
已经足够了。

CLASSIFICATION

分类

This is a winner’s script because Jeder is script-driven and does what he has to do. It is a Goal-Structured Can Script with the slogan ‘If you can’t do it one way you can try another.’ It is based on an ‘Always’ plan, ‘Always keep trying.’ After Hello, the next thing is to get to work.

这是一份制胜的剧本，因为杰德严格按照剧本行事，并且会完成他必须做的事情。这是一份目标导向的“可行剧本”，其口号是“如果一种方法行不通，你可以尝试另一种方法”。它基于“始终”的计划，“始终坚持尝试”。问候过后，下一步就是开始工作。

G • Florence, or See It Through

G • 佛罗伦萨，或看完它

Florence’s mother wanted her to marry well and settle down to a life in high society, but God’s voice came to Florence and told her that her destiny was to serve the human race. For fourteen years everyone around her fought her decision, but at last she prevailed and began her career as a nurse. By tremendous efforts and still against opposition from those around her, she gained the favor of the Establishment and even of the Queen. She dedicated herself completely to her work and would have no part of intrigue or public acclaim. She revolutionized not only nursing, but also public health throughout the British Empire.

弗洛伦斯的母亲希望她嫁个好人家，过上流社会的生活，但上帝的声音告诉弗洛伦斯，她的使命是服务于人类。十四年来，她身边的人都反对她的决定，但最终她坚持己见，开始了她的护士生涯。凭借着巨大的努力，尽管周围人反对，她还是赢得了上流社会乃至女王的青睐。她全身心投入工作，不参与任何阴谋诡计，也不追求公众的赞誉。她不仅革新了护理事业，也彻底改变了整个大英帝国的公共卫生。

CLINICAL ANALYSIS

临床分析

Thesis : Florence’s mother wants her to be socially ambitious, but somewhere inside her a voice says she is destined for greater things. She fights her mother vigorously to gain her way. Other people put obstacles in her way, but instead of spending her time playing games with them, she goes around them to find more challenges, and becomes a heroine.

论点：弗洛伦斯的母亲希望她能在社会上有所建树，但她内心深处却有一个声音告诉她，她注定要成就一番更大的事业。她奋力反抗母亲，力图实现自己的目标。其他人也给她设置了重重障碍，但她并没有与他们周旋，而是绕过他们去寻找新的挑战，最终成为了一位女英雄。

CLINICAL DIAGNOSIS:
临床诊断： 		Adolescent crisis with hallucinations.
伴有幻觉的青少年危机。
HEROINE:
女英雄： 		Joan of Arc.
圣女贞德。
ROLES:
角色： 		Heroine , Opponents.
女主角，对手。
SWITCHES:
开关： 		Victim, Heroine.
受害者，女英雄。
PARENTAL PRECEPT:
父母训诫： 		‘Marry rich.’
“嫁给有钱人。”
PARENTAL PATTERN:
父母模式： 		‘Do as you’re told.’
“照我说的做。”
PARENTAL INJUNCTION:
父母禁令： 		‘Don’t talk back.’
“别顶嘴。”
HALLUCINATED INJUNCTION (presumably father’s voice):
幻觉中的禁令（大概是父亲的声音）： 		‘Be a heroine like Joan of Arc.’
“要做像圣女贞德那样的女英雄。”
POSITION:
位置： 		‘I’m OK – if I produce.’
“如果我能拿出成绩，我就没问题。”
‘They’re OK – if they let me.’
“他们没问题——如果他们让我进去的话。”
DECISION:
决定： 		‘If I can’t serve humanity one way, I’ll serve it another.’
“如果我不能用一种方法为人类服务，我就会用另一种方法为人类服务。”
SWEATSHIRT:
运动衫： 		Front – ‘Take care of the soldiers.’
前线——“照顾好士兵们。”
Back – ‘Do it better than before.’
回来——“做得比以前更好。”
TRADING STAMPS:
交易邮票： 		Not a collector.
我不是收藏家。
GAME:
游戏： 		No time for games.
没时间玩游戏。
ANTITHESIS:
对立： 		None necessary.
无需这样做。
PERMISSION:
允许： 		Already has enough.
已经足够了。

CLASSIFICATION

分类

This is a winner’s script and is classified the same as the one above. In both these cases, the subjects have taken losing scripts (Hannibal, Napoleon, Joan of Arc) and turned them into winning ones despite all external opposition. This was accomplished by leaving alternatives open so that they could go around the opposition instead of meeting it head on. This is the quality of flexibility, which in no way diminishes determination or effectiveness. Thus, if Napoleon and Joan of Arc had made conditional decisions, their script payoffs would have been quite different: for example, ‘If I can’t fight the English, I’ll fight disease.’

这是一个胜利者的剧本，与上文所述剧本的分类相同。在这两个例子中，主人公（汉尼拔、拿破仑、圣女贞德）都将原本注定失败的剧本转化为胜利的剧本，克服了所有外部阻力。他们通过保留备选方案来实现这一点，从而能够绕过阻力，而不是正面迎击。这就是灵活性的体现，它丝毫不会削弱决心或效率。因此，如果拿破仑和圣女贞德做出的是条件性决策，那么他们的剧本最终结果将会截然不同：例如，“如果我无法与英国人作战，我就与疾病作斗争。”

H • Tragic Scripts

H • 悲剧剧本

There is still considerable debate as to whether winners are winners because they have winning scripts, or because they have permission to be autonomous. But there is little doubt that losers are following the programing of their parents and the urgings of their own inner demons. Tragic scripts (which Steiner calls ‘hamartic’ ones 1 ) may be either noble or ignoble. The noble ones are a source of inspiration and of noble dramas. The ignoble ones repeat the same old scenes and the same old plots with the same drab cast, set in the dreary ‘catchment areas’ which society conveniently supplies as depots where losers can collect their payoffs: saloons, pawnshops, brothels, courtrooms, prisons, state hospitals, and morgues. Because of the stereotyped outcomes, it is easy to see the scripty elements in such life courses. Thus, books on psychiatry and criminology which give numerous and extensive case histories are excellent sources for studying scripts. 2

关于成功者之所以成功，是因为他们拥有成功的剧本，还是因为他们被允许自主行事，至今仍存在诸多争论。但毫无疑问，失败者遵循着父母的教条和内心恶魔的驱使。悲剧剧本（施泰纳称之为“缺陷”剧本）可以是高尚的，也可以是卑劣的。高尚的剧本是灵感的源泉，也是高尚戏剧的创作源泉。卑劣的剧本则重复着同样的场景和情节，由同样的乏味角色演绎，故事发生在社会精心安排的阴郁“收容区”：酒吧、当铺、妓院、法庭、监狱、公立医院和停尸房，失败者们在这里领取他们的“报酬”。由于结局千篇一律，我们很容易在这样的人生轨迹中看到剧本式的痕迹。因此，提供大量详尽案例的精神病学和犯罪学书籍是研究剧本的绝佳资料来源。

A bad script is laid on the child by the Fascist Sneer, and he clings to it on the principle of the Nostalgic Prisoner. The Fascist Sneer is as old as history, and works as follows. The people are told that the enemy king or leader is filthy, incoherent, debased, and brutish, more animal than human. When he is captured, he is put in a cage with a few rags, no toilet facilities, and no eating utensils. After a week or so he is exhibited to the people, and sure enough, he is filthy, incoherent, debased, and brutish, and gets more and more so as time goes on. Then the conquerors smile and say: ‘I told you so.’

法西斯式的嘲讽给孩子灌输了一种错误的观念，而孩子却出于怀旧的心态紧紧抓住这种观念不放。法西斯式的嘲讽由来已久，其运作方式如下：先告诉民众敌方的国王或领袖肮脏、语无伦次、堕落、野蛮，简直比动物还不如。俘虏之后，把他关进笼子里，里面只有几件破布，没有厕所，也没有餐具。大约一周后，他被示众，果然不出所料，他肮脏、语无伦次、堕落、野蛮，而且随着时间的推移，情况越来越糟。然后，征服者们会笑着说：“我早就告诉过你们了。”

Children are essentially captives of their parents, and can be reduced to any state the parents desire. For example, a girl is told that she is a hysterical, self-pitying crybaby. The parents know her weak spot and can torment her in front of visitors until she finds it intolerable and is reduced to tears. Since this is labeled ‘self-pity,’ she tries hard not to cry, and so when she does give way, it is like an explosion. Then the parents can say: ‘What a hysterical reaction! Every time we have visitors she does that. What a crybaby,’ etc. The key question of script analysis research is: ‘How would you raise a child so that when she grew up, she would react the way this patient does?’ In answering this question, the script analyst more and more frequently is able to describe the patient’s upbringing accurately before he is told about it.
