孩子本质上是父母的俘虏，可以被父母塑造成任何他们想要的状态。例如，一个女孩被告知她是个歇斯底里、自怜自艾的爱哭鬼。父母知道她的弱点，可以在访客面前折磨她，直到她无法忍受，最终泪流满面。由于这种行为被贴上了“自怜”的标签，她会努力克制自己不哭，所以一旦崩溃，就像爆炸一样。这时父母就可以说：“真是歇斯底里！每次有访客她都这样。真是个爱哭鬼！”等等。脚本分析研究的关键问题是：“你会如何养育一个孩子，让她长大后像这位病人一样？”在回答这个问题时，脚本分析师越来越能够在被告知病人的成长经历之前，就准确地描述出病人的成长经历。

Many people who have spent long years in prison find the outside world cold, difficult, and frightening, and commit an offense in order to be sent back to prison. It may be miserable, but it is familiar, they know the rules so as to keep out of serious trouble, and there are old friends there. In the same way, when a patient attempts to break out of his script cage, he finds it cold ‘out there,’ and since he no longer plays the old games, he loses his old friends and has to make new ones, which is often scary. Therefore he slides back into his old ways, like a Nostalgic Prisoner.

许多在监狱里待了多年的人觉得外面的世界冷酷、艰难、可怕，于是他们故意犯罪，希望重返监狱。监狱或许很痛苦，但却很熟悉，他们了解规矩，所以不会惹上大麻烦，而且那里还有老朋友。同样，当一个病人试图挣脱他固有的思维模式时，他会发现“外面的世界”很冷酷，因为他不再玩以前的游戏，他失去了老朋友，不得不结交新朋友，这往往令人恐惧。因此，他就像一个怀旧的囚犯，滑回了以前的生活方式。

All this may make the script and its effects a little more understandable.

这一切或许能让剧本及其效果更容易理解一些。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 Steiner, C. M. Games Alcoholics Play. Loc. cit . Liddell and Scott give several variants of which the most relevant is hamartetikos (prone to failure), from Aristotle, Eth. N.2, 3, 7.

1 Steiner, C. M. Games Alcoholics Play. 同上。Liddell 和 Scott 给出了几个变体，其中最相关的是 hamartetikos（容易失败），出自亚里士多德，《民族志》第 2、3、7 章。

2 One of the most recent, and most enlightening and convincing studies of a particular kind of loser is Another Look at Sex Offenders in California , by Louise V. Frisbie. (California Department of Mental Hygiene, Sacramento, 1969.) While there is reason to believe that the author knows at least of the existence of script analysis, characteristically (of criminologists) she ignores it, while offering many clear examples of scripty behavior. E.g., a man was put on three years’ probation and committed no known offenses until two weeks before his probation expired. He could offer no explanation for becoming involved, but managed to get arrested for ‘perversion’ with a prostitute (p. 60). Ben Karpman’s two-volume Studies in Criminal Psychopathology (Medical Science Press, Washington, D.C., 1933 and 1944) offer fascinating examples of hamartia with full case histories. The first volume was published in the midst of the first wave of ‘bottom dog’ books during the Great Depression, heralded by Edward Dahlberg’s novel of that name ( Bottom Dogs , 1930) and was far more interesting and convincing than most of the fiction published during that period. The current wave of bottom-dog literature (dating perhaps from William Burroughs’ Naked Lunch [Grove Press, New York, 1962]) is more sophisticated, but no less dreary and stereotyped. From the script point of view, nothing has changed during the past thirty years, not even the style, which, after all, goes back to Joyce’s Ulysses (1922) or at least to his Work in Progress ( Finnegans Wake ) and other things published in transition of the late twenties. Joyce even wore dark glasses, like many of his current imitators. (Dr Stephen Karpman, incidentally, originator of the Drama Triangle described in Chapter 10, is Dr Ben Karpman’s son.)

2 近期最引人入胜、最具启发性和说服力的研究之一是路易丝·V·弗里斯比 (Louise V. Frisbie) 的《加州性犯罪者再探》(Another Look at Sex Offenders in California)（加州心理卫生部，萨克拉门托，1969 年）。尽管有理由相信作者至少了解脚本分析的存在，但她却一如既往地（犯罪学家的惯常做法）对此视而不见，同时提供了许多清晰的脚本行为案例。例如，一名男子被判处三年缓刑，在缓刑期满前两周才犯下已知的罪行。他无法解释自己为何卷入其中，却因与妓女发生“变态行为”而被捕（第 60 页）。本·卡普曼 (Ben Karpman) 的两卷本《犯罪精神病理学研究》(Studies in Criminal Psychopathology)（医学科学出版社，华盛顿特区，1933 年和 1944 年）提供了大量关于过失性行为的精彩案例，并附有完整的案例历史。第一卷出版于大萧条时期，正值第一波“底层人物”小说浪潮兴起之际，这股浪潮的先驱是爱德华·达尔伯格的同名小说《底层人物》（1930）。与当时出版的大多数小说相比，第一卷更有趣、更引人入胜。如今的“底层人物”文学浪潮（或许可以追溯到威廉·巴勒斯的《裸体午餐》（纽约格罗夫出版社，1962））虽然更加老练，但依然乏味且千篇一律。从剧本的角度来看，过去三十年间没有任何改变，甚至连风格也未曾改变，毕竟其风格可以追溯到乔伊斯的《尤利西斯》（1922），或者至少可以追溯到他的未完成作品《芬尼根守灵夜》以及二十年代末期其他一些过渡时期的作品。乔伊斯甚至像他许多当代的模仿者一样，戴着墨镜。 （顺便一提，第十章中描述的戏剧三角理论的创始人斯蒂芬·卡普曼博士是本·卡普曼博士的儿子。）

#↩

CHAPTER THIRTEEN

第十三章

Cinderella

灰姑娘

A • Cinderella’s Background

A • 灰姑娘的背景

For the script analyst, the story of Cinderella has everything. It includes a large variety of interlocking scripts, innumerable nooks and crannies where delightful new discoveries can be made, and millions of real-life counterparts for every role.

对于剧本分析师来说，《灰姑娘》的故事应有尽有。它包含了各种相互关联的剧本，无数可以进行精彩新发现的角落和缝隙，以及每个角色在现实生活中数百万个原型。

Cinderella in this country usually means ‘The Little Glass Slipper.’ This is a translation of the French version of Charles Perrault, first published in 1697, and first Englished by Robert Samber in 1729. 1 In his dedication to the Countess of Granville, Samber makes it clear that he understands very well the scripty influence of such stories. He says that Plato ‘desires Children might suck in those Fables with their Milk, and recommends it to Nurses to teach them to ’em.’ Perrault’s Morals to the tale of ‘Cinderilla’ were, of course, Parental Precepts.

在这个国家，灰姑娘通常指的是“小玻璃鞋”。这是夏尔·佩罗的法语版《灰姑娘》的英译本，该版本最初出版于1697年，并于1729年由罗伯特·桑伯首次翻译成英文。在献给格朗维尔伯爵夫人的献词中，桑伯明确表示他非常了解这类故事的文学影响。他说，柏拉图“希望孩子们能一边喝奶一边吸收这些寓言故事，并建议保姆们教给孩子们这些故事”。佩罗在《灰姑娘》的故事中传达的道德教训，当然就是父母的教诲。

But that thing, which we call good grace,

但那件我们称之为恩典的事，

Exceeds by far a handsome face;

远胜于英俊的脸庞；

Its charms by far surpass the other,

它的魅力远远胜过其他所有东西。

And this was what her good Godmother

这就是她善良的教母所希望的。

Bestow’d on Cinderilla fair,

赐予灰姑娘的礼物，

Whom she instructed with such care,

她如此细心地教导他们，

And gave her such a graceful mien,

并赋予她如此优雅的气质，

That she became thereby a Queen.

她因此成为了女王。

The last three lines describe the Parental pattern which Cinderella received from her godmother, and which exactly parallels the pattern described for the ‘lady’ in Chapter Six . Perrault also draws a second moral, which stresses the need for Parental permission if a child is ever to amount to anything.

最后三行描述了灰姑娘从教母那里继承的父母模式，这与第六章中对“淑女”的描述完全一致。佩罗还借此引申出第二个寓意，强调孩子若想有所成就，就必须得到父母的许可。

A great advantage ’tis, no doubt, to man,

毫无疑问，这对人类来说是一个巨大的优势。

To have wit, courage, birth, good sense and brain …

拥有智慧、勇气、天赋、良好的判断力和头脑……

But none of these rich graces from above,

但这些来自上天的丰厚恩典，没有一样是真正降临的。

In your advancement in the world will prove

你在世界上的发展将会证明这一点。

Of any use, if Godsires make delay,

如果天意迟迟未至，那也毫无用处。

Or Godmothers your merit to display.

或者让教母们展示你的功绩。

Samber’s translation was slightly changed by Andrew Lang for his Blue Fairy Book , which is one of the most popular fairy-tale books read to and by children, and that is whence they get their first picture of Cinderella. In this kindly French version, Cinderella forgives her two stepsisters, and finds rich husbands for them. Grimm’s Fairy Tales , which are also very popular in this country, contains the German version, called ‘Ashenputtel.’ This is a bloody tale ending with the sisters’ eyes being systematically pecked out by doves. Cinderella stories are found in many other nations. 2

桑伯的译本经安德鲁·朗稍作修改，收录于他的《蓝皮童话书》中。这本书是深受孩子们喜爱的童话故事集，孩子们从中第一次接触到灰姑娘的故事。在这个温馨的法语版本中，灰姑娘原谅了她的两个姐姐，并为她们找到了富有的丈夫。同样在英国广受欢迎的格林童话中，收录了德语版本，名为《灰姑娘》（Ashenputtel）。这是一个血腥的故事，结局是两个姐姐的眼睛被鸽子一个个啄瞎。灰姑娘的故事在许多其他国家也有流传。

With this background, we are ready to consider a Martian view of Cinderella, patterned after Perrault, which is the version most English-speaking children have in mind, and discuss the various scripts involved, many of which will be easily recognizable in real life. What Martian and real life tell us, as in the case of Little Red Riding Hood, is something very important: what happens to the characters after the book story ends.

有了这些背景知识，我们就可以考虑火星人眼中的灰姑娘故事了，这个故事以佩罗的版本为蓝本，这也是大多数英语国家的孩子心中熟悉的版本。我们还可以讨论其中涉及的各种剧本，其中许多剧本在现实生活中很容易辨认。正如小红帽的故事一样，火星人和现实生活都告诉我们一个非常重要的问题：故事结束后，书中的人物会发生什么？

B • The Story of Cinderella

B • 灰姑娘的故事

According to Perrault, there was once upon a time a gentleman who married for his second wife a widow, the proudest and most haughty woman that ever was known. (No doubt, as is usually the case with such brides, she was also frigid.) She had two daughters who were exactly like her in all things. He also had a daughter by his first wife who was good and sweet which she took from her mother, who was the best creature in the world.

据佩罗所说，从前有一位绅士，他的第二任妻子是一位寡妇，她是世上最骄傲、最傲慢的女人。（毫无疑问，像这类新娘一样，她也性情冷淡。）她生了两个女儿，各方面都和她一模一样。这位绅士与第一任妻子也育有一女，善良可爱，继承了她母亲的优秀品质——她的母亲是世上最好的人。

As soon as the wedding was over, the stepmother began to treat Cinderella most cruelly. She could not bear the qualities of this pretty girl because they made her own daughters so much the more hated and despised. The poor girl bore all patiently, and dared not tell her father, who would have rattled her off, for his wife governed him entirely. When the girl had done her work, she used to go into the chimney corner and sit down upon the cinders, so they called her Cinderarse, or, more politely, Cinderella.

婚礼一结束，继母就开始对灰姑娘百般刁难。她无法忍受这个漂亮女孩的种种优点，因为这些优点让她自己的女儿更加遭人憎恨和鄙视。可怜的灰姑娘默默忍受着这一切，不敢告诉父亲，因为父亲肯定会把她骂得狗血淋头，而他完全受妻子控制。灰姑娘做完家务后，常常走到壁炉角落，坐在炉灰上，所以人们叫她“灰姑娘屁股”，或者更客气一点，叫她“灰姑娘”。

Now it happened that the King’s son gave a ball, and invited all persons of quality to it, including the two sisters. Cinderella helped them do their hair and get dressed. Meanwhile they teased her because she was not invited, and she agreed that such a glamorous occasion was not for the likes of her. After they left, she started to cry. But her fairy godmother came along and promised that she should go, too. She instructed Cinderella: ‘Go into the garden and bring me a pumpkin.’ She then scooped out the pumpkin and turned it into a golden coach. There were mice for horses, a rat for a fat jolly coachman with fine whiskers, and lizards for footmen. Cinderella got a fine dress to wear, and jewels, and little glass slippers. Her godmother warned her not to stay at the ball after the clock struck twelve.

国王的儿子举办了一场舞会，邀请了所有上流人士，包括两位姐姐。灰姑娘帮她们梳妆打扮。她们却嘲笑她没有被邀请，灰姑娘也承认，如此盛大的场合确实不适合她。她们离开后，灰姑娘开始哭泣。这时，她的仙女教母出现了，答应她也应该去。她吩咐灰姑娘：“去花园里给我摘个南瓜。”然后，她挖空了南瓜，把它变成了一辆金色的马车。马是老鼠做的，胖乎乎、长着漂亮胡须的马车夫是只老鼠做的，侍从是蜥蜴做的。灰姑娘得到了一件漂亮的礼服、珠宝和一双水晶鞋。她的教母叮嘱她，午夜十二点以后就不要再待在舞会上了。

Cinderella made a sensation at the dance. The Prince gave her the most honorable place, and the King himself, old as he was, could not help looking at her, and whispering about her to the Queen. At a quarter to twelve, she left. When her sisters came home, she pretended that she had been asleep. They told her about the beautiful strange Princess. Cinderella smiled, and said: ‘Oh, she must be very handsome indeed. How I would like to see her! Lend me some of your clothes, so I can go there tomorrow night.’ But they said they wouldn’t lend their clothes to such a Cinderarse, and Cinderella was glad, because she wouldn’t have known what to do if they had agreed.

灰姑娘在舞会上引起了轰动。王子给了她最尊贵的位置，就连年迈的国王也忍不住多看她一眼，还私下向王后谈论她。十二点四十五分，她离开了。姐姐们回家后，她假装睡着了。姐姐们告诉她那位美丽而神秘的公主。灰姑娘笑着说：“哦，她一定非常漂亮。我真想见见她！借我几件衣服吧，这样我明天晚上就可以去见她了。”可是姐姐们说她们不会把衣服借给灰姑娘这样的笨蛋，灰姑娘反而很高兴，因为如果她们答应了，她真不知道该怎么办。

The next night Cinderella was having such a good time that she forgot to leave until the clock started to strike twelve. As soon as she heard it, she jumped up and fled, nimble as a deer. The Prince chased her, but he could not catch hold of her, even though in her haste she lost one of her glass slippers, which the Prince took up very carefully. A few days later, the Prince caused it to be proclaimed, by sound of trumpet, that he would marry her whose foot this slipper would just fit. He sent men around to try the slipper on all the women in the kingdom. After the two sisters had tried to thrust their feet into it without success, Cinderella, who knew the slipper, said laughing: ‘Let me try it.’ Her sisters laughed, too, and began to make fun of her. The gentleman who was sent to try the slipper said that he had orders to let everybody do so. He told Cinderella to sit down, and found that the slipper fitted her as if it had been made of wax. The astonishment her two sisters were in was very great; but much greater when Cinderella pulled out of her pocket the other slipper and put it upon her foot. Then her godmother came in, and with her wand changed Cinderella’s clothes into rich and magnificent garments.

第二天晚上，灰姑娘玩得正开心，直到钟声敲响十二点才想起离开。她一听到钟声，就跳起来像小鹿一样敏捷地逃走了。王子追赶她，却怎么也抓不住她。灰姑娘慌乱中丢了一只水晶鞋，王子小心翼翼地捡了起来。几天后，王子吹响号角，宣布他将迎娶能穿上这只水晶鞋的女子。他派人去全国试穿水晶鞋。两个姐姐试了好几次都没成功，灰姑娘认出了这只鞋，笑着说：“让我试试吧。”她的姐姐们也跟着笑了起来，开始取笑她。奉命试穿水晶鞋的绅士说，他奉命让每个人都试穿。他让灰姑娘坐下，发现水晶鞋对她来说就像蜡做的一样合脚。她的两个姐姐惊讶极了；但当灰姑娘从口袋里掏出另一只水晶鞋穿上时，她们更是惊愕不已。这时，她的教母走了进来，用魔杖将灰姑娘的衣服变成了华丽精美的服饰。

When they saw that she was the beautiful Princess, the two sisters threw themselves at her feet and said: ‘Sorry,’ whereupon Cinderella embraced them and forgave them. Then she was taken to the Prince, and a few days later he married her. Cinderella gave her two sisters lodgings in the palace, and married them the same day to two great lords of the court.

当她们看到她就是美丽的公主时，两个姐姐立刻跪倒在她脚下，连声道歉：“对不起！”灰姑娘拥抱了她们，原谅了她们。之后，她被带到王子面前，几天后，王子娶了她。灰姑娘为她的两个姐姐在宫殿里安排了住处，并在同一天将她们分别嫁给了宫廷里的两位显贵。

C • Interlocking Scripts

C • 互锁脚本

There are so many interesting features in this story, that it is difficult to know where to begin the discussion. First of all, the cast is much larger than it appears at first sight. In order of appearance, the persons are as follows:

这个故事有很多引人入胜之处，真不知从何说起。首先，它的演员阵容远比乍看之下要庞大得多。按出场顺序，人物如下：

Father

父亲

Stepmother

后妈

Daughter A

女儿A

Daughter B

女儿B

Cinderella

灰姑娘

(Mother)

（母亲）

Godmother

教母

(Coachman, Footmen)

（马车夫，侍从）

(People at the ball)

（舞会上的人们）

Prince

王子

King

国王

(Queen)

（女王）

(Guards)

（卫兵）

A Gentleman

一位绅士

Two Lords

两位领主

This comprises nine principal characters, a few silent parts and one-liners, and lots of extras. The most interesting thing about the cast is that almost all of them are crooked, as we shall see shortly.

这部剧由九个主要角色、几个无声角色和几句台词，以及众多群众演员组成。演员阵容最有趣的地方在于，几乎所有人都有些不正经，我们稍后就会看到。

Another feature is the clarity of the switches, which is common to most stories intended for children. Cinderella starts out as an OK person, then becomes first a Victim, later a teasing Persecutor, and finally a Rescuer. The stepmother and her daughters are changed from Persecutors into Victims, much more so in the German ‘Ashenputtel’ version, where the two stepsisters cut off parts of their feet in an attempt to make the slipper fit. The story also introduces the other two classical roles, as found in the ‘Alcoholic’ game. The Connection in this case is played by the godmother, who supplies Cinderella with what she needs, while the Patsies are the lords who were chosen to marry the wicked sisters.

另一个特点是人物转变的清晰性，这在大多数儿童故事中都很常见。灰姑娘一开始是个还不错的女孩，然后先是成为受害者，之后又变成戏弄她的迫害者，最后成为拯救者。继母和她的女儿们也从迫害者变成了受害者，在德语版《灰姑娘》（Ashenputtel）中尤其如此，两个继姐为了让灰姑娘穿上水晶鞋，甚至不惜砍掉自己脚的一部分。故事还引入了另外两个经典角色，类似于“酗酒者”游戏中的角色。在这个故事里，“牵线人”是教母，她为灰姑娘提供所需的一切；而“替罪羊”则是被选中与恶毒的姐姐们结婚的贵族。

Let us now consider the scripts of the people involved. It takes a little time to realize how many of the characters have their scripts revealed in this apparently simple tale.

现在让我们来分析一下相关人物的剧本。需要花点时间才能意识到，在这个看似简单的故事中，有多少角色的剧本已经揭晓。

1. Cinderella . She has a happy childhood, but then must suffer until a certain event happens. The crucial scenes, however, are time structured: she can enjoy herself as much as she pleases until the stroke of midnight, and then she must return to her former state. Cinderella apparently avoided the temptation to play ‘Ain’t It Awful,’ even with her father, and is simply a melancholy, forlorn figure until the action begins with the ball. Then she plays ‘Try and Catch Me’ with the Prince, and later, with a scripty smile, ‘I’ve Got a Secret’ with her sisters. The climax comes with a smashing game of ‘Now She Tells Us,’ as Cinderella, with a teasing laugh, gets the payoff for the winning script.

1. 灰姑娘。她拥有一个快乐的童年，但之后却不得不忍受苦难，直到某个特定事件发生。然而，关键场景的时间结构却十分严谨：午夜钟声敲响之前，她可以尽情享受快乐，之后则必须回到从前的状态。灰姑娘似乎克制住了自己不去玩“Ain't It Awful”游戏的冲动，即使是和父亲一起玩，在舞会开始之前，她一直是一个忧郁、孤独的角色。之后，她和王子玩了“Try and Catch Me”游戏，后来又带着一丝刻意的微笑，和姐妹们玩起了“I've Got a Secret”游戏。高潮出现在一场精彩绝伦的“Now She Tells Us”游戏中，灰姑娘带着一丝戏谑的笑声，为这场精彩的剧情画上了圆满的句号。

2. Father . Father’s script calls for him to lose his first wife and then cast off his daughter and marry a bossy (and presumably frigid) woman who will make him and her suffer. But he has a trick up his sleeve, as we shall soon see.

2. 父亲。父亲的剧本要求他先失去第一任妻子，然后抛弃女儿，娶一个专横跋扈（而且很可能性情冷淡）的女人，让他和女儿都饱受折磨。但他还有后招，我们很快就会看到。

3. Stepmother . She has a loser’s script. She, too, plays ‘Now She Tells Me,’ seducing the father into marrying her and then revealing her true, wicked self immediately after the wedding. She lives through her daughters, and hopes to get a princely payoff for them from her mean behavior, but ends up the loser.

3. 继母。她的剧本注定失败。她也上演了一出“现在她告诉我”的戏码，先是勾引孩子父亲娶她，然后在婚礼后立刻暴露了自己邪恶的真面目。她寄希望于女儿们，希望通过自己的恶行给她们带来丰厚的回报，但最终却成了失败者。

4. The Stepsisters . Their counterscripts are based on their mother’s precept ‘Take care of yourself first and don’t give a sucker an even break,’ but the outcome is based on the injunction ‘Don’t succeed.’ Since that is also the script injunction for their mother, it was evidently transmitted from their grandparents. They play a hard game of ‘Schlemiel,’ first getting Cinderella (or Cinderarse, as they called her) thoroughly messed up, and then apologizing and obtaining her forgiveness.

4. 继姐们。她们的反制策略基于母亲的教诲“先照顾好自己，别给傻瓜任何机会”，但最终的结果却遵循着“不要成功”的原则。由于这也是她们母亲奉行的准则，显然是从祖父母那里传承下来的。她们玩着一种名为“倒霉蛋”的恶作剧游戏，先是把灰姑娘（或者像她们叫的那样，灰姑娘的屁股）彻底搞砸，然后再道歉并博得她的原谅。

5. Godmother . Actually, she is the most interesting of all the characters. What were her motives in outfitting Cinderella for the ball? Why didn’t she just have a nice talk with her and comfort her, instead of sending her out into all the glitter? The situation was that stepmother and stepsisters were gone for the evening, and only Cinderella and her father were left in the house. Why was godmother so anxious to get rid of Cinderella? What was going on ‘back at the ranch,’ where godmother and father were alone for the evening, while everyone else was away at the ball? Her telling Cinderella not to stay after midnight was a good way to insure that Cinderella would stay out that long, and also to insure that she would be the first to get home. This avoided the risk of the other females finding godmother there, since Cinderella’s approach gave her warning to take off in good time. From a cynical point of view, the whole story sounds like a setup to allow father and godmother to spend the evening together.

5. 教母。实际上，她是所有角色中最有趣的一个。她为灰姑娘准备舞会礼服的动机是什么？为什么不和灰姑娘好好聊聊，安慰安慰她，而是把她赶到那光鲜亮丽的舞会现场呢？当时的情况是，继母和两个姐姐晚上都出去了，家里只剩下灰姑娘和她的父亲。教母为什么这么急着赶走灰姑娘？“在农场那边”究竟发生了什么？当其他人都去参加舞会的时候，教母和父亲独自待在那里。她叮嘱灰姑娘午夜之后不要待在外面，这既能确保灰姑娘待到那么晚，又能确保她第一个回家。这样一来，其他女孩就有机会发现教母，因为灰姑娘的举动给了她提前离开的预警。从愤世嫉俗的角度来看，整个故事听起来像是为了让父亲和教母共度良宵而精心安排的。

6. The Prince . The Prince was a jerk, and no doubt got what he deserved after he was married. He lets the girl get away twice in a row without getting any clue as to her identity. Then he is unable to catch her in a foot race, even though she is limping along with only one shoe. Instead of finding her himself, he sends a friend to do the job for him. And finally, he marries this girl of dubious upbringing and questionable family less than a week after he meets her. In spite of the superficial impression that he wins her, all this points to a loser’s script.

6. 王子。王子是个混蛋，结婚后他无疑得到了应有的下场。他连续两次让女孩溜走，却丝毫没有察觉她的身份。之后，即使女孩一瘸一拐地只穿了一只鞋，他还是没能在赛跑中追上她。他没有亲自去找，而是派朋友去帮忙。最后，在认识这个出身可疑、家世不明的女孩不到一周后，他就娶了她。尽管表面上看起来他赢得了她的芳心，但这一切都指向一个失败者的剧本。

7. The King . The King has an eye for the girls, and is a bit of a blabbermouth. Nor does he protect his son from his own impulsiveness.

7. 国王。国王好色，而且有点爱胡说八道。他也不保护自己的儿子免受冲动行为的伤害。

8. The Gentleman . He is the straightest of all the characters in the story. Instead of being sloppy or supercilious, and laughing at Cinderella as her sisters were doing, he gets his job done with a fine sense of justice. Nor does he run off with Cinderella himself, as a lesser man might have done, but brings her safely to his employer. He is honest, efficient, and conscientious.

8. 绅士。他是故事中最正直的角色。他不像灰姑娘的姐姐们那样马虎傲慢，嘲笑她，而是以公正无私的态度出色地完成了工作。他也没有像一些心胸狭隘的人那样私奔灰姑娘，而是安全地把她送到了雇主那里。他诚实、高效、尽职尽责。

9. The two lords , of course, are patsies to allow themselves to be married off to two very uncool girls whom they know nothing about, having only met them on their wedding day.

9. 当然，这两位勋爵是傻瓜，竟然让自己娶了两个非常没品、自己一无所知的女孩，只在婚礼当天才见到她们。

D • Cinderella in Real Life

D • 现实生活中的灰姑娘

The important thing is that all these characters can be picked out in real life. Here, for example, is the story of a Cinderella.

重要的是，所有这些人物都能在现实生活中找到原型。例如，这里讲述的就是灰姑娘的故事。

Ella’s parents got divorced when she was little, and she stayed with her mother. Shortly afterward, her father remarried. He had two daughters by his second wife, who was jealous of Ella when she came to visit, and also begrudged the money her father sent for her support. A few years later, her mother also remarried, and then Ella had to go to live with her father because her mother and new stepfather were more interested in drinking than in taking care of her. Ella wasn’t at all happy in her new home because her stepmother made it clear that she didn’t like her, and her father did little to protect her. She always had the last choice in everything, and her sisters teased her. She grew up very shy and had few dates when she was a teenager, while her sisters led an active social life in which she was not invited to share.

艾拉小时候父母离异，她跟着母亲生活。不久后，父亲再婚，与第二任妻子育有两个女儿。艾拉来探望时，继母总是嫉妒她，也对父亲寄来的生活费心存不满。几年后，母亲也再婚了，艾拉不得不搬去和父亲一起住，因为母亲和继父都沉迷于酒精，对照顾她漠不关心。艾拉在新家过得并不开心，继母毫不掩饰地表达了对她的厌恶，而父亲也对她疏于保护。她总是被排在最后，姐姐们还经常取笑她。艾拉从小性格内向，十几岁时几乎没有约会，而姐姐们则过着丰富多彩的社交生活，却从未邀请她参与其中。

Ella had one advantage, however. She knew something the others didn’t know. Her father had a mistress, a divorcée named Linda, with a Jaguar, who wore very expensive hippie-type necklaces and sometimes smoked marijuana. Ella and Linda secretly became good friends, and used to have long talks about their problems with dad. In fact, Linda gave Ella advice about many different things, and was like a godmother to her. She was particularly concerned because Ella did not have much social life.

然而，艾拉却有一个优势。她知道一些别人不知道的事情。她的父亲有个情妇，名叫琳达，是个离异女子，开着一辆捷豹，戴着非常昂贵的嬉皮士风格项链，有时还抽大麻。艾拉和琳达偷偷成了好朋友，经常长时间地谈论她们和父亲之间的问题。事实上，琳达在很多方面都给了艾拉建议，就像她的教母一样。她尤其关心艾拉，因为艾拉几乎没有什么社交生活。

One afternoon Linda said: ‘Your mother is away, and your sisters are going out on dates, so why don’t you go out, too? It’s no fun sitting at home all by yourself. I’ll lend you my car and some clothes, and you can go to the Rock-and-Roll Ballroom where there are lots of boys you can meet. Come over to my place about six and we’ll eat and I’ll fix you up.’ Ella figured Linda and her father were going to spend the evening together, and she agreed.

一天下午，琳达说：“你妈妈不在家，你姐姐们都出去约会了，你为什么不也出去玩玩呢？一个人待在家里太无聊了。我可以借你我的车和一些衣服，你可以去摇滚舞厅，那里有很多男孩子可以认识。六点左右来我家，我们一起吃饭，我帮你打扮一下。”艾拉觉得琳达和她爸爸晚上要一起玩，于是就答应了。

Linda thought Ella looked very nice all dressed up. ‘Don’t hurry back,’ she said, as she handed Ella the keys to her beautiful car.

琳达觉得艾拉打扮得非常漂亮。“别急着回去，”她说着，把她那辆漂亮车的钥匙递给了艾拉。

At the dance, Ella met a nice boy named Roland, and started to go out with him. But a poor guitar-player friend of his was much more interested in Ella than he was, and soon she was going out secretly with Prince, the guitar-player. She didn’t want Prince to call at her house because she knew her mother wouldn’t approve of his unkempt appearance, so Roland would come and pick her up with his date and then they would meet Prince and the four of them would go somewhere together. Meanwhile, her father and stepmother and sisters thought she was dating Roland, and Ella and he had lots of fun over that.

在舞会上，艾拉遇到了一个名叫罗兰的帅气男孩，并开始和他约会。但罗兰一个穷吉他手朋友却对艾拉更感兴趣，很快，艾拉就和这位吉他手王子秘密交往了。她不想让王子来她家，因为她知道母亲不会喜欢他邋遢的外表，所以罗兰会带着他的约会对象来接她，然后他们再去和王子碰面，四个人一起出去玩。与此同时，她的父亲、继母和姐妹们都以为她和罗兰在交往，艾拉和罗兰也因此玩得不亦乐乎。

Prince was not really poor. He came from a well-to-do family and had a good education, but he wanted to make it on his own as an entertainer. He began to get more and more famous. After he was well known, he and Ella decided to tell her family the real story before they found out from someone else. It came as a complete surprise to her sisters, who adored Prince’s records, and they were very jealous when Ella announced that she had won such a rich prize for a husband. But she didn’t bear them any grudge for their ill-treatment, and often got them free tickets to Prince’s concerts. She even introduced them to some of his square friends.

王子其实并不穷。他出身富裕家庭，受过良好的教育，但他想靠自己的努力成为一名艺人。他的名气越来越大。成名之后，他和艾拉决定在家人从别人那里得知真相之前，把真相告诉他们。这让艾拉的姐妹们大吃一惊，她们一直很喜欢王子的唱片，当艾拉宣布自己嫁给了如此富有的丈夫时，她们非常嫉妒。但艾拉并没有因为她们的冷落而记恨她们，还经常弄到王子演唱会的免费门票。她甚至把她们介绍给了王子的一些“老实人”朋友。

E • After the Ball is Over

E • 球结束后

We have already seen that Little Red Riding Hood’s childhood adventure with the wolf (her grandfather) had a profound effect on her life when she grew up.

我们已经看到，小红帽童年时与狼（她的祖父）的冒险经历对她长大后的生活产生了深远的影响。

Knowing what real people do, it is not hard to surmise also what happened to Cinderella after she married. She found that being a Princess was lonely. She wanted to play ‘Try and Catch Me’ with the Prince some more, but he was not much fun. She teased her sisters when they came to visit her, but that didn’t amuse her for long either, particularly since they were not very good sports about it now that she had the upper hand. The King sometimes looked at her oddly, and he wasn’t as old as he pretended to be, but he wasn’t as young as he pretended to be either; in any case, she didn’t want to think about things like that. The Queen was nice to her, but very proper as a Queen had to be. As for the rest of the people at court, Cinderella had to be very proper to them. In due time, she did have the son that she and everybody else were waiting for, and there was much joy and celebration. But she did not have any other children, and since the little Duke was taken care of by nursemaids and governesses as he grew up, Cinderella was soon as bored as before, particularly during the day when her husband was out hunting, and in the evening when he sat with his gentlemen friends losing money at cards.

了解现实生活中人们的所作所为，不难推测灰姑娘婚后的生活。她发现当公主很孤独。她想再和王子玩“捉迷藏”，但他并不怎么有趣。姐姐们来探望她时，她会捉弄她们，但这也没能让她开心多久，尤其是在她占上风之后，姐姐们就没那么好说话了。国王有时会用奇怪的眼神看着她，他既不像他假装的那样老，也不像他假装的那样年轻；总之，她不想去想这些。王后对她很好，但举止得体，就像王后必须做的那样。至于宫廷里的其他人，灰姑娘也必须对他们彬彬有礼。最终，她生下了她和所有人都期盼的儿子，宫廷里一片欢腾，热闹非凡。但她没有其他孩子，而且由于小公爵从小由保姆和家庭教师照顾，灰姑娘很快就和以前一样感到无聊，尤其是在白天丈夫外出打猎的时候，以及晚上他与他的绅士朋友们坐在一起打牌输钱的时候。

After a while, she made an odd discovery. The people who interested her most, although she tried to keep it a secret, were the scullery maids and the cinder maids who cleaned the fireplaces. She would find all sorts of excuses to be around while they were working. Pretty soon she was making suggestions to them from her own long experience with these matters. Then she found, riding around the little kingdom in her carriage, sometimes with her son and his governess and sometimes without them, and strolling through the poorer parts of the towns and villages, something she had known all along: all over the kingdom there were thousands of women doing scullery work and cleaning out hearths. She would stop and gossip with them and talk about their work.

过了一段时间，她有了一个奇怪的发现。尽管她努力保守秘密，但她最感兴趣的却是洗碗女佣和清理壁炉的灰烬女佣。她会找各种借口待在她们身边，看着她们干活。很快，她就根据自己在这方面多年的经验，给她们提建议。后来，她坐着马车在小王国里四处游荡，有时带着儿子和他的家庭教师，有时独自一人，漫步在城镇乡村的贫民区，她发现了一件自己一直都知道的事情：整个王国里有成千上万的妇女在做洗碗和清理壁炉的工作。她会停下来和她们闲聊，谈论她们的工作。

Soon she got into the habit of making regular rounds to some of the poorest homes where the women had to work the hardest. She would put on old clothes and sit in the cinders with them talking, or help them in the kitchen. Word soon got around in the kingdom about what she was doing, and the Prince even quarreled with her about it, but she insisted that that was what she wanted to do more than anything else, and kept on doing it. One day, one of the ladies of the court, who was also bored, asked permission to go with her. As time went on, others got interested. Pretty soon, dozens of noble ladies were putting on their oldest clothes every morning and going into town to help poor housewives with their meanest work, meanwhile gossiping with them and hearing all sorts of interesting tales.

很快，她就养成了定期走访一些最贫困家庭的习惯，这些家庭的妇女们不得不承担最繁重的家务。她会穿上旧衣服，坐在煤渣堆里和她们聊天，或者帮她们做些厨房里的活。很快，她所做的事情就传遍了整个王国，甚至连王子都为此和她争吵过，但她坚持说这是她最想做的事情，并继续坚持下去。有一天，一位同样感到无聊的宫廷女官请求和她一起去。随着时间的推移，其他人也开始对此感兴趣。不久之后，每天早上都有几十位贵族小姐穿上她们最旧的衣服，进城去帮助那些贫困的家庭主妇们做些最卑微的家务，同时和她们闲聊，听她们讲述各种有趣的故事。

Then the Princess had the idea of all the helping ladies getting together to talk about the problems they encountered, so she organized them into the Ladies’ Cinder and Scullery Society, with herself as President. Now, whenever foreign chimney sweeps, vegetable-peddlers, woodcutters, scullery maids, or trash-collectors passed through town, they were invited to the palace to talk to the Society about what was new in their trades and how things were done in their countries. In this way Cinderella found her place in life, and she and her new friends contributed much to the welfare of the kingdom.

于是，公主想出了一个主意，让所有乐于助人的女佣们聚在一起，讨论她们遇到的问题。她组织她们成立了“灰姑娘和洗碗女佣协会”，自己担任会长。现在，每当外国的烟囱清洁工、菜贩、伐木工、洗碗女佣或垃圾收集员路过小镇时，她们都会被邀请到宫殿，与协会成员交流各自行业的最新动态以及她们国家的运作方式。就这样，灰姑娘找到了自己的人生方向，她和她的新朋友们也为王国的福祉做出了巨大贡献。

F • Fairy Tales and Real People

F • 童话故事与真实人物

Looking around in society or in one’s clinical practice, it is not difficult to find examples of every character in the Cinderella story, from Cinderella herself, and her immediate family, through the ineffectual Prince and the King, and even down to the jolly, whiskered coachman who never said a word and who started out life as a rat. There are also shoe-fitters who Come To Find Out that what looks like a sow’s ear is really a silk purse.

无论在社会上还是在临床实践中，环顾四周，都不难找到灰姑娘故事中每个角色的原型：从灰姑娘本人及其家人，到软弱无能的王子和国王，甚至到那位从不说话、长着胡子、原本是只老鼠的快乐马车夫。就连那些鞋匠，最终也会发现，看似猪耳朵的东西其实是丝绸钱包。

While the therapist can listen to the patient and search around in his head for a fairy tale which may match what he hears, or leaf through Stith Thompson’s motif-index when he gets home, a simpler way is to ask the patient himself to tell his life story as a fairy tale. An example of this was Drusilla, who was not a patient, but obliged during a seminar on fairy tales.

治疗师可以倾听患者的讲述，并在脑海中寻找可能与之相符的童话故事，或者回家后翻阅斯蒂斯·汤普森的童话主题索引。但更简单的方法是请患者自己将自己的人生故事讲述成一个童话。德鲁西拉就是一个例子，她并非患者，但在一次关于童话的研讨会上欣然应允。

An ancestor of Drusilla’s, many generations back, invented a widely used device, so that his name is still a household word. The story starts with Drusilla’s mother Vanessa, who was a descendant of this patriarch. Vanessa’s father died when she was quite young and she went to live in the home of her great-uncle, Charles. Charles lived on a large ranch near Los Angeles, complete with swimming pool, tennis courts, private lake, and even a golf course. Vanessa grew up in these surroundings and met people from many countries. She was not too happy, however, and when she was seventeen she eloped with a man from the Philippines, named Manuel. Their two daughters, Drusilla and her sister Eldora, were raised on a plantation there. Drusilla was her father’s favorite. Eldora was something of a tomboy and became very athletic, an expert horsewoman, archer, and golfer. Her father used to beat her, but he never laid a hand on Drusilla. One day when Eldora was about eighteen her father wanted to punish her. By this time Eldora was as tall as he was and much stronger. As he advanced on her she cowered, as she had always done, but suddenly Drusilla observed a strange transformation. Eldora drew herself up, flexed her muscles, and said to her father, ‘Don’t you dare ever lay a hand on me again.’ She looked him fiercely in the eye and her father in his turn now cowered and backed away. Shortly after this, Vanessa divorced him and went with her two children to live on Uncle Charles’ estate.

德鲁西拉的祖先，在很多代以前，发明了一种广泛使用的装置，以至于他的名字至今仍家喻户晓。故事要从德鲁西拉的母亲瓦妮莎说起，她是这位先祖的后裔。瓦妮莎的父亲在她很小的时候就去世了，她便去投奔她的叔祖父查尔斯。查尔斯住在洛杉矶附近的一个大型牧场里，那里设施齐全，有游泳池、网球场、私人湖泊，甚至还有一个高尔夫球场。瓦妮莎在这样的环境中长大，结识了来自世界各地的人。然而，她并不快乐，17岁那年，她与一位名叫曼努埃尔的菲律宾男子私奔了。他们的两个女儿，德鲁西拉和她的妹妹埃尔多拉，在那里的一个种植园长大。德鲁西拉是她父亲最宠爱的女儿。埃尔多拉则像个假小子，运动天赋极佳，擅长骑马、射箭和高尔夫。她的父亲经常打她，但从未对德鲁西拉动过手。埃尔多拉大约十八岁的时候，有一天她父亲想惩罚她。那时埃尔多拉已经和他一样高，而且力气比他大得多。他逼近她时，她像往常一样畏缩着，但德鲁西拉突然注意到她身上发生了奇怪的变化。埃尔多拉挺直了身子，绷紧了肌肉，对父亲说：“你胆敢再碰我一下试试！”她狠狠地瞪着他的眼睛，她父亲顿时畏缩起来，退缩了。不久之后，瓦妮莎和他离婚了，带着两个孩子搬去查尔斯叔叔的庄园居住。

Drusilla in her turn now lived on her great-uncle’s ranch and met a man from a faraway country, whom she married. By him she had two children. But she always liked to make things so she became a weaver, and finally a teacher of weaving. It was because of her interest in weaving that she came to the seminar on fairy tales.

德鲁西拉后来住在她叔祖父的牧场里，在那里她遇到了一个来自遥远国度的男子，并嫁给了他。她和他育有两个孩子。但她一直喜欢动手制作东西，于是成为了一名织布工，最终成为了一名织布教师。正是出于对织布的兴趣，她才来参加童话故事研讨会。

Drusilla was asked to tell her story in the form of a fairy tale, using the script analyst’s language of frogs, princes, princesses, winners and losers, witches and ogres. Here is the way she told it:

德鲁西拉被要求用童话故事的形式讲述她的故事，使用剧本分析师常用的语言，比如青蛙、王子、公主、赢家和输家、女巫和食人魔。以下是她的讲述方式：

‘Once upon a time there was a king who conquered many lands, which his oldest son inherited. The kingdom was passed on from generation to generation. Since the oldest son inherited the kingdom, the younger sons got very little. One of the poor younger sons had a daughter Vanessa, but he died while on a hunt. Vanessa’s uncle, the king, then took her to live with him at the palace and there she met a prince from a strange and faraway land. The prince took her away from the kingdom to his own kingdom by the sea, where many strange flowers and forests grew. After a while, however, she found that her prince, Manuel, was really a frog. Manuel was equally surprised when he discovered that the beautiful bride whom he had married because he thought she was a princess turned out to be a witch. Manuel and Vanessa had two daughters. The oldest, Eldora, was a frog like her father and he did not like her at all and used to scold her and beat her when she was little. The younger daughter, Drusilla, was a princess, and Manuel treated her like one.

从前，有一位国王征服了许多土地，并将这些土地传给了他的长子。王国世代相传。由于长子继承了王位，次子们得到的很少。其中一个贫穷的次子生了一个女儿，名叫瓦妮莎，但他在一次狩猎中丧生。瓦妮莎的叔叔，也就是国王，把她接到宫殿里与自己一起生活。在那里，她遇到了一位来自遥远异域的王子。王子带她离开了王国，来到他位于海边的王国，那里生长着许多奇花异草和茂密的森林。然而，过了一段时间，她发现她的王子曼努埃尔其实是一只青蛙。曼努埃尔同样惊讶地发现，他以为是公主而娶的美丽新娘，竟然是一位女巫。曼努埃尔和瓦妮莎有两个女儿。大女儿埃尔多拉和她的父亲一样是一只青蛙，父亲非常不喜欢她，经常在她小时候责骂她、打她。小女儿德鲁西拉是一位公主，曼努埃尔也像对待公主一样对待她。

‘One day a fairy came to Eldora and said to her, “I will protect you. If your father ever tries to beat you again you must tell him to stop.” So the next time Manuel tried to beat Eldora she suddenly felt very strong and told him that he must never beat her again. Manuel was very indignant and thought it was his wife Vanessa who had caused Eldora to turn on him, so Vanessa decided to move away. She and her two daughters left the faraway kingdom and went back to the kingdom of Uncle Charles where the two girls lived happily until one day a prince came and fell in love with Drusilla. They were married with great pomp and had two beautiful daughters and Drusilla lived happily ever after, raising her children and weaving beautiful tapestries.’

有一天，一位仙女来到埃尔多拉面前，对她说：“我会保护你。如果你的父亲再敢打你，你一定要让他住手。”于是，曼努埃尔下次再想打埃尔多拉时，她突然感到自己力大无穷，便告诉他，他以后绝对不能再打她。曼努埃尔非常生气，认为是他的妻子瓦妮莎害得埃尔多拉对他如此反感，于是瓦妮莎决定离开。她带着两个女儿离开了遥远的王国，回到了查尔斯叔叔的王国。两个女儿在那里过着幸福的生活，直到有一天，一位王子来到这里，爱上了德鲁西拉。他们举行了盛大的婚礼，生下了两个美丽的女儿。从此，德鲁西拉过上了幸福的生活，抚养着孩子们，织着美丽的挂毯。

Everybody at the seminar thought that was a fine story.

研讨会上的每个人都认为这是一个很棒的故事。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 Samber’s book is entitled Histories or Tales of Past Times: With Morals. By M. Perrault . It was printed for J. Pote, at Sir Isaac Newton’s Head, and R. Montagu, the Corner of Great Queen Street, 1729.

1 桑伯的书名为《往昔故事集：附寓言》，作者是佩罗先生。该书于1729年由J. Pote在艾萨克·牛顿爵士书店和R. Montagu在皇后大街拐角处印刷出版。

2 Thompson, Stith. Motif-Index of Folk-Literature . Indiana University Press, Bloomington and London, 1966. Cinderella-type tales are classified by Thompson under ‘Unpromising heroine. Usually, but not always, the youngest daughter.’ Some of the sources he gives are: Irish, Breton, Italian, Tuamotu, and Zuñi. He also includes ‘Unpromising heroes’ as male Cinderellas. He refers back to ‘Victorious younger daughter,’ which gives a large number of references from all over the world, including India and China. There are also ‘Abused youngest daughter’ and, most widespread of all, ‘Cruel Stepmother.’ Other common roles and transactions are ‘Prince in love with lowly girl,’ ‘Girl sends sign message to prince,’ and ‘Little girl bribes prince to marry her.’ Ashes as the abode of an unpromising heroine are found in French, Spanish, Italian, Icelandic, Chinese, and Micmac Indian lore, among others. The ‘Slipper Test’ is also fairly widespread. The original French Cendrillon wore slippers of squirrel fur ( vair , as it is called in heraldry), which was taken for verre and mistranslated as glass. Ashenputtel’s slippers were gold. Cinderella, as we know her, probably originated in Naples as La Gatta Cenerentola . In French she is Cu Cendron, Ash Bottom or Cinderarse, and in English, Cinderbreech, at times. There is an opera by Rossini called La Cenerentola , fn1 and two ballets. In the ballet by d’Erlanger and Fokine the two sisters are played by male dancers, which is supposed to be comic, as comedy goes in the Russian ballet. The most famous ballet on this subject is by Prokofiev.

2 汤普森，斯蒂斯。《民间文学主题索引》。印第安纳大学出版社，布卢明顿和伦敦，1966年。汤普森将灰姑娘式的故事归类为“前途渺茫的女主角。通常（但不总是）是最小的女儿。”他列举的一些来源包括：爱尔兰、布列塔尼、意大利、图阿莫图和祖尼。他还将“前途渺茫的男主角”归类为男性灰姑娘。他回顾了“胜利的幼女”这一主题，并列举了来自世界各地（包括印度和中国）的大量相关案例。还有“受虐待的小女儿”以及流传最广的“恶毒继母”。其他常见的角色和情节包括“王子爱上卑微的女孩”、“女孩向王子传递暗号”以及“小女孩贿赂王子娶她”。在法国、西班牙、意大利、冰岛、中国和米克马克印第安人的传说中，都有灰烬作为命运多舛的女主角的居所的记载。“鞋子测试”也相当普遍。最初的法国灰姑娘穿着松鼠皮（纹章学中称为vair）制成的鞋子，这种材质被误认为是verre，并被错误地翻译成玻璃。灰姑娘的鞋子是金的。我们今天所知的灰姑娘，可能起源于那不勒斯，名为La Gatta Cenerentola。在法语中，她被称为Cu Cendron、Ash Bottom或Cinderarse，在英语中有时也被称为Cinderbreech。罗西尼有一部名为《灰姑娘》（La Cenerentola）的歌剧，还有两部芭蕾舞剧。在德·埃尔朗格和福金的芭蕾舞剧中，两位姐妹由男舞者扮演，这在俄罗斯芭蕾舞中被认为是喜剧。以这一题材为主题的最著名的芭蕾舞剧是普罗科菲耶夫的作品。

Cf. Barchilon, J. and Pettit, H. (eds.) The Authentic Mother Goose . Alan Swallow, Denver, 1960.

参见 Barchilon, J. 和 Pettit, H. (编)《正宗的鹅妈妈童谣》。Alan Swallow，丹佛，1960 年。

fn1 Performed by the San Francisco Opera in 1969, and in New York in 1958, and in April, 1970. Rossini calls the sisters Clorinda and Tisbe.

fn1 1969 年由旧金山歌剧院演出，1958 年在纽约演出，1970 年 4 月演出。罗西尼称这对姐妹为克洛琳达和蒂斯贝。

#↩

CHAPTER FOURTEEN

第十四章

How Is the Script Possible?

这个脚本是如何实现的？

Jeder sits at a player piano, his fingers wandering over the keys. The roll of paper, punched out long ago by his forebears, turns slowly as he pumps away. The music pours forth in a pattern that he cannot change, at times melancholy, at times gay, now jarring, and now full of melody. Occasionally he strikes a note or a chorus whose sound may blend with what is written, or disturb the smooth flow of the fateful song. He pauses to rest, for the roll is thicker than the whole scroll of the law in the temple. It contains the law and the prophets, the songs and the lamentations, an old testament and a new: a truly magnificent, a mediocre, a dreary, or a miserable gift given to him piece by piece by his loving, indifferent, or hateful parents. He is under the illusion that the music is his own, and has for his witness his body, slowly wearing out from hour after hour and day after day of pumping. Sometimes, during the pauses, he rises to take a bow or a boo from his friends and relatives, who also believe that he is playing his own tune.

杰德坐在自动钢琴前，手指在琴键上游走。那卷由他的祖辈很久以前打孔的纸卷，随着他不停地按压琴键缓缓转动。音乐以一种他无法改变的模式倾泻而出，时而忧郁，时而欢快，时而刺耳，时而旋律优美。偶尔，他会弹奏出一个音符或一段副歌，其声音或许与乐谱融为一体，或许会扰乱这首命运之歌的流畅旋律。他停下来休息片刻，因为这卷琴卷比圣殿里整卷律法书还要厚。它包含了律法和先知，歌曲和哀歌，旧约和新约：这是一份真正辉煌的礼物，或许是一份平庸的礼物，或许是一份沉闷的礼物，或许是一份悲惨的礼物，由他慈爱的、冷漠的或憎恨的父母一点一点地赠予他。他误以为这音乐是他自己的，而他日复一日、时时刻刻按压琴键，身体日渐衰弱，便是最好的证明。有时，在演奏间隙，他会起身接受朋友和亲戚的鞠躬或喝倒彩，他们也认为他是在演奏自己的曲子。

How is it that the members of the human race, with all their accumulated wisdom, self-awareness, and desire for truth and self, can permit themselves to remain in such a mechanical situation, with its pathos and self-deception? Partly it is because we love our parents and partly it is because life is easier that way, but partly also it is because we have not yet evolved far enough from our apelike ancestors to have it otherwise. We are more aware of ourselves than apes are, but not really very much. Scripts are only possible because people don’t know what they are doing to themselves and to others. In fact, to know what one is doing is the opposite of being scripted. There are certain aspects of bodily, mental, and social functioning which happen to man in spite of himself, which slip out, as it were, because they are programed to do so. These heavily influence his destiny through the people around him, while he still retains the illusion of autonomy. But there are also certain remedies which can be applied.

人类拥有如此丰富的智慧、自我意识以及对真理和自我的渴望，为何会允许自己停留在如此机械的境地，沉溺于其中的悲情和自欺欺人？部分原因是出于对父母的爱，部分原因是这样生活更轻松，但也有部分原因是我们尚未进化到足以摆脱猿类祖先的程度。我们比猿类更了解自己，但其实也只是略胜一筹。脚本之所以存在，是因为人们不了解自己对自身和他人的影响。事实上，了解自己的行为恰恰与被脚本束缚截然相反。人类的某些生理、心理和社会功能并非出于自身意愿，而是自然而然地发生，仿佛是被预先设定好的程序。这些功能通过周围的人深刻地影响着人类的命运，而人类却仍然保留着自主的幻觉。但并非没有办法改变这种现状。

A • The Plastic Face

A • 塑料脸

It is, above all, the plasticity of the human face which makes life an adventure rather than a controlled experience. This is based on an apparently trivial biological principle which has an enormous social power. 1 The human nervous system is so constructed that the visual impact on the onlooker of small movements of the facial muscles is greater than the kinesthetic impact on the subject. A two-millimeter movement of one of the small muscles around the mouth may be quite imperceptible to Jeder but quite obvious to his companions. This can be easily verified in front of a mirror. The extent to which the subject is unaware of what he looks like is easily demonstrated by the commonplace act of picking the front of the teeth with the tongue. Jeder may do this with what seems to him extreme discretion and delicacy. As far as he can judge from his kinesthetic or muscular sensations, he is hardly moving his face at all. But if he does it in front of a mirror, he sees that which feels like a minor movement of the tongue actually brings about a gross distortion of his features, especially the chin and including the neck muscles. If he pays more attention than he usually does to his muscular sensations, he will also notice that the movement is affecting his forehead and temples.

归根结底，正是人类面部的可塑性，使得生活成为一场冒险，而非一种可控的体验。这基于一个看似微不足道的生物学原理，却蕴含着巨大的社会力量。人类神经系统的构造使得面部肌肉的细微动作对旁观者的视觉影响，远大于对受试者自身的动觉影响。杰德可能完全察觉不到嘴周某块小肌肉两毫米的移动，但他的同伴却能清晰地看到。这一点在镜子前很容易验证。用舌头轻舔牙齿这个看似平常的动作，就能轻易地展现出受试者对自己外貌的无知程度。杰德或许会以他自认为极其谨慎和轻柔的方式完成这个动作。就他从动觉或肌肉感觉判断而言，他几乎感觉不到自己面部的任何动作。但如果他对着镜子做这个动作，就会发现原本感觉只是舌头轻微移动的动作，实际上却会严重扭曲他的面部特征，尤其是下巴和颈部肌肉。如果他比平时更仔细地感受肌肉的感觉，还会注意到这个动作也影响到他的额头和太阳穴。

In the heat of a social encounter, this phenomenon may occur dozens of times without him being aware of it: what seems to him like a small excursion of his muscles of expression causes a major change in his appearance. On the other hand, the Child in Zoe, the onlooker, is watching (as much as good manners permit) for signs which will give her an indication of Jeder’s attitude, feelings, and intent. Thus Jeder is always giving away far more than he thinks he is, unless he is one of those people who habitually keep their features immobile and inscrutable and are careful not to reveal their reactions. The importance of facial plasticity, however, is shown by the fact that such an inscrutable person makes others uneasy, since they get no clues as to how to adapt their behavior.

在社交场合的热烈气氛中，这种现象可能会发生几十次，而他却浑然不觉：在他看来只是表情肌的轻微抽动，却会让他外貌发生巨大的变化。另一方面，佐伊内心深处的那个孩子，也就是旁观者，会（在礼貌允许的范围内）观察着杰德的言行举止，试图从中判断他的态度、感受和意图。因此，除非杰德是那种习惯于保持面部表情不动、难以捉摸，并且小心翼翼地不让外界察觉他内心反应的人，否则他总是会泄露出比他自己认为的更多的信息。然而，面部表情的可塑性之所以重要，恰恰在于这样一个事实：一个如此难以捉摸的人会让其他人感到不安，因为他们无法从中获得任何线索来调整自己的行为。

This principle clarifies the origin of the almost uncanny ‘intuition’ of babies and young children about people. Since babies have not yet been taught that they must not look too closely at people’s faces, they are free to do so, and see much that others miss and that the subject is not aware he is giving away. In everyday life, Zoe’s Adult is politely careful not to look too closely at what happens to other people’s faces while they talk, but meanwhile her Child is rudely ‘peeking,’ as it were, all the time, and thus forming judgments, usually accurate, of what the other is really up to. This is particularly apt to occur in the ‘first ten seconds’ after meeting a new person, before he has a chance to figure out how to present himself, and thus he tends to give away things he later hides. That is the value of first impressions.

这一原则解释了婴儿和幼儿对人近乎不可思议的“直觉”的由来。由于婴儿尚未被教导不要仔细观察他人的面部表情，他们可以自由地这样做，并看到许多其他人忽略的细节，以及当事人自己并未意识到正在泄露的信息。在日常生活中，佐伊的成年母亲会礼貌地注意不去仔细观察他人交谈时的面部表情，而她的孩子却总是“偷看”，仿佛在无礼地窥视着什么，从而形成对对方真实意图的判断，而且通常都很准确。这种情况尤其容易发生在初次见面后的“最初十秒钟”，在对方还没来得及思考如何展现自己之前，他们往往会透露一些之后会隐藏的信息。这就是第一印象的价值所在。

The social effect of this is that Jeder never knows how much he is giving away by his facial plasticity. Things which he tries to hide even from himself are quite apparent to Zoe, who reacts accordingly, much to Jeder’s surprise. He is continually giving out script signals without being aware of it. Others respond ultimately to these signals, instead of to Jeder’s persona or presentation of himself. In this way the script is kept going without Jeder having to take the responsibility for it. He can keep his illusion of autonomy by saying: ‘I don’t know why she acted that way, I didn’t do anything to bring it on. People sure are funny.’ If his behavior is odd enough, others may react in a fashion which is quite beyond his comprehension, and in this way delusions can be established or reinforced.

这种做法的社会影响在于，杰德始终意识不到自己通过面部表情泄露了多少信息。他试图隐藏甚至对自己都毫不知情的事情，佐伊却看得一清二楚，并做出了相应的反应，这令杰德大吃一惊。他不断地发出剧本信号，却浑然不觉。其他人最终是对这些信息做出反应，而不是对杰德的形象或自我呈现做出反应。这样一来，剧本得以继续上演，而杰德却无需承担任何责任。他可以通过说：“我不知道她为什么那样做，我没做什么惹她生气的事。人们真是奇怪。”来维持他自主的假象。如果他的行为足够怪异，其他人可能会做出他完全无法理解的反应，从而建立或强化他的错觉。

The remedy for this is simple. If Jeder studies his facial expressions in the mirror, he will soon see what he is doing to make people react the way they do, and he will then be in a position to change the situation if he wants to. Unless he is an actor, he will probably not want to. In fact, most people are so intent on keeping their scripts going that they will find all sorts of excuses not even to study themselves in the mirror. 2 They may claim, for example, that this procedure is ‘artificial,’ which means that the only thing that is ‘natural’ is to let the script proceed to its mechanical, foreordained conclusion.

解决办法很简单。如果杰德对着镜子仔细观察自己的面部表情，他很快就会明白自己究竟做了什么才会让人们产生那样的反应，这样他就能随时改变局面。除非他是演员，否则他可能根本不会想改变。事实上，大多数人一心只想按剧本表演，以至于会找各种借口连照镜子都不肯。例如，他们可能会声称这种做法是“人为的”，也就是说，唯一“自然”的做法就是让剧本按照预先设定的机械方式发展下去。

Clara, a well-bred Latin-American woman, offered a poignant example of the profound effect that the plastic face has on human relationships. She came to the group because her husband was about to leave her, and she said she had ‘no one to talk to,’ although she had three grown children living at home. Her husband refused to come to the group, but her twenty-year-old son readily accepted the invitation.

克拉拉是一位出身良好的拉丁美洲女性，她用一个令人心酸的例子说明了整容对人际关系产生的深远影响。她来参加小组活动是因为丈夫即将离开她，她说自己“无人倾诉”，尽管她有三个已经成年的孩子住在家里。她的丈夫拒绝参加小组活动，但她二十岁的儿子欣然接受了邀请。

‘I hesitate to talk to my mother,’ he said, ‘and it’s hard for me to talk about her here, because her feelings get hurt easily and sometimes she has a martyr attitude. I always have to think before I say anything to her about how she’ll take it, and so I really can’t speak frankly.’

“我不太愿意跟母亲说话，”他说，“在这里谈论她也很难，因为她很容易受伤，有时她会摆出一副受害者的姿态。我每次跟她说话之前都要先想想她会怎么想，所以我真的没法坦诚相待。”

While he enlarged on this subject for a few minutes, his mother sat next to him with her body tense and her hands folded gracefully in her lap as she had been taught from childhood, so that the only parts of her that moved visibly were her face, head, and neck. As she listened to what her son said, she first raised her eyebrows in surprise, then frowned, then shook her head slightly, then pursed her lips, then bowed her head sadly, then looked up again, and then tilted her head to one side in a martyred attitude. All the time he talked, these plastic movements of the head and face continued, a veritable cinema of emotional expression.

在他滔滔不绝地讲述这个话题的几分钟里，他的母亲坐在他身旁，身体紧绷，双手优雅地交叠放在膝上，这是她从小就被教导的姿势，因此她身上唯一可见的动静只有脸、头和脖子。听着儿子的讲述，她先是惊讶地挑了挑眉，然后皱起眉头，接着轻轻摇了摇头，抿了抿嘴，然后悲伤地低下头，接着又抬起头，最后歪着头，一副受难者的姿态。在他说话的整个过程中，她头部和面部的这些细微动作始终不停地进行着，宛如一部生动的情感表达电影。

When her son had finished his report, Dr Q asked her:

当她儿子写完报告后，Q医生问她：

‘Why were you moving your face all the time he was talking?’

“他说话的时候，你为什么一直动脸？”

‘I wasn’t doing that,’ she objected in surprise.

“我没有那样做，”她惊讶地反驳道。

‘Then why were you moving your head around?’

“那你为什么一直摇头晃脑呢？”

‘I didn’t know I was.’

“我不知道我是。”

‘Well, you were,’ said Dr Q. ‘All the time he was talking, your face was reacting to what he said, and that’s exactly why he feels uneasy when he talks to you. You tell him he can say anything he wants, but since your reactions to what he says are quite clear, even when you don’t say a word, he hesitates. And you don’t even realize that you’re reacting. Now if it has that effect on him after he’s grown up, imagine what it does to a three-year-old, who’s carefully watching his mother’s face all the time to see how he affects her. That’s why he thinks before he speaks to you, and why you feel you have nobody to talk to.’

“没错，”Q博士说，“他说话的时候，你的表情一直在回应他的话，这就是为什么他跟你说话时会感到不自在。你告诉他可以畅所欲言，但因为你对他的话的反应如此明显，即使你一句话也不说，他也会犹豫。而你甚至没有意识到自己在做出反应。如果这对一个长大成人的孩子都有影响，想想看，这对一个三岁的孩子会造成怎样的影响？他总是仔细观察母亲的表情，看看自己对母亲的影响。这就是为什么他跟你说话前会反复思考，也是为什么你觉得没人可以倾诉。”

‘Well, what can be done about it?’ she asked.

“那又能怎么办呢？”她问道。

‘When you get home, you could stand in front of a mirror while he’s talking to you so you can see how it works. But right now, what do you think about what he said?’ suggested Dr Q, and the conversation went on from there.

“你回家后，可以站在镜子前，听他跟你说话，这样你就能明白是怎么回事了。不过现在，你觉得他说的怎么样？”Q医生建议道，谈话就此继续下去。

In this case, Clara’s Parent was listening to her son with motherly respect, and that was her active Self at the moment. Meanwhile, her Child was reacting to what he said in quite another way, but neither her Parent nor her Adult was aware of her facial movements because she couldn’t ‘feel’ them. Her son, however, was fully informed of her Child’s reactions because they were right in front of his eyes. Her Parent was sincere but out of touch, and everybody in the group except herself could see why he hesitated to talk frankly to her.

在这种情况下，克拉拉的母亲正以母性的尊重倾听儿子的讲话，这就是她此刻的主动自我。与此同时，她的孩子对儿子的话语却有着截然不同的反应，但她的母亲和成年自我都没有察觉到孩子的面部表情，因为她无法“感受”到这些。然而，她的儿子却完全了解孩子的反应，因为这些反应就在他的眼前。她的母亲虽然真诚，却显得格格不入，除了她自己之外，小组里的每个人都能理解他为何迟迟不愿与她坦诚相待。

The plastic-face principle is related both to ‘mother’s smile’ as previously described, and to the ‘gallows laugh.’ Mother may be quite unaware of what her face is doing, and of the powerful effect it has on her children. 3

“塑料脸”原理既与前文所述的“母亲的微笑”有关，也与“绞刑架下的笑声”有关。母亲可能完全没有意识到自己的面部表情，以及这种表情对孩子产生的强大影响。

B • The Moving Self

B • 移动的自我

Along with the biological principle of the Plastic Face, the psychological principle of the Moving Self is equally important in keeping the script going, and is based on a similar defect of awareness. The feeling of ‘Self’ is a mobile one. It can reside in any of the three ego states at any given moment, and can jump from one to the other as occasion arises. That is, the feeling of Self is independent of all other properties of ego states and of what the ego state is doing or experiencing. It is like a charge of electricity that is free to jump from one capacitor to another, regardless of what the capacitors are used for; the feeling of Self is carried along with this ‘free cathexis.’ 4

与“可塑面孔”的生物学原理一样，“移动自我”的心理学原理对于维持这种模式的运转也同样重要，并且都基于类似的意识缺陷。“自我”的感觉是流动的。它可以在任何时刻存在于三种自我状态中的任何一种，并可以根据需要从一种状态跳转到另一种状态。也就是说，“自我”的感觉独立于自我状态的所有其他属性，也独立于自我状态正在做什么或正在经历什么。它就像一团电荷，可以自由地从一个电容器跳到另一个电容器，而不管这些电容器的用途是什么；“自我”的感觉就伴随着这种“自由的投注”而流动。

Whenever one of the ego states is fully active, that ego state is experienced at that moment as the real Self. When Jeder comes on with his angry Parent, he feels that that is really he, himself. A few minutes later, in his Adult ego state, when he wonders why he did it, he experiences the Adult as his real Self. Still later, if he is feeling ashamed in his Child ego state because he was so mean, his Child is felt as his real Self. (All this, of course, assumes that the incident is part of his real living, and that he is not merely playing the role of an angry Parent or of a contrite Child. Role-playing is the Child being phony, and is not real Self.)

当某种自我状态完全激活时，那一刻，该自我状态就会被体验为真实的自我。当杰德的愤怒父母自我状态出现时，他感觉那就是他自己。几分钟后，当他的成人自我状态出现，当他疑惑自己为什么会那样做时，他会体验到成人自我状态才是真实的自我。再过一段时间，如果他因为自己太过刻薄而在儿童自我状态中感到羞愧，那么儿童自我状态就会被体验为真实的自我。（当然，这一切的前提是，这件事是他真实生活的一部分，而不是他仅仅在扮演愤怒的父母或懊悔的孩子的角色。角色扮演是儿童自我状态的伪装，并非真实的自我。）

To illustrate the effect that the mobile Self has in everyday life, let us take the homely example of a nagging wife. Ordinarily Zoe is good-natured, sociable, and adaptable, but at certain times she becomes very critical of her husband. This is her nagging Parent. Later, she brings out again her fun-loving, sociable, adapted Child, and forgets what she has said to him in her Parent ego state. But he does not forget, and remains wary and detached. If this sequence is repeated again and again, his wariness and detachment become permanent, which she fails to understand. ‘We have so much fun together,’ says her charming Child. ‘Why is it that you withdraw from me?’ When her Child is her real Self, she forgets or overlooks what she said while her Parent was her real Self. Thus one ego state does not keep a very good record of what the other ego states have done. Her Parent overlooks all the fun they have had, and her Child forgets all the criticism she has offered. But Jeder’s Child (and Adult as well) remembers what her Parent said, and he lives in a continual state of apprehension that it will happen again.

为了说明移动自我对日常生活的影响，我们不妨举一个唠叨妻子的例子。佐伊通常性格温和、善于交际、适应力强，但有时她会变得非常挑剔丈夫。这就是她唠叨的“父母”自我。之后，她又会展现出她热爱生活、善于交际、适应力强的“孩子”自我，并忘记了她以“父母”自我状态对丈夫说过的话。但丈夫并没有忘记，他仍然保持警惕和疏离。如果这种模式反复出现，他的警惕和疏离就会变成永久性的，而佐伊却无法理解。“我们在一起玩得那么开心，”她迷人的“孩子”自我说道，“你为什么疏远我呢？”当“孩子”自我成为她真正的自我时，她会忘记或忽略她在以“父母”自我状态时说过的话。因此，一种自我状态并不能很好地记录其他自我状态的行为。她的“父母”自我忽略了他们曾经拥有的所有快乐时光，而她的“孩子”自我则忘记了她曾经提出的所有批评。但杰德的孩子（以及成年后的他）都记得父母说过的话，他一直生活在恐惧之中，害怕同样的事情会再次发生。

Jeder, on the other hand, may take very good care of her in his Parent ego state, but his Child may complain about her and whine. His Parent, overlooking or forgetting what his Child has done, may then reproach her with ingratitude ‘after all he has done for her.’ She may appreciate what he has done, but lives in apprehension of his Child’s next sallies. His Parent thinks that he himself, his real Self, has always been considerate of her, which is true. But it is also true that when his whining Child is active, that is also he himself, his real Self. Thus by one ego state or real Self forgetting what the others have done, Jeder can again keep his script going without having to take responsibility for it. His Parent can say: ‘I’ve always been so nice to her, I don’t know why she acts this way. I didn’t do anything to bring it on. Women sure are funny.’ His Parent forgets how his Child has provoked her, but she, being the victim, doesn’t. These two examples explain the tenacity of the OK positions described in Chapter 5, Section F .

另一方面，杰德在父母自我状态下可能对她照顾有加，但他的孩子自我状态却可能抱怨她、哭闹。他的父母自我状态忽略或忘记了孩子自我状态的所作所为，然后可能会责备她忘恩负义，“毕竟他为她做了那么多”。她或许感激他的付出，但却时刻提防着孩子自我状态的下一次挑衅。他的父母自我状态认为，他自己，他真正的自我，一直都很体贴她，这没错。但同样不可否认的是，当他哭闹的孩子自我状态活跃时，那也是他自己，他真正的自我状态。因此，由于一个自我状态或真正的自我状态忘记了其他状态或自我状态的所作所为，杰德可以再次重复他的剧本，而无需承担任何责任。他的父母自我状态可能会说：“我一直对她很好，我不知道她为什么会这样。我没有做任何事来招惹她。女人真是奇怪。”他的父母自我状态忘记了孩子自我状态是如何激怒她的，但她作为受害者，却不会忘记。这两个例子解释了第 5 章 F 节中描述的 OK 立场的顽固性。

Now that the principle is clear, a more lively example is in order. Such a heedless or irresponsible shift from one ego state to another might be called an ‘ego trip,’ but since that term is hippies’ slang for boasting, it might be more courteous to let them keep it and find another name for shifting ego states. We shall therefore call the following anecdote ‘Aminta and Mab, or A PAC Trip Through the Psyche.’

既然原理已经明确，那就需要一个更生动的例子。这种漫不经心或不负责任地从一种自我状态转换到另一种自我状态的行为，或许可以称之为“自我之旅”，但由于这个词是嬉皮士用来指代吹嘘的俚语，所以或许更礼貌的做法是让他们继续用这个词，而我们则另找一个词来描述这种自我状态的转换。因此，我们将以下轶事命名为“阿明塔和玛布，或一次穿越心灵的PAC之旅”。

Mab and her mother made each other so nervous that Mab took off for the weekend to visit a girl friend in another city. Her mother tracked her down by telephone and said: ‘If you aren’t home by Sunday morning, I’ll lock you out of the house.’ So Mab came back Sunday evening. Her mother refused to let her in and told her she would have to find her own apartment. Mab spent that night at the home of a neighboring girl friend. On Monday morning her mother called and forgave her. Mab told this episode to Dr Q, along with other examples of her mother’s inconsistency. Some of the stories weren’t at all clear, so Dr Q decided to talk to Mab and her mother together to see if he could find out what was really going on.

玛布和她母亲的关系非常紧张，以至于玛布周末跑去另一个城市看望她的一个女朋友。她母亲打电话找到了她，威胁说：“如果你周日早上还没回家，我就把你锁在门外。”于是玛布周日晚上回来了。她母亲拒绝让她进门，并告诉她必须自己找房子住。玛布当晚借宿在邻居一个女朋友家。周一早上，她母亲打电话来原谅了她。玛布把这件事以及她母亲前后矛盾的其他例子都告诉了Q医生。有些故事语焉不详，所以Q医生决定分别与玛布和她母亲谈话，看看能否弄清楚事情的真相。

As soon as they sat down, Aminta, the mother, came on with a strong Parent, righteously criticizing Mab for her sloppiness, her irresponsibility, her marijuana smoking, and other matters not uncommonly disputed between mothers and their eighteen-year-old girls. During the recital, Mab first sat with a slight smile, as though to say: ‘There she goes again!’ Then she looked away, as though to say: ‘I can’t stand it any more.’ After that she stared at the ceiling, as though to say: ‘Is nobody up there going to rescue me?’ Aminta paid no attention to Mab’s responses, but went ahead with her tirade.

她们刚坐下，母亲阿明塔就咄咄逼人地开始训斥玛布，义正言辞地批评她邋遢、不负责任、吸食大麻，以及其他一些母亲和十八岁女儿之间常见的争论话题。朗诵过程中，玛布先是带着一丝微笑坐着，仿佛在说：“她又来了！”然后她移开视线，仿佛在说：“我受够了。”之后，她盯着天花板，仿佛在说：“难道上面没有人来救我吗？”阿明塔对玛布的反应置若罔闻，继续她的训斥。

When this was exhausted, Aminta changed her tune. She began to talk about what a hard time she was having; not in a whining Childlike way, but giving a realistic Adult appraisal of her marital problems, which were well known to Dr Q. At this juncture Mab turned and looked directly at her mother with an entirely new expression, as though to say: ‘After all, she is a real person.’ As Aminta went on, Dr Q was able to trace her shifts in ego state from moment to moment, based on his detailed knowledge of her background and experiences. At one stage she went through the same sequence as she had during the ‘lockout’ episode, first coming on with her angry Father Parent (turning Mab out of the house), and then relenting as her tender Mother Parent took over (worrying about her ‘little girl’ wandering around the town with no place to lay her head). This was followed by more Adult, then helpless Child, and after that angry Father again.

当这一切结束后，阿明塔改变了说法。她开始倾诉自己的困境；不再是孩子般哭闹，而是以成年人的视角，理性地分析自己的婚姻问题，这些问题Q博士早已知晓。这时，玛布转过身，用一种截然不同的表情直视着母亲，仿佛在说：“她毕竟也是个活生生的人。”随着阿明塔的讲述，Q博士凭借对她背景和经历的深入了解，能够追踪她自我状态的瞬息变化。有一段时间，她经历了与“锁门事件”中相同的过程：先是愤怒的父亲本性（把玛布赶出家门），然后温柔的母亲本性占据主导（担心“小女儿”在城里游荡，无处可去）。之后，她又展现出成年人的一面，接着是无助的孩子本性，最后再次回到愤怒的父亲本性。

These wanderings can be traced by a line drawn through Aminta’s ego states as in Figure 13 . Starting with FP (Father Parent), we move on to MP (Mother Parent), then down to A (Adult), followed by C (Child), then returning to FP. Listening further, the line took the course shown in the diagram, FP to A to C and back to MP. In this way we can follow Aminta’s PAC Trip as she moves from one circle to another.

这些游走轨迹可以通过一条穿过阿明塔自我状态的线来追踪，如图13所示。从FP（父亲/父母）开始，我们依次经过MP（母亲/父母），然后向下到达A（成人），接着是C（儿童），最后回到FP。继续聆听，这条线沿着图中所示的路径行进，从FP到A到C，再回到MP。通过这种方式，我们可以跟随阿明塔的PAC之旅，看她如何从一个圆圈移动到另一个圆圈。

The question is, what does this line represent? It represents Aminta’s feeling of Self, a feeling which does not reside in any one ego state, but can move freely from one to another, carried along by the ‘free cathexis.’ No matter which circle she was in at any moment, she still felt that it was her ‘real Self’ talking. The course or locus of the free cathexis is a continuous line.

问题是，这条线代表什么？它代表阿明塔的自我感受，这种感受并不局限于任何单一的自我状态，而是可以自由地在不同状态之间转换，由“自由投注”牵引。无论她身处哪个层面，她都感觉那是她的“真我”在说话。自由投注的路径或轨迹是一条连续的线。

FIGURE 13

图 13

Aminta is not aware that ‘she’ is changing or that her behavior is changing from moment to moment, because the feeling ‘This is really me’ stays the same throughout. Thus, when we say that ‘she’ moved from one ego state to another, we mean her free cathexis did, carrying with it a continuous feeling of real Self. To ‘herself’ she seemed the same consistent person all along, but she changed so much from one phase to the next, that to someone else it seemed as though there were several different people there (in her head), each taking its turn in talking. That is the way it seemed to Mab, and that is why she could not cope with her mother. She was unable to get any feeling of consistency that would enable her to predict how Aminta would behave or respond from one moment to the next, so that she could adapt herself to her mother’s mood. And Mab’s behavior at times seemed just as arbitrary to her mother.

阿明塔并没有意识到“她”正在改变，也没有意识到自己的行为每时每刻都在变化，因为“这才是真正的我”这种感觉始终如一。因此，当我们说“她”从一种自我状态转换到另一种自我状态时，我们指的是她自由的投注状态发生了转变，并伴随着一种持续的真实自我感。对“她自己”而言，她似乎始终如一，但她从一个阶段到另一个阶段的变化如此之大，以至于在别人看来，仿佛在她脑海里有好几个不同的人，轮流说话。玛布就是这么觉得的，这也是她无法与母亲相处的原因。她无法获得任何一致性的感觉，从而无法预测阿明塔下一刻的行为或反应，也无法调整自己以适应母亲的情绪。而玛布的行为有时在母亲看来也同样随意。

Since both Aminta and Mab understood their own ego states, it was not difficult to clarify the situation for them, and they got along better after that.

由于阿明塔和玛布都了解自己的自我状态，所以向她们解释清楚情况并不难，之后她们的关系也更好了。

The behavior of Clara, as described in the previous section, illustrates another way in which the lack of recognition between the different ego states has a profound effect on the whole life course of the person, and the spouse and children as well. There two ego states were active simultaneously, one listening sympathetically and the other grimacing, while they studiously ignored each other like suspicious strangers, although they had been cooped up in the same inner space ship for forty-five years.

如前文所述，克拉拉的行为揭示了不同自我状态之间缺乏认知如何对个体及其配偶和子女的整个人生轨迹产生深远影响。在克拉拉的例子中，两种自我状态同时活跃：一种充满同情地倾听，另一种则面露凶相，尽管它们已被困在同一艘内在飞船中长达四十五年，却仍然像互不信任的陌生人一样刻意忽略彼此。

Another interesting variant occurs when the person refuses to acknowledge his own behavior even to himself. (This, too, was mentioned toward the end of Chapter Five .) Thus, a man may continue to say sincerely that he is a good driver, even though he has at least one serious accident every year, and a woman may maintain that she is a good cook even though she burns the dinner regularly. The sincerity comes from the fact that the Adult in each case is a good driver or a good cook, and the accidents are caused by the Child. Because such people have a thick and rigid boundary between the two ego states, the Adult pays no heed to what the Child has done, and can truthfully say that ‘I (my Adult Self) have never made a mistake.’ The same can happen to people who are less up tight and behave well when they are sober (with the Adult in charge) but make mistakes when they are drinking (when the Child takes over). Some of these even black out when they drink so that the Adult is completely unaware of what they have done in their intoxicated state, and in this way they can maintain the fiction of righteousness in a watertight, alcoholic way. This can happen the other way round with a person who is ineffectual in the Adult state, but has a productive Child. Just as the ‘bad’ people don’t understand the reprimands or criticisms they get for their follies, so these ‘good’ people are unable to accept compliments for what they produced, or do so only out of politeness. The Adult really doesn’t know what people are talking about when they say that the Child’s creations are worthwhile or valuable, since the Adult was out of commission when they were created.

另一种有趣的变体是，这个人甚至拒绝承认自己的行为，哪怕是对自己。（这一点在第五章末尾也提到过。）因此，一个人可能仍然真诚地说自己是个好司机，即使他每年至少发生一次严重事故；一个女人可能坚持认为自己厨艺精湛，即使她经常把饭菜烧糊。这种真诚源于这样一个事实：在每种情况下，成年人都是一个好司机或好厨师，而事故是由孩童造成的。由于这类人在两种自我状态之间有着一道厚重而僵硬的界限，成年人对孩童的所作所为毫不在意，并可以理直气壮地说：“我（我的成年人自我）从未犯过错。”同样的情况也可能发生在那些不那么拘谨、清醒时（成年人主导）表现良好，但在饮酒后（孩童占据主导）却容易犯错的人身上。有些人甚至会在饮酒后失去意识，以至于成年后的自己完全不记得自己在醉酒状态下做了什么，从而得以用酒精营造出天衣无缝的正义假象。反过来，有些人成年后无能为力，但童年时期却颇有建树。正如“坏人”无法理解自己因愚蠢行为而受到的责备或批评一样，这些“好人”也无法接受别人对他们作品的赞扬，或者只是出于礼貌才勉强接受。当人们称赞童年时期的作品有价值时，成年后的自己其实并不理解，因为这些作品诞生时，成年后的自己早已神志不清。

We have also previously discussed the rich woman who doesn’t become poor when she loses her money, and the poor man who doesn’t become rich when he gets some. In those cases, the Child knows from his script directives whether he is rich or poor, and mere money isn’t going to change his position. Similarly, the man’s Child knows whether he is a good driver, or not, and the woman’s whether she is a good cook, and a few accidents or spoiled meals are not going to change the Child’s mind.

我们之前也讨论过，富婆失去财富后不会变穷，穷人得到一些钱后也不会变富。在这些例子中，孩子从剧本指令中就能判断自己是富是穷，金钱本身并不会改变他的处境。同样，男人的孩子知道他开车技术好不好，女人的孩子知道她厨艺好不好，几次小事故或饭菜失败也不会改变孩子的看法。

The position after a PAC trip is usually one of bland disclaimer. ‘I’m OK. My own Parent didn’t notice me doing anything, so I don’t know what you’re talking about.’ In these cases there is a clear implication that the other person is not-OK for reacting to any objectionable behavior. This is an emergency sweatshirt that reads ‘I forgive myself’ on the front, and ‘Why can’t you forgive me?’ on the back.

家长会之后，通常的回应是敷衍的免责声明：“我没事。我自己的父母都没注意到我做了什么，所以我不知道你在说什么。” 在这种情况下，言下之意很明显：对方对任何不当行为的反应都是不对的。这就好比一件应急卫衣，正面写着“我原谅自己”，背面写着“你为什么不原谅我？”

There is a simple remedy for this common lack of awareness, in one ego state, for what the other ego states have done. That is for the Adult to remember and to take full responsibility for the actions of all the real Selves. This will stop the cop-outs (‘You mean to tell me I did that? I must have been out of my mind!’) and replace them with face-ups (‘Yes, I remember doing that, and it was really I myself who did it,’ or even better, ‘I’ll see that that doesn’t happen again.’) It is apparent that this suggestion has many legal implications, since it would tend to eliminate the cowardly and convenient insanity cop-out. (‘Wooden Brain,’ or ‘You can’t blame the me for what the I did.’)

对于这种常见的意识缺失——即在一种自我状态下，意识不到其他自我状态所做的事情——有一个简单的解决方法。那就是让“成人”记住并承担所有真实自我行为的全部责任。这将阻止推卸责任（“你是说我做了那件事？我当时一定是疯了！”），取而代之的是坦诚面对（“是的，我记得我做过那件事，而且确实是我做的。”或者更好的是，“我会确保那种事不再发生。”）。显然，这个建议具有许多法律意义，因为它有助于消除懦弱且方便的以精神错乱为借口的推卸责任方式（“我脑子不好使”，或者“你不能因为我做了什么就怪我。”）。

C • Fascination and Imprinting

C • 迷恋与印记

These are best illustrated by considering the difficulties of Neville and his wife, Julia. Neville had a mole on his left cheek which exerted a morbid fascination on Julia’s Child. During their courtship she succeeded in suppressing the slight repulsion aroused by this blemish, but as time passed it became increasingly troublesome, so that by the end of the honeymoon it was almost impossible for her to look straight at his face. She did not mention this uneasiness to him for fear of hurting his feelings. She did think of suggesting that he have it removed, but she decided that this would merely replace the mole with a scar, which she might find even more troublesome, so she said nothing.

内维尔和他的妻子朱莉娅的遭遇最能说明这一点。内维尔左脸颊上有一颗痣，这颗痣让朱莉娅的孩子产生了一种病态的迷恋。在他们恋爱期间，朱莉娅努力压抑着对这颗痣的些许反感，但随着时间的推移，这种反感变得越来越强烈，以至于蜜月结束时，她几乎无法直视他的脸。她害怕伤害他的感情，所以没有向他提起这种不安。她确实想过建议他把痣去掉，但她转念一想，那样只会留下疤痕，而她可能会觉得疤痕更让她困扰，所以她什么也没说。

Neville, on his side, was a pimple-picker, and whenever they were lying naked together he would inspect her body, and if he found any sort of minute bulge on her skin, he would feel a strong urge to pick it out with his fingernail. Julia found this a very disagreeable intrusion on her person. Sometimes his urge was so great and her objections so vehement, that they would end up turning away from each other in ill-humor.

内维尔则是个爱抠痘痘的人，每当他们赤身裸体地躺在一起时，他都会仔细检查她的身体，如果发现她皮肤上有任何细小的凸起，他都会忍不住用指甲抠出来。朱莉娅觉得这种行为非常令人反感。有时他的欲望如此强烈，而她的反对又如此激烈，以至于他们最终会因为不愉快而互相推开。

In the course of time they also discovered that they had an unfortunate difference in their sexual tastes, which at first seemed trivial, but later became a serious bone of contention. Neville, who had been raised by a nursemaid in the West Indies, was turned on by smocks and sandals, while Julia, following the examples of her mother and sister, liked to dress more fashionably and wear high heels. Neville had, in fact, what amounted to a fetish for sandals, while Julia had a ‘counterfetish’ for high heels; she wanted men to be excited by the way she dressed. Hence, when she complied with Neville’s desires and wore sandals, she was turned off, while if she went about the house in high heels, he was turned off. Thus, although from the outside they seemed to be happily mated, their union was seriously disturbed by seeming trivialities based on very early experiences. This was particularly distressing because they themselves had thought they would make an ideal couple, well matched by all the conventional social and psychological computer standards.

随着时间的推移，他们发现彼此在性偏好上存在着令人遗憾的差异。起初，这看似无关紧要，但后来却成了严重的矛盾根源。内维尔在西印度群岛由保姆抚养长大，对宽松长袍和凉鞋情有独钟；而朱莉娅则受母亲和姐姐的影响，喜欢穿着更时尚的服饰和高跟鞋。事实上，内维尔对凉鞋有着近乎迷恋的癖好，而朱莉娅则对高跟鞋有着“反向迷恋”；她希望男人能被她的穿着所吸引。因此，当她顺从内维尔的意愿穿上凉鞋时，她会感到反感；而如果她穿着高跟鞋在家中走动，内维尔又会感到厌烦。就这样，尽管从表面上看他们是一对幸福的伴侣，但这些基于早期经历的看似微不足道的小事却严重影响了他们的婚姻。这尤其令人沮丧，因为他们自己曾认为他们会是一对理想的伴侣，在所有传统的社会和心理标准下都堪称完美匹配。

Fascination occurs in lower animals, and also in infants at a certain age. The Child parts of both Neville and Julia continued to be fascinated (positively in his case, negatively in hers) by minor skin blemishes after they grew up. Imprinting has been mainly studied in birds, who will mistake for their mothers whatever objects are shown to them during the early days of their existence outside the egg. Thus ducks can be ‘imprinted’ or turned on by a piece of colored cardboard, and will follow it around a track as though it were their mother. Sexual fetishes, which also develop very early in life, exert a similar influence on men, while women may become devoted to counterfetishes which they discover are sexually exciting to the men around them.

迷恋现象不仅存在于低等动物中，也存在于特定年龄段的婴儿中。内维尔和朱莉娅的“孩童”人格在长大后仍然对一些细微的皮肤瑕疵保持着浓厚的兴趣（内维尔是积极的，朱莉娅是消极的）。印刻现象主要在鸟类身上进行研究，鸟类会在破壳而出后的早期阶段，将任何出现在它们眼前的物体误认为是自己的母亲。因此，鸭子可以被一块彩色纸板“印刻”或“激发”兴趣，并像追随母亲一样跟随它沿着轨道前进。性恋物癖也在生命早期发展起来，对男性产生类似的影响，而女性则可能沉迷于她们发现能够激发周围男性性欲的反向恋物癖。

Fascinations and fetishes are very deep-seated, and may seriously disturb the smooth course of living in those who are afflicted with them, very much as drug addiction does. In spite of all attempts at rational Adult control, the Child is almost irresistibly repulsed by or attracted to the specific object, and as a result may make sacrifices out of all proportion to the situation in order to avoid or attain it. Hence, fascinations and fetishes may play an important part in determining the outcome of a script, particularly in the selection of those destined to play the principal roles. This is another factor which lessens the individual’s ability to decide for himself what his fate will be.

迷恋和恋物癖根深蒂固，如同毒瘾一般，会严重扰乱受其困扰者的正常生活。尽管成年人竭尽全力进行理性控制，孩子几乎无法抗拒地被特定的对象所吸引或排斥，因此，为了避免或获得它，他们可能会做出与实际情况不成比例的牺牲。因此，迷恋和恋物癖可能在决定人生剧本的走向方面发挥重要作用，尤其是在选择扮演主角的人选方面。这也是削弱个人自主决定自身命运能力的另一个因素。

The remedy for fascinations is to become aware of them, to talk them over, and to decide whether they can be lived with. The last part can be ‘skulled out’ in ‘head transactions’ – internal dialogues between the Adult and the Child, in this case keeping the Parent out of it until the other two understand each other clearly. After that the Parent can be allowed its say. If the person decides in his head that he can live comfortably with a negative fascination – such as a girl with a physical defect – well and good. If not, then either a remedy must be sought or he should look for a new companion. He cannot realize, without considerable analysis of his thoughts and feelings, how much such a single item may be affecting his reactions, usually as a result of his own early experiences. On the other hand, a positive fascination may enslave him beyond the bounds of reason, and should be just as carefully considered. Exactly the same applies to women who are fascinated by blemishes in their men.

克服迷恋的方法是意识到它们的存在，与它们进行讨论，并决定是否能够接受它们。最后一部分可以通过“头脑对话”来解决——即成人与儿童之间的内心对话，在这种情况下，要先排除父母的参与，直到前两者彼此理解为止。之后，父母才能发表意见。如果一个人在头脑中决定可以坦然接受某种负面的迷恋——例如，迷恋一个有身体缺陷的女孩——那就很好。如果不是，那么他要么需要寻求解决办法，要么应该寻找新的伴侣。如果不深入分析自己的想法和感受，他无法意识到这样一件小事对他的反应产生了多大的影响，这通常是由于他早年的经历造成的。另一方面，正面的迷恋可能会使他失去理智，因此也应该同样谨慎对待。同样的道理也适用于那些迷恋伴侣身上瑕疵的女性。

The remedy for fetishes is similar. But since here another person is actively involved, there are other helpful possibilities as well. There can be an agreement for mutual indulgences, and the fetish may be happily ‘lived out’ with the lapse of time.

治疗恋物癖的方法类似。但由于恋物癖涉及另一方，因此还有其他一些有效的方法。双方可以达成协议，互相满足对方的欲望，随着时间的推移，恋物癖或许能够得到圆满的解决。

D • The Odorless Smell

D • 无味气味

In addition to the biological peculiarities of the human organism described above (the plastic face, the moving self, fascination and imprinting), there are more elusive possibilities which could have an equally profound effect on human living. The first of these is extrasensory perception. If Dr Rhine’s 5 cards are sending out signals which cannot be detected by the present generation of physical instruments, but can be received by a properly attuned human mind, that is obviously a matter of considerable, though not necessarily decisive, importance. If such signals exist, their objective detection would be of interest at first mainly for sensational reasons, and there would be a field day in the Sunday supplements. The later developments of such a discovery cannot be foreseen until it occurs. No doubt it would interest the military, which is already doing research in this field, especially if the target could be selected, just as it would be in the case of the long-distance atomic- and hydrogen-bomb detonator which could be flown over the factories and depots of a potential enemy.

除了上文所述的人体生物学特性（可塑性强的面部表情、善于表达的自我意识、迷恋和印记）之外，还有一些更为难以捉摸的可能性，它们同样会对人类生活产生深远的影响。其中之一便是超感官知觉。如果莱茵博士的卡片发出的信号无法被现有的物理仪器探测到，但却能被适当调整的人类思维接收，那么这显然是一件意义重大的事情，尽管未必是决定性的。如果此类信号确实存在，那么最初对其进行客观探测的目的可能主要在于其耸人听闻的程度，届时报纸的周日增刊将会大肆报道。在发现此类信号之前，我们无法预知其后续发展。毫无疑问，军方对此会很感兴趣，因为他们已经在进行这方面的研究，尤其是在能够像远程原子弹和氢弹引爆器那样，将目标锁定在潜在敌人的工厂和仓库上空的情况下。

Telepathy would be of considerably more significance if it existed. If one human mind can send readable messages to another, and an objective means for controlling and recording such messages could be devised, that would help to understand many things about human behavior. This is the second possibility. ‘Telepathic phenomena,’ when they are reported, seem to occur most often and most poignantly between intimately related people such as husbands and wives, or parents and children, who are presumably more closely attuned to each other than to other members of the human race. Telepathy would offer an ideal medium for hovering parents to exert control over their children’s behavior, and would certainly be of prime interest to the script analyst if it existed. Intuition, which is a function of the Child ego state, 6 often verges on telepathy, in that rather obscure facts about other people can be intuited with a minimum of sensory clues. 7

如果心灵感应真的存在，其意义将更加重大。如果一个人的心灵能够向另一个人发送可读的信息，并且能够设计出一种客观的方法来控制和记录这些信息，那将有助于我们理解人类行为的许多方面。这是第二种可能性。“心灵感应现象”的报道似乎最常发生在关系亲密的人之间，例如夫妻或父母子女，他们彼此之间的默契可能比与其他人类成员之间的默契更高。心灵感应将为过度干预子女行为的父母提供理想的媒介，如果它真的存在，无疑会引起剧本分析师的极大兴趣。直觉是儿童自我状态的一种功能，它常常接近心灵感应，因为人们只需极少的感官线索就能直觉地感知到关于他人的模糊信息。

When telepathy has been claimed to occur, it is very fragile and easily broken, and depends a great deal upon the frame of mind of the agent and the percipient. Extraneous factors, such as challenges by scientists, seem to diminish its accuracy or abolish it altogether, according to the published results of such challenges. 8 This does not necessarily mean that telepathy does not exist, but rather gives us an indication of its nature if it does exist. I would propose the following hypothesis, which explains, with only one major and one minor assumption, all the scientifically established (mostly negative) findings. If telepathy occurs, then the young infant is the best percipient; as he grows older, this faculty becomes corrupted and progressively more unreliable, so that it occurs only sporadically and under special conditions in grownups. In structural language, the hypothesis reads: If telepathy exists, it is a function of the very young Child, and soon becomes corrupted and impaired by interference from the Parent and the Adult.

当人们声称心灵感应存在时，它非常脆弱且容易被打破，并且很大程度上取决于施事者和受事者的心理状态。根据已发表的挑战结果，诸如科学家的质疑等外部因素似乎会降低其准确性，甚至完全消除它。 8 这并不一定意味着心灵感应不存在，而是为我们揭示了如果它存在的话，其本质是什么。我提出以下假设，该假设仅用一个主要假设和一个次要假设，就能解释所有已确立的（大多为否定性的）科学发现。如果心灵感应存在，那么幼小的婴儿是最佳的感知者；随着年龄的增长，这种能力会逐渐受损，变得越来越不可靠，以至于在成年人身上，心灵感应只会在特殊情况下偶尔发生。用结构化的语言来说，该假设是：如果心灵感应存在，它是幼童的一种能力，很快就会受到父母和成年人的干扰而受损。

Third, just as interesting and important, although more materialistic, is the question of odorless smells. It is well known that the male of the Bombyces moth can detect downwind the presence of a freshly emerged female as far as a mile away, and large numbers of males will fly against the wind and assemble around a caged female. 9 We have to assume that the female gives off an odorous substance which attracts the males through something like the sense of smell. The question at issue here is: Does the male ‘know’ that he is ‘smelling’ something, or does he respond ‘automatically’ to the chemical? It is probable that he is not ‘aware’ of what happens, but simply responds, and flies toward the female. That is, he is attracted through his olfactory system by an ‘odorless’ smell.

第三，同样有趣且重要的，尽管更偏向物质层面的，是关于无味气味的问题。众所周知，蚕蛾雄性能够顺风探测到一英里外刚羽化的雌蛾，大量的雄蛾会逆风飞向被囚禁的雌蛾。我们必须假设雌蛾会散发出某种气味物质，通过类似嗅觉的机制吸引雄蛾。这里的关键问题是：雄蛾是否“知道”自己“闻到”了什么，还是它只是“自动”地对这种化学物质做出反应？很可能它并没有“意识到”发生了什么，只是做出反应，飞向雌蛾。也就是说，它是通过嗅觉系统被一种“无味”的气味吸引的。

With a human being, the situation regarding smells is this: (1) If he smells certain odors, such as the perfume of flowers, he is aware of them and is consciously attracted to them. The experience may leave memory traces and that, as far as we know, is all there is to it. (2) If he smells other odors, such as feces, two things commonly occur: (a) he is aware of them and is consciously repelled by them; and (b) without any volition on his part, his autonomic nervous system is affected by them, and he may gag or throw up. (3) We can postulate a third situation: in the presence of certain chemicals, his nervous system is affected in a subtle way without his smelling anything or being aware of it. I am not speaking here of toxic matter such as carbon monoxide, but of substances which stimulate specific receptors and leave specific traces or engrams in the brain.

对人类而言，嗅觉的情况如下：(1) 如果闻到某些气味，例如花香，他会意识到这些气味的存在，并被其吸引。这种体验可能会留下记忆痕迹，据我们所知，这就是全部。(2) 如果闻到其他气味，例如粪便的气味，通常会发生两种情况：(a) 他会意识到这些气味的存在，并对其产生厌恶感；(b) 他的自主神经系统会在不知不觉中受到影响，导致他作呕或呕吐。(3) 我们还可以假设第三种情况：在某些化学物质存在的情况下，他的神经系统会以一种微妙的方式受到影响，而他却闻不到任何气味，也意识不到这种影响。我这里指的不是一氧化碳之类的有毒物质，而是那些能够刺激特定受体并在大脑中留下特定痕迹或记忆印记的物质。

Several facts should be noted in this connection.
