17 Berne, E.“员工-患者员工会议。”《美国精神病学杂志》，125：286-293，1968 年 9 月。

#↩

CHAPTER SEVENTEEN

第十七章

The Script Signs

剧本符号

The first duty of a group therapist, whatever theoretical approach he is using, is to observe every movement of every muscle of every patient during every second of the group meeting. In order to accomplish this, he should limit the size of his group to no more than eight patients, and take whatever other measures are necessary to insure that he will be able to carry out this duty with the greatest possible efficiency. 1 If he chooses as his approach script analysis, the most powerful instrument known for effective group treatment, what he is looking for and listening for primarily are those specific signs which indicate the nature of the patient’s script and its origins in past experience and parental programing. Only if the patient gets ‘out of his script’ can he emerge as a person capable of autonomous vitality, creativity, fullfilment, and citizenship.

无论采用何种理论方法，团体治疗师的首要职责都是在团体治疗的每一秒，观察每位患者每一块肌肉的每一个动作。为了做到这一点，他应该将团体人数限制在八人以内，并采取其他一切必要措施，以确保能够尽可能高效地履行这一职责。如果他选择脚本分析作为方法——这是目前已知最有效的团体治疗工具——那么他主要寻找和倾听的是那些能够揭示患者脚本本质及其源于过往经历和父母教养的特定信号。只有当患者“摆脱脚本的束缚”时，他才能成为一个拥有自主活力、创造力、成就感和公民意识的人。

A • The Script Signal

A • 脚本信号

For each patient there is a characteristic posture, gesture, mannerism, tic, or symptom which signifies that he is living ‘in his script,’ or has ‘gone into’ his script. As long as such ‘script signals’ occur, the patient is not cured, no matter how much ‘progress’ he has made. He may be less miserable, or happier, living in his script world, but he is still in that world and not in the real world, and this will be confirmed by his dreams, his outside experiences, and his attitude toward the therapist and the other members of the group.

每个患者都有其特有的姿势、手势、习惯、抽动或症状，这些都表明他正“活在自己的剧本里”，或者已经“陷入”了自己的剧本。只要这些“剧本信号”持续存在，无论患者取得了多少“进步”，他都无法痊愈。他或许在自己的剧本世界里感觉不那么痛苦，甚至更快乐，但他仍然身处那个世界，而非真实世界。这一点会在他的梦境、外部经历以及他对治疗师和其他小组成员的态度中得到印证。

The script signal is usually first perceived intuitively by the therapist’s Child 2 (preconsciously, not unconsciously). Then one day it comes into full awareness and is taken over by his Adult. He immediately recognizes that it has been characteristic of the patient all along, and he wonders why he never really ‘noticed’ it before.

治疗师的“孩子”（Child）通常会首先凭直觉感知到这种脚本信号（前意识层面，而非无意识层面）。然后有一天，这种信号会完全进入他的意识，并被他“成人”的认知所掌控。他立刻意识到，这其实一直是患者的特征，并疑惑自己之前为何从未真正“注意到”过它。

Abelard, a middle-aged man who complained of depression and slowing up, had been in the group for three years and had made reasonably good ‘progress’ before Dr Q had more than a vague idea of what his script signal was. Abelard had Parental permission to laugh, which he did with great vigor and enjoyment at every opportunity, but he did not have permission to speak. If addressed, he went through a complicated, sluggish routine before he answered. He slowly pulled himself up in his chair, took hold of a cigarette, coughed, hummed as though collecting his thoughts, and then began: ‘Well …’ Then, one day when the group was discussing having babies, and other sexual matters, Dr Q ‘noticed’ for the first time that there was one other thing Abelard did before he spoke: he slid his hands under his belt quite far down. Dr Q said ‘Get your hands out of your pants, Abel!’ at which everyone, including Abelard, began to laugh, and suddenly they realized that he had been doing this all along, but no one had ever ‘noticed’ it before, neither the other members, Dr Q, nor Abelard himself. It then became clear that Abelard was living in a script world where the prohibition against talking was so severe that his testicles were in jeopardy. No wonder, then, that he never talked unless someone gave him permission to by asking him a question! As long as this script signal was present he could not be free to talk spontaneously, nor to decide other matters that were bothering him.

阿贝拉尔是一位中年男子，他抱怨自己抑郁，反应迟钝。他参加小组已经三年了，在Q医生对他的“脚本信号”有了大致了解之前，他已经取得了相当不错的“进步”。阿贝拉尔得到了父母的许可可以大笑，他抓住一切机会尽情地欢笑，但却没有发言的许可。如果有人和他说话，他会先进行一套复杂而迟缓的例行程序。他慢慢地在椅子上坐直，拿起一支烟，咳嗽几声，哼着歌，仿佛在整理思绪，然后才开口：“嗯……”后来有一天，小组讨论生育和其他性话题时，Q医生第一次“注意到”阿贝拉尔在发言前还有一个动作：他会把手伸到腰带下面很深的地方。 Q博士说：“把你的手从裤子里拿出来，亚伯！”话音刚落，包括亚伯拉尔在内的所有人都笑了起来。他们这才恍然大悟，原来他一直都在这么做，只是之前没人“注意到”过，无论是其他成员、Q博士，还是亚伯拉尔自己。这时大家才明白，亚伯拉尔生活在一个剧本世界里，那里禁止说话的禁令如此严苛，以至于他的睾丸都岌岌可危。难怪他从不说话，除非有人问他问题，让他开口！只要这个剧本信号存在，他就无法自由地自发说话，也无法决定其他困扰他的事情。

A more common and similar script signal occurs among women, and may also be perceived intuitively for a long time before it comes into full awareness; from experience, however, the therapist soon learns to see and evaluate it more quickly. Some women sit relaxed until a sexual subject comes up, and then they not only cross their knees, but wind the upper instep around the lower ankle, often simultaneously crossing their arms over their chests and sometimes also leaning forward. This posture forms a triple or quadruple protection against a violation which exists only in their script worlds and not in the real world of the group.

一种更常见且类似的脚本信号出现在女性群体中，这种信号可能在被完全意识到之前，会长时间以直觉的方式被感知；然而，根据经验，治疗师很快就能学会更快地观察和评估这种信号。有些女性会放松地坐着，直到谈到性话题，这时她们不仅会翘起二郎腿，还会将脚背缠绕在脚踝上，通常同时双臂交叉抱在胸前，有时还会身体前倾。这种姿势构成了一种三重或四重的保护，用来抵御只存在于她们脚本世界中而非群体现实世界中的侵犯。

Thus, it is possible to say to a patient: ‘It’s nice that you’re feeling better and making progress, but you can’t get well until you stop …’ and the script signal is inserted. This is the opening statement of an attempt to get a ‘cure contract’ or a ‘script contract’ instead of a ‘making progress’ contract. The patient may then agree that he is coming to the group to get out of his script, rather than to get companionship and handy household hints as to how to be happy while living in fear or misery. Clothing is a fertile field for script signals: the woman who is well dressed except for her shoes (she will be ‘rejected’ as her script calls for); the Lesbian who wears ‘dikey’ clothes (she will probably play ‘Making Ends Meet’ with money, be exploited by her girl friends, and attempt suicide); the male homosexual who wears ‘queenie’ clothes (he will get mixed up with women who put their lipstick on crooked, get beaten up by his lovers, and attempt suicide); and the woman who puts her lipstick on crooked (she will often be exploited by male homosexuals). Other script signs are blinking, tongue-chewing, jaw-clamping, sniffing, hand-wringing, ring-turning, and foot-tapping. An excellent list can be found in Feldman’s book on mannerisms of speech and gestures. 3

因此，可以对病人说：“很高兴你感觉好多了，也取得了进步，但你只有停止……”，才能真正康复，这样就插入了脚本信号。这是试图达成“治愈协议”或“脚本协议”而非“进步协议”的开场白。病人随后可能会同意，他来参加小组是为了摆脱自己的脚本，而不是为了获得陪伴和如何在恐惧或痛苦中保持快乐的实用生活小贴士。服装是脚本信号的重要载体：一位衣着考究却鞋子不合适的女士（她会像脚本要求的那样被“拒绝”）；一位穿着“女同性恋”服装的女同性恋（她可能会为了钱而节衣缩食，被闺蜜们剥削，并试图自杀）；一位穿着“娘娘腔”服装的男同性恋（他会和那些涂口红歪歪扭扭的女人混在一起，被情人殴打，并试图自杀）。还有那种涂口红涂歪了的女人（她常常会被男同性恋者利用）。其他一些肢体语言符号包括眨眼、咬舌头、咬紧牙关、吸鼻子、搓手、转动戒指和跺脚。费尔德曼关于言语和手势习惯的书中列出了一个非常好的清单。

Posture and carriage are also revealing. The tilt of the head in ‘Martyr’ and ‘Waif’ scripts is one of the commonest script signals. An extensive discussion can be found in Deutsch, 4 and a psychoanalytic interpretation, particularly of signals given while lying on the analytic couch, is given by Zeligs. 5

姿势和仪态也颇具启发性。“殉道者”和“孤儿”字形中头部的倾斜是最常见的字形特征之一。Deutsch 对此有详尽的论述，而 Zeligs 则从精神分析的角度，特别是对躺在分析床上时所呈现的信号，进行了解释。

The script signal is always a reaction to some Parental directive. In order to deal with it, the directive must be uncovered, which is usually easy to do, and the precise antithesis must be found, which may be more difficult, particularly if the signal is a response to an actual hallucination.

脚本信号总是对某种父母指令的反应。为了应对它，必须先找出该指令（这通常很容易做到），然后找到与之完全相反的指令（这可能更困难，尤其当该信号是对实际幻觉的反应时）。

B • The Physiological Component

B • 生理成分

The sudden onset of symptoms is also usually a script sign. Judith’s script called for her to ‘go crazy,’ as her sister had done, but she was resisting this parental command. As long as her Adult was in charge she was a normal healthy American girl. But if someone around her acted ‘crazy’ or said he felt ‘crazy,’ her Adult would drain away and her Child would be left with no protection. She would immediately get a headache and excuse herself, thus getting away from the scripty situation. On the couch, a similar sequence would occur. As long as Dr Q would talk to her or answer her, she was in good shape, but if he remained silent, her Adult would fade out, her Child would begin to come on with crazy thoughts, and she would get an instant headache. With some patients, nausea occurs in exactly the same way, only here the parental directive is ‘get sick’ instead of ‘go crazy,’ or, in grownup language, ‘be neurotic’ instead of ‘be psychotic.’ Anxiety attacks with palpitation, or sudden outbreaks of asthma or hives are also script signals.

症状的突然出现通常也是剧本的征兆。朱迪丝的剧本要求她像她姐姐那样“发疯”，但她却抗拒着这种来自父母的指令。只要她的“成人”角色掌控着局面，她就是一个正常健康的美国女孩。但如果她身边有人表现得“疯了”或者说自己感觉“疯了”，她的“成人”角色就会消失，她的“孩童”角色就会失去保护。她会立刻头痛，然后找借口离开，从而摆脱剧本设定的情境。在沙发上，类似的情况也会发生。只要Q医生和她说话或回答她的问题，她就一切正常；但如果他保持沉默，她的“成人”角色就会消失，“孩童”角色就会开始出现疯狂的想法，她也会立刻头痛。有些患者的恶心症状也以同样的方式出现，只是父母的指令是“生病”而不是“发疯”，或者用成人的语言来说，是“神经质”而不是“精神病”。伴有心悸的焦虑发作，或哮喘或荨麻疹的突然发作也是脚本信号。

Allergic outbreaks when the script is threatened may be quite severe. For example, Rose had been a hiker all her life, and had not suffered from poison oak since childhood. But when her psychoanalyst told her to get a divorce, she got such a severe attack that she had to be hospitalized, and terminated her analysis. He was not aware that her script called for her to get a divorce, but forbade it until her children were grown up. Severe attacks of asthma can also occur at such junctures, requiring hospitalization in an oxygen tent. A full awareness of the patient’s script can (I think) prevent such serious outbreaks. Ulcerative colitis and perforated gastric ulcer also come under suspicion here at times. In one case a paranoid gave up his script world and started to live in the real world without sufficient preparation and ‘protection,’ and less than a month later sugar appeared in his urine, marking the onset of diabetes. This brought him back to the ‘safety’ of his ‘Fall Sick’ script in a modified way.

当患者的“剧本”受到威胁时，过敏反应可能会非常严重。例如，罗斯一生都是徒步旅行者，自幼便未曾患过毒橡树皮炎。但当她的精神分析师建议她离婚时，她却突发严重的过敏反应，不得不住院治疗，并终止了与她的分析。这位分析师并不知道罗斯的“剧本”要求她离婚，但他禁止她这样做，直到她的孩子长大成人。严重的哮喘发作也可能在这样的时刻发生，需要患者入住氧气帐篷接受治疗。我认为，充分了解患者的“剧本”可以预防此类严重的过敏反应。溃疡性结肠炎和胃穿孔有时也需要引起怀疑。在一个案例中，一位偏执狂放弃了他“剧本”中的世界，开始在缺乏充分准备和“保护”的情况下生活在现实世界中，不到一个月后，他的尿液中就出现了糖，标志着糖尿病的开始。这让他以一种改变的方式回到了他“生病”的“剧本”中的“安全”状态。

The slogan ‘Think sphincter’ also refers to the physiological component of the script. The man with a tight mouth, and the person who eats, drinks, smokes, and talks simultaneously (as far as possible) are typical ‘script characters.’ The man addicted to laxatives or enemas may have an archaic ‘bowel’ script. Women with violation scripts may keep their Levator eni and Sphincter cunni muscles tightened up, resulting in painful intercourse. Premature and retarded ejaculation, and asthma, may also be regarded as sphincter disturbances of a scripty nature.

“想想括约肌”这句口号也指代了脚本的生理组成部分。嘴巴紧闭的人，以及尽可能同时进食、饮水、吸烟和说话的人，都是典型的“脚本人物”。沉迷于泻药或灌肠的人可能具有古老的“肠道”脚本。具有侵犯脚本的女性可能会使肛提肌和阴道括约肌持续紧绷，导致性交疼痛。早泄、延迟射精和哮喘也可能被视为脚本性质的括约肌功能障碍。

Sphincters are the organs of final display or payoff. The actual ‘cause’ of sphincter disturbances is of course nearly always in the central nervous system. The transactional aspects, however, do not arise from the ‘cause’ but from the effect. For example, whatever the ‘cause’ of premature ejaculation in the central nervous system, the effect is on the relationship between the man and his mate, and thus premature ejaculation arises from, or is a part of, or contributes to his script, which is usually a ‘failure’ script in other areas besides sex.

括约肌是最终展示或释放的器官。括约肌功能障碍的真正“原因”当然几乎总是存在于中枢神经系统。然而，其影响并非源于“原因”，而是源于“结果”。例如，无论中枢神经系统中早泄的“原因”是什么，其结果都会影响男性与其伴侣之间的关系。因此，早泄源于男性的某种“失败”模式，或者说是这种模式的一部分，或者说是这种模式的促成因素。这种模式通常在性以外的其他领域都是一种“失败”。

The importance of ‘thinking sphincter’ lies in the way the sphincters can be used transactionally. The Child in Mike intuitively senses very quickly in what way various people want to use sphincters against him. He knows that this man wants to urinate on him, that one wants to defecate on him, that a woman wants to spit on him, and so forth. 6 And he is almost always right, as he finds out in the long run if he engages with any of these people.

“思考括约肌”的重要性在于括约肌可以被巧妙地运用。迈克内心深处的孩童能够很快地凭直觉感知到不同的人想要如何利用括约肌来对付他。他知道这个人想在他身上撒尿，那个人想在他身上拉屎，一个女人想朝他吐口水，等等。 6 而且，他的预感几乎总是正确的，只要他最终与这些人接触，就会发现这一点。

What happens is this. When Mike first meets Pat (in the first ten seconds or at most, ten minutes, after they first set eyes on each other), Mike’s Child senses exactly what Pat’s Child is up to. But as quickly as possible, Pat’s Child, with the assistance of his Adult and Parent, generates a thick smoke screen which, like a jinn, gradually takes on a human form as Pat’s persona, or disguise. Mike then starts to ignore and bury his Child’s intuitive perception in favor of accepting Pat’s persona. Thus Pat cons Mike out of his accurate perception and offers his persona instead. Mike accepts Pat’s persona because Mike is just as busily throwing up a smoke screen to con Pat, and he is so intent on this that he forgets not only what his Child knows about Pat, but also what he knows about himself. I have discussed the first ten seconds in more detail elsewhere. People ignore their intuitive perceptions and accept each other’s personas instead because that is the polite thing to do and plays along with the needs of their games and scripts. This mutual acceptance is called ‘the social contract.’ 7

事情是这样的。当迈克第一次见到帕特时（最多十秒钟，或者最多十分钟），迈克的“孩子”就能准确地察觉到帕特的“孩子”的意图。但帕特的“孩子”会在他的“成人”和“父母”的帮助下，迅速制造出一层浓厚的烟雾，这层烟雾如同精灵一般，逐渐幻化成帕特的人形，或者说是伪装。迈克开始忽略并掩盖他“孩子”的直觉，转而接受帕特的伪装。就这样，帕特欺骗了迈克，让他失去了原本的判断，转而展现出自己的真实面目。迈克之所以接受帕特的伪装，是因为他自己也忙于制造烟雾来欺骗帕特，他如此专注于此，以至于不仅忘记了“孩子”对帕特的了解，也忘记了自己对自己的了解。我在其他地方更详细地讨论过最初的十秒钟。人们之所以忽略自己的直觉，转而接受彼此的伪装，是因为这样做是礼貌之举，也符合他们游戏和剧本的需要。这种相互接受被称为“社会契约”。

The script significance of sphincters is that each person seeks, and intuitively spots, someone who has a complementary script. Thus, to put it in the most basic terms, the person whose script calls for him to eat shit will seek out someone whose script calls for him to shit on people. They will hook into each other in the first ten minutes, spend more or less time disguising the sphincter basis of their attraction for each other, and if they continue beyond this point, eventually they will satisfy each other’s script needs.

括约肌的剧本意义在于，每个人都会寻找并凭直觉发现与自己剧本互补的人。因此，简单来说，剧本要求他吃屎的人会寻找剧本要求他欺负别人的人。他们会在最初的十分钟内互相吸引，或多或少地掩饰彼此吸引力的“括约肌”基础，如果他们继续发展下去，最终会满足彼此剧本的需求。

If this does not sound credible, consider the more flagrant cases where there is an immediate satisfaction of script needs. A male homosexual can go into a men’s room or bar, or even walk down the street, and in ten seconds he can unerringly spot the man he is looking for, one who will not only give him the kind of sexual satisfaction he wants, but do it in the way his script calls for: in a semi-public place where the thrills of a game of ‘Cops & Robbers’ are added to the sexual satisfaction, or in a quiet place where they may form a longer-lasting liaison which may (if the script calls for it) end in murder. An experienced heterosexual man walking down the right street in any large city can usually pick out unerringly just the woman he wants: one who will not only give the desired type of sexual satisfaction, but will also play the games that fit into his script. He can get rolled, paid, drunk, high, killed, or married, whichever one his script calls for. Many civilized or well-brought up people learn to ignore or suppress their intuitions, although these abilities can be unmasked and developed under proper conditions.

如果这听起来不够可信，不妨想想那些更明目张胆的例子，在这些例子中，剧本的需求能够立即得到满足。一个男同性恋者可以走进男厕所或酒吧，甚至走在街上，十秒钟之内就能准确地找到他想要的男人，这个人不仅能给他想要的性满足，还能按照剧本的要求进行：在一个半公开的场所，在性满足之外，再加入一场“警察抓小偷”游戏的刺激；或者在一个安静的地方，他们可以建立一段更长久的亲密关系，而这段关系（如果剧本需要的话）最终可能会以谋杀告终。一个经验丰富的异性恋男人，走在任何大城市的合适街道上，通常都能准确地找到他想要的女人：她不仅能给他想要的性满足，还能玩一些符合他剧本的游戏。他可以被骗、被付钱、被灌醉、被吸毒、被杀，或者被娶，一切都取决于剧本的要求。许多受过良好教育或文明的人学会了忽略或压制自己的直觉，尽管这些能力在适当的条件下是可以被发现和发展的。

C • How to Listen

C • 如何聆听

In the first section we described some of the visual script signals. We now turn to the art of listening. The therapist can either listen to the patients with his eyes closed, assuring them at some point that he is not asleep, and rewarding them for their indulgence by telling them what he has heard, or listen to a tape recording of a group meeting, again preferably with his eyes closed so as to shut out visual distractions. One of the scripty things taught to almost all children, along with not looking at people too carefully is not to listen with their eyes closed, lest they hear too much. This injunction is not always easy to overcome – mother wouldn’t like it.

在第一部分，我们描述了一些视觉脚本信号。现在，我们来谈谈倾听的艺术。治疗师可以闭着眼睛倾听患者，并在某个时刻向他们保证自己没有睡着，并通过告诉他们自己听到的内容来奖励他们的耐心；或者，治疗师也可以听一段小组会议的录音，同样最好闭着眼睛，以避免视觉干扰。几乎所有孩子都被教导的脚本之一，除了不要仔细地盯着别人看之外，就是不要闭着眼睛听，以免听到太多。这条禁令并不总是容易克服——妈妈肯定不会喜欢的。

Even if he has never seen the patients, and initially knows nothing about their previous histories, an experienced script analyst can learn an enormous amount from a ten- or twenty-minute tape run of a treatment group. Starting with zero information he should, merely by listening to an unknown patient talk for a while, be able to give a quite detailed account of his family background, favorite games, and probable destiny. After thirty minutes, the returns diminish because of fatigue, and no tape ought to be played for more than a half-hour at one sitting.

即使从未见过患者，最初也对他们的既往病史一无所知，经验丰富的脚本分析师也能从一段十分钟或二十分钟的治疗小组录音中获取大量信息。他应该能够从零信息出发，仅仅通过聆听一位陌生患者的讲话，就能相当详细地描述出他的家庭背景、喜爱的游戏以及可能的人生轨迹。三十分钟后，由于疲劳，分析效果会逐渐减弱，因此任何录音都不应一次性播放超过半小时。

There is always room for improvement in knowing how to listen. This is a kind of Zen proposition, since for the most part it depends on what is going on in the listener’s head, rather than on what is taking place outside. The useful part of the listening is done by that aspect of the personality known as ‘The Professor,’ the Adult in the Child (see Figure 7 ). The Professor commands the power of intuition, 8 and the most important aspect of intuition concerns transactional sphincter behavior: What sphincter does the other fellow want to use on me, and which one does he want me to use on him? Where do these desires come from, and where are they headed for? By the time this archaic or ‘primal’ information filters through to the Adult of the listener, it may be elaborated into something more specific: information about the patient’s family background, 9 his instinctual strivings, 10 his occupation, and his script goal. What is necessary, then, is to know how to free the Professor to do his job most effectively. The rules for this are as follows:

倾听的技巧总有提升的空间。这有点像禅宗的理念，因为倾听在很大程度上取决于倾听者的内心活动，而非外部环境。真正有效的倾听是由人格中被称为“教授”的那一面——即“孩童中的成人”（见图7）——完成的。“教授”掌控着直觉的力量，而直觉最重要的方面在于互动式的“括约肌”行为：对方想对我使用哪种“括约肌”，又想让我对他使用哪种？这些欲望从何而来，又将走向何方？当这些原始的、“本能的”信息传递给倾听者内心的“成人”时，它可能会被进一步加工成更具体的信息：例如患者的家庭背景、本能的追求、职业以及人生目标。因此，关键在于如何让教授能够最有效地完成工作。具体原则如下：

1. The listener should be in good physical condition, having had a good night’s sleep, fn1 and should not be under the influence of alcohol, medications, or drugs which impair his mental efficiency. This includes both sedatives and stimulants.

1. 听者应身体状况良好，睡眠充足，且不应受酒精、药物或任何会损害其精神状态的毒品的影响。这包括镇静剂和兴奋剂。

2. He must free his mind of outside preoccupations.

2. 他必须让自己的思想摆脱外界的干扰。

3. He must put aside all Parental prejudices and feelings, including the need to ‘help.’

3. 他必须摒弃所有父母的偏见和感情，包括“帮助”的需要。

4. He must put aside all preconceptions about his patients in general and about the particular patient he is listening to.

4. 他必须放下对病人的所有成见，以及对正在听他讲话的这位病人的所有成见。

5. He must not let the patient distract him by asking questions or making other demands, and should learn harmless ways of warding off such interruptions.

5. 他不能让病人通过提问或提出其他要求来分散他的注意力，并且应该学习一些无害的方法来避免这种干扰。

6. His Adult listens to the content of what the patient says, while his Child-Professor listens to the way he says it. In telephone language, his Adult listens to the information, and his Child listens to the noise. 11 In radio language, his Adult listens to the program, and his Child listens to how the machine is working. Thus, he is both a listener and a repairman. If he is a counselor, it is enough for him to be a listener, but if he is a therapist, his most important job is making repairs.

6. 他的“成人”倾听患者所说的话的内容，而他的“儿童教授”则倾听患者说话的方式。用电话沟通的语言来说，“成人”倾听信息，“儿童”倾听噪音。用广播的语言来说，“成人”倾听节目内容，“儿童”倾听机器的运行情况。因此，他既是倾听者，也是维修者。如果他是咨询师，倾听就足够了；但如果他是治疗师，他最重要的工作就是进行维修。

7. When he begins to feel tired, he stops listening and starts looking or talking instead.

7. 当他开始感到疲倦时，他就会停止倾听，转而开始看或说话。

D • Basic Vocal Signals

D • 基本发声信号

After he has learned how to listen, he must learn what to listen for. From the psychiatric point of view there are four basic vocal signals: sounds, accents, voices, and vocabulary.

学会倾听之后，他必须学会倾听什么。从精神病学的角度来看，有四种基本的声音信号：音调、口音、嗓音和词汇。

1 • BREATHING SOUNDS

1 • 呼吸声

The commonest breathing sounds and their usual meanings are as follows: coughs (nobody loves me), sighs (if only), yawns (buzz off), grunts (you said it), and sobs (you got me); and various kinds of laughs such as jollies, chuckles, snickers, and titters. The three most important types of laughs, known colloquially as Ho Ho, Ha Ha, and He He, will be discussed further on.

最常见的呼吸声及其通常含义如下：咳嗽（没人爱我）、叹气（要是……就好了）、打哈欠（滚开）、咕哝（你说得对）、抽泣（你抓到我了）；以及各种笑声，例如欢笑、轻笑、窃笑和咯咯笑。三种最重要的笑声，俗称“嚯嚯”、“哈哈”和“嘿嘿”，将在后文进一步讨论。

2 • ACCENTS

2 • 口音

Culture has very little to do with scripts. There are winners and losers in every layer of society and in every country, and they go about fulfilling their destinies in much the same way all over the world. For example, the prevalence of mental illness in any large group of people is pretty much the same all over, 12 and there are suicides everywhere. Every large group in the world also has its leaders and its rich men.

文化与剧本关系不大。社会各个阶层、每个国家都有赢家和输家，他们实现自身命运的方式在世界各地大同小异。例如，任何大型人群中精神疾病的患病率都大致相同，自杀事件也随处可见。世界上每个大型群体也都有自己的领袖和富豪。

Nevertheless, foreign accents do have some meaning for the script analyst. First, they make possible educated guesses about early Parental precepts, and that is where culture does come in: ‘Do as you’re told’ in Germany, ‘Be quiet’ in France, and ‘Don’t be naughty’ in Britain. Secondly, they indicate the flexibility of the script. A German who has been in this country for twenty years and still speaks with a thick accent probably has a less flexible life plan than a Dane who speaks good American after only two years. Thirdly, the script is written in the native language of the Child, and script analysis is swifter and more effective if the therapist can speak that language. A foreigner living out his script in America is the equivalent of putting on Hamlet in Japanese in the Kabuki theater. A great deal is going to be lost or misunderstood if the critic does not have the original at hand.

然而，外国口音对剧本分析者来说确实具有一定的意义。首先，它们可以帮助我们推测早期父母的教诲，而这正是文化发挥作用的地方：德国人说“听话”，法国人说“安静点”，英国人说“别淘气”。其次，它们表明了剧本的灵活性。一个在美国生活了二十年却仍然操着浓重口音的德国人，其人生规划的灵活性可能不如一个仅仅生活了两年就能说一口流利美式英语的丹麦人。第三，剧本是用孩子的母语写成的，如果治疗师能够说这种语言，剧本分析就会更加迅速有效。一个外国人在美国按照自己的剧本生活，就好比在歌舞伎剧院用日语演绎《哈姆雷特》。如果评论者手边没有原文，很多信息都会丢失或被误解。

Native accents are also informative, particularly if they are affected. A man who speaks with a Brooklyn accent but throws in a few Boston or Broadway broad a ’s clearly shows the influence of a hero or a parental person he is carrying around in his head, and that person must be tracked down, because his influence is probably widespread, even if the patient denies it. ‘She passed a remok, or I should say an epigram,’ or ‘We left oily, but didn’t get to the game until hof time,’ clearly indicates a split in the Parental directives.

母语口音也具有参考价值，尤其是刻意模仿的口音。一个操着布鲁克林口音，却夹杂着几声波士顿或百老汇式的粗重发音的人，显然受到了他脑海中某个英雄或长辈的影响。这个人必须被找到，因为即使患者否认，他的影响也可能非常广泛。“她通过了一条评论，或者我应该说是一句警句”，或者“我们出发时很忙，但直到比赛结束才到场”，这些话都清楚地表明父母的指示出现了分歧。

3 • VOICES

3 • 声音

Each patient has at least three different voices, Parent, Adult, and Child. He may keep one, or even two of them carefully hidden for a long time, but they will slip out sooner or later. Usually a careful listener can hear at least two of them in any fifteen-minute period. The patient may say a whole Parental paragraph with only one Child whine, or a whole Adult paragraph with only one Parental scold, but an alert listener will pick up the key phrase. Other patients change voices from one sentence to another, or even use two or three voices in a single sentence.

每位患者至少有三种不同的声音：父母声、成人声和儿童声。他可能会长时间小心翼翼地隐藏其中一种甚至两种声音，但它们迟早会流露出来。通常，细心的倾听者在任何十五分钟内至少可以听到其中两种声音。患者可能会用父母的语气说完一段话，只夹杂着一次儿童的抱怨；或者用成人的语气说完一段话，只夹杂着一次父母的责骂，但警觉的倾听者会捕捉到关键的短语。还有一些患者会在句子之间切换声音，甚至在一句话中使用两到三种声音。

Each of the voices reveals something about the script. A Parental voice, speaking to another person, uses Parental slogans and precepts, and duplicates what father or mother would have said in the same situation: ‘Doesn’t everybody?’, ‘Look who’s talking,’ ‘You’ve got to keep your mind occupied,’ ‘Why don’t you try harder?’, ‘You can’t trust anybody.’ An unswerving Adult voice usually means that the Child is being suppressed by Parental command in favor of some humorless pedantic pattern perhaps loaded with a few ‘official’ or anal jokes. This indicates that the Child will therefore find devious ways of expression or periodically explode, giving rise to the nonadaptive behavior and waste of energy which makes a loser. The Child voice indicates the script role: ‘Cute Kid,’ ‘Little Old Me,’ ‘Clinging Whine,’ for example. Thus, the Parental voice tells the counterscript, The Adult voice gives the pattern, and the Child voice takes the script role.

每一种声音都揭示了剧本的某些信息。父母的声音，在对另一个人说话时，会使用父母的口号和教条，重复父母在相同情况下会说的话：“难道不是每个人都这样吗？”、“瞧瞧是谁在说话”、“你得让自己的大脑忙起来”、“你为什么不更努力一点？”、“你不能相信任何人。” 坚定不移的成人声音通常意味着孩子正被父母的命令所压制，取而代之的是一些毫无幽默感的迂腐模式，其中可能夹杂着一些“官方”或刻板的笑话。这表明孩子因此会寻找狡猾的表达方式，或者周期性地爆发，从而导致不适应的行为和能量的浪费，最终成为失败者。孩子的声音则表明了剧本角色：“可爱的小孩”、“我这个小老太太”、“爱哭鬼”，例如。因此，父母的声音讲述着反剧本，成人的声音提供了模式，而孩子的声音则扮演了剧本角色。

4 • VOCABULARY

4 • 词汇

Each ego state may also have its own vocabulary. Parental words, such as ‘bad,’ ‘stupid,’ coward,’ and ‘ridiculous,’ tell what Jeder is most afraid of being, and tries hardest to avoid. A persistent Adult technical vocabulary may be simply a way of avoiding people, as is common in engineering, aviation, and finance, under a script directive of ‘Do great things but don’t get involved personally.’ The Adult ‘helpnik’ vocabularies (PTA, psychology, psychoanalysis, social science) may be used in an intellectual Rite of Spring, where the victim’s dismembered psyche is left scattered over the floor on the theory that he will eventually join himself together and be more fertile afterward. The story line of this script reads: ‘I’ll tear you apart, and remember I’m only trying to help you. But you’ll have to put yourself together, since nobody else can do it for you.’ Sometimes the patient is his own favorite Ritual victim. The Child vocabulary may be the obscene words of revolt, the clichés of compliance, or the sweet phrases of charming innocence.

每一种自我状态都可能拥有其独特的词汇。父母的词汇，例如“坏”、“蠢”、“懦夫”和“荒谬”，揭示了杰德最害怕成为什么样的人，以及他最努力想要避免成为什么样的人。持续使用的成人技术词汇可能仅仅是一种逃避人际交往的方式，这在工程、航空和金融领域很常见，遵循着“成就伟业，但不要卷入个人事务”的剧本指令。成人的“帮手”词汇（家长教师协会、心理学、精神分析、社会科学）可能被用于一场智力版的《春之祭》，受害者的残肢断臂散落在地板上，其理论依据是他最终会重新拼凑起来，并在之后变得更加富有创造力。这个剧本的故事线是：“我会把你撕成碎片，记住我只是想帮助你。但你必须自己重新拼凑起来，因为没有人能替你做到。”有时，病人自己就是他最喜欢的仪式受害者。儿童的词汇可能是反抗的粗俗言语，顺从的陈词滥调，或是天真烂漫的甜美词句。

A typical triad often found in the same person is Parental marshmallow-throwing, Adult dissection, and Child obscenity. For example: ‘We all have our ups and downs; I think you’re handling it beautifully. Of course you have to split off your autonomous ego from your identification with your mother. After all, it’s a shitty world.’ This script comes right out of Dante’s Inferno : ‘How to keep smiling while reading a textbook when you’re up to your neck in sewage.’

同一个人身上常常会同时出现三种典型特征：父母的“棉花糖式”哄骗、成年人的“解剖式”剖析、以及儿童的“粗俗”言语。例如：“我们都会经历起起落落；我觉得你处理得很好。当然，你必须把你的独立自我与你母亲的认同区分开来。毕竟，这世界糟透了。” 这段话简直就是从但丁的《神曲·地狱篇》里搬出来的：“当你被污水淹没到脖子时，如何才能一边看教科书一边保持微笑？”

E • Choice of Words

E • 用词选择

Sentences are constructed jointly by the Parent, Adult, and Child, and each one reserves and exercises the right to insert words and phrases according to its needs. In order to understand what is going on in the patient’s head, the therapist must be able to break the finished product down into its significant components. This is called transactional parsing and is somewhat different from grammatical parsing.

句子由家长、成人和儿童共同构建，每个人都保留并有权根据自身需要插入词语和短语。为了理解患者的想法，治疗师必须能够将最终的句子分解成各个重要组成部分。这被称为事务性句法分析，与语法句法分析有所不同。

1 • PARTS OF SPEECH

1 • 词类

Adjectives and abstract nouns are name-calling. The correct response to a person who says that he suffers from ‘passive dependency’ or that he is ‘an insecure sociopath’ is ‘What names did your parents call you when you were little?’ Action euphemisms such as ‘aggressive expression’ or ‘sexual intercourse’ should be eliminated by asking ‘What did you call that when you were little?’ ‘Expressive aggression’ is a pure artifact and means that Pat has gone to a modern dance class or been wrestled by a Gestalt therapist, while ‘intercoursal sex’ means that he attends meetings of the Sexual Freedom League. fn2

形容词和抽象名词都是人身攻击。如果有人说自己患有“被动依赖症”或“缺乏安全感的反社会人格”，正确的回应应该是“你小时候父母叫你什么？”。像“攻击性表达”或“性交”这样的动作委婉说法应该被直接问“你小时候怎么称呼这个？”来消除。“表达性攻击”纯粹是人为造作，意味着帕特去上了现代舞课或者被格式塔治疗师“摔跤”过；而“性交”则意味着他参加了性自由联盟的会议。

Adverbs are a little more intimate. Thus ‘I sometimes feel sexual excitement’ is over there in the vague distance, while ‘I sometimes get sexually excited’ is over here. The precise psychological significance of adverbs, however, remains to be clarified.

副词则更显私密。例如，“我有时会感到性兴奋”就显得遥远而模糊，而“我有时会性兴奋”则显得更加直接。然而，副词的确切心理意义仍有待阐明。

Pronouns, verbs, and concrete nouns are the most real parts of speech, and ‘tell it like it is.’ Telling it like it is may mean that the patient is ready to get well. Thus, a woman who is afraid of sex often stresses adjectives and abstract nouns: ‘I had a satisfactory sexual experience.’ Later on, she may emphasize pronouns and verbs: ‘We really turned on.’ One woman went to the hospital the first time to have ‘an obstetrical experience.’ The second time, she went to have a baby. Patients ‘express hostility against authority figures.’ When they become real people, they just swear or tear up the papers. On the therapist’s side, the one who reports: ‘We initiated the interview by exchanging positive greetings. The patient then related that he had expressed hostility by performing an act of physical aggression against his wife,’ is having a harder time than the one who says: ‘The patient said Hello and told me that he hit his wife.’ In one case the therapist maintained that a boy ‘attended a residential school setting in the private area,’ while the boy said that he merely ‘went to boarding school.’

代词、动词和具体名词是最真实的词类，也是“实话实说”。实话实说可能意味着病人已经准备好康复。因此，一个害怕性爱的女性常常强调形容词和抽象名词：“我获得了一次令人满意的性体验。”之后，她可能会强调代词和动词：“我们真的很兴奋。”一位女性第一次去医院是为了“体验产科”。第二次，她去医院是为了生孩子。病人“对权威人物表现出敌意”。当他们真正面对病人时，他们就会咒骂或撕毁文件。治疗师这边，报告者会说：“我们以互相问候的方式开始了访谈。”患者随后叙述说，他曾通过对妻子实施肢体攻击来表达敌意，这种说法比“患者跟我打招呼，然后告诉我他打了妻子”的说法更难被接受。在一个案例中，治疗师坚持认为一个男孩“在私立寄宿学校就读”，而男孩则说他只是“去寄宿学校”。

The most important single word in script language is the particle ‘but,’ which means ‘According to my script, I don’t have permission to do that.’ Real people say: ‘I will,’ or ‘I won’t,’ or ‘I won,’ or ‘I lost,’ while ‘I will but …’ ‘I won’t but …’ ‘I won but …’ or ‘I lost but …’ are all scripty.

脚本语言中最重要的一个词是助词“但是”，它的意思是“根据我的脚本，我没有权限这样做”。现实生活中人们会说：“我会”、“我不会”、“我赢了”、“我输了”，而“我会但是……”“我不会但是……”“我赢了但是……”或“我输了但是……”都是脚本语言。

2 • OK WORDS

2 • OK 词语

The rule for listening to tape recordings is: If you can’t hear what the patient is saying, don’t worry about it, because usually he isn’t saying anything. When he has something to say, you’ll hear him, no matter how noisy or poor the recording is. Sometimes a poor tape recording is better than a good one for clinical purposes. If every word can be heard, the listener may become distracted by the content, and lose the more important script indices. For example: ‘I met a man at a bar and he made a pass at me. So after he got too fresh I said to him, I said “Whom do you think you are anyhow,” so he could see I was a lady, but he kept on so after a while I told him off.’ This is a rather dull, uninstructive, and commonplace tale. It is much more revealing on a poor recording, where it comes out: ‘Mumble mumble mumble PASS AT ME mumble mumble FRESH mumble mumble mumble SEE I WAS A LADY mumble mumble TOLD HIM OFF.’ Here the audible words are ‘the OK Words.’ This patient is under instructions from her mother to TELL MEN OFF, thus proving that SHE IS A LADY, providing she can collect enough trading stamps or PASSES to justify herself (as a lady) in becoming angry. The instruction reads ‘Remember LADIES get angry when men make passes at them.’ Father throws in helpfully: ‘There are lots of FRESH guys at bars. I ought to know.’ So she goes to bars and sets about proving that she is a lady.

听录音的原则是：如果听不清病人在说什么，不必担心，因为通常情况下他并没有说话。当他想说什么的时候，无论录音多么嘈杂或质量多么差，你都能听清。有时，出于临床目的，质量差的录音反而比质量好的录音更有用。如果每个字都能听得清清楚楚，听者可能会被内容分散注意力，从而忽略更重要的文本索引。例如：“我在酒吧遇到一个男人，他想勾引我。他举止太过分后，我回敬他，我说‘你以为你是谁？’这样他就能看出我是个女人，但他还是不依不饶，所以过了一会儿我就训斥了他。”这是一个相当乏味、毫无启发性且老套的故事。在一段音质较差的录音中，情况更加扑朔迷离，录音里是这样的：“咕哝咕哝咕哝 搭讪我 咕哝咕哝 帅哥 咕哝咕哝咕哝 看，我可是个淑女 咕哝咕哝 训斥了他。” 这里能听清的词是“正确的说法”。这位病人被她母亲指示要训斥男人，以此证明自己是个淑女，前提是她能收集到足够的“通行证”或“通行证”，来证明自己（作为淑女）有理由生气。指示是：“记住，淑女在男人搭讪时会生气。” 父亲还“好心”地插话说：“酒吧里有很多帅哥。我应该知道。” 于是她就去酒吧，开始证明自己是个淑女。

After she has been in psychoanalytic therapy for a while, her tape goes: ‘Mumble mumble mumble SADISTIC MAN mumble mumble mumble MY MASOCHISTIC SELF mumble mumble. Mumble mumble mumble EXPRESSING MY USUAL HOSTILITY mumble mumble.’ She has replaced the old OK Words with some new OK Words. If she transfers to a transactional analyst, the tape goes: ‘Mumble mumble HIS CHILD mumble mumble mumble MY PARENT mumble mumble played “RAPO.”’ But a month later there are no more mumbles even on a poor and noisy tape, and what comes through clearly is ‘I’ve met some awfully nice men since I stopped going to bars.’

在她接受一段时间的精神分析治疗后，她的录音带内容是：“咕哝咕哝咕哝 虐待狂男人 咕哝咕哝咕哝 我受虐的一面 咕哝咕哝 咕哝咕哝 表达我一贯的敌意 咕哝咕哝。”她用一些新的“OK词”替换了以前的“OK词”。如果她转而接受人际沟通分析师的治疗，录音带内容会变成：“咕哝咕哝 他的孩子 咕哝咕哝咕哝 我的父母 咕哝咕哝 播放了“RAPO”。”但一个月后，即使是音质很差、噪音很大的录音带，也不再有咕哝声了，清晰地录下的是：“自从我不再去酒吧后，我遇到了一些非常好的男人。”

OK Words tell the story much better than the story itself. It might take months of conventional therapy to unravel the details of a hard-luck story told in the clear by a female graduate student, but if the tape goes ‘Mumble mumble mumble STUDIED HARD mumble mumble GOOD GRADES BUT mumble mumble TERRIBLE AFTERWARD,’ the loud OK Words that come through tell the story of her life right there: ‘You’re supposed to work hard and succeed except that something is supposed to go wrong so you’ll end up feeling terrible.’ The OK Words state her script directives loud and clear.

“OK”这个词比故事本身更能说明问题。或许需要几个月的传统心理治疗才能理清一位女研究生讲述的悲惨故事的细节，但如果录音带里是“咕哝咕哝 努力学习 咕哝咕哝 成绩好 但是 咕哝咕哝 之后糟透了”，那么响亮的“OK”就直接揭示了她的人生故事：“你应该努力学习并取得成功，但总会发生一些意想不到的事情，让你最终感觉糟糕透顶。”这些“OK”清晰响亮地传达了她的人生剧本。

The OK Words referred to in the last section come from the parental precepts, patterns, and threats. Precepts such as ‘Be a lady,’ ‘Study hard,’ give Lady and Study as OK Words. The threat ‘Otherwise something awful will happen’ gives Something Awful as an OK Word. When a patient gets couch-broken, the therapist’s vocabulary becomes OK Words, and indeed, this is one of the signs that the patient is couch-broken. She says masochism, hostility, Parent, Child, etc., because at this stage the therapist becomes a substitute parent, and his OK vocabulary replaces the original one learned in childhood. OK Words are those approved by the Parent part of the patient’s father, mother, therapist, or other parental person.

上一节提到的“OK词”源自父母的教诲、模式和威胁。例如，“做个淑女”、“努力学习”这样的教诲，会衍生出“淑女”和“学习”这两个“OK词”。“否则就会发生可怕的事情”这样的威胁，则会衍生出“可怕的事情”这个“OK词”。当患者被“沙发驯服”后，治疗师的词汇也会变成“OK词”，而这恰恰是患者被“沙发驯服”的标志之一。她会提到受虐倾向、敌意、父母、孩子等等，因为在这个阶段，治疗师扮演了替代父母的角色，他/她的“OK词”取代了患者童年时期习得的词汇。这些“OK词”是患者的父亲、母亲、治疗师或其他长辈认可的“父母”角色所使用的词汇。

3 • SCRIPT WORDS

3 • 脚本词

We remember, however, that many of the script controls are given by the Child part of the father or mother, and these rely on a whole other vocabulary of Script Words and Phrases, which are usually quite different from the OK Words. Some of them, indeed, may be in direct contradiction. A woman who uses very lady-like OK Words when she is in her antiscript may use very foul language when she is in her script. Thus, she may call her children ‘my lovely teen-agers’ when she is sober, and ‘those shitfaces’ when she is drunk. Script words give important information regarding script roles and script scenes, both of which are important in trying to reconstruct the script world, or the kind of world the patient’s Child is living in.

然而，我们必须记住，许多脚本控制是由父母双方的“孩子”部分赋予的，而这些控制依赖于一套完全不同的脚本词汇和短语，这些词汇和短语通常与“正常用语”（OK Words）截然不同。事实上，其中一些词汇甚至可能直接矛盾。一位女性在处于反脚本状态时可能使用非常淑女的“正常用语”，但在处于脚本状态时则可能使用非常粗俗的语言。因此，她清醒时可能会称呼自己的孩子为“我可爱的青少年”，而醉酒时则会称他们为“那些混蛋”。脚本词汇提供了关于脚本角色和脚本场景的重要信息，这两者对于尝试重建脚本世界，或者说患者“孩子”所生活的世界至关重要。

In men’s scripts, the commonest roles for females are girls, ladies, and women. In women’s scripts, males becomes kids, men, and old men. More specialized are ‘little girls’ and ‘dirty old men.’ These two attract each other, especially in bars. The man refers to the women he meets as ‘nice little girls.’ The woman refers to the men she meets as ‘dirty old men.’ He needs a little girl for his script and she needs a dirty old man for hers, and when they meet the action begins and they know what to say to each other after they say Hello. Various women live in worlds populated by wolves, beasts, charmers, cats, creeps, suckers, and pricks, and their menfolk see them as dishes, bitches, grooves, chicks, broads, whores, and cunts. All these are script words which emerge in the course of conversation or group treatment.

在男性的剧本中，女性最常见的角色是女孩、女士和女人。在女性的剧本中，男性则变成孩子、男人和老男人。更具体的角色还有“小女孩”和“老色鬼”。这两个群体相互吸引，尤其是在酒吧里。男人称他遇到的女性为“可爱的小女孩”，女人称她遇到的男性为“老色鬼”。他需要一个小女孩来配合他的剧本，她需要一个老色鬼来配合她的剧本，当他们相遇时，故事就开始了，在打招呼之后，他们就知道该说什么了。不同的女性生活在一个充满狼、野兽、花花公子、猫、怪胎、傻瓜和混蛋的世界里，而她们的男性朋友则把她们视为尤物、婊子、性感尤物、小妞、荡妇、妓女和贱货。所有这些都是剧本词汇，会在对话或群体交往中出现。

The script scenes are usually centered around one or other room of the house: the nursery, the bathroom, the kitchen, the living room, and the bedroom, and these are located in such expressions as ‘plenty to drink,’ ‘all that crap,’ ‘a regular feast,’ ‘all those people,’ and ‘sock it to them.’ Each of these rooms has its own vocabulary, and the person stuck in any of these chambers will use the appropriate expressions over and over. Equally common is the workroom, signified by ‘Get your ass over there.’

剧本场景通常围绕房子里的某个房间展开：育婴室、浴室、厨房、客厅和卧室，这些房间对应的表达方式包括“酒水管够”、“一堆废话”、“丰盛的大餐”、“那么多人”和“狠狠揍他们”。每个房间都有其独特的词汇，被困在任何一个房间里的人都会反复使用相应的表达方式。同样常见的还有工作室，比如“赶紧过去”。

Counterscript words can also be detected in people who are fighting their scripts. Jack, the Sisyphus mentioned in Chapter Twelve , became a professional baseball player, partly because it was his thing and partly because he was boxed into it by his uncle. As Dr Q listened to him one day, he noticed for the first time a tremendous power behind the word ‘not,’ which Jack said frequently, and a lesser but still striking impact whenever Jack said ‘something else.’ He immediately sensed intuitively the meaning behind these two terms. Whenever Jack said ‘not,’ he was pitching, and whenever Jack pitched his Child was saying ‘not’ – ‘You’re not going to hit it!’ Whenever he said ‘something else,’ he was throwing to first base, and whenever he was throwing to first base, he was saying ‘something else’ – ‘If I can’t strike you out we’ll try something else.’ Jack not only confirmed these intuitions, but related how a pitching coach had told him the same thing in different language. ‘Relax! If you throw every pitch that hard, you’re going to get a bum shoulder!’ Which Jack eventually did. Like Dr Q, the coach had perceived, on the basis of his intuition and experience, that Jack was pitching in anger, and he knew that was no good.

反脚本的词语也能在那些与自身脚本抗争的人身上被发现。第十二章中提到的西西弗斯——杰克，成为了一名职业棒球运动员，部分原因是这是他的兴趣所在，部分原因是他叔叔的安排。有一天，Q博士在听杰克说话时，第一次注意到杰克经常说的“不”这个词背后蕴藏着巨大的力量，而每当杰克说“别的什么”时，也会产生一种虽小但同样引人注目的影响。他立刻凭直觉感受到了这两个词背后的含义。每当杰克说“不”时，他就在投球；每当杰克投球时，他的孩子就在说“不”——“你打不到！”每当他说“别的什么”时，他就在传球到一垒；每当他传球到一垒时，他就在说“别的什么”——“如果我不能三振你，我们就试试别的办法。”杰克不仅证实了这些直觉，还讲述了一位投球教练如何用另一种语言告诉他同样的事情。“放松！ “如果你每球都投得那么用力，你的肩膀肯定会受伤！”杰克最终真的受伤了。和Q博士一样，教练凭借直觉和经验判断出杰克是在愤怒中投球，他知道这样不好。

Jack’s antiscript was to succeed as a baseball player, and behind his professional pitching was a great rage against his father and uncle for commanding him to be a loser. Thus, every time he threw the ball he was fighting his script and trying to smash his way out of his bag into success. This gave him tremendous speed, and his antiscript gave him superb control. The only thing he lacked was the ability to cool it and fit his pitches into the context of the batting order and the state of the game. In the end, his nonadaptive rage brought about just the payoff he was trying to avoid, and he had to quit the game. The intuitive perceptiveness of the Adult in the therapist’s Child, the Professor, is his most valuable therapeutic instrument. The acute sensitivity of a properly attuned Professor is demonstrated by the fact that Dr Q knew all this in spite of the fact that he had only been to one professional baseball game in his whole life, although he had pitched in many sandlot softball games.

杰克的反脚本是成为一名成功的棒球运动员，而他职业投球的背后，是对父亲和叔叔让他成为失败者的强烈怨恨。因此，每次投球，他都在与自己的脚本抗争，试图用尽全力冲向成功。这赋予了他惊人的速度，而他的反脚本则赋予了他卓越的控球能力。他唯一缺乏的是冷静下来，并将投球策略与击球顺序和比赛形势相协调的能力。最终，他这种不适应的愤怒带来了他一直试图避免的后果，他不得不退出棒球界。治疗师的“孩子”（即教授）身上成人的直觉洞察力是他最宝贵的治疗工具。一位真正理解“教授”的敏锐感知力体现在，尽管Q博士一生只看过一场职业棒球比赛，但他却了解这一切，尽管他参加过许多街头垒球比赛。

4 • METAPHORS

4 • 隐喻

Closely allied to script words are metaphors. Thus, Mary had two different and separate vocabularies of metaphors. In one, she was all at sea, couldn’t fathom anything, could hardly keep her head above water, had stormy days, and waves of feelings. At other times, life was a feast, she could eat her words, she had lots of goodies, or she might feel sour or bitter because that was the way the cookie crumbled. She married a sailor and complained of obesity. When she felt at sea, all her lingo was maritime, and when she was overeating, it was culinary. Thus she fell from the ocean to the kitchen and back again, and the therapist’s problem was to get her feet on the ground. Metaphors are an extension of the script scene, and a change in metaphors means a change of scene. In her case, the stormy waters turned out to be a sea of anger.

与剧本词汇紧密相连的是隐喻。因此，玛丽拥有两套截然不同的隐喻词汇。有时，她茫然无措，什么都想不明白，几乎无法自拔，情绪如同暴风雨般起伏。有时，生活却像盛宴，她可以收回之前的话，享受着各种美好事物，或者她可能因为事与愿违而感到酸涩或苦涩。她嫁给了一位水手，并抱怨自己肥胖。当她感到茫然无措时，她所有的语言都与航海有关；而当她暴饮暴食时，她使用的语言则与烹饪有关。于是，她一会儿从海洋坠入厨房，一会儿又回到海洋，治疗师的任务就是让她脚踏实地。隐喻是剧本场景的延伸，隐喻的改变意味着场景的改变。对她而言，暴风雨般的景象最终变成了愤怒的海洋。

5 • SECURITY PHRASES

5 • 安全短语

Some people have to go through certain rituals or make certain gestures before they begin to talk, in order to protect themselves or apologize for speaking. These rituals are addressed to their Parents. We have already cited the case of Abelard, who always slid his hands under his belt before he began to talk. It was evident that he was protecting his testicles from some inner assailant who was scheduled to attack him when he was off guard because he was speaking to somebody, so he always took care of that danger before he ventured to speak. In other cases these security measures are incorporated into the sentence structure. There are various degrees of protection in answering a question like: ‘Did you ever get mad at your sister?’ ‘ Maybe I did’ implies a Parental order ‘Never commit yourself.’ ‘I think maybe I did’ implies two Parental orders: ‘How can you be sure?’ and ‘Don’t commit yourself.’ The first usually comes from father, the second from mother. ‘I think maybe I might have’ contains a triple protection. Security phrases are chiefly of prognostic value. It is much easier for the therapist to penetrate one layer of security measures than three. ‘I think maybe I might have’ is similar to the Berkeley Subjunctive, and is likewise designed to protect and conceal a very young and very apprehensive Child who is not going to let anybody in very easily.

有些人开口说话前必须进行某些仪式或做出某些手势，以保护自己或为开口道歉。这些仪式是向父母发出的。我们之前提到过阿伯拉尔的例子，他每次开口说话前都会把手伸进腰带里。显然，他是在保护自己的睾丸，以免被某种内在的“攻击者”趁他与人交谈时放松警惕而袭击，所以他总是在开口前先排除这种危险。在其他情况下，这些安全措施会融入到句式结构中。例如，回答“你有没有生过你姐姐的气？”这类问题时，保护的程度各不相同。“也许我生过气”暗示着父母的命令：“不要轻易做出承诺”。“我想我可能生过气”则暗示着父母的两条命令：“你怎么能确定？”和“不要轻易做出承诺”。第一条通常来自父亲，第二条来自母亲。“我想我可能生过气”则包含了三重保护。这些安全短语主要具有预示意义。对治疗师来说，突破一层安全措施远比突破三层容易得多。“我想我可能……”类似于伯克利虚拟语气，同样是为了保护和掩饰一个非常年幼且极度焦虑的孩子，他不会轻易让任何人走进他的内心。

6 • THE SUBJUNCTIVE

6 • 虚拟语气

The subjunctive, or as it is called colloquially, the ‘Berkeley Subjunctive,’ comprises three items. First, the phrases ‘if’ or ‘if only;’ secondly, the use of subjunctives or conditionals such as would, should, and could; and thirdly, the noncommitment words such as ‘toward.’ The Berkeley Subjunctive is most highly developed on college campuses. The classical phrase is ‘I should, and I would if I could, but …’ Variants are ‘If only they would, I could, and I think I probably should, but …’ or ‘I should, and I probably could, but then they would …’

虚拟语气，或俗称“伯克利虚拟语气”，包含三个要素。首先是短语“if”或“if only”；其次是虚拟语气或条件句，例如 would、should 和 could；第三是表示不确定的词语，例如 toward。伯克利虚拟语气在大学校园中最为盛行。经典的表达是“I should, and I would if I could, but…”，其变体有“If only they would, I could, and I think I probably should, but…”或“I should, and I probably could, but then they would…”。

This subjunctive attitude becomes formalized in the titles of books, theses, papers, and student assignments. Common examples are ‘Some Factors Involved In …’ (=if only), or ‘Toward a Theory of …’ (=I would if I could, and I know I should). In the extreme case, the title reads: ‘Some Introductory Remarks Concerning Factors Involved in Gathering Data Toward a Theory of…’ – a very modest title indeed, since it is plain that it will take abut two hundred years before the theory itself will be ready for publication. It is obvious that this man’s mother told him not to stick his neck out. His next paper, presumably, will be: ‘Some Intermediate Remarks Concerning … etc.’ and then ‘Some Final Remarks Concerning … etc.’ Having disposed of Remarks, presumably the titles of his succeeding papers will get shorter and shorter. By the time he is forty, he will have the prolegomena shaved off and will come out with number six, ‘Toward a Theory of …’ but the actual theory is rarely forthcoming. If it is, and the seventh paper is the theory itself, then there will be an eighth entitled: ‘Oops, Sorry. Back to the Old Computer.’ He is always on the way, but never gets to the next station.

这种虚拟语气在书籍、论文、文章和学生作业的标题中得到了正式体现。常见的例子有“……涉及的一些因素”（=但愿如此），或者“关于……的理论”（=如果可以，我会这么做，而且我知道我应该这么做）。极端情况下，标题会写成：“关于收集数据以构建……理论的一些引言性说明”——这确实是一个非常谦虚的标题，因为很明显，这个理论本身还需要大约两百年才能准备好发表。显然，这个人的母亲告诫他不要冒险。他的下一篇论文，大概会是：“关于……的一些中间性说明”等等，然后是“关于……的一些最终说明”等等。在处理完“说明”之后，他后续论文的标题大概会越来越短。到他四十岁时，他会删掉序言，发表第六篇论文《论……的理论》，但真正的理论却很少出现。即便出现了，第七篇论文才是理论本身，那么就会有第八篇论文，标题是《哎呀，抱歉。还是用回老电脑吧》。他总是在路上，却永远到不了下一站。

This is not amusing for the therapist who undertakes to treat a man who is writing a paper with such a title. Pat will also be complaining of not being able to finish his thesis, inability to concentrate, sexual and marital problems, depression, and suicidal impulses. Unless the therapist can find a way to change the script, the treatment will follow exactly the eight stages outlined above, each phase taking six months to a year or more, with the therapist writing the final paper (the Oops one) instead of the patient. In script language, ‘toward’ means ‘don’t get there.’ Nobody asks ‘Does this airplane go toward New York?’ nor would many people want to travel with a pilot who says: ‘Yes, we’re going toward New York.’ He either goes to New York or you take another airplane.

对于一位接手治疗一位正在撰写题为“哎呀”论文的男士的治疗师来说，这可不是什么好笑的事。帕特还会抱怨自己无法完成论文、无法集中注意力、性生活和婚姻出现问题、抑郁，甚至有自杀倾向。除非治疗师能找到办法改变这种状况，否则治疗将严格按照上述八个阶段进行，每个阶段持续六个月到一年甚至更久，最终由治疗师而不是患者来撰写论文（也就是那篇“哎呀”的论文）。在剧本语言中，“朝向”意味着“到不了”。没人会问“这架飞机飞往纽约吗？”，也没多少人愿意乘坐一位说“是的，我们飞往纽约”的飞行员的飞机。要么他真的飞往纽约，要么你就换乘另一架飞机。

7 • SENTENCE STRUCTURE

7 • 句子结构

Besides the subjunctivists there are other people who are forbidden to finish anything or come to the point, so when they talk they ‘run off at the mouth.’ Their sentences are strung out with conjunctions: ‘Yesterday I was sitting at home with my husband and … and … and then … and … and then …’ Often the directive is ‘Don’t tell any of the family secrets!’ so they go all around the secret and play with it as long as they can without giving it away.

除了虚拟语气者之外，还有一些人被禁止把话说完或切入正题，所以他们说话时总是“滔滔不绝”。他们的句子充斥着连词：“昨天我和我丈夫坐在家里，然后……然后……然后……然后……然后……”通常，他们被要求“不要泄露任何家庭秘密！”，所以他们会绕着秘密打转，尽可能长时间地玩弄它，不让它泄露出去。

Some speakers are careful to balance everything: ‘It’s raining, but the sun will come out soon.’ ‘I have a headache, but my stomach is better.’ ‘They’re not very nice, but on the other hand, they look cheerful.’ The directive in this case seems to be ‘Don’t look at anything too closely.’ The most interesting example of this type was a man who had been a diabetic since the age of five, and had been taught to balance his diet with the utmost care. When he spoke, he weighed every word with similar care, and balanced each of his sentences very cautiously and precisely. These precautions made him very difficult to listen to. All his life he had been in a rage against the unfair restrictions imposed on him because of the disease, and his speech became very unbalanced when he was angry. (The implications of this for the psychology of diabetes must await further study.)

有些说话者会小心翼翼地平衡一切：“现在下雨了，但太阳很快就会出来。”“我头疼，但胃好多了。”“他们不太友善，但另一方面，他们看起来很开心。”这种情况下，其意图似乎是“不要仔细观察任何事情”。这类人中最有趣的例子是一位五岁就患有糖尿病的男子，他从小就被教导要极其谨慎地平衡饮食。说话时，他斟酌每一个字，小心翼翼地斟酌每一个句子。这些谨慎让他的讲话很难让人听进去。他一生都在对疾病给他带来的不公平限制感到愤怒，生气时，他的言语就会变得非常混乱。（这对于糖尿病心理学的意义还有待进一步研究。）

Another type of sentence structure is the dangling point, with free use of ‘and so forth’ and ‘et cetera.’ ‘Well, we went to the movies and so forth, and then I kissed her and so forth, and then she stole my wallet and so forth.’ Unfortunately, this often conceals a deep anger against the mother. ‘Well, I’d like to tell her what I think of her, et cetera.’ ‘What is “et cetera”?’ ‘What I’d really like to do is cut her to pieces.’ ‘Et cetera’? ‘No, no more “et cetera”. That’s the et cetera.’ Sentence structure offers a fascinating field for study.

另一种句式结构是悬垂句，随意使用“and so forth”和“et cetera”。例如：“嗯，我们去看电影了，然后我吻了她，然后她偷了我的钱包，然后她偷了我的钱包。” 不幸的是，这种句式往往掩盖了对母亲的深深愤怒。“嗯，我想告诉她我对她的看法，等等。” “什么是‘et cetera’？” “我真想把她剁成碎片。” “等等？” “不，不要再用‘et cetera’了。那就是‘et cetera’。” 句式结构是一个引人入胜的研究领域。

F • The Gallows Transaction

F • 绞刑架交易

Jack: I stopped smoking. I haven’t had a cigarette for over a month.

杰克：我戒烟了。我已经一个多月没抽烟了。

Della: And how much weight have you put on, heh, heh, heh?

黛拉：你胖了多少啊，呵呵呵呵？

Everyone smiled at this sally except Jack and Dr Q.

除了杰克和Q博士之外，所有人都对这个莎莉笑了。

Dr Q: Well, you really are getting well, Jack. You didn’t fall for that one.

Q医生：嗯，杰克，你真的康复得很快。你没上当。

Della: I want to get well, too. I could have bitten my tongue off for saying that. That was my mother talking. I was trying to do to Jack exactly what she does to me.

黛拉：我也想好起来。我真后悔说了那句话。那是我妈妈在说话。我当时是想用她对我做的一切来对待杰克。

Don (a new member): What’s so terrible about that? Just a little joke.

唐（新成员）：这有什么可怕的？只是个小玩笑而已。

Della: My mother came to see me the other day and she tried to do it to me again, but I wouldn’t let her. It sure made her mad. She said ‘You’re sure putting on weight again, ha ha.’ I was supposed to laugh, too, and say ‘Yeah, I’m overeating, ha ha.’ But instead I said ‘You’re kind of heavy yourself.’ So then she changed the subject and said ‘How can you live in a rundown shack like this?’

黛拉：前几天我妈来看我，她又想嘲笑我，但我没让她得逞。她气坏了。她说：“你又胖了，哈哈。” 我本来也应该笑，说：“是啊，我吃太多了，哈哈。” 但我却说：“你自己也挺胖的。” 然后她就转移话题，说：“你怎么能住在这么破烂的房子里？”

It is pretty clear from this that for overweight Della, keeping mother happy = putting on weight and laughing about it, the tragedy of her life, and that not laughing about it is impudent and makes mother unhappy. She is supposed to hang herself while they have a good chuckle over it.

很明显，对于超重的德拉来说，让母亲开心就等于让自己增重，然后拿这件事——她人生的悲剧——开怀大笑；而对这件事不笑则是无礼的，会让母亲不高兴。她应该在她们的嘲笑声中上吊自杀。

The gallows laugh is the dying man’s joke, or famous last words. As already noted, the crowds of spectators at the Tyburn or Newgate hangings in the eighteenth century used to admire people who died laughing: ‘I was the capper, see,’ says Daniel Then. ‘We had the cull all set up and then something went wrong. The others got away but I got nabbed, ha ha ha!’ And ‘Ha, ha, ha,’ roars the crowd in appreciation of the jest as the trap is sprung, ‘the damber died game.’ Danny seems to be laughing at the wry joke fate played on him, but deep down he knows who is responsible, and he is really saying: ‘Well, mother (or father), you predicted I’d end up on the gallows, and here I am, ha ha ha.’ The same thing happens in a minor way at almost any group-treatment session.

绞刑架上的笑声是垂死之人开的玩笑，或是著名的遗言。正如前文所述，十八世纪泰伯恩或纽盖特绞刑场上的围观群众常常津津乐道于那些临死前还在笑的人：“我就是那个负责抓人的，”丹尼尔·森说道，“我们把一切都安排好了，结果出了点岔子。其他人都逃脱了，只有我被抓住了，哈哈哈哈！”随着绞刑架的开启，围观群众发出阵阵欢呼，仿佛在为这个玩笑喝彩，“这傻瓜死得真痛快！”丹尼表面上似乎在嘲笑命运对他开的玩笑，但内心深处他知道是谁造成的，他真正想说的是：“好吧，妈妈（或爸爸），你预言我会上绞刑架，现在我真的上来了，哈哈哈哈。”几乎在任何团体治疗中，都会以类似的方式出现。

Danny Now was one of four children, none of whom had permission to succeed. The parents were both a little dishonest in socially acceptable ways, and the children each carried this tendency a little further. One day Danny told about his troubles at college. He was falling behind in his work, so he had paid a ghost writer in advance to do his thesis. The group listened with interest as he described his negotiations with this man, and told how the ghost writer had also undertaken to write theses for some of Danny’s friends, all of whom had paid in advance. The other members asked questions here and there, until finally Danny came to the point. The writer had absconded to Europe, taking all the money he had collected, and without leaving any theses behind. At this, the group broke into uproarious laughter in which Danny joined.

丹尼·诺是四个孩子中的一个，他们都没有被允许获得成功。他的父母在为人处世方面都有些许不诚实，但这种不诚实在社会上是可以接受的，而孩子们则把这种倾向发挥得更甚一些。一天，丹尼讲述了他在大学里的困境。他的作业落后了，所以他提前付钱请了一位代笔人帮他写论文。大家饶有兴致地听他描述与这位代笔人谈判的过程，以及这位代笔人还接手了他几个朋友的论文代写工作，而这些朋友也都提前付了钱。其他成员时不时地提出一些问题，直到丹尼终于说到重点。那位代笔人卷款潜逃去了欧洲，没有留下任何论文。听到这话，大家哄堂大笑，丹尼也跟着笑了起来。

The others said they thought the story was funny for two reasons: first, the way Danny told it, as though he expected them to laugh, and would be disappointed if they didn’t: and second, because it was the sort of thing they expected, or perhaps even hoped, would happen to Danny because of the complicated way he went about doing things instead of carrying out his obligations in a straightforward, honest way. They all knew that Danny was supposed to fail, and it was amusing to see how much effort he put into it. They joined in Danny Now’s laughter the same way the crowd had joined in Danny Then’s. Later they would all be depressed about it, Danny most of all. His laugh said ‘Ha, ha, ha, mother, you always loved me when I failed, and here I go again.’

其他人说他们觉得这个故事好笑有两个原因：第一，丹尼讲故事的方式，好像他期待他们笑，如果他们不笑他会很失望；第二，因为他们早就预料到，甚至可能希望丹尼会遭遇这种事，因为他做事总是喜欢走弯路，而不是坦诚直率地履行自己的职责。他们都知道丹尼注定要失败，而看到他为了失败付出那么多努力，真是滑稽可笑。他们跟着丹尼现在的笑声一起笑，就像之前大家跟着丹尼过去的笑声一起笑一样。后来，他们都会为此感到沮丧，尤其是丹尼。他的笑声仿佛在说：“哈哈哈哈，妈妈，你总是爱我，即使我失败了，现在我又来了。”

The Adult in the Child, The Professor, has had the task from earliest years of keeping mother contented so that she will stay with him and protect him. If she likes him and expresses the liking with a smile, he feels safe even when he is actually in trouble or even in dire peril of death. Crossman 13 discusses this in more detail. In normal mothering, she says, mother’s Parent and Child both like kids. So when mother smiles both her Parent and her Child are pleased with her offspring, and things will proceed smoothly between them. In other cases, mother’s Parent smiles at her son because she is supposed to, while her Child is angry at him. He can get on the good side of her Child, and get a smile that way, by behavior which her Parent might disapprove of. For example, by demonstrating that he is ‘bad,’ he may get a Child smile because he has proven that he is not-OK, and that pleases the Child in mother – what we have previously called ‘the witch mother.’ From all this, Crossman concludes that both script and antiscript can be considered attempts to evoke mother’s smile: the antiscript for the approving smile of mother’s (and father’s) Parent, the script for the smile of mother’s Child, who enjoys the baby’s pain or discomfiture.

孩子内心深处的“成人”，也就是“教授”，从孩提时代起就肩负着让母亲感到愉悦的使命，这样母亲才会留在他身边保护他。如果母亲喜欢他，并用微笑表达这份喜爱，即使他身处困境，甚至面临生命危险，他也会感到安全。克罗斯曼（Crossman）对此进行了更详细的探讨。她指出，在正常的母子关系中，母亲的“父母”和“孩子”都喜欢孩子。因此，当母亲微笑时，母亲的“父母”和“孩子”都会对孩子感到满意，彼此之间也会相处融洽。但在另一些情况下，母亲的“父母”对儿子微笑，只是因为她应该这样做，而孩子却对他生气。孩子可以通过一些“父母”可能不赞同的行为来博得孩子的好感，从而获得孩子的微笑。例如，通过表现出“坏”，他可能会得到母亲的孩童般的微笑，因为他证明了自己不好，这取悦了母亲内心深处的孩童——我们之前称之为“巫婆妈妈”。由此，克罗斯曼得出结论：脚本和反脚本都可以被视为试图唤起母亲的微笑：反脚本是为了唤起母亲（和父亲）父母那赞许的微笑，脚本是为了唤起母亲内心孩童的微笑，孩童会享受婴儿的痛苦或不适。

The gallows laugh, then, occurs when Danny ‘finds himself’ with the rope around his neck, and his Child says: ‘I didn’t really want to end up this way. How did I get here?’ Then Mother (in his head) smiles, and he realizes that she had conned him into it. He then has the choice of either going crazy, killing her, killing himself, or laughing. At such moments he may envy the brother who chose instead to go to the mental hospital, or the sister who elected to kill herself, but he is not ready for either of those – yet.

于是，绞刑架上的笑声出现了：丹尼“发现自己”脖子上套着绳子，他的孩子说道：“我真的不想落得这般下场。我怎么会到这儿来？”这时，母亲（在他脑海里）笑了，他意识到自己被骗了。他面临着四个选择：要么发疯，要么杀了她，要么自杀，要么大笑。在这样的时刻，他或许会羡慕选择去精神病院的哥哥，或是选择自杀的姐姐，但他还没准备好面对这一切——至少现在还没。

The gallows laugh or the gallows smile occurs after a special kind of stimulus and response called the ‘gallows transaction.’ A typical example is an alcoholic who has not had a drink for six months, as everyone in the group knows. Then one day he comes in and lets the others talk for a while. When they have gotten all their troubles off their chests, so that he has the stage to himself, he says: ‘Guess what happened over the weekend?’ One look at his slightly smiling face and they know what happened. They get ready to smile, too. One of them sets up the gallows transaction by asking: ‘What happened?’ ‘Well, I took one drink and then another, and the next thing I knew’ – by this time he is laughing and so are they – ‘I went on a three-day bender.’ Steiner, 14 who first described these phenomena clearly, says it thus: ‘In the case of the Alcoholic, White tells the audience about last week’s bender while the audience (including, perhaps, the therapist) beams with delight. The smile of the Children in the audience parallels and reinforces the smile of the witch mother or ogre who is pleased when White obeys the injunction (“Don’t think – drink”), and in effect tightens the noose around White’s neck.’

绞刑架下的笑声或微笑，源于一种被称为“绞刑架交易”的特殊刺激与反应。一个典型的例子是，一个酗酒者已经六个月没喝酒了，大家都知道。有一天，他走进来，让其他人聊了一会儿。当他们倾诉完所有烦恼，只剩下他一个人时，他问道：“猜猜周末发生了什么？” 大家只要看一眼他脸上那抹淡淡的微笑，就知道发生了什么。他们也准备跟着微笑起来。其中一人通过提问“发生了什么事？”来引出这场“绞刑架交易”。“嗯，我喝了一杯，又喝了一杯，然后——”这时他笑了，其他人也笑了——“我连续喝了三天。”施泰纳（Steiner）是第一个清晰描述这种现象的人，他这样说道：“在《酗酒者》这部影片中，怀特向观众讲述了他上周的酗酒经历，而观众（或许也包括治疗师）则兴高采烈。观众席上孩子们的笑容与女巫母亲或食人魔的笑容遥相呼应，并强化了后者的笑容——当怀特听从了‘别想——喝酒’的命令时，女巫母亲或食人魔的笑容令她感到高兴，实际上，这反而收紧了套在怀特脖子上的绞索。”

The gallows laugh (which results from a gallows transaction) means that if the patient laughs while recounting a misfortune, and particularly if the other group members join in the laughter, that misfortune is part of the catastrophe of the patient’s script. When the people around him laugh, they reinforce the payoff, hasten his doom, and prevent him from getting well. In this way, the parental come-on is brought to fruition, ha ha.

绞刑架式的笑声（源于绞刑架式的交易）意味着，如果病人在讲述不幸遭遇时发笑，尤其是当其他成员也跟着笑时，那么这不幸遭遇就成了病人剧本中灾难的一部分。当周围的人笑的时候，他们强化了剧本的结局，加速了他的厄运，并阻碍了他的康复。这样一来，父母的诱导就得以实现，哈哈。

G • Types of Laughter

G • 笑的类型

It can be fairly said that script analysts and their groups have more fun than anybody, even though they do refrain from laughing at the hanging or when someone gets his feet dirty. There are several kinds of laughs which are of interest in script analysis. 15

可以说，剧本分析师及其团队比任何人都更享受工作，尽管他们不会在看到绞刑或有人弄脏脚时发笑。剧本分析中有很多种笑点都值得关注。

1 • SCRIPTY LAUGHS

1 • 剧本式的笑声

a. ‘Heh Heh Heh’ is the Parental chuckle of the witch mother or ogre father who is leading someone, usually his own offspring, down the primrose path of derision and defeat. ‘How much weight did you put on, heh heh heh?’ (Sometimes written ‘ha ha.’) This is the scripty laugh.

a. “嘿嘿嘿”是巫婆母亲或食人魔父亲的惯用笑声，他们正引导某人（通常是自己的孩子）走上一条充满嘲讽和失败的道路。“你胖了多少啊，嘿嘿嘿？”（有时写作“哈哈”。）这是戏谑的笑声。

b. ‘Ha Ha Ha’ is the Adult’s chuckle of rueful humor. As in Danny’s case, it signifies a superficial insight. From his recent experiences, Danny had learned not to trust ghost writers, but he had not learned much about himself and his own weaknesses, which would again and again lead him into similar traps until the final one was sprung. This is the gallows laugh.

b. “哈哈哈哈”是成年人苦涩的笑声。就像丹尼的情况一样，它象征着肤浅的领悟。从最近的经历中，丹尼学会了不要相信代笔作家，但他对自己和自身的弱点却知之甚少，这让他一次又一次地落入类似的陷阱，直到最终的陷阱打开。这是绞刑架下的笑声。

c. ‘He He He’ is the Child’s laugh when he is going to pull a fast one. He is really getting into a game of ‘Let’s Pull a Fast One on Joey,’ a true con game where he is enticed into thinking that he is going to fool somebody, but he himself ends up being the victim instead. For example, Danny Now said ‘He He He!’ when a ghost writer explained how they could pull a fast one on the English professor, but then Come to Find Out, Danny ended up as the victim. This is the gamy laugh.

c. “嘿嘿嘿！”是孩子准备耍花招时的笑声。他正沉浸在“咱们来捉弄乔伊”的游戏里，这其实是一个真正的骗局，他被引诱着以为自己能骗到别人，结果自己反而成了受害者。例如，当一个代笔作家解释他们如何捉弄英语教授时，丹尼·诺就发出了“嘿嘿嘿！”的笑声，但结果却发现，丹尼自己才是受害者。这就是那种狡猾的笑声。

2 • HEALTHY LAUGHS

2 • 健康的笑声

d. ‘Ho Ho Ho’ is the Parent’s laugh at the Child’s struggle to succeed. It is patronizing, benevolent, and helpful, at least as far as the immediate problem is concerned. It usually comes from people who are not too heavily involved and can turn over the final responsibility to someone else. It demonstrates to the child that there are rewards for nonscripty behavior. This is the granddad or Santa Claus laugh.

d. “Ho Ho Ho”是父母对孩子努力奋斗的笑声。这种笑声带有居高临下的意味，既仁慈又有帮助，至少在眼前的问题上是如此。它通常来自那些没有过多参与孩子成长、可以将最终责任推卸给其他人的人。这种笑声向孩子表明，不按常理出牌的行为是有回报的。这就是爷爷或圣诞老人的笑声。

e. There is another kind of ‘Ha Ha Ha’ which is much more hearty and meaningful. This signifies true insight on the part of the Adult as to how he has been conned, not by external figures, but by his own Parent and Child. It is similar to what psychologists call an ‘aha experience’ (although I personally have never heard anyone except a psychologist say ‘aha’ on such occasions). This is the laugh of insight.

e. 还有另一种“哈哈哈哈”，它更加发自内心，也更有意义。这代表着成年人真正领悟到自己是如何被欺骗的，而欺骗他的并非外在的人，而是自己的父母和孩子。这类似于心理学家所说的“顿悟”（尽管我个人从未听过除了心理学家以外的人在这种场合说“啊哈”）。这是顿悟的笑声。

f. ‘Wow Wow’ is the Child laugh of sheer fun or the belly laugh of older people who have bellies. It only comes to people who are script free or can put their scripts aside for the occasion. This is the spontaneous laugh of healthy people.

f. “哇哇”是孩子纯粹的、发自内心的笑声，或是老年人因肚子而发出的那种开怀大笑。这种笑声只属于那些无需刻意准备，或者能够暂时放下预设的人。这是健康人自然而然发出的笑声。

H • Grandmother

H • 祖母

No one who has ever known his grandmother is an atheist, even if she herself was one, for all grandmothers, good or evil, are watching somewhere out there, usually on pass from Heaven. During group meetings (and often during poker games as well) she hovers in the corner of the room by the ceiling. If a patient’s Child does not have complete confidence in his Parent, in time of need he usually feels that he can still trust grandmother, and he will gaze up at the ceiling in her direction to get protection and guidance from her invisible presence. It should be remembered that grandmothers are even more powerful than mothers, although they may appear but seldom on the scene. But when they do, they have the final say. This is well known to readers of fairy tales, where the old crone can put a blessing or a curse on the baby prince or princess, and the bad fairy or the fairy godmother cannot take it away, but can only tone it down. Thus, in ‘Sleeping Beauty’ the old crone condemns the princess to die. The good fairy modifies this to sleeping for one hundred years. That is the best she can do, for as she says: ‘I have no power to undo entirely what my elder has done.’

凡是认识自己祖母的人，都不会是无神论者，即便她本人是。因为所有的祖母，无论善恶，都在某个地方默默地注视着我们，通常是从天堂俯瞰。在集体会议期间（也常常在扑克牌局中），她会徘徊在房间角落的天花板旁。如果病人的孩子对父母不够信任，在需要帮助的时候，他通常会觉得可以信赖祖母，于是会抬头望向天花板，寻求祖母无形的庇佑和指引。要知道，祖母的力量甚至比母亲还要强大，尽管她们偶尔会出现，但很少露面。然而，一旦出现，她们就拥有最终决定权。童话故事的读者对此并不陌生，老妪可以给王子或公主降下祝福或诅咒，而坏仙女或仙女教母无法消除诅咒，只能减轻其威力。例如，在《睡美人》中，老妪诅咒公主死去，而善良的仙女则将诅咒改为沉睡一百年。这是她所能做的最好的了，正如她所说：“我没有能力完全撤销长辈所做的一切。”

Thus grandmother, for good or evil, is the court of last appeal, and if the therapist succeeds in breaking the curse put on the patient by her mother, he still has grandmother to reckon with. A good therapist, therefore, must learn how to deal with antagonistic grandmothers as well as with mothers. In therapeutic situations, grandmothers always think they are right, and justified. The therapist has to talk firmly to them: ‘Do you really want Zoe to be a failure? Do you really think your complaint will be well received at Headquarters if you tell them the truth? The truth is that I am not seducing your granddaughter into bad ways, but I am actually giving her permission to be happy. Whatever you tell them, remember that psychiatrists come from Headquarters, too, and will also be heard there. Zoe cannot speak for herself against you, but I can speak for her.’

因此，无论好坏，祖母都是最终的裁决者。即使治疗师成功打破了母亲强加在病人身上的诅咒，他仍然要面对祖母的挑战。所以，一位优秀的治疗师必须学会如何应对敌对的祖母，就像应对母亲一样。在治疗过程中，祖母总是认为自己是对的，而且有理有据。治疗师必须坚定地与她们对话：“你真的希望佐伊一事无成吗？你真的认为如果你把真相告诉总部，你的投诉会被接受吗？事实是，我并没有引诱你的孙女走上歧途，我实际上是在允许她获得幸福。无论你怎么说，记住，精神科医生也来自总部，他们的声音也会被总部听到。佐伊无法为自己辩解，但我可以替她说话。”

In most cases, it is grandmother who decides which cards Jeder will get when he plays poker. If he keeps in good with her he will certainly not lose, and will usually win. If he offends her by thought or deed, he is bound to lose. But he must remember that the other players have grandmothers, too, and they may be just as powerful as his. In addition, they may be in better standing with their grandmothers than he is with his.

大多数情况下，杰德玩扑克时，决定他拿到哪几张牌的是他的祖母。如果他跟祖母关系好，肯定不会输，通常都会赢。如果他在思想或行为上得罪了祖母，就肯定会输。但他必须记住，其他玩家也有祖母，而且她们的影响力可能和他的祖母一样大。此外，他们和祖母的关系可能比他好得多。

I • Types of Protest

一、抗议的类型

The main types of protest are anger and weeping. These are highly regarded by the majority of group therapists as ‘expressing real feelings,’ while laughter is for some reason not so highly thought of, and is sometimes lightly dismissed as not expressing a ‘real feeling.’

主要的抗议形式是愤怒和哭泣。大多数团体治疗师都高度重视这两种形式，认为它们是“表达真实感受”的方式，而笑声不知为何却不被重视，有时甚至被轻描淡写地认为并非表达“真实感受”。

Since about ninety per cent of anger is a ‘racket’ encouraged by the Parent, the real question is ‘What good does it do to get angry?’ It seldom accomplishes anything that cannot be done better without it, and the price is hardly worth paying: four to six hours of disturbed metabolism, and possibly several hours of insomnia. The crucial point in the after-burn of anger occurs when Jeder stops saying to himself or his friends: ‘I should have …’ (using the past tense) and switches into ‘I’d like to …’ (using the present tense). This staircase anger is nearly always misguided. The rule for staircase anger is the same as the rule for staircase wit. ‘If you didn’t say it on the spot, don’t go back to say it afterward, as your intuition was probably right in the first place.’ The best policy is to wait until the next occasion, and then if you are really ready to do better, you will.

既然大约百分之九十的愤怒都是父母怂恿的“炒作”，那么真正的问题是“生气有什么好处？”它很少能带来任何不生气就做不到的事情，而且代价几乎不值得：四到六个小时的新陈代谢紊乱，甚至可能几个小时的失眠。愤怒余波的关键在于，当杰德不再对自己或朋友说“我本应该……”（使用过去时）时，转而说“我想……”（使用现在时）。这种阶梯式愤怒几乎总是错误的。阶梯式愤怒的规则与阶梯式机智的规则相同：“如果你当时没说出口，事后就不要再说了，因为你的直觉很可能一开始就是对的。”最好的做法是等到下一次机会，如果你真的准备好做得更好，你就会去做。

The phase of the present tense (I’d like to …’) is usually short lived, and the future tense soon takes over: ‘Next time I’ll …’ This signifies a shift from Child to Adult. I am firmly convinced (without any chemical evidence) that the shift from past to future coincides with a shift in metabolic chemistry, and is merely a slight change in some small radical of some complex hormonal substance – a simple process of reduction or oxidation. This is another assault on the illusion of autonomy. As the person shifts from past to future in his indignation, he thinks ‘I am calming down,’ or someone says: ‘Now you are being more sensible.’ But in fact he is neither ‘calming’ nor ‘being’ and is simply reacting to a trivial chemical change.

现在时态（“我想……”）通常持续时间很短，将来时态很快就会取代现在时态：“下次我会……”。这标志着从儿童到成人的转变。我坚信（尽管没有任何化学证据），从过去到未来的转变与代谢化学的变化同时发生，仅仅是某种复杂激素物质中某个微小基团的轻微变化——一个简单的还原或氧化过程。这又是对自主幻觉的又一次冲击。当一个人在愤怒中从过去转向未来时，他会想“我正在冷静下来”，或者有人会说：“你现在更理智了。”但事实上，他既没有“冷静下来”，也没有“理智”，而只是对一个微不足道的化学变化做出了反应。

Nearly all anger is part of a game of ‘Now I’ve Got You, You Son of a Bitch’ (NIGYSOB). (‘Thank you for giving me an excuse to get angry.’) Jeder is in fact pleased at being wronged, since he has been carrying around a bag of anger since early childhood and it is a relief to vent some of it legitimately. (‘Who wouldn’t get angry under such conditions?’) The question here is whether abreaction is beneficial. Freud long ago said it didn’t do the job. Nowadays, however, for most group therapists it is the mark of a ‘good’ group meeting, and leads to lively staff conferences. Everybody is delighted and exhilarated and relieved when a patient ‘expresses anger.’ Therapists who encourage patients to do this, or even demand it from them, feel very supercilious toward their less trippy colleagues and have no hesitation in saying so. The reductio ad absurdum of this attitude is in the following statement by an imaginary patient: ‘I took public transportation toward my occupational area and resolved that today I would really communicate with authority figures by expressing real feelings. So I screamed at my boss and threw my typewriter through the window. He was very happy, and said “I’m glad that we’re finally communicating and that you’re freely expressing your hostility. That’s the kind of employee we like to have around here. I note that you have liquidated a fellow employee who happened to be standing under the window, but I hope this will not arouse hampering guilt feelings in you that will interfere with our interpersonal interaction.”’

几乎所有的愤怒都属于“现在我抓到你了，你这混蛋”（NIGYSOB）游戏的一部分。（“谢谢你给了我一个发火的借口。”）杰德实际上很高兴自己受到了委屈，因为他从小就积攒着满满的愤怒，能够合法地发泄出来让他感到轻松。（“在这种情况下谁不会生气呢？”）问题在于，宣泄是否有益。弗洛伊德很久以前就说过它不起作用。然而，如今对于大多数团体治疗师来说，这却是“成功”团体会议的标志，并能带来热闹的员工会议。当病人“表达愤怒”时，每个人都感到高兴、兴奋和如释重负。那些鼓励病人这样做，甚至要求病人这样做的治疗师，会觉得那些不那么“迷幻”的同事非常傲慢，并且毫不犹豫地表达出来。这种态度的荒谬之处可以从一位假想病人的以下陈述中看出：“我乘公共交通工具去上班，下定决心今天一定要和权威人士好好沟通，表达我的真实感受。于是我冲着老板大吼大叫，还把打字机扔出了窗外。他非常高兴，说：‘我很高兴我们终于开始沟通了，你也能够自由地表达你的敌意。这正是我们想要的员工。我注意到你把一个碰巧站在窗下的同事给解决了，但我希望这不会让你产生阻碍我们人际交往的内疚感。’”

The distinction between racket anger and genuine anger is often easy to make. After NIGYSOB anger the patient may smile, whereas genuine anger is usually followed in the group by weeping. In any case, the patients should understand that they are not permitted to throw things, or assault or strike each other in the group. Any attempt to do so should be physically restrained, and, except in special cases, a patient who does either of these things should be dropped from the group. There are, however, some therapists who contract to let patients express their anger physically, and have proper facilities and personnel for handling the possible complications.

区分虚假愤怒和真怒通常很容易。虚假愤怒过后，患者可能会微笑，而真怒过后，患者通常会在小组中哭泣。无论如何，患者都应该明白，他们不允许在小组中扔东西、攻击或殴打他人。任何此类行为都应受到身体约束，除特殊情况外，任何做出此类行为的患者都应被移出小组。然而，也有一些治疗师允许患者以肢体方式表达愤怒，并配备了相应的设施和人员来处理可能出现的并发症。

Weeping is also a racket in most cases, or may even be a dramatic put-on. The response of the other group members is the best way to judge this. If they feel annoyed or overly sympathetic, the tears are probably spurious. Genuine weeping usually results in a respectful silence and genuine responses of Aristotelian tragic pity.

在大多数情况下，哭泣也是一种作秀，甚至可能是一种夸张的表演。其他成员的反应是判断真假的最佳方法。如果他们感到恼火或过分同情，那么这些眼泪很可能是装出来的。真正的哭泣通常会换来一片肃穆的沉默和亚里士多德式的真挚的悲悯之情。

J • The Story of Your Life

J • 你人生的故事

One of the most instructive tales ever written for the script analyst is The Strange Life of Ivan Osokin , by P. D. Ouspensky, the well-known mystic. Ivan Osokin is given a chance to relive his life, and the prediction is that he will make the same mistakes all over again, and that he will repeat all the behavior he regrets. The hero replies that this will be no great wonder, since he will be deprived of the memory of what he has been through and will therefore have no way of avoiding his errors. He is told that quite to the contrary, and against the usual policy in such cases, he will be permitted to remember everything and will still make the same mistakes. On these terms he accepts, and sure enough, even though he can foresee each disaster that he brings on himself, he does repeat his previous behavior, as Ouspensky skillfully and convincingly demonstrates. Ouspensky attributes this to the force of destiny, and the script analyst will agree with him, adding only that that destiny was programed into him in his early years by his parents, and did not come from a metaphysical or cosmic force. The script analyst’s position, then, is the same as Ouspensky’s: every individual is compelled by his script to repeat again and again the same patterns of behavior no matter how much he regrets their consequences. In fact, the regret is itself a motive for repeating them, and they are repeated, in fact, just in order to collect regrets.

对于剧本分析而言，最具启发性的故事之一当属著名神秘主义者乌斯宾斯基的《伊凡·奥索金的奇异人生》。故事讲述了伊凡·奥索金获得重生的机会，预言他会重蹈覆辙，再次犯下所有令他后悔的行为。主人公回应说，这不足为奇，因为他将被剥夺记忆，无法避免犯错。然而，他被告知，恰恰相反，与通常的做法不同，他将被允许记住一切，却依然会犯同样的错误。伊凡接受了这一条件，果不其然，尽管他能够预见自己将招致的种种灾难，但他仍然重蹈覆辙，正如乌斯宾斯基巧妙而令人信服地论证的那样。乌斯宾斯基将此归因于命运的力量，剧本分析家对此表示赞同，并补充说，这种命运是他的父母在他幼年时就灌输给他的，并非来自某种形而上学或宇宙力量。因此，剧本分析家的立场与乌斯宾斯基相同：每个人都受其剧本的驱使，一遍又一遍地重复相同的行为模式，无论他多么后悔这些行为的后果。事实上，后悔本身就是重复这些行为的动机，而这些行为的重复，实际上仅仅是为了积累后悔。

This picture can be rounded out by including another tale: ‘The Strange Case of M. Valdemar,’ by Edgar Allan Poe. M. Valdemar is hypnotized just before his death, and survives for a long time. Eventually, he is brought out of his hypnotic trance, and immediately, before the gaze of the horrified onlookers, he turns into a putrefying corpse, in just the state he would have been in if he had died on the day he was hypnotized. That is, he ‘caught up with himself.’ In script terms, this is also an everyday occurrence. The child is, in effect, hypnotized by his parents into carrying out a certain life pattern. He will show all the signs of vitality as long as it is humanly possible for him to continue, until his script destiny is completed. After that he may fall apart very rapidly. In effect, many people are ‘propped up’ by their scripts, and as soon as the script is completed, they deteriorate. That is the fate of many old or ‘retired’ people all over the world, as I have noted. (Not only in ‘our society,’ as is commonly claimed.)

我们可以加入另一个故事来完善这幅图景：埃德加·爱伦·坡的《瓦尔德马先生的奇案》。瓦尔德马先生在临死前被催眠，并存活了很长时间。最终，他从催眠状态中醒来，立刻在惊恐的旁观者面前变成了一具腐烂的尸体，就像他如果在被催眠当天死去时一样。也就是说，他“追上了自己”。从剧本的角度来看，这也是一种日常现象。孩子实际上被父母催眠，去执行某种生活模式。只要他还能继续下去，他就会展现出所有活力，直到他的剧本命运完成。之后，他可能会迅速崩溃。实际上，许多人被他们的剧本“支撑”着，一旦剧本完成，他们就会衰败。正如我之前提到的，这是世界各地许多老年人或“退休”人士的共同命运。（并非像人们通常声称的那样，这种情况只存在于“我们这个社会”。）

The script itself is under the protection of the Greek Goddess of Necessity, ‘the sublime Ananke ,’ as Freud calls her. In psychoanalytic language, it is driven by the repetition compulsion, the compulsion to do the same thing over and over. Thus, a short script may be repeated over and over in the course of a lifetime (a woman marries one alcoholic after another, on the premise that each time it will be different; or a man marries one invalid wife after another, thus undergoing a whole series of bereavements). Furthermore, in a diluted form, the whole script may be repeated every year (Christmas depressions due to disappointment) within the larger framework of the lifetime script (eventual suicide due to a very big disappointment). Also, it may be repeated every month within the year (menstrual disappointments). And beyond that, it may also be repeated every day in a smaller version. Even more microscopically, it may be run through in an hour: for example, the whole script, in watered-down form, may occur in the course of the weekly group meeting, week after week, if only the therapist knows where to look. Sometimes a mere few seconds of activity may reveal the ‘story of the patient’s life.’ I have given an example elsewhere of the commonest form of that, which may be called ‘Rush and Stumble’ – and ‘Quick Recovery.’ 16

剧本本身受到希腊必然女神——弗洛伊德称之为“崇高的阿南刻”——的庇护。用精神分析的语言来说，它受强迫性重复的驱使，即反复做同一件事的强迫。因此，一个简短的剧本可能会在人的一生中反复出现（例如，一个女人接连嫁给一个又一个酗酒者，因为她相信每次都会有所不同；或者一个男人接连娶一个又一个体弱多病的妻子，从而经历一系列的丧亲之痛）。此外，在更宏大的人生剧本框架下（最终因巨大的失望而自杀），整个剧本可能会以稀释的形式每年重复出现（例如，因失望而导致的圣诞节抑郁）。它也可能会在每个月重复出现（例如，经期的失望）。不仅如此，它还可能以较小的版本每天重复出现。更细致地观察，它可能在一个小时内就发生：例如，如果治疗师知道该如何观察，那么整个剧本的简化版可能在每周的小组会议中反复出现。有时，仅仅几秒钟的活动就能揭示“患者的人生故事”。我曾在其他地方举过一个最常见的例子，可以称之为“匆忙与跌跌撞撞”——以及“快速恢复”。

‘Mrs Sayers stretched her arm out across Mrs Catters’s chest to reach for an ash tray on the end table. As she drew her arm back she lost her balance and almost fell off the settee. She recovered just in time, laughed deprecatingly, muttered “Excuse me!” and settled back to smoke. At this moment, Mrs Catters took her attention away from Mr Troy long enough to murmur: “Pardon me!”’

赛耶斯太太伸手越过卡特斯太太的胸口去拿茶几上的烟灰缸。她缩回手臂时失去平衡，差点从沙发上摔下来。她及时稳住身形，无奈地笑了笑，低声说了句“不好意思！”，然后又坐回沙发上继续抽烟。这时，卡特斯太太才把注意力从特洛伊先生身上移开，低声说道：“对不起！”

Here, condensed into a few seconds, is the story of Mrs Sayers’s life. She tries to be careful but does things in an awkward way. She almost comes to grief but is rescued just in time. She apologizes, but then someone else takes the blame. One could almost visualize her ogre father telling her to fall over, or pushing her (script), and her mother rescuing her in the nick of time (counterscript). After that, she apologizes politely for being clumsy. (She learned in childhood that it paid to be clumsy if she wished to keep her father’s love, because that was the way he wanted it; furthermore, it gave her an excuse to apologize, and that was one of the few times when he listened to her and acknowledged her existence.) Then comes the script twist, which makes the whole episode into a drama rather than a mere catalogue of misfortune: someone else takes the final blame and apologizes even more sincerely. Here we have a classical illustration of the Karpman triangle 17 for categorizing scripts and theatrical dramas ( Figure 12 , Chapter Ten).

短短几秒钟，就浓缩了赛耶斯太太的一生。她小心翼翼，却总是笨手笨脚。她差点遭遇不测，幸亏及时被救。她道了歉，但最终却有人替她背了黑锅。人们几乎可以想象她那暴戾的父亲故意让她摔倒，或者推她一把（剧本），而她的母亲则在千钧一发之际将她救了下来（反剧本）。之后，她礼貌地为自己的笨拙道歉。（她从小就明白，如果想赢得父亲的爱，笨手笨脚反而有好处，因为这正是父亲想要的；此外，这给了她一个道歉的借口，而这也是父亲为数不多的几次认真倾听她、认可她存在的时刻。）接下来，剧情出现了转折，将整个事件从一连串的不幸遭遇变成了一出戏剧：最终，有人替她承担了责任，并更加真诚地道歉。这里我们有一个经典的卡普曼三角图 17 ，用于对剧本和戏剧进行分类（图 12，第十章）。

K • The Script Switches

K • 脚本切换

According to Karpman, all dramatic action can be summarized as switches between three main roles: Victim, Persecutor, and Rescuer. Those switches occur at varying speeds and may go in either direction. In the drama Rush and Stumble – and Quick Recovery, we have a very rapid set of switches.
