Mrs Sayers starts off with Father (in her head) as Persecutor (‘pushing’ her), Mother in her head as Rescuer (‘rescuing her from falling’), and herself as Victim. That is the way the triangle stands in her head, the skull script. In the action script, she makes herself the Persecutor by brushing against Mrs Catters, who thus becomes her Victim. She apologizes for this, but Mrs Catters in turn (in accordance with the needs of her script) pulls a very quick switch, and instead of behaving like a Victim, apologizes as though she had done something wrong, thus taking the role of Persecutor.

根据卡普曼的理论，所有戏剧行为都可以概括为三种主要角色之间的转换：受害者、迫害者和拯救者。这些转换发生的速度各不相同，方向也各不相同。在戏剧《匆忙与跌倒——以及快速恢复》中，我们看到了一系列非常快速的转换。一开始，塞耶斯太太脑海中，父亲是迫害者（“推”她），母亲是拯救者（“救她于水火之中”），而她自己则是受害者。这就是她脑海中的三角形结构，也就是所谓的“骷髅剧本”。在行动剧本中，她不小心碰到了卡特斯太太，卡特斯太太因此变成了她的受害者，她也因此成为了迫害者。她为此道歉，但卡特斯太太（根据剧本的需要）迅速转换了角色，不再表现得像个受害者，而是像做错了什么事一样道歉，从而扮演了迫害者的角色。

In this condensed set of transactions we learn a great deal about the story of two lives. Mrs Sayers ordinarily came on like a plaintive victim; it is now clear that she can switch into the role of Persecutor providing it is ‘accidental’ and she apologizes for it. The goal of the Rush and Stumble script is to be relieved of responsibility by getting the Victim to apologize. She has found a complementary script figure in Mrs Catters, whose script is evidently called something like ‘Hit Me and I’ll Apologize,’ or ‘I’m Sorry My Face Got in the Way of Your Fist’ – the typical script of the wife of an alcoholic.

在这几段简短的对话中，我们得以了解两个人的生活故事。赛耶斯太太通常扮演一个哀怨的受害者；现在看来，只要是“意外”，并且她为此道歉，她就能摇身一变成为施害者。这种“急躁踉跄”式的剧本，其目的就是通过让受害者道歉来摆脱责任。她在卡特斯太太身上找到了一个与之互补的角色，卡特斯太太的剧本显然叫做“打我一下我就道歉”或者“对不起，我的脸挡了你的拳头”之类的——典型的酗酒者妻子的剧本。

Danny, the young man without a thesis, also ran through the drama story of his life in recounting his experience. As already noted, the name of his favorite game, which is also the title of his script, is ‘Let’s Pull A Fast One on Joey.’ Danny meets a friendly neighborhood Rescuer who offers for a fee to help him pull a fast one on his Victim, the professor. Danny ends up holding the bag as the Victim, and his friendly Rescuer turns out to be a better crook or Persecutor than Danny is. The professor, who, unknown to himself, was originally slated to be the Victim, now has to play the part of Rescuer to Danny who comes to him for help in order to graduate. That is the story of Danny’s life. He gets outsmarted in his attempts to pull a fast one, and ends up being a martyr; but since everyone can see that he arranged his own downfall, instead of sympathy he gets laughter. He not only fails to accomplish his task, he even fails at being a martyr. That is one thing that keeps him from attempting suicide. He knows that if he tries, he will either bungle it in some laugh-provoking fashion, or if he succeeds, something will happen that will make the whole sacrifice seem humorous. Even his attempts at psychosis are unconvincing and just make the other group members laugh. What his mother has given him is a benevolent trap for a script. ‘Look,’ she has instructed him, ‘you’re going to fail in everything. It’s no use beating your head against the wall, because you’ll even fail at going crazy or killing yourself, so go on out there and try it for a while, and when you’re convinced, come back to me like a good boy and I’ll take care of everything for you.’

丹尼，这个没有论文的年轻人，在讲述自己的经历时，也上演了一出人生闹剧。正如前文所述，他最喜欢的游戏，同时也是他剧本的标题，叫做“咱们来捉弄乔伊”。丹尼遇到了一位友好的邻居“救世主”，这位“救世主”提出要收费帮他捉弄“受害者”——那位教授。结果丹尼反而成了受害者，而他那位友好的“救世主”却比丹尼更会耍花招，或者说更像个“迫害者”。教授原本是“受害者”，却不知自己身在其中，现在不得不扮演“救世主”的角色，帮助前来求助以求顺利毕业的丹尼。这就是丹尼的人生故事。他试图捉弄别人，结果却弄巧成拙，最终成了“殉道者”；但由于所有人都看得出来，这一切都是他咎由自取，所以人们非但没有同情他，反而嘲笑他。他不仅没能完成任务，甚至连当殉道者都失败了。正是这一点阻止了他自杀。他知道，如果他尝试自杀，要么会以某种滑稽的方式搞砸，要么即使成功了，也会发生一些事让整个牺牲显得荒诞可笑。就连他装疯卖傻的尝试都显得很不逼真，只会让其他组员发笑。他母亲给他的，其实是一个精心设计的陷阱剧本。“听着，”她指示他，“你做什么都会失败。撞墙也没用，因为你连发疯或自杀都做不到，所以出去试试吧，等你确信了，就乖乖地回来，我会为你安排好一切。”

This is one reward for the group therapist if he watches every movement of every patient at every moment during the session. He may observe one of his patients going through his script in condensed form in the space of a few seconds. Those few seconds may break the case wide open by telling him the story of the patient’s life, which he might otherwise have to spend laborious months or years in digging out and clarifying. Unfortunately, there is no rule to pass on about how to know when this is happening. It probably happens with every patient at every group meeting in some form or other, more or less heavily disguised or coded. Its detection then depends on the therapist’s readiness to understand what is happening, and that depends on his intuition. When his intuition is ready not only to understand what the patient is doing, but also to communicate that understanding to his Adult, then he will be able to recognize the patient’s script when he sees it, including the roles he and the other group members play. Since these roles are essential to know in order to carry on the treatment successfully, that will be the subject of the next chapter.

如果团体治疗师在治疗过程中时刻关注每位患者的每一个动作，这将是他的一项重要收获。他可能会观察到，某位患者在短短几秒钟内就完成了他原本的“脚本”。这短短几秒钟或许就能让治疗师豁然开朗，揭示出患者的人生故事，而这些故事原本可能需要花费数月甚至数年的时间才能挖掘和澄清。遗憾的是，目前并没有任何规则可以指导我们如何识别这种情况。这种情况很可能以某种形式发生在每位患者身上，每次团体治疗中，只是伪装或编码的程度有所不同。因此，能否识别出这种“脚本”取决于治疗师是否准备好理解正在发生的事情，而这取决于他的直觉。当治疗师的直觉不仅能够理解患者的行为，还能将这种理解传达给他的“成人”（指治疗师的内在认知），那么他就能识别出患者的“脚本”，包括他自己和其他组员扮演的角色。由于了解这些角色对于成功开展治疗至关重要，因此这将是下一章的主题。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 Berne, E. Principles of Group Treatment. Loc. cit .

1 Berne, E. 团体治疗原则。同上。

2 The Child’s perceptions often occur in dreams as day residues, caricatures, or symbols: perceptions which the Adult was not aware of but which nevertheless registered. Such perceptions are the basis for intuitive judgments. See Berne, E. ‘Concerning the nature of Diagnosis.’ Loc. cit . Also refs. 6, 8, 9, 10, and 11.

2 儿童的感知常常以白日残留、漫画式描绘或象征的形式出现在梦中：这些感知是成人并未意识到的，但却被其所感知。此类感知是直觉判断的基础。参见 Berne, E.《论诊断的本质》。同上。另见参考文献6、8、9、10和11。

3 Feldman, S. S. Mannerisms of Speech and Gestures in Everyday Life . International Universities Press, New York, 1959.

3 Feldman, S. S. 日常生活中的言语和手势习惯。国际大学出版社，纽约，1959 年。

4 Deutsch, F. ‘分析姿势学’。精神分析季刊，21：196–214，1952。

11 Berne, E. ‘论交流的本质’。同上。

12 参见 Berne, E. ‘比较精神病学的困难：斐济群岛’。《美国精神病学杂志》，116：104–109，1959 年。

13 Crossman, P. ‘Position and Smiling.’ Loc. cit .

13 Crossman, P. ‘姿势与微笑’。同上。

14 Steiner, C. M. ‘A Script Checklist.’ Loc. cit .

15 Grotjahn, M. Beyond Laughter . McGraw-Hill Book Company, New York, 1957.

15 Grotjahn, M.《超越欢笑》。纽约麦格劳-希尔图书公司，1957 年。

16 Berne, E. Transactional Analysis in Psychotherapy. Loc. cit ., pp. 123 ff.

16 Berne, E. 心理治疗中的交互分析。同上，第 123 页及后续页。

17 Karpman, S. ‘Fairy Tales and Script Drama Analysis.’ Loc. cit .

17 Karpman, S. ‘童话故事和剧本戏剧分析’。同上。

fn1 This probably means REM sleep. Often a therapist who has lain awake tossing all night will find his intuition sharper than usual the next morning. The hypothesis would be that his Adult is tired from lack of NREM sleep while his Child is in extra-good shape from plenty of REM sleep.

fn1 这可能意味着快速眼动睡眠（REM睡眠）。通常，彻夜难眠的治疗师第二天早上会发现自己的直觉比平时更加敏锐。假设是，他的成年人由于缺乏非快速眼动睡眠（NREM睡眠）而感到疲惫，而他的儿童则由于充足的快速眼动睡眠（REM睡眠）而状态极佳。

fn2 ‘Noun adjectives’ ending in ‘ic,’ such as hysteric, sociopathic, psychopathic, are usually put-downs applied to patients. ‘Verb adjectives’ ending in ‘ive,’ like punitive and manipulative, are more neutral, and can be applied to patients and staff members alike.

fn2 以“ic”结尾的名词形容词，例如 hysteric（歇斯底里的）、sociopathic（反社会的）、psychopathic（精神病态的），通常是对病人的贬义形容词。以“ive”结尾的动词形容词，例如 punitive（惩罚性的）和 manipulative（操纵性的），则更为中性，既可用于形容病人，也可用于形容工作人员。

#↩

CHAPTER EIGHTEEN

第十八章

The Script in Treatment

治疗中的剧本

A • The Role of the Therapist

A • 治疗师的角色

We have already discussed how the patient comes to choose a particular therapist, if he has a choice. If he has no choice, he will attempt to maneuver the therapist he is assigned to into fulfilling the role required by his script. Once he gets past the preliminary phase, he will try to make the doctor fit the childhood slot reserved for the ‘magician’ in order to get from him the type of magic he needs: ‘science,’ ‘chicken soup,’ or ‘religion.’ While the patient’s Child is setting up the games and script scenes required to accomplish this, his Adult will try to get whatever insight he can from the treatment. The sooner the therapist recognizes the role he is expected to play, and can foresee the script drama which the patient, in his own good time, will try to bring to a climax, the sooner he can do something about it, and the more effective he will be in helping the patient out of his script world and into the real one, where he can be cured instead of merely making progress.

我们之前已经讨论过，如果病人有选择权，他会如何挑选特定的治疗师。如果没有选择权，他会试图操控分配给他的治疗师，让他扮演自己剧本中设定的角色。一旦度过了初步阶段，他就会试图让医生符合他童年时期“魔术师”的角色设定，以便从中获得他所需要的“魔法”：无论是“科学”、“心灵鸡汤”还是“宗教”。当病人内心的“孩子”在构建实现这一目标所需的游戏和剧本场景时，他的“成人”则会试图从治疗中获取任何可能的启示。治疗师越早意识到自己应该扮演的角色，越早预见到病人会在某个合适的时机试图将剧本推向高潮的剧情，就能越早采取行动，也就越能有效地帮助病人走出剧本世界，进入现实世界，在那里他才能真正得到治愈，而不仅仅是取得一些进展。

B • Game Dosage

B • 游戏剂量

The ‘neurotic,’ many clinicians have said, does not come for treatment in order to get better, but to learn how to be a better neurotic. 1 The game analyst says something similar: the patient comes not to learn how to be straight, but to learn how to play his games better. Hence he will quit if the therapist declines to play entirely, and also if the therapist is a pigeon and can be too easily conned. In this respect, transactional games are like chess: an enthusiastic chess player is not interested in people who do not want to play at all, nor in people who do not offer any real opposition. In a treatment group, a confirmed ‘Alcoholic’ player will get angry if no one offers to rescue or persecute him, or play the patsy or the connection, and will soon leave. He will also leave if the rescuers are too sentimental, or the persecutors too vehement, because there is no fun if he hooks them too easily. Like other game players, he prefers a little finesse and some reticence on the part of his partners or opponents. If they come on very strong, like the Salvation Army, he may not stay long.

许多临床医生都说过，“神经质”患者前来接受治疗并非为了康复，而是为了学习如何更好地扮演“神经质”的角色。游戏分析师也持类似观点：患者前来并非为了学习如何坦诚相待，而是为了学习如何更好地玩转自己的游戏。因此，如果治疗师完全拒绝参与游戏，或者治疗师过于容易被欺骗，患者就会退出。从这个角度来看，交易型游戏就像下棋：一位热情的棋手对那些根本不想下棋的人，以及那些不构成任何真正挑战的人，都不会感兴趣。在治疗小组中，一个被确诊为“酗酒者”的患者，如果没人愿意拯救他、迫害他、扮演替罪羊或牵线搭桥的角色，他就会生气，并很快离开。如果拯救者过于感性，或者迫害者过于激烈，他也会离开，因为如果他太容易被他们吸引，游戏就失去了乐趣。和其他玩家一样，他喜欢对手或搭档手法娴熟、略带矜持。如果对方咄咄逼人，像救世军那样，他可能不会待太久。

He may also resign from Alcoholics Anonymous if he feels it does not offer any real challenge with its claim of ‘It’s Not You, It’s a Disease,’ and its threats of ‘Wooden Liver.’ Only if he stays on past that stage will he begin to appreciate its real value. Synanon does better by playing it tough and saying: ‘It’s not a disease, it’s your own responsibility that you’re a dope fiend.’ Hence the ‘Alcoholic’ player may move out of AA and try the family doctor, who is not so sure it is a disease. If he is a real sport he will take on a psychotherapist, even one who says it isn’t a disease at all. If he is ready to get well, he may look for a script analyst, or stumble on one accidentally, and then if things go right he may find himself quitting the game. 2

如果他觉得匿名戒酒互助会（AA）的“这不是你的错，而是一种疾病”的说法以及“肝脏僵硬”的威胁无法提供任何真正的挑战，他可能会退出。只有坚持到那个阶段，他才会开始意识到AA的真正价值。Synanon（一个支持戒酒互助会的组织）则做得更好，他们采取强硬态度，声称：“这不是疾病，你吸毒成瘾是你自己的责任。” 因此，这位“酗酒者”可能会离开AA，转而去看家庭医生，而家庭医生并不确定这是否是一种疾病。如果他真的有决心，他会去看心理治疗师，即使治疗师认为这根本不是一种疾病。如果他准备好康复，他可能会寻找剧本分析师，或者偶然遇到一位，如果一切顺利，他可能会发现自己已经退出了游戏。

‘If It Weren’t For Them’ players, particularly the Arsisiety Type, behave similarly. A therapist who will not play at all and demands individual responsibility rather than Arsisiety will soon lose them. If the therapist believes too strongly in Arsisiety, the treatment degenerates into a pastime of ‘Ain’t It Awful’ between him and the patient. Most such patients become bored with this after a while and transfer to someone else who will put up at least a token argument for psychodynamics or self-appraisal. This often happened in the 1930s when young ‘Communists’ went to ‘Communist’ therapists, but soon broke off in favor of more conventional ones. If the therapist feels guilty about Arsisiety, he will form an alliance with the patient instead of treating him, which may be all to the good, but it should not be called treatment.

“若非他们”型患者，尤其是那些装腔作势型患者，行为模式类似。如果治疗师完全不参与这种“装腔作势”的讨论，而是要求患者承担个人责任，而不是装腔作势，那么他很快就会失去这些患者。如果治疗师过于相信装腔作势，治疗就会沦为他和患者之间“真糟糕”的闲聊。大多数这样的患者过一段时间就会感到厌倦，转而寻找其他至少会象征性地支持心理动力学或自我评估的治疗师。这种情况在20世纪30年代经常发生，当时年轻的“共产主义者”会去找“共产主义”治疗师，但很快就转而选择更传统的治疗师。如果治疗师对装腔作势感到内疚，他就会与患者建立一种联盟关系，而不是真正地治疗患者。这种联盟关系或许有益，但这不应该被称为治疗。

The Board, The Establishment, and The Man really do exist, but Mr Arsisiety, upon whom so much is blamed, is a myth. Each person has his own society, with friends as well as enemies. Psychiatry cannot fight The Board, The Establishment, or The Man, it can only fight what is in the patient’s head. The patient and the therapist both have to face that sooner or later. Psychiatric treatment, like all medical treatment, can only be effective under reasonably decent conditions. In cases where ‘If It Weren’t For Them’ is an empty stomach, the chair or couch has no place, but where it is a game it must be stopped sooner or later, and the skill of the therapist lies in doing that without driving the patient away. Dusay 3 gives an excellent summary of the ways games can be handled in treatment.

董事会、体制和当权者确实存在，但被人们归咎于“阿西西蒂先生”的形象却是个神话。每个人都有自己的社交圈，既有朋友也有敌人。精神病学无法对抗董事会、体制或当权者，它只能对抗患者内心的想法。患者和治疗师迟早都必须面对这一点。精神治疗，如同所有医疗治疗一样，只有在相对合理的条件下才能有效。如果“如果不是因为他们”指的是饥饿，那么椅子或沙发就毫无用处；但如果指的是游戏，那么游戏必须迟早停止，治疗师的技巧就在于如何在不吓跑患者的情况下做到这一点。杜赛（Dusay）对如何在治疗中处理游戏问题做了精彩的总结。

Thus game dosage, properly chosen and timed for each patient, will decide whether or not he continues in treatment.

因此，对于每位患者而言，游戏剂量必须选择得当，并把握好时机，才能决定他是否能够继续接受治疗。

C • Motives for Therapy

C • 治疗动机

Usually the patient comes to therapy for two reasons, neither of which places the script in jeopardy. His Adult comes in order to find out how to be more comfortable living in his script. The most forthright example of this is the homosexual of either sex, who usually makes an honest declaration in this respect. The male homosexual, for example, does not want to leave his script world which is populated by women who are either dangerous and hateful schemers, or else innocent and occasionally amiable weirdos. All he wants is to live more comfortably in that world, and only rarely does he wish to see women as real people. Other therapeutic goals of a similar nature are: ‘How to live more comfortably while bashing your head against a stone wall,’ ‘How to live more comfortably while holding on to the sides of a tunnel,’ ‘How to keep other people from making waves when you’re up to your chin in Shit Creek,’ and ‘How to outcrook the crooks when the whole world is Crooksville.’ Any vigorous attempt to change the script world itself must be postponed until after the patient is firmly established in therapy and understands how it fits into his script.

通常，患者前来接受治疗的原因有两个，这两个原因都不会危及他既定的人生剧本。他内心深处的“成人”前来寻求如何更自在地生活在这个剧本中。最直白的例子是同性恋者，无论男女，他们通常都会坦诚地表达自己的感受。例如，男同性恋者并不想离开他所处的剧本世界，在这个世界里，女性要么是危险可恨的阴谋家，要么是天真无邪、偶尔有些古怪的怪人。他想要的只是在这个世界里更自在地生活，他很少会希望把女性看作真正的人。其他类似的治疗目标包括：“如何在撞墙时更舒适地生活”、“如何在隧道边缘挣扎时更舒适地生活”、“如何在深陷困境时不被他人打扰”以及“如何在骗子横行的世界里智胜骗子”。任何试图改变既定世界本身的尝试都必须推迟到患者在治疗中站稳脚跟并理解治疗如何融入自身剧本之后。

Besides the rational Adult desire to live more comfortably, there is a more urgent Child reason why the patient comes to therapy, and that is to advance his script through transactions with the therapist.

除了成年人想要过上更舒适生活的理性愿望之外，患者来接受治疗还有一个更迫切的儿童时期的原因，那就是通过与治疗师的互动来推进自己的剧情发展。

D • The Therapist’s Script

D • 治疗师的脚本

The seductive female patient is the most common example of this. As long as she can seduce him, no matter how subtly or spiritually, he is playing his part and will be unable to cure her. Under these conditions, she may make all sorts of ‘progress’ in order to please him, and to gratify or even help herself, but he will not be able to get her to ‘flip out’ of her script and ‘flip in’ to the real world. This fact is the legitimate basis for the ‘analytic reticence’ or the ‘analytic frustration’ which Freud spoke of. By remaining independent of the patient’s maneuvers, and sticking strictly to his job of analyzing her resistances, her instinctual vicissitudes, and when necessary, the transference, the analyst avoids the possibility of being seduced physically, mentally, or morally. Counter-transference means that not only does the analyst play a role in the patient’s script, but she plays a role in his. In that case, both of them are getting scripty responses from each other, and the result is the ‘chaotic situation’ which analysts speak of as making it impossible for the analysis to proceed to its proper goal.

最具诱惑力的女病人就是这方面最常见的例子。只要她能诱惑他，无论手段多么隐晦或精神层面，他都只是在扮演自己的角色，而无法治愈她。在这种情况下，她可能会为了取悦他、满足自己甚至帮助自己而做出各种“进步”，但他却无法让她“跳出”剧本，回归现实世界。这正是弗洛伊德所说的“分析性缄默”或“分析性挫败感”的合理基础。分析师通过保持独立于病人的种种举动之外，严格履行分析病人阻抗、本能变化以及必要时分析移情的职责，从而避免在生理、心理或道德上被病人诱惑。反移情意味着，不仅分析师在病人的剧本中扮演着角色，病人也在分析师的剧本中扮演着角色。在这种情况下，双方都得到了对方千篇一律的回应，结果就是分析人士所说的“混乱局面”，使得分析无法达到其应有的目标。

A simple way to avoid most of these difficulties is to ask the patient right at the beginning, when the contract has been set up, ‘Are you going to let me cure you?’

避免这些困难的简单方法就是在一开始就和病人签订合同时问他：“你愿意让我治好你吗？”

At the end of the line there is the therapist who has actual sexual relations with his patients, which may give both of them considerable script pleasure as well as sexual pleasure, but makes it impossible for either of them to benefit from the treatment. In between is the pernicious technique of the therapist telling the patient that she excites him sexually, on the grounds that this will make their ‘communication’ better. It certainly will, and if properly timed can prolong the treatment if it does not scare her away, but it is no help in getting her out of her script, since it is merely an admission on the part of the therapist that she fits into his life plan. In the commonest case, if the patient sits with her knees apart, the proper procedure is not to have a ‘frank discussion’ about the therapist’s sexual fantasies, but to tell her to pull her skirt down. With that come-on out of the way, the treatment can proceed on its useful course without being adulterated with a crude game of ‘Rapo.’ Similarly, if the patient sits with her hands clasped behind her head, thrusting her breasts out at the therapist, he can say ‘Amazing!’ or ‘Stupendous!’ and that will usually put things back in their proper perspective. If a homosexual man sits with his legs wide apart to exhibit his basket, the therapist can say: ‘Tremendous basket you’ve got there. Well, to get back to your diarrhea …’ etc. If the patient replies ‘Fuck you!’ the answer is ‘Not me. I’m here to cure you. What about the diarrhea?’

这条路的尽头是治疗师与患者发生实际性关系，这或许能给双方带来相当程度的剧本满足感和性快感，但却使双方都无法从治疗中获益。介于两者之间的是一种有害的技巧：治疗师告诉患者，她能激发他的性欲，理由是这样做能改善他们的“沟通”。这当然会改善沟通，如果时机把握得当，而且没有吓跑患者，甚至可以延长治疗时间，但这对帮助患者摆脱剧本束缚毫无帮助，因为这仅仅是治疗师承认患者符合他的生活计划。最常见的情况是，如果患者双膝分开坐着，正确的做法不是与治疗师坦诚地讨论他的性幻想，而是让她把裙子脱下来。排除了这种挑逗之后，治疗就可以顺利进行，不会被粗俗的“拉波”游戏所干扰。同样地，如果病人双手抱头，挺胸抬头对着治疗师，治疗师可以说“太棒了！”或“太赞了！”，这通常能让病人把事情摆正过来。如果一个男同性恋双腿大张着展示他的“宝贝”，治疗师可以说：“你的宝贝真棒。好了，说回你的腹泻……”等等。如果病人回答“去你的！”，治疗师的回答是“我不是来找茬的。我是来治你的。腹泻怎么办？”

E • Predicting the Outcome

E • 预测结果

The therapist’s first task is to find out what role he fits in the patient’s script, and what is supposed to happen between them. A good example is the patient whose script directive is ‘You can go to a psychiatrist as long as you don’t get cured, because you have to kill yourself in the end.’ The patient gets what fun he can out of this grim destiny by playing ‘Now He Tells Me.’ This game can usually be anticipated from the patient’s history, particularly if he has been to other therapists. The events leading up to the termination of previous therapy should be gone over in detail. When the therapist is sure of his ground, he can then use the antithesis previously described, which consists simply of giving a straight prediction of the outcome: ‘What you’re going to do is come here for six months or a year, and then at the end of a session you’re going to say “By the way, I won’t be back any more.” We can both save six months of our lives by breaking that up right now. Or if you’d rather go through with it, it’s all right with me, since I can always learn something by your coming here.’

治疗师的首要任务是弄清楚自己在患者的“剧本”中扮演什么角色，以及他们之间应该发生什么。一个很好的例子是，患者的“剧本”指令是“你可以去看精神科医生，只要你得不到治愈，因为你最终还是要自杀。” 患者会通过玩“现在他告诉我”的游戏来从这种悲观的命运中获得乐趣。这种游戏通常可以根据患者的既往经历来预测，尤其是在他接受过其他治疗师治疗的情况下。应该详细回顾导致之前治疗终止的事件。当治疗师确信自己的立场后，就可以使用前面提到的反义词，即直接预测结果：“你会来这里六个月或一年，然后在每次疗程结束时说‘对了，我不会再来了’。如果我们现在就结束这段关系，我们双方都可以节省六个月的时间。”或者，如果你还是想亲自来，我也没意见，因为你的到来总能让我学到一些东西。

This is much better than waiting until the patient does turn in his resignation, and then saying (somewhat prissily): ‘Perhaps you had better come in and talk it over before making such a serious decision,’ or something like that. By that time it is too late, and the therapist has already demonstrated his stupidity, so why should the patient continue to come to someone he can con so easily? The therapist’s job is to see it coming before it happens, and not to try to pick up the pieces afterward.

这比等到病人递交辞呈后，再（略显矫揉造作地）说：“或许你最好先来谈谈，再做这么重要的决定”之类的话要好得多。到那时就太晚了，治疗师已经暴露了自己的愚蠢，病人为什么还要继续找一个如此容易被他欺骗的人呢？治疗师的职责是在事情发生之前就预见到它的苗头，而不是事后试图收拾残局。

A simple way to avoid many of the difficulties mentioned in the last four sections is to ask the patient right at the beginning, as soon as the contract has been set up: ‘Are you going to let me help you find the cure?’

避免前四节中提到的许多困难的一个简单方法是，在合同签订之初就立即询问患者：“你愿意让我帮助你找到治疗方法吗？”

Briefly, there are three possible outcomes to therapy.

简而言之，治疗可能有三种结果。

1. The therapist can play out an act or scene in the patient’s script, after which the patient leaves, ‘not improved,’ ‘improved,’ or ‘much improved,’ as it is commonly stated on statistical tables. But in no such case will the patient be cured.

1. 治疗师可以按照患者的剧本进行表演，之后患者离开时，要么“没有改善”，要么“有所改善”，要么“明显改善”，就像统计表格上通常写的那样。但无论如何，患者都不会被治愈。

2. The patient may have an ‘until’ script: ‘You can’t succeed until you meet certain conditions.’ The commonest spellbreaker or internal cutout is the one discussed earlier: ‘—until you have lived to be older than your father (mother, brother, sister) was when he died.’ This is a ‘clock time’ release. Once the patient meets this condition, he has ‘permission’ to get well, so that, no matter how many unavailing therapists he has been to previously, the fortunate one who takes him on at this time will be able to chalk up a success (unless he makes an outright error). Since the patient is now ‘ready for therapy’ and ‘ready to get well,’ almost any reasonably competent and discreet therapist can cure him. Similarly, when Sleeping Beauty was ‘ready’ to wake up, almost any prince would do, since this release was built into her script. The ‘until’ script with a ‘goal time’ release may be more of a challenge. E.g., ‘You can’t get well until you meet a therapist who can outwit you (or who is smarter than I, your father).’ Here the therapist may have to answer a riddle (‘You’re supposed to guess that.’) or perform some other magic task. The patient may run through many therapists before she finds one who knows the key. The therapist is then in the position of the prince who must guess the riddle or perform the task that wins the princess, or lose his head. If he does find the secret, the patient is delivered from the power of her father’s (or her witch mother’s) spell. This means that she is then permitted to get well, and will, because that spellbreaker is built into the script just as it is built into the fairy tale.

2. 患者可能存在一种“直到”脚本：“你必须满足某些条件才能成功。”最常见的破除障碍或内在限制是前面讨论过的：“——直到你的年龄超过你父亲（母亲、兄弟、姐妹）去世时的年龄。”这是一种“时间限制”式的释放机制。一旦患者满足了这个条件，他就“被允许”康复，因此，无论他之前看过多少无效的治疗师，此时接手他的幸运儿都能取得成功（除非他犯了明显的错误）。由于患者现在“准备好接受治疗”并且“准备好康复”，几乎任何一位称职且谨慎的治疗师都能治愈他。同样，当睡美人“准备好”醒来时，几乎任何王子都能做到，因为这种释放机制已经内置在她的脚本中。带有“目标时间”释放机制的“直到”脚本可能更具挑战性。例如，“你只有遇到一个能智胜你（或者比我，你父亲，更聪明）的治疗师，才能康复。”这里，治疗师可能需要回答一个谜语（“你应该能猜到。”）或完成一些其他的魔法任务。病人可能要辗转于许多治疗师之间，才能找到一个知道关键所在的人。此时，治疗师就如同王子一般，必须猜出谜语或完成任务才能赢得公主的芳心，否则就会丢掉性命。如果他找到了秘密，病人就能摆脱父亲（或她那巫婆母亲）的魔法控制。这意味着她可以康复，而且也一定会康复，因为破除魔法的机制早已被设定在剧本中，就像童话故事本身一样。

3. The third case is where the script decrees that the patient must never get well, but the therapist manages to overthrow this curse. This takes enormous potency and skill on his part. He must win the complete trust of the patient’s Child, since success depends entirely upon the Child having more confidence in him than in the original parent who dictated the script. In addition, he must have a sound knowledge of script antitheses or cutoffs, and how and when to apply them.

3. 第三种情况是，剧本规定病人永远无法康复，但治疗师设法打破了这个诅咒。这需要治疗师拥有极强的能力和技巧。他必须赢得病人内心深处孩子的完全信任，因为成功完全取决于孩子对他的信任程度是否超过对制定剧本的父母的信任。此外，他还必须精通剧本中的对立句或截断句，以及如何和何时运用它们。

The difference between the spellbreaker (the internal release or cutout) and the script antithesis (the external release or cutoff) can be illustrated as follows. Sleeping Beauty was condemned to sleep for a hundred years, after which, providing a prince kissed her, (apparently) she could resume her life. The prince kissing her was the internal release or cutout: the remedy written into the script to lift the curse. If a prince had come along after only twenty years and said: ‘You really don’t have to lie there,’ that would be a script antithesis or cutoff (if it worked): something from outside, not provided for in the script, which can break it up.

咒语解除器（内部释放或切断）与剧本对立面（外部释放或切断）之间的区别可以举例说明。睡美人被诅咒沉睡一百年，之后，只要有王子吻她，（表面上）她就能恢复生命。王子吻她就是内部释放或切断：剧本中写明的解除诅咒的办法。如果仅仅过了二十年，王子出现并对她说：“你真的不必躺在那里”，那么这就是剧本对立面或切断（如果有效的话）：来自外部、剧本中没有规定的事物，可以打破诅咒。

F • The Script Antithesis

F • 脚本对立

All that has been said up to now is merely a preparation for answering the question ‘What can be done about it?’ Psychiatric treatment boils down to three main ingredients: (1) ‘Being there;’ (2) ‘Handy household hints;’ and (3) ‘Flipping in.’

到目前为止所说的一切都只是为了回答“对此可以做些什么？”这个问题做准备。精神治疗归根结底包含三个主要要素：（1）“陪伴”；（2）“实用的家庭小贴士”；以及（3）“积极参与”。

‘Being there’ means that the patient knows there is somewhere he can go, someone he can talk to, someone he can play his games with to cover up his anxieties and relieve his depressions, and someone who will encourage him, forgive him, prescribe penances, or feed him cookies – all of these being a kind of priestly function which is of value mainly to a lonely Child. Patients who lacked an effective parent in early life, patients whose mothers or fathers died before they were ten, five, or two, or who were deserted, ignored, or cast out, must have the vacuum filled by someone who will ‘be there’ before any other kind of treatment will be effective.

“陪伴”意味着病人知道他有地方可去，有人可以倾诉，有人可以陪他玩游戏来掩饰焦虑、缓解抑郁，有人会鼓励他、原谅他、为他制定惩罚措施，或者给他饼干——所有这些都具有某种神圣的象征意义，尤其对孤独的孩子而言。那些在幼年时期缺乏有效父母关爱的病人，那些父母在他们十岁、五岁甚至两岁之前就去世的病人，或者那些被遗弃、忽视或赶出家门的病人，必须先有人“陪伴”填补他们内心的空缺，其他任何治疗才能奏效。

‘Handy household hints’ is advice given by the therapist, telling the patient how to be happy or less miserable in his script world. ‘Hold on tighter.’ ‘Don’t give your grandmother’s address to a wolf.’ ‘Get her telephone number before midnight.’ ‘Don’t take candy from strangers.’ Such hints are of value mainly to the confused schizoid Child, Little Red Riding Hood, Cinderella’s Prince, Hansel and Gretel.

“实用生活小贴士”是治疗师给出的建议，告诉患者如何在他的虚构世界里感到快乐或不那么痛苦。“抓紧了。”“别把奶奶的地址告诉狼。”“午夜前拿到她的电话号码。”“别接受陌生人的糖果。”这类建议主要对精神分裂症患者——比如小红帽、灰姑娘的王子、汉塞尔和格蕾特——有用。

‘Flipping in’ means getting the patient out of his script and into the real world. In its most elegant form, it requires the therapist to think of the one single intervention which will do the most to break up the script: the most effective script antithesis. The following case history will illustrate the kind of probing, intuition, and professional confidence required to accomplish this.

“翻转入场”是指引导患者跳出固有的思维模式，回归真实世界。最精妙的做法是，治疗师需要思考一种能够最大程度打破固有思维模式的干预措施：即最有效的思维模式对立面。以下案例将阐述实现这一目标所需的探究能力、直觉和专业自信。

AMBER

琥珀色

Amber McArgo came a very long distance to see Dr Q, whom she had heard of from some friends. Back in her native city of Bryneira, she had gone to three different ‘psychoanalysts’ who had been unable to help her. Dr Q knew that these people were not really psychoanalysts, but were among the poorer therapists in Bryneira, who had confused her, one after the other, by using long words like ‘identification,’ ‘dependence,’ ‘masochism,’ etc. She told Dr Q that she would have to fly back home that same night to take care of her children, so that he had the interesting challenge of trying to cure her in one visit.

安珀·麦卡戈远道而来拜访Q医生，她是从朋友那里听说过他的。在她的家乡布吕内拉，她曾看过三位不同的“精神分析师”，但他们都无能为力。Q医生知道这些人并非真正的精神分析师，而是布吕内拉一些水平不高的治疗师，他们一个接一个地用“认同”、“依赖”、“受虐倾向”等晦涩难懂的词汇让她感到困惑。她告诉Q医生，她当晚就要飞回家照顾孩子，所以他面临着一个有趣的挑战：如何在一次就诊中治愈她。

She had complained of apprehensiveness, palpitation, insomnia, depression, and inability to get her work done. She had had no sexual desire and no sexual intercourse for the past three years. Her symptoms had begun when her father was found to have diabetes. After taking a psychiatric and medical history, Dr Q encouraged her to talk more about her father. At the end of forty minutes, it appeared to him that the purpose of her illness was to keep her father alive. As long as she was sick, he had a chance to survive. If she got better, he would die. In fact, this was only her Child’s script illusion, since the diabetes was mild and well controlled, and he was in no danger of dying, but she preferred to think that she had the sole power to keep him alive.

她抱怨自己焦虑不安、心悸、失眠、抑郁，而且无法完成工作。过去三年，她一直没有性欲，也没有性生活。她的症状始于父亲被诊断出患有糖尿病之后。在了解了她的精神病史和既往病史后，Q医生鼓励她多谈谈她的父亲。四十分钟后，Q医生认为她生病的目的是为了让她的父亲活下去。只要她生病，她的父亲就有机会活下去。如果她好转，她的父亲就会死去。事实上，这只是她“儿童剧本”式的错觉，因为父亲的糖尿病病情轻微且控制良好，根本没有生命危险，但她宁愿相信自己拥有让父亲活下去的唯一力量。

The Parental precepts were: ‘Be a good girl. We live only for you.’ Her father’s injunction appeared to be ‘Don’t stay healthy, or you’ll kill me!’ but Dr Q decided that there was something more to it. Her ‘nervous’ mother had given her an example of how to be sick, and that was the pattern she was following.

父母的训诫是：“做个乖女孩。我们活着都是为了你。”她父亲的告诫似乎是“别生病，不然你会害死我的！”但Q医生认为其中另有隐情。她那“神经兮兮”的母亲给她树立了生病的榜样，而她正是在效仿这种模式。

Dr Q now had to find out whether she had something to replace her script with if she gave it up. Everything hinged on that. If he attacked the script and she had nothing to put in its place, she might get worse. It appeared that she had a rather solid counterscript based on the precept ‘Be a good girl,’ which at this point in her life meant ‘Be a good wife and mother.’

Q医生现在必须弄清楚，如果她放弃那套说辞，是否有其他东西可以替代。一切都取决于此。如果他攻击她的说辞，而她又没有其他东西可以替代，她的情况可能会恶化。看来她有一套相当稳固的反制说辞，其核心是“做一个好女孩”，在她人生的这个阶段，这意味着“做一个好妻子和好母亲”。

‘What would happen if your father did die?’ he asked.

“如果你的父亲去世了，会发生什么？”他问道。

‘Then I’d get worse,’ replied Amber.

“那我的情况会更糟，”安珀回答道。

This indicated that her script was not an ‘until’ script, but a tragic one, which in this case made Dr Q’s task easier. If her instructions had been ‘Stay sick until your father dies!’ she might have chosen to do that rather than risk the consequences of getting better, which in her Child’s mind might cause his death. But evidently the script actually read: ‘You have made your father sick, so you must get sick also to keep him alive. If he dies, you must suffer the consequences.’ This gave Amber a much more clear-cut decision to make: ‘Either get better now, or continue to suffer now and suffer more later until your own death!’

这表明她的剧本并非“直到”剧本，而是一个悲剧剧本，这使得Q医生的任务变得更容易。如果她的指示是“一直生病直到你父亲去世！”，她或许会选择这样做，而不是冒着康复的后果——在她孩子看来，康复可能会导致父亲的死亡。但显然，剧本的真正内容是：“你让你的父亲生病了，所以你也必须生病才能让他活下去。如果他死了，你必须承担后果。”这让安珀面临着一个更加明确的选择：“要么现在就康复，要么继续受苦，以后还要承受更多痛苦直到死亡！”

With the way now prepared, Dr Q said:

Q博士说，一切准备就绪后：

‘It sounds to me as though you’re staying sick to save your father’s life.’

“听起来你好像是为了救你父亲的命才故意装病。”

This statement was carefully worded and timed so as to reach her Parent, Adult, and Child simultaneously. Both her Mother Parent and her Father Parent could not help but be pleased that she was such a ‘good girl’ as to suffer for her father’s sake. The Child in her Father would be additionally gratified that she was following his instructions to get sick (evidently he liked nervous women, since he had married one). The Adult in her Mother would be pleased that Amber had learned her lesson well and knew how to be a good invalid. How the Child in her Mother would react Dr Q had no way of knowing, but he would watch out for that. So much for the different parts of Amber’s Parent. Amber’s own Adult, he thought, would agree, since his diagnosis was probably correct. Amber’s Child would also be agreeable, because he was in effect telling her that she was a ‘good girl’ and was obeying all the instructions of both her parents. The test would be in her reply. If she said ‘Yes, but …’ there was going to be trouble, but if she accepted his diagnosis with no ‘ifs’ or ‘buts,’ things might turn out well.

这段话措辞谨慎，时机也经过精心安排，旨在同时触动她内心的父母、成人和孩童。她的母亲和父亲都会为她如此“乖巧”，为了父亲而受苦而感到欣慰。父亲内心的孩童会更加高兴，因为她听从了他的指示去生病（显然他喜欢神经质的女人，因为他娶了一位）。母亲内心的成人会欣慰地看到安珀吸取了教训，懂得如何做一个好病人。至于母亲内心的孩童会作何反应，Q医生无从知晓，但他会密切关注。以上便是安珀内心父母的不同面向。他想，安珀自身的成人面向也会同意，因为他的诊断很可能是正确的。安珀内心的孩童也会赞同，因为他实际上是在告诉她，她是个“好女孩”，并且听从了父母双方的所有指示。最终的考验将在于她的回应。如果她说“是的，但是……”，那就会有麻烦；但如果她毫无保留地接受他的诊断，事情或许会朝着好的方向发展。

‘H’m!’ said Amber. ‘I think you’re right.’

“嗯！”安珀说，“我想你是对的。”

With this answer, Dr Q now felt free to proceed with the antithesis to the script, which meant getting Amber to ‘divorce’ her father. The watchwords here were the three ‘Ps’ of script antithesis: potency, permission, and protection.

有了这个答案，Q博士终于可以自由地进行与剧本截然相反的计划了，也就是让安珀与她父亲“离婚”。这里的关键词是剧本反面的三个“P”：效力（Potency）、许可（Legend）和保护（Protection）。

1. Potency. Was he powerful enough to prevail at least temporarily over her father? There were two things in his favor there. First, she actually did seem tired of being sick. Perhaps she had gone to her other therapists to play games or to learn how to live more comfortably with her symptoms, but the fact that she had planned such a long journey to see Dr Q indicated that perhaps she was really ready to flip in and get well. Secondly, since she had actually made the trip (rather than saying she was much too fearful to do it), that probably meant that her Child had a high regard for his magical potency as a curer. fn1

1. 效力。他的力量是否强大到足以至少暂时战胜她的父亲？在这方面，他有两点优势。首先，她似乎真的厌倦了生病。或许她去其他治疗师那里只是为了玩游戏，或者学习如何更舒适地与症状共处，但她特意安排了这么远的旅程去看Q医生，这表明她或许真的准备好振作起来，彻底康复了。其次，既然她真的去了（而不是说她太害怕而不敢去），这可能意味着她的孩子非常信任他作为治愈者的魔法效力。

2. Permission. He had to word the permission very carefully. Like the pronouncements of the oracle at Delphi, his words would be twisted to her own needs. If she could find exceptions, she would, since, as already noted, under such conditions the Child behaves like a smart lawyer looking for loopholes in a contract.

2. 许可。他必须非常谨慎地措辞。就像德尔斐神谕的预言一样，他的话会被她曲解，以满足她自己的需要。如果她能找到例外，她一定会这么做，因为正如前面提到的，在这种情况下，孩子就像一个精明的律师，会寻找合同中的漏洞。

3. Protection. This was the most serious problem in the present situation. Because Amber was leaving immediately after the interview, she could not return to Dr Q for protection if she disobeyed the injunction to be sick. Her Child would be exposed to her Parent’s wrath with no one to reassure her in her panic. The telephone might help, but not very much after seeing him in person only once.

3. 保护。这是目前情况下最严重的问题。由于安珀在面谈结束后立即离开，如果她不听劝告生病，就无法回到Q医生那里寻求保护。她的孩子将独自承受父母的怒火，而无人能在她惊慌失措时安抚她。电话或许能起到一些作用，但毕竟只见过他一次，作用有限。

Dr Q proceeded as follows. First he hooked Amber’s Adult.

Q博士的操作步骤如下。首先，他用钩子钩住了Amber的成鱼。

‘Do you really think you can save him by getting sick yourself?’ he asked.

“你真的认为你让自己生病就能救他吗？”他问道。

To which Amber’s Adult could only reply: ‘I guess not.’

对此，安珀的成年版只能回答：“我想不是吧。”

‘Is he in danger of dying?’

“他有生命危险吗？”

‘Not in the near future, according to what his doctors tell me.’

“据他的医生说，近期内不会有这样的机会。”

‘But you’re under some sort of curse that requires you to get sick and stay sick in order to save his life, and that’s what you’re doing.’

“但是你中了某种诅咒，必须生病并一直生病才能救他的命，而你现在正在做的就是这个。”

‘I think you’re right.’

“我觉得你说得对。”

‘Then what you need is permission to get well.’ He looked at Amber and she nodded.

“那么你需要的是允许自己康复。”他看着安珀，她点了点头。

‘Then you have my permission to get well.’

“那么，你可以安心养病了。”

‘I’ll try.’

'我会尽力。'

‘Trying won’t do it. You have to decide. Either divorce your father and let him go his own way and you go yours, or don’t divorce him and leave things as they are. Which do you want to do?’

“光靠尝试是行不通的。你必须做出决定。要么和父亲离婚，让他走自己的路，你也走自己的路；要么不离婚，维持现状。你想怎么做？”

There was a long silence. Finally she said:

一阵漫长的沉默后，她终于开口说道：

‘I’ll divorce him. I’ll get well. You’re sure I have your permission?’

“我会和他离婚。我会好起来的。你确定我得到了你的许可吗？”

‘Yes, you do.’

“是的，你的确如此。”

Then he had another idea. He invited her to stay over after lunch and come to a group meeting, to which she agreed.

然后他又有了另一个主意。他邀请她午饭后留下来参加一个小组会议，她同意了。

As the interview terminated, he looked her in the eyes and said: ‘Your father won’t die if you get well,’ to which she made no reply.

采访结束时，他看着她的眼睛说：“如果你康复了，你父亲就不会死。”她没有回答。

Two hours later, Dr Q explained to his group that Amber had come a long distance to see him and had to leave that evening. He asked if they would agree to having her attend the group meeting, which they did. She fitted in well because she had read a book about transactional analysis and understood what they meant when they talked about Parent, Adult, Child, games, and scripts. After she told her story, they quickly got the point, as Dr Q had.

两小时后，Q博士向小组解释说，Amber远道而来见他，当晚就要离开。他询问大家是否同意她参加小组会议，大家同意了。她很快就融入了小组，因为她读过一本关于人际沟通分析的书，理解了他们所说的“父母”、“成人”、“儿童”、“游戏”和“脚本”等概念。在她讲述了自己的经历后，大家很快就明白了Q博士的意思。

‘You’re staying sick in order to keep your father from dying,’ said one of them.

“你故意装病是为了不让你父亲死，”其中一人说道。

‘What’s your husband like?’ asked another.

“你丈夫是什么样的人？”另一个人问道。

‘He’s like the Rock of Gibraltar,’ replied Amber.

“他就像直布罗陀巨岩一样坚不可摧，”安珀回答道。

‘So you came all the way out here to consult the Great Pyramid,’ said a third, meaning Dr Q.

“所以你千里迢迢来到这里是为了咨询大金字塔吗？”第三个人说道，指的是Q博士。

‘He’s not the Great Pyramid,’ objected Amber.

“他又不是大金字塔，”安珀反驳道。

‘He is to your Child,’ said someone, and she had no reply to that.

“他是你孩子的，”有人说道，她对此无言以对。

Dr Q said nothing, and just listened. As the discussion proceeded, someone asked:

Q博士一言不发，只是静静地听着。讨论进行中，有人问道：

‘Have you given her permission to get well?’

“你允许她康复了吗？”

Dr Q nodded.

Q博士点了点头。

‘Why don’t you give it to her in writing, if she’s leaving?’

“如果她要离开，为什么不把这件事写下来给她呢？”

‘Maybe I will,’ he said.

“也许我会吧，”他说。

Finally he heard what he had been waiting for. When they asked her about her sex life, Amber volunteered that she had had frequent sexual dreams about her father. As the meeting drew to a close, Dr Q wrote out the permission, which read:

他终于听到了他一直期待的消息。当他们问及她的性生活时，安珀主动透露她经常梦到和父亲发生性关系。会议临近结束时，Q医生写下了许可书，内容如下：

‘Stop having sex with your father.

“停止和你父亲发生性关系。”

‘Amber has permission to have sex with other men besides her father. Amber has permission to get well and stay well.’

“安珀有权与父亲以外的其他男人发生性关系。安珀有权康复并保持健康。”

‘What do you think he means?’ asked someone.

“你觉得他是什么意思？”有人问道。

‘I’m not sure. Does he mean I should have an affair?’

“我不确定。他的意思是说我应该出轨吗？”

‘No, he doesn’t. He means you have permission to have sex with your husband.’

“不，他不是这个意思。他的意思是，你有权和你的丈夫发生性关系。”

‘Oh. One of the other doctors said I should have an affair. It scared me.’

“哦。另一位医生说我应该出轨。这吓到我了。”

‘That’s not what Dr Q means.’

“Q博士的意思并非如此。”

She put the paper in her purse, and then someone got suspicious.

她把纸条放进钱包里，然后有人起了疑心。

‘What are you going to do with that paper?’

“你打算怎么处理那张纸？”

‘She’s going to show it to her friends, I bet.’

“我敢打赌，她肯定会拿给朋友们看。”

Amber smiled. ‘That’s right.’

艾梅柏笑了。“没错。”

‘A written message from the Great Pyramid, eh? That’ll make you famous at home.’

“来自大金字塔的亲笔信？那你肯定会在家乡出名。”

‘You won’t get better if you show it to your friends. That’s a game!’ said another.

“如果你把视频给朋友看，你就不会进步。那只是一场游戏！”另一个人说道。

‘I think they’re right,’ said Dr Q. ‘Maybe you shouldn’t have it in writing.’

“我觉得他们是对的，”Q博士说，“也许你不应该把它写下来。”

‘You mean you want it back?’

你是说你想把它要回来？

Dr Q nodded, and she handed it back to him. ‘Do you want me to read it out loud to you?’ he asked.

Q博士点点头，把纸条递还给他。“你想让我大声读给你听吗？”他问道。

‘I can remember.’

“我记得。”

Dr Q did give her something in writing, which were the names of two real psychoanalysts in Bryneira. He was sorry there were no transactional analysts there. ‘When you get home, go and see one of these men,’ he advised her.

Q医生确实给了她一些书面材料，上面列着布赖尼拉两位真正的精神分析师的名字。他很遗憾那里没有交互分析师。“你回家后，去找其中一位看看，”他建议道。

A couple of weeks later he got a letter from her.

几周后，他收到了她的来信。

‘I want to thank everybody for giving me their time. When I left, I felt 99% cured. Things went well, and I had overcome some major problems. I felt I could solve the others by myself. My father no longer had the same hold over me, and I no longer feared his death. My sex life was back to normal for the first time in three years. I looked well and felt well. I had a few low periods, but I recovered very quickly. Then I decided to see Dr X as you advised me.’

“我想感谢大家抽出时间帮助我。离开的时候，我觉得自己已经痊愈了99%。一切都很顺利，我克服了一些重大问题。我觉得剩下的问题我自己也能解决。父亲不再像以前那样控制我，我也不再害怕他的离世。三年来，我的性生活第一次恢复了正常。我气色很好，感觉也很好。期间有过几次情绪低落的时候，但我很快就恢复了。然后，我决定按照您的建议去看X医生。”

This story is offered as an example of how a script analyst thinks. The results were quite satisfactory for a single interview and a single group meeting, since the patient took advantage of the specific permission that was offered to her, and got whatever advantages she could out of that.

这个故事旨在说明剧本分析师的思考方式。由于患者充分利用了事先获得的许可，并从中获取了尽可能多的益处，因此，仅凭一次面谈和一次小组会议，结果就相当令人满意。

G • The Cure

G • The Cure

It is evident that Amber was not permanently cured. Nevertheless, the script antithesis offered to her did have a well-defined therapeutic effect and is likely to be of some permanent benefit. But however gratifying, these are only by-products. The real aim of the script antithesis is to gain time so that the patient can dig further into his script apparatus with the object of changing his original script decision. Thus the patient with a Parental voice urging ‘Kill yourself,’ and a discouraged Child replying ‘Yes, mother,’ is told ‘Don’t do it!’ This simple antithesis is given in such a way that the therapist’s voice will be heard at the critical moment in opposition to the suicidal provocation, so that the patient may be held back on the very brink of death. The reprieve so gained is put to good advantage in the treatment. Pat is there because of the script decision he made in childhood, and he has now borrowed enough time to rescind that by making another, different decision.

显然，安珀并没有被彻底治愈。然而，提供给她的脚本对立疗法确实产生了明确的治疗效果，并且很可能带来一些长期的益处。但是，无论多么令人欣慰，这些都只是副产品。脚本对立疗法的真正目的是争取时间，以便患者能够更深入地挖掘其脚本机制，从而改变其最初的脚本决定。例如，当患者听到父母的声音催促“去死吧”，而沮丧的孩童回答“好的，妈妈”时，治疗师会告诉患者“别这么做！”。这种简单的对立疗法旨在让治疗师的声音在关键时刻与自杀的挑衅形成对比，从而在患者濒临死亡的边缘将其拉回现实。由此获得的喘息之机在治疗中得到了充分利用。帕特之所以来到这里，是因为他童年时期做出的脚本决定，而现在他已经获得了足够的时间，可以通过做出另一个不同的决定来撤销这个决定。

As he cuts loose from his Parental programing, his Child becomes more and more free. At a certain point, with the help of the therapist and his own Adult, he is capable of breaking out of his script entirely and putting his own show on the road, with new characters, new roles, and a new plot and payoff. Such a script cure, which changes his character and his destiny, is also a clinical cure, since most of his symptoms will be relieved by his redecision. This can happen quite suddenly, so that the patient ‘flips in’ right before the eyes of the therapist and the other group members. He is no longer a sick person or a patient, but a well person with some disabilities and weaknesses which he can now deal with objectively.

当他摆脱父母的束缚时，他内心的“孩子”会变得越来越自由。在治疗师和他内心“成人”的帮助下，他最终能够彻底挣脱束缚，开启属于自己的人生篇章，塑造新的角色，构思新的情节，并最终获得新的回报。这种改变他性格和命运的“剧本疗法”，同时也是一种临床疗法，因为他的重新抉择能够缓解大部分症状。这种转变可能非常突然，患者会在治疗师和其他组员的注视下“彻底转变”。他不再是病人，而是一个拥有健康体魄的人，只是存在一些缺陷和弱点，但他现在可以客观地去面对它们。

This is analagous to what happens after a successful abdominal operation. For the first few days, the patient is a sick person who is making progress, walking a little farther each day, and sitting up a little longer. Then on the fifth or sixth day or so, he wakes up in quite a different capacity. He is now a well person with some bothersome disabilities: weakness and a sore belly perhaps. But he is no longer content merely to make progress. He wants to get out, and his disabilities are no longer crippling, but merely bothersome afflictions that he wants to get rid of as quickly as possible so that he can resume his life in the great world outside. And all this happens overnight, in a single dialectical switch. That is the way it is with ‘flipping in’ in script analysis: one day a patient, and the next a real person raring to go.

这类似于一次成功的腹部手术后的情况。最初几天，病人虽然身体虚弱，但每天都在进步，每天能走得更远，坐得更久。到了第五六天左右，他醒来时的状态截然不同。他现在是一个健康的人，只是有些恼人的后遗症：比如虚弱和腹痛。但他不再满足于仅仅取得进步。他渴望走出病房，这些后遗症不再是致命的，而只是些恼人的不适，他想尽快摆脱它们，重新融入外面的世界。这一切都发生在一夜之间，就像一个辩证的开关。剧本分析中的“转变”也是如此：前一天还是个病人，第二天就变成了一个跃跃欲试、渴望行动的活生生的人。

Nan lived at home with her parents. Her father was a professional patient who was paid a monthly salary by a government agency for being depressed. She was raised to follow in his footsteps, but when she got to be eighteen, she was tired of missing all the fun. She made progress in the group for about six months until one day she decided to get well.

楠和父母住在一起。她的父亲是一名职业病人，因为患有抑郁症而从政府机构领取月薪。楠从小就被培养成父亲那样的人，但到了十八岁，她厌倦了错过所有乐趣。她在互助小组里坚持了大约六个月，直到有一天，她下定决心要康复。

‘How do I get well?’ she asked.

她问：“我该如何康复？”

‘Mind your own business,’ replied the therapist.

“管好你自己的事，”治疗师回答道。

The following week she came back dressed differently and in quite a different frame of mind. It was a struggle for her to take care of her own emotional business instead of her father’s, but she learned to do it better and better. Instead of getting sick when he did, she let him get sick by himself. She also cut out her mother’s programing, which in summary read: ‘Life is a struggle, stay home with Dad.’ She made a whole new set of autonomous decisions. She took off her ‘daughter of a schizophrenic’ fn2 uniform and began to dress like a woman. She went back to college, had lots of dates, and was elected Queen of the student body. All that remained to tell her was ‘It isn’t true that your life is a struggle unless you make it so. Stop struggling and start living.’ She succeeded in doing that, too. fn3

接下来的一周，她回来了，穿着打扮和心态都截然不同。她很难不再像以前那样照顾父亲的情绪，而是专注于自己的情感问题，但她逐渐学会了更好地处理。父亲生病时，她不再跟着生病，而是让他独自承受。她也摆脱了母亲的“洗脑”，母亲的“洗脑”简而言之就是：“生活很艰难，待在家里陪爸爸。”她做出了一系列全新的自主决定。她脱下了“精神分裂症患者的女儿”的标签，开始像个女人一样打扮自己。她重返大学校园，约会不断，还当选为学生会主席。她终于明白：“除非你自己让它变得艰难，否则你的生活并非真的艰难。停止挣扎，开始生活。”她也成功地做到了这一点。

References

参考

1 Lorand, S. Technique of Psychoanalytic Therapy . International Universities Press, New York, 1947.

1 Lorand, S. 精神分析疗法技术。国际大学出版社，纽约，1947 年。

2 Steiner, C. M. Games Alcoholics Play. Loc. cit .

2 Steiner, C. M. Games Alcoholics Play. 同上。

3 Dusay, J. M. ‘Response in Therapy.’ Transactional Analysis Bulletin , 5: 136–37, April, 1966.

3 Dusay, J. M. ‘治疗中的反应’。《人际沟通分析公报》，5：136–37，1966 年 4 月。

fn1 A doctor’s duty is to exploit every possible means for the patient’s cure. Or, stated in practical terms: ‘The patient’s health is more important than what the pursed lips will say at the staff conference.’

fn1 医生的职责是竭尽所能治愈病人。或者，用更实际的话来说：“病人的健康比医务人员会议上那些抿着嘴说的话更重要。”

fn2 I don’t know enough about women’s clothes to describe this accurately, but I know it when I see it. It is a kind of negating of the body, where the ‘I am a schizophrenic’ uniform makes a caricature of the body.

fn2 我对女装了解不多，无法准确描述这种现象，但我一眼就能认出来。这是一种对身体的否定，那种“我是精神分裂症患者”的装束反而成了对身体的一种讽刺。

fn3 This was not an accident, since another patient in the same group flipped in on the same day and made much the same sort of redecisions. Both of these women could easily have become chronic patients, whose main contribution to humanity through the years might have been thick, complicated charts in the clinic file.

fn3 这并非偶然，因为同一天，同一组患者中的另一位也改变了主意，做出了类似的决定。这两位女性原本都可能成为长期病人，她们多年来对人类的主要贡献或许就是诊所档案里厚厚的、复杂的病历记录。

#↩

CHAPTER NINETEEN

第十九章

The Decisive Intervention

决定性干预

A • Final Common Pathways

A • 最终共同路径

What happens in the patient’s head is unknown to the therapist unless it is expressed in some outward sound or movement. Each ego state, in principle, finds its own final pathway for such outward expression. In the classical example, Bridy is asked: ‘How is your marriage?’ and replies pompously: ‘My ma-ridge; is perf-ict.’ As she says this, she takes hold of her wedding ring with the thumb and forefinger of her right hand and simultaneously crosses her legs and begins to swing her right foot. Someone then asks: ‘That’s what you say, but what is your foot saying?’ upon which Bridy looks down at her foot in surprise. Another member of the group then inquires: ‘And what was your right hand saying to your wedding ring?’ whereupon Bridy begins to weep and ends up telling them that her husband drinks and beats her.

除非患者将内心的想法表达出来，例如发出声音或做出动作，否则治疗师无法得知。原则上，每一种自我状态都会找到其自身最终的表达途径。在一个经典的例子中，有人问布里迪：“你的婚姻怎么样？”她傲慢地回答：“我的婚姻完美无瑕。”说着，她用右手的拇指和食指握住结婚戒指，同时翘起二郎腿，开始摆动右脚。这时有人问：“你嘴上这么说，但你的脚在说什么呢？”布里迪惊讶地低头看向自己的脚。另一位成员接着问：“那你的右手对你的结婚戒指说了什么呢？”布里迪顿时泣不成声，最后告诉他们，她的丈夫酗酒并殴打她。

When Bridy becomes more sophisticated in transactional analysis, she is able to tell them the origin of her three replies to the question. The sentence ‘My marriage is perfect’ was said or dictated by a pompous, unyielding Mother Parent, who took over Bridy’s talking apparatus as a final common pathway. Her right hand was taken over by her Adult to verify that she was really and possibly permanently married to a scoundrel. Her legs were crossed by her Child, to keep him out, and she then offered him a few tentative kicks. The use of the passive voice in this paragraph signifies that the various parts of her body were merely instruments at the service of her ego states for final common pathways.

当布里迪在人际沟通分析中变得更加成熟时，她能够告诉他们她对那个问题的三个回答的由来。“我的婚姻很完美”这句话是由一个傲慢自大、固执己见的“母亲父母”说的，或者说是她口述的，这个“母亲父母”控制了布里迪的说话机制，作为最终的共同路径。她的右手被“成人”控制，以确认她确实可能永远嫁给了一个无赖。她的双腿被“孩子”控制，以阻止他靠近，然后她试探性地踢了他几脚。这段话中使用被动语态表明，她身体的各个部分仅仅是服务于她自我状态的工具，作为最终的共同路径。

There are three principal ways in which the final common pathway is selected: by dissociation, by exclusion, or by integration. If the ego states are dissociated from each other and do not ‘communicate,’ then each will find its own pathway for expression, independently of the others, so that each one is ‘unconscious’ of what the others are doing. Thus, Bridy’s talking Parent was not aware of her fingering Adult or her kicking Child, nor were the other two aware of each other. This reflects the situation as it was in real life. As a child, Bridy could not speak freely to her parents, and had to do things behind their backs. If she was caught, she tried to evade taking responsibility for her actions by claiming that she (her Adult) didn’t know what she (her Child) was doing. Clinically, this is a hysterical situation, where the Child can do all sorts of complex things while the Adult disclaims knowledge of them, and the Parent is out of it.

最终共同路径的选择主要有三种方式：分离、排斥或整合。如果自我状态彼此分离且不“沟通”，那么每个自我状态都会找到自己的表达路径，彼此独立，因此每个自我状态都“无意识”地了解其他自我状态的行为。因此，布里迪的“会说话的父母”意识不到她抚摸成人或踢踹儿童的行为，而其他两个自我状态彼此也意识不到。这反映了现实生活中的情况。布里迪小时候无法与父母自由交流，只能背着他们做事。如果被发现，她会试图逃避责任，声称她（她的成人）不知道她（她的儿童）在做什么。从临床角度来看，这是一种癔症状态，儿童可以做出各种复杂的行为，而成人则否认知情，父母则完全置身事外。

Exclusion means that one ego state is much more highly ‘cathected’ than the others, and takes over at will regardless of their strivings. In groups, this is most dramatically seen in religious or political fanatics, where the excluding Parent takes over all the pathways of expression (except for an occasional ‘unconscious’ lapse), and rides roughshod over the Child and Adult as well as all the other members of the group. This also occurs in a milder degree in compensated schizophrenics, where the Parent takes over and excludes the ‘bad’ or unreliable Child, and the ineffectual, poorly ‘cathected’ Adult as well, in order to keep out of the hospital or the shock-treatment room. This again reflects the actual childhood situation, where the child was left to his own devices and self-development, providing he did not dare to take the initiative when the parents were around.

排斥意味着某个自我状态比其他自我状态更受“情感寄生”（cathected），并随意占据主导地位，全然不顾其他自我状态的努力。在群体中，这种现象在宗教或政治狂热分子身上表现得最为显著，排斥型的“父母”状态掌控了所有表达途径（除了偶尔的“无意识”失误），并肆意践踏“儿童”状态、“成人”状态以及群体中的所有其他成员。在代偿性精神分裂症患者中，这种现象也有轻微的体现，他们的“父母”状态会接管并排斥“坏的”或不可靠的“儿童”状态，以及无能的、情感寄生较弱的“成人”状态，以避免被送进医院或电击治疗室。这再次反映了真实的童年情境：孩子被放任自流，任其自我发展，前提是他不敢在父母在场时主动行事。

A ‘normal’ type of exclusion occurs in well-organized personalities, where one ego state takes over with the consent of the others. The Child and the Parent, for example, let the Adult take over during working hours. In return for this cooperation, the Child is allowed to take over at parties, and the Parent at other appropriate times, as at PTA meetings.

一种“正常”的排斥现象发生在组织良好的人格中，在这种人格中，一种自我状态会在其他自我状态的同意下占据主导地位。例如，儿童和家长允许成人在工作时间主导。作为这种合作的回报，儿童被允许在聚会上主导，而家长则被允许在其他合适的场合主导，例如家长会上。

Integration means that all three ego states express themselves at once, as in artistic productions and professional dealings with people.

整合意味着所有三种自我状态同时表达出来，例如在艺术创作和与人的专业交往中。

Voice and posture are both good examples of final common pathways. The voice is particularly valuable in detecting compromises. Thus, many women say intelligent things in a little girl voice with considerable assurance. Here the compromise is between a Parent who is saying: ‘Don’t grow up,’ an Adult who is offering counsel, and a Child who enjoys being protected. This can be called an ‘Adult-programed Child,’ or a ‘precocious Child.’ Many men say intelligent things in a grown-up voice lacking in assurance. Here the Parent is saying ‘Who do you think you are?’ the Child is saying ‘I want to show off,’ and the Adult is saying ‘I’ve got something you can try out.’ This can be called a Child-programed Adult. Parent-programed Child (‘Mommy said to.’) and Adult-programed Parent (‘Do it just this way.’) are also common.

声音和姿态都是最终共同路径的典型例子。声音在识别妥协方面尤其重要。因此，许多女性会用稚嫩的嗓音自信满满地说出一些聪明的话。这里存在着一种妥协：一方面是“别长大”的家长，另一方面是提供建议的成年人，以及渴望被保护的孩子。这可以被称为“成人编程的孩子”或“早熟的孩子”。许多男性也会用缺乏自信的成熟嗓音说一些聪明的话。这里家长会问“你以为你是谁？”，孩子会说“我想炫耀”，而成年人会说“我有个东西你可以试试”。这可以被称为“儿童编程的成年人”。“家长编程的孩子”（“妈妈说要这么做。”）和“成年人编程的家长”（“就这么做。”）也很常见。

Posture indicates not only the principal ego states, but also their different aspects. Thus, the Critical Parent sits upright and points his finger straight ahead, while the Nurturing Parent opens up and forms a receptive circle with her body. The Adult posture is flexible, alert, and mobile. The Adapted Child withdraws by curling up (emprosthotonos), and may ultimately end in a fetal position with as many muscles as possible in flexion. The Expressive Child opens up (opisthotonos) with as many muscles as possible in extension. Emprosthotonos occurs with weeping, and opisthotonos with laughing. Even curling up one finger, such as the forefinger, can give a feeling of insecurity and withdrawal, while extending it gives a feeling of confidence and openness. Pointing it stiffly ahead gives the Parental feeling of putting up an impenetrable obstacle against the approach of anyone else’s person or ideas.

姿势不仅体现主要的自我状态，也体现其不同的面向。例如，批判型父母端坐，手指直指前方；而养育型父母则舒展身体，以身体形成一个接纳的圆圈。成人的姿势灵活、警觉且充满活力。适应型儿童会蜷缩身体（前弓反张），最终可能蜷成胎儿状，尽可能地屈曲肌肉。表达型儿童则会舒展身体（后弓反张），尽可能地伸展肌肉。前弓反张通常伴随哭泣，而后弓反张则伴随大笑。即使是蜷缩一根手指，例如食指，也会给人一种不安全感和退缩感，而伸展手指则会给人一种自信和开放感。僵硬地将手指指向前方，会让父母感觉自己筑起了一道坚不可摧的屏障，阻挡任何人或任何想法的靠近。

Put in another way, the Child retains more or less complete control over the involuntary muscles, the Adult usually controls movements of the voluntary muscles, especially the larger ones, and the Parent controls the attitude, or the balance of the tonus between the flexor and extensor muscles.

换句话说，儿童或多或少完全控制着非自主肌肉，成人通常控制着自主肌肉的运动，尤其是较大的肌肉，而父母控制着屈肌和伸肌之间的张力平衡。

It is apparent from all this that final common pathways are selected or apportioned after a kind of dialogue in the head. There are four dialogues possible between simple ego states: three duologues (P–A, P–C, A–C), and one triologue (P–A–C). If the Parental voice splits up into Father and Mother, as it usually does, and if other Parental figures chime in, the situation is more complicated. Each voice may be accompanied by its own set of ‘gestures’ expressed by a chosen set of muscles or a special part of the body. But whatever the nature of the dialogue, its outcome will be expressed through final common pathways, or more precisely, there will be one final common pathway by dominance, agreement, or compromise, while the frustrated ego states will find subsidiary pathways for expression.

由此可见，最终的共同路径是在头脑中经过某种对话后选择或分配的。简单的自我状态之间存在四种可能的对话：三种二元对话（P-A、P-C、A-C）和一种三元对话（P-A-C）。如果父母的声音像通常那样分裂成父亲和母亲，并且其他父母形象也加入进来，情况就变得更加复杂。每种声音都可能伴随着其自身的一套“姿态”，这些姿态由一组特定的肌肉或身体的特定部位表达出来。但无论对话的性质如何，其结果都将通过最终的共同路径表达出来，或者更准确地说，最终会通过支配、同意或妥协形成一条共同路径，而受挫的自我状态则会找到辅助路径来表达。

B • Voices in the Head

B • 脑海中的声音

How real are the voices referred to above? Breuer 1 discovered ego states (separate states of consciousness) almost one hundred years ago, but did not follow up his discovery. His colleague, Freud, at about the same time, became convinced that visual imagery expressed wishes, and spent the greater part of his life involved with that idea. As a result he neglected the auditory aspect of the psyche. Even Federn, 2 who first developed the idea of ‘a mental duologue between two parts of the ego,’ overlooked the question of actual voices and spoke of the duologue as being visually represented (in dreams, for example). Freud’s main contribution here was his statement that voices and words heard in dreams represent voices and words that had actually been heard in waking life. 3

上述声音究竟有多真实？布鲁尔（Breuer）在近百年前发现了自我状态（意识的不同状态），但他并未对此发现进行深入研究。他的同事弗洛伊德几乎在同一时期确信视觉意象表达了愿望，并将毕生精力投入到这一理念中。因此，他忽略了心理的听觉层面。即使是费德恩（Federn），这位最早提出“自我两部分之间的心理对话”概念的人，也忽略了实际声音的问题，而只是将这种对话描述为视觉呈现（例如在梦中）。弗洛伊德的主要贡献在于，他指出梦中听到的声音和词语代表了清醒生活中实际听到的声音和词语。

The clinical rule derived from experience with transactional analysis has already been noted. The Child expresses his wishes in visual images; but what he does about them, the final display through the final common pathway, is determined by auditory images, or voices in the head, the result of a mental dialogue. fn1 This dialogue between Parent, Adult, and Child is not ‘unconscious,’ but preconscious, which means that it can easily be brought into consciousness. Then it is found that it consists of sides taken from real life, things which once were actually said out loud. The therapeutic rule is a simple derivative of this. Since the final common pathway of the patient’s behavior is determined by voices in his head, this can be changed by getting another voice into his head, that of the therapist. If this is done under hypnosis, it may not be effective, since that is an artificial situation. But if it is done in a waking state, it may work better because the original voices were implanted in the patient’s head also in the waking state. Exceptions occur when a witch or ogre parent shouts the child into a state of panic, which is essentially a traumatic fugue.

临床上已提及一条源自人际沟通分析经验的规则。儿童以视觉意象表达愿望；但他如何行动，最终通过共同路径展现出来，则是由听觉意象或脑海中的声音决定的，这是心理对话的结果。 fn1 父母、成人和儿童之间的这种对话并非“无意识的”，而是前意识的，这意味着它很容易被带入意识层面。随后会发现，它由取自真实生活的各个方面构成，即曾经被大声说出口的话。治疗规则正是由此简单推导而来。由于患者行为的最终共同路径是由其脑海中的声音决定的，因此可以通过将另一个声音——治疗师的声音——植入其脑海中来改变这种情况。如果在催眠状态下进行，可能效果不佳，因为催眠是一种人为设定的情境。但如果在清醒状态下进行，效果可能会更好，因为最初的声音在患者清醒状态下就已经植入其脑海中了。但也有例外，比如当女巫或食人魔父母大声喊叫，使孩子陷入恐慌状态时，这本质上是一种创伤性离境状态。

As the therapist gets more and more information from different patients as to what the voices in their heads are saying, and becomes more and more experienced in relating this to their behavior as expressed through final common pathways, he develops a very acute ability and judgment in this regard. He begins to hear the voices in a patient’s head very quickly and accurately, usually before the patient can clearly hear them herself. If he asks a loaded or sensitive question which she takes a little time to answer, he can observe a twitch here, a contraction there, and a shift of expression, so that he can follow the ‘skull dialogue’ almost as though he were listening to a tape recording. An illustration of this was given in the case of Mab as she listened to her mother’s tirade in Chapter Fourteen (B).

随着治疗师从不同的患者那里获得越来越多的信息，了解他们脑海中的声音在说什么，并且越来越擅长将这些声音与他们通过最终共同通路表达的行为联系起来，他在这方面的能力和判断力也日渐敏锐。他开始能够非常迅速且准确地听到患者脑海中的声音，通常在患者自己能够清晰听到之前就做到了。如果他问了一个带有暗示性或敏感的问题，而患者需要一些时间来回答，他就能观察到患者身体的细微抽搐、肌肉的收缩以及表情的变化，从而几乎就像在听录音一样，能够追踪患者的“脑内对话”。第十四章（B）中，玛布聆听母亲咆哮的案例就体现了这一点。

Once he understands what is going on, his next task is to give the patient permission to listen, and to teach her how to hear the voices which are still there in their pristine force from childhood. Here he may have to overcome several kinds of resistance. She may be forbidden to listen by Parental directives, such as: ‘If you hear voices, you’re crazy.’ Or her Child may be afraid of what she will hear. Or her Adult may prefer not to listen to the people governing her behavior in order to maintain her illusion of autonomy.

一旦他了解了情况，下一步就是允许病人倾听，并教她如何聆听那些自童年起就清晰而强烈的声音。在此过程中，他可能需要克服多种阻力。例如，父母可能会禁止她倾听，比如：“如果你听到声音，你就疯了。”或者，她的孩子可能害怕听到什么。又或者，她的成年人为了维护自主的幻觉，可能宁愿不听从那些支配她行为的人的指示。

Many ‘actionistic’ therapists become very skillful at bringing these voices to life by special techniques, where the patient finds himself carrying on the dialogue out loud, so that both he and the audience can plainly see that what he says has been in his head all along. Gestalt therapists often use ‘the empty chair,’ where the patient moves from one chair to the other, playing two parts of himself. 4 Psychodramatists supply trained assistants who play one role while the patient himself plays another. 5 Watching or reading about such sessions, it soon becomes clear that the sides for each role come from different ego states or different aspects of the same ego state, and consist of dialogue which has been running in the patient’s head since his early years. However, almost everybody mutters to himself at some time or another, so every patient has a good start toward unearthing his mental dialogue without such special techniques. As a general rule, phrases in the second person (‘You should have,’ etc.) come from the Parent, while those in the first person (‘I must,’ ‘Why did I?’ etc.) come from the Adult or Child.

许多“行动主义”治疗师非常擅长运用特殊技巧将这些内心的声音具象化，让患者不由自主地大声重复对话，这样患者和旁观者都能清楚地看到，他所说的内容其实一直都在他的脑海中。格式塔治疗师经常使用“空椅子”疗法，让患者在两把椅子间来回移动，扮演自己的两个角色。心理剧治疗师则会安排受过训练的助手扮演一个角色，而患者本人则扮演另一个角色。观看或阅读此类治疗过程，很快就会发现，每个角色的两侧都来自不同的自我状态，或是同一自我状态的不同面向，并且包含着患者自幼年起就在脑海中反复出现的对话。然而，几乎每个人都会在某个时候自言自语，因此，即使没有这些特殊技巧，每个患者都能很好地开始挖掘自己的内心对话。一般来说，第二人称短语（“你应该……”等）来自父母，而第一人称短语（“我必须……”，“我为什么……”等）来自成人或儿童。

With some sort of encouragement, the patient soon becomes aware of his most important script directives as spoken in his head, and can report them to the therapist. The therapist must then give Pat the option of choosing between them, discarding the nonadaptive, useless, harmful, or misleading ones, and keeping the adaptive or useful ones. Even better, he may enable Pat to get a friendly divorce from his parents and make a fresh start altogether (although often the friendly divorce will be preceded by an angry phase, as most divorces are at the beginning, even if they eventually end up friendly). This means he must give Pat permission to disobey the Parental directives, not in rebellion, but rather in autonomy, so that he will be free to do things his own way and not have to follow his script.

经过某种鼓励，患者很快就能意识到自己脑海中最重要的指令，并能将其告知治疗师。治疗师随后必须让帕特在这些指令中做出选择，舍弃那些不适应环境、无用、有害或误导性的指令，保留那些适应环境或有用的指令。更理想的情况是，治疗师可以帮助帕特与父母友好地“离婚”，重新开始（尽管友好离婚之前通常会经历一段愤怒的阶段，就像大多数离婚在初期一样，即使最终以友好告终）。这意味着治疗师必须允许帕特违背父母的指令，并非出于反叛，而是出于自主，这样他才能自由地按照自己的方式行事，而不必遵循父母的指令。

An easier way to handle this is to give the patient drugs such as meprobamate, phenothiazines, or amitriptyline, all of which mute the Parental voices. This relieves the Child’s anxiety or depression and thus ‘makes the patient feel better.’ But there are three disadvantages. First, these drugs tend to dumb down the whole personality, including the voice of the Adult. Some physicians, for example, advise the patient not to drive a car while he is taking them. Second, they make psychotherapy more difficult precisely because the Parent’s voices cannot be heard clearly, and so the script directives may be masked or de-emphasized. And third, therapeutic permission given under such conditions may be freely exercised, since the Parental prohibitions are temporarily out of commission, but if and when the drug is discontinued, the Parent usually comes back in full force, and may even take revenge on the Child for the liberties he took while the Parent was decommissioned.

更简便的方法是给患者服用甲丙氨酯、吩噻嗪类药物或阿米替林等药物，这些药物都能抑制父母的声音。这可以缓解孩子的焦虑或抑郁，从而“让患者感觉好些”。但这种方法有三个缺点。首先，这些药物往往会削弱整个人格，包括成人的声音。例如，一些医生会建议患者在服用这些药物期间不要开车。其次，由于父母的声音无法清晰地被听到，因此这些药物会使心理治疗更加困难，因为脚本指令可能会被掩盖或弱化。第三，在这种情况下给予的治疗许可可能会被随意行使，因为父母的禁令暂时失效，但如果停药，父母的声音通常会完全恢复，甚至可能对孩子在父母声音失效期间的“自由行为”进行报复。

C • The Dynamics of Permission

C • 权限的动态

Transactional analysis as a therapeutic method is based on the assumption that words and gestures can have a therapeutic effect without any bodily contact with the patient beyond a handshake. If a transactional analyst considers that bodily contact is desirable for a certain patient, he refers her to a dance class, sensory-awareness group, or a ‘permission class.’ Permission classes differ from the other two because they are run by people trained in transactional analysis who follow the prescription of the therapist rather than imposing their own theories or needs on the patient. Thus, a transactional analyst may decide: ‘This patient needs hugging, but I can’t hug him and still do well-planned therapy, so I’ll refer him to a permission class with a prescription for hugging.’ Or: ‘This patient needs loosening up through dance and informal touch contact with people, but I’m not running a dance class, so I’ll refer her to a permission class with a prescription for dancing.’

作为一种治疗方法，交互分析基于这样的假设：即使除了握手之外没有其他身体接触，言语和手势也能产生治疗效果。如果交互分析师认为某个患者需要身体接触，他会建议她参加舞蹈课、感官觉察小组或“许可课”。许可课与其他两种课程的不同之处在于，它由接受过交互分析训练的人员授课，他们会遵循治疗师的指导，而不是将自己的理论或需求强加给患者。因此，交互分析师可能会决定：“这位患者需要拥抱，但我不能拥抱他，否则就无法进行精心设计的治疗，所以我建议他参加一个许可课，并给他开具拥抱的处方。”或者：“这位患者需要通过舞蹈和与他人的非正式身体接触来放松身心，但我没有开设舞蹈课，所以我建议她参加一个许可课，并给她开具跳舞的处方。”

Permission classes are run as groups, so that the patient does not get individual hugging or individual dancing exercises. All the patients do the same things at the same time, but the teacher is aware of each one’s special needs and devotes some attention to them. (The patients do not have to do the same things at the same time. The teacher merely makes the suggestion, but each person is free to do as he wishes – that is part of the permission derived from the class. Usually, however, they enjoy the participation with other people, something they may have missed in childhood.)

许可课程以小组形式进行，这样患者就不会得到单独的拥抱或单独的舞蹈练习。所有患者同时进行相同的活动，但老师会关注每位患者的特殊需求，并给予相应的关注。（患者不必同时进行相同的活动。老师只是提出建议，每个人都可以自由选择——这是课程所赋予的许可的一部分。通常，他们很享受与他人一起参与活动，这可能是他们在童年时期所缺失的。）

Dr Q attended a permission class in order to find out how it felt and what he could learn. When the instructor suggested: ‘Everybody sit on the floor,’ the voices in his head said: ‘My Child and my Adult agree to accept your suggestion to sit on the floor,’ and he did so. Where was his Parent? His Adult and Parent had previously agreed that the Parent would leave the Child free to do as he pleased, under some Adult control, unless things ‘went too far,’ i.e., got too sexy. His Child did get slightly aroused but there was no need for the Parent to come out, since his Adult was quite able to handle the situation. This gives some clue as to how permission takes effect.

Q博士参加了一个关于“许可”的课程，想体验一下这种感觉，并学习一些相关知识。当老师提议“大家坐在地板上”时，他脑海中响起的声音：“我的孩子和我的成年人同意接受您的建议，坐在地板上。”于是他照做了。他的父母在哪里呢？他的成年人和父母之前已经达成一致：父母会允许孩子在成年人的某种控制下自由行动，除非事情“太过分”，比如变得过于性感。他的孩子确实有些兴奋，但父母无需出面，因为他的成年人完全能够处理这种情况。这或许能让我们更好地理解“许可”是如何生效的。

Since permission is the decision intervention for script analysis, it is worth having as clear as possible an understanding of how it works, and every opportunity should be taken to learn about it by observing this in different situations.

由于许可是脚本分析的决策干预手段，因此有必要尽可能清楚地了解其运作方式，并应抓住一切机会，通过在不同情况下观察来学习它。

When Jeder already has permission from his Parent to do something, no internal dialogue is necessary. This corresponds to the literal meaning of permission, which is a license. Once a person has a license to do something, he does not have to report back each time he wants to do it. Only if he abuses the license and goes too far will he hear from the authorities under ordinary circumstances. Some parents, of course, are ‘inspectors’ by nature, and even after they give a license they want to oversee everything. People who have such Parents in their heads will be very inhibited and edgy.

当孩子已经得到父母的许可去做某事时，就不需要进行任何内心的挣扎。这符合许可的字面意思——一种执照。一旦一个人获得了做某事的执照，他就不必每次想做这件事都向上汇报。通常情况下，只有当他滥用执照、做得太过分时，才会受到当局的关注。当然，有些父母天生就是“监督者”，即使给了许可，他们也想监督一切。有这样父母的人会感到非常拘束和焦虑。

When there is a prohibition against doing something, a dialogue will result whenever the person starts to do it. The Parent becomes active and says ‘No!’ in a hard script, ‘Watch out!’ in a threatening one, or ‘Why do you want to do that?’ in a soft one – usually whatever the actual parent would say in real life. The energy which the Child had mobilized to do it is then taken over by the Parent, and is used by him to restrain the Child. The more energy the Child had mobilized to put into it, the more energetic can the Parent become by appropriating this energy. Under these conditions, how can the Child be given permission to do something? If an outsider says: ‘Let him do it!’ the Parent becomes alarmed, and his prohibitions become even more energetic, so that the Child alone does not have a chance. The outsider, however, can seduce the Child by supplying ‘energy’ in the form of encouragement or pressure. The Child may then go ahead and do it. But after it is done, the still active and energetic Parent moves in and causes the ‘hangover’ phenomenon, as in alcoholic hang-overs, guilt feelings, and manic-depressive depression following too much Child freedom.

当某事被禁止时，一旦孩子开始做这件事，就会引发一场对话。父母会变得积极主动，用强硬的语气说“不行！”，用威胁的语气说“小心！”，或者用温和的语气问“你为什么要这样做？”——通常情况下，父母会用类似他们在现实生活中会说的话来表达。孩子原本用来做这件事的能量会被父母吸收，并被用来约束孩子。孩子投入的能量越多，父母就能越有效地吸收这些能量。在这种情况下，如何才能允许孩子去做某件事呢？如果一个外人说：“让他做吧！”，父母就会感到恐慌，他的禁令会变得更加严厉，以至于孩子自己根本没有机会。然而，外人可以通过鼓励或施压来“诱导”孩子，孩子就可能最终去做这件事。但事后，仍然活跃且精力充沛的父母介入，导致“宿醉”现象，就像酗酒后的宿醉、内疚感以及给予孩子过多自由后出现的躁郁症一样。

This is the state of affairs with a weakly ‘cathected’ or inactive Adult. In fact, the Adult is the only force which can effectively intervene between the Parent and the Child, and all therapeutic interventions must take account of that. It appears that the Adult can get permission from the outside to mobilize its own energy, or can be charged up by an outside source. It is then in a position to intercede between Parent and Child. It takes on the Parent, thus leaving the Child free to go ahead. If the Parent later objects, the Adult remains ‘cathected’ and can oppose him.

这就是“依附”程度较低或不活跃的成年人所处的状态。事实上，成年人是唯一能够有效介入父母与孩子之间关系的力量，所有治疗干预都必须考虑到这一点。成年人似乎可以从外部获得许可来调动自身的能量，或者可以从外部来源获得能量。之后，它便能够介入父母与孩子之间。它承担起父母的责任，从而使孩子能够自由地继续前进。如果父母之后提出反对，成年人仍然“依附”着父母，并可以与之对抗。

The relationship between the Parent and the Child also applies in reverse. Not only can the Parent grab energy from the Child to oppose it, but it can transfer energy to the Child to goad it on. Thus a ‘bad’ Parent makes a ‘bad’ Child not only by directing, but also by energizing the Child to do ‘bad’ things. 6 This is well known to schizophrenics who have been cured by transactional analysis through re-parenting. 7 In re-parenting, the Adult also performs its function by getting turned on enough to argue with the discarded Parent if he becomes active again.

父母与子女之间的关系也反过来适用。父母不仅可以从子女那里汲取能量来对抗子女，还可以将能量传递给子女来怂恿其作恶。因此，“坏”父母不仅通过引导，而且还通过激发子女的潜能来造就“坏”子女。这一点对于那些通过人际沟通分析和“再养育”疗法治愈的精神分裂症患者来说并不陌生。在“再养育”过程中，如果被抛弃的父母再次活跃起来，成年人也会通过被激发出足够的能量来与之争论，从而发挥其应有的作用。

We have noted that there are positive permissions or licenses, where the therapist or the Adult says ‘Let him do it!’ and negative permissions or releases, where the argument is ‘Stop pushing him into it!’

我们注意到，存在积极的许可或授权，治疗师或成年人会说“让他去做吧！”，也存在消极的许可或放行，理由是“别再强迫他了！”。

Hence, the decisive factor in therapy is to hook the patient’s Adult first. If the therapist and the Adult can agree and form an alliance, this alliance can be used against the Parent to give the Child permission: either to do something forbidden, or to disobey a Parental provocation. After the crisis is over, Pat’s Child still has to confront a fully charged Parent. In the case of a positive permission (‘You may have an orgasm with your husband if you want to.’), the child may be drained of energy and too weak to resist the punishing Parent. After negative permission (‘You don’t have to get drunk to prove you’re a man.’), the Child is tense and edgy and perhaps resentful against whomever gave him the permission to resist. In this frustrated and vulnerable state, he has no defense against the Parent’s taunts. In both cases, this is the point at which the therapist must be available to protect the Child against the Parent’s retribution or jeers.

因此，治疗的关键在于首先与患者的“成人”建立联系。如果治疗师和“成人”能够达成共识并建立联盟，这种联盟就可以被用来对抗“父母”，从而给予“孩子”某种许可：无论是去做一些被禁止的事情，还是违抗“父母”的挑衅。危机过后，“孩子”仍然要面对一位情绪激动的“父母”。如果“父母”给予的是积极的许可（“如果你想的话，你可以和你的丈夫达到性高潮。”），孩子可能已经精疲力竭，无力抵抗“父母”的惩罚。如果“父母”给予的是消极的许可（“你不需要喝醉来证明你是个男人。”），孩子会感到紧张、焦虑，甚至可能对给予他反抗许可的人心怀怨恨。在这种沮丧和脆弱的状态下，他无法抵御“父母”的嘲讽。在这两种情况下，治疗师都必须在此时出现，保护孩子免受“父母”的报复或嘲弄。

Now we can speak with some assurance of the ‘three Ps’ of therapy, which determine the therapist’s effectiveness. These are potency, permission, and protection. 8 The therapist must give the child permission to disobey the Parental injunctions and provocations. In order to do that effectively, he must be and feel potent: not omnipotent, but potent enough to deal with the patient’s Parent. Afterward he must feel potent enough, and the patient’s Child must believe he is potent enough, to offer protection from the Parental wrath. (The word ‘potency’ is used here in a sense which applies to female therapists as well as male ones.)

现在我们可以比较有把握地谈论治疗的“三要素”，它们决定了治疗师的有效性。这三要素分别是：效能（Potency）、许可（Legend）和保护（Protection）。治疗师必须允许孩子违抗父母的禁令和挑衅。为了有效地做到这一点，治疗师必须感到自己拥有效能：并非全能，而是足以应对患者的父母。之后，治疗师必须感到自己拥有足够的效能，并且患者的孩子也必须相信他拥有足够的效能，才能保护自己免受父母的愤怒。（这里“效能”一词的含义同样适用于男性和女性治疗师。）

Della ( Chapter Three ) offers a simple illustration. Della had blackouts when she drank and was in danger of ruining herself during these episodes.

第三章中的德拉提供了一个简单的例子。德拉喝酒后会断片，在这些断片期间，她随时都有可能毁掉自己。

(1) ‘If I don’t stop doing that,’ she said (Adult), ‘I’m going to ruin myself and my children.’

（1）她说（成年人）：“如果我不停止这样做，我会毁了自己和我的孩子。”

(2) ‘That’s right,’ replied Dr Q (Adult), thus hooking into her already active Adult. (3) ‘So you need permission to stop drinking.’

（2）“没错，”Q博士（成年人）回答道，从而与她已经活跃的成年人建立了联系。（3）“所以你需要得到许可才能停止饮酒。”

(2) ‘I certainly do.’ (Adult.)

（2）“我当然愿意。”（成人）

(6) ‘Right! (4) So stop drinking.’ (Parent to her Child.)

（6）“对！（4）所以别再喝酒了。”（家长对孩子说。）

(5) ‘What shall I do when I get all tensed up?’ she asked. (Child.)

（5）“我紧张的时候该怎么办？”她问。（孩子）

(5) ‘Telephone me.’ (Adult procedure.)

（5）“给我打电话。”（成人程序。）

Which she did, with good results. Here the transactions are: (1) Hook the Adult, or wait until it is active. (2) Form an alliance with the Adult. (3) State your plan and see if the Adult agrees with it. (4) If everything is clear, give the Child permission to disobey the Parent. This must be done clearly and in simple imperatives, with no ifs, ands, or buts. (5) Offer the Child protection from the consequences. (6) Reinforce this by telling the Adult it is all right. It should be mentioned that this was Dr Q’s second attempt to give Della permission. The first time her Child answered instead of her Adult: ‘But what’ll I do if I get tensed up and want to drink?’ As soon as he heard the Child’s ‘but,’ ‘if,’ and ‘and,’ Dr Q knew that the permission would not take hold, so he aborted the maneuver and went on to something else. This time she said: ‘What shall I do when I get all tensed up?’ Since there were no ifs, ands, or buts in this sentence, he thought she was ready to make it. The permission was a potent one because Dr Q did not use any ifs, ands, or buts either. It will be noted that he did not follow the steps in numerical order, but adapted them to what was going on.

她照做了，而且效果不错。以下是具体步骤：（1）吸引成年人的注意力，或者等到它主动出击。（2）与成年人结盟。（3）陈述你的计划，看看成年人是否同意。（4）如果一切都清楚，就允许孩子违抗父母的命令。这必须清晰明确，使用简单的命令式，没有任何“如果”、“但是”或“但是”。（5）保护孩子免受后果的影响。（6）通过告诉成年人这样做没关系来强化这种信任。值得一提的是，这是Q博士第二次尝试允许黛拉违抗父母的命令。第一次，黛拉的孩子代替成年人回答说：“可是如果我紧张想喝酒怎么办？” Q博士一听到孩子的“但是”、“如果”和“而且”，就知道这个许可不会生效，于是他放弃了这个策略，转而采取了其他措施。这次她说：“如果我紧张得不行该怎么办？”由于这句话里没有任何“如果”、“但是”之类的疑问句，他认为她已经准备好了。这个许可很有说服力，因为Q博士也没有使用任何“如果”、“但是”之类的疑问句。值得注意的是，他并没有按照步骤顺序进行，而是根据实际情况进行了调整。

In summary: (1) Permission means a license to give up behavior which the Adult wants to give up, or a release from negative behavior. (2) Potency means power to confront. ‘If’ and ‘but’ do not signify potency to a Child. Any permission which contains an ‘if’ in the form of a condition or a threat, is no good, and if it is conditioned, qualified, or reduced by a ‘but’ it is no good either. (3) Protection means that during this phase the patient can call on the therapist to exercise his potency again in time of need. His protective power resides as much in the timbre of his voice as in what he says.

综上所述：（1）许可是指允许成年人放弃其想要放弃的行为，或从负面行为中解脱出来。（2）效力是指对抗的能力。“如果”和“但是”对儿童而言并不代表效力。任何带有条件或威胁的“如果”都是无效的，任何附加条件、限制或被“但是”削弱的许可也同样无效。（3）保护是指在此阶段，患者可以在需要时再次请求治疗师运用其效力。他的保护力不仅体现在他所说的话中，也体现在他说话的语气中。

FIGURE 18

图18

Figure 18 shows the three steps in giving effective permission. The first vector, AA, represents hooking the Adult. The second vector, PC, is the permission itself. The third vector, PC, represents the therapist giving protection to the patient’s Child against an aroused Parent.

图 18 展示了有效给予许可的三个步骤。第一个向量 AA 代表吸引成人。第二个向量 PC 代表许可本身。第三个向量 PC 代表治疗师保护患者的“儿童”免受性兴奋的“父母”的伤害。

A timid therapist is as out of place trying to tame an angry Parent as a timid cowboy is trying to ride a bucking bronco. And if the therapist gets thrown, he lands right on the patient’s Child.

胆怯的治疗师试图安抚愤怒的家长，就像胆怯的牛仔试图驾驭桀骜不驯的野马一样格格不入。如果治疗师被甩下来，他就会直接摔在病人的孩子身上。

D • Curing Patients vs. Making Progress

D • 治愈病人与取得进展

Herbert O. Yardley 9 describes the long, drawn-out, and excruciating task of breaking one of the Japanese codes during World War I – without knowing Japanese. One of his assistants had the following dream:

赫伯特·O·亚德利（Herbert O. Yardley）描述了第一次世界大战期间破解日军密码的漫长、艰辛和痛苦的过程——而他本人却不懂日语。他的一位助手做了这样一个梦：

‘I am walking on a beach with a heavy sack of pebbles which I have to carry and which tires me out. I can get some relief as follows: whenever I find a pebble on the beach that matches one of the pebbles in my load, I can get rid of the one I am carrying.’

“我背着一袋沉重的鹅卵石走在沙滩上，这让我很累。我可以这样减轻一些负担：每当我在海滩上找到一颗与我袋子里的鹅卵石相匹配的鹅卵石时，我就可以扔掉我背着的那颗。”

This beautiful dream shows how the laborious task of solving the code, one word at a time, was translated into visual images. It is also a parable of what it is like for the patient to ‘make progress.’ Script analysis attempts to cut the straps so that the patient can drop the whole load at once and feel free as quickly as possible. Undoubtedly the slower ‘pebble by pebble’ system of therapy gives the therapist a great feeling of confidence that he knows what he is doing, but script analysts are getting a greater feeling of confidence, too, and more and more often they are finding where to cut so as to relieve the patient of his burden all at once. Nothing is lost by this, since it is quite possible to go through the now discarded sack pebble by pebble and do the same job as the psychoanalytic therapist, after the patient gets better.
