The slogan of ‘Making-Progress Therapy’ is ‘You can’t get better until you are fully analyzed,’ while the slogan of ‘Curing-Patients Therapy’ is ‘Get well first, and we’ll analyze it later if you still want to.’ This is similar to the problem of the Gordian Knot. Many people tried to unravel the knot, since it was prophesied that whoever did would become the master of Asia. Alexander came along and cut through it with his sword. The others complained loudly that that was not the way he was supposed to do it, that he was taking the easy way out, oversimplifying the problem. But he did get the job done, and he did get his reward.

这个美丽的梦境展现了如何将逐字逐句破解密码的艰辛过程转化为视觉图像。它也象征着患者“取得进步”的过程。脚本分析试图剪断束缚患者的绳索，让他们能够一次性卸下所有重担，尽快获得自由。毫无疑问，这种缓慢的“循序渐进”的治疗方法能让治疗师对自己的工作充满信心，但脚本分析师也越来越自信，他们也越来越频繁地找到可以剪断绳索的地方，从而一次性地减轻患者的负担。这样做并没有什么损失，因为在患者康复后，完全可以像精神分析治疗师那样，一次又一次地处理这些被丢弃的重担。 “循序渐进疗法”的口号是“只有经过全面分析，你才能好转”，而“治愈型疗法”的口号是“先治好病，如果你还想分析，我们以后再说”。这类似于戈尔迪之结的问题。许多人试图解开这个结，因为预言说，谁能解开它，谁就能成为亚洲之王。亚历山大出现了，用他的剑斩断了它。其他人大声抱怨说，他没有用正确的方法，他走了捷径，把问题过于简单化了。但他确实完成了任务，也确实得到了他的奖赏。

To put it another way, a therapist can be either a botanist or an engineer. A botanist goes into the underbrush and looks at each leaf and flower and blade of grass to find out what is happening there. Meanwhile the hungry farmer says: ‘But we need that land for crops.’ ‘Takes a long time,’ says the botanist. ‘You can’t hurry a project like this.’ The engineer says: ‘How come all that underbrush is growing there? Let’s change the drainage, and that’ll clear the land. Just find the creek and build the right dam, and all your troubles will soon be over. No sweat.’ But if the ‘hungry farmer’ is a patient starving for affection, he says: ‘Oh, but I love all that underbrush, so I’d rather starve until we go over every leaf and flower and blade of grass.’ The botanist makes progress, and the engineer fixes it up – if the patient will let him. That’s because botany is a science and engineering is a method for changing things.

换句话说，治疗师可以是植物学家，也可以是工程师。植物学家会深入灌木丛，仔细观察每一片叶子、每一朵花、每一根草，找出其中的奥秘。与此同时，饥肠辘辘的农夫会说：“可是我们需要这块地种庄稼啊。” “这需要很长时间，”植物学家说，“这种事急不得。” 工程师会说：“为什么那里长了这么多灌木？我们来改造一下排水系统，就能清理出这片土地。只要找到小溪，建好合适的堤坝，你的所有烦恼很快就能解决。轻而易举。” 但如果这位“饥肠辘辘的农夫”是一位渴望关爱的病人，他会说：“哦，可是我喜欢这些灌木，所以我宁愿饿着肚子，直到我们仔细检查每一片叶子、每一朵花、每一根草。” 植物学家会取得进展，而工程师会进行收尾工作——如果病人愿意的话。那是因为植物学是一门科学，而工程学是改变事物的方法。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 Breuer, J. and Freud, S. Studies in Hysteria . Nervous and Mental Disease Monographs, New York, 1950, pp. 14–32.

1 Breuer, J. 和 Freud, S. 癔症研究。神经和精神疾病专著，纽约，1950 年，第 14-32 页。

2 Federn, P. Ego Psychology and the Psychoses . Basic Books, New York, 1952, Chapter 4.

2 Federn, P. 自我心理学与精神病。纽约基础书籍出版社，1952 年，第 4 章。

3 Freud, S. The Interpretation of Dreams . The Macmillan Company, New York, 1915.

3 弗洛伊德，S.《梦的解析》。纽约麦克米伦公司，1915年。

4 Perls, F. S. Gestalt Therapy Verbatim. Loc. cit .

4 Perls, F. S.格式塔疗法逐字稿。同上。

5 Moreno, J. L. ‘Psychodrama.’ in American Handbook of Psychiatry , Vol 2, Basic Books, New York, 1959.

5 Moreno, J. L.《心理剧》，载于《美国精神病学手册》第 2 卷，纽约基础书籍出版社，1959 年。

6 Psychoanalysis accepts the idea that energy can be transferred from the Id into the Superego, and that the Superego is in fact a split-off part of the Id. It is less enthusiastic about the idea that the energy can be transferred back from the Superego into the Id, but that is what takes place in active schizophrenia, so this phenomenon must be studied energetically. Psychoanalysis, in practice at least, discourages the Adult by abuse of the term ‘intellectualizing.’ That is why ‘transference cures’ are the bane of ‘psychoanalytic therapy.’ Little possibility is left for anything else. Only in the terminal phase of formal psychoanalysis is the Adult allowed full expression, and when that happens the patient is regarded as ‘cured.’ Put in another way, a psychoanalytic patient is cured when the analyst finally gives him permission to think for himself. In transactional analysis, the Adult is enlisted as an ally as soon as possible and proves its worth. Protection does not imply a transference cure, it is merely a way of passing through a shaky phase to self-confidence. A person learning horseback riding or skin-diving or flying needs similar protection at first, but that does not mean in any reprehensible sense that he is ‘dependent’ on his instructor. When he is ready, he takes off by himself (in those sports, perhaps after ten weeks). Anybody learning to face a powerful force of nature needs ten weeks of protection, perhaps more in some cases.

6. 精神分析接受能量可以从本我转移到超我的观点，并且超我实际上是本我分裂出来的部分。它不太热衷于能量可以从超我转移回本我的观点，但这正是活跃期精神分裂症中发生的情况，因此必须从能量学的角度研究这种现象。至少在实践中，精神分析滥用“理智化”一词来抑制成人意识的表达。这就是为什么“移情治愈”是“精神分析疗法”的祸根。除此之外，几乎没有其他可能性。只有在正式精神分析的终末阶段，成人意识才被允许充分表达，而当这种情况发生时，患者就被视为“治愈”。换句话说，当分析师最终允许患者独立思考时，精神分析患者就被治愈了。在交互分析中，成人意识会尽快被纳入盟友的角色，并证明其价值。保护并不意味着转移治疗，它仅仅是一种帮助人们度过脆弱阶段、建立自信的方法。学习骑马、潜水或飞行的人起初也需要类似的保护，但这并不意味着他“依赖”教练。当他准备好时，他就可以独自起飞（在这些运动中，或许需要十周时间）。任何学习如何面对强大自然力量的人都需要十周的保护，在某些情况下可能需要更长时间。

7 Schiff, J., et al . ‘Reparenting in Schizophrenia.’ Transactional Analysis Bulletin , 8:45–75, July, 1969.

7 Schiff, J. 等人。“精神分裂症患者的再养育。”《交互分析公报》，8:45–75，1969 年 7 月。

8 Crossman, P. ‘Permission and Protection.’ Transactional Analysis Bulletin , 5:152, July, 1966.

8 Crossman, P. ‘许可和保护’。《交易分析公报》，5:152，1966 年 7 月。

9 Yardley, H. O. The American Black Chamber . Bobbs-Merrill Company, New York, 1931.

9 Yardley, H. O. 美国黑人商会。鲍勃斯-梅里尔公司，纽约，1931 年。

fn1 The situation must be different with deaf children, and also with the blind, but so far nothing is known about how scripting occurs under such handicaps.

fn1 聋童和盲童的情况肯定有所不同，但到目前为止，对于这类残疾情况下脚本是如何产生的，我们一无所知。

#↩

CHAPTER TWENTY

第二十章

Three Case Histories

三个案例分析

A • Clooney

克鲁尼

Clooney was a thirty-one-year-old housewife whom Dr Q had known since she was eighteen years old, long before he knew very much about script analysis. When she first came to him she was scared, lonely, awkward, and blushing. She gave the impression that an angel spirit had come down from Heaven looking for a body to travel around in, and after settling in Clooney’s, felt that she had made a slight error. She had few acquaintances and no friends. She reacted to the boys at school by being supercilious and sarcastic, which effectively chased them away. She was also overweight.

克鲁尼是一位三十一岁的家庭主妇，Q博士从她十八岁起就认识她，那时他对剧本分析还一窍不通。她第一次来找他时，既害怕又孤独，笨拙又害羞。她给人的感觉就像一个从天而降的天使，正在寻找一个可以寄宿的躯体。在克鲁尼家安顿下来后，她觉得自己好像犯了个小错误。她几乎没什么熟人，也没有朋友。在学校里，她对男生的态度傲慢又讽刺，结果把他们都吓跑了。她还很胖。

Her first course of therapy was based mainly on structural analysis, with only a few rudimentary ideas about games and scripts, but it was effective enough so that she got married and had two children. She returned about five years later because she was having difficulties with her outside social life, and thought that was unfair to her husband. One thing that bothered her was that she drank a lot at parties in order to loosen up, and then she did crazy things like taking off all her clothes on a dare. She improved enough at that time so that she could go to parties without drinking to excess. Although she was still unhappy on such occasions, she was able to talk to people, and thought that was good enough.

她的第一个疗程主要基于结构分析，只涉及一些关于游戏和脚本的初步概念，但效果显著，让她得以结婚生子。大约五年后，她再次接受治疗，因为她的社交生活遇到了困难，她认为这对丈夫不公平。令她困扰的一件事是，为了放松，她会在聚会上大量饮酒，然后做出一些疯狂的事情，比如在打赌时脱光衣服。那时她的情况有所好转，可以参加聚会而不至于过度饮酒。虽然在这样的场合她仍然感到不快乐，但她能够与人交谈，她觉得这就足够了。

About five years after that, she returned again, this time determined to get well instead of just making progress. After five group meetings and two individual sessions, she requested another individual session. On that occasion, she sidled into the office, made a half-hearted gesture at closing the door behind her, and sat down. Dr Q shut the door and sat down, too. The following exchanges then took place.

大约五年后，她再次前来，这次她决心彻底康复，而不仅仅是取得进步。在参加了五次小组会议和两次个人咨询后，她要求再进行一次个人咨询。这次，她悄悄走进办公室，漫不经心地做了个关门的动作，然后坐了下来。Q医生也关上门坐了下来。接下来发生了以下对话。

C: I’ve been thinking about what you told me last week – you said I should grow up. You told me that before, but I wasn’t able to listen. My husband has given me permission to grow up, too.

C：我一直在想你上周跟我说的话——你说我应该长大。你以前也跟我说过，但我当时没听进去。我丈夫也允许我长大了。

Q: I didn’t say grow up. I don’t think I’ve ever said that to anybody. I said you had permission to be a woman, which is quite a different thing. Growing up is making progress, but being a woman means that your Adult takes over and you get well.

问：我没说要你长大。我想我从来没对任何人说过这样的话。我说的是你有权利做一个女人，这完全是两回事。长大意味着进步，而做一个女人意味着你内心的成年人会接管一切，你会变得健康快乐。

C: Well, my husband said that when we first got married he needed me to be dependent on him, but now he doesn’t need that any more, so I have his permission to become a woman.

C：嗯，我丈夫说我们刚结婚的时候他需要我依赖他，但现在他不再需要那样了，所以我得到了他的许可，可以成为一个女人。

Q: How did your husband get so smart?

问：你丈夫怎么变得这么聪明？

C: He’s been here, too, in spirit at least. We talk over what happens here and he’s learned a lot about it, so he understands.

C：他也一直在这里，至少精神上是如此。我们会谈论这里发生的事情，他了解了很多，所以他能理解。

Q: Your mother was like your husband. She needed you, too.

问：你的母亲就像你的丈夫一样。她也需要你。

C: That’s exactly right. She needed me to be dependent on her.

C：没错。她需要我依赖她。

This puzzled Dr Q, because that was mother’s Parent giving directives to Clooney, telling Clooney to be dependent on her, a directive which Clooney carried into her marriage. But if the script theory was correct, it seemed there should also be an important script control coming from mother’s Child. While Dr Q was pondering this, Clooney changed the subject.

这让Q博士感到困惑，因为那是母亲的父母在给克鲁尼下指令，告诉克鲁尼要依赖她，而克鲁尼把这条指令带进了婚姻。但如果剧本理论正确，那么似乎也应该有来自母亲的孩子的重要剧本控制。Q博士还在思考这个问题时，克鲁尼就转移了话题。

C: Then you always talk about my bottom, and we know there was something that happened in the bathroom that I’ve never been able to remember.

C：然后你总是谈论我的屁股，我们都知道在浴室里发生了一些我一直记不起来的事情。

Q: Well, the scene I’m thinking of is a very common one. The little girl goes into the living room where mother is with her friends, and her diapers fall off and everybody says ‘Isn’t that cute!’

问：嗯，我想到的场景很常见。小女孩走进客厅，妈妈正和朋友们在一起，她的尿布掉了，大家都说“真可爱！”

C: Yes, that happened to me.

C：是的，我也遇到过这种情况。

Q: And then the little kid gets very embarrassed and blushes, and maybe her bottom blushes, too, and that makes it worse because then everybody gets really interested and says: ‘Now look at that! That really is cute, ho ho ho.’

问：然后小女孩就非常尴尬，脸红了，也许她的屁股也红了，这让情况更糟，因为这样大家都会很感兴趣，说：“快看！真可爱，呵呵呵。”

C: That’s really the way I feel.

C：我的确也是这么想的。

Q: That has something to do with your taking your clothes off at a party. That’s one way you know of making contact with people.

问：这跟你在派对上脱衣服有关。这是你用来和人搭讪的一种方式。

At this point Dr Q drew on the blackboard the diagram in Figure 19A . (It is the custom among transactional analysts to have a blackboard on the wall for the purpose of drawing such diagrams when occasion calls for them.)

此时，Q 博士在黑板上画出了图 19A 所示的图表。（交易分析师通常会在墙上安装一块黑板，以便在需要时绘制此类图表。）

Q: This diagram shows the relationship between your Child and your husband’s Parent. It was the same when you were growing up. Your mother’s Parent needed you to depend on her, and your Child went along with that. So you see as far as that part of your marriage goes, your husband really fills in for your mother.

问：这张图展示了你和你丈夫父母之间的关系。你小时候也是这样。你母亲的父母需要你依赖她，而你也顺从了这一点。所以你看，在你们婚姻的这一部分，你丈夫实际上扮演了你母亲的角色。

C: That’s right. I married him because he’s like my mother.

C：没错。我嫁给他是因为他就像我的母亲一样。

Q: Yes, but somehow your mother’s Child must come into it, too.

问：是的，但不知何故，你母亲的孩子也必须牵涉其中。

C: Oh, yes. She always smiled when something embarrassing happened or when one of us girls did something she thought was naughty. Then she would say: ‘But isn’t it awful?’

C：哦，是的。每当发生尴尬的事情，或者我们女生做了她认为不好的事情时，她总是笑着说：“可是这不是很糟糕吗？”

Q: It’s very important to know whether she laughed or smiled first and then said ‘Isn’t it awful?’ or said ‘Isn’t it awful?’ first and then smiled.

问：要知道她是先笑了，然后说“是不是很糟糕？”，还是先说了“是不是很糟糕？”，然后才笑，这一点非常重要。

C: Oh, you mean if she let her Child out first and then apologized to her Parent, or talked with her Parent first and then let her Child out.

C：哦，你的意思是，如果她先放孩子出去，然后向父母道歉，或者先和父母谈过，然后再放孩子出去。

Q: That’s right.

问：没错。

C: I see what you mean. Well, she smiled first.

C：我明白你的意思了。嗯，是她先笑的。

Q: Oh, then she wanted you to do the things she couldn’t do, and that really tickled her Child, but then she had to apologize to her Parent. That’s exactly what you do: you’re always apologizing to your Parent. You go ahead and do your mother’s naughties for her, and then you keep saying: ‘What do I do about guilt feelings?’ Like after your mother’s Child encourages you to do something, her Parent moves in and clamps down on you.

问：哦，然后她想让你做她做不到的事，这让她的孩子很开心，但她又不得不向父母道歉。你就是这样：你总是向父母道歉。你替你妈妈做了她不该做的事，然后你不停地说：“我该怎么克服内疚感？”就像你妈妈的孩子鼓励你做某件事之后，她的父母就会介入并严厉地管束你。

C: Yes, I know. But what do I do about the guilt feelings?

C：是的，我知道。但我该如何克服这种内疚感呢？

Q: You get a divorce from your mother. Mind your own business. Take care of your own problems instead of being a stooge for her. Let her do her own naughties, and if that upsets her, then it’s her problem.

问：你跟你妈离婚了。管好你自己的事。别给她当傀儡，自己解决自己的问题。让她自己去惹事，如果这让她不高兴，那是她自己的问题。

C: My aunt was the same way.

C：我姑姑也是这样。

Q: So now we put an arrow in the diagram where your mother’s Child is encouraging your Child to act up. ( Figure 19B .) Then her Child is pleased and smiles, and after that her Parent comes out with ‘Isn’t it awful?’ But there’s still something missing, because your father should come into it.

问：现在我们在图中用箭头标出你母亲的孩子鼓励你的孩子胡闹的地方（图19B）。然后她的孩子很高兴，笑了，之后她母亲就说“这难道不好吗？”但这里还缺少些什么，因为你父亲也应该参与进来。

C: I know how he came into it. He always said I was a coward and couldn’t do it. He said he was a coward, too. When he was sick and in pain he would moan and then say: ‘I’m a coward, I can’t stand it.’

C：我知道他是怎么卷进来的。他总是说我是个懦夫，做不到。他也说自己是个懦夫。他生病疼痛的时候，会呻吟着说：“我是个懦夫，我受不了。”

Q: Oh. Then we can fill in your script diagram with that. ( Figure 19C .) Up above, I imagine his Parent was telling you to be brave, but down below his Child was telling your Child that in the end you’ll both be cowards. What did your mother tell you up above?

问：哦。那我们就可以用这个来完善你的脚本图了。（图19C）我猜想，上面他父母的角色是在告诉你要勇敢，而下面他孩子的角色则是在告诉你孩子，最终你们都会成为懦夫。你母亲在上面跟你说了什么？

C: Be a good girl so people will like you.

C：做个乖女孩，这样别人才会喜欢你。

Clooney’s main complaint is being scared of people. Since she doesn’t know how to talk to strangers, she would rather stay home with her children than go to parties. Both her parents are likewise socially anxious and awkward. The script matrix ( Figure 19C ) takes account of all these factors.

克鲁尼的主要问题是害怕与人交往。由于她不知道如何与陌生人交谈，她宁愿待在家里陪孩子，也不愿参加聚会。她的父母也同样有社交焦虑和笨拙。剧本矩阵（图 19C）考虑到了所有这些因素。

1 PP:Mother’s Parent saying ‘Be a good girl.’ (Precept)

1 PP：母亲的父母说“要做个好女孩”。（箴言）

2 CC:Mother’s Child saying ‘Do naughty embarrassing things.’ (Provocation)

2 CC：母亲的孩子说“做些淘气又尴尬的事”。（挑衅）

3 AA:Mother’s Adult showing her how to be an awkward social coward. (Pattern)

3 AA：母亲作为成年人，教她如何成为一个笨拙的社交懦夫。（模式）

4 PC:Mother’s Parent rebuking her for being naughty. (Prohibition)

4. 母亲的父母责备她淘气。（禁止）

5 PP:Father’s Parent saying ‘Be brave.’ (Precept)

5 PP：父亲的父母说“要勇敢”。（箴言）

6 CC:Father’s Child saying: ‘We’ll both be cowards.’ (Seduction)

6 CC：父亲的孩子说：“我们都会成为懦夫。”（诱惑）

7 AA:Father’s Adult showing her how to be a coward. (Pattern)

7 AA：父亲作为成年人，教她如何做一个懦夫。（模式）

8 PC:Father’s Parent rebuking her for being a coward. (Prohibition)

8. PC：父亲的父母斥责她是懦夫。（禁止）

Here the script directives seem to be equally distributed between both parents. Both of them are showing her how to be a coward, and both of them are making her feel guilty. So she has no one to support her when she is afraid, and no one to appeal to when she feels remorse. That’s why she feels lonely. But her mother’s Child is spunky, so Clooney has permission to do impulsive spunky things like taking her clothes off, since she knows mother really thinks (or once thought) that to be cute. Then she suffers for it later when both Parents move in on her.

剧本的指令似乎平均分配给了父母双方。他们都在教她如何懦弱，也都在让她感到内疚。所以，当她害怕时，没有人支持她；当她感到懊悔时，也没有人可以倾诉。这就是她感到孤独的原因。但她母亲的孩子性格活泼，所以克鲁尼被允许做一些冲动而活泼的事情，比如脱衣服，因为她知道母亲真的觉得（或者曾经觉得）这很可爱。然后，当父母都搬来和她同住时，她就为此付出了代价。

C: You know this is the first time I’ve really seen what my father did in this picture, although we’ve talked about it before. But now I really get it.

C：你知道吗，虽然我们之前也谈过这件事，但这是我第一次真正理解我父亲在这张照片里所做的一切。但现在我完全明白了。

Q: There’s an awful lot here for one session.

问：一次课程的内容太多了。

C: Yes, I understand part of it, but the rest I’ll have to think about.

C：是的，我明白一部分，但其余的我需要好好想想。

Q: Yes, you may not understand it all by next week, but don’t get flustered, we’ll go over it again.

问：是的，你可能下周还不能完全理解，但别慌张，我们会再讲一遍。

There’s one more thing I want to say. We can see how your Child acts up and your Parent makes you feel guilty. And you can see that actually your mother kept you in the Child position, and so did your husband, because they both needed you to be like that. In that way you were just a puppet in their scripts. But I guess you contributed your fifty per cent in continuing that kind of relationship. The question is, where is your Adult in all this?

还有一件事我想说。我们可以看到你的孩子如何表现叛逆，你的父母如何让你感到内疚。你也应该明白，实际上你的母亲和丈夫都把你塑造成了孩子，因为他们都需要你那样。在他们看来，你只是他们剧本里的傀儡。但我想，你也为维持这种关系贡献了自己一半的责任。问题是，在这一切中，你的“成人”在哪里？

One of the things that happened today is that when you came in, you half shut the door. You didn’t either leave it open for me to shut, or shut it yourself.

今天发生的一件事是，你进来的时候，门只关了一半。你既没把门敞开让我关上，也没自己关上。

C: But it’s your door.

C：但这是你的门。

Q: But it’s your interview. Why do I have a door?

问：但这是你面试啊。为什么我面前会有扇门？

C: So someone in the waiting room won’t overhear me.

C：这样候诊室里的人就不会听到我说话了。

Q: Well, do you want them to overhear you?

问：那你希望他们听到你们的对话吗？

C: He, he, he. Maybe I do.

C：呵呵，呵呵，呵呵。也许吧。

Q: Well, it’s your session, so in that sense it’s your door.

问：嗯，这是你的时段，所以从这个意义上讲，这是你的选择。

C: Yes, but I wouldn’t dare take over a thing like that.

C：是的，但我不敢接手这样的事情。

Dr Q did not respond to this. He was thinking. If she were confident and straight, she’d either walk in and let him shut the door, or else close it herself. Well, she had half an Adult, so she shut it halfway. At the social level, she didn’t feel enough of a lady to leave it up to him, but she was afraid or embarrassed to shut it completely herself, so she compromised. As a Good Little Girl she made the gesture, and as an almost woman, she let him finish the job. At the psychological level it was different. She was shy about speaking up in the group, but her Child was willing or even hoping to be ‘overheard’ through a half-open door, especially when there was really nobody in the next room to overhear her. That all came under the heading of ‘exposing herself,’ but these games would have to be dealt with later. She had had enough for one day. Finally he said:

Q医生没有回应。他陷入了沉思。如果她自信又坦率，要么会走进去让他关门，要么自己关上。然而，她只有半个成年人的意识，所以只关了一半。从社交层面来说，她觉得自己不够淑女，无法完全依赖他，但她又害怕或不好意思自己把门完全关上，所以她妥协了。她像个乖乖女一样做了这个动作，又像个准女人一样，让他完成了剩下的工作。从心理层面来说，情况就不同了。她在小组里不好意思发言，但她内心的孩子却愿意，甚至希望透过半开的门“被人听到”，尤其是在隔壁房间根本没人的情况下。这一切都属于“暴露自己”的范畴，但这些游戏以后再说吧。她今天已经受够了。最后，他说：

Q: Anyway, that’s where your Adult comes into the picture: what you decide to do, like close the door or leave it open. Well, I’ll see you next week at the same time.

问：总之，这就需要你这个成年人来决定了：比如，你决定关上门还是敞开着门。好的，我们下周同一时间再见。

FIGURE 19A

图 19A

FIGURE 19B

图 19B

FIGURE 19C

图 19C

This interview was the culmination of many years of work. When Clooney first came, the doctor knew very little about scripts. Now he knew a great deal more and had a lively interest in the subject. Clooney knew a great deal more, too, and was ready to get well, with some assistance from her husband, who was now an amateur but shrewd script analyst at second hand. Sessions with Clooney were generally difficult and unproductive. She was usually droopy and plaintive, demanding reassurance from the doctor, asking him unanswerable questions, getting annoyed when he did not give the right answers, and playing ‘Yes But’ if he tried. This time she was animated and receptive and thoughtful. She leaned forward in her chair instead of drooping, and so did he. They both talked in a quick and lively way. Her Child had given up moaning and making progress in favor of getting well, so her Adult was free to listen and think. She was willing to look at her own father instead of seeing Dr Q as a father. That freed her to listen to his Adult, instead of hearing him as a critical Parent. She was transformed from a patient with a ‘Wooden Brain’ into a real person with some problems (such as ‘expressing herself’) to be solved. All her life she had been flipped out, and this was the week she flipped in.

这次面谈是多年努力的结晶。克鲁尼第一次来的时候，医生对剧本知之甚少。如今，他了解得多了，也对这个领域产生了浓厚的兴趣。克鲁尼的了解也更加深入，她渴望康复，这得益于她丈夫的帮助——他现在虽然是业余的，但却是一位精明的剧本分析师。与克鲁尼的会谈通常都很困难，而且收效甚微。她总是垂头丧气，怨天尤人，不断地向医生寻求安慰，问一些根本无法回答的问题，如果医生没有给出正确的答案，她就会恼火，如果医生试图给出答案，她还会反驳。但这一次，她精神焕发，积极倾听，并且深思熟虑。她不再垂头丧气，而是向前倾身坐在椅子上，医生也一样。他们两人都语速很快，谈吐生动。她的孩子已经放弃了抱怨和追求进步，转而专注于康复，所以她成熟的一面可以自由地倾听和思考。她愿意把目光投向自己的父亲，而不是把Q医生当作父亲。这让她能够以成年人的视角倾听他，而不是把他当作一个苛刻的家长。她从一个“大脑僵化”的病人，变成了一个有血有肉、需要解决一些问题（比如“表达自我”）的真人。她一生都处于一种崩溃的状态，而这周，她终于恢复了正常。

She was now in a good position to consider objectively the body aspects of her script, where her buttocks played an important role. Through her blushing Child, they controlled how she sat, how she walked, what she was afraid of, what she wanted to do, and how the Child in other people reacted to her. This level was the Child in her Child, much of which is what psychoanalysis calls ‘the unconscious.’ It remained, therefore, to dig up the long forgotten transactions with her parents which focused her fears, desires, and attention on this part of her body. And that had to be done under careful Adult and therapeutic control so that she would be able to handle the confusing and dangerous feelings usually connected with blushing buttocks.

她现在能够客观地审视自己剧本中关于身体的各个方面，其中臀部扮演着重要的角色。通过她内心那个容易脸红的“孩子”，她学会了控制自己的坐姿、走路姿势、恐惧的事物、想要做的事情，以及他人内心那个“孩子”对她的反应。这一层面就是她内心深处的“孩子”，其中很大一部分正是精神分析所说的“无意识”。因此，接下来要做的就是挖掘出那些早已被遗忘的、与父母之间的互动，正是这些互动将她的恐惧、欲望和注意力集中在了身体的这个部位。而这一切必须在成人的谨慎引导和治疗下进行，这样她才能处理那些通常与脸红相关的令人困惑和危险的情绪。

B • Victor

B • 维克多

When Victor came for treatment, he was heavily involved in games with his superior, an aging elephant who played ‘Now I’ve Got You.’ Victor responded with ‘Look How Hard I’ve Tried,’ ‘There I Go Again,’ and ‘Kick Me.’ When Victor was about to leave for a new job, his wife said to a friend: ‘He’s going to try it and see how it works out.’

维克多来接受治疗时，正和他的上司——一头年迈的大象——玩着游戏，大象玩的是“现在我抓到你了”。维克多则回应着“看看我有多努力”、“我又来了”和“踢我”。维克多即将离开去新工作时，他的妻子对一位朋友说：“他打算去试试，看看效果如何。”

‘I’m not going to try it,’ said Victor. ‘I’m going to do it.’

“我不是要试探，”维克多说，“我要去做。”

‘So you’ve finally given up that trying stuff!’ said the friend.

“所以你终于放弃尝试那些事了！”朋友说。

‘Well, so now you’ve got permission to succeed,’ said Dr Q, when Victor related this anecdote.

“好吧，现在你获得了成功的许可，”当维克多讲述这个轶事时，Q 博士说道。

‘It’s not that I’ve got permission to succeed,’ replied Victor. ‘What I’ve got is permission to stop “trying.”’

“并不是说我被允许成功，”维克多回答说，“而是说我被允许停止‘尝试’。”

‘How does that work?’ asked Dr Q.

Q博士问道：“这是怎么回事？”

‘My mother used to say: “Keep trying, and if it doesn’t work, it’ll be all right anyway.” Now that I know Martian, I can see that my Child translated that into “Don’t succeed, it’s better to go home to mother.” So I need to be released from trying, so I can just do it. I’m a big boy now. Well, can you give me the names of some people in New York?’

“我妈妈以前常说：‘坚持尝试，就算失败了也没关系。’现在我懂了火星语，我才明白我的孩子把这句话翻译成了‘别成功了，还不如回家找妈妈。’所以我需要从尝试中解脱出来，这样我才能真正去做。我现在是个大男孩了。对了，你能告诉我一些纽约人的名字吗？”

Something made Dr Q hesitate, but since it was customary to give patients the names of some people when they were moving to another city, he looked in his psychiatric directory and gave Victor the names and addresses of two doctors back East.

Q 医生有些犹豫，但由于按照惯例，当病人搬到另一个城市时，要给他们一些人的姓名，所以他查阅了自己的精神病学名录，给了维克多两位东部医生的姓名和地址。

‘Will you send them my chart, or whatever your records are?’

“你会把我的图表或者你的任何记录发给他们吗？”

This time Dr Q listened to his intuition, and replied:

这一次，Q博士听从了自己的直觉，回答道：

‘Not unless they ask.’

“除非他们主动要求。”

‘How come?’

'怎么会？'

‘Well, now you’re well, you’re supposed to have left all that behind. If something goes wrong, you can tell them about it yourself.’ Now he knew what was wrong. Victor had freed himself from the elephant and also from Dr Q, but in his Child mind, he was already under the protection of the two psychiatrists back East, and to that extent had given up some of his newly won, and hard-won, autonomy. ‘I’ll tell you what. Burn that paper with the two names on it.’

“好了，现在你康复了，应该已经把那些都抛在脑后了。如果出了什么事，你可以自己告诉他们。”现在他明白了问题所在。维克多虽然摆脱了大象和Q博士的控制，但在他孩童般的认知里，他已经受到东部两位精神科医生的保护，某种程度上，他放弃了一些来之不易的自主权。“我告诉你，把那张写着两个名字的纸烧掉。”

‘But I’ll remember them anyway, so I might as well just carry it in my wallet.’

“但我反正都会记住的，所以不如就把它们放在钱包里吧。”

‘Burn it.’

“烧掉它。”

‘A ritual,’ said Victor.

“一种仪式，”维克多说。

‘That’s right. It’s your Adult telling your Child you can sacrifice them and make it on your own.’

“没错。这是成年人在告诉你的孩子，你可以牺牲他们，靠自己成功。”

Victor looked at him, and Dr Q knew what he was thinking. (‘I’ll try.’)

维克多看了他一眼，Q博士知道他在想什么。（“我会试试。”）

‘Burn it,’ he repeated.

“烧掉它，”他重复道。

Victor smiled. The session was over. They rose and shook hands, and that was the end of Victor’s treatment.

维克多笑了。疗程结束了。他们起身握手，维克多的治疗也就此结束。

C • Jan and Bill

C • Jan 和 Bill

Jan and Bill came to Dr Q with a request for group therapy. They had been in transactional analytic groups (or ‘TA groups,’ as they called them) for about a year with several different therapists who worked together, and they had also been in four or five ‘marathons.’ They both felt grateful for these experiences, which had brought them closer together, and also had other beneficial results. It was evident that they were very much in love after three years of marriage, and that they were very fond of their two babies.

简和比尔来找Q医生，希望参加团体治疗。他们之前参加过大约一年的交互分析小组（他们称之为“TA小组”），由几位不同的治疗师共同指导，他们还参加过四五次“马拉松式”治疗。他们都对这些经历心存感激，这些经历不仅拉近了彼此的距离，也带来了其他益处。结婚三年后，他们显然依然恩爱如初，而且非常疼爱他们的两个孩子。

‘How long is it since you’ve been in the group?’ asked Dr Q.

Q 博士问道：“你加入这个小组有多久了？”

Bill looked at Jan. She smiled at him and replied:

比尔看着简。简对他笑了笑，回答道：

‘We stopped about a year ago.’

“我们大约一年前就停止了。”

‘Well, why do you want to start again?’

“那么，你为什么想重新开始呢？”

‘There are a lot of things that could be improved,’ said Bill. ‘I feel good most of the time, but I’d like to feel good all the time.’

比尔说：“有很多方面可以改进。我大部分时间感觉都不错，但我希望一直都感觉不错。”

‘That’s a pretty tough assignment,’ said Dr Q.

Q博士说：“那真是一项艰巨的任务。”

‘Well, I can be more specific than that,’ Bill continued. ‘My job of selling rare books is really a matter of relating to people. Before I went into TA, I would never have thought that I could be a salesman, but now I am, and a good one. But I could do better if my Adult stayed in control even under stress. For instance, I think I’m due for a raise. I make about eight hundred dollars a month now, which is the most I’ve ever earned in my life, and it’s the first time we’ve ever been able to get the things we wanted instead of living on the edge all the time.

“嗯，我可以说得更具体些，”比尔继续说道。“我卖珍稀书籍的工作其实就是与人建立联系。在从事TA工作之前，我从没想过自己能当销售员，但现在我成了销售员，而且还做得不错。不过，如果我的‘成人’（指我的内在动力）即使在压力下也能保持理智，我还能做得更好。比如说，我觉得我应该涨工资了。我现在每月收入大约八百美元，这是我这辈子赚到的最高收入，也是我们第一次能够买到想要的东西，而不是一直过着捉襟见肘的生活。”

‘But asking for a raise is not easy in a small establishment with only two or three employees, and I think my boss would rather not give me one. But I know the business well enough and I’m effective enough to deserve one. I could never have said something like that two years ago, but now I really believe it. The problem is to keep my Adult on the ball and not let my Child take over at the critical moment and start some games going. I’ve also got to know what my boss is up to, because he has some games of his own. So I can either flub it by asking for it in such a way as not to get it, and then get mad, which would be dangerous and unnecessary, or I can cut through his games and get him to sit down with me and figure out how much I’m worth. So I need a little help right now to do that.

“但在只有两三个员工的小公司里，要求加薪并不容易，而且我觉得老板并不想给我加薪。但我对业务足够了解，工作能力也足够强，理应得到加薪。两年前我绝对不敢这么说，但现在我真的相信自己可以。问题在于，我该如何保持理智，而不是在关键时刻让孩子气占据上风，耍些小花招。我还得了解老板的意图，因为他也有自己的一套伎俩。所以我可以选择用一种不恰当的方式提出加薪要求，结果却不成功，然后大发雷霆，这既危险又没必要；或者我可以识破他的伎俩，让他坐下来和我好好谈谈，评估一下我的价值。所以，我现在需要一些帮助。”

‘I think what I really want and need is a little more work on my script. My father was an alcoholic and my mother went along with it, so I have a failure script always lurking in the background. That’s why I still goof up occasionally, and I want to stop it. So I need some more understanding of my script and some good permissions. Is that a good enough contract for us to work with?’

“我觉得我真正需要的是对我的剧本进行更多打磨。我父亲酗酒，母亲也纵容他，所以我的剧本一直潜藏着失败的阴影。这就是为什么我偶尔还会犯错，而我想要改掉这个毛病。所以我需要更深入地了解我的剧本，并获得一些必要的授权。这样的合同足够我们合作吗？”

‘I’m not sure yet,’ said Dr Q. ‘Is there anything more specific?’

Q博士说：“我还不确定。还有更具体的要求吗？”

‘I still do drink more often than I think I should to do the best job,’ said Bill.

“我仍然比我认为应该做的更频繁地喝酒，这样才能把工作做到最好，”比尔说。

‘How about an anti- “Alcoholic” contract to start with?’ suggested Dr Q. ‘That’ll help us get at your script and strengthen your Adult, too.’

“不如先签订一份反‘酗酒’协议怎么样？”Q博士建议道，“这有助于我们了解你的病情，也能加强你的成人治疗效果。”

‘That sounds fine for a start,’ said Bill.

“听起来不错，可以先试试看，”比尔说。

‘What do you want to get out of it, Jan?’

“简，你想从中得到什么？”

‘I want my Child to be freer and more creative. I’m a lab technician and I still work part-time at that, but I started writing after I got into Dr X’s group and I’m doing well at it. I just want to do better. I have a lot of witch instructions from my mother that my Child is still scared of, and that interferes. Also, I need regular stroking to keep happy, and I could do better at getting it.’

“我希望我的孩子更自由、更有创造力。我是一名实验室技术员，现在还在兼职做这行，但自从加入X博士的小组后，我开始写作，而且写得还不错。我只是想做得更好。我有很多母亲传下来的巫术指令，我的孩子仍然很害怕，这影响了我的创作。另外，我需要经常被抚摸才能保持快乐，但我在这方面做得还可以更好。”

‘Tell me a dream,’ requested Dr Q.

Q医生请求道：“请告诉我一个梦。”

‘I used to have the most horrible nightmares. You see I spent a couple of years in my childhood being bombed and running for air-raid shelters in London, and I only saw my father once, when he was on leave, during that period. But now I have beautiful dreams, soaring and flying and beautiful colors.’

“我以前经常做可怕的噩梦。你知道，我小时候有几年时间伦敦遭受轰炸，我只能躲进防空洞，那段时间我只见过我父亲一次，当时他正在休假。但现在我做的都是美丽的梦，梦里我翱翔、飞翔，到处都是美丽的色彩。”

‘Dr X seems to have done an awfully good job for both of you,’ said Dr Q. ‘Why do you want to come into my groups?’

Q医生说：“X医生似乎对你们俩都非常尽心尽力。你们为什么想加入我的小组呢？”

‘He certainly did a lot for us,’ said Bill. ‘But toward the end we seemed to have reached a plateau, and we think you might have some fresh ideas for us. We’re still far from perfect. We both started out as frogs, and now Jan is certainly a princess and I think I can learn to be a prince.’

“他确实帮了我们很多，”比尔说。“但到了后期，我们似乎遇到了瓶颈，我们觉得你或许能给我们一些新的想法。我们离完美还差得很远。我们俩一开始都像青蛙一样笨拙，现在简已经是一位公主了，我想我也能学会成为一位王子。”

Jan smiled when he said that, a beautiful smile that certainly belonged to a princess. But she still had some remnants of her war neurosis. She no longer panicked when she heard loud sounds, but they did disturb her train of thought. So in her case they agreed on a contract to cure her vestiges of apprehension. That should release her creative Child still further, which was her main goal, and also make her more comfortable with the children and them more comfortable, too. Dr Q had no doubt that Dr X would be agreeable to these undertakings, so he proceeded to take a psychiatric and medical history from each of them as a preparation for coming into one of his groups.

简听到这话时笑了，那笑容美得像公主一般。但她身上仍然残留着一些战争带来的神经质。她不再像以前那样听到巨响就惊慌失措，但巨响仍然会打断她的思路。因此，他们达成了一项协议，旨在治愈她残存的恐惧。这应该能进一步释放她内心深处的创造力，这也是她的主要目标，同时也能让她和孩子们相处得更自在，孩子们也会更放松。Q博士确信X博士会同意这些方案，于是他开始分别询问他们的精神病史和病史，作为他们加入他的小组的准备工作。

This case illustrates the convenience of transactional analysis. Jan and Bill and their therapists all spoke the same language, so the couple could transfer from one therapist to another anywhere along the line without noticeably retarding their rate of improvement. Although Dr Q was a stranger to both of them, they had no difficulty in explaining to him what they had accomplished so far and what more they hoped to do. They also knew where the difficulties lay and were able to explain that in simple language that all three of them understood.

这个案例体现了人际沟通分析的便捷性。简和比尔以及他们的治疗师都使用同一种语言，因此这对夫妇可以在治疗过程中随时更换治疗师，而不会明显影响他们的康复速度。尽管Q医生对他们来说是个陌生人，但他们仍然能够轻松地向他解释他们迄今为止取得的成就以及他们希望达成的目标。他们也清楚自己面临的困难所在，并且能够用三人都能理解的简单语言进行解释。

When they started in the group, they were able to explain to the other patients exactly where they stood, and the other patients knew what they were talking about. And by listening to the others, Jan and Bill could soon see how far along each one was and where he was headed. This took up their first meeting. After that, they were ready to engage in more personal transactions with the other patients, who were soon able to find traces of Bill’s alcoholic Father Parent, Jan’s Witch Mother, and other significant items. All this was possible because everyone spoke the same simple language and meant the same thing when he used the same word. And the most useful words were basic English ones, which could be understood by a kindergarten child out of his own experience: parent, adult, child, games, permission, and script. (Children who don’t understand ‘Script’ can understand ‘What you’re going to do with your life.’)

他们刚加入小组时，就能向其他病友清晰地解释自己的处境，而其他病友也都能理解他们的感受。通过倾听其他病友的讲述，简和比尔很快就能了解每个人的进展以及未来的方向。这构成了他们第一次小组会议的内容。之后，他们便开始与其他病友进行更深入的交流。其他病友很快就能从比尔的酗酒父亲、简的巫婆母亲以及其他一些重要经历中找到蛛丝马迹。这一切之所以成为可能，是因为每个人都说着同一种简单易懂的语言，同一个词的意思也完全一致。而最常用的词汇都是一些基本的英语词汇，即使是幼儿园的孩子也能根据自身经验理解：父母、成人、孩子、游戏、许可和剧本。（即使孩子不理解“剧本”这个词，也能理解“你的人生目标是什么”。）

#↩

PART V

第五部分

Scientific Approaches to Script Theory

脚本理论的科学方法

#↩

CHAPTER TWENTY-ONE

第二十一章

Objections to the Theory of Script

对文字理论的反对意见

Many people object to the theory of scripts, each from his own point of view. The more satisfactorily these objections can be answered, the stronger the inference that script theory is valid.

许多人对脚本理论持反对意见，每个人都从各自的角度出发。对这些反对意见的回应越令人满意，就越能有力地证明脚本理论的有效性。

A • Spiritual Objections

A • 精神上的反对意见

Some people feel intuitively that the theory of scripts cannot be valid because it is contrary to the destiny of man as a creature of free will. The whole idea arouses in them a kind of revulsion, since it appears to reduce mankind to a mechanism without a vitality to call his own, very much as, in its extreme form, conditioning theory does. These people are also, and for the same humanitarian reasons, uneasy about psychoanalytic theory, which in one form constricts man into a closed-off, cybernetic energy system with only a few restricted input and output channels, and leaves no room for his godhead. These are the moral descendants of people who felt the same way about the Darwinian theory of natural selection, which in their minds reduced the processes of life to mechanics and left no room for Mother Nature’s creativity. They, in turn, are the descendants of those who found Galileo intolerably impudent. Nevertheless, such objections, arising as they do from a philanthropic regard for human dignity, must be treated with proper consideration. The answer, or apology if you will, is as follows:

有些人凭直觉感到脚本理论不成立，因为它违背了人类作为自由意志生物的命运。这种理论在他们心中激起一种反感，因为它似乎将人类简化为一台没有自身生命力的机器，这与极端形式的条件反射理论非常相似。出于同样的人道主义原因，这些人也对精神分析理论感到不安，因为精神分析理论在某种程度上将人限制在一个封闭的、控制论式的能量系统中，只有少数受限的输入输出通道，完全不给人类的神性留下任何空间。这些人是那些对达尔文自然选择理论抱有同样感受的人的道德继承者，在他们看来，达尔文的自然选择理论将生命过程简化为机械运动，完全无视大自然的创造力。而他们又是那些认为伽利略傲慢无礼的人的继承者。然而，这些出于对人类尊严的博爱而产生的反对意见，必须得到妥善的对待。答案，或者说道歉，如下：

1. Structural analysis does not pretend to answer all questions about human behavior. It states certain propositions about observable social behavior, and about inner experiences, and these propositions are valid. It does not deal, formally at least, with the essence of being, the Self. It deliberately provides a concept which is beyond its province, the construct of free cathexis, wherein that Self resides, and thereby sets aside a whole field, in many respects the most crucial one, for philosophers, metaphysicians, theologians, and poets to deal with as they see fit. It in no way attempts to encroach on this well-defined area, and expects the same courtesy in return from those who do deal with the problem of man’s essence or Self. It has no desire to intrude into either the ivory tower, the cathedral, the minstrel’s pad, or the courtroom, but on the other hand, neither does it expect to be dragged into any of them against its will.

1. 结构分析并不试图解答所有关于人类行为的问题。它阐述了一些关于可观察的社会行为和内在体验的命题，而这些命题是有效的。至少在形式上，它并不涉及存在的本质——自我。它刻意提供了一个超出其范畴的概念——自由投注的建构，自我就存在于其中，从而为哲学家、形而上学家、神学家和诗人划出了一个领域，在许多方面，这都是至关重要的领域，供他们根据自己的需要进行探讨。它绝无意侵犯这个界限分明的领域，并期望那些研究人类本质或自我问题的学者也能给予同样的尊重。它既不想闯入象牙塔、大教堂、吟游诗人的住所，也不想被强行拖入其中，但另一方面，它也不希望违背自己的意愿被卷入其中。

2. Script theory does not pretend that all human behavior is directed by the script. It leaves as much room as possible for autonomy, and indeed, autonomy is its ideal. It only states that relatively few people attain it completely, and then only on special occasions. Its whole purpose is to increase the distribution of that invaluable commodity, and it offers a method for doing so. But the first requirement is to separate the spurious from the genuine, and that is its whole task. It does forthrightly call a chain a chain, however, and this should not be taken as an insult by those who love their chains or choose to ignore them.

2. 脚本理论并非声称所有人类行为都受脚本支配。它尽可能地为自主性留出空间，事实上，自主性正是其理想。它只是指出，只有极少数人能够完全实现自主性，而且只有在特殊情况下才能做到。其全部目的在于增加这种宝贵资源的分配，并为此提供了一种方法。但首要条件是区分真假，而这正是其全部任务。然而，它直言不讳地将锁链称为锁链，这不应被那些热爱锁链或选择无视锁链的人视为冒犯。

B • Philosophical Objections

B • 哲学上的反对意见

These are both transcendental and existential. Script analysis sees imperatives as directives from the parents, the purpose of most existences being to carry out those directives. If the philosopher says: ‘I think, therefore I am,’ the script analyst asks: ‘Yes, but how do you know what to think?’ The philosopher answers: ‘Yes, but that’s not what I’m talking about.’ Because they are both saying ‘Yes, but’ it appears that they will get nowhere. But this is a misapprehension that can be easily clarified.

这些既是超越性的，也是存在性的。脚本分析将命令视为来自父母的指令，大多数人存在的目的就是为了执行这些指令。如果哲学家说：“我思故我在”，脚本分析家会问：“是的，但你怎么知道该想什么呢？”哲学家回答：“是的，但这并不是我要说的。”因为他们都在说“是的，但是”，所以看起来他们似乎无法达成共识。但这是一种误解，很容易澄清。

1. The script analyst deals only with phenomena, and does not intrude on the territory of the transcendentalist. What he says is: ‘If you stop thinking the way your parents ordered you to think, and start thinking for yourself, you will think better.’ If the philosopher objects that he is already thinking for himself, the script analyst may have to tell him that that is to some extent an illusion, and furthermore, that it is the one illusion he cannot afford. The philosopher may not like that, but the script analyst has to stick to what he knows. Thus, the conflict, as is the case with the spiritual objectors, is between something the philosopher doesn’t like and something the script analyst knows, and there the matter must rest until the philosopher is willing to take himself more seriously.

1. 剧本分析师只关注现象，并不涉足先验论者的领域。他会说：“如果你不再按照父母教你的方式思考，而是开始独立思考，你的思考能力就会更强。”如果哲学家反驳说他已经在独立思考了，剧本分析师或许不得不告诉他，这在某种程度上是一种错觉，而且，这是他无法承受的错觉。哲学家可能不喜欢这样，但剧本分析师必须坚持自己的认知。因此，正如那些精神层面的反对者一样，冲突在于哲学家不喜欢的东西和剧本分析师知道的东西之间，而这个问题只能暂时搁置，直到哲学家愿意更认真地看待自己。

2. When the script analyst says: ‘The purpose of most existences is to carry out the parental directives,’ the existentialist objects: ‘But that is not really a purpose in the sense I use the word.’ To which the script analyst replies: ‘If you find a better one, let me know.’ What he means is that the individual cannot even begin to think of finding a better purpose as long as he is content to follow his parental directives. What he offers is autonomy. The existentialist then says: ‘Yes, but my problem is what do you do with autonomy after you have it?’ The script analyst replies: ‘I don’t know any more than you do about that. All I know is that some people are less miserable than others because they have more options in life.’

2. 当剧本分析师说：“大多数人存在的目的就是执行父母的指示”时，存在主义者反驳道：“但这并非我所理解的‘目的’。”剧本分析师回答说：“如果你找到了更好的目的，请告诉我。”他的意思是，只要一个人满足于遵循父母的指示，他就根本无法思考寻找更好的目的。他所提供的是自主性。存在主义者接着说：“是的，但我的问题是，拥有自主性之后该如何运用它？”剧本分析师回答说：“对此我并不比你懂得多。我只知道，有些人比其他人更不痛苦，因为他们在生活中拥有更多选择。”

C • Rational Objections

C • 理性反对意见

The rational objection is: ‘You yourself said that the function of the Adult is to make rational decisions, and that everybody has an Adult to make them with. How then can you also say that the decisions have already been made by the Child?’

合理的反对意见是：“你自己也说过，成年人的职责是做出理性的决定，而且每个人都有一个成年人可以和他们一起做决定。那么，你怎么能说这些决定已经由孩子做出了呢？”

A good point. But there are hierarchies of decisions, and the highest level is the decision to follow or not to follow a script, and until that decision is made, all other decisions will not avail to change the individual’s ultimate destiny. The hierarchy goes as follows: (1) To follow or not to follow a script. (2) If a script, which one? If not a script, what to do instead? (3) ‘Permanent’ decisions: to get married or not, to have children or not, to commit suicide, to kill somebody, to go crazy, to resign or get fired, or to succeed. (4) ‘Instrumental’ decisions: which girl to marry, how many children to have, how to commit suicide, etc. (5) ‘Temporal’ decisions: when to get married, when to have children, when to commit suicide, etc. (6) ‘Expedient’ decisions: how much money to give your wife, which school to send your children to, etc. (7) ‘Urgent’ decisions: whether to go to the party or stay home and have sex, whether to spank your son or scold him, whether to visit the prospect today or tomorrow, etc. Each level in this hierarchy is subject to all the higher ones, and each lower level is trivial compared to the ones above it. Yet all levels contribute directly to the final outcome, and are designed to bring it about more effectively, whether that is script directed or autonomously chosen. Therefore, until the first decision is made, no other decisions are ‘rational’ in an ultimate existential sense, but are ‘directed’ decisions rationalized on spurious grounds.

你说得对。但决策是有层级的，最高层级是是否遵循既定剧本的决定。在做出这个决定之前，其他所有决定都无法改变个人的最终命运。这个层级如下：（1）是否遵循既定剧本。（2）如果是剧本，是哪一套？如果不是剧本，该怎么做？（3）“永久性”决定：结婚还是不结婚，生孩子还是不生孩子，自杀还是杀人，精神崩溃还是辞职或被解雇，以及是否成功。 （4）“工具性”决策：娶哪个女孩，生几个孩子，如何自杀等等。（5）“时间性”决策：何时结婚，何时生育，何时自杀等等。（6）“权宜性”决策：给妻子多少钱，送孩子去哪所学校等等。（7）“紧急性”决策：去参加聚会还是待在家里做爱，打儿子屁股还是训斥他，今天还是明天去见心仪对象等等。这个层级中的每一层都受到上一层的影响，每一层都显得微不足道。然而，所有层级都直接影响最终结果，并且都是为了更有效地实现最终结果而设计的，无论这种结果是由既定的程序引导还是自主选择的。因此，在做出第一个决策之前，从根本的存在主义意义上讲，其他任何决策都不是“理性的”，而是基于虚假理由而合理化的“受引导的”决策。

‘But,’ says the rational objector, ‘there is no script.’

“但是，”理性的反对者说，“没有剧本。”

Since this is a rational objector, and he is not saying that merely because script theory makes him nervous, we take the trouble to answer him. This is our chance to make a very strong inference. First we ask him if he had read this book carefully, and then we offer him some of our strongest arguments, which may or may not convince him.

既然这位反对者是理性的，而且他并非仅仅因为脚本理论让他感到不安才提出异议，我们就应该认真回应他。这是我们做出有力推论的机会。首先，我们询问他是否仔细阅读过这本书，然后提出一些我们最有力的论据，这些论据或许能说服他，或许不能。

Suppose then that there is no script. In that case (a) People do not hear voices in their heads telling them what to do, or if they do hear them, they always act independently (i.e., neither in compliance nor rebellion) of these voices; (b) People with many different voices telling them what to do (e.g., people raised in a series of foster homes) are as sure of themselves as people raised in one stable home; (c) People who shoot drugs or overdrink or move their bowels on the floor (hippies of a certain type) will not usually feel that they are being pushed by inner forces beyond their control toward a well-defined destiny, but instead regard each such act as an isolated, autonomous decision. Or alternatively, the ‘inner forces’ are irreversible and not subject to change by psychological methods.

那么假设不存在既定的剧本。在这种情况下，(a) 人们不会听到脑海中有声音告诉他们该做什么，或者即使听到了，他们的行为也总是独立于这些声音之外（即既不顺从也不反抗）；(b) 那些脑海中充斥着各种不同声音的人（例如，在多个寄养家庭长大的人）与那些在一个稳定的家庭中长大的人一样自信；(c) 那些吸毒、酗酒或在地板上大小便的人（某些类型的嬉皮士）通常不会觉得自己被某种无法控制的内在力量推向一个既定的命运，而是将每一次这样的行为都视为一个孤立的、自主的决定。或者，这种“内在力量”是不可逆转的，无法通过心理方法改变。

If all, or perhaps even any, of these hypotheses are true, then perhaps there is no script. But the clinical evidence is that they are all false, therefore there is a script.

如果所有这些假设，或者哪怕其中任何一个假设都成立，那么或许根本不存在什么既定的剧本。但临床证据表明，这些假设都是错误的，因此，剧本是存在的。

D • Doctrinal Objections

D • 教义异议

Doctrinal objections fall into two main classes: religious and psychoanalytic. From a religious point of view, the script question is one of predestination or something like it, vs . free will: Presbyterians vs . Jews, Roman Catholics vs . Christian Scientists, etc. Such differences in viewpoint, as they are usually stated, are beyond the province of scientific inquiry.

教义上的反对意见主要分为两类：宗教性的和精神分析性的。从宗教角度来看，剧本问题本质上是预定论或类似理论与自由意志之争：例如长老会教徒与犹太教徒、罗马天主教徒与基督教科学派教徒等等。通常认为，这种观点上的差异超出了科学探究的范畴。

The psychoanalytic objections are Jesuitical ones. As a doctrine, script analysis is not independent of or irrelevant to psychoanalysis, it is an extension of it, and hence is regarded by some as anti-analytic, and as, in effect, not paganism, but a heresy within the doctrine itself. Thus, the Monophysite heresy was merely an extension of Roman Catholic doctrine, and it made the Church much more uneasy than did paganism, for which the penalty was only conversion, rather than decapitation.

精神分析学的反对意见源于耶稣会。作为一种教义，脚本分析并非独立于精神分析之外或与之无关，而是精神分析的延伸，因此被一些人视为反分析的，实际上并非异教，而是教义内部的异端。因此，一性论异端仅仅是罗马天主教教义的延伸，它给教会带来的不安远比异教更大，因为异教的惩罚仅仅是皈依基督教，而非斩首。

In order to discuss the objections raised by some psychoanalysts (usually when confronted by a living staff member who actually wants to do script analysis in a psychoanalytically oriented clinic or hospital), it is necessary to find the meaning of ‘anti-analytic.’

为了讨论一些精神分析师提出的反对意见（通常是在面对一位在精神分析导向的诊所或医院中真正想进行脚本分析的在世工作人员时），有必要找出“反分析”的含义。

Script analysts subscribe to the doctrines of Freud in their entirety, and only wish to add something in the light of further experience. The differences between the orthodox view and that of script analysis is one of emphasis. Actually, script analysts are ‘better Freudians’ than orthodox analysts. The writer, for example, besides having repeated and confirmed the conventional observations of Freud, also believes right down the line with him concerning the death instinct, and the pervasiveness of the repetition compulsion. For this, he has been called ‘anti-Freudian.’ He also believes that short words can express what we know about the human mind more concisely, cogently, and intelligibly than long words, and that Freud’s terminology has been misused for a purpose which Freud himself would decry – to obscure the facts. He has been called ‘anti-analytic’ for this; not for doing anything about it, but merely for expressing the idea. 1 Script analysts believe in the unconscious, but they emphasize the conscious when dealing with patients for whom orthodox psychoanalysis is more or less unsuitable, according to Freud’s own statement. 2 Furthermore, script analysts do not pretend that what they do is psychoanalysis, since it isn’t. (Most therapists who do psychoanalytic therapy, which is not psychoanalysis, attempt to follow the rules laid down for psychoanalysis, which are of course inappropriate and hinder the treatment.) Hence, script analysis may be called ‘para-Freudian’ (by someone who has private reasons for making an issue of it), but cannot rightly be called anti-analytic, and certainly not anti-Freudian.

脚本分析师完全认同弗洛伊德的理论，并希望根据进一步的经验加以补充。正统观点与脚本分析之间的区别在于侧重点的不同。实际上，脚本分析师比正统分析师更“弗洛伊德”。例如，笔者除了重复并证实了弗洛伊德的传统观点外，在死亡本能和强迫性重复的普遍性方面也完全赞同弗洛伊德的观点。因此，他被称作“反弗洛伊德主义者”。他还认为，短词比长词更能简洁、有力、易懂地表达我们对人类心智的认知，并且弗洛伊德的术语被滥用，其目的正是弗洛伊德本人会谴责的——掩盖事实。因此，他被称作“反分析主义者”。并非为了采取任何行动，而仅仅是为了表达这种想法。 1 脚本分析师相信无意识的存在，但根据弗洛伊德本人的说法，当面对那些或多或少不适合正统精神分析的患者时，他们会强调意识层面。 2 此外，脚本分析师并不假装他们所做的是精神分析，因为它并非精神分析。（大多数进行精神分析疗法的治疗师，实际上并非精神分析，却试图遵循精神分析的规则，而这些规则显然是不恰当的，并且会阻碍治疗。）因此，脚本分析可能会被某些出于私人原因而称之为“准弗洛伊德主义”，但不能被恰当地称为反分析主义，当然更不能称之为反弗洛伊德主义。

Another doctrinal objection to script theory is that it is nothing new; it is merely Adler’s life style in more fashionable clothes, or an archer version of Jung’s archetypes, etc. The fact is that the facts were always there, and they were observed by many keen observers, and whether script theory corroborates what others have said, or they corroborate script theory, is immaterial. Freud takes seventy-nine pages (in my edition) to summarize the observations of his precursors in dream theory, many of whom made ‘psychoanalytic’ statements; Darwin takes only nine, but he quotes many ‘evolutionary’ statements made by others before him. But statements, however accurate and numerous, do not make a theory. The crux of script theory lies in structural analysis. Without the theory of ego states, and specifically Parent, Adult, and Child ego states, there can be an infinite number of pertinent observations and statements, but there can be no script theory. To be worthy of the name, any theory in any branch of science has to be based on structural elements, and without them it will fall like a house of cards, which may be pretty to look at, but has nothing to support it under the slightest adversity, and cannot bear anything but its own weight.

对脚本理论的另一个教义性反对意见是，它并非什么新鲜事物；它只不过是换了更时髦外衣的阿德勒的生活方式，或是荣格原型理论的弓箭手版本等等。事实上，事实一直存在，并且被许多敏锐的观察者所发现，而脚本理论是否印证了其他人的观点，或者其他人的观点是否印证了脚本理论，都无关紧要。弗洛伊德用了七十九页（在我读过的版本中）来总结梦境理论先驱们的观察结果，其中许多人发表了“精神分析”式的论述；达尔文只用了九页，但他引用了许多前人的“进化论”论述。然而，无论论述多么准确、多么众多，都不能构成理论。脚本理论的核心在于结构分析。如果没有自我状态理论，特别是父母、成人和儿童自我状态理论，即使有无数相关的观察和论述，也无从谈起脚本理论。任何科学分支中的任何理论，要想名副其实，都必须建立在结构要素之上；否则，它就会像纸牌屋一样轰然倒塌，虽然看起来很漂亮，但在最轻微的逆境面前却没有任何支撑，只能承受自身的重量。

Script theory has the same advantages over its predecessors as the Arabic system of numerals has over the Roman system, and for the same reason: the elements are better to work with. Imagine the task of a Roman builder who has to bill you for fifty items, beginning with MCMLXVIII building blocks at LXXXVIII oboli each. A modern contractor could do the whole thing in less than half an hour by using better number elements, and he could use the time saved to think about architecture, without the irrelevant distractions imposed on his Roman colleague.

文字理论相对于其前身，正如阿拉伯数字系统相对于罗马数字系统一样具有优势，原因也相同：其元素更易于操作。试想一下，一位罗马建筑师需要计算五十件物品的费用，每件物品都由价值 88 奥波利（Oboli）的 MCMLXVIII 个建筑构件组成。而现代承包商如果使用更高效的数字元素，不到半小时就能完成所有工作，节省下来的时间可以用来思考建筑本身，而不会像他的罗马同行那样被无关紧要的琐事分散注意力。

In practice, most doctrinal objections result from what Freud calls ‘the aversion characteristic of scientific men to learning something new.’ This is no longer as prevalent as it was in his day, when he noted the reaction to his dream theory: ‘naturally least attention has been bestowed upon it by the so-called “investigators of dreams” … my only possible answer to my critics would be to read this book over again. Perhaps also the request should be that they read it as a whole.’ An improvement on psychoanalysis is no more anti-analytic than an improvement on airplanes is a slur on the Wright brothers.

实际上，大多数教义上的反对意见源于弗洛伊德所说的“科学家对学习新事物的固有厌恶”。这种现象如今已不如他那个时代那么普遍。弗洛伊德曾注意到人们对他的梦理论的反应：“所谓的‘梦的研究者’自然对此漠不关心……我对批评者的唯一回应就是让他们重读一遍这本书。或许还应该要求他们通读全书。”对精神分析的改进并不比对分析的改进更反分析，正如对飞机的改进并不比对莱特兄弟的诋毁更反分析一样。

E • Empirical Objections

E • 经验性反对意见

We shall consider here only the commonest of the empirical objections to script theory since that can be dealt with most concisely: ‘If people’s destinies are determined by parental programing, how come children from the same family turn out so differently?’

我们在这里只考虑对脚本理论最常见的经验性反对意见，因为这种反对意见可以最简洁地处理：“如果人们的命运是由父母的程序决定的，那么为什么来自同一家庭的孩子会如此不同呢？”

The first comment is that children from the same family do not always turn out differently. In some families they do, in others they don’t. There are many cases where all the siblings are uniformly successful, uniformly alcoholic, uniformly suicidal, or uniformly schizophrenic. Such outcomes are often attributed to heredity, leaving the geneticists in a sophistical position when the siblings turn out differently: they can then argue, somewhat unconvincingly, from an adulterated Mendelianism, which amounts to little more than mumbling. The self-determinists are in the converse position: they argue vigorously for the cases where the siblings turn out differently, but are reduced to muttering when faced with uniformity. Script theory can take both situations in its stride.

首先要指出的是，同一家庭的孩子并非总是性格迥异。有些家庭的孩子性格迥异，有些则不然。很多情况下，兄弟姐妹要么全都成功，要么全都酗酒，要么全都自杀，要么全都患有精神分裂症。这种结果通常被归因于遗传，这就让遗传学家在兄弟姐妹性格迥异的情况下陷入了诡辩：他们只能勉强地从一种掺杂了其他因素的孟德尔遗传学出发进行论证，但这不过是空谈。自我决定论者则处于相反的境地：他们极力论证兄弟姐妹性格迥异的情况，但面对性格一致的情况却束手无策。而脚本理论则能轻松应对这两种情况。

The script at issue here is the parent’s script, of which the offspring’s script is a derivative. Children turn out differently for the same reason that Cinderella turned out differently from her stepsisters. The stepmother’s script was to have losers for daughters and a winner for a stepdaughter. In the other well-known fairy-tale motif, the two clever older brothers turn out in the long run to be stupid, while the stupid younger brother turns out to be the cleverest (as their mother secretly knew all along, since she set it up that way). On the other hand, both of the Roman Gracchi boys were equally talented and equally devoted to the interests of the people, and both of them came to the same end by assassination; while the five or ten or fifteen or twenty children of Niobe (depending upon who counted them), all came to the same end as part of her (Niobe’s) ‘Pride and Fall’ script. The mother’s script may call for her to raise ten policemen (Glory be!) or ten robbers (Get ’em, boys!), or five policemen and five robbers (Let’s you and him fight!), and a shrewd woman will have no difficulty in realizing any of these projects if she has the ten boys to raise.

这里讨论的剧本是父母的剧本，子女的剧本是其衍生而来。孩子们的命运之所以不同，原因与灰姑娘和她的继姐妹们截然不同的原因相同。继母的剧本是让女儿们一事无成，而让继女成为成功者。在另一个著名的童话故事中，两个聪明的哥哥最终变得愚蠢，而愚蠢的弟弟却成了最聪明的（他们的母亲其实早就知道这一点，因为这是她一手安排的）。另一方面，罗马的格拉古兄弟才华横溢，同样致力于人民的利益，最终都死于刺杀；而尼俄柏的五个、十个、十五个或二十个孩子（取决于谁来统计），也都按照她（尼俄柏）的“傲慢与衰落”剧本走向了相同的结局。母亲的剧本可能要求她培养十个警察（荣耀归于上帝！）或十个强盗（抓住他们，孩子们！），或者五个警察和五个强盗（让你和他打一架！），如果一个精明的女人有十个男孩要养，那么实现这些计划中的任何一个都不会有困难。

F • Developmental Objections

F • 发展性异议

Developmental objections to script theory center around infantile psychosexual crises and adolescent identity crises.

对脚本理论的发展性反对意见主要集中在婴儿期性心理危机和青少年期身份认同危机上。

1. In regard to the first, a script does not negate instinctual strivings, or prevail over early traumata. On the contrary, it goes along with them. It offers an ongoing social matrix for acting out sexual fantasies, whatever their origin. It says that instinctual strivings, or sexual fantasies, can be given free play, or become repressed, distorted, or sublimated, but that in the long run they are in the service of a higher principle which directs the timing, force, and mode of their expression in accordance with the requirements of the script, or what Freud would call the destiny compulsion. At this level, the script directive reads: ‘Do what you like, as long as meanwhile you collect enough trading stamps to justify the outcome.’ Hence, script theory is not behaviorism. It does not postulate that everything, or even very much, of what most people do is the result of ‘conditioning.’ All it requires is that the person follow orders at certain critical moments; for the rest, he is free to go wherever and do whatever his fancy dictates.

1. 关于第一点，脚本并非否定本能的渴望，也并非凌驾于早期创伤之上。恰恰相反，它与这些渴望相辅相成。它为性幻想的实现提供了一个持续的社会框架，无论其起源如何。脚本理论认为，本能的渴望或性幻想可以自由发挥，也可以被压抑、扭曲或升华，但从长远来看，它们服务于一个更高的原则，该原则根据脚本的要求（或弗洛伊德所说的命运强制）来指导其表达的时机、力度和方式。在这个层面上，脚本的指令是：“做你想做的，只要你同时收集到足够的‘交易印章’来证明结果的合理性。” 因此，脚本理论并非行为主义。它并不假定大多数人的所有行为，甚至大部分行为，都是“条件反射”的结果。它所要求的仅仅是，个体在某些关键时刻遵循指令；至于其他方面，他可以自由地去任何地方，做任何他想做的事情。

2. It is true that some adolescents shake off their scripts completely and become autonomous. Others, however, merely rebel (following a parental directive to rebel), thus fulfilling their scripts in a kind of Appointment in Samarra tragedy: the faster they think they are running away from their parents’ programing, the closer they are to following it. Others shake off the script temporarily, and then subside into suburban desperation. The ‘identity diffusion’ of this period is merely a bad script. In Erikson’s view, it is a struggle against mother in which she loses. But script analysts take the opposite position: it is a struggle with mother in which she wins. Her son becomes a bum not in spite of her, but because of her, because he cannot get permission to succeed against her orders. The therapy then is not directed toward bringing him back to mother so that he can be a good boy, but to divorcing him from mother so that he can have permission to do things right.

2. 诚然，有些青少年能够彻底摆脱既定的剧本，变得独立自主。然而，另一些青少年却只是（奉父母之命）反叛，从而以一种类似《萨马拉之约》的悲剧方式实现了他们的剧本：他们越是自以为逃离父母的设定，就越是接近于遵循它。还有一些青少年只是暂时摆脱了剧本，然后沉沦于郊区生活的绝望之中。这一时期的“身份认同扩散”仅仅是一个糟糕的剧本。在埃里克森看来，这是一场与母亲的斗争，而母亲最终失败。但剧本分析学家则持相反的观点：这是一场与母亲的斗争，而母亲最终获胜。她的儿子之所以沦为游手好闲之徒，并非与母亲无关，而是因为她，因为他无法获得违背母亲命令的许可。因此，治疗的目的并非让他回到母亲身边，成为一个好孩子，而是让他与母亲脱离关系，从而获得做正确事情的许可。

G • Clinical Objections

G • 临床异议

The commonest clinical objection to script theory is that a patient cannot be cured in the psychoanalytic sense by dealing with conscious material alone. This is correct. But:

临床上对脚本理论最常见的反对意见是，仅靠处理意识层面的内容，无法从精神分析的角度治愈病人。这没错。但是：

1. The unconscious has become fashionable, and hence grossly overrated. That is, by far the larger percentage of what is called unconscious nowadays is not unconscious, but preconscious. The patient, however, will oblige the therapist who is looking for ‘unconscious’ material by advancing preconscious material with a spurious label. This is easily verified by asking the patient ‘Was it really unconscious, or was it just vaguely conscious?’ True unconscious material (for example, the original castration fear and the original Oedipal rage) is truly unconscious, and not vaguely conscious. Therefore the script analyst dealing with conscious material is engaged with a far larger area of the psyche than many people would suppose. In any case, there is no proscription against the script analyst dealing with unconscious material (that is, some of the primal derivatives of the original castration fear and the original Oedipal rage) if he is equipped to do so. And he will do so, because, of course, it is these very experiences which form the basic protocol for the script.

1. 无意识如今已成为一种时尚，因此也被严重高估。也就是说，如今所谓的无意识，绝大部分并非真正的无意识，而是前意识。然而，患者为了迎合治疗师对“无意识”素材的渴求，会用一个虚假的标签来呈现前意识素材。这一点很容易验证，只需问患者：“它真的是无意识的，还是只是模糊的意识？”真正的无意识素材（例如，最初的阉割恐惧和最初的俄狄浦斯情结）是真正意义上的无意识，而非模糊的意识。因此，处理意识素材的脚本分析师所接触到的心理领域远比许多人想象的要广阔得多。无论如何，如果脚本分析师具备相应的能力，那么处理无意识素材（即最初阉割恐惧和最初俄狄浦斯情结的一些原始衍生成分）并没有什么禁忌。他一定会这样做，因为，当然，正是这些经历构成了剧本的基本框架。

2. It is commonly assumed that there is some sort of legislation which gives psychoanalysts the irrevocable right to define a cure. This is not so. Even if there were such legislation, they would be in a difficult position, because their definitions (which are almost synonymous with the termination of treatment) are not clearly stated or unanimously accepted among themselves. Their criteria can usually be boiled down to a pragmatic statement which applies equally well to those therapies which are not psychoanalysis: e.g., ‘The patient is cured when he is symptom-free and can work and love effectively.’ Script analysis can accomplish that at least as frequently as psychoanalysis can. 3

2. 人们通常认为存在某种法律赋予精神分析师不可撤销的权力来定义“治愈”。事实并非如此。即使存在这样的法律，他们也会处境艰难，因为他们的定义（几乎等同于终止治疗）既不明确，也未得到同行的一致认可。他们的标准通常可以简化为一个务实的陈述，这个陈述同样适用于非精神分析疗法，例如：“当患者没有症状，能够有效地工作和恋爱时，就治愈了。” 脚本分析至少与精神分析一样，都能达到这个目的。

In conclusion, it should be mentioned that there are two kinds of people who have objections to script theory. The first are theoreticians and clinicians, who can be met courteously on their own debating ground, wherever it may be, and who will show script analysts the same consideration that script analysts show them, which mainly consists of reading each other’s literature with reasonable care and objectivity. The second are those in administrative positions who can and sometimes do block the intellectual and professional development of younger clinicians, especially psychiatric residents, by actually and overtly forbidding them to use script theory in their work. Some of these are just poorly educated, grumpy, or unreasonably prejudiced people, and to them there is nothing to be said. But there are also some highly educated, benevolent, and more openminded administrators and supervisors who have done the same thing. These are mostly well-trained psychoanalysts. For their benefit, it may be pointed out that Freud himself was a script-ridden person, a fact which he openly acknowledged. His heroes were military ones, and he passionately admired Bonaparte. His metaphors were often taken from the battlefield, and so was some of his vocabulary. His slogan is given in the epigraph to his book on dreams, which in my edition reads: ‘ Flectere si nequeo Superos, Acheronta movebo ,’ roughly translated as ‘If I can’t bend the Heavens, I’ll raise Hell,’ which he did. His ‘mysterious’ and ‘obsessional’ idea that he would die precisely at the age of fifty-one is a typical scripty prophecy. Freud’s father’s motto was: ‘Something will turn up,’ and that was a precept Freud devoutly believed in, as his letters show. His hero, Napoleon, whose very words he quoted in referring to his own ‘court’ (Abraham, Ferenczi, Rank, and Sachs, ‘ Un parterre des rois ’), died at the age of fifty-one. 4

总之，需要指出的是，对脚本理论持反对意见的人主要分为两类。第一类是理论家和临床医生，无论在何处，都可以礼貌地与他们进行辩论，他们也会像脚本分析师对待他们那样，认真客观地阅读彼此的文献。第二类是身居要职的行政人员，他们有时会阻碍年轻临床医生（尤其是精神科住院医师）的学术和职业发展，因为他们会公开禁止年轻医生在工作中使用脚本理论。这些人中有些只是缺乏教育、脾气暴躁或抱有不合理的偏见，对此我们无话可说。但也有一些受过高等教育、心地善良、思想开放的行政人员和主管也做过同样的事情。这些人大多是训练有素的精神分析师。为了他们的理解，值得一提的是，弗洛伊德本人也深受脚本理论的束缚，这一点他曾公开承认。他的英雄都是军人，他对拿破仑·波拿巴崇拜不已。他的比喻常常取材于战场，一些词汇也源于此。他的座右铭出现在他那本关于梦的著作的题词中，在我所读的版本中是：“Flectere si nequeo Superos, Acheronta movebo”，大致翻译为“如果我无法改变苍天，我就掀起地狱”，而他也确实做到了。他“神秘”而“执着”地认为自己会在五十一岁正好死去，这是一种典型的预言式预言。弗洛伊德父亲的座右铭是：“总会有办法的”，而弗洛伊德对此深信不疑，这一点在他的信件中可见一斑。他崇拜的英雄拿破仑，他曾引用拿破仑的话来形容自己的“宫廷”（亚伯拉罕、费伦齐、兰克和萨克斯，《国王的宫廷》），享年五十一岁。

Notes & References

注释与参考文献

1 Giovacchini, P. L. ‘Characterological Aspects of Marital Interaction.’ Psychoanalytic Forum 2: 7–29, Spring, 1967, with discussion by E. Berne and reply by Giovacchini.

1 Giovacchini, P. L. ‘婚姻互动的性格方面’。精神分析论坛 2: 7–29，1967 年春季，E. Berne 对此进行了讨论，Giovacchini 对此作出了回应。

2 Freud, S. New Introductory Lectures on Psycho-Analysis . W. W. Norton & Company, New York, 1933, p. 212.

2 弗洛伊德，S.《精神分析新导论》。纽约：W. W. Norton & Company，1933 年，第 212 页。

3 Cf. Hamburg, D. A. et al., loc. cit ., 1967. About half the patients in that study ‘completed treatment’ and were judged by their therapists to be improved in ‘total functioning.’ Figures reported at meetings by transactional analysts (as well as individual case reports) compare very favorably with this. (It must be said that there are as yet no published figures for transactional analysis, in general, although there are some for special populations, as when it is used in prisons.)

3 参见 Hamburg, D. A. 等人，同上，1967 年。该研究中约有一半的患者“完成了治疗”，并且他们的治疗师认为他们的“整体功能”有所改善。人际沟通分析师在会议上报告的数据（以及个案报告）与此相比非常令人满意。（必须指出的是，目前尚无关于人际沟通分析的总体已发表数据，尽管有一些针对特殊人群（例如在监狱中使用）的数据。）

4 Robert, M. The Psychoanalytic Revolution . Harcourt, Brace & World, New York, 1967, p. 94. For an even scriptier scene, see p. 215f. Jones, E. The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud. Loc. cit ., Volume 1, p. 342, gives the Napoleonic quotation.

4 Robert, M.《精神分析革命》。Harcourt, Brace & World出版社，纽约，1967年，第94页。关于更生动的场景，请参见第215页及后续页。Jones, E.《西格蒙德·弗洛伊德的生平与著作》。同上，第1卷，第342页，引用了拿破仑的名言。

#↩

CHAPTER TWENTY-TWO

第二十二章

Methodological Problems

方法论问题

A • Map and Territory

A • 地图和领土

If we say that the script follows or is matched by a fairy tale, there is a danger of Procrustes. The therapist picks out a fairy tale prematurely, and then stretches the patient or cuts him down so that he will fit it. Procrustes is very common in all the behavioral sciences. The scientist has a theory, and then stretches, cuts down, or weighs the data to match it, sometimes by overlooking hidden variables, sometimes by ignoring items that do not fit, or even at times manipulating the data with flimsy excuses so that they will fit better.

如果我们说治疗方案遵循或符合某个童话故事，那就存在陷入普罗克鲁斯忒斯陷阱的风险。治疗师过早地选定一个童话故事，然后为了迎合这个故事而对患者进行拉伸或削减。普罗克鲁斯忒斯陷阱在所有行为科学领域都非常普遍。科学家先有一个理论，然后为了使其符合理论而对数据进行拉伸、削减或加权，有时忽略隐藏变量，有时忽略不符合理论的数据，甚至有时用牵强的借口操纵数据，使其更好地符合理论。

Procrustes is most active at clinical staff conferences, where there is no control match at all, so that the situation is wide open for speculations, bright ideas, orthodoxy, and authoritative pronouncements ex cathedra . In order to cut down on the casuistry and sophistry of such conferences, each one should include two cases with similar histories, preferably one without any apparent pathology along with that of the patient. It is amazing how closely the ‘case history’ of many a well-functioning, productive person can resemble the ‘case history’ of a psychiatric patient. That is to say, for every schizophrenic with a certain kind of upbringing, there appears to be a nonschizophrenic with the same upbringing. It should be noted that most staff conferences are based on an unstated but ever present assumption: ‘The patient is sick, and our job is to prove it and then find out why he is.’ Staff meetings can become much more interesting by reversing this to read: ‘The patient isn’t sick, and our job is to prove that and then find out why he isn’t.’

普罗克鲁斯忒斯最活跃的场合是临床人员会议，因为这类会议完全没有对照组，所以各种臆测、奇思妙想、正统观念和权威的教条式宣言都层出不穷。为了减少此类会议中的诡辩和诡辩，每次会议都应该包含两个病史相似的案例，最好其中一个没有任何明显病理，与患者的情况并列。令人惊讶的是，许多功能健全、富有成效的人的“病史”与精神病患者的“病史”竟如此相似。也就是说，对于每一个具有某种特定成长经历的精神分裂症患者，似乎都存在一个具有相同成长经历的非精神分裂症患者。值得注意的是，大多数员工会议都基于一个未明言但却始终存在的假设：“病人生病了，我们的工作是证明这一点，然后找出原因。” 如果反过来，员工会议就会变得更有趣，变成：“病人没病，我们的工作是证明这一点，然后找出原因。”

In Procrustes, the information is stretched or cut down to fit the hypothesis or diagnosis. In The Unicorn, 1 the hypothesis or diagnosis is stretched or cut down to fit the recalcitrant data. Thus, in ESP experiments, if the subject’s percentage of correct hits is unsatisfactory, his guesses on this try can be matched against the way the cards turned up on the last trial, or two, five, or ten trials earlier, or on the next trial, or is found somewhere which matches his guesses on this trial. Then a claim can be put in, rightly or wrongly, but certainly unsoundly, for delayed telepathy or premature clairvoyance. The same plan is followed by the fortuneteller who predicts that one of the greatest earthquakes in history will take place in 1969. When it does not occur, he says that he may have transposed a digit, so the earthquake is really due in 1996; or maybe it was just a reincarnation memory trace of the great earthquake of 1699. Which great earthquake of 1699? The one in Rabaul, of course. Well, there are earthquakes in Rabaul nearly every day, and every year there is bound to be one which is greater than the others. Or maybe it was the great Italian earthquake of 1693 that he was re-experiencing? So he went back 300 years and was only six years off, and who could quarrel over a mere two per cent error?

在普罗克鲁斯忒斯（Procrustes）的理论中，信息会被拉伸或删减以符合假设或诊断。在独角兽（The Unicorn）的理论中，假设或诊断也会被拉伸或删减以符合难以捉摸的数据。因此，在超感官知觉（ESP）实验中，如果受试者的正确率不理想，他这次的猜测可以与上次试验、两次、五次或十次试验，或者下一次试验中出现的牌面情况进行比对，或者在其他地方找到与他这次猜测相符的信息。然后，无论对错，都可以提出延迟心灵感应或过早预知的说法，但肯定是不合理的。算命先生也遵循同样的套路，他预测历史上最严重的地震之一将在1969年发生。当地震没有发生时，他声称自己可能弄错了数字，所以地震实际上应该发生在1996年。或许这只是1699年大地震的转世记忆痕迹。哪场1699年的大地震？当然是拉包尔地震。拉包尔几乎每天都有地震，而且每年总会有一次震级更大的地震。又或许，他重温的是1693年的意大利大地震？这样一来，他回到了300年前，结果只差了6年，谁又能为区区2%的误差斤斤计较呢？

Now if script analysts are going to approach the subject with any degree of scientific objectivity and true curiosity, they have to avoid both Procrustes and The Unicorn, and that is hard to do. In fact there is no doubt that both of them have appeared in this book, although I have tried my best to prevent it. With such a complex concept, in its early stage of development, it is difficult to avoid them completely. They are still making frequent appearances in psychoanalytic theory almost a century after Bertha Pappenheim (Anna O.) discovered the cathartic method. 2 And Procrustes is still the patron saint of sociology, as The Unicorn is of psychology.

如果剧本分析家想要以任何程度的科学客观性和真正的好奇心来研究这个主题，他们就必须避开普罗克鲁斯忒斯和独角兽，但这很难做到。事实上，毫无疑问，尽管我尽力避免，但这两个概念都出现在了这本书中。对于这样一个复杂且尚处于早期发展阶段的概念来说，完全避开它们几乎是不可能的。在贝尔塔·帕彭海姆（安娜·O.）发现宣泄疗法近一个世纪之后，它们仍然频繁出现在精神分析理论中。普罗克鲁斯忒斯仍然是社会学的守护神，正如独角兽是心理学的守护神一样。

What then is the best way to proceed? This was outlined by a dentist with a clinical interest in transactional analysis, Dr Rodney Pain, 3 who is also an aviator. He compared the problem of validating script theory to the Map-Ground problem. A flyer looks at his map and sees a telephone pole and a silo. He looks at the ground and sees a telephone pole and a silo. He says: ‘Now I know where we are,’ but he is actually lost. His friend says: ‘Wait a minute. On the ground are a telephone pole, a silo, and an oil derrick. Find those on the map.’ ‘Well,’ says the flyer, ‘the pole and the silo are there, but the derrick isn’t. Maybe they left it out.’ So his friend says: ‘Lend me the map.’ He looks over the whole map, including sections that the flyer ignored because he thought he knew where he was. The friend finds, twenty miles off their charted course, a pole, a silo, and a derrick. ‘We’re not here,’ he says, ‘where you had your pencil mark, but away over there.’ ‘Oh, sorry,’ says the pilot. The moral is, look at the ground first, and then at the map, and not vice versa.

那么，最佳的解决之道是什么呢？一位对人际沟通分析有临床兴趣的牙医罗德尼·佩恩博士（Dr Rodney Pain）对此进行了阐述，他同时也是一位飞行员。他将验证脚本理论的问题比作“地图-地面”问题。一位飞行员看着地图，看到一根电线杆和一个筒仓。他又看向地面，看到一根电线杆和一个筒仓。他自言自语道：“现在我知道我们在哪儿了。”但实际上他迷路了。他的朋友说：“等等。地面上有一根电线杆、一个筒仓和一个石油钻井架。在地图上找到它们。”飞行员说：“嗯，电线杆和筒仓都在，但钻井架不在。也许他们漏掉了。”于是他的朋友说：“把地图借给我。”他仔细查看了整张地图，包括飞行员因为自以为知道位置而忽略的部分。朋友在偏离航线二十英里的地方发现了一根杆子、一个筒仓和一个起重机。“我们不在你画的铅笔标记处，”他说，“而是在那边。”“哦，抱歉，”飞行员说。这说明，应该先看地面，再看地图，而不是反过来。

In other words, the therapist listens to the patient and gets the plot of his script first, then he looks in Andrew Lang or Stith Thompson, and not vice versa. In that way he will get a sound match, and not just a bright idea. Then he can use the fairy tale to predict where the patient is headed, verifying from the patient (not from the book) all the way.

换句话说，治疗师首先倾听患者的讲述，了解其人生剧本的大致走向，然后再去阅读安德鲁·朗或斯蒂斯·汤普森的作品，而不是反过来。这样，他才能找到真正契合的案例，而不仅仅是灵光一现的想法。之后，他就可以运用童话故事来预测患者的人生走向，并始终以患者的讲述（而非书本）为依据进行验证。

B • The Conceptual Grid

B • 概念网格

Transactional analysis is such a rich mesh of intertwined concepts, all consistent with each other, that it is possible to wander around in any direction and come up with something interesting and useful. But that is quite different from the logical approach to a theory.

人际沟通分析是一个由众多相互交织的概念构成的复杂网络，所有概念彼此协调一致，因此，无论朝哪个方向探索，都可能得出有趣且有用的结论。但这与逻辑推理的理论方法截然不同。

Consider the following brief excerpt of a case which was presented at the San Francisco Transactional Analysis Seminar as a focus for discussion of script theory.

请看以下案例的简短摘录，该案例曾在旧金山人际沟通分析研讨会上作为脚本理论讨论的重点进行展示。

A woman who came for treatment for frigidity proposed that the therapist have intercourse with her. Her mother had taught her how to dress and act sexy, and her father had encouraged this.

一位因性冷淡前来治疗的女性提出希望治疗师与她发生性关系。她的母亲从小就教她如何穿着打扮和举止性感，而她的父亲也鼓励她这样做。

The purpose of the discussion was to try to show that the script matrix, as presently constructed, is inaccurate. According to Figure 7 , which shows the second-order structure of the Child, the Parent in the Child (PC) functions like an implanted electrode, while the Adult in the Child (AC) is the intuitive Professor who is an expert judge of other people. Dr Z, who presented the patient, maintained that in her case PC functioned like an Adapted Child, and AC functioned like an electrode. He offered developmental data from her childhood to support this. Others chimed in with logical arguments on both sides, drawing from their clinical experiences. They talked about games, scripts, and the patient’s Natural Child. Would the standard script matrix stand up against this deliberately planned assault? The arrows drawn by Dr Z between the patient, her father, and her mother, took quite a different course from those shown in Figure 7 . Apparently a good case had been made to overthrow it. But on closer scrutiny, the arguments turned out to have grave defects.

讨论的目的是试图证明目前构建的脚本矩阵并不准确。根据图7所示的儿童二阶结构，儿童中的父母（PC）如同植入的电极，而儿童中的成人（AC）则是一位直觉敏锐的教授，能够准确判断他人。Z医生介绍了这位患者，他认为在她身上，PC的作用类似于适应性儿童，而AC的作用则类似于电极。他提供了患者童年时期的发展数据来支持这一观点。其他人也纷纷从各自的临床经验出发，提出了正反双方的逻辑论证。他们讨论了游戏、脚本以及患者的自然儿童状态。标准的脚本矩阵能否经受住这种精心策划的挑战？Z医生在患者、她的父亲和母亲之间绘制的箭头与图7所示的箭头走向截然不同。显然，推翻脚本矩阵的论证似乎很有说服力。但仔细审视后，这些论证却暴露出严重的缺陷。

First of all, when Dr Z, with help from the audience, tried to define what he meant by PC, AC, Adapted Child, and electrode, he and they talked at one moment from a developmental point of view, then from a behavioral point of view, at times using logic and at other times empiricism. Some of them brought in transactions, others, games and scripts. It turned out that there were four different frameworks being used, each with its own language and approach, and the definitions wandered unsystematically from one to the other. The first framework was structural and transactional, with four key ego terms: states, transactions, games, and scripts. The second was validating, again with four key terms. They could talk about her behavior, which offered operational criteria; her mental processes, which included voices in her head giving her directives; her developmental history, which showed the origins of her behavior patterns; and the kind of social responses she elicited by her behavior. The third language dealt with naming her ego states. They could be named according to psychobiological principles: the Parent in her Child, the Adult in her Child, etc., or described functionally by adjectives: Adapted Child, Natural Child, etc. The arguments themselves could be termed logical on the one hand, or empirical on the other.

首先，当Z博士在观众的帮助下试图解释PC、AC、适应性儿童和电极的含义时，他和观众一会儿从发展心理学的角度讨论，一会儿又从行为学的角度讨论，有时运用逻辑，有时运用经验主义。有些人提到了互动，有些人提到了游戏和脚本。结果发现，他们使用了四种不同的框架，每种框架都有其自身的语言和方法，定义也杂乱无章地在各个框架之间转换。第一个框架是结构性的和互动性的，包含四个关键的自我概念：状态、互动、游戏和脚本。第二个框架是验证性的，同样包含四个关键概念。他们可以讨论她的行为（这提供了操作性标准）、她的心理过程（包括她脑海中发出指令的声音）、她的发展史（这揭示了她行为模式的起源）以及她的行为所引发的社会反应。第三种语言则用于命名她的自我状态。它们可以根据心理生物学原理命名：孩子身上的父母，孩子身上的成人等等；或者用形容词进行功能性描述：适应型儿童，自然型儿童等等。这些论证本身一方面可以被称为逻辑性的，另一方面也可以被称为经验性的。

If all these frameworks are tabulated, the result is a terminological grid, as shown here , classified into transactional terms, validating terms, modifying terms, and methodological terms.

如果将所有这些框架制成表格，结果就是一个术语表，如图所示，分为事务术语、验证术语、修改术语和方法论术语。

TERMINOLOGICAL GRID

术语表

TRANSACTIONAL
交易 		VALIDATING
验证 		MODIFYING
修改 		METHODOLOGY
方法论
Ego States
自我状态 		Operational
操作 		Structural (Biological)
结构（生物学） 		Logical
逻辑
Transactions
交易 		Phenomenological
现象学 		Functional (Descriptive)
功能性（描述性） 		Empirical
经验
Games Historical
游戏历史 		Scripts Social
社交脚本

If we draw lines across this grid to include one term from each column, it is apparent that there will be 4×4×2×2=64 possible paths for discussion. (We do not count the words in parentheses.) Unless everybody follows the same path, the various discussions cannot be correlated without an enormous amount of labor and definition: essentially an impossible task in a limited amount of time (such as one long evening) if twenty discussants take twenty different paths. If one goes Ego States-Historical-Descriptive-Empirical, while another follows Games-Social-Biological-Logical, they may both make sense, but they are following such different lines of reasoning that they cannot really settle anything between them.

如果我们在这个网格上画线，每条线包含一列中的一个术语，那么显然会有 4×4×2×2=64 条可能的讨论路径。（括号内的词语不计入在内。）除非每个人都遵循同一条路径，否则各种讨论之间无法关联起来，这需要大量的工作和定义：如果二十位讨论者各自选择不同的路径，那么在有限的时间（例如一个漫长的夜晚）内完成这项任务几乎是不可能的。如果一位讨论者遵循“自我状态-历史-描述-经验”的路径，而另一位讨论者遵循“博弈-社会-生物-逻辑”的路径，虽然两者可能都有道理，但它们的推理思路截然不同，因此无法真正达成共识。

In the simplest example, if one argument takes a structural or biological approach to the Child ego state, and another takes a functional or descriptive approach, it is impossible to reconcile the two. This is demonstrated in Figure 20 . In Figure 20A the structural division of the Child into its main aspects is represented by horizontal lines separating the second-order Parent, Adult, and Child components. In Figure 20B , vertical lines are used to indicate its functional aspects: in this case, Adapted, Rebellious, and Natural Child. Whichever scheme is used, the lines have to go in different directions to indicate that the approaches are different. One uses structural nouns, the other uses functional adjectives as modifiers, and the nouns and adjectives do not belong to the same framework or come from the same viewpoint. Similar considerations apply to the other columns in the grid.

最简单的例子是，如果一种论证采用结构或生物学方法来分析儿童自我状态，而另一种论证采用功能或描述性方法，那么这两种方法就无法调和。图20展示了这一点。在图20A中，儿童自我状态的结构划分用水平线表示，水平线分隔了二阶的父母、成人和儿童三个组成部分。在图20B中，垂直线则表示其功能方面：在本例中为适应型儿童、叛逆型儿童和自然型儿童。无论采用哪种方案，线条的方向都必须不同，以表明两种方法的差异。一种使用结构名词，另一种使用功能形容词作为修饰语，而这些名词和形容词并不属于同一框架，也并非来自同一视角。类似的考虑也适用于网格中的其他列。

The only way to have a well-reasoned and decisive argument is to choose one path through the grid and stick to that. Dr Z was given this option, and chose Ego States-Social-Descriptive-Empirical: not a promising path for the job in hand, but it was his presentation, and his privilege to choose. Thus committed, it became apparent that his arguments were not nearly as convincing as they seemed at first when he was free to jump from one path to another. The same applied to his supporters when they tried to follow his selection. In other words, what had seemed plausible and well organized when all sorts of jumps and distractions were permitted, did not stand up so well when closer reasoning was required. On this basis, the original script matrix retained its supremacy, at least until a better-prepared assault could be launched.

要想提出条理清晰、论证充分的论点，唯一的办法就是在网格中选择一条路径并坚持下去。Z博士被赋予了这样的选择权，他选择了“自我状态-社会-描述-经验”这条路径：这条路径对于当前的任务来说并非理想之选，但这毕竟是他的演讲，他有权做出选择。一旦他选择了这条路径，他的论点就远没有最初看起来那么令人信服——当他可以自由地在不同的路径之间切换时，他的论点似乎更有说服力。他的支持者们在试图跟随他的选择时也遇到了同样的问题。换句话说，当允许各种跳跃和干扰时，那些看似合理且条理清晰的论点，在需要更严谨的推理时，就显得站不住脚了。基于此，最初的脚本矩阵仍然占据主导地位，至少在更充分的论证出现之前是如此。

FIGURE 20A

图 20A

FIGURE 20B

图 20B

The Child Ego State from Two Points of View

从两个角度看儿童的自我状态

It is necessary, then, for any argument about transactional analysis, including script analysis, to state its choices from the above grid before it can be considered valid. If it wanders from its self-chosen path, it becomes invalid by reason of looseness, sophistry, or obfuscation. Therefore, anyone proposing to engage in such an argument should select one term from each column as a framework for his definitions, and adhere rigorously to that. Otherwise the argument is open to methodological question and will not stand up under objective criticism, no matter how convincing it appears from a rhetorical point of view.

因此，任何关于交互分析（包括脚本分析）的论证，都必须先从上述框架中选择合适的术语，才能被视为有效。如果论证偏离了其既定路径，则会因松散、诡辩或含糊其辞而失效。因此，任何打算进行此类论证的人都应该从每一列中选择一个术语作为其定义的框架，并严格遵循该框架。否则，无论从修辞角度来看多么令人信服，该论证都将面临方法论上的质疑，并且经不起客观的批判。

C • Soft Data and Hard Data

C • 软数据和硬数据

The data of script analysis are mostly soft. Because scripts are existential commitments, they cannot be investigated in artificial situations experimentally. The payoff must have overriding significance for the protagonist. As an example, there is no such thing as a reliable experimental poker game. A player will play one way when the stakes are trivial and another way when they are significant. A good high-stake player may lose in penny ante, and a good penny-ante player may panic in a high-stake game. Scripts can only be tested in high-stake situations, and these are not available under ordinary civil conditions.
