There is but one way to find the answer to the question: ‘Would you throw yourself on a land mine to save the lives of your comrades?’ It can only be tested existentially on a battlefield, and all simulations are trivial.

剧本分析的数据大多是软性的。因为剧本是关乎生存的承诺，所以无法在人为设定的情境中进行实验性研究。回报必须对主人公具有压倒性的意义。例如，不存在可靠的实验性扑克游戏。玩家在赌注很小的时候会采取一种策略，在赌注很大的时候则会采取另一种策略。一个优秀的高额赌注玩家可能在低额赌注的游戏中输掉，而一个优秀的低额赌注玩家在高额赌注的游戏中可能会惊慌失措。剧本只能在高额赌注的情境中得到检验，而这种情境在普通的民事环境中是不存在的。对于“你会为了拯救战友的生命而跳进地雷吗？”这个问题，只有一种方法可以找到答案。那就是在战场上进行存在性检验，而所有模拟都显得微不足道。

The data of script analysis can be sorted roughly in order of increasing hardness as follows: historical, cultural, clinical, logical, intuitive, developmental, statistical, introspective, experimental, and blind matching. This may seem a strange array to scientists accustomed to studying trivialities of human behavior, such as the ones commonly tested in the psychological and social sciences. It will seem less strange to psychotherapists, and least strange to psychoanalysts, since both of them deal with hard games and hard payoffs such as divorce, suicide, and homicide. There can hardly be such a thing as an experimental suicide or homicide in a decent society.

脚本分析的数据大致可以按难度递增的顺序排列如下：历史性、文化性、临床性、逻辑性、直觉性、发展性、统计性、内省性、实验性和盲匹配。对于习惯于研究人类行为琐碎细节（例如心理学和社会科学中常见的那些行为）的科学家来说，这或许显得有些奇怪。但对于心理治疗师来说，这似乎没那么奇怪；而对于精神分析师来说，这则最为自然，因为他们都处理着离婚、自杀和杀人等棘手且后果严重的问题。在一个文明社会里，几乎不可能存在所谓的实验性自杀或杀人行为。

1. Historical. Since the beginning of mankind, man has suspected that his destiny is not autonomously determined, but is controlled by some outside force. The very universality of this belief requires that it be critically examined rather than summarily dismissed by calling it metaphysical.

1. 历史因素。自人类诞生之初，人们就怀疑自身的命运并非自主决定，而是受某种外力掌控。这种信念的普遍性决定了我们必须对其进行批判性审视，而不是简单地将其斥为形而上学的谬论。

2. Cultural. This same belief is the foundation of most human cultures, which requires that it also be taken seriously, just as economic motives are taken seriously for the same reason.

2. 文化因素。这种信念是大多数人类文化的基础，因此也需要认真对待，就像出于同样的原因，经济动机也需要认真对待一样。

3. Clinical. Clinical data is not rigorous because it can be subject to different interpretations. But the investigator who wishes to minimize or deny the influence of the script on clinical phenomena must have adequate training in script analysis, and give it an adequate clinical trial before he is competent to pass judgment on it. Exactly the same statement can and has been made about psychoanalysis. Similarly, a man who looks through a microscope or a telescope and says: ‘I don’t see anything,’ is hardly a competent critic of bacteriology or astronomy unless he has had a thorough training in how to use the instrument.

3. 临床。临床数据并不严谨，因为它可能受到不同解读的影响。但是，如果研究者想要尽量减少或否认脚本对临床现象的影响，就必须接受过充分的脚本分析培训，并进行充分的临床试验，才能做出判断。同样的道理也适用于精神分析。同样，一个人如果只是透过显微镜或望远镜观察，然后说：“我什么也没看到”，那么除非他接受过如何使用这些仪器的全面培训，否则很难称得上是合格的细菌学或天文学评论家。

4. Logical. We have previously noted that people can be told what to do and not do. They can be effectively encouraged to drink or commit suicide by means of words, and they can be effectively restrained from doing either of those things by means of words, providing they are the right words. Therefore, it follows that it is quite possible to raise a child to do either of those things when he grows up. This is tested by the following question: ‘How would you raise a child to turn out the way you have?’ People with ‘good’ scripts are quite willing to answer this question, and their answers are often credible. People with ‘bad’ scripts are reluctant to make the attempt, but if they do, their answers are equally credible.

4. 合乎逻辑。我们之前已经提到，人们可以被告知该做什么和不该做什么。通过言语，可以有效地鼓励他们喝酒或自杀；同样，只要措辞得当，也可以有效地阻止他们做这些事。因此，完全有可能把孩子培养成你这样的人。我们可以用以下问题来检验这一点：“你会如何培养一个孩子，让他变成你这样的人？” 那些拥有“良好”思维模式的人很乐意回答这个问题，而且他们的答案往往可信。那些拥有“不良”思维模式的人则不愿尝试回答，但如果他们尝试了，他们的答案同样可信。

5. Intuitive. An experienced script analyst will make intuitive judgments which can subsequently be tested. E.g., ‘Since you often try to do two things at once but don’t do either of them well, I infer that your parents had different goals for you and they never quite got together on how you could attain both of them. That is, your parents did not clarify their differences.’ ‘That is exactly how it was.’ If the answer is negative, in my experience this probably means that the diagnostician is not competent, or else that in the particular case some personal consideration has interfered with his intuition. 4

5. 直觉。经验丰富的剧本分析师会做出一些直觉判断，这些判断随后可以得到验证。例如，“因为你经常试图同时做两件事，但两件事都做不好，我推断你的父母对你有不同的期望，而且他们从未就如何让你同时实现这两个期望达成一致。也就是说，你的父母没有明确彼此的分歧。”“确实如此。”如果答案是否定的，根据我的经验，这可能意味着诊断者不够称职，或者在特定案例中，某些个人因素干扰了他的直觉。

6. Developmental. Hearing children state their scripts is one of the most convincing pieces of evidence, especially if the children can be followed over a long period to see whether they carry them out. This does not refer to choice of a career (‘I want to be a fireman.’), but to payoff transactions (‘I wish I were dead.’).

6. 发展性。聆听儿童陈述他们的脚本是最有说服力的证据之一，尤其是在能够长期跟踪观察儿童是否会执行这些脚本的情况下。这并非指职业选择（“我想当消防员。”），而是指满足某种欲望的交易（“我希望我死了。”）。

7. Statistical. The most relevant statistical work is the study of the effects of fairy tales on subsequent careers and mode of death, previously cited from the work of Rudin. 5

7. 统计学。最相关的统计学研究是关于童话故事对后续职业生涯和死亡方式的影响，该研究此前已引用自鲁丁的著作。 5

8. Introspective. This is the most convincing criterion of all. As soon as a person becomes accustomed to hearing the voices in his head which he has suppressed or repressed since early childhood, and confirms that these voices speak the actual words spoken by his parents during that period, he realizes the extent to which his most significant behavior is programed.

8. 内省。这是所有标准中最具说服力的。一旦一个人习惯于听到他自幼年起就被压抑或抑制的内心声音，并确认这些声音正是他父母在那段时间里说过的话，他就会意识到自己最重要的行为在多大程度上是被预先设定好的。

9. Experimental. For reasons given above, experimental validation of script theory is not possible with human beings, although certain elements can be examined in this way. But animal experimentation can be extrapolated into the framework of script theory, as has been done with the rat experiments cited in Chapter Three .

9. 实验。如上所述，虽然可以通过实验检验某些要素，但用人类进行脚本理论的实验验证是不可能的。然而，动物实验的结果可以外推到脚本理论的框架内，正如第三章中引用的老鼠实验那样。

10. Blind Matching. In a few cases, where a supervisor had inferred the script of a student, but had not brought the subject up with him, and the student then transferred to a therapist, both supervisor and therapist inferred the same script, and when this was communicated to the student, he agreed. In these cases, the two script analysts had been acquainted with the subject over a long period and had a wide range of behavior to survey. This can be considered hard data. Applied systematically, it would require several script analysts to listen to a taped interview and thence infer the script of the subject. These inferences could then be matched against the subject’s life course, with a five-year follow-up. A pilot study would first test three types of tape interviews, autobiographical, free association, and use of the script check list, to see which type yielded the most solid data pertaining to the script. This procedure offers the best opportunity for obtaining hard data.

10. 盲比匹配。在少数情况下，督导员推断出了学生的脚本，但并未与学生本人讨论过该学生的情况。之后，该学生转介给治疗师，督导员和治疗师推断出的脚本相同，当这一结果告知学生后，学生也表示同意。在这些案例中，两位脚本分析师与受试者相识已久，并对其行为进行了广泛的考察。这可以被视为可靠的数据。系统地应用此方法，需要多位脚本分析师聆听录音访谈，并据此推断受试者的脚本。然后，可以将这些推断结果与受试者的生活历程进行匹配，并进行为期五年的追踪调查。一项试点研究将首先测试三种类型的录音访谈：自传式访谈、自由联想访谈和使用脚本核对表访谈，以确定哪种类型能够提供最可靠的脚本数据。此方法为获取可靠的数据提供了最佳机会。

Present indications are that script theory is softer than learning theory, harder than social and economic theory, and is approaching the hardness of psychiatric diagnosis, as far as predicting human behavior is concerned.

目前的迹象表明，就预测人类行为而言，脚本理论比学习理论要软，比社会和经济理论要硬，并且正在接近精神病学诊断的难度。

References

参考

1 Cole, L. C. ‘Biological Clock of the Unicorn.’ Science , 125: 874, May 3, 1957.

1 Cole, L. C. ‘独角兽的生物钟’。科学，125：874，1957 年 5 月 3 日。

2 Jones, E. The Life and Work of Sigmund Freud. Loc. cit ., Vol. 1, p. 223.

2 Jones, E. 西格蒙德·弗洛伊德的生平与著作。同上，第 1 卷，第 223 页。

3 Pain, R. ‘A Parable.’ Transactional Analysis Bulletin , 7:69, July, 1968.

3 Pain, R.《一个寓言》。《人际沟通分析公报》，7:69，1968 年 7 月。

4 Berne, E. ‘Intuition VI.’ Loc. cit .

4 Berne, E.“直觉 VI”。引用。

5 Rudin, S. A. op. cit .

5 Rudin, S. A. op. cit.

#↩

CHAPTER TWENTY-THREE

第二十三章

The Script Check List

剧本检查清单

A • Definition of a Script

A • 脚本的定义

In order to tell whether or not a certain set of transactions is a game, we look for certain special features. If there is a con, a handle or gimmick, a switch, and a payoff, then we have identified a game. If, in addition, we can do a structural analysis showing which ego states are active during each transaction, and a clinical analysis, which clarifies the advantages gained from playing it and how they got started, then we can say that we have not only identified the game, but that we understand it. The items required for such an understanding can be put down as a ‘check list,’ and the formal analysis of a game is based on such a check list. The game check list describes the anatomy of a game, which is a small segment of life.

为了判断一组交易是否构成博弈，我们需要寻找一些特殊特征。如果其中包含骗局、技巧或花招、转换机制以及回报，那么我们就识别出了一场博弈。此外，如果我们还能进行结构分析，揭示每次交易中哪些自我状态处于活跃状态，并进行临床分析，阐明参与博弈所获得的益处以及这些益处是如何产生的，那么我们不仅可以说识别出了这场博弈，而且可以说我们理解了它。理解这场博弈所需的要素可以列成一份“检查清单”，而对博弈的正式分析正是基于这份清单。博弈检查清单描述了博弈的构成要素，而博弈只是人生的一小部分。

The anatomy of a script, which deals not with a small segment, but with the whole course of a human life from birth or even earlier until death or even later, is naturally more complicated. A game may be compared to a flip of the wrist, which contains eight bones and involves seven others; a script may be compared to a mountain-climbing expedition, which involves the complete human skeleton of 206 bones. Thus the ‘check list’ for a script contains many more items than does the check list for a game, but such a check list is the easiest way to understand how a script is put together.

剧本的结构自然更为复杂，它并非只关注人生中的一小部分，而是涵盖了从出生甚至更早到死亡甚至更晚的整个人生历程。游戏可以比作手腕的一次翻转，它由八块骨头组成，并涉及另外七块骨头；而剧本则可以比作一次登山探险，它涉及到由206块骨头组成的完整人体骨骼。因此，剧本的“检查清单”比游戏的检查清单包含的项目要多得多，但这样的清单却是理解剧本构成方式的最简便方法。

The first problem is to define a script so that it can be identified when it appears. Any definition will be subject to alteration with advancing knowledge in the field. Game theory is now like a well-made bicycle which will travel reliably and without hesitation over short distances, but script theory is like a one-cylinder automobile of 1900 which may or may not work when it is most needed, so skeptics can still cry: ‘Get a horse!’ (or at least a couch), and perhaps demand that a more conventional therapist with a red flag walk ahead of the script analyst to warn timid people to keep out of the way.

首要问题在于如何定义脚本，以便在其出现时能够识别出来。任何定义都会随着该领域知识的进步而不断修正。博弈论如今就像一辆制造精良的自行车，能够可靠且毫不犹豫地短途行驶；而脚本理论则像一辆1900年的单缸汽车，在最需要的时候可能运转不灵，也可能完全失灵。因此，怀疑论者仍然可以高喊：“换匹马吧！”（或者至少弄张沙发），甚至可能要求一位更传统的治疗师举着红旗走在脚本分析师前面，警告那些胆怯的人避让。

The following definition, based on the current state of knowledge, will serve for the present to distinguish what is a script from what is a ‘not-script.’ A script is an ongoing program, developed in early childhood under parental influence, which directs the individual’s behavior in the most important aspects of his life.

根据目前的知识水平，以下定义将用于区分什么是脚本和什么是“非脚本”。脚本是一种持续进行的程序，它在幼儿时期在父母的影响下形成，指导着个人在其生活中最重要的方面的行为。

The terms used in this definition can be defined as follows, using standard dictionaries, with some additional explanation.

本定义中使用的术语可参照标准词典进行如下定义，并作一些补充说明。

Ongoing = continually moving forward (Webster). This implies irreversibility, a one-way street. Each move approaches closer to the termination.

持续进行 = 不断向前（韦氏词典）。这暗示着不可逆性，一条单行道。每一步都离终点更近一步。

Program = a plan or schedule to be followed (Random House). This means that there is a plan, which is a scheme of action, project, design; the way in which it is proposed to carry out some proceeding (Oxford), and also a schedule. The anlage or skeleton of the plan can be found in a specific fairy tale.

程序 = 一个需要遵循的计划或时间表（兰登书屋）。这意味着存在一个计划，即行动方案、项目或设计；它描述了拟定的执行方式（牛津词典），同时也包含一个时间表。计划的雏形或框架可以在某个特定的童话故事中找到。

Parental influence = actual transactions with the parents or their equivalents. This means that the influence was exerted in a specific, observable way at a specific moment of time.

父母的影响 = 与父母或其监护人的实际互动。这意味着这种影响是在特定的时间以特定、可观察的方式施加的。

Directs = the person must follow directives, but has free choice in matters where the directive does not apply. In some cases there is a special directive that says: ‘Turn the card over,’ which means ‘In this area do the opposite of what I say.’ Thus ‘rebellion,’ when it occurs, is really part of the script, and is not the same as ‘throwing the card away,’ which is autonomy.

指令 = 当事人必须服从指令，但在指令不适用的事项上拥有自由选择权。在某些情况下，会有一条特殊的指令，例如“翻牌”，其含义是“在这个领域，做与我相反的事情”。因此，当“反抗”发生时，它实际上是既定规则的一部分，与“弃牌”（即自主）截然不同。

Important aspects = at least marriage, child-rearing, divorce, and manner of death, if that is chosen.

重要方面 = 至少包括婚姻、子女抚养、离婚以及死亡方式（如果选择的话）。

We can test this definition by seeing how well it defines ‘not-script.’ ‘Not-script’ would then be reversible behavior, with no particular time schedule, developed later in life, and not under parental influence. This is a fairly good description of autonomy, which is, in fact, the opposite of script. For example, the autonomous person can reverse his guilts, fears, angers, hurts, and inadequacies and start over without being in a hurry to bring things to a head, instead of following his parents’ directive to collect trading stamps and use them with reasonable speed to justify his behavior in marriage, child-rearing, divorce, and death.

我们可以通过检验这个定义对“非脚本”的定义是否准确来验证它。“非脚本”指的是可逆的行为，没有特定的时间表，在人生后期发展起来，并且不受父母的影响。这相当准确地描述了自主性，而自主性实际上与脚本截然相反。例如，一个自主的人可以逆转自己的内疚、恐惧、愤怒、伤痛和不足感，重新开始，而无需急于将事情推向高潮，而不是像父母那样，为了在婚姻、育儿、离婚和死亡等人生大事上合理化自己的行为，而被迫收集“交易邮票”并迅速使用它们。

Hence, the definition is exclusive: that is, by defining script it also defines ‘not-script,’ and that makes it worthwhile. If, then, we find that an individual’s behavior in the most important aspects of his life is directed by an ongoing program developed in early childhood under parental influence, we can say that we have identified a script. This can be reduced to a formula, as in the case of games, and the script formula will read:

因此，该定义具有排他性：也就是说，通过定义脚本，它也定义了“非脚本”，这使得它具有价值。那么，如果我们发现一个人在其生活中最重要的方面所表现出的行为是由一个在幼儿时期受父母影响而形成的持续程序所指导的，我们就可以说我们已经识别出了一个脚本。这可以简化为一个公式，就像游戏的情况一样，脚本公式如下：

EPI → Pr → C → IB → Payoff (Formula S)

EPI → Pr → C → IB → Payoff（方程式 S）

where EPI = Early Parental Influence, Pr = Program, C = Compliance, and IB = Important Behavior. Whatever behavior fits in with this formula is part of a script, and whatever behavior does not fit in with it is not part of a script. Every script will fit this formula, and no other behavior will fit it.

其中，EPI 代表早期父母影响，Pr 代表项目，C 代表服从，IB 代表重要行为。符合此公式的行为属于某个脚本，不符合此公式的行为则不属于任何脚本。每个脚本都符合此公式，其他任何行为都不符合。

For example, a simple reflex is programed by the nervous system, and not by early parental influence (no EPI); the individual may comply with a blow on his knee tendon, but this is not important behavior (not IB). If an individual learns to drink socially, late in life, that may be social compliance, but if it is not part of his program (not Pr) to become an alcoholic, the drinking will not be important behavior (not IB), and will not be an important influence on his payoff – his marriage, child-rearing, or manner of dying. If a boy is heavily programed by his parents to be a trustfund bum when he grows up, but does not comply (no C), then his important behavior is not ‘scripty.’ If a child is moved from one foster home to another, his EPI may be spotty, and his program will be poorly organized (no Pr); he may comply as best he can, but never marry, raise children, stake his life on anything, or make any important decision (no IB). These examples illustrate how each item in the formula applies in actual practice. The tendon reflex is not based on EPI, the social drinking is not part of Pr, the non-bum has EPI and Pr but does not have C; and the orphan avoids IB.

例如，简单的反射是由神经系统而非早期父母影响（无早期父母影响）决定的；个体可能会对膝盖肌腱受到打击做出反应，但这并非重要行为（非重要行为）。如果一个人在晚年学会社交饮酒，这可能是社交顺从，但如果成为酗酒者并非其既定目标（非父母影响），那么饮酒就不是重要行为（非重要行为），也不会对其最终结果——婚姻、育儿或死亡方式——产生重要影响。如果一个男孩从小就被父母灌输长大后成为富二代的思想，但他没有顺从（无父母影响），那么他的重要行为就不是“脚本式”的。如果一个孩子被频繁地从一个寄养家庭转移到另一个寄养家庭，他的早期父母影响可能不稳定，其人生规划也可能混乱（无父母影响）；他可能尽力顺从，但永远不会结婚、养育子女、为任何事赌上终身，或做出任何重要决定（非重要行为）。这些例子说明了公式中的每一项在实际应用中是如何运作的。肌腱反射不是基于EPI，社交饮酒不是Pr的一部分，非流浪汉有EPI和Pr但没有C；孤儿避免IB。

Formula S, then, serves to identify a script in the same way that Formula G ( Chapter Two ) serves to identify a game. It should be noted that the formula only applies to ‘scripty’ people; the behavior of an autonomous person cannot be reduced to a formula because such a person is making his own decisions on his own grounds from moment to moment. In the same way, inbred laboratory mice can be programed by conditioned reflexes, and their behavior can be directed by the experimenter. Thus, they act like machines run by a trained operator, just as ‘scripty’ people act like machines operated by their parents. But wild mice do not respond in the same way; they act like ‘real’ people, and make their own decisions. They refuse to accept the experimenter’s program when they are put in the laboratory; 1 they do not rebel, they simply act independently and autonomously.

因此，公式S的作用在于识别一种脚本，正如公式G（第二章）的作用在于识别一种游戏一样。需要注意的是，该公式仅适用于“脚本型”人；自主型人的行为无法被简化为公式，因为这类人会根据自身情况，随时做出自己的决定。同样，近交系实验室小鼠可以通过条件反射进行编程，其行为可以由实验者控制。因此，它们的行为就像由训练有素的操作员操控的机器，正如“脚本型”人的行为就像由父母操控的机器一样。但野生小鼠的反应却截然不同；它们的行为就像“真正的”人，并做出自己的决定。当被放入实验室时，它们拒绝接受实验者的程序；它们并非反抗，而是独立自主地行动。

B • How to Verify a Script

B • 如何验证脚本

If the script is properly diagnosed, then it should be possible to find some elements which can be treated quantitatively. For example, what percentage of all women own red coats? How many Rapunzels actually have long blond hair? These are mostly of the nature of incidence-and-prevalence studies, and their real value is to dissect out the essential elements of scripts in order to make their diagnosis more rigorous. In the case of LRRH, the diagnostic criteria as they are understood at present read as follows:

如果剧本诊断正确，那么应该可以找到一些可以量化处理的要素。例如，有多少比例的女性拥有红色外套？有多少长发公主实际上拥有金色长发？这些大多属于发病率和患病率研究的范畴，其真正的价值在于剖析剧本的基本要素，从而使诊断更加严谨。就LRRH而言，目前理解的诊断标准如下：

1. Her mother must have sent her on errands to her grandmother’s house when she was a little girl.

1. 她小时候，她妈妈一定经常派她去奶奶家跑腿。

2. Her grandfather must have played with her sexually during those visits.

2. 她的祖父在那些探望期间肯定对她进行了性侵犯。

3. She must be the one most likely to be chosen to run errands in later life.

3. 她很可能是晚年最有可能被选中去跑腿办事的人。

4. She must be contemptuous about men her own age and curious about older men.

4. 她一定鄙视同龄的男人，对年长的男人感到好奇。

5. She must have a naive kind of courage, confident that there will always be someone to rescue her if she gets into trouble.

5. 她一定有一种天真的勇气，相信如果她遇到麻烦，总会有人来救她。

If, and only if, all five of these criteria are present, then the diagnosis of an LRRH script is justified. If it is, then it can be predicted that the patient will put herself in the way of older men, will complain that older men (‘dirty old men’) are making passes at her, will look for someone to rescue her from them, and will laugh when they are discomfited. But many questions come to mind. Do all women who meet these criteria actually spend time in the woods picking flowers? And do they all own red coats? How many other items could be added to the list? How many of the items are redundant – that is, how many of them could be eliminated without affecting predictive accuracy, and what is the smallest number of essential ones which would predict all the others and script outcome as well? What is the correlation between the items? Do all women who were seduced in childhood by their grandfathers like to pick flowers in the woods? Are women who spend time picking flowers in the woods also the ones most likely to be chosen to run errands? Do all women who meet the five criteria end their lives as spinsters, or after a relatively brief marriage, as divorcées? This kind of factor analysis would greatly help to test the validity and usefulness of script analysis.

只有当这五项标准全部符合时，才能诊断为“老男人性骚扰”（LRRH）脚本。如果符合，那么可以预测，患者会故意接近年长男性，抱怨年长男性（“猥琐老头”）对她动手动脚，会寻求他人解救，并在他们尴尬时大笑。但许多问题随之而来。所有符合这些标准的女性真的都会花时间在树林里采花吗？她们都拥有红色外套吗？还可以添加多少其他项目？其中有多少项目是多余的——也就是说，有多少项目可以在不影响预测准确性的情况下被删除？能够预测所有其他项目和脚本结果的最少必要项目是多少？这些项目之间有什么关联？所有童年时期被祖父诱惑的女性都喜欢在树林里采花吗？那些花时间在树林里采花的女性也最有可能被选中去跑腿吗？符合这五项标准的女性最终都终身未嫁，或者在相对短暂的婚姻后离婚吗？这种因素分析将极大地有助于检验剧本分析的有效性和实用性。

The LRRH criteria are largely ‘subjective,’ but then there are other variables which are objective. One of these is family constellation. The most reliable way to study this from a script point of view is to find ‘scripty’ families. One indication in this regard is the naming of children after their parents or after living members of their families, since this is a clear indication that the parents expect the offspring to be like their namesakes, and also implies ‘I am bringing you up (programing you) to be like your namesake.’ If a person who meets this namesake requirement comes to a psychiatrist, that strengthens the assumption that he is saddled with a script, since this is regularly the case with psychiatric patients; it also offers an opportunity to investigate whether the script is related to the name. If it is, then the patient is a proper subject for study in this connection. The following is an example of such a scripty family.

LRRH标准在很大程度上是“主观的”，但也存在一些客观变量。其中之一就是家庭结构。从脚本角度研究家庭结构最可靠的方法是寻找“脚本型”家庭。这方面的一个指标是给孩子取与父母或在世家庭成员相同的名字，因为这清楚地表明父母期望子女像他们的同名者一样，也暗示着“我正在把你培养成（设定成）像你的同名者一样的人”。如果一个符合这种同名者要求的人去看精神科医生，这强化了他被某种脚本束缚的假设，因为这种情况在精神科患者中很常见；这也提供了一个机会来探究这种脚本是否与名字有关。如果有关，那么这位患者就是这方面研究的合适对象。以下就是一个具有这种脚本型家庭的例子。

The Baker family consisted of three girls: Dona, Mona, and Rona. The mother’s family consisted of two girls: Dona and Mona. Thus Dona was named after her mother, and her younger sister Mona was named after her mother’s younger sister. When Rona was born, they had run out of script names on the mother’s side, so she was named after her father’s younger sister. The two Donas, mother and daughter, were repeatedly arrested together for the same offenses and shared the same jail tank. The two Monas, aunt and niece, both got married to men who deserted them and were left to raise children by themselves with no support from the fathers. The two Ronas both hated men, led them on, and then drew away. Thus the Donas played ‘Cops and Robbers’ together, the Monas played ‘Who Needs Him?’ and the Ronas played ‘Rapo.’ When Mona and Rona (the daughters) came for treatment, it was evident that they were headed for the same kind of endings as their respective aunts, and neither of them liked the prospect, but they felt helpless, by themselves, to break up their scripts.

贝克家有三个女儿：多娜、莫娜和罗娜。母亲那边有两个女儿：多娜和莫娜。因此，多娜的名字取自母亲，妹妹莫娜的名字取自母亲的妹妹。罗娜出生时，母亲那边的家族名字已经用完了，所以她的名字取自父亲的妹妹。两个多娜，母女俩，因为同样的罪行多次被捕，关押在同一个牢房里。两个莫娜，姑姑和侄女，都嫁给了抛弃她们的男人，独自抚养孩子，没有得到孩子父亲的任何帮助。两个罗娜都憎恨男人，她们先是勾引男人，然后又疏远他们。于是，多纳姐妹一起玩“警察抓小偷”的游戏，莫纳姐妹一起玩“谁需要他？”的游戏，罗纳姐妹一起玩“拉波”的游戏。当莫纳和罗纳（女儿们）来接受治疗时，很明显她们的结局和她们各自的姑姑一样，她们都不喜欢这种前景，但她们觉得自己无力改变这种命运。

Another ‘scripty’ development is repeated marrriages and divorces, which can not only be objectively verified, but are accurately numerable. One or two divorces may be considered independently of mother’s script, but as the number of divorces rises, the clinician cannot help but be struck by the fact that the greater the number of the mother’s divorces, the more likelihood there is that the daughters will follow in her footsteps. A similar relationship is frequent with arrests or alcoholic hospitalizations of the mother. Sociologists claim that such events may be dependent on social and economic factors, but if we consider arrests and hospitalizations separately, the case is harder to make: that is, it may be that arrests and alcoholic hospitalizations, taken together, are affected by ‘social and economic factors’ in some independent way, but it is important that where there is a choice, some families choose one, other families the other.

另一个“脚本化”的发展趋势是反复结婚和离婚，这不仅可以客观验证，而且可以精确计数。一两次离婚或许可以独立于母亲的“脚本”来考虑，但随着离婚次数的增加，临床医生不禁会注意到，母亲离婚次数越多，女儿步其后尘的可能性就越大。母亲被捕或因酗酒住院也常常与此存在类似的关联。社会学家认为，这些事件可能取决于社会和经济因素，但如果我们分别考虑被捕和住院，这种说法就难以成立：也就是说，被捕和因酗酒住院这两个因素本身或许会以某种独立的方式受到“社会和经济因素”的影响，但重要的是，在有选择的情况下，有些家庭会选择其中一种，而另一些家庭则会选择另一种。

We are not concerned here with whether the patient breaks the law or drinks, since such acts may not necessarily be central to his script. What we want to know is whether he is ‘scripty’ about stealing or drinking and plays games with them: ‘Cops and Robbers’ or ‘Alcoholic.’ The question is whether he steals or drinks enough to be, or in order to be, arrested or hospitalized. A professional thief or a drinking man may play the games he favors and be a winner and retire rich, honored, and happy; that is one kind of script. Another may be a loser and end up in an institution. That is quite a different one. What is important in script analysis is not the act, but the ultimate response and payoff which it yields, since that is what is important for the individual and the people around him.

我们在此并不关注患者是否违法或酗酒，因为这些行为未必是他人生剧本的核心。我们想知道的是，他是否对偷窃或酗酒抱有“剧本式”的执念，并以此为乐，比如玩“警察抓小偷”或“酗酒者”之类的游戏。问题在于，他偷窃或酗酒的程度是否足以让他被捕或住院，或者说，他这样做是为了让自己被捕或住院。一个职业窃贼或一个酗酒者或许会玩他喜欢的游戏，并且最终获胜，功成身退，过上富裕、受人尊敬且幸福的生活；这是一种人生剧本。而另一个人则可能最终失败，住进精神病院。这完全是另一种人生剧本。在人生剧本分析中，重要的不是行为本身，而是行为最终带来的反应和结果，因为这才是对个体及其周围人真正重要的。

Another ‘scripty’ area is death. The most frequent script indicator here is when the person expects, or feels that he is expected, to die at the same age as the parent of his own sex did. It seems that the death of the father at a certain age sentences the son (in his own mind) to die before or at the same age, and the same applies to mothers and daughters. While this is subjective, it does involve numbers, and has the added advantage of being easy to check. More objective is the age at which suicide or homicide is attempted or committed, and the relationships of these to deaths of ancestors or near relatives. Regarding causes of death, as already noted, Rudin studied the relationships between stories told to children (‘achievement’ stories or ‘power’ stories) and those causes of death which would here be called ‘scripty,’ and finds many interesting correlations between the types of stories read in childhood in seventeen countries and later causes of death. 2

另一个“脚本化”领域是死亡。这里最常见的脚本化指标是，当一个人预期或感觉自己应该在与同性别父母相同的年龄去世时。似乎父亲在某个年龄去世就注定了儿子（在他自己看来）会在父亲去世之前或与父亲同龄去世，母亲和女儿之间也是如此。虽然这带有主观性，但它确实涉及数字，而且还有一个优点，那就是易于核实。更客观的是自杀或他杀的年龄，以及这些行为与祖先或近亲死亡的关系。关于死因，正如前面提到的，鲁丁研究了讲给孩子听的故事（“成就”故事或“权力”故事）与那些在这里被称为“脚本化”的死因之间的关系，并发现十七个国家儿童时期阅读的故事类型与后来的死因之间存在许多有趣的关联。

All the relationships mentioned above between parents and their children can be scored categorically. A person named after a family member either does or does not follow the script of his namesake; the patient either does or does not follow the parental script in regard to marriage, divorce, jail, or hospitalization; and he either does or does not expect to die at the same age as his deceased parent. The script problem is a decisive one for human living; the whole meaning of life depends on whether or not script theory is valid. If we are free agents, that is one thing; if we spend most of our time, and our most decisive moments, following instructions received in infancy and childhood, with the pathetic illusion of free will, that is quite another story. It will take at least ten thousand cases to give a feeling of conviction one way or another about such a fundamental matter. Any confidence extended to a study of fewer than that number will really be a scientific courtesy rather than a valid conviction. Kinsey, as a taxonomist, worked with sets as high as 100,000 specimens of wasps; his books on sexual behavior are based on twelve thousand cases and still leave room for extensive controversy. 3 Since many clinicians see one hundred new patients a year, ten thousand cases is not an unattainable goal, and is well worth the effort. I have seen more than ten thousand games being played in the last ten years (five hundred weeks, about fifty patients seen each week) and a series of such size gives me a feeling of unshakable confidence in transactional game theory. What is needed is a similar series for script theory.

上述所有父母与子女之间的关系都可以进行分类评分。一个以家庭成员命名的人，要么遵循其同名者的剧本，要么不遵循；病人要么遵循其父母在婚姻、离婚、入狱或住院方面的剧本，要么不遵循；他要么预期自己会与已故父母同龄去世，要么不预期自己会同龄去世。剧本问题对人类生活至关重要；生命的全部意义取决于剧本理论是否有效。如果我们是自由行动者，那是一回事；如果我们把大部分时间，以及我们最关键的时刻，都花在遵循婴儿期和童年时期接受的指令上，并怀着自由意志的可悲错觉，那又是另一回事了。至少需要一万个案例才能对这样一个根本性问题得出确切的结论。任何基于少于此数量的研究而得出的结论，实际上都只是出于科学礼貌，而非真正的确信。金赛作为一名分类学家，曾研究过多达十万个黄蜂标本；他关于性行为的著作基于一万两千个案例，但仍然存在诸多争议。由于许多临床医生每年接诊一百名新患者，因此一万个案例并非遥不可及的目标，而且非常值得付出努力。在过去的十年里（五百周，每周约五十名患者），我观察到超过一万场博弈，如此规模的案例系列让我对交易博弈论充满信心。现在需要的是一个类似的脚本理论案例系列。

In regard to the questions above, the correlations will either be consistent with and reinforce script theory, or they will be inconsistent with it and weaken it. It will be necessary to find these correlations for different parts of the country and for different countries of the world, as well as making historical studies, in order to determine whether script theory is in truth ‘a fact about human nature’ or a mere regional impression derived from and confined to a selected population (psychiatric patients); or worse, merely a bright idea with no solid backing in reality.

关于上述问题，相关性要么与脚本理论相符并强化它，要么与之相悖并削弱它。为了确定脚本理论究竟是“关于人性的客观事实”，还是仅仅源于特定人群（精神病患者）且局限于特定区域的印象，或者更糟的是，仅仅是一个缺乏现实支撑的空想，我们需要在全国不同地区和世界不同国家寻找这些相关性，并进行历史研究。

What is required is what Platt 4 calls ‘strong inference.’ It is impossible in a finite time to test the universality of script theory by interviewing every human being, but it can easily be disproven, if it is erroneous, by a relatively small sample (say ten thousand cases). The script analyst, in order to maintain his position that script programing by the parents is a universal directive for all human beings everywhere, and is thus ‘a fact about human nature,’ would require, for the strongest possible inference, that all the above correlations should come out very highly positive in every large series.

普拉特所说的“强推论”正是我们所需要的。在有限的时间内，通过采访每个人来检验脚本理论的普遍性是不可能的，但如果脚本理论是错误的，那么通过一个相对较小的样本（比如一万个案例）就可以很容易地将其证伪。脚本分析师为了坚持其观点，即父母的脚本编程是适用于世界各地所有人的普遍指令，因此是“关于人性的事实”，就需要证明，为了获得最强的推论，上述所有相关性在所有大型系列中都必须呈现极高的正相关。

As an aid to the clinician, wherever he may be, we shall now give a ‘script check list,’ consisting of questions which are designed to elicit the maximum of information for each of the numerous items required for a clear understanding of a script.

为了帮助临床医生，无论他身在何处，我们现在将提供一个“剧本检查清单”，其中包含一些问题，旨在获取对剧本中众多项目进行清晰理解所需的最大信息。

C • Introduction to the Script Check List

C • 剧本检查清单简介

In order to understand a script clearly, we should understand each aspect, the history of that aspect, and its articulations with all other aspects. This can be most conveniently done by taking the items in chronological order. For each item, a single question is given which is most likely to elicit the maximum amount of relevant information. Other questions are included, which will help if more elaboration is desired about certain specific items. Alternative questions are given where the main question is often found to be inapplicable or unanswerable.

为了清晰地理解剧本，我们应该理解每个方面，了解每个方面的历史背景，以及它与其他所有方面的联系。最便捷的方法是按时间顺序分析各个部分。针对每个部分，我们提出一个最有可能引出最多相关信息的问题。此外，我们还提供了一些其他问题，以便在需要对某些特定部分进行更详细阐述时提供帮助。如果主要问题不适用或无法回答，我们还会提供一些替代问题。

Script analysis in its present form was mainly developed at the San Francisco Transactional Analysis Seminar during the years 1966–1970, and it is almost impossible to dissect out the originator of many of the ideas, since more than one hundred clinicians took part in the weekly discussions during the period. Specific contributions have been published in the Transactional Analysis Bulletin by Pat Crossman, Mary Edwards, Stephen Karpman, David Kupfer, I. L. Maizlish, Ray Poindexter, and Claude Steiner. The original stimulus came from the present writer in a chapter in Transactional Analysis in Psychotherapy , 5 later elaborated in other books and at the Seminar.

现今的脚本分析主要发展于1966年至1970年间的旧金山交互分析研讨会，由于当时有超过一百位临床医生参与每周的讨论，因此几乎不可能追溯到许多思想的最初提出者。帕特·克罗斯曼、玛丽·爱德华兹、斯蒂芬·卡普曼、大卫·库普弗、I. L. 梅兹利什、雷·波因德克斯特和克劳德·施泰纳等人的具体贡献已发表在《交互分析公报》上。最初的灵感来源于笔者在《心理治疗中的交互分析》一书中撰写的一个章节，该章节后来在其他著作和研讨会上得到了进一步阐述。

The idea of a check list was first proposed by Claude Steiner (Berkeley), and Martin Groder and Stephen Karpman (both of San Francisco). It was designed to be used as a shortcut in treatment, giving a quick way of finding the active elements in a patient’s script so that its tragic progress could be headed off as quickly and effectively as possible. Their list included seventeen of the most decisive items. 6 The comprehensive list given below includes those items, along with many others derived from the material in Parts II, III, and IV of this book. It is intended for teaching, research, and other specialized purposes, and contains about 220 items. It is followed by a more manageable, condensed version for everyday use.

清单的概念最初由克劳德·施泰纳（伯克利）以及马丁·格罗德和斯蒂芬·卡普曼（均来自旧金山）提出。它的设计初衷是作为治疗中的捷径，帮助快速找到患者病情发展过程中的关键因素，从而尽可能迅速有效地阻止病情恶化。他们的清单包含了十七项最重要的内容。 6 下文提供的完整清单包含了这些内容，以及本书第二、三、四部分中的许多其他内容。该清单适用于教学、研究和其他专业用途，包含约220项内容。之后附有更便于日常使用的精简版。

D • A Script Check List

D • 剧本检查清单

Questions are given in chronological order as far as it is convenient to do so, with clinical observations put last, thus following for the most part the order in the text. Each stage of development is numbered in sequence, and the questions dealing with that stage are given its key number. The number of the chapter dealing with each stage is given in parentheses. The letter in the key number refers to the section in the corresponding chapter. For example, Stage 1, Prenatal, is discussed in Chapter Four . Its heading therefore reads 1. Prenatal Influences ( Chapter 4 ). The question, number 1F.4 indicates that this is a Stage 1, or ‘Prenatal’ question, that is discussed in Section F of Chapter Four , and that it is the fourth question referring to that section. 2A.3 means Stage 2 ( Chapter Five ), the third question referring to Section A of that chapter. A ‘P’ after the key number means that the question is intended to be asked of the patient’s parents. Thus 2A.3P gives the same location as 2A.3 but means that this time the question is for the parents, not for the patient. This system sorts out the text so that the questions themselves occur in numerical order and can be used separately from the text.

问题尽可能按时间顺序排列，临床观察放在最后，因此在很大程度上与正文顺序一致。每个发育阶段按顺序编号，与该阶段相关的问题也用相应的编号表示。每个阶段对应的章节号用括号括起来。编号中的字母代表相应章节中的部分。例如，第一阶段“产前”在第四章讨论，因此其标题为“1. 产前影响（第四章）”。问题编号 1F.4 表示这是一个关于第一阶段（即“产前”）的问题，在第四章的 F 部分讨论，并且是该部分的第四个问题。2A.3 表示第二阶段（第五章），是该章 A 部分的第三个问题。编号后的“P”表示该问题是要询问患者的父母的。因此，2A.3P 与 2A.3 的位置相同，但这次的问题是针对家长而非患者。该系统对文本进行排序，使问题本身按数字顺序排列，并且可以与文本分开使用。

1 • PRENATAL INFLUENCES ( CHAPTER FOUR )

1 • 产前影响（第四章）

1B.1
1B.1 		What kind of lives did your grandparents lead?
你的祖父母过着怎样的生活？
1C.1
1C.1 		What is your position in the family?
你在家里的地位是什么？
a. What is the date of your birth?
a. 你的出生日期是什么时候？
b. What is the birthday of your next oldest sibling?
b. 你排行第二的兄弟姐妹的生日是什么时候？
c. What is the birthday of your next youngest sibling?
c. 你最小的弟弟妹妹的生日是什么时候？
d. Have you any special interest in dates?
d. 你对约会有什么特别的兴趣吗？
1C.1P
1C.1P 		How many brothers and sisters do you have?
你有几个兄弟姐妹？
a. How many children do you (does your Parent, Adult, Child) (want, expect) to have?
a. 你（父母、成年人、孩子）想要、期望生几个孩子？
b. How many children did your parents want to have?
b. 你父母想要几个孩子？
c. Do you have any special interest in dates?
c. 你对日期有什么特别的兴趣吗？
1D.1
1D.1 		Were you wanted?
你被通缉了吗？
1D.1P
1D.1P 		Did you want him?
你想要他吗？
a. Was he planned?
a. 他是计划中的吗？
b. Where and when was he conceived?
b. 他是在哪里、什么时候受孕的？
c. Was an abortion attempted?
c. 是否尝试过堕胎？
d. How do you feel about sex?
d. 你对性有什么看法？
1E.1
1E.1 		How did your mother feel about your birth?
你母亲对你的出生有何感受？
1E.2
1E.2 		Who was there when you were born?
你出生时谁在场？
a. Was it a Caesarean or a forceps delivery?
a. 是剖腹产还是产钳助产？
1F.1
1F.1 		Have you ever actually read your birth certificate?
你真的看过自己的出生证明吗？
1F.2
1F.2 		Who chose your name?
谁给你取的名字？
1F.3
1F.3 		Whom were you named after?
你的名字是根据谁起的？
1F.4
1F.4 		Where does your surname come from?
你的姓氏来自哪里？
1F.5
1F.5 		What did they call you as a child?
你小时候他们都怎么称呼你？
a. What is your Child’s name?
a. 您的孩子叫什么名字？
b. Did you have a nickname as a child?
b. 你小时候有昵称吗？
1F.6
1F.6 		What did the other kids call you in high school?
高中时其他孩子都怎么称呼你？
1F.7
1F.7 		What do your friends call you now?
你的朋友现在都怎么称呼你？
a. What does your mother, father, call you now?
a. 你父母现在怎么称呼你？

2 • EARLY CHILDHOOD ( CHAPTER FIVE )

2 • 幼儿期（第五章）

2A.1
2A.1 		How did your mother and father teach you table manners?
你的父母是如何教你餐桌礼仪的？
a. What does your mother say when she is feeding a baby?
a. 你妈妈在喂婴儿的时候会说什么？
2A.1P
2A.1P 		What happened during his nursing period?
他在哺乳期发生了什么事？
a. What did you used to say to him then?
a. 那时你都跟他说些什么？
2A.2
2A.2 		Who gave you your toilet training?
谁教你上厕所的？
2A.3
2A.3 		How did they train you and what did they say?
他们是如何训练你的？他们都说了些什么？
a. What do your parents say about toilet training?
a. 你父母对如厕训练有什么看法？
2A.3P
2A.3P 		How and when did you toilet-train him?
你是如何以及何时开始训练他上厕所的？
a. What did you used to say to him then?
a. 那时你都跟他说些什么？
2A.4
2A.4 		Did you get lots of enemas or laxatives as a child?
你小时候经常灌肠或服用泻药吗？
2B.1
2B.1 		How did your parents make you feel when you were little?
你小时候，父母是如何对待你的？
a. How did you feel about yourself when you were little?
a. 你小时候对自己的感觉如何？
2B.2
2B.2 		What did you decide about life when you were little?
你小时候就对人生有了怎样的规划？
2C.1
2C.1 		How did the world look to you when you were little?
你小时候眼中的世界是什么样的？
a. How did you feel about other people?
a. 你对其他人有什么感觉？
2C.2
2C.2 		Do you remember as a child ever deciding that never again would you do a certain thing or show a certain feeling?
你是否记得小时候曾下定决心，再也不做某件事或表达某种情感？
a. Did you decide always to do a certain thing, no matter what?
a. 你是否决定无论如何都要做某件事？
2C.3
2C.3 		Are you a winner or a loser?
你是赢家还是输家？
2C.4
2C.4 		When did you decide that?
你是什么时候决定的？
2D.1
2D.1 		What was your interpretation of what went on between your parents when you were little?
你小时候是如何理解父母之间发生的事情的？
a. What did you feel like doing about it?
a. 你当时想怎么做？
2E.1
2E.1 		What kind of people did your parents look down on?
你父母瞧不起哪些人？
a. What kind of people do you dislike most?
a. 你最讨厌哪种人？
2E.2
2E.2 		What kind of people did your parents look up to?
你的父母敬仰什么样的人？
a. What kind of people do you like best?
a. 你最喜欢哪种类型的人？
2F.1
2F.1 		What happens to people like you?
像你这样的人会怎么样？

3 • MIDDLE CHILDHOOD ( CHAPTERS SIX & SEVEN )

3 • 童年中期（第六章和第七章）

3A.1
3A.1 		What did your parents tell you to do when you were little?
你小时候，父母都教你做什么？
a. What did they say to you when you were very little?
a. 你小时候，他们都跟你说过些什么？
3A.2
3A.2 		What was your parents’ favorite slogan?
你父母最喜欢的口号是什么？
3A.3
3A.3 		What did your parents teach you to do?
你的父母教过你做什么？
3A.4
3A.4 		What did they forbid you to do?
他们禁止你做什么？
3A.5
3A.5 		If your family were put on the stage, what kind of a play would it be?
如果你的家庭被搬上舞台，那会是一出什么样的戏？

4 • LATER CHILDHOOD ( CHAPTER SEVEN )

4 • 童年后期（第七章）

4A.1
4A.1 		What was your favorite fairy tale as a child?
你小时候最喜欢的童话故事是什么？
a. What was your favorite nursery rhyme as a child?
a. 你小时候最喜欢的童谣是什么？
b. What was your favorite story as a child?
b. 你小时候最喜欢的故事是什么？
4A.2
4A.2 		Who read it to you or told it to you?
谁读给你听的，或者告诉你的？
a. Where, when?
a. 地点，时间？
4A.3
4A.3 		What did the reader say about it?
读者对此有何评价？
a. How did she react to the story?
a. 她对这个故事有何反应？
b. What did her face say about it?
b. 她的表情说明了什么？
c. Was she interested in it, or was she just reading it for your sake?
c. 她对这本书感兴趣吗？还是她只是为了你才读这本书？
4A.4
4A.4 		Who was your favorite character as a child?
你小时候最喜欢的角色是谁？
a. Who was your hero?
a. 你的英雄是谁？
b. Who was your favorite villain?
b. 你最喜欢的反派角色是谁？
4B.1
4B.1 		How did your mother react when things got tough?
当生活遇到困难时，你母亲的反应是什么？
4B.2
4B.2 		How did your father react when things got tough?
当遇到困难时，你父亲的反应是什么？
4C.1
4C.1 		What kind of feelings bother you the most?
哪些情绪最让你困扰？
4C.2
4C.2 		What kind of feelings do you like best?
你最喜欢哪种感觉？
4C.3
4C.3 		What is your most frequent reaction when things get tough?
当遇到困难时，你最常见的反应是什么？
4C.4
4C.4 		When a storekeeper gives you trading stamps, what do you do with them?
当店主给你交易印章时，你会怎么处理它们？
4D.1
4D.1 		What are you waiting for in life?
你还在等什么？
4D.2
4D.2 		What is your favorite ‘if only?’
你最喜欢哪个“如果当初……”的事？
4D.3
4D.3 		What does Santa Claus look like to you?
你觉得圣诞老人长什么样？
a. Who or what is your Santa Claus?
a. 你心中的圣诞老人是谁或是什么？
4D.4
4D.4 		Do you believe in immortality?
你相信永生吗？
a. What were your parents’ favorite games?
a. 你父母最喜欢的游戏是什么？
4E.1
4E.1 		What kind of hassles did your parents get into?
你父母都遇到过哪些麻烦事？
4E.1P
4E.1P 		What games did you teach the patient when he was little?
你教过这位病人玩什么游戏？
a. What games did you play with your parents when you were little?
a. 你小时候和父母玩过什么游戏？
4E.2
4E.2 		How did your teachers get along with you at school?
在学校里，你的老师和你相处得怎么样？
4E.3
4E.3 		How did the other kids get along with you at school?
在学校里，其他孩子和你相处得怎么样？
4F.1
4F.1 		What did your parents talk about at the dinner table?
你父母在餐桌上都聊些什么？
4F.2
4F.2 		Did your parents have any hang-ups?
你父母有什么顾虑吗？

5 • ADOLESCENCE ( CHAPTER EIGHT )

5 • 青春期（第八章）

5A.1
5A.1 		What do you talk about with your friends?
你和朋友们平时都聊些什么？
5B.1
5B.1 		Who is your hero nowadays?
你现在的偶像是谁？
5B.2
5B.2 		Who is the worst person in the world?
谁是世界上最坏的人？
5C.1
5C.1 		How do you feel about people masturbating?
你对人们自慰有什么看法？
5C.2
5C.2 		How would you feel if you masturbated?
如果你自慰，你会感觉如何？
5D.1
5D.1 		What happens to your body when you get nervous?
当你紧张时，你的身体会发生什么变化？
5E.1
5E.1 		How do your parents behave when there is company around?
当有客人来访时，你的父母表现如何？
5E.2
5E.2 		What do they talk about when they are alone or with their buddies?
他们独处时或与朋友在一起时都聊些什么？
5F.1
5F.1 		Have you ever had a nightmare?
你做过噩梦吗？
a. What kind of a world do you see in your dreams?
a. 你在梦中看到的世界是什么样的？
5F.2
5F.2 		Tell me any dream you ever had.
告诉我你做过的任何梦。
5F.3
5F.3 		Have you ever had any delusions?
你曾经有过妄想症吗？
5F.4
5F.4 		How do people look to you?
你觉得别人怎么看你？
5G.1
5G.1 		What is the best thing you can do with your life?
你人生中最有意义的事情是什么？
5G.2
5G.2 		What is the worst thing you can do with your life?
你一生中能做的最糟糕的事是什么？
5G.3
5G.3 		What do you want to do with your life?
你的人生目标是什么？
5G.4
5G.4 		What do you expect to be doing five years from now?
你希望五年后自己在做什么？
a. Where do you expect to be ten years from now?
a. 你希望十年后自己身在何处？
5H.1
5H.1 		What is your favorite animal?
你最喜欢的动物是什么？
a. What animal would you like to be?
a. 你想变成什么动物？
5I.1
5I.1 		What is your life slogan?
你的人生格言是什么？
a. What would you put on your sweatshirt so people would know it was you coming?
a. 你会把什么图案印在你的卫衣上，让别人知道是你来的？
b. What would you put on the back of it?
b. 你会在背面写些什么？

6 • MATURITY ( CHAPTER NINE )

6 • 成熟（第九章）

6A.1
6A.1 		How many children do you expect to have?
你预计会生几个孩子？
a. How many children does your (Parent, Adult, Child) want to have?
a. 您的（家长、成人、儿童）想要几个孩子？
(This should be correlated with 1C.1 and 1C.1P)
（这应该与 1C.1 和 1C.1P 相关）
6A.2
6A.2 		How many times have you been married?
你结过几次婚？
6A.3
6A.3 		How many times has each of your parents been married?
你的父母每人结过几次婚？
a. Did they have any lovers?
a. 他们有过情人吗？
6A.4
6A.4 		Have you ever been arrested?
你曾被逮捕过吗？
a. Has either of your parents ever been arrested?
a. 你的父母中有人被逮捕过吗？
6A.5
6A.5 		Have you ever committed any crimes?
你曾经犯过罪吗？
a. Has either of your parents done likewise?
a. 你的父母中有人也这样做过吗？
6A.6
6A.6 		Have you ever been in a mental hospital?
你曾经住过精神病院吗？
a. Has either of your parents?
a. 你的父母中有谁有？
6A.7
6A.7 		Have you ever been hospitalized for alcoholism?
你曾因酗酒住院治疗吗？
a. Has either of your parents?
a. 你的父母中有谁有？
6A.8
6A.8 		Have you ever attempted suicide?
你曾经尝试过自杀吗？
a. Has either of your parents?
a. 你的父母中有谁有？
6B.1
6B.1 		What will you do in your old age?
你老了以后打算做什么？

7 • DEATH ( CHAPTER TEN )

7 • 死亡（第十章）

7B.1
7B.1 		How long are you going to live?
你打算活多久？
7B.2
7B.2 		How did you pick that age?
你是怎么选定这个年龄的？
a. Who died at that age?
a. 谁在那个年龄去世了？
7B.3
7B.3 		How old was your father, mother (if not living) at death?
你父亲去世时多大年纪？（如果母亲已去世，则指母亲去世时年龄较小）
a. How old was your maternal grandfather when he died? (For males.)
a. 你的外祖父去世时多少岁？（仅限男性）
b. How old were your grandmothers when they died? (For females.)
b. 你的祖母去世时多大年纪？（仅限女性）
7B.4
7B.4 		Who will be at your deathbed?
谁会在你临终时陪伴在你身边？
7B.5
7B.5 		What will your last words be?
你临终遗言会是什么？
a. What will their last words be?
a. 他们临终遗言会是什么？
7C.1
7C.1 		What will you leave behind?
你会留下什么？
7D.1
7D.1 		What will they put on your tombstone?
他们会在你的墓碑上刻些什么？
a. What will it say on the front of your tombstone?
a. 你的墓碑正面会写些什么？
7D.2
7D.2 		What will you put on your tombstone?
你的墓碑上会刻些什么？
a. What will it say on the back?
a. 背面会写什么？
7E.1
7E.1 		What surprises will they find after you are dead?
你死后，他们会发现什么意想不到的东西？
7F.1
7F.1 		Are you a winner or a loser?
你是赢家还是输家？
7G.1
7G.1 		Do you prefer time structure or event structure? (Explain terms.)
你更喜欢时间结构还是事件结构？（请解释相关术语。）

8 • BIOLOGICAL FACTORS ( CHAPTER THIRTEEN )

8 • 生物因素（第十三章）

8A.1
8A.1 		Do you know how your face looks when you react to something?
你知道你对某事做出反应时脸上的表情是什么样吗？
8A.2
8A.2 		Do you know how other people respond to your facial reactions?
你知道别人对你的面部表情作何反应吗？
8B.1
8B.1 		Can you tell the difference between your Parent, your Adult, and your Child?
你能区分父母、成年人和孩子吗？
a. Can other people tell the difference in you?
a. 其他人能看出你有什么不同吗？
b. Can you tell the difference in other people?
b. 你能分辨出其他人之间的区别吗？
8B.2
8B.2 		How does your real self feel?
你内心真实的感受如何？
8B.3
8B.3 		Does your real self always control your actions?
你的真实自我总是能控制你的行为吗？
8C.1
8C.1 		Do you have any sexual hang-ups?
你有什么性方面的心理障碍吗？
8C.2
8C.2 		Do things go round and round in your head?
你是不是经常胡思乱想？
8D.1
8D.1 		Are you conscious of odors?
你对气味敏感吗？
8E.1
8E.1 		How far ahead do you begin to worry about things before they happen?
你通常会在事情发生前多久开始担心？
8E.2
8E.2 		How long do you worry about things after they are over?
事情结束后，你还会为此烦恼多久？
a. Do you ever lie awake at night planning revenge?
a. 你有没有在夜里辗转反侧，计划复仇？
b. Do your feelings interfere with your work?
b. 你的情绪会影响你的工作吗？
8F.1
8F.1 		Do you like to show that you are able to suffer?
你喜欢表现出自己能够承受痛苦吗？
a. Would you rather be happy than prove yourself?
a. 你宁愿快乐也不愿证明自己吗？
8G.1
8G.1 		What do the voices in your head tell you?
你脑海中的声音在告诉你什么？
8G.2
8G.2 		Do you ever talk to yourself when you are alone?
你独处的时候会自言自语吗？
a. When you are not alone?
a. 当你不是一个人的时候？
8G.3
8G.3 		Do you always do what the voices in your head tell you?
你总是听从脑海中声音的指示吗？
a. Does your Adult or Child ever argue with your Parent?
a. 你的成年人或孩子是否曾经和你的父母发生过争吵？
8H.1
8H.1 		What are you like when you are a real person?
真实的你是什么样子的？

9 • THE CHOICE OF THERAPIST ( CHAPTER FIFTEEN )

9 • 选择治疗师（第十五章）

9B.1
9B.1 		Why did you choose my profession?
你为什么选择我的职业？
a. What do you think about being assigned to one of my profession.
a. 你觉得被分配到我的专业领域怎么样？
b. Which profession would you prefer?
b. 你更喜欢哪种职业？
9B.2
9B.2 		How did you choose me?
你为什么会选择我？
9B.3
9B.3 		Why did you choose me?
你为什么选择我？
a. What do you think of being assigned to me?
a. 你觉得被分配到我这个岗位怎么样？
9B.4
9B.4 		Who was the magician in your childhood?
你童年记忆中的魔术师是谁？
9B.5
9B.5 		What kind of magic are you looking for?
你在寻找哪种魔法？
9C.1
9C.1 		Have you had any previous psychiatric experience?
您之前有过精神科方面的就诊经历吗？
9C.2
9C.2 		How did you choose your previous therapist?
你当初是如何选择你的上一位心理咨询师的？
a. Why did you go to him?
a. 你为什么去找他？
9C.3
9C.3 		What did you learn from him?
你从他身上学到了什么？
9C.4
9C.4 		Why did you leave?
你为什么离开？
9C.5
9C.5 		Under what circumstances did you leave?
你是在什么情况下离开的？
9C.6
9C.6 		How do you select a job?
如何选择工作？
9C.7
9C.7 		How do you quit a job?
如何辞职？
9C.8
9C.8 		Have you ever been in a psychiatric hospital or ward?
你曾经住过精神病院或精神病房吗？
a. What did you have to do to get there?
a. 你为了到达那里都做了些什么？
b. What did you have to do to get out?
b. 你为了逃出去做了什么？
9C.9
9C.9 		Can you tell me any dream you ever had?
你能告诉我你曾经做过的任何梦吗？

10 • THE SCRIPT SIGNS ( CHAPTER SIXTEEN )
10 • 脚本符号（第十六章）
(Questions the therapist asks himself)
（治疗师自问的问题）

10A.1
10A.1 		What is the script signal?
什么是脚本信号？
10A.2
10A.2 		Is he having hallucinations?
他是不是出现了幻觉？
10B.1
10B.1 		What is the physiological component?
生理成分是什么？
10C.1
10C.1 		What is the most frequent respiratory expression?
最常见的呼吸表达方式是什么？
10C.2
10C.2 		What causes voice switches?
什么原因会导致语音切换？
10C.3
10C.3 		How many vocabularies are there?
词汇表有多少种？
10C.4
10C.4 		What is the favorite part of speech?
你最喜欢的词类是什么？
10C.5
10C.5 		When is the subjunctive used?
何时使用虚拟语气？
10C.6
10C.6 		Where do the OK words come from?
“OK”这个词是从哪里来的？
10C.7
10C.7 		What are the script phrases?
剧本台词是什么？
10C.8
10C.8 		What is the metaphor scene?
这是什么隐喻场景？
10C.9
10C.9 		How are the sentences constructed?
这些句子是如何构成的？
10C.10
10C.10 		What are the security phrases?
安全短语是什么？
10D.1
10D.1 		When does the gallows laugh occur?
绞刑架上的笑声何时出现？
10D.2
10D.2 		What is the gallows transaction?
什么是绞刑架交易？
10E.1
10E.1 		Is he consulting his grandmother?
他是在向他奶奶请教吗？
10F.1
10F.1 		What is the story of his life?
他的人生故事是怎样的？
10F.2
10F.2 		What is his favorite drama switch?
他最喜欢哪部电视剧？

11 • THE SCRIPT IN TREATMENT ( CHAPTER EIGHTEEN )

11 • 治疗中的剧本（第十八章）

11A.1
11A.1 		How do you think your treatment will end?
你觉得你的治疗会如何结束？
11B.1
11B.1 		Do you think I am smarter than you are?
你认为我比你聪明吗？
11B.2
11B.2 		Who is causing your trouble?
谁给你惹麻烦了？
11B.3
11B.3 		How well do you want to get?
你想达到什么水平？
11B.4
11B.4 		What would you like to happen here?
你希望这里发生什么？
11B.5
11B.5 		Are you ready to get well now?
你现在准备好康复了吗？
a. What has to happen before you can get well?
a. 你康复之前需要发生什么？
11B.6
11B.6 		What keeps you from getting well?
是什么阻碍了你康复？
11C.1
11C.1 		Do you think I could handle your parents?
你觉得我能应付得了你的父母吗？
a. Were your parents very powerful?
a. 你的父母很有权势吗？
11D.1
11D.1 		Would you rather get well or be completely analysed?
你宁愿康复还是接受全面分析？
a. Would you rather get well or get out of the hospital?
a. 你宁愿康复还是出院？
b. Would you rather get well or stay in the hospital?
b. 你宁愿康复还是继续住院？

E • A Condensed Check List

E • 简明检查清单

The following list includes only those items related specifically to script analysis, and is intended as an adjunct, and not as a replacement, for psychiatric history-taking. The fifty-one questions chosen are more ‘natural’ and less intrusive, and in most cases will promote rapport rather than challenge it.

以下清单仅包含与剧本分析相关的项目，旨在作为精神病史采集的辅助手段，而非替代。所选的五十一个问题更加“自然”，侵入性更小，并且在大多数情况下有助于建立融洽的关系，而不是破坏这种关系。

1B.1
1B.1 		What kind of lives did your grandparents lead?
你的祖父母过着怎样的生活？
1C.1
1C.1 		What is your position in the family?
你在家里的地位是什么？
1E.2
1E.2 		Who was around when you were born?
你出生时身边有哪些人？
1F.3
1F.3 		Whom were you named after?
你的名字是根据谁起的？
1F.4
1F.4 		Where does your surname come from?
你的姓氏来自哪里？
1F.5
1F.5 		What did they call you as a child?
你小时候他们都怎么称呼你？
1F.6
1F.6 		Do you have any nicknames?
你有什么昵称吗？
2A.4
2A.4 		Were you constipated as a child?
你小时候便秘吗？
2F.1
2F.1 		What happens to people like you?
像你这样的人会怎么样？
3A.1
3A.1 		What did your parents say to you when you were little?
你小时候，父母都跟你说过些什么？
4A.1
4A.1 		What was your favorite fairy tale as a child?
你小时候最喜欢的童话故事是什么？
4A.3
4A.3 		What did the reader say about it?
读者对此有何评价？
4B.1
4B.1 		How did your parents react when things got tough?
当你遇到困难时，你的父母是什么反应？
4C.1
4C.1 		What kind of feelings bother you the most?
哪些情绪最让你困扰？
4F.1
4F.1 		What did your parents talk about at the dinner table?
你父母在餐桌上都聊些什么？
4F.2
4F.2 		Did your parents have any hang-ups?
你父母有什么顾虑吗？
5F.2
5F.2 		Tell me any dream you ever had.
告诉我你做过的任何梦。
5F.3
5F.3 		Have you ever had any delusions?
你曾经有过妄想症吗？
5G.4
5G.4 		What do you expect to be doing five years from now?
你希望五年后自己在做什么？
5I.1
5I.1 		What would you put on your sweatshirt so people would know it was you coming?
你会把什么图案印在你的卫衣上，好让别人知道是你来的？
6A.8
6A.8 		Have you ever attempted suicide?
你曾经尝试过自杀吗？
6B.1
6B.1 		What will you do in your old age?
你老了以后打算做什么？
7B.1
7B.1 		How long are you going to live?
你打算活多久？
7B.2
7B.2 		How did you pick that age?
你是怎么选定这个年龄的？
7D.1
7D.1 		What will they put on your tombstone?
他们会在你的墓碑上刻些什么？
7D.2
7D.2 		What will you put on your tombstone?
你的墓碑上会刻些什么？
7F.1
7F.1 		Are you a winner or a loser?
你是赢家还是输家？
8A.1
8A.1 		Do you know how your face looks when you react to things?
你知道你对事物做出反应时脸上的表情是什么样吗？
8B.3
8B.3 		Does your real self always control your actions?
你的真实自我总是能控制你的行为吗？
8C.1
8C.1 		Do you have any sexual hang-ups?
你有什么性方面的心理障碍吗？
8D.1
8D.1 		Are you conscious of odors?
你对气味敏感吗？
8E.1
8E.1 		How far ahead do you begin to worry about things?
你一般会提前多久开始担心事情？
8E.2
8E.2 		How long do you worry about things after they are over?
事情结束后，你还会为此烦恼多久？
8F.1
8F.1 		Do you like to show that you are able to suffer?
你喜欢表现出自己能够承受痛苦吗？
8G.1
8G.1 		What do the voices in your head tell you?
你脑海中的声音在告诉你什么？
9B.2
9B.2 		How did you choose me?
你为什么会选择我？
9C.3
9C.3 		What did you learn from your previous therapist?
你从之前的心理治疗师那里学到了什么？
9C.4
9C.4 		Why did you leave him?
你为什么离开他？
9C.9
9C.9 		Can you tell me any dream you ever had?
你能告诉我你曾经做过的任何梦吗？
(Questions the therapist asks himself)
（治疗师自问的问题）
10A.1
10A.1 		What is the script signal?
什么是脚本信号？
10A.2
10A.2 		Is he having hallucinations?
他是不是出现了幻觉？
10C.1
10C.1 		What is the most frequent respiratory expression?
最常见的呼吸表达方式是什么？
10C.6
10C.6 		Where do the OK words come from?
“OK”这个词是从哪里来的？
10C.8
10C.8 		What is the metaphor scene?
这是什么隐喻场景？
10C.10
10C.10 		What are the security phrases?
安全短语是什么？
10D.1
10D.1 		What is the gallows transaction?
什么是绞刑架交易？
10E.1
10E.1 		Is he consulting his grandmother?
他是在向他奶奶请教吗？
10F.1
10F.1 		What is the story of his life?
他的人生故事是怎样的？
11A.1
11A.1 		How do you think your treatment will end?
你觉得你的治疗会如何结束？
11B.5
11B.5 		What has to happen before you can get well?
康复之前需要满足哪些条件？
11D.1
11D.1 		a. Would you rather get well or be completely analyzed?
a. 你宁愿康复还是接受全面分析？
b. Would you rather get well or leave the hospital?
b. 你宁愿康复还是出院？

F • A Therapy Check List

F • 治疗检查清单

This is a list of forty items which indicate that the patient has come out of his script. He may be considered completely cured when the answer to all these questions is Yes. This gives a quantitative way of estimating how effective his treatment has been up to any given point. So far there is no convincing way of weighing the items, so for the present they may be given equal weight. The list is designed to test the theory that a script cure and a clinical cure are identical. It is primarily intended to be used when the patient terminates treatment. It is best used in a treatment group, and the patient’s responses are considered valid if the therapist and the other group members concur with him, and questionable if they do not, making due allowance for possible ulterior motives on the part of all concerned.

这是一份包含四十项内容的清单，用于判断患者是否已摆脱其固有思维模式。当所有问题的答案均为“是”时，即可认为患者已完全康复。该清单提供了一种量化评估治疗效果的方法，可用于评估患者在任何特定阶段的疗效。目前尚无令人信服的方法来衡量这些项目的重要性，因此暂时将它们赋予相同的权重。该清单旨在检验“思维模式治愈”和“临床治愈”是否等同的理论。它主要用于患者终止治疗时。该清单最好在治疗小组中使用，如果治疗师和其他小组成员都认同患者的回答，则患者的回答被认为是有效的；如果他们不认同，则患者的回答值得怀疑，同时也要考虑到所有相关人员可能存在的其他动机。

The questions are keyed in the same way as the script check list.

这些问题的标注方式与剧本检查清单相同。

1F.7
1F.7 		Do your friends now call you by the name you like?
你的朋友现在都叫你你喜欢的名字吗？
2B.1
2B.1 		Are you an OK person?
你是个还不错的人吗？
2C.1
2C.1 		Does the world look different to you now?
你现在眼中的世界和以前不一样了吗？
2C.2
2C.2 		Are you free of delusions?
你是否摆脱了妄想？
2C.3
2C.3 		Have you changed your childhood decision?
你改变过小时候的决定吗？
3A.1
3A.1 		Have you stopped doing destructive things your parents ordered you to do?
你是否已经停止做父母命令你做的那些具有破坏性的事情了？
3A.4
3A.4 		Can you now do constructive things your parents forbade you to do?
你现在可以做一些父母禁止你做的有建设性的事情了吗？
4A.4
4A.4 		Do you have a new hero, or see the old one differently?
你心中有了新的英雄，还是对旧英雄有了不同的看法？
4C.1
4C.1 		Have you stopped collecting trading stamps?
你停止收集集邮邮票了吗？
4C.3
4C.3 		Do you react differently than your parents did?
你的反应和你的父母不一样吗？
4D.1
4D.1 		Are you living right now?
你现在还活着吗？
4D.2
4D.2 		Have you given up saying ‘if only’ or ‘at least’?
你已经不再说“要是……就好了”或者“至少……”了吗？
4E.1
4E.1 		Have you given up playing the games your parents played?
你已经放弃玩父母玩过的游戏了吗？
4I.1
4I.1 		Have you taken off your sweatshirt?
你把运动衫脱掉了吗？
5F.1
5F.1 		Has your dream world changed?
你的梦境世界改变了吗？
6A.6
6A.6 		Have you given up your script payoff: prison, hospital, suicide?
你是否放弃了剧本中的结局：监狱、医院、自杀？
7B.1
7B.1 		Are you going to live longer than you used to think?
你觉得自己会比以前预想的活得更久吗？
7B.5
7B.5 		Have you changed your last words?
你修改过遗言吗？
7D.1
7D.1 		Have you changed your epitaph?
你改过墓志铭吗？
8A.1
8A.1 		Are you aware of how your facial reactions affect other people?
你是否意识到你的面部表情会如何影响他人？
8B.1
8B.1 		Do you know which ego state is in charge at a given moment?
你知道在某一时刻是哪种自我状态占据主导地位吗？
8B.3
8B.3 		Can your Adult talk straight to your Parent and Child?
您的成年人能否直接与您的父母和孩子沟通？
8C.1
8C.1 		Can you get turned on sexually without artificial stimulation?
不借助人工刺激也能产生性欲吗？
8D.1
8D.1 		Are you aware of how odors affect you?
你知道气味会对你产生什么影响吗？
8E.1
8E.1 		Have you cut down your reach-back and after-burn so they do not overlap?
你是否减少了后撤步和后燃动作，使它们不再重叠？
8F.1
8F.1 		Are you happy rather than just brave?
你感到快乐而不仅仅是勇敢吗？
9B.5
9B.5 		a. Have you changed your reason for coming to therapy?
a. 你来接受治疗的理由有改变吗？
b. Have you stopped doing what used to get you into the hospital?
b. 你是否已经停止做以前那些会导致你进医院的事情了？
10A.1
10A.1 		Is your script signal gone?
你的脚本信号消失了吗？
10A.2
10A.2 		Are you free of hallucinations?
你没有出现幻觉吗？
10B.1
10B.1 		Are your physical symptoms gone?
你的身体症状消失了吗？
10C.1
10C.1 		Have you given up coughing, sighing, and yawning for no apparent reason?
你是否已经不再无缘无故地咳嗽、叹气和打哈欠了？
10C.4
10C.4 		Do you use verbs, instead of adjectives and abstract nouns, when talking about people?
你在谈论人时，会使用动词而不是形容词和抽象名词吗？
10C.8
10C.8 		Do you use a wider variety of metaphors?
你是否会使用更多种类的比喻？
10C.9
10C.9 		Are your sentences crisper?
你的句子更简洁了吗？
10C.10
10C.10 		Have you stopped hedging when you say something?
你说话不再拐弯抹角了吗？
10D.1
10D.1 		Have you stopped smiling and laughing when you describe your own errors?
当你描述自己的错误时，你是否已经不再面带微笑、开怀大笑了？
11A.1
11A.1 		Do you see your therapist differently?
你对你的治疗师的看法有改变吗？
11B.1
11B.1 		Have you stopped playing games with him?
你不再和他一起玩游戏了吗？
11C.1
11C.1 		Are you able to stop playing games before they begin?
你能在游戏开始前停止玩游戏吗？
11D.1
11D.1 		Do you think you have gotten cured rather than just made progress?
你认为自己已经痊愈，还是仅仅取得了进步？

References

参考

1 Kavanau, J. L. ‘Behavior of Captive White-Footed Mice.’ Science , 155: 1623–1639. March 31, 1967.

1 Kavanau, J. L. ‘圈养白足鼠的行为’。科学，155：1623–1639。1967 年 3 月 31 日。

2 Rudin, S. A., op. cit .

2 Rudin, S. A.，同上。

3 Kinsey, A. C. et al. Sexual Behavior in the Human Male . W. B. Saunders Company, Philadelphia, 1948.

3 Kinsey, A. C. 等人。《男性性行为》。W. B. Saunders 公司，费城，1948 年。

4 Platt, J. R. ‘A Strong Inference.’ Science , 146: 347–353, October 16, 1964.

4 Platt, J. R.“一个强有力的推论。”科学，146：347–353，1964 年 10 月 16 日。

5 Berne, E. Transactional Analysis in Psychotherapy. Loc. cit .

5 Berne, E. 心理治疗中的交互分析。同上。

6 Steiner, C. M. ‘A Script Checklist.’ Loc. cit .

6 Steiner, C. M.《剧本检查清单》。同上。

#↩

Appendix

附录

What Do You Say

你怎么说

After You Say Hello?

你打完招呼之后？

There is a simple rule here: the harder the script, the easier it is to know what to say. We have already mentioned Oedipus, who got by with two one-liners: ‘Wanna fight?’ for men, and ‘Wanna make it with a kid half your age?’ for women. Criminals use one-liners too: ‘Where’s the dough?’ for robbers, and ‘Shut up!’ for rapists. Similarly with addicts: ‘Have a drink!’ or ‘Got a fix?’ Some criminals and schizophrenics don’t even bother to say Hello.

这里有个简单的规律：剧本越难，就越容易知道该说什么。我们之前提到过俄狄浦斯，他只用了两句俏皮话就搞定了：对男人说“想打架吗？”，对女人说“想跟个小屁孩上床吗？”。罪犯也用俏皮话：抢劫犯说“钱在哪儿？”，强奸犯说“闭嘴！”。瘾君子也一样：“喝一杯！”或者“有货吗？”有些罪犯和精神分裂症患者甚至懒得说“你好”。

For others, there are six possible situations. (1) Where talking is obligatory and the situation is highly structured, as in the courtroom or the doctor’s office. This is easy because of the professional structure. (2) Where talking is obligatory and the structure is social. The possibilities here range from the banal ‘Warm enough for you?’ to ‘Is that an Ethiopian necklace?’ (3) Where talking is obligatory and the situation is unstructured, as in certain kinds of ‘encounter’ groups. This is a more or less new invention of the human race and presents difficulties for certain people. The most impersonal ‘personal’ remark that is possible in such situations is ‘Nice shoes you have on.’ (4) Where talking is permissible but not obligatory. This is often the case at outdoor concerts, marches, etc. ‘Groovy!’ is a universal second line here. The third line should be a throw-off, e.g.: ‘Hello.’ ‘Hello.’ ‘Groovy.’ ‘Yeah.’ ‘The lighting, I mean.’ ‘Oh, I thought you meant the music,’ and from then on it’s all gravy. (5) Where talking is not customary and requires some courage. This is the most difficult, since rejection is legitimate and the talker is always working on a probability basis. Ovid, The Art of Love , Book 1, is the man to consult here. His suggestions are just as good for New York, San Francisco, London, or Paris of today as they were for Rome two thousand years ago. If you make it with Book I, you will be ready to go onto the more advanced stages in Book II, and if that works out you will be ready for home plate, which is Book III. (6) Where talking is forbidden, as on the New York subway. Except under the most unusual circumstances, only people with very hard scripts will try it.

对另一些人来说，则有六种可能的情况。(1) 在必须说话且场合高度结构化的环境中，例如法庭或医生办公室。由于其专业性，这种情况很容易应对。(2) 在必须说话且场合具有社交性的情况下。这种情况下，可以问的问题从平淡无奇的“够暖和吗？”到“那是埃塞俄比亚项链吗？”不等。(3) 在必须说话且场合非结构化的环境中，例如某些类型的“交流”小组。这或多或少算是人类的新发明，对某些人来说会造成困难。在这种情况下，最不带个人色彩的“个人”评论可能是“你的鞋子真好看”。(4) 在允许说话但并非必须的情况下。这种情况常见于户外音乐会、游行等场合。“太棒了！”是这里通用的第二句口头禅。第三句应该是个开场白，例如：“你好。”“你好。”“真棒。”“是啊。”“我是说灯光。”“哦，我还以为你说的是音乐呢。”从那以后就一切顺利了。(5) 在不习惯说话且需要一些勇气的地方。这是最难的，因为被拒绝是理所当然的，而且说话者总是在基于概率进行尝试。奥维德的《爱情的艺术》第一卷是这里值得参考的。他的建议对今天的纽约、旧金山、伦敦或巴黎，和两千年前的罗马一样适用。如果你能顺利通过第一卷，你就可以进入第二卷的更高级阶段，如果第二卷也成功了，你就可以进入最终阶段，也就是第三卷。(6) 在禁止说话的地方，例如纽约地铁。除非在极其特殊的情况下，否则只有那些准备非常充分的人才会尝试这样做。

The classical joke here concerns the man whose conversation with women ran as follows: ‘Hello.’ ‘Hello.’ ‘Would you like to go to bed?’ A friend advised him that it would be better to make some conversation before he asked the question. So the next time he was introduced to a girl, he said: ‘Hello. Have you ever been to Ethiopia?’ ‘No.’ ‘Then let’s go to bed.’ Actually that is not a bad line. Here are some possibilities.

这个经典笑话讲的是一个男人和女人搭讪的对话是这样的：“你好。”“你好。”“你想去睡觉吗？”一个朋友建议他最好先聊聊天再问这个问题。于是下次他被介绍给一个女孩时，他说：“你好。你去过埃塞俄比亚吗？”“没有。”“那我们去睡觉吧。”其实这句开场白还不错。以下是一些可能的接龙方式。

Wistful: ‘Hello.’

怅然若失：“你好。”

‘Hello.’

'你好。'

‘Have you ever been to Ethiopia?’

你去过埃塞俄比亚吗？

‘No.’

'不。'

‘Neither have I. I’d sure like to travel though. Have you traveled much?’

“我也没有。不过我真的很想去旅行。你经常旅行吗？”

Naive: ‘Hello.’

天真地说：“你好。”

‘Hello.’

'你好。'

‘Have you ever been to Ethiopia?’

你去过埃塞俄比亚吗？

‘No.’

'不。'

‘It’s a beautiful country. One time when I was there I saw a man eat a lion.’

“那是一个美丽的国家。有一次我在那里的时候，亲眼看到一个人吃狮子。”

‘Man eat a lion?’

“人吃狮子？”

‘Barbecue. Have you eaten yet? Do you like barbecues? I know a little place …’ etc.

“烧烤。你吃过饭了吗？你喜欢烧烤吗？我知道一家小店……”等等。

These few suggestions are offered out of courtesy, in order to make good on the title of this book, and are intended only to stimulate the reader’s ingenuity.

出于礼貌，为了不辜负本书的书名，我们提出以下几点建议，其目的仅仅是为了激发读者的创造力。

#↩

Glossary

词汇表

Antiscript
反脚本 		The inverse of the script. The defiant opposite of what each directive calls for.
剧本的反面。与每条指令的要求完全相反。
Adult
成人 		An ego state oriented toward objective, autonomous data-processing and probability-estimating.
一种以客观、自主的数据处理和概率估计为导向的自我状态。
After-Burn
余燃 		The period of time before a past event is assimilated.
过去事件被同化之前的这段时间。
Button
按钮 		An internal or external stimulus which turns on scripty or gamy behavior.
引发脚本性或赌博性行为的内部或外部刺激。
Child
孩子 		An archaic ego state. The Adapted Child follows parental directives. The Natural Child is autonomous.
一种古老的自我状态。适应型儿童服从父母的指令。自然型儿童则具有自主性。
Clock-Time
时钟时间 		A period measured by clock or calendar.
以时钟或日历计量的时期。
Come-on
快点 		A provocation or seduction into nonadaptive behavior.
挑衅或引诱他人做出不适应性行为。
Commitment
承诺 		An operationally ratified decision to follow certain principles of action in order to attain a certain goal.
为实现特定目标而遵循某些行动原则的、经操作性批准的决定。
Contract
合同 		An explicit agreement between a patient and a therapist which states the goal of the treatment during each phase.
患者与治疗师之间达成的明确协议，规定了每个治疗阶段的目标。
Conviction
定罪 		A firm opinion about the OKness or not-OKness of oneself on the one hand, and the rest of the world on the other.
一方面对自己是否合格有坚定的看法，另一方面对世界其他地方有坚定的看法。
Counterscript
反脚本 		A possible life plan based on parental precepts.
根据父母教诲制定的可能人生规划。
Curse
诅咒 		The script injunction.
脚本禁令。
Cut-off
隔断 		A script release from without.
外部脚本发布。
Cut-out
剪下 		A script release from within.
内部脚本发布。
Death Decree
死刑判决书 		A fatal script payoff.
致命的剧本结局。
Decision
决定 		A childhood commitment to a certain form of behavior, which later forms the basis of character.
童年时期对某种行为方式的坚持，日后会形成性格的基础。
Demon
恶魔 		(a) Urges and impulses in the child which apparently fight the script apparatus, but in reality often reinforce it. (b) The whispering voice of the Parent urging the Child on to nonadaptive impulsive behavior. The two usually coincide in their aims.
（a）儿童的冲动和欲望表面上与既定的行为模式对抗，但实际上往往会强化这种模式。（b）父母的低语怂恿儿童做出不适应的冲动行为。两者通常目的一致。
Depression
沮丧 		The failure of a dialogue between the Child and the Parent.
儿童与父母之间对话的失败。
Drama Triangle
戏剧三角 		A simple diagram showing the possible switches of roles in a game or script. The three major roles are Persecutor, Victim, and Rescuer.
一个简单的图表，展示了游戏或剧本中可能出现的角色转换。三个主要角色分别是迫害者、受害者和拯救者。
Earthian
地球人 		One whose judgments are based on preconceptions rather than on what is actually happening. A square.
那些基于先入为主的观念而非实际情况做出判断的人。一个老古板。
Earthian Viewpoint
地球人的观点 		One which is obscured by preconceptions learned from other people, usually in early childhood.
一种被从他人那里习得的先入之见所蒙蔽的观点，通常是在童年早期形成的。
Ego State
自我状态 		A consistent pattern of feeling and experience directly related to a corresponding consistent pattern of behavior.
一种持续的情感和体验模式，与相应的持续行为模式直接相关。
Electrode
电极 		The Parent in the Child. When activated, it brings about an almost automatic response.
孩子心中的父母。一旦被激活，它几乎会引发自动反应。
Family Culture
家庭文化 		The chief interest of the family, particularly in regard to bodily functions.
家庭的主要关注点，尤其是在生理机能方面。
Family Drama
家庭剧 		A dramatic series of events which occurs repeatedly in each family, and which forms the protocol for the script.
一系列戏剧性的事件在每个家庭中反复发生，并构成了剧本的框架。
Gallows Laugh
绞刑架上的笑声 		The laugh or smile which accompanies a gallows transaction, and which is usually shared by the others present.
绞刑架交易中伴随的笑声或微笑，通常也会被在场的其他人所分享。
Gallows Transaction
绞刑架交易 		A transaction which leads directly toward the script payoff.
直接导致脚本收益的交易。
Game
游戏 		A series of transactions with a con, a gimmick, a switch, and a crossup, leading to a payoff.
一系列包含骗局、噱头、交换和交叉操作的交易，最终带来回报。
Game Formula
游戏公式 		The sequence of events occurring in a game, expressed as a formula by means of letter symbols: C + G = R →S →X →P.
游戏中发生的事件顺序，用字母符号表示为公式：C + G = R →S →X →P。
Gamy Behavior
赌博行为 		Behavior which seems more calculated to get an eventual trading-stamp payoff than to accomplish its declared purpose.
这种行为似乎更是为了最终获得交易凭证的回报，而不是为了实现其宣称的目的。
Gimmick
手法 		A special attitude or weakness which makes a person vulnerable to games or scripty behavior.
一种特殊的态度或弱点，使人容易受到游戏或脚本行为的影响。
Goal Time
进球时间 		A period terminated by the attainment of a goal.
以达成目标为标志的时期。
Illusion
错觉 		An unlikely hope which the Child clings to and which influences all his decisive behavior.
这是一个不太可能实现的希望，孩子却紧紧抓住这个希望，并影响着他所有的决定性行为。
Injunction
禁令 		A prohibition or negative command from a parent.
来自父母的禁止或否定命令。
Intimacy
亲密关系 		A game-free exchange of emotional expression without exploitation.
不涉及游戏、不带剥削的情感交流。
Life Course
生命历程 		What actually happens.
实际发生的情况。
Life Plan
人生规划 		What is supposed to happen according to the script.
根据剧本应该发生什么。
Life Sentence
无期徒刑 		A negative but not fatal script payoff.
剧本结局虽然不利，但并非致命。
Loser
失败者 		Someone who does not accomplish a declared purpose.
未能达成既定目标的人。
Martian
火星人 		One who observes Earthly happenings without preconceptions.
能够不带任何成见地观察世间万物的人。
Martian Viewpoint
火星视角 		The naivest possible frame of mind for observing Earthly happenings.
观察世间万物最天真的心态。
Mortgage
抵押 		An optional obligation undertaken to structure long periods of time.
为规划较长时期而承担的可选义务。
Nonwinner
非获奖者 		Someone who works hard just to break even.
辛勤工作却只能勉强收支平衡的人。
Ogre Father
食人魔之父 		The Child ego state of the father, which forms the Parent of his daughter’s Child ego state and directs the tragic script. In a productive script, this is called the Jolly Giant.
父亲的孩童自我状态，会塑造女儿孩童自我状态中的父母角色，并主导悲剧剧本的走向。在积极的剧本中，这被称为“快乐的巨人”。
OK Words
OK Words 		Words rewarded by parental approval.
言语能获得父母的认可。
Overlap
重叠 		When reach-back begins before after-burn has subsided.
后撤动作在余燃尚未消退之前就开始了。
Palimpsest
重写本 		A later version of a script arising from new potentialities as the child enters later phases of development.
随着儿童进入发展后期阶段，新的可能性不断涌现，由此产生了剧本的后续版本。
Parent
父母 		An ego state borrowed from a parental figure. It may function as a directing influence (the Influencing Parent), or be directly exhibited as parental behavior (the Active Parent). It may be nurturing or controlling.
一种借自父母形象的自我状态。它可以发挥指导作用（影响型父母），也可以直接表现为父母的行为（主动型父母）。它可以是养育型的，也可以是控制型的。
Pattern
图案 		A style of life based on parental instruction or example.
一种以父母教导或榜样为基础的生活方式。
Permission
允许 		(1) A parental license for autonomous behavior. (2) An intervention which gives the individual a license to disobey a parental injunction if he is ready, willing, and able, or releases him from parental provocations.
（1）父母给予子女自主行为的许可。（2）一种干预措施，允许个人在准备好、愿意且能够的情况下违抗父母的禁令，或者使个人免受父母的挑衅。
Persona
人格 		A masked presentation of self. It usually is at an eight- to twelve-year-old level.
一种伪装的自我呈现方式。通常相当于八到十二岁儿童的水平。
Position
位置 		A concept of OKness and not-OKness which justifies a decision; a position from which games are played.
一种判断“可以”与“不可以”的概念，以此来证明决策的合理性；一种进行博弈的立场。
Prescription
处方 		A set of precepts offered by a nurturing parent.
一位慈爱的父母所提供的一系列准则。
Program
程序 		The life style which results from all the elements of the script apparatus taken together.
由剧本体系所有要素共同作用所产生的生活方式。
Protocol
协议 		The original dramatic experiences upon which the script is based.
剧本所依据的原始戏剧经历。
Provocation
挑衅 		Nonadaptive behavior encouraged or demanded by a parent.
父母鼓励或要求的不适应性行为。
Racket
球拍 		The sexualization and transactional seeking and exploitation of unpleasant feelings.
将不愉快的情绪性化、交易化，并加以利用。
Reach-Back
后退 		The period of time during which an impending event influences behavior.
即将发生的事件影响行为的时间段。
Release, External
发布，外部 		An outside intervention which releases the individual from the demands of his script. A cut-off.
外部干预使个人摆脱了自身剧本的束缚。一种切断。
Release, Internal
发布，内部 		A condition built into the script whereby the individual is released from it. A cut-out.
剧本中预设的一种条件，使个体得以脱离剧本。一种脱离机制。
Re-Parenting
重新养育子女 		Cutting off early parental programing and substituting a new and more adaptive program through regression, especially in schizophrenics.
切断早期父母的教育程序，并通过退行训练代之以新的、更具适应性的程序，尤其适用于精神分裂症患者。
Role
角色 		A set of transactions played out in any of the three ego states according to the demands of the script.
根据剧本的要求，在三种自我状态中的任何一种状态下上演的一系列交易。
Santa Claus
圣诞老人 		The illusory source of the illusory gift which the Child spends his life waiting for.
孩童一生都在等待的那份虚幻礼物，其虚幻的来源也是虚幻的。
Script
脚本 		A life plan based on a decision made in childhood, reinforced by the parents, justified by subsequent events, and culminating in a chosen alternative.
以童年时期做出的决定为基础，经父母强化，由后续事件证明合理，最终选择的生活计划。

Antithesis
对立 		A command which directly contradicts the parental injunction; a therapeutic intervention which brings about temporary or permanent release from the demands of the script. An external release.
直接违背父母训诫的指令；一种治疗干预，使人暂时或永久地摆脱既定模式的束缚。一种外部的解脱。
Apparatus
设备 		The seven elements that make up a script.
剧本的七个组成要素。
Can Script
可编写脚本 		One stated in positive terms.
以积极的方式表达。
Can’t Script
不会写脚本 		One stated in negative terms.
以否定形式陈述。
Check List
检查清单 		A list of questions carefully selected and worded so as to get the greatest amount of information, with the least ambiguity, concerning the script.
精心挑选并措辞的问题清单，旨在以最小的歧义获取有关剧本的最大信息量。
Controls
控制 		The payoff, the injunctions, and the provocations which control the individual’s scripty behavior.
利益、禁令和挑衅控制着个人的脚本行为。
Currency
货币 		The medium that leads to the script payoff: words, money, or tissues are examples.
剧本带来的回报媒介：文字、金钱或纸巾都是例子。
Directives
指令 		Controls, patterns, and other script equipment.
控制、模式和其他脚本设备。
Driven
驱动 		Of a person who has to accomplish what his script calls for at any cost, but may have fun on the side.
一个必须不惜一切代价完成剧本要求的人，但可能会在业余时间享受乐趣。
Episcript
Episcript 		An excess of parental programing. See Overscript.
家长过度干预。参见“过度干预”。
Equipment
设备 		Parental stimuli and responses out of which the individual constructs his script apparatus.
父母的刺激和回应，个体由此构建出自己的脚本系统。
Failure
失败 		If the script cannot be carried through, it leads to despair.
如果剧本无法执行，就会导致绝望。
Formula
公式 		The sequence of events essential to the progress of a script, expressed in a formula by means of letter symbols: EPI →Pr →C →IB.
脚本进展所必需的事件顺序，用字母符号表示为公式：EPI → Pr → C → IB。
Hamartic
错构 		One with a self-destructive, tragic ending.
一个以自我毁灭和悲剧收场的故事。
Matrix
矩阵 		A diagram showing the parental directives which form the basis of the script.
一张图表，展示了构成脚本基础的父母指令。
Outbreak
暴发 		(or Outbreak of Script) shifting from more or less rationally controlled behavior into a scripty scene.
（或剧本式行为的爆发）从或多或少理性控制的行为转变为剧本式的行为。
Overscript
覆盖脚本 		An excess of parental programing which is passed from one person to another, as from parent to child. Whoever has this ‘hot potato’ at any given moment is overscripted. An episcript.
父母灌输的过多观念会从一个人传递给另一个人，就像父母传给孩子一样。任何时刻，谁掌握了这颗“烫手山芋”，谁就被过度灌输了观念。这是一种后置的、附加的观念。
Payoff
付清 		The ultimate destiny or final display that marks the end of a life plan.
标志着人生计划终结的最终命运或最终展示。
Primal
原始 		The earliest version of the script, based on the infant’s interpretation of the family drama.
剧本的最早版本是根据婴儿对家庭悲剧的理解而创作的。
Ridden
骑术 		Of a person who must concentrate on his script at the expense of everything else.
一个必须全神贯注于剧本创作，而忽略其他一切的人。
Set
放 		The dreamlike setting in which the Child plays out the script.
孩子在如梦似幻的场景中上演着剧本。
Sign
符号 		A special item of behavior which gives a clue to a patient’s script.
一种特殊的行为，可以揭示患者的治疗脚本。
Signal
信号 		A movement or mannerism which marks scripty behavior.
一种带有刻板印象的动作或习惯。
Space
空间 		The space within which the decisive transactions of a script take place.
剧本中关键情节发生的空间。
Theme
主题 		Love, hate, revenge, or jealousy are the commonest.
爱、恨、复仇或嫉妒是最常见的几种情感。
Velocity
速度 		The number of role switches occurring in a script in a given unit of time.
脚本在给定时间单位内发生的角色转换次数。
World
世界 		The distorted world in which the script is played out.
剧本上演的扭曲世界。

Scripty Behavior
脚本行为 		Behavior which seems more motivated by a script than by rational considerations.
这种行为似乎更多是受剧本驱使，而非出于理性考虑。
Spellbreaker
破咒者 		An internal release, built into the script.
脚本中内置的内部发布版本。
Slot
投币口 		A place in a script to be filled by any person who will respond according to its demands.
剧本中的一个位置，任何能够按照剧本要求做出回应的人都可以担任。
Stopper
塞子 		A script injunction or prohibition.
剧本禁令或禁止令。
Stroke
中风 		A unit of recognition, such as ‘Hello.’
识别单位，例如“你好”。
Structural Analysis
结构分析 		Analysis of the personality, or of a series of transactions, according to Parent, Adult, and Child ego states.
根据父母、成人和儿童自我状态对人格或一系列行为进行分析。
Sweatshirt
运动衫 		A life motto which is apparent from the person’s demeanor.
从一个人的举止中就能看出他的人生格言。
Switch
转变 		1. A switch from one role to another in game or script.
1. 在游戏或剧本中从一个角色切换到另一个角色。
2. A maneuver which forces or induces another person to switch roles.
2. 迫使或诱使他人改变角色的手段。
3. An internal or external stimulus which turns off adaptive behavior.
3. 能够抑制适应性行为的内部或外部刺激。
Therapeutic Hypothesis
治疗假设 		A hypothesis concerning the value of a planned therapeutic operation.
关于计划治疗手术价值的假设。
Totem
图腾 		An animal which fascinates the individual and influences his behavior.
一种令个体着迷并影响其行为的动物。
Trading Stamp
交易邮票 		A feeling ‘collected’ as the payoff in a game.
在游戏中获得“成就感”的回报。
Transaction
交易 		A transactional stimulus from a certain ego state in the agent plus a transactional response from a certain ego state in the respondent. A transaction is the unit of social action.
行为主体基于某种自我状态产生的交易性刺激，加上回应者基于某种自我状态产生的交易性反应。交易是社会行为的基本单位。
Transactional Analysis
交易分析 		(1) A system of psychotherapy based on the analysis of transactions and chains of transactions which occur during treatment sessions. (2) A theory of personality based on the study of specific ego states. (3) A theory of social action based on the rigorous analysis of transactions into an exhaustive and finite number of classes based on the specific ego states involved. (4) The analysis of single transactions by means of transactional diagrams; this is transactional analysis proper.
（1）一种基于对治疗过程中发生的互动及其链进行分析的心理治疗体系。（2）一种基于对特定自我状态研究的人格理论。（3）一种基于对互动进行严格分析，并将其归类为基于特定自我状态的详尽且有限数量的类别的社会行为理论。（4）通过互动图分析单个互动；这便是真正的互动分析。
Winner
优胜者 		Someone who accomplishes his declared purpose.
实现了自己既定目标的人。
Witch Mother
女巫之母 		The Child ego state of a mother, which forms the Parent of her son’s Child ego state and directs the tragic script. In a productive script, this is called the Fairy Godmother.
母亲的孩童自我状态，会塑造儿子孩童自我状态中的父母角色，并主导悲剧剧本的走向。在积极的剧本中，这被称为“仙女教母”。
World View
世界观 		The Child’s distorted view of the world and the people around him, upon which his script is based.
孩子的扭曲世界观和对周围人的看法，正是剧本的基础。
#↩

指数

Electra, 73

伊莱克特拉，73

electrode, the, 141–3

电极，141–3

emprosthotonos，408

enemas, 187

灌肠，187

English, Fanita, 327

英文，Fanita，327

episcript, 327

题注，327

Eratostratus, 352

埃拉托斯特拉图斯，352

Erikson, E., 46, 80, 160, 190, 326, 334, 339, 446

埃里克森，E.，46、80、160、190、326、334、339、446

ESP experiments, 451

ESP实验，451

ethos, 165

伦理，165

Europa, story of, 61–3

欧罗巴的故事，61-3

experimental data, 459

实验数据，459

Fairbairn, W. R. D., 162

费尔贝恩，W. R. D.，162

fairy tales, 59–68

童话故事，59-68页

family culture, 188–94

家庭文化，188–94

fascination, 288–90

迷恋，288–90

fascist, the little, 302–5

法西斯，小，302-5

Federn, Paul, 308, 352, 409

费德恩，保罗，308，352，409

Feldman, S. S., 355

费尔德曼，S.S.，355

Ferenczi, 448

费伦齐，448

fetishes, sexual, 289–90

恋物癖，性，289–90

Fiji Islanders, smile, 22

斐济岛民，微笑，22

final common pathways, 406–9

最终共同通路，406–9

Fodor, N., 100

福多尔，N.，100

forenames, 101–3

名字，101–3

Fortune Cookie Theory, 146

幸运饼干理论，146

fortunetellers, 451

算命先生，451

‘Foundling Script’, 100

《弃儿手稿》，100

Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, 21

天启四骑士，21

Freud, Sigmund, 79, 133, 180, 189, 238, 310–11, 316, 334, 339, 381, 392, 409, 442–3, 448

弗洛伊德，西格蒙德，79、133、180、189、238、310-11、316、334、339、381、392、409、442-3、448

friends, 28

朋友，28

Frog Prince, 134

‘frogs’, 58, 233; See also losers

#↩

About the Author

作者简介

Dr Eric Berne, as the originator of transactional analysis, was always recognised as an important innovator in the field, but it was not until his Games People Play became an international bestseller that his methods achieved wide popularity. In his writings, until his death in 1970, Dr Berne outlined the principles of his system in works such as Games People Play , A Layman’s Guide to Psychiatry , Sex in Human Loving , and Principles of Group Treatment . Dr Berne was a practising psychiatrist in Carmel, California, and held many important posts in professional psychiatric organisations and clinics.

作为人际沟通分析的创始人，埃里克·伯恩博士一直被公认为该领域的重要创新者，但直到他的著作《人间游戏》成为国际畅销书后，他的方法才广为人知。在1970年去世前，伯恩博士在其著作中阐述了其体系的原则，例如《人间游戏》、《精神病学入门》、《人类之爱中的性》和《团体治疗原则》。伯恩博士是加利福尼亚州卡梅尔市的一位执业精神科医生，并在多个专业精神病学组织和诊所担任要职。
